PREFACE 
    This Code constitutes a complete republication of the general and permanent ordinances of the Village of Roselle. 
    Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 1970 Code, as supplemented through February 1990, and ordinances subsequently adopted by the board. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. By use of the comparative table appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any ordinance included herein. 
    The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this Code. 
Numbering System 
    The numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the chapter number and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of Chapter 1 is numbered 1-2 and the first section of Chapter 4 is 4-1. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter and at the same time new sections or even whole chapters can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 3-1 and 3-2 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 3-1.5. New chapters may be included in the same manner. If the new material is to be included between Chapters 12 and 13, it will be designated as Chapter 12.5. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division. 
Index 
    The index has been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
    A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up-to-date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited and the appropriate page or pages affected will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
    Keeping this publication up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised sheets are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
    This publication was under the direct supervision of Robert L. Laslie, Vice-President-Supplements, and Anne Wilson, Supplement Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
    The publisher is most grateful to Glenn F. Spachman, Village Manager and Linda McDermott, Village Clerk, for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the village readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the village's affairs. 
MUNICIPAL CODE CORPORATION Tallahassee, Florida

Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Code of Ordinances, Village of Roselle, Illinois," and may be so cited. 
(Code 1956,  776) 
State Law reference- Revision and codification of ordinances, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  1-2-3 et seq. 
Sec. 1-2. - Rules of construction and definitions 
    In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances, the rules and definitions set out in this section shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the board of trustees. The rules of construction and definitions set out herein shall not be applied to any section of this Code which shall contain any express provisions excluding such construction, or where the subject matter of context of such section may be repugnant thereto. 
    Generally. All general provisions, terms, phrases and expressions contained in this Code shall be liberally construed in order that the true intent and meaning of the board of trustees may be fully carried out. 
    In the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code, they shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of the Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than the general provision imposed by the Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed to be controlling. 
    Board, board of trustees, village board. Whenever the words "board," "board of trustees" or "village board" are used, they shall be construed to mean the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Roselle. 
    Computation of time. The time within which any act provided by law is to be done shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last, unless the last day is Saturday or Sunday or is a holiday as defined or fixed in any statute now or hereafter in force in this state, and then it shall also be excluded. If the day succeeding such Saturday, Sunday or holiday is also a holiday or a Saturday or Sunday then such succeeding day shall also be excluded. 
    Corporate or village limits. The term "corporate limits" or "village limits" shall mean the legal boundaries of the Village of Roselle. 
    Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring the head of a department or some other village officer to do some act or perform some duty, it is to be construed to authorize the head of the department or other officer to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act or perform the duty unless the terms of the provision or section specify otherwise. 
    Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males. 
    Health officer shall mean: 
(a)  In DuPage County, the director of the DuPage County Health Department or his authorized representative. 
(b)  In Cook County, a registered sanitarian recommended by the director of village services and personnel, appointed by the president with the consent of the board of trustees. 
    Joint authority. All words giving a joint authority to three (3) or more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such persons or officers. 
    Month. The word "month" shall mean a calendar month. 
    Nontechnical and technical words. Words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning. 
    Number. A word importing the singular number only may extend and be applied to several persons and things as well as to one person and thing. 
    Oath. The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation maybe substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." 
    Officers generally. Whenever any officer is referred to by title, such as "village clerk," "president," etc., such reference shall be construed as if followed by the words "of the Village of Roselle." 
    Owner. The word "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant, or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The word "person" shall extend and he applied to associations, clubs, societies, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals. 
    Personal property includes every species of property except real property, as herein described. 
    Preceding, following. The words "preceding" and "following" mean next before and next after, respectively. 
    Property. The word "property" shall include real and personal property. 
    Real property shall include lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
    Shall. The word "shall" is mandatory. 
    Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" shall mean any portion of a street between the curb line and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians, excluding parkways. 
    Signature or subscription includes a mark when the person cannot write. 
    State. The words "the state" or "this state" shall be construed to mean the State of Illinois. 
    Street. The word "street" shall be construed to embrace streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts and all other public ways in the village, and shall include all areas thereof embraced between the property lines and dedicated to the public use. 
    Tenant or occupant. The words "tenant" or "occupant" applied to a building or land, shall include any person holding a written or oral lease or who occupies the whole or a part of such buildings or land, either alone or with others. 
    Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. 
    Village shall mean the Village of Roselle, Illinois. 
    Wholesale, wholesaler, etc. In all cases where the words,"wholesale," "wholesaler," or "wholesale dealer" are used in this Code, unless otherwise specifically defined, they shall be understood and held to relate to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things in quantity to persons who purchase for purposes of resale, as distinguished from a retail dealer who sells in smaller quantities direct to the consumer. 
    Written or in writing shall be construed to include any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. 
    Year. The word "year" shall mean a calendar year. 
(Code 1956, ㎣ 767, 768, 770, 771; Ord. No. 599-76,  1, 2-24-76; Ord. No. 782-78,  1, 8-7-78) 
State Law reference- For similar rules of statutory construction, see ILCS Ch. 1. 
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such section, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
Sec. 1-4. - Amendments to Code. 
    All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion herein, or in the case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby and the subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time as this Code of Ordinances and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code of Ordinances by the board of trustees. 
(Code 1956,  772) 
Sec. 1-5. - Unauthorized alteration or tampering with Code. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in the village to change or amend, by additions or deletions, any part or portions of this Code, or to insert or delete pages, or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the village to be misrepresented thereby. 
Sec. 1-6. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
    When any ordinance repealing a former ordinance, clause or provision shall be itself repealed, such repeal shall not be construed to revive such former ordinance, clause or provision unless it shall be therein so expressly provided. 
    The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed or cause of action arising under the ordinance repealed. 
Sec. 1-7. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    The sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional, invalid or unenforceable by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality, invalidity or unenforceability shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code. 
Sec. 1-8. - General penalty for violation of Code; continuing violations. 
(a)  Whenever in this Code, or any other ordinance of the village, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or whenever in such Code or ordinance the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, and where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision shall be a petty offense and punished by a fine in accordance with subsections (b), (c), or (d) of this section. Each day of any violation of any provision of this Code or ordinance subject to this penalty section shall constitute a separate offense. Any penalty imposed for violation of this Code or other ordinance and subject to this provision may include some reasonable public service work, such as, but not limited to, the pick-up of litter in public parks or along public highways, the maintenance of public facilities, or, where applicable, the abatement of the condition that is the basis for the conviction. 
(b)  Where the violation is a single day offense, a fine shall be imposed of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00), nor more than nine hundred fifty dollars ($950.00); or 
(c)  Where the violation occurs over multiple days but has terminated by the date of conviction, a fine shall be imposed of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00), nor more than nine hundred fifty dollars ($950.00), for each day of the offense, from the date of the offense through the date that the violation terminated; or 
(d)  Where a violation continues to exist as of the date of conviction, the court shall retain jurisdiction for imposition of a continued daily fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00), nor more than nine hundred fifty dollars ($950.00) per day, for each day of the violation until there is compliance with this Code or abatement of the condition. 
(Code 1956, ㎣ 120, 769; Ord. No. 675-77,  1, 7-5-77; Ord. No. 2309-93,  1, 3-22-93; Ord. No. 2010-3502,  1, 3-8-10) 
State Law reference- Limitation on penalties, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1. 
Sec. 1-8.1. - Alternative settlements/fines for certain violations/administrative adjudication. 
    Any person charged with any offense subject to administrative adjudication who pays an alternative settlement, or who stipulates to being or is adjudicated liable in conformance with chapter 24, article I, "code hearing department" of the Code of Ordinances for the Village of Roselle shall pay a fine in conformance with the Fine Table for Alternative Settlement/Administrative Adjudication which is incorporated into this section as if fully set forth as appendix A to this section.

Sec. 1-9. - Imprisonment until fine and costs paid. 
    The person upon whom any fine or penalty is imposed, upon order of the court before which the conviction is had, may be imprisoned until the fine, penalty and costs are paid. No imprisonment, however, shall exceed six (6) months for any one offense. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-9. 
Sec. 1-10. - Working of prisoners; credit against fine and costs. 
    Every person committed for the violation of this Code or an ordinance shall be required to work at whatever labor his strength permits, within and without the place of incarceration, not to exceed ten (10) hours each working day. The committed person shall be allowed, exclusive of his board, A credit of five dollars ($5.00) for each day's work on account of the fine, penalty and costs. 
State Law reference- For similar provisions, see 65 ILCS 5/1-2-9. 
Sec. 1-11. - Officers, employees not liable to fine for failure to perform duties. 
    No provision of this Code designating the duties of any officer or employee shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine or penalty provided in this Code for a failure to perform such duty, unless the intention of the board of trustees to impose such a fine or penalty on such officer or employee is specifically clear and expressed in the section creating the duty. 
(Code 1956,  770) 
Sec. 1-12. - Acts punishable under different sections. 
    In all cases where the same offense is made punishable or is created by different clauses or sections of this Code, the prosecuting officer may elect under which to proceed; but not more than one recovery shall be held against the same person for the same offense. Provided that the revocation of a license or permit shall not be considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any other penalty being enforced. 
(Code 1956,  769) 
Sec. 1-13. - Surety bonds. 
    Whenever a surety bond to indemnify the village is required as a prerequisite to exercising the duties of any office or position, or to the issuance of a license or permit or for the exercise of any special privilege, the surety on such bond shall be a corporation licensed and authorized to do business in this state as a surety company, in the absence of specific provision to the contrary by ordinance. 
    Whenever in its opinion additional sureties or an additional surety may be needed on any bond to indemnify the village against loss or liability because of the insolvency of the existing surety or sureties or for any other reason, the village may order a new surety or sureties to be secured for such bond. If such new surety or sureties are not procured within ten (10) days from the time such order is transmitted to the principal on the bond, or his assignee, the board shall declare the bond to be void, and thereupon such principal or assignee, shall be deemed to have surrendered the privilege or position as a condition of which bond was required. 
(Code 1956,  135) 
Cross reference- Bond of officers generally,  2-56; bond of village clerk,  2-86; bond of village treasurer,  2-102; bond of village collector,  2-113; bond for taxicabs,  9-198; bond required for house moving, raising or shoring,  9-453; bond for outdoor advertisers,  9-486; paving bonds,  18-7; bonds for gas pumps on streets,  18-10; bonds required for work on sewers,  22-59. 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Elections to conform to statute. 
    Elections for municipal officers shall be held as provided by statute, and at the time prescribed by statute. 
(Code 1956,  134) 
State Law reference- Elections generally, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 46; time of elections, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  3-5-3. 
Sec. 2-2. - Fiscal year. 
(a)  Commencing May 1, 2000, the fiscal year for the village shall begin on the first of May, 2000, and shall end on the last day of December, 2000; and 
(b)  Commencing January 1, 2001, the fiscal year for the village shall begin on the first day of January of each year and shall end on the last day of December of the same calendar year. 
(Code 1956,  131; Ord. No. 2000-2749,  1, 1-10-00) 
State Law reference- Fiscal year defined, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  1-1-2(5). 
Sec. 2-3. - Design of seal. 
    The corporate seal of the village shall be a circular disc, so designated as to impress the words "Village of Roselle, DuPage and Cook Counties, Ill." on the periphery thereof and "Village Seal" in the center. 
(Code 1965,  130) 
State Law reference- Authority to have seal, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24  2-3-8. 
Sec. 2-4. - Disposition of funds. 
    All money collected in behalf of the village shall be paid by the collecting employee to the director of finance within one (1) business day of receipt, and shall be deposited by the director of finance to a village account specified by the director of finance. 
(Code 1956,  119; Ord. No. 2340A-93,  1, 6-28-93) 
Sec. 2-5. - Board of local improvements. 
(a)  Established. There is hereby established the board of local improvements for the village, which shall consist of the president and all the members of the board of trustees. 
(b)  Powers, duties. The board of local improvements shall have the powers and perform the duties assigned to it by statute, this Code or ordinance. 
(Code 1956,   66, 67) 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 18; water and sewers, Ch. 22. 
State Law reference- Local improvements generally, see Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  9-1-1 et seq. 
Sec. 2-6. - Petty cash fund. 
(a)  The village administrator is hereby authorized to direct the village director of finance to issue checks for the purpose of establishing and maintaining petty cash funds to cover minor operator expenses in an amount not to exceed a total of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). 
(b)  Each department head as appointed by the village president or village administrator shall have the authority to administer the petty cash funds established for their respective departments in accordance with the direction of the village administrator, provided that said funds be used only for minor operating expenses and in conformance with any rules or regulation as may be established from time to time by the village administrator and the village purchasing manual. Any person incurring expenses withdrawn from the petty cash fund shall provide the director of finance with detailed records showing to whom payment was made, the purpose for which it was made, the date of the actual payment and a receipt for such payment. 
(Ord. No. 412-73, ㎣ 1, 2, 3-5-73; Ord. No. 1793-89,  1, 2-13-89; Ord. No. 2340A-93,  2, 6-28-93) 
Sec. 2-7. - Indemnification of officers, employees and certain committee members re Open Meetings Act. 
(a)  The village shall indemnify any person who was or is a party or is threatened to be made a party to any threatened, pending or completed action, suit or proceeding, whether civil, criminal, administrative or investigative (other than an action by or in the right of the village) by reason of the fact that he or she is or was an elected or appointed officer, employee, or a member of a committee appointed by the president and board of trustees of the village charged with violating the Open Meetings Act (hereinafter referred to as the act), Ill. Rev. Stat., Ch. 102, paragraphs 41 through 46, inclusive. Said indemnification shall be against expenses (including attorneys' fees), judgments, fines and amounts paid in settlement actually and reasonably incurred by him or her in connection with such action, suit or proceeding arising out of the alleged violation or violations of the act, if he or she acted in good faith and in a manner he or she reasonably believed to be in or not opposed to the best interests of the village, and, with respect to any criminal action or proceeding, had no reasonable cause to believe his or her conduct was unlawful. The termination of any action, suit or proceeding by judgment or settlement, conviction or upon a plea of nolo contendere or its equivalent, shall not, of itself, create a presumption that: 
(1)  The person did not act in good faith and in a manner which he or she reasonably believed to be in or not opposed to the best interest of the village; and 
(2)  With respect to any criminal action or proceeding, had reasonable cause to believe that his or her conduct was unlawful. 
(b)  To the extent that an elected or appointed officer, employee or appointed member of a committee of the village has been successful on the merits or otherwise in defense of any action, suit or proceeding referred to in subsection (a) or in defense of any claim, issue or matter therein, he or she shall be indemnified against expenses (including attorneys' fees) actually and reasonably incurred by him or her in connection therewith. 
(c)  Any indemnification under subsection (a), unless ordered by a court, shall be made by the village only as authorized in the specific case upon a determination that indemnification of the elected or appointed officer, employee or appointed member of a committee is proper in the circumstances because he or she has met the applicable standard of conduct set forth in subsection (a) and such expenses and attorneys' fees, including the choice of an attorney, was approved in writing by the president and board of the village prior to, or at the time, such expenses and fees were incurred. Such determination shall be made by a majority vote of the president and board of trustees. 
(d)  The indemnification provided for in this section shall not be deemed exclusive of any other rights to which those indemnified may be entitled under any contract, agreement or vote of the president and board of trustees or otherwise, both as to any action of said person in his or her official capacity and as to action in another capacity while holding such office, and shall continue as to a person who has ceased to be an elected or appointed officer, employee or appointed committee member and shall inure to the benefit of the heirs, executors and administrators of such a person. 
(Ord. No. 1157-83, ㎣ 1-4, 4-11-83) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1157-83, ㎣ 1-4, adopted Apr. 11, 1983, did not specify manner of codification; hence, inclusion herein as  2-7 has been at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 2-8. - Remote attendance. 
    Remote attendance of village board meetings shall be allowed in conformance with 5 ILCS 120/7, as may be amended from time to time, and these rules. 
(Ord. No. 2015-3764,  1, 2-9-15) 
Sec. 2-9. - Rules and regulations of remote attendance. 
    Prerequisites: A member of the corporate authority of the village may attend a meeting electronically only if the following prerequisites are satisfied: 
(a)  The member shall notify the village clerk and village administrator at least 72 hours prior to the meeting, unless impractical, that the member may not attend as a result of: 
(1)  Personal illness or physical disability; 
(2)  Because of employment or the business of the village; or 
(3)  As the result of a family or other emergency. 
(b)  The notification shall be provided by the village clerk or village administrator to the president who shall bring the matter forward at the village board meeting for which remote attendance is requested but only so long as a majority of a quorum is physically present at the meeting. The member seeking remote attendance shall be allowed remote attendance so long as a majority of the quorum present votes to approve the remote attendance. The member seeking remote attendance shall not be allowed to vote on the motion for remote attendance. 
(c)  A further prerequisite for remote attendance shall be the ability of village staff to make necessary technical arrangements to allow remote attendance. Technical arrangements shall enable the public, the remote attendee and village board to hear all communications in open sessions and for the village board to be able to hear all communications in executive sessions. 
(Ord. No. 2015-3764,  1, 2-9-15) 
Sec. 2-10. - Remote attendance locations. 
    Remote attendance of open sessions shall be allowed only in the council chamber of the village hall and remote attendance at executive sessions shall only be allowed in the large conference room directly adjacent to the council chamber unless officially relocated in conformance with the Open Meetings Act. 
(Ord. No. 2015-3764,  1, 2-9-15) 
Sec. 2-11. - Rights and obligations of remote attending member. 
    A remote attending member shall have the right to express his/her comments during the meeting and participate in the same capacity as those members physically present subject to all general procedures and rules previously adopted by the village board. The member shall also be permitted to vote. Each member attending remotely shall, prior to expressing comments, identify themselves for the record and speak loudly enough to be able to be heard by members of the village board as well as the public. A member attending remotely shall vote by stating the words: aye, nay, or other vote as allowed by Robert's Rules of Order. A member attending electronically may leave a meeting and return, as in the case of any attending member, provided that such member shall announce his/her leaving and returning. 
(Ord. No. 2015-3764,  1, 2-9-15) 
Sec. 2-12. - Meeting minutes. 
    The village clerk shall record remote attending member statements and votes in the same manner as if the member was physically present at the meeting. 
(Ord. No. 2015-3764,  1, 2-9-15) 
Sec. 2-13. - Remote attendance equipment. 
    Failure to have, or the malfunction of, remote attendance equipment, shall disqualify any member's remote attendance. Staff shall exercise reasonable efforts to provide functional equipment to satisfy the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2015-3764,  1, 2-9-15) 
Secs. 2-14-2-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PRESIDENT AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-16. - President to be mayor. 
    The village president may be referred to as mayor of the village. The term "village president" as used in any ordinance, resolution, motion or other action of the corporate authorities shall be construed as meaning the mayor; and the term "mayor" wherever so used shall be construed to mean the village president. The title "mayor" as used in the minutes of the meetings of the corporate authorities or any other official document shall be construed as meaning "village president." 
(Ord. No. 123-63, 9-3-63) 
State Law reference- President may be called mayor, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  1-1-2.1. 
Sec. 2-17. - Term of president; to be president of board of trustees. 
    The village president shall be elected for a term of four (4) years, and he shall be the president of the board of trustees, as is provided by statute. 
(Code 1956,  1) 
State Law reference- Term of president, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  3-5-1; to be president of board, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  3-12-2. 
Sec. 2-18. - President to preside. 
    The village president shall be the presiding officer of all regular and special meetings of the board of trustees. The village president or any member of the board of trustees may preside at committee of the whole meetings. 
(Code 1956,  9; Ord. No. 2340A-93,  3, 6-28-93) 
State Law reference- For similar provisions see Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  3-12-2. 
Sec. 2-19. - President's oath and salary. 
(a)  Effective May 2017, the village president shall take the oath of office as prescribed by state statute and shall receive an annual salary of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) for serving as Chief Executive Officer of the Village of Roselle, which shall be paid in accordance with the schedule of salary payments for village employees. After serving the first consecutive three hundred sixty-five (365) day period, the salary shall increase by the lesser sum of two (2) percent or the prior year's cumulative consumer price index for all urban consumers (Chicago-Gary-Kenosha) as computed by the Federal Bureau of Labor, for each successive 365-day period of the village president's term. 
(b)  A village president filling the unexpired term of a prior village president shall not be entitled to an increase as provided in this article until they have served three hundred sixty-five (365) days in the office of village president. 
(Code 1956,  4; Ord. No. 2340A-93,  4, 6-28-93; Ord. No. 2010-3643,  1, 9-10-12; Ord. No. 2016-3863,  1, 9-26-16) 
State Law reference- Bond, oath of officers, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  3-14-3; compensation of president, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  3-13-6. 
Sec. 2-20. - President's duties, generally. 
    The president shall be the chief executive officer of the village, and shall perform all such duties as may be required of him by statute or ordinance. He shall have the power and authority to inspect all books and records kept by any village officer or employee at any reasonable time. He shall have supervision over all the executive officers of the village, and over all the employees of the village. He shall sign all orders upon the treasurer of the village, and perform such other acts as by law and ordinance may be required. 
(Code 1956,  2) 
State Law reference- Powers, duties of presidents, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  3-12-2. 
Sec. 2-21. - President to designate duties of subordinates. 
    Whenever there is a question as to the respective powers or duties of any appointed officer of the village, this shall be settled by the president; and he shall have the power to delegate to any such officer any duty which is to be performed when no specific officer has been directed by the board of trustees to perform that duty. 
(Code 1956, ㎣ 3, 96) 
State Law reference- Duties of officers generally, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  3-12-1. 
Sec. 2-22. - President pro tem. 
    During a temporary absence or disability of the village president, the board of trustees shall elect one of its number to act as president pro tem, who during the absence or disability of the president shall perform the duties pertaining to the office. 
(Code 1956,  5) 
State Law reference- Presidents pro tem, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  3-11-7. 
Sec. 2-23. - Composition, term of board of trustees, general powers, duties. 
    The board of trustees, consisting of six (6) members, shall be elected to office for a four-year term, according to the method provided by statute. This board shall be the legislative department of the village government, and shall perform such duties and have such powers as may be delegated by statute to it. 
(Code 1956,  6) 
State Law reference- Composition, term of board, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  3-5-2. 
Sec. 2-24. - Oath of trustees. 
    The members of the board of trustees shall take the oath of office prescribed by statute. 
(Code 1956,  7) 
State Law reference- Oath of officers, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  3-14-3. 
Sec. 2-25. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2340A-93,  5, adopted June 28, 1993, repealed former  2-25, which pertained to the compensation of the village president. 
Sec. 2-26. - Compensation of trustees. 
(a)  Applicability. The provisions of this section shall apply alike to all trustees of the village, regardless of the time of the election of any such officer. 
(b)  Establishment. The trustees of the village shall receive such salaries as shall be provided from time to time by ordinance, subject to the provisions of the statutes of this state. 
(Ord. No. 211-67, ㎣ 1-4, 4-15-67; Ord. No. 658-77,  1, 2-7-77; Ord. No. 1555-87,  2, 4-27-87) 
State Law reference- Compensation of trustees, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  3-13-7. 
Sec. 2-27. - Time, place of regular meetings. 
    The regular meetings of the president and board of trustees shall be held on the second and fourth Mondays of each month at 8:00 p.m. in a location to be designated by the president and board of trustees. In the event that such meeting falls on a village holiday, the meeting shall be held on the next business day. If a holiday falls on Saturday or Sunday, the following Monday shall be considered a village holiday, and the meeting shall be held on the subsequent Tuesday. 
(Ord. No. 211-67,  5, 4-15-67; Ord. No. 74-464,  1, 1-28-74; Ord. No. 75-548,  1, 4-21-75; Ord. No. 625-76,  1, 7-6-76; Ord. No. 736-78,  1, 2-13-78; Ord. No. 1286-89,  1, 11-16-84; Ord. No. 87-1572,  1, 6-8-87; Ord. No. 2340A-93,  6, 6-28-93) 
Sec. 2-28. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-3643,  2, adopted Sept. 10, 2012, repealed  2-28 which pertained to village president's expense account and derived from Ord. No. 2543-96,  1, 9-23-96; Ord. No. 2000-2800,  1, adopted 10-30-00. 
Sec. 2-29. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2340A-93,  7, adopted June 28, 1993, repealed former  2-29, which pertained to special meetings. 
Secs. 2-30-2-33. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RULES OF ORDER 

Sec. 2-34. - Robert's Rules adopted. 
    Robert's Rules of Order shall govern the deliberations of the board of trustees except when in conflict with this division. 
(Code 1956,  15) 
Sec. 2-35. - Suspension of rules. 
    The rules of order, other than those prescribed by statute, may be suspended at any time by the consent of a majority of the members present at any meeting. 
(Code 1956,  14) 
Sec. 2-36. - Order of business. 
    The order of business of the board of trustees shall be governed by the order of the agenda. 
(Code 1956,  10) 
Sec. 2-37. - Quorum, vote required. 
    A majority of the trustees or three (3) plus the president shall constitute a quorum to do business, but no ordinance shall be passed except upon the favorable vote of a majority of the elected members, as provided by statute. 
(Code 1956,  16) 
Sec. 2-38. - When resolutions to be written. 
    Any resolutions submitted to the board of trustees shall be reduced to writing before being voted upon on request of any two (2) members of the board. 
(Code 1956,  12) 
Sec. 2-39. - Rescinding action. 
    No vote or action of the board of trustees shall be rescinded at any special meeting of the board or trustees unless there be present at such special meeting as many members of the board of trustees as were present at the meeting when such vote or action was taken, as provided by statute. 
(Code 1956,  11) 
Sec. 2-40. - Addressing meeting. 
    No person other than the president or a member of the board shall address that body at any regular or special meeting except upon consent of a majority of the members present. 
(Code 1956,  13) 
Sec. 2-41. - Committees. 
(a)  The village president shall appoint all standing committees with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(b)  Special committees shall be created from time to time as directed by the board of trustees. 
(c)  All standing and special committees shall consist of three (3) members each, including the chairman, unless the board shall direct otherwise. All committees shall be appointed by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(Code 1956,  16; Ord. No. 554-75, 5-5-75) 
Sec. 2-42. - Disturbing meetings. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb any meeting of the board of trustees or of any committee thereof. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be fined not less than one dollar ($1.00) nor more than ten dollars ($10.00) for each offense. 
(Code 1956,  18) 
Secs. 2-43-2-52. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES GENERALLY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Police pension fund,  16-12 et seq. 

Sec. 2-53. - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply alike to all officers and employees of the village, regardless of the time of the creation of the office or position or the time of the appointment of the officer or employee. 
(Code 1956,  90) 
Sec. 2-54. - Appointments. 
    All officers other than elective officers, including the village administrator, shall be appointed by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees as is provided by statute, and provided further that all employees shall, in the absence of any provisions of the contrary, be appointed or selected by the village administrator. 
(Code 1956,  91; Ord. No. 599-76,  2, 2-24-76; Ord. No. 1137-83,  1, 1-10-83) 
Sec. 2-55. - Oath. 
    Every officer of the village, shall before entering upon his duties, take the oath prescribed by statute. 
(Code 1956,  94) 
State Law reference- Oath of office, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  3-14-3. 
Sec. 2-56. - Bond. 
    The village shall provide a bond for every officer as required by state law and in such amount and with such sureties as determined by the corporate authorities but in no event in an amount less than that established by state law and conditioned upon the faithful performance of duties of their office. 
(Code 1956,  98; Ord. No. 2340A-93,  8, 6-28-93) 
Cross reference- Requirements for surety bonds generally,  1-13. 
State Law reference- Bond of officers, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  3-14-3. 
Sec. 2-57. - Terms, vacancies. 
    Every appointive officer of the village shall hold office until the first day of May following his appointment or until his successor is appointed and qualified, unless it is otherwise provided by ordinance. In case of a vacancy in any such place, it shall be filled in the same manner in which appointments or selections are made, in the absence of provision to the contrary. 
(Code 1956,  92) 
Sec. 2-58. - Salaries. 
    All officers and employees of the village shall receive such salary as may be from time to time provided by ordinance. 
(Code 1956,  95) 
State Law reference- Compensation generally, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  3-13-1. 
Sec. 2-59. - Surrender of effects of office. 
    Every elected and appointed village official, within one (1) week of the expiration of their term for any cause whatsoever, shall deliver to the village clerk all books and records which are the property of the village. Every employee of the village, upon their leaving of employment for any cause whatsoever, shall immediately deliver to the village administrator all records which are the property of the village. 
(Code 1956,  100; Ord. No. 2340A-93,  9, 6-28-93) 
Sec. 2-60. - Arrest authority. 
    The village president, members of the board of trustees as well as every policeman are hereby declated to be conservators of the peace by statute. 
(Code 1956  99) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  3-9-4. 
Sec. 2-61. - Availability of records for inspection. 
    All records kept by any officer of the village shall be open to inspection by the president, any member of the board of trustees, or the village administrator at all reasonable times, whether or not such records are required to be kept by statute or ordinance. 
(Code 1956,  97; Ord. No. 599-76,  3, 2-24-76; Ord. No. 898-79,  1, 11-12-79) 
Sec. 2-62. - Accounting for monies. 
    Every officer and employee of the village shall, within one (1) business day of receipt, turn over all village money received by them in their official capacity to the director of finance with a statement showing the source from which the same was received. 
(Code 1956,  93; Ord. No. 2340A-93,  10, 6-28-93) 
Secs. 2-63-2-65. - Reserved.

Secs. 2-66, 2-67. - Reserved.

ARTICLE IV. - APPOINTIVE OFFICERS 
DIVISION 1. - BUDGET OFFICER AND ANNUAL BUDGET[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1420-86, ㎣ 1-7, adopted April 14, 1986, did not specifically amend the Code; therefore, inclusion as ㎣ 2-78-2-84 was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 2-78. - Office created. 
    This village hereby adopts Section 8-2-9.1 through 8-2-9.10 of Chapter 24 of the Illinois Revised Statutes, 1985. The office of budget officer as provided for in said sections is hereby created. Such budget officer shall be designated by the president, with the approval of the corporation authorities. The budget officer shall take oath and post bond as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 1420-86,  1, 4-14-86) 
Sec. 2-79. - Duties. 
    The municipal budget officer shall compile a budget, such budget to contain estimates of revenues available to the municipality for the fiscal year for which the budget is drafted, together with recommended expenditures for the municipality and all of the municipality's departments, commissions and boards. Revenue estimates and expenditure recommendations shall be presented in a manner which is in conformity with good fiscal management practices. Substantial conformity to a chart of accounts, now or in the future, recommended by the National Committee on Governmental Accounting, (or) the Auditor of Public Accounts of the State of Illinois, or the Division of Local Government Affairs and Property Taxes of the Department of Revenue of the State of Illinois or successor agencies shall be deemed proof of such conformity. The budget shall contain actual or estimated revenues and expenditures for two (2) years immediately preceding the fiscal year for which the budget is prepared. So far as is possible, the fiscal data for such two (2) fiscal years shall be itemized in a manner which is in conformity with the chart of accounts approved above. Each budget shall show the specific fund from which each anticipated expenditure shall be made. 
(Ord. No. 1420-86,  2, 4-14-86) 
Sec. 2-80. - Annual budget-Generally. 
    Passage of the annual budget by the corporate authorities shall be in lieu of passage of the appropriation ordinance as required by Section 8-2-9 of said Chapter 24. The annual budget need not be published except in a manner provided for in Section 8-2-9.9. The annual budget shall be adopted by the corporate authorities before the beginning of the fiscal year to which it applies. 
(Ord. No. 1420-86,  3, 4-14-86) 
Sec. 2-81. - Same-Preparations considerations. 
    In the preparation by the municipal budget officer of the annual budget, an amount not to exceed three (3) percent of the equalized assessed value of property subject to taxation by the municipality may be accumulated in a separate fund for the purpose or purposes of specific capital improvements, repairs, and/or replacements of specific types of municipal equipment or other tangible property, both real and personal, to be designated as the "Capital Improvement, Repair or Replacement Fund." Expenditures from the capital improvement, repair or replacement fund shall be budgeted in the fiscal year in which the capital improvement, repair or replacement will occur. Upon the completion or abandonment of any object for which the capital improvement, repair or replacement fund, or should any surplus monies remain after the completion or abandonment of any object for which the capital improvement, repair or replacement fund was inaugurated, then such funds no longer necessary for capital improvement, repair or replacement shall be transferred into the general corporate fund of the municipality on the first day of the fiscal year following such abandonment, completion or discovery of surplus funds. 
(Ord. No. 1420-86,  4, 4-14-86) 
Sec. 2-82. - Same-Revisions. 
    The corporate authorities may delegate authority to heads of municipal departments, boards or commissions to delete, add to, change or create sub-classes within object classes budgeted previously to the department, board, or commission, subject to such limitation or requirement for prior approval by the budget officer or executive officer of the municipality or the president and board of trustees, upon a two-thirds ( 2/3 ) vote of the corporate authorities then holding office, may establish. By a vote of two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of the members of the corporate authorities then holding office, the annual budget for the municipality may be revised by deleting, adding to, changing or creating sub-classes within object classes and object classes themselves. No revision of the budget shall be made increasing the budget in the event funds are not available to effectuate the purpose of the revision. 
(Ord. No. 1420-86,  5, 4-14-86) 
Sec. 2-83. - Same-Public hearing. 
    The corporate authorities shall make the tentative annual budget conveniently available to public inspection for at least ten (10) days prior to the passage of the annual budget, by publication in the journal of the proceedings of the corporate authorities or in such other form as the corporate authorities may prescribe. Not less than one (1) week after the publication of the tentative annual budget, and prior to final action on the budget, the corporate authorities shall hold at least one (1) public hearing on the tentative annual budget, after which hearing or hearings the tentative budget may be further revised and passed without any further inspection, notice or hearing. Notice of this hearing shall be given by publication in a newspaper having a general circulation in the municipality at least one week prior to the time of the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 1420-86,  6, 4-14-86) 
Sec. 2-84. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 2001-2832, adopted March 26, 2001, repealed  2-284. Former  2-284 pertained to limitations on changes and derived from  7 of Ord. No. 1420-86, adopted April 14, 1986. 
DIVISION 2. - VILLAGE CLERK/DEPUTY CLERK[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-3644,  1, adopted Sept. 24, 2012, repealed the former Div. 2, ㎣ 2-85-2-91, and enacted a new Div. 2 as set out herein. The former Div. 2 pertained to village clerk/deputy clerk and derived from Ord. No. 2008-3410,  1, 9-22-08. 

Sec. 2-85. - Election, term. 
    The village clerk shall be elected to serve a four-year term until a successor is elected and qualified as provided by statute. The village clerk shall provide village clerk services at village hall in such manner and devoting such time as is necessary to accomplish the duties set forth in section 2-89. 
(Ord. No. 2012-3644,  1, 9-24-12) 
Sec. 2-86. - Clerk's office. 
(a)  The village clerk shall be in charge of work necessary to complete those duties specified by state statute and this division. The village clerk's position shall be part time requiring no more than thirty (30) hours per week. 
(b)  The village clerk shall report directly to the president and board of trustees and shall be responsible for the fidelity of the deputy clerk as further authorized herein. 
(Ord. No. 2012-3644,  1, 9-24-12) 
Sec. 2-87. - Vacancy in office. 
    If the office of the village clerk becomes vacant for any reason or the village clerk becomes incapacitated, the president and board of trustees shall in the case of vacancy appoint a successor, or in the case of incapacity, direct the deputy village clerk to perform the clerk's services as provided by state statute. 
(Ord. No. 2012-3644,  1, 9-24-12) 
Sec. 2-88. - Village clerk's salary. 
    The village clerk shall be paid on a bi-monthly basis as follows: 
(a)  If unregistered or uncertified, in the amount of eleven thousand seven hundred dollars ($11,700.00) per year of term of office; upon the documented completion of at least forty (40) hours of training to become a registered clerk as provided by the Municipal Clerks of Illinois or International Institute of Municipal Clerk's, a bonus of eleven thousand and seven hundred dollars ($11,700.00) shall be paid in the last pay period of the calendar year that the training is completed. The bonus may be paid annually for additional three (3) years upon the completion of each additional forty (40) hours of documented training in furtherance of becoming a registered clerk being completed. 
(b)  If registered, in conformance with the requirements of the Illinois Municipal Clerks of Illinois in the amount of twenty-seven thousand seven hundred fifty dollars ($27,750.00) per year of term of office; or 
(c)  If certified in conformance with the requirements of the International Institute of Municipal Clerks, the amount of thirty-nine thousand ($39,000.00) per year of term of office; 
(d)  For an incumbent village clerk re-elected as of the effective date of this article, and for each successive period of three hundred sixty-five (365) day thereafter, the salary of that village clerk shall be increased, by the lesser sum of two (2) percent or the prior year's cumulative consumer price index for all urban consumers (Chicago-Gary-Kenosha) as computed by the Federal Bureau of Labor. The increase for an unregistered or uncertified clerk shall be paid on the base salary of eleven thousand seven hundred dollars ($11,700.00) plus bonus earned in the corresponding three hundred sixty-five (365) day period. The increased amount for registered or certified clerks shall be based upon the level of certification existing as of the first date of salary for the subsequent three hundred sixty-five (365) day period and shall not be increased during the same three hundred sixty-five (365) day period even if additional registration or certification is earned during an existing three hundred sixty-five (365) day period. For all non-incumbent clerks elected as of the effective date of this article, salary increases shall not occur until three hundred and sixty-five (365) days after the non-incumbent clerk first commences his/her term of office. 
(e)  Village clerk's filling the unexpired term of a prior village clerk shall not be entitled to an increase as provided in this article until they have served three hundred sixty-five (365) days after taking the office of village clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2012-3644,  1, 9-24-12; Ord. No. 2016-3865,  1, 9-26-16) 
Sec. 2-89. - Duties. 
    The village clerk shall have the following duties: 
(a)  Shall be the custodian of the village seal, shall affix its impression on documents whenever required and shall attest to all contracts and documents requiring sealing. 
(b)  Shall be custodian of and maintain all documents and records of the village except those assigned to the custody and control of some other officer. The village clerk's record documents shall include: 
(1)  All ordinances and resolutions of the village; 
(2)  All annexation agreements; 
(3)  All contracts of the village; 
(4)  All liquor and business licenses; 
(5)  All minutes to the village board meeting; 
(6)  All minutes of the village board committee meeting; 
(7)  All lawsuits by and against the village; 
(8)  All policies adopted by resolution of the village board; 
(9)  All other documents which must be maintained by village clerks under Illinois law. 
(c)  Shall attend all meetings of the corporate authorities, keep a record of the proceedings in a journal, and make available for public inspection copies of the minutes of those meetings, within seven (7) days of approval by the corporate authorities. 
(d)  Shall record all documents of the village requiring recording with a recorder of deeds. 
(e)  Shall provide for the codification of ordinances of general application not less than annually. 
(f)  Shall keep and maintain a proper index of all documents and records kept by the village clerk so ready access thereto and use thereof maybe had; 
(g)  Shall oversee and coordinate the destruction of village documents and records as allowed by the secretary of state local records unit. 
(h)  Shall be the primary FOIA officer within the village and maintain compliance as determined by the Illinois Attorney General's Office and the Open Meetings Act. 
(i)  Shall be the primary OMA officer within the village and maintain compliance as determined by the Illinois Attorney General's Office and the Open Meetings Act. 
[j]  Shall appoint a deputy clerk in conformance with the authorization set forth in this division. 
[k]  Shall keep an account showing all money received by the office of the clerk and the source and disposition thereof, and provide all such information to the village finance director. 
[l]  Such other duties as are assigned by the president and board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 2012-3644,  1, 9-24-12) 
Sec. 2-90. - Deputy clerk. 
    There shall be a deputy clerk who shall exercise those powers and duties of the village clerk, when the village clerk is absent from the place where the clerk's office is maintained and the village clerk has given written direction to the deputy clerk to exercise the clerk's powers, or where the corporate authorities of the village have determined by resolution that the office of the village clerk has become vacant or the village clerk is temporarily or permanently incapacitated to perform the clerk's duties. 
(Ord. No. 2012-3644,  1, 9-24-12) 
Sec. 2-91. - Deputy clerk per diem. 
    The deputy clerk shall be paid two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) at the end of each quarter of the village clerk's term that the deputy clerk is appointed to serve. If more than one deputy clerk is appointed in any quarter, the two hundred fifty dollar ($250.00) payment shall be divided by the number of deputy clerks appointed in that quarter and the quotient of the division shall be paid to them equally regardless of the number of days served. 
(Ord. No. 2012-3644,  1, 9-24-12) 
Secs. 2-92-2-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - VILLAGE TREASURER[5] 

Footnotes:

The treasurer shall be bonded in accordance with state statutes and shall report directly to the president and board of trustees. Sec. 2-108. - Deputy village treasurer; position created; duties; etc. 
    There is hereby created the office of deputy village treasurer, who shall be nominated by the village treasurer, and appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, and who shall have all of the powers and duties as the village treasurer as are imposed and granted by the statutes of the State of Illinois and the ordinances of the village. The deputy treasurer shall report directly to the village treasurer and president. 
(Ord. No. 1981-90,  1, 7-23-90) 
Sec. 2-109. - Special assessments accounts. 
    The director of finance shall maintain suitable books containing accurate and detailed account of all special assessments levied for any improvement and when all costs and expenses of any improvement which has been made by special assessment have been fully satisfied and there is a sum of money collected in excess of the entire cost of such improvement, shall report to the corporate authorities in writing the amount of such excess. The director of finance shall also keep account of all rebates on special assessments ordered by the corporate authorities, issue warrants therefore to the respective parties in title thereto, keep an account of the same, and whenever the full amount of such rebate has been paid out, report the fact to the corporate authorities. 
(Ord. No. 2340A-93,  15, 6-28-93) 
Sec. 2-110. - Special assessment accounts against the village. 
    The director of finance shall keep a separate memorandum account showing any amount assessed against the village for public benefits in consequence of special assessments. Such accounts shall show the amount of each installment and each assessment. 
(Ord. No. 2340A-93,  16, 6-28-93) 
Sec. 2-111. - Reserved.

DIVISION 5. - VILLAGE ATTORNEY 

Sec. 2-125. - Office created; appointment. 
    There is hereby created the office of village attorney, who shall be an officer of the village. The attorney shall be appointed by the president, by and with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(Code 1956,  43; Ord. No. 608-76,  1, 3-1-76; Ord. No. 1513-86,  1, 12-22-86) 
Sec. 2-126. - Special counsel. 
    The president with the consent of the board of trustees may from time to time retain an attorney to represent or advise the village on legal matters if no village attorney has been appointed; and he may likewise retain special counsel to advise or represent the village on special matters or to assist the village attorney. 
(Code 1956,  44; Ord. No. 608-76,  1, 3-1-76; Ord. No. 1513-86,  1, 12-22-86) 
Sec. 2-127. - Duties. 
    The attorney shall prosecute or defend any and all suits or actions at law or equity to which the village may be a party, or in which it may be interested, or which may be brought against or by, any officer of the village on behalf of the village or in the capacity of such person as an officer of the village; provided, however, he shall not act as village prosecutor unless otherwise directed. The attorney shall attend the regular meetings of the president and board of trustees so as to serve as counsel to the corporate authorities or village administrator as well as to perform such other legal services as may be directed by the corporate authorities or village administrator. 
(Code 1956,  47; Ord. No. 608-76,  1, 3-1-76; Ord. No. 1513-86,  1, 12-22-86) 
Sec. 2-128. - To give advice. 
    The attorney shall be the legal adviser of the village and shall render advice on all legal questions affecting it, whenever requested to do so by any village official. Upon request by the president, he shall reduce any such opinion to writing. 
(Code 1956,  47; Ord. No. 608-76,  1, 3-1-76) 
Sec. 2-129. - Additional duties. 
    The village attorney shall perform such other duties as may be prescribed by the board of trustees. 
(Ord No. 608-76,  1, 3-1-76) 
Secs. 2-130-2-134. - Reserved.

DIVISION 8. - FIRE CHIEF AND DEPUTY FIRE CHIEF[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2014-3745,  1, adopted June 23, 2014, amended Div. 8 in its entirety, in effect repealing and reenacting said division to read as set out herein. The former Div. 8, ㎣ 2-162-2-168, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 2007-3334,  1, adopted Oct, 8, 2007, repealing the former Div. 8 ㎣ 2-162-2-165, which pertained to chief of the fire department and derived from Ord. No. 602-76,  1, 3-1-76; Ord. No. 932-80,  1, 4-7-80; Ord. No. 2398-94,  1, 5-23-94. 
Cross reference- Fire protection and prevention, Ch. 7. 

Sec. 2-162. - Positions created. 
    There are hereby created the positions of Fire Chief and Deputy Fire Chief of the Roselle Fire Department. 
(Ord. No. 2014-3745,  1, 6-23-14) 
Sec. 2-163. - Fire chief. 
    The chief of the fire department shall be appointed by the president, by and with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 2014-3745,  1, 6-23-14) 
Sec. 2-164. - Appointment deputy fire chief. 
    The Deputy Fire Chief of the Roselle Fire Department shall be appointed by the fire chief of the fire department by and with the advice and consent of the village administrator. 
(Ord. No. 2014-3745,  1, 6-23-14) 
Sec. 2-165. - Fire chief/employment status. 
    The fire chief of the fire department shall serve at the pleasure of the president, by and with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, and his removal, discharge or discipline shall not be subject to the jurisdiction or authority of the Roselle Fire and Police Commission but instead shall be solely subject to the authority of the president, by and with the advice and consent, of the village board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 2014-3745,  1, 6-23-14) 
Sec. 2-166. - Deputy fire chief/employment status. 
    The deputy fire chief shall be exempt from applicable state statutes regulating the appointment, promotion, removal, discharge and/or discipline of fire officers and shall not be subject to the jurisdiction of the Roselle Fire and Police Commission. The deputy fire chief shall serve at the discretion of the fire chief, with the advice and consent of the village administrator. 
(Ord. No. 2014-3745,  1, 6-23-14) 
Sec. 2-167. - Deputy fire chief-Internal appointment. 
    In the event a current sworn full-time member of the village's fire department is appointed deputy fire chief, the appointment shall be considered an internal appointment. If an internally appointed deputy fire chief is removed from the position of deputy fire chief for any reason, the sworn full-time member shall revert back to the rank he/she held immediately prior to the appointment of deputy fire chief, without regard as to whether a vacancy exists in that rank. A deputy fire chief, having been appointed from any rank of sworn full-time member of the village's fire department, shall be permitted, regardless of rank, to participate in the promotional exam process and be eligible for a promotion to a higher rank than he/she held prior to the deputy fire chief appointment, without having to resign as deputy fire chief. 
(Ord. No. 2014-3745,  1, 6-23-14) 
Sec. 2-168. - Duties of the deputy fire chief. 
    The duties of the deputy fire chief shall be established in the Village of Roselle Deputy Fire Chief job description, as may be amended from time to time, and also upon direction from the fire chief. 
(Ord. No. 2014-3745,  1, 6-23-14) 
Sec. 2-168.5. - Qualifications for deputy fire chief. 
    The deputy fire chief shall be appointed from within or outside the village's fire department, and in making the appointment, the fire chief shall consider the following factors or other factors as deemed by the fire chief to be significant to the appointment: 
(1)  Job experience. 
(2)  Management experience. 
(3)  Budget knowledge. 
(4)  Planning ability. 
(5)  Organizational skills. 
(6)  Interpersonal skills. 
(7)  Education/training. 
(8)  Ability to evaluate and assign staff. 
(9)  Ability to research wide and complex issues. 
(10)  Reporting skills. 
(Ord. No. 2014-3745,  1, 6-23-14) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2014-3745,  1, adopted June 23, 2014, set out provisions intended for use as  2-169. Inasmuch as there were already provisions so designated, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as  2-168.5.

DIVISION 10. - DEPUTY CHIEF[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2340A-93,  20, adopted June 28, 1993, repealed former div. 10, ㎣ 2-175-2-177, which pertained to the village forester. Ord. No. 2000-2752,  1, adopted Jan. 24, 2000, enacted a new div. 10, pertaining to the office of deputy chief, to read as herein set out. 

Sec. 2-175. - Office created. 
    There is hereby created the position of deputy chief. There shall be two (2) deputy chief positions in the Roselle Police Department, which shall be appointed by the chief of the police department. The deputy chief of police shall be exempt from applicable state statutes regulating the appointment, promotion, removal, discharge and/or discipline of law enforcement officials, officers, and employees, including 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-1 et seq., as amended. Deputy chiefs shall serve at the discretion of the chief, and if removed from that position, shall revert to the rank held immediately prior to appointment to the deputy chief's position. 
(Ord. No. 2000-2752,  1, 1-24-00) 
Sec. 2-176. - Qualification. 
    The deputy chief shall be appointed from any rank of sworn, full-time officers of the village's police department, and shall have at least five (5) years of full-time service as a police officer in the village police department. In making the appointment, the chief of police shall consider the following factors: 
(1)  Job experience; 
(2)  Management experience; 
(3)  Budget knowledge; 
(4)  Planning ability; 
(5)  Organizational skills; 
(6)  Interpersonal skills; 
(7)  Education/training; 
(8)  Ability to evaluate and assign staff; 
(9)  Ability to research wide and complex issues; and 
(10)  Reporting skills. 
(Ord. No. 2000-2752,  1, 1-24-00) 
Sec. 2-177. - Duties. 
    The duties of the deputy chief shall be as follows: 
(1)  Perform any and all other lawful duties assigned by the chief of police; 
(2)  Act for the chief of police during the absence of the chief or as designated; execute general and special assignments in the planning, administration, coordination, direction and review of department operations and activities; 
(3)  Serve as a member of the department's management team; provide assistance and advice to the chief of police; assist in setting departmental goals and evaluating the extent and nature of their accomplishment; 
(4)  Represent the department in relationships with other governmental officials and members of the public; conduct special assignments at the direction of the chief of police; 
(5)  Direct and coordinate activities in the department; develop policies and procedures; participate in the preparation of the department's budget; administrative and staff services; and 
(6)  Other related work. 
(Ord. No. 2000-2752,  1, 1-24-00)

ARTICLE IV.5. - BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 286-70 did not expressly amend this Code, hence codification of ㎣ 1-8 as Art. IV.5, ㎣ 2-179-2-186 respectively, was at the discretion of the editors. Secs. 9 and 10 of said ordinance, directory provisions, were omitted, to preserve Code format. 

Sec. 2-179. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created a board of fire and police commissioners consisting of three (3) members, as provided by statute. 
(Ord. No. 286-70,  1, 4-13-70) 
Sec. 2-180. - Appointment, terms of members. 
    The members of said board shall be considered officers of the village and they shall be appointed by the president of the village, by and with the consent of the board of trustees. The terms of office of the members of the board of fire and police commissioners shall be three (3) years and until their respective successors are appointed and have qualified; provided that no such appointment shall be made by any president within thirty (30) days before the expiration of his term of office. The president shall appoint the first members of such board, one of whom shall be appointed to serve until the end of the then current municipal year, another to serve until the end of the municipal year next ensuing and the third to serve until the end of the municipal year second next ensuing; provided that each of the first members of the board shall serve until his successor is appointed and has qualified. The board members shall elect a chairman to serve during the municipal fiscal year. 
(Ord. No. 286-70,  2, 4-13-70) 
Sec. 2-181. - Vacancies. 
    Vacancies on the board of fire and police commissioners shall be filled in the same manner as the original appointments. 
(Ord. No. 286-70,  3, 4-13-70) 
Sec. 2-182. - Qualifications; oath; bond; removal. 
(a)  The members of the board of fire and police commissioners shall have such qualifications as are now, or may hereafter be, required by law. No person holding a lucrative office under the United States, the State of Illinois, or any political subdivision thereof, or a municipality, shall be a member of the board of fire and police commissioners or the secretary thereof. The acceptance of any such lucrative office by a member of the board shall be treated as a resignation of his office as a member of the board or the secretary thereof. No person shall be appointed a member of the board of fire and police commissioners who is related, either by blood or marriage to the degree of first cousin, to any elected official of this Village of Roselle. No more than two (2) members of the board shall belong to the same political party existing in the village at the time of such appointments and as defined in Section 10-2 of the Election Code. If only one or no political party exists in the village at the time of such appointments, then state or national political party affiliations shall be considered in making such appointments. Party affiliation shall be determined by affidavit of the person appointed as a member of the board. 
(b)  Each member of the board of fire and police commissioners shall file an oath and a fidelity bond in such amount as may be required by the president and board of trustees. 
(c)  Members shall not be subject to removal, except for cause, upon written charges, and after an opportunity to be heard within thirty (30) days in his or their own defense, before a regular meeting of the president and board of trustees. A majority vote of the president and board of trustees shall be required to remove any such member from office. 
(Ord. No. 286-70,  4, 4-13-70) 
Sec. 2-183. - Appointments by board of fire and police commissioners. 
    Such board of fire and police commissioners shall conduct examinations for, and appoint all officers and members of the fire and police department of the village (except the chief of police and the chief of the fire department, which appointments shall be made by the president and board of trustees as provided by statute; except nonsworn or civilian employees of the fire and police departments, and except volunteer firefighters and volunteer officers of the fire department including those officers and firefighters who are members of the Roselle Fire Department, Inc., a not-for-profit corporation with which the village contracts for manpower). All appointments made by the board of fire and police commissioners shall be from the rank next below that to which the appointment shall be made, other than that of the lowest rank. 
(Ord. No. 286-70,  5, 4-13-70; Ord. No. 932-80,  1, 4-7-80) 
Cross reference- Appointment of chief of fire department,  2-163; chief of police,  2-169. 
Sec. 2-184. - Rules; quorum. 
    Such board of fire and police commissioners shall make such rules and make such appointments and removals except those herein reserved to the president and board of trustees and shall have such other and further powers as is provided by statute. A majority of the board constitutes a quorum for the conduct of all business. 
(Ord. No. 286-70,  6, 4-13-70) 
Sec. 2-185. - Secretary; attorney for board; compensation of secretary and members of board. 
    The board may employ a secretary or may designate one of its own members to act as secretary. The secretary may be paid a reasonable compensation for his services, to be fixed by the president and board of trustees. The president and board of trustees may also fix the compensation to be paid to the members of the board, but until the president and board of trustees make provision therefor, the members of the board shall serve without compensation. The attorney retained by the president and board of trustees to act as attorney for the village shall also represent the board of fire and police commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 286-70,  7, 4-13-70) 
Sec. 2-186. - Annual report. 
    Annually, at any time the president and board of trustees may provide, the board of fire and police commissioners shall submit to the president a report of its activities and of the rules in force and the practical effect thereof. In this report, the board of fire and police commissioners may make suggestions which it believes would result in greater efficiency in the fire and police departments. The president shall transmit the report of the board of trustees. The board of fire and police commissioners shall also submit an annual budget request to the president and board of trustees prior to the end of each fiscal year. 
(Ord. No. 286-70,  8, 4-13-70) 
Sec. 2-187. - Reserved.
