(4)  To notify the secretary of state where a club incorporated under the General Not-For-Profit Corporation Act or a foreign corporation functioning as a club in this state under a certificate of authority issued under that Act has violated the Illinois Liquor Control Act by selling or offering for sale at retail, alcoholic liquors without a retailer's license; 
(5)  To receive complaints from any citizen within his jurisdiction that any provision of the Illinois Liquor Control Act, or any ordinances, rules or regulations adopted pursuant thereto, have been or are being violated to act upon such complaints in a manner provided by this chapter and/or by the Illinois Liquor Control Act; 
(6)  To levy fines for violation of the provisions of this chapter not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each violation nor more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) per year; 
(7)  To examine and cause to be examined under oath any applicant for a local license or for renewal thereof, or any licensee upon whom notice of revocation or suspension has been served in the manner provided herein and to examine or cause to be examined, the books and records of such applicant or licensee; to hear testimony and take proof for his information in the performance of his duties, and for such purpose to issue subpoenas; 
(8)  To report to the village board from time to time actions which have been taken to grant or deny liquor licenses or to penalize licensees; 
(9)  To make and adopt such reasonable rules and regulations as he deems necessary in the performance of his duties; 
(10)  To appoint with the advice and consent of the village board, a local liquor commissioner pro tem to serve when the local liquor control commissioner is unable to serve as a result of disability or physical absence from the municipality. 
(11)  To declare any license forfeited or lapsed when a licensee has, for a period of more than thirty (30) successive calendar days, ceased to do business or closed his place of business without written permission from the local liquor commissioner. 
(12)  To keep or caused to be kept, a complete record of all licenses issued by the local liquor commissioner pursuant to this chapter. 
(13)  To impose additional restrictions or conditions on a licensee which are not inconsistent with other provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93) 
Sec. 3-5. - Violation hearings. 
    The following procedures shall be followed with respect to allegations of violations of the Roselle Liquor Control Ordinance. 
(1)  No hearing into an alleged violation of the Roselle Liquor Control Ordinance shall be had except upon a minimum of fourteen (14) calendar days written notice, personally served, or served by certified or registered mail, upon the licensee. Should the licensee refuse or be unavailable for service, the village clerk is hereby irrevocably appointed on behalf of the licensee for purposes of receipt of such service. The written notice shall outline the basic allegations made against the licensee and specify a hearing date and time. Continuances of a hearing may be granted within the discretion of the liquor control commissioner provided that the licensee submit, at least seven (7) calendar days prior to hearing, a written request for a continuance specifying the reasons that the hearing should be continued. Any licensee charged with a violation of the Roselle Liquor Control Ordinance may, at his sole expense, be represented by an attorney of his own choosing. The violation hearing shall be recorded by an Illinois Certified Shorthand Reporter. 
(2)  Each notice of violation shall contain an "arraignment form," a copy of which is attached hereto and incorporated herein as if fully set forth as appendix A. Seven (7) calendar days prior to hearing of an alleged liquor control ordinance violation, the licensee shall complete the arraignment form and file it with the village clerk. Any licensee who fails to file the form within seven (7) calendar days prior to hearing shall have a plea of not guilty entered on his behalf by the village clerk. If the licensee subsequently enters a plea of guilty, the licensee shall reimburse the village for any and all out-of-pocket expenses, including reasonable attorney's fees, shorthand reporter appearance fees, and the costs for having police officers and witnesses present to testify, resulting from the licensee's failure to timely file the arraignment form with the village clerk. 
(3)  Upon a plea of guilty, the liquor commissioner may review the licensee's record and the circumstances surrounding the offense and impose any penalties set forth in this section 3-5. The liquor control commissioner shall further have the option, upon a plea of guilty; to require a hearing in aggravation and mitigation if the liquor control commissioner determines it is necessary, based upon the number, type and frequency of violations, to determine appropriate penalties. In the case of a hearing in aggravation and mitigation the licensee and the village shall have the option of being represented by legal counsel. 
(4)  The local liquor commissioner may, in accordance with the Illinois Liquor Control Act, revoke, or suspend any license issued under the provisions of this chapter and/or levy a fine on the licensee if it is determined that the licensee has violated any provisions of this chapter. The fine imposed shall not exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each violation nor more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) per year. The local liquor commissioner may further order additional alcohol awareness training if he determines that a pattern of violations warrants such training. Each day on which a violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. In imposing a penalty, the local liquor commissioner shall take into consideration any and all factors in mitigation presented by the licensee and in aggravation presented by the village prosecutor. The local liquor commissioner shall further have the right to review any and all relevant materials contained in the liquor licensee's files that may have bearing on the penalty to be imposed. 
(5)  The local liquor commissioner shall, within fourteen (14) calendar days after such hearing, enter a written judgment order making findings of fact. A finding of not guilty shall terminate the proceeding. If a finding of guilty is entered and if it is determined that a fine should be imposed or the license should be revoked or suspended, the local liquor commissioner shall state within his judgment order the reason for such determination. All fines imposed by the local liquor commissioner shall be paid to the village clerk within fourteen (14) calendar days of their imposition. Failure to pay any fines or costs imposed within fourteen (14) calendar days of notification is a violation of this chapter and may be cause for license suspension or revocation. In the event of an appeal to the Illinois Liquor Control Commission, or in cases where an appeal was taken pursuant to the Administrative Review Act, payment shall be due within fourteen (14) calendars days after the entry of a final order affirming the determination of the local liquor commissioner. 
(6)  In addition to any fine, revocation, or suspension of any license, the local liquor commissioner may require the liquor licensee to reimburse the village for any and all out-of-pocket costs associated with a violation hearing in which there has been a finding of guilty or such lesser sum as the local liquor commissioner may allow. These costs include but are not limited to the village prosecutor's fees, certified shorthand reporter fees, the cost of preparing and mailing notices and orders, and all other miscellaneous expenses incurred by the village. 
(7)  If the local liquor commissioner has reason to believe that any continued operation of a particular licensed premises will immediately threaten the welfare of the community, he may, upon issuance of a written order stating the reason for such conclusion, and without notice or hearing, order the licensed premises closed for not more than seven (7) calendar days, giving the licensee an opportunity to be heard during that period, except that if that licensee is also engaged in another business on the licensed premises, such order shall not be applicable to such other businesses. 
(8)  In addition to violations of this chapter, the local liquor commissioner may refuse the issuance or renewal of a liquor license, or suspend or revoke such license, without hearing, upon receiving notice from the State of Illinois of any of the following violations of the Retailers Occupation Tax Act, approved June 28, 1933, as amended: 
a.  Failure to make a required tax return; 
b.  The filing of a fraudulent return; 
c.  Failure to pay all or part of any tax or penalty finally determined to be due; 
d.  Failure to keep books and records; 
e.  Failure to secure and display a certificate or sub-certificates of registration; 
f.  Wilful violation of any rule or regulation of the Illinois Department of Revenue relating to the administration and enforcement of tax liability. 
(9)  Review of decisions of the Local liquor commissioner shall be as provided for in 235 ILCS 5/7-9 of the Illinois Liquor Control Act and shall be limited to a review of the official records of the proceeding of the local liquor commissioner. 
(Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93; Ord. No. 2010-3544,  1, 10-11-10) 
Sec. 3-6. - Alcohol awareness training. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, deliver, serve, prepare, pour, mix or draw alcoholic liquor in any establishment having a liquor license under the provisions of section 3-19 of this chapter where such sale, delivery or service is intended for consumption on the premises unless that person has successfully completed an alcohol awareness training program accredited by the State of Illinois or conducted by the Roselle Police Department. It shall also be unlawful for any owner of a business possessing a Class E, F, G, H, I, J, K, L, M, N, R and S Liquor License to allow alcoholic beverages to be consumed on the premises unless a person present on licensed premises has successfully completed an alcohol awareness training program accredited by the State of Illinois or conducted by the Roselle Police Department. For all categories of Roselle Liquor Licenses, any and all persons required to submit to a background check pursuant to the Roselle Liquor Control Ordinance shall complete an alcohol awareness training program accredited by the State of Illinois or conducted by the Roselle Police Department within the time period set forth in subsection (g) of this section. 
(b)  Any person successfully completing the required alcohol awareness training program shall present proof of the successful completion of that program to the village clerk who shall then enter that person's name on a roll of persons qualified to sell, deliver, serve, prepare, pour, mix or draw alcoholic beverages in any establishment having a liquor license under provisions of section 3-19 of this chapter. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any establishment possessing a village liquor license and serving alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises to permit any person who has not complied with the provisions of this article or whose name is not contained on the current role of the village clerk to serve, prepare, pour, mix or draw alcoholic liquor within that establishment. 
(d)  All license holders shall maintain proof upon the premises that all persons selling, delivering, serving, preparing, pouring, mixing or drawing alcoholic liquor have successfully completed an alcohol awareness training program accredited by the State of Illinois. 
(e)  Any person registered on the roll of the village clerk may have their name suspended or stricken from the roll for violation of one (1) or more of the following provisions: 
(1)  Any felony; 
(2)  Being a keeper or keeping a house of ill fame as described in Illinois Revised Statutes, Chapter 38, Section 11; 
(3)  Pandering or other crime or misdemeanor of village ordinance which is a crime opposed to decency and morality, as defined in Illinois Revised Statutes, Chapter 38, Article 11; 
(4)  Sale of alcoholic beverages to a minor; 
(5)  Gambling as described in Illinois Revised Statutes, Chapter 38, Article 28, and/or village's ordinances dealing with gambling; 
(6)  Possession or sale of cannabis or controlled substances as described in Illinois Revised Statutes, Chapter 56; 
(7)  Any violation of any other provision of the Roselle Liquor Control Ordinance. 
(f)  As an alternative to suspension or striking the name of the person from the roll of the village clerk, the local liquor commissioner may fine the violator in a sum not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(g)  Any person currently selling, delivering, serving, preparing, pouring, mixing or drawing alcoholic liquor on the premises, in any establishment having a Roselle liquor license shall have ninety (90) calendar days from the effective date of this article to comply with this article. Any person hired subsequent to the date of this article shall comply with this article within sixty (60) calendar days of their hiring. 
(Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93; Ord. No. 2016-3832,  2, 3-14-16) 
Sec. 3-7. - Exceptions. 
    This article shall not be applicable to holders of class "A," "B," "C," "D," "L," "P," and "Q" liquor licenses. 
(Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93) 
Secs. 3-8-3-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RETAIL LICENSES 

Sec. 3-19. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful in the Village of Roselle to make any sale or offer for sale as defined herein or for any BYO premises to allow consumption, any alcoholic liquor, beer or wine, without having a retail liquor license, special events license, BYO license or be in violation of the terms of any such license. BYO license applicants shall satisfy all requirements set forth in subsections (a), (b), and (c) of section 3-31 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93; Ord. No. 2016-3832,  3, 3-14-16) 
Sec. 3-20. - Application. 
    A person wishing to file an application for a liquor license may obtain the application form from the village clerk in a form prescribed by the local liquor commissioner providing information as required by this chapter, as well as any and all other information deemed necessary by the local liquor commissioner, to assess the applicants qualifications for a village liquor license. The application shall be verified by oath or affidavit and shall be signed by: (i) the applicant, if the applicant is an individual; (ii) the president and secretary if the applicant is a club or corporation; or (iii) a general partner if the applicant is a partnership. 
(Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93) 
Sec. 3-21. - Processing fee. 
(a)  Retail licenses. A processing fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00) and one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each individual required to be identified on a new retail liquor license application or a six (6) year retail renewal application shall be paid at the time the application is made for a new retail license or upon a six (6) year retail license renewal date. Fingerprinting of identified persons is included in this fee. A fee of forty-four dollars ($44.00) per individual for fingerprinting shall also be paid upon a three (3) year fingerprint check required by section 3-25 of this chapter. An additional fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per person for new managers shall be paid upon submission of a new manager's application as required by section 3-36 of this chapter. All processing fees shall be non-refundable regardless of the outcome of the application. 
(b)  BYO licenses. A processing fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each BYO license shall be paid at the time an application is made for the BYO license. Fingerprinting of one (1) identified person is included in this fee. Any additional persons required to be fingerprinted under the terms of this article for a BYO applicant shall pay a fingerprinting fee of forty-four dollars ($44.00) All BYO processing fees shall be non-refundable regardless of the outcome of the application. 
(Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93; Ord. No. 2009-3482,  1, 12-14-09; Ord. No. 2016-3832,  4, 3-14-16) 
Sec. 3-22. - Application contents. 
(a)  Each application for a liquor license required by this chapter, except class "N" and "O" licenses, shall contain the following statements and information: 
(1)  The applicants name, mailing and residence addresses, and business and residence telephone number; 
(2)  The name and address of the applicant's business; 
(3)  If applicable, the assumed name of the business or the date of the filing of the assumed name with the county clerk of DuPage and Cook County; 
(4)  In the case of a corporation, if an Illinois corporation, the date of its incorporation, or if a foreign corporation, the state where it was incorporated and the date of its becoming qualified under the Illinois Business Corporation Act to transact business in Illinois, and in either case a statement of the objects for which the corporation is organized, the full name, age, address and telephone number of all officers, and directors of the corporation; 
(5)  Where an individual, proprietorship or partnership, the citizenship of the applicant, his place of birth, and if a naturalized citizen, the time and place of his naturalization; 
(6)  The length of time the applicant has been in business; 
(7)  If applicable, the name, age, address and telephone number of the person(s) who will manage the business of the applicant within the village; 
(8)  The character of the business of the applicant; 
(9)  The length of time the applicant has been in business of that character; 
(10)  Whether the applicant has goods, wares, and merchandise on hand at the time application is made; 
(11)  The location or description of the premises or the place of business which is to be operated under such license, and the following information: 
a.  If a leased premises, a copy of the lease shall be provided, establishing that the lease is for a term sufficient in length to encompass the term of the license sought; and 
b.  The name and address of the owner or owners of the premises and the names and addresses of the owners of the beneficial interest of any trust if said premises are being held in trust. 
(12)  A statement whether the applicant has made application for a similar or other license on the premises other than those described in his application, and the disposition of such application; 
(13)  A statement signed by or on behalf of the applicant, and by all individuals required to be identified therein, that each of them has never been convicted of a felony and is not disqualified to receive a license by reason of any matter or thing contained in the laws of the State of Illinois or the ordinances of the village; 
(14)  If applicable, a list of any and all felony convictions, misdemeanor convictions, alcohol related traffic offenses, and all sentences of court supervision; 
(15)  Whether a previous license issued by any state or subdivision thereof, or by the federal government, has been issued and if so, when and where, and whether any such previous license has been the subject of the imposition of a fine, suspension, or revocation. If any such license has been the subject of the imposition of a fine, suspension, or revocation, the reasons for such shall be stated; 
(16)  A statement that the applicant and all the individuals required to be identified in the application have not in the past, and will not in the future, violate any of the laws of any state or subdivision thereof, or the United States, or any ordinance of any local government authority controlling the retail sale of alcoholic liquor and the conduct of his place of business; 
(17)  The applicant's retailer's occupation tax (ROT) registration number and a statement of whether the applicant is delinquent in the payment of the retailer's occupation tax and, if so, the reasons therefore; 
(18)  A statement whether the applicant is delinquent under the thirty-day credit law and, if so, the reasons therefore; 
(19)  Whether the applicant, any individual identified in the application or any other person directly or indirectly interested in the place of business possesses a current federal wagering and gaming device stamp and, if so, the reasons therefore; 
(20)  Whether the applicant, any individual identified in the application or any other person directly or indirectly interested in the place of business is a public official, a police officer and, if so, the particulars thereof; 
(21)  A statement whether the applicant is in violation of 65 ILCS 5/6-6 of the Liquor Control Act and, if so, the reasons therefore; 
(22)  Such additional information or identification as the local liquor commissioner may deem necessary in order to establish the character of the applicant. 
(b)  No license shall issue until the applicant(s) has/have been investigated by the local liquor commissioner and all of the information described provided. New applicants shall not be licensed until they have been finger printed and photographed by the village police department and record searches made of the files of the Illinois Bureau of Investigation and any other record agency that the police chief shall deem necessary. A copy of the fingerprints and photographs shall be retained in the files of the village clerk who shall file a statement with the local liquor commissioner informing him of the results of the police fingerprint check and background investigation. 
(Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93) 
Sec. 3-23. - Class "P" and "Q": special event license applications. 
    Applications for class "P" and "Q": special event licenses shall be made to the local liquor commissioner verified by oath or affidavit and shall contain the following statements and information: 
(1)  The name of the organization; 
(2)  The name of the event chairman; 
(3)  The address of the event chairman; 
(4)  The home phone number of the event chairman; 
(5)  The work phone number of the event chairman; 
(6)  A description of the nature of the event; 
(7)  A description of the location of the event; 
(8)  A description of the dates of events if available. If the dates of events are not available as of the date of application, they shall be provided to the village clerk at least seven (7) calendar days prior to commencement of the event; 
(9)  A description of what the profits from the event will be used for; 
(10)  The character of the nonprofit business of the applicant; 
(11)  The date that the not for profit business was incorporated under the laws of the State of Illinois; 
(12)  Such other information or identification as the local liquor commissioner may deem necessary in order to establish the character of the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93) 
Sec. 3-24. - Dram shop insurance required. 
    Prior to the issuance of a village liquor license the license applicant shall file with the local liquor control commissioner written proof of dram shop insurance covering the term of the license in that amount necessary to satisfy the maximum liability exposure set forth in 235 ILCS 5/6-21 of the Liquor Control Act, as amended or as may be amended from time to time. The certificate of insurance shall be issued from a dram shop insurance carrier licensed to do business in the State of Illinois. 
(Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93; Ord. No. 2010-3544,  2, 10-11-10) 
Sec. 3-25. - Renewal of license. 
    Each licensee, except class "P", wishing to renew a village liquor license shall do so upon expiration of the term stated in the license. At least fourteen (14) days prior to the expiration, the licensee shall file with the local liquor commissioner an application form in conformance with section 3-21. Upon renewal the licensee shall only answer those portions of the application for which the answers have changed from the last application. After a licensee has held a village liquor license for a continuous period of three (3) years, the licensee shall submit to a recheck of fingerprints. A fee of forty-four dollars ($44.00) per individual shall be paid for rechecking fingerprints. After a licensee has held a village liquor license for a continuous period of six (6) years, the licensee shall submit a re-application conforming with all requirements set forth in section 3-21, including a recheck of fingerprints. Upon re-application, the licensee shall pay a re-application fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00) plus one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each additional person listed on the application. This fee will include the cost of rechecking fingerprints. Prior to renewing a license the local liquor commissioner shall determine that the licensee remains qualified to receive a license and that the premises for which such renewal is sought are suitable for the purpose. Provided further that the renewal privilege herein provided shall not be construed as a vested right which shall in any case prevent the village board from decreasing the number of licenses to be issued within their jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93; Ord. No. 2009-3482,  1, 12-14-09) 
Sec. 3-26. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 2571-97,  1, adopted March 24, 1997, repealed  3-26 in its entirety. Formerly  3-26 pertained to lottery and derived from Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93. See the Code Comparative Table. 
Sec. 3-27. - Processing of application. 
    The local liquor commissioner shall approve or disapprove the application for any liquor license within twenty-one (21) calendar days of receipt of the results of the fingerprint check from the Illinois Department of Identification unless the local liquor commissioner determines that additional information is necessary to ascertain the character of the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93) 
Sec. 3-28. - Persons not entitled to license. 
    No license required by this chapter shall be issued to: 
(1)  A person who is not a resident of the village; 
(2)  A person who is not of good character and reputation; 
(3)  A person who is not a citizen of the United States; 
(4)  A person who has been convicted of a felony under any federal or state law unless it has been more than five (5) years since the individual's completion of probation or parole and the local liquor commissioner determines that such person has been sufficiently rehabilitated to warrant the public trust. The burden of proof of sufficient rehabilitation shall be upon the applicant; 
(5)  A person who has been convicted of being a keeper or is keeping a house of ill fame; 
(6)  A person who has been convicted of pandering or other crime or misdemeanor opposed to decency or morality; 
(7)  A person whose license under this Act has been revoked for cause; 
(8)  A person, who at the time of application for renewal of any license issued hereunder, would not be eligible for such license upon first application; 
(9)  A co-partnership, if any general partnership thereof, or any limited partnership thereof, owning more than five (5) percent of the aggregate limited partner interest in such co-partnership would not be eligible to receive a license hereunder for any reason other than residence within the political subdivision, unless residency is required by the local ordinance; 
(10)  A corporation, if any officer, manager or director thereof, or any stockholder or stockholders owning in the aggregate more than five (5) percent of the stock of such corporation, would not be eligible to receive a license hereunder for any reason other than citizenship and residence within the political subdivision; 
(11)  A corporation, unless it is incorporated in Illinois, or unless it is a foreign corporation which is qualified under the "Business Corporation Act" of 1983 to transact business in Illinois; 
(12)  A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent unless the manager or agent possesses the same qualifications required by the licensee; 
(13)  A person who has been convicted of a violation of any federal or state laws concerning the manufacture, possession or sale of alcoholic liquor, or has forfeited his bond to appear in court to answer charges for any such violation; 
(14)  A person who does not own or beneficially own the premises for which the license is sought, or does not have a lease thereon for the full period for which the license is to be issued; 
(15)  Any law enforcing public official, police officer, mayor or member of the village board, and no such official shall be interested directly in the manufacture, sale or distribution of alcoholic liquor; 
(16)  A person who is not the owner or a beneficial owner of the business to be operated by the licensee; 
(17)  A person who has been convicted of a gambling as prescribed by any of subsections (a)(3) through (a)(10) of section 28-1 of, or as prescribed by section 28-3 of, "Criminal Code of 1961," approved July 28, 1961, as heretofore or hereafter amended, or as prescribed by a statute replaced by any of the aforesaid statutory provisions; 
(18)  A person to whom a federal wagering stamp has been issued by the federal government for the current tax period; 
(19)  A co-partnership to which a federal wagering stamp has been issued by the federal government for the current tax period, or if any of the partners have been issued a federal gaming device a stamp or federal wagering stamp by the federal government for the current tax period; 
(20)  A corporation, if any officer, manager or director thereof, or any stockholder(s) owning in the aggregate more than twenty (20) percent of the stock of such corporation has been issued a federal wagering stamp for the current tax period; 
(21)  Any premises for which a federal wagering stamp has been issued by the federal government for the current tax period. 
(Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93) 
Sec. 3-29. - Personal nature of license; transferability. 
    A license shall be purely a personal privilege, good for not to exceed one (1) year after issuance, unless sooner revoked as is in this chapter provided, and shall not constitute property, nor shall it be subject to attachment, garnishment or execution, nor shall it be alienable or transferable, voluntarily or involuntarily, or subject to being encumbered or hypothecated. Such license shall cease upon the death of a licensee and shall not descend by laws of intestate or intestate devolution, provided that executors or administrators of the estate of any deceased licensee, and the trustee of any insolvent or bankrupt licensee, may exercise the privileges of the deceased, insolvent or bankrupt licensee after the death of such decedent, or such insolvency or bankruptcy until the expiration of such license but not longer than six (6) months after the death, bankruptcy or insolvency of such licensee. All license fees shall be nonrefundable. 
(Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93) 
Sec. 3-30. - Change of location. 
    A retail liquor dealer's license shall permit the sale of alcoholic liquor only on the premises described in the application and license. Such location may only be changed upon written permission to make such change issued by the local liquor commissioner. No change of location shall be permitted unless the proposed new location is a proper one for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor under the laws of this state and this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93) 
Sec. 3-31. - Restrictions of issuance. 
(a)  No license shall be issued for the sale at retail of any alcoholic liquor within one hundred (100) feet of any church, school, other than an institution of higher learning, hospital, home for the aged or indigent persons or for veterans, their spouses or children. This prohibition shall not apply to hotels offering restaurant service, regularly organized clubs, food shops or other places where the sale of alcoholic liquor is not the principle business carried on nor to the renewal of a license for a premises within one hundred (100) feet of any church or school where such church or school has been established within such one hundred (100) feet since the issuance of the original license. In the case of a church, the distance of one hundred (100) feet shall be measured to the nearest part of any building used for worship services or educational programs and not to property boundaries. 
(b)  Except in cases of hotels and clubs, no alcoholic liquor shall be sold at retail upon any premises which has any access which leads from such premises to any other portion of the same building or structure used for, dwelling or lodging purposes and which is permitted to be used or kept accessible for use by the public. This provision shall not prevent any connection between premises and such other portion of the building or structure which is used by the licensee, his family and personal guests. 
(c)  Nothing in this section shall prohibit, the issuance of a class "N" license to any church or private school to sell at retail alcoholic liquor such sales are limited to periods when groups are assembled on the premises solely for the promotion of some common object other than the sale or consumption of alcoholic liquors. 
(Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93) 
Sec. 3-32. - Classification of licenses. 
    Licenses shall be and are hereby divided into the following classes: 
(1)  Class "A" licenses shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquors by businesses whose primary business is the sale of alcoholic liquor, but not for consumption on the premises. 
(2)  Class "B" licenses shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquors by grocery stores or drug stores having a minimum retail floor space of 8,000 square feet. No more than a maximum of fifteen (15) percent of the licensee's retail floor space shall be allocated to the sale of alcoholic liquors. 
(3)  Class "C" licenses shall authorize the retail sale by grocery stores of beer in cans or bottles or other sealed containers, and/or wine, but not for consumption on the premises where sold. 
(4)  Class "D" licenses shall authorize the retail sale, on the premises specified in the license of beer and wine in its original package only in gas stations containing convenience stores of no less than one thousand six hundred (1,600) square feet subject to the following conditions and restrictions: 
a.  The one thousand six hundred (1,600) square feet shall be measured as the above grade square footage of the convenience store portion of the gas station contained entirely within a single structure on the gas station premises. 
b.  The portion of a class "D" licensed premises allocated for "package sales" shall be no more than twenty-five (25) percent of the total square footage of the convenience store and be segregated from the remaining portion of the convenience store as approved by the liquor commissioner by means of walls, shelving, and temporary barriers. The temporary barriers shall be used only at ingress/egress points to the segregated area. Only beer and wine, and items ancillary to alcoholic beverages, such as: corkscrews, pre-packaged alcoholic mixers, etc. shall be sold or marketed from the area segregated for the sale of beer and wine. The area segregated for the sale of beer and wine shall be closed to the public by means of the shelving, walls, refrigeration units and temporary barriers except during hours where the sale of beer and wine is permitted under the village code. The licensee shall prohibit anyone from entering the segregated area during hours in which the sale of beer and wine is prohibited except for purposes of restocking and then only by employees. 
c.  Each transaction for the sale of beer and wine shall be with point of sale equipment that shall scan the identification of the customer to verify the customer's age. 
d.  Beer shall not be sold in quantities of less than four (4) cans or bottles to any customer. 
e.  The sale of wine in individual serving bottles of less than 750 ml or less than one-half (11/2) pint, is prohibited. 
(5)  Class "E" licenses shall permit the retail sale and wholesale of wine and/or beer for consumption both on and off the premises specified. 
(6)  Class "F" licenses shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises in restaurants devoted to the regular service of the meals containing a bar and which has a minimum of thirty-six (36) seats available to patrons excluding seats at the bar. 
(7)  Class G License shall authorize the retail sale of beer in cans or bottles or other sealed containers, and/or wine in sealed containers, not for consumption on premises, by restaurants holding a Class "F" or Class "I" liquor license and subject to the following conditions: 
a.  All orders shall be placed and picked up at the "Take-out" or "Carry-out" location approved by the liquor commissioner in writing; 
b.  Delivery orders of beer and or wine by a licensee, or any delivery service of any type whatsoever, are prohibited; 
c.  Any employee serving and delivering beer or wine in the approved take-out/carry-out location shall be twenty-one (21) years of age or older as well as BASSET trained and certified; 
d.  The person picking up an order that contains packaged beer or wine shall be over the age of twenty-one (21) years old; 
(8)  Class 'H' License: shall authorize the retail sale of wine and specialty premium beers only on the premises specified on the license, subject to the following conditions: 
a.  At least ten (10%) percent of the retail space shall be devoted to the sale of quality boutique type food items and gifts; 
b.  Quality boutique type specialty food items and/or appetizers shall be available for patrons during business hours when the wine and specialty beers are offered; 
c.  Wine and specialty premium beer tasting shall be permitted on the premises; 
d.  No such license shall be granted to or retained by any establishment whose primary business is that of a convenience store; 
e.  The premises shall have seating for a minimum of twenty-four (24) patrons. 
(9)  Class "I" licenses shall permit the retail sale of alcoholic liquors for consumption only on the premises in restaurants having seating for no less than thirty-six (36) patrons and only from the kitchen or a service counter as defined herein. 
(10)  Class "J" licenses shall permit the retail sale in restaurants having seating for no less than thirty (30) patrons of draft beer, bottled beer, and/or wine for consumption only on the premises specified and only from the kitchen or a service counter as defined herein. 
(11)  Class "K" licenses shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquors for consumption only on the premises specified, being a "club" as defined herein. 
(12)  Class "L" licenses shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquor, for consumption on the specified premises, as an adjunct to a principal spa and salon business. The issuance of a class L license shall be expressly subject to the following conditions: 
a.  The retail sale of alcoholic liquor shall be limited to one drink per hour per customer or patron of the premises, and no such customer or patron shall be served more than three (3) alcoholic beverages during the permitted hours of retail sale of alcoholic liquor during any one calendar day. 
b.  Customers and patrons shall not be served alcoholic beverages unless receiving contemporaneous spa/salon services from the license holder. 
c.  No live entertainment of any nature shall be permitted on the specified premises. 
d.  No window or any other external signage shall be permitted on the specified premises or surrounding property that indicates that alcoholic liquor is available for retail sale at the specified premises, provided, however, that the business identification signage may contain the word "bar", and provided further that the word "bar" is only used as part of the business name. 
e.  No person holding a class L license issued pursuant to this chapter shall sell or permit to be sold, offer for sale, give away, or deliver any alcoholic liquor except between the hours of 11:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. Monday through Saturday or between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. on Saturdays to only bridal parties receiving salon and spa services. 
(13)  Class "M" licenses shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquors for consumption only, on the premises specified, at one (1) or more locations within the premises of any motel, hotel, recreational or resort facility, as provided in the village zoning ordinance, and which shall also include bowling alleys. 
(14)  Class "N" licenses shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquors for consumption on the premises only by banquet halls where the principal purpose of the business is to serve food in connections with weddings, parties, social functions, political gatherings or business meetings. A class "N" license shall permit the retail sale of alcoholic liquors at more than one location on the same premises under the control of one (1) ownership. 
(15)  Class "O" licenses shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic beverages by a caterer providing alcoholic beverages only in conjunction with food services. All class "O" license holders shall notify the chief or designate of the Roselle Police Department at least fourteen (14) calendar days prior to a catered event in which alcoholic beverages will be provided within the village. Lesser notification may be approved by the chief of the village police department if he finds that the license holder's failure to notify was due to no fault or delay on the part of the license holder. The class "O" license shall be valid only within the municipal boundaries of the village and any alcoholic beverages being transported by the class "O" license holder shall be contained entirely within a sealed container. A vehicle shall not be considered a sealed container. No class "O" license shall serve alcoholic liquor at a single location for more than three (3) consecutive twenty-four-hour periods and no class "O" licensee shall serve liquor at the same location more than four (4) times per year. A class "O" licensee may transport alcohol in a motor vehicle which has previously been opened provided that such alcoholic liquor is contained in a sealed and opaque box, carton, or other similar container. The holder of a valid caterers liquor license of another municipality may cater alcoholic beverages within the village provided that the issuing municipality grants reciprocal privileges to a licensed Roselle caterer. 
(16)  Class "P" license shall authorize the sale of draft or bottled beer and wine by a not for profit club or corporation for a temporary period of time not to exceed more than fourteen (14) days in any calendar year. 
(17)  Class "Q" licenses shall authorize the sale of alcoholic liquor by a "for profit" individual, partnership or corporation applicant already holding another valid village liquor license for a temporary event not to exceed (7) days within any calendar year. The seven-day period may be extended in sole discretion of the liquor commissioner upon good cause shown by the applicant for the class "Q". Due to the unique temporary event character of the "class "Q" license" the liquor commissioner may enter an order suspending operation of the "class "Q" license" pending a liquor code violation hearing or where the liquor commissioner deems such suspension necessary to protect the public health, safety and welfare based on needs for event traffic control or other police services not anticipated at the time of the issuance of the license. The liquor commissioner may also impose operational conditions related to event traffic control or police services at the time of or subsequent to the issuance of a class Q license as may be consistent with the public health safety and welfare. 
(18)  Class "R" licenses shall authorize patrons to bring their own beer and wine to a BYO licensee's premises for consumption on the premises. The BYO licensee may charge a corking and glass fee for patrons who do not bring their own openers and/or glasses. 
(19)  Class "S" license shall authorize the sale of wine by bona fide cooking schools to enrolled cooking school students. The wine sold to the enrolled cooking students may be sold on the premises as part of the cooking classes or as no more than twelve (12) bottles per enrolled student, per class taken, for carry out so long as the wine sold has been used in conjunction with the enrolled students cooking class. The bona fide cooking school shall create and maintain class rosters for each cooking class identifying the number of carry out bottles sold to each enrolled student. These rosters shall be maintained by the cooking school for a period of three (3) years after the completion of each cooking class and shall be available for audit by the liquor commissioner upon request. For purposes of this section, a bona fide cooking school shall be defined as: a for-profit business offering classes in the culinary arts to students who pay a fee to take such classes from instructors who have received formal training in the culinary arts. 
(20)  Class "T" licenses shall authorize the holder of a Class "F", Class "I", Class "K", or Class "M" Liquor License, and which also possesses a valid video gaming license issued by the Illinois Gaming Board to sell alcoholic liquor for consumption only on the premises where video gaming devices are located strictly subject to the following conditions: 
a.  Class "T" licensees shall not be issued to a fast food restaurant. For purposes of this article a fast food restaurant is defined as a restaurant where patrons order food at a counter or other location and not from a waiter or waitress at the table from which the food is to be consumed, and where the food is not delivered to the customer at the customer's table. All food ordered by patrons of a Class "T" licensee shall be delivered, by the Class "T" licensee's wait staff, to the table where the food will be consumed; and 
b.  All Class "T" license applicants shall submit the information required by the Liquor Control Commissioner in a Class "T" application form; and 
c.  The corporate authorities of the Village shall have approved sufficient Class "T" licenses to allow the applicant to apply for a Class "T" license; and 
d.  Class "T" license holders shall be in good standing under the Liquor Control Ordinance and other ordinances of the Village for no less than one (1) year prior to its application for a Class "T" license. To be "in good standing" the licensee shall: 
(i)  owe no sums of money to the village at the time of its application; 
(ii)  have held a Village of Roselle consumption on the premises liquor license; 
(iii)  been in continuous bona fide operation under that license for no less than twelve (12) months at the time of its application for the Class "T" license; 
(iv)  have had no legal violations causing a suspension of its liquor or business license in the twelve (12) months prior to its application for a Class "T" license 
(v)  be in compliance with all dram shop and video gaming laws, rules and regulations of the Village of Roselle and the State of Illinois; and 
e.  The applicant shall not have allowed use of any video gaming device or other gambling on the license holder's premise until the Class "T" license has been issued; and 
f.  The Class "T" license holder shall maintain video surveillance of the video gaming devices in conformance with surveillance regulations established by the Roselle Liquor Commissioner; and 
g.  The Class "T" license holder shall openly and clearly display a valid Village Video Gaming Device sticker on each of its gaming devices on the licensed premises. No video gaming device shall be located, maintained or operated on the licensed premises without first obtaining a valid video gaming device sticker; and 
h.  A holder of a Class "J" License in effect prior to the effective date of this amendment shall be entitled to apply for a Class T license subject to all the other terms and conditions for a Class T License and the Roselle Liquor Control Ordinance. No other Class J licensees shall be eligible for a Class T License. 
(Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93; Ord. No. 2571-97,  2, 3-24-97; Ord. No. 99-2731,  1, 12-6-99; Ord. No. 2001-2882,  1, 11-12-01; Ord. No. 2005-3148,  2, 1-24-05; Ord. No. 2005-3191,  1, 8-22-05; Ord. No. 2018-3987,  1, 11-12-18) 
Sec. 3-34. - Terms and fees. 
(a)  All liquor licenses shall terminate on April 30 following the date of issuance when the full annual fee is paid. Full annual fees shall be paid for any license issued after May 1 but before June 1. The fee for any license issued on or after June 1 shall be prorated at the rate of one-twelfth ( 1/12 ) of the amount of the full annual fee for each month or portion thereof remaining to the next April 30. Fees may be paid in two (2) identical semiannual installments equal to fifty (50) percent of the full annual fee plus a ten (10) percent convenience/processing fee. Licenses paid in two (2) semiannual installments shall expire October 31 with respect to the first installment and may be reissued to expire April 30 upon payment of the second installment. All license fees shall be nonrefundable. 
(b)  The fees for the various classes of licenses shall be as follows: 
Class Annual Fee "A" $1,500.00 "B" $1,500.00 "C" $1,250.00 "D" $3,750.00 "E" $1,500.00 "F" $3,700.00 "G" $500.00 "H" $1,500.00 "I" $2,525.00 "J" $1,500.00 "K" $275.00 "L" $1,250.00 "M" $2,625.00 + $1,000.00 for each bar "N" $3,750.00 "O" $375.00 "P" $25.00 per day, per event "Q" $25.00 per day "R" $250.00 "S" $187.50 "T" $500.00 + $25.00 per year per video gaming device.  
(c)  There shall be no refund of the license fee for any portion of a year during which the licensee ceases to engage in the business of selling alcoholic liquor. 
(d)  No licensee shall continue to engage in the business of selling alcoholic liquor until the fees described herein have been paid. 
(Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93; Ord. No. 2571-97,  4, 3-24-97; Ord. No. 99-2731,  3, 12-6-99; Ord. No. 2001-2882,  1, 11-12-01; Ord. No. 2005-3148,  3, 1-24-05; Ord. No. 2007-3337,  2, 10-8-07; Ord. No. 2010-3544,  4, 10-11-10; Ord. No. 2011-3592,  2, 9-12-11; Ord. No. 2013-3693,  2, 8-12-13; Ord. No. 2014-3721,  2, 3-10-14; Ord. No. 2015-3799,  1, 9-14-15; Ord. No. 2016-3832,  9, 3-14-16; Ord. No. 2017-3902,  2, 4-24-17) 
Sec. 3-35. - Change in personnel. 
(a)  The occurrence of any one (1) or more of the following events shall be deemed to constitute a change in the identity of the holder of a license issued under this chapter for which a new license shall be required: 
(1)  With respect to any licensee that is a corporation, the replacement or addition of any officer, of the corporation, or any shareholder owning directly or indirectly (including ownership by members of the same household) five (5) percent or more of the outstanding shares of any class of the capital stock of said corporation; 
(2)  With respect to any licensee that is a general partnership, the replacement or addition of any general partner; 
(3)  With respect to any licensee that is a limited partnership the replacement or addition of any general partner or of any limited partner holding directly or indirectly (including ownership by members of the same household) more than five (5) percent interest in the earnings of said limited partnership. 
(b)  No later than seven (7) calendar days after the occurrence of an event described in subsection 3-35(a) a licensee shall give the local liquor commissioner written notice describing the event in reasonable detail and submit a new application in conformance with section 3-22 of this chapter. A processing fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be paid upon submission of the new application. So long as the application is pending and not acted upon by the local liquor commissioner, the licensee may continue to conduct its business and operations under the license in effect immediately prior to such occurrence. Failure to give the notice required by this subsection (b) shall constitute a violation subjecting the licensee's license to revocation, suspension or fine. 
(Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93; Ord. No. 2010-3544,  5, 10-11-10) 
Sec. 3-36. - Notification and application for new managers. 
(a)  A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager(s), and who acquires, hires, transfers in, promotes or appoints new manager(s), not listed as a manager(s) in the original application for a retail liquor license, shall, within seven (7) calendar days, of the date the new manger(s) commences his/her duties, submit a "new manager's application" to the local liquor commissioner which shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The new manager's full name, birth date, current address, telephone number, driver's license number, and social security number; 
(2)  The new manager's citizenship as well as the place of birth and the date and a place of naturalization if applicable; 
(3)  The new manager shall state in the application whether he/she has ever sold, delivered, or given away any alcoholic liquor in violation of any statute, state law, or any ordinance, to a person under the minimum age required to purchase or possess liquor; 
(4)  The new manager shall affirm by his signature that he/she has never been convicted of a felony and would not be disqualified to receive a liquor license by reason of any manner or thing contained in the laws of the State of Illinois provisions of this chapter; 
(5)  Arrange for fingerprinting at the Roselle Police Department; and 
(6)  A fee of $100.00 shall be paid to the village clerk. 
(b)  The applicant may continue to conduct its business under the license in effect prior to retaining such new manager until such time as the local liquor commissioner approves or disapproves of the manager. If the local liquor commissioner disapproves of the manager the licensee shall terminate the new manager's duties with respect to the sale of alcohol. If the licensee is able to provide for the continued management of licensed premises by any person previously qualified to manage the licensed premises, by reason of a prior application, the licensee may continue to sell alcoholic liquor. 
(Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93; Ord. No. 2009-3482,  1, 12-14-09) 
Sec. 3-37. - Closing hours. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale or resale at retail in the village any alcoholic liquor between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on any day except Saturday, Sunday or a federally designated legal holiday when the closing hour for retail liquor sales shall be no later than 2:00 a.m. and except for New Year's Day when the latest closing hour for retail liquor sales shall be 3:00 a.m. No alcoholic liquor shall be delivered, distributed or given away without charge by any holder of any retail liquor license after closing hours as designated herein. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to keep open for business or to admit the public to any premises in or on which all the liquor is sold at retail during the hours within which the sale of liquor is prohibited; provided that in the case of restaurants, hotels and clubs, such establishments may be kept open during such hours, but no alcoholic liquor shall be sold or consumed by the public during such hours; provided, further, that in the case of grocery stores or automotive service stations (gas stations) such stores may be kept open during such hours, but no alcoholic liquor shall be sold to the public during such hours, and the inventory of alcoholic beverages shall be stored or segregated in such a manner within the grocery store or automotive service station (gas station) that such inventory of alcoholic beverages is inaccessible to the public. The manner of such storage or closing shall be approved by the local liquor commissioner. 
(c)  For purposes of this section, it shall be considered a violation if any glass or other vessel containing alcoholic liquor shall be present, on any bar or table where patrons are served, or at any premises licensed under this chapter, at any time during the closing hours specified herein when no alcoholic liquor may be sold, given away, offered for sale or consumed, in, upon or about any such premises. 
(Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93; Ord. No. 2571,  5, 3-24-97; Ord. No. 99-2731,  4, 12-6-99; Ord. No. 2008-3395,  1, 6-9-08) 
Sec. 3-38. - Wine/beer sampling. 
    The holder of a valid class A or B liquor license may offer for consumption on the licensed premises, wine or premium beer samplings, not exceeding one (1) ounce per sampling container and no more than four (4) sampling containers per patron during any business day, for purposes of marketing the sale of wine or premium beers for off premise consumption. Sampling shall be conducted within or immediately adjacent to an area containing wine and/or beer for retail sale and shall be no closer than fifteen (15) feet from the closest interior edge of any check out lane. A person, otherwise qualified under this section, to deliver wine and beer shall be present and deliver all samples to potential customers. All wine or premium beer samplings provided pursuant to this section shall otherwise conform with all other terms and conditions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2007-3304,  1, 5-14-07) 
Secs. 3-39-3-44. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RESTRICTIONS AND REQUIREMENTS FOR CONDUCT ON THE LICENSE PREMISES 

Sec. 3-45. - Display of license. 
    Any license issued under this chapter shall be displayed by the licensee at all times in a conspicuous place where it is readily visible to an inspecting officer. 
(Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93) 
Sec. 3-46. - Responsibility for agents and employees. 
    Every act or omission of whatsoever nature, constituting a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter by an officer, director, manager or other agent or employee of any licensee, if such act is committed or omission is made within the scope of such agency or employment with or without authorization, knowledge or approval of the licensee, shall be deemed and held to be the act of the employer or licensee and such employer and licensee shall be punishable in the same manner as if the act or omission had been personally done or omitted. 
(Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93) 
Sec. 3-47. - Sanitation. 
    All premises used for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor, or for the storage of such liquor for sale, shall be kept in full compliance with the ordinances regulating the condition of premises used for the storage or sale of food for human consumption. 
(Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93) 
Sec. 3-48. - Diseased employees. 
    It shall be unlawful to employ in any premises used for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor any person who is afflicted with or a carrier of any contagious, infectious or venereal disease and it shall be unlawful for any person who is afflicted with or is a carrier of any such disease to work in or about any premises or to be engaged in any way in the handling, preparation or distribution of such alcoholic liquor. 
(Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93) 
Sec. 3-49. - Prohibited activities on licensed premises. 
(a)  Gambling. It shall be unlawful to permit any gambling or gaming on any premises licensed to sell alcohol except where such gambling or gaming is licensed and conducted in conformance with 20 ILCS 1605/3 et seq. "Illinois Lottery Law", 230 ILCS 20/1 et seq. "Illinois Pull Tabs and Jar Games Act", 230 ILCS 25/1 et seq., "Bingo License and Tax Act", 230 ILCS 30/1 et seq., "Charitable Games Act" and 230 ILCS 40/1 et seq., "Illinois Video Gaming Act", and Roselle Liquor Control Ordinance. 
(b)  Solicitation. It shall be unlawful for any licensee, its manager, or any other person in charge of any license premises where alcoholic liquor is sold or offered for sale or consumption thereon to engage, employ, or permit the engagement or employment of any person who shall solicit any patron or customer thereof to purchase alcoholic or nonalcoholic liquor for said person, or any other person therein; nor shall any person solicit any patron or customer therein to purchase alcoholic or nonalcoholic liquor for himself, herself or any other person therein; provided, however, that nothing herein contained shall prohibit any adult manager, bartender, or waitress who shall be regularly employed therein from accepting and serving the order of a patron or customer in the regular course of employment such as a manager, bartender or waitress. 
(c)  Sexually explicit conduct. It shall be unlawful for licensee, its manager, or other person in charge of a licensed premises to sell or to permit the following conduct, books, magazines, coin operated motion picture devices, films, video tapes, or movies depicting, describing, or relating to the following kinds of conduct on such premises: 
(1)  The performance of acts or simulated acts of sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation, or any sexual acts which are prohibited by the law; 
(2)  The actual or simulated touching, caressing or fondling of the breasts, buttocks, anus, or genitals; 
(3)  The actual or simulated display of breasts, pubic hair, anus, vulva or genitals. 
(Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93; Ord. No. 2583-97,  1, 8-28-97; Ord. No. 2013-3693,  3, 8-12-13) 
Sec. 3-50. - Sales to persons under twenty-one and certain other persons prohibited; minors prohibited in establishments. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years to purchase or obtain any alcoholic liquor in any place in the village where alcoholic liquor is sold. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years to consume, purchase, or accept delivery of alcoholic liquor or have alcoholic liquor in his or her possession within the village; provided that the possession and dispensing, or consumption by a person under the age of twenty-one (21) years of alcoholic liquor in the performance of a religious service or ceremony, or the consumption by a person under the age of twenty-one (21) years under the direct supervision and approval of the parents or guardians of such underaged person in the privacy of the parents' or guardians' home is not prohibited. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years to misrepresent his or her age for the purpose of purchasing or obtaining alcoholic liquor in any place in the village where alcoholic liquor is sold. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful to transfer, alter, or deface any identification card; use the identification card of another; carry or use false or forged identification card; or obtain an identification card by means of false information for the purpose of purchasing or attempting to purchase or possess alcoholic liquor by any person under twenty-one (21) years of age. 
(e)  In every licensed premises in the village where alcoholic liquor is sold there shall be displayed at all times in a prominent place a printed card which shall be supplied by the village clerk and which shall read substantially as follows: 
"WARNING TO MINORS 
You are subject to a fine up to FIVE HUNDRED DOLLARS ($500.00) under the ordinances of the Village of Roselle if you purchase alcoholic liquor or misrepresent your age for the purpose of purchasing or obtaining alcoholic liquor." 
(f)  No licensee nor officer, associate, representative, agent or employee of a licensed premise shall sell, give, allow the consumption of, or deliver alcoholic liquor to any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years or to any intoxicated person or to any person known by him to be a habitual drunkard, spendthrift, insane, mentally ill, mentally deficient or in need of mental treatment. No person, after purchasing or otherwise obtaining alcoholic liquor from a licensee or opening alcoholic liquor in a BYO establishment, shall sell, deliver, or allow delivery of such alcoholic liquor to a person under the age of twenty-one (21) years except for small quantities of less than one (1) ounce in the performance of a religious ceremony or service. 
(g)  It shall be unlawful for the holder of any Class "A", "E", or "F" license to allow or permit any minors to remain on the licensed premises provided that this subsection shall not apply to a minor who is accompanied by his/her parent or guardian or to any licensed premises which delivers its principle business for the sales or service of other commodities than alcohol. Minors under no circumstances shall be permitted to sit at a bar. 
(h)  It shall be unlawful for any parent or guardian to permit any minor child of which he or she may be parent or guardian to violate any provision of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93; Ord. No. 2016-3832,  10, 3-14-16) 
Sec. 3-51. - Enforcement of underage sales. 
(a)  If a licensee, its agents or employees believes or has reason to believe that a sale, delivery, or allowing consumption on a BYO premises of any alcoholic liquor is prohibited because patron is under age, he shall demand presentation of some form of positive identification containing proof of age issued by federal, state, county or municipal government or subdivision or agency thereof. If the licensee determines that a patron is under age it shall not serve or allow the consumption of alcoholic beverages by the minor on its premises. If the minor is intoxicated in the opinion of the licensee it shall contact local law enforcement. 
(b)  For the purpose of preventing the violation of section 3-47, any licensee, or his agent or employee, may refuse to sell or serve alcoholic beverages to any person who is unable to produce adequate written evidence of identity and of the fact that he or she is over the age of twenty-one (21) years. 
(c)  Adequate written evidence of age and identity of the person is a document issued by a federal, state, county, or municipal government, or subdivision or agency thereof, including, but not limited to, a motor vehicle operator's license, a registration certificate issued under the Federal Selective Service Act, or an identification card issued to a member of the armed forces. Proof that the defendant-licensee, or his employee or agent, demanded, was shown and reasonably relied upon such written evidence in any transaction, forbidden by this section is competent evidence and may be considered in any criminal prosecution therefor or to any proceedings for the suspension or revocation of any license based thereon. 
(Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93; Ord. No. 2016-3832,  11, 3-14-16) 
Sec. 3-52. - Employing persons under age eighteen. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person under twenty-one (21) years of age to pour, mix, or serve alcoholic beverages with or without compensation, on the premises of any liquor licensee licensed by the village for consumption on the premises. Furthermore, it shall be unlawful for any person under eighteen (18) years of age, employed by not for consumption on the premises licensee, to sell, distribute, or deliver any alcoholic liquor, with or without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93) 
Sec. 3-53. - Drinking alcohol in a public place. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or drink alcoholic liquor in or on any street, alley or other public place in the village except at public places in conjunction with service by the holder of a valid class "P" or "Q" license at a special event as defined herein or on a public sidewalk or right-of-way in conjunction with a sidewalk seating permit issued by the village and the local liquor commissioner in conformance with chapter 9, article XI, "sidewalk seating permits" of the Code of Ordinances of the Village of Roselle. 
(Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93; Ord. No. 2007-3309,  1, 6-11-07) 
Sec. 3-54. - Transportation of possession of alcoholic beverages. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to transport, carry, or possess, or have any alcoholic liquor upon his person on any street, alley, public place or within any motor vehicle within the village except in an unopened original package or container or except in a public place when such is authorized in conjunction with a class "P" or "Q" license. 
(Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93) 
Sec. 3-55. - "Drinks," certain sales. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any licensee, their employee, or agent, on licensed premises where alcoholic liquor is sold or offered for sale for consumption thereon, to engage in any of the following conduct: 
(1)  Deliver more than two (2) drinks to any individual at one time for that individual's consumption; 
(2)  Deliver to any person or group of persons any unlimited number of drinks during any period of time for a fixed price, except at private banquets not open to the public; 
(3)  Deliver drinks to any person or group of persons on any day at prices less than those charged the general public on that entire day, except at private banquets not open to the public; 
(4)  Increase the volume of alcoholic liquor contained in a drink without a proportionate increase in the price charged for such drink as compared to the prices charged during the same calendar week. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, drink shall be defined as any object containing alcoholic liquor including but not limited to glasses, cans, mugs, bottles, pitchers, or carafes. 
(Ord. No. 2303-93,  1, 3-8-93; Ord. No. 2016-3832,  12, 3-14-16) 
Sec. 3-56. - Sale, possession, and transfer of powdered alcohol prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any licensee or person, to sell, offer for sale, transfer, possess, receive, or purchase for resale in the Village of Roselle any product consisting of, or containing powdered alcohol. 
(Ord. No. 2016-3844,  2, 5-23-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2016-3844,  2, adopted May 23, 2016, amended  3-56 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former  3-56, pertained to sale of containers containing less than one-half point prohibited and derived from Ord. No. 2392-94,  1, 5-9-94; Ord. No. 2411-94,  1, adopted 6-27-94. 
Sec. 3-57. - All village licenses to be current. 
    It shall be unlawful for any licensee to sell or offer for sale any alcoholic liquor unless the licensee possess all licenses required under the Code of Ordinances for the Village of Roselle. 
(Ord. No. 2003-2987,  1, 3-24-03) 
Sec. 3-58. - Other prohibited conduct. 
    It shall be unlawful for any licensee, its employee, or agent, at, upon or within a licensed premises, during business hours, to violate any: Penal ordinance of the Village of Roselle; provision of the Illinois State Criminal Code of 1961 (720 ILCS 5/1-1 et. seq.,) as may be amended from time to time; or any federal statute or law prohibiting criminal conduct. 
(Ord. No. 2009-3473,  1, 9-28-09) 
Sec. 3-59. - Reserved. 
Sec. 3-60. - Violation of the Illinois Video Gaming Act. 
    It shall be unlawful for any license holder, its employee or agent, at or upon a class "T" licensed premise, to violate any penal ordinance of the Village of Roselle; any provision of the Illinois State Criminal Code 720 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.; or any provision of the Illinois Video Gaming Act or rules, regulations, or restrictions imposed by the Illinois Gaming Board. upon a finding of a violation of any of the foregoing by a class "T" licensee the liquor commissioner shall have the authority to impose any penalty authorized by this code including the imposition of a fine and/or to suspend or revoke the class "T" license and/or suspend or revoke the underlying consumption on the premises license. 
(Ord. No. 2013-3693,  4, 8-12-13) 
Chapter 4 - ANIMALS AND FOWL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- License fee for animal hospitals,  9-16(1); license fee for kennels and pet shops,  9-16(42); licensing and regulation of kennels and pet shops,  9-462 et seq.; noisy animals or birds,  11-2(5); animal fighting,  13-7; trespass by animals,  13-42; unlawful to injure a domestic animal, ㎣ 13-43(4), 13-44(4); killing animals,  13-90. 
State Law reference- Animal regulations generally, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 8. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4-1. - Cruelty. 
    No person shall cruelly treat any animal in the village in any way; any person who inhumanely beats, underfeeds, overloads, or abandons any animal shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this section. 
(Code 1956,  501) 
State Law reference- Authority to prohibit cruelty, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  11-5-6. 
Sec. 4-2. - Killing dangerous animals. 
    The members of the police department or any other person in the village, are authorized to kill any dangerous animal of any kind when it is necessary for the protection of any person or property. 
(Code 1956,  505) 
Sec. 4-3. - Dangerous animals at large; parades thereof. 
    It shall be unlawful to permit any dangerous animal of any kind to run at large within the village; exhibitions or parades of animals which are ferae naturae in the eyes of the law may be conducted only upon securing a permit from the board of trustees. 
(Code 1956,  502) 
Cross reference- Circus parades,  9-66 et seq. 
Sec. 4-4. - Livestock, poultry at large. 
    It shall be unlawful to permit any cattle, horse, ass, mule, swine, sheep, goat, geese or other poultry to run at large in the village; any such animal running at large in any public place in the village shall be impounded in the manner provided for dogs. It shall be further unlawful to picket or tie any such animal in any of the streets of the village for the purpose of grazing or feeding. 
(Code 1956,  504) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate animals at large, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  11-20-9. 
Sec. 4-5. - Unattended animals. 
    It shall be unlawful to leave any horse or other draft animal unattended in any street without having such animal securely fastened. 
(Ord. No. 60-58,  3.26, 6-4-59) 
Sec. 4-6. - Diseased animals. 
(a)  No domestic animal afflicted with a contagious or infectious disease shall be allowed to run at large, or to be exposed in any public place whereby the health of man or beast may be affected; nor shall such diseased animal be shipped or removed from the premises of the owner thereof, except under the supervision of the health officer. 
(b)  It is hereby made the duty of the health officer to secure such disposition of any diseased animal and such treatment of affected premises as to prevent the communication and spread of contagion or infection, except in cases where the state veterinarian is empowered to act. 
(Code 1956,  506) 
Sec. 4-7. - Livestock, poultry prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful and a nuisance for any person to keep or raise any cattle, hogs, sheep, horses, chickens, geese or other poultry or livestock within the corporate limits of the village except that a person may keep or raise no more than five (5) nonhoming pigeons provided that such pigeons are caged. 
(Ord. No. 2280-93,  1, 1-25-93) 
Sec. 4-8. - Cleanliness of places where kept. 
    No person shall cause or allow any stable or place where any animal is or may be kept to become unclean or unwholesome. 
(Code 1956,  507) 
Sec. 4-9. - Beekeeping prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to keep or harbor bees in the village. 
(Code 1956,  508) 
Sec. 4-10. - Hatcheries prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate, maintain or establish any chicken hatchery any place in the village. 
(Code 1956,  602) 
Secs. 4-11-4-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DOGS 

Secs. 4-21-4-24. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2005-3207,  1, adopted December 12, 2005, repealed ㎣ 4-21-4-24, in their entirety. Formerly, said sections pertained to license required; tax; vaccination prerequisite to license; tag required; collar required; wearing of tag and derived from Code 1956,  510; Ord. No. 56-1-A,  15, 4-23-56; Ord. No. 60-67, 9-26-60; Ord. No. 921-80,  1, 3-10-80; Ord. No. 2002-2903,  1, 2-25-02. 
Sec. 4-25. - Running at large defined, prohibited. 
    No dog shall run at large within the village. Running at large shall be deemed to mean any dog which is not on the animal owner's property. It shall be the duty of the dog owner to make certain that his/her dog is not a dog running at large. Any dog owner whose dog is running at large, whether such dog owner has or does not have knowledge of the dog running at large, shall be guilty of a petty offense. 
(Ord. No. 2263,  1, 12-14-92) 
State Law reference- Authority to prohibit animals at large, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  11-20-9. 
Sec. 4-26. - Impounding. 
    Each and every dog, or other domestic animal, impounded by the police or any other animal control officer in accordance with the provisions of chapter 4, "animals and fowl", of the Code of Ordinances of the Village of Roselle shall be subject to the terms and conditions of this section. The Roselle Police Department, upon impounding any animal shall notify the owner of such animal that it may be redeemed within seven (7) days of the notice by paying all license or other fees due the village, together with all the village's out of pocket costs for the impounding of such animal. Any animal not redeemed within seven (7) days of notice under this section may be euthanized. If an impounded animal is not redeemed, the owner of the animal shall reimburse the village for all out of pocket costs incurred for the impounding and euthanizing the animal. Payment of fees and costs under this section shall not absolve an owner or person in control of an animal for the payment of fines and costs for the violation of any other section of this chapter. 
(Code 1956,  511; Ord. No. 2010-3536,  1, 9-27-10) 
Sec. 4-27. - Killing vicious dogs. 
    It shall be lawful for the chief of police or other police officer to kill any vicious dog at large within the limits of the village which cannot safely be taken up and impounded. 
(Code 1956,  511) 
Sec. 4-28. - Biting dogs. 
    Whenever any dog bites a person, the owner of said dog shall immediately notify the village health officer who shall order the dog held on the owner's premises or shall have it impounded for a period of two (2) weeks. The dog shall be examined immediately after it has bitten anyone and again at the end of the two-week period. If at the end of two (2) weeks a veterinarian is convinced that the dog is then free from rabies the dog shall be released from quarantine or from the pound as the case may be. If the dog dies in the meanwhile its head shall be sent to the state department of health for examination for rabies. 
(Code 1956,  513) 
Sec. 4-29. - Dogs at public events. 
    No person shall bring to, or keep or maintain, any dog at any public event of the village including but not limited to the Lions Carnival, the Rose Parade, Fourth of July Festivities and the Taste of Roselle. This provision shall not prohibit the presence of dogs assisting the handicapped or any dog being used by law enforcement or public safety officials within the course of their official duties. 
(Ord. No. 2127-91,  1, 10-14-91; Ord. No. 2162-92,  1, 4-13-92)
