Sec. 6-26. - Basic building codes. 
    The following codes are hereby adopted as the building codes of the Village of Roselle, as if fully set forth in this article with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes prescribed in section 6-27 of this article. 
(1)  International Building Code for Commercial and Industrial. All construction other than one-family and two-family dwellings shall be regulated by the International Building Code," 2006 Edition as amended, including each and all of its regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions, advisory notes and applicable appendices except as amended by section 6-27 of this article. 
(2)  2006 International Residential Code. All construction of one-family and two-family dwellings, and their accessory structures, shall be regulated by the "2006 International Residential Code, including each and all of its regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions, advisory notes and applicable appendices, except as amended by section 6-27 of this article.

Chapter 1, Administration 
Section 101. Title: Insert, These regulations shall be known as the Building Code of the Village of Roselle, hereinafter referred to as "this Code." 
Section 101.4.1: Delete in its entirety. 
Section 101.4.4: Delete in its entirety. 
Section 103 through Section 115: Delete in their entirety. 
Chapter 5, General Building Heights and Areas 
Section 502.1: Definitions. Delete in their entirety Basement, Height Building, and Height Story. 
Chapter 6, Types of Construction 
Section 602.3: Type III. Delete in its entirety. 
Section 602.5: Insert. Type V construction shall be limited to multifamily type construction of townhomes and rowhomes with separate entrances and a maximum height of three (3) stories above grade and any accessory building allowed by the Roselle Zoning Ordinance. 
Section 603.1(23): Insert the following, (23).1 Corridors. Public corridors in mercantile, office buildings, schools or other uses which typically divide the building, with a tenant or rooms on each side, shall have a fire resistance rating of 2 (two) hours. All corridor doors shall be 1-1/2 hour fire rated doors, frames and hinges with hydraulic closer. If glass sidelights are used in the corridor wall, the glass shall be 1-1/2 hour fire rated, or a wall washer sprinkler head shall be located at each glass panel. 
2.  Hallways. Hallways or corridors within an office or tenant finish-out area shall NOT be required to have a 2 (two) hour fire rating. The corridors and hallways that are created by office systems furniture, cubicles, glass partitions or gypsum wall board within a tenant space shall not be required to have a fire rating; except, that all gypsum board partitions shall be constructed of 5/8 inch gypsum wall board on each side of metal studs @ 16 inch O.C. minimum construction. 
Section 603.1.2 Piping: Delete in its entirety and replace with; The use of combustible piping materials shall be permitted when installed in accordance with the standards of the International Mechanical Code and the State of Illinois Plumbing Code. 
Section 603.1.3 Electrical: Delete ICC Electrical Code and replace with National Electrical Code 2008. 
Section 603.1.24. Insert the following: 24. Tenant Separation Walls - Office & Mercantile. The tenant separation walls in multiple tenant retail or office uses shall utilize an approved 2 (two) hour fire resistance rated gypsum wall assembly. Such walls shall extend from the floor to the underside of the deck above and shall have sound attenuation blankets. 
Chapter 9, Fire Protection Systems 
Section 903.2 Where required insert: Approved automatic sprinkler systems shall be installed in all new principal buildings, additions, and structures of all use groups regardless of size. Building additions of 50% or more shall require automatic sprinkler protection to both the addition and the existing building.

Sec. 6-28. - Fire limits established. 
    The fire limits in the Village of Roselle, Counties of DuPage and Cook, State of Illinois, as defined and established in the Basic Building Code are hereby changed by deleting and amending Section 301.0 and by inserting in lieu thereof the following: 
    Section 301.0. Fire district subdivisions. For the purpose of control of use and construction of buildings, the building official shall establish limiting districts designated fire district no. 1, fire district no. 2 and outside fire limits under the legal procedure of the municipality for creating and establishing fire districts. 
    301.1. Fire District No. 1. Fire district no. 1 shall comprise the areas housing all that real estate within the Village of Roselle now or hereafter zoned M, limited manufacturing district, and R-4, multiple-family residence district. 
    301.2. Fire District No. 2. Fire district no. 2 shall comprise the areas housing all the real estate within the Village of Roselle now or hereafter zoned in any of the business district zoning districts. 
    301.3. Outside fire limits. Outside fire limits shall comprise all other areas not included in fire district nos. 1 and 2. 
(Ord. No. 392-72,  3, 7-24-72; Ord. No. 502-74,  1, 10-10-74) 
Sec. 6-29. - Effect of provisions on impending suits, liabilities, etc. 
    Nothing in sections 6-26 through 6-28 or in the building code hereby adopted shall be construed to affect any suit or proceeding impending in any court, or any rights acquitted, or liability incurred, or any cause or causes of action acquired or existing, under any act or ordinance; nor shall any just or legal right or remedy of any character be lost, impaired or affected by sections 6-26 through 6-28. 
(Ord. No. 392-72,  4, 7-24-72; Ord. No. 502-74,  1, 10-10-74)

ARTICLE III. - VILLAGE BUILDING CODE[3] 
Footnotes:

DIVISION 1. - ADMINISTRATION; DEFINITIONS; ARCHITECTURAL DESIGN 

Sec. 6-46. - Title. 
    This article may be referred to as the "Building Code of Roselle." 
(Ord. No. 59-13, Art. I,  1.01, 2-22-65) 
Sec. 6-47. - Definitions. 
    In the interpretation of this code, all words other than the terms herein specifically defined shall have their ordinarily accepted meanings as implied by the context or as customarily used in the construction industry. 
    Alley. A supplementary thoroughfare which is less than thirty (30) feet in width dedicated for the public use of vehicles and pedestrians and affording access to abutting property. 
    Approved. Approved by the building official or other authority having jurisdiction. 
    Approved rules. The legally adopted rules of the building official or of a recognized authoritative agency. 
    Attic. The space between the ceiling beams of the top habitable story and the roof rafters, in which the area at a height of seven and one-third (7 1/3 ) feet above the attic floor is not more than one-third ( 1/3 ) of the area of the floor next below. A habitable attic is an attic which has a stairway as a means of access and egress. 
    Basement. A portion of a building located partly underground, but having less than half its clear floor-to-ceiling height below the average grade of the adjoining ground. 
    Board of appeals. Whenever the words "board of appeals" are used in the building code, it shall be held to mean president and board of trustees of the Village of Roselle. 
    Boardinghouse. See rooming house. 
    Building height. The vertical distance measured from the established curb level to the highest point of the under side of the ceiling beams, in the case of a flat roof; to the deck line of a mansard roof; and to the mean level of the under side of rafters between the eaves and the ridge of a gable, hip or gambrel roof. Chimneys, spires, towers, elevator penthouses, tanks and similar projections other than signs shall not be included in calculating the height. 
    Building inspector. The officer, supervising board, committee or commission charged by law with the administration and enforcement of the building code, or the duly authorized representative of such official, board or commission. 
    Building line. The front line of the building or the legally established line which determines the location of the building with respect to the street lot line. 
    Building official. Whenever the words "building official" are used in the building code, it shall be held to mean the building inspector for the Village of Roselle. 
    Building service equipment. The mechanical, electrical or elevator equipment, including piping, wiring, fixtures and other accessories which provide sanitation, lighting, heating, ventilation, firefighting and transportation facilities essential for the habitable occupancy of the building or structure for its designated use and occupancy. 
    Cellar. The portion of a building located partly or wholly underground and having half or more than half of its clear floor-to-ceiling height below the average grade of the adjoining ground. 
    Certificate of use and occupancy. The certificate issued by the building inspector permitting the occupation and use of a building in accordance with the approved plans and specifications which certifies compliance with the provisions of law for the use and occupancy of the building in its several parts together with any special stipulations or conditions of the building permit. 
    Change of use. An alteration of a building or structure by change of use, heretofore existing, to a new use group which imposes other special provisions of law governing building construction, equipment or exits. 
    Court. A portion of a lot unoccupied above grade but partially or wholly surrounded by the walls of a structure. 
    Court, inner. A court surrounded on all sides by the exterior walls of a structure or by such walls and a lot line. 
    Court, outer. A court having at least one side thereof opening onto a street, alley, yard or other permanent open space. 
    Dormitory. A building containing a room or rooms arranged for sleeping quarters with accommodations for six (6) but not more than twenty (20) individuals and having common toilet and bathroom facilities. 
    Dwelling, multiple-family. A dwelling containing three (3) or more dwelling units. 
    Dwelling, single-family. A dwelling containing one dwelling unit which is either detached, semidetached or attached. 
    Dwelling, two-family. A dwelling containing two (2) dwelling units which are detached, semidetached or attached. 
    Dwelling unit. A group of rooms constituting all or part of a dwelling which are arranged, designed, used or intended for use exclusively as living quarters for one family and an aggregate of not more than two (2) roomers or boarders, and which include complete kitchen facilities, permanently installed. 
    Exitway. The exit doorway or doorways, or such doorways with connecting hallways and stairways, either interior or exterior, or fire escapes, by means of which the occupants may proceed safely from a room or space to a street or public space. 
    Fire division. The interior means of separation of one part of a floor area from another part together with fire-resistive floor construction to form a complete fire barrier between adjoining or superimposed floor areas in the same building or structure. 
    Fire-resistive ratings. The measured time in hours or fractions thereof that the material or construction will withstand fire exposed as determined by fire tests conducted in conformity to recognized standards. 
    Fire separation. Exterior fire exposure; the distance in feet measured from any other building on the site, or from an interior lot line, or from the opposite side of a street or other public space to the buildings. 
    Fire wall. An interior wall which completely subdivides a building into limited fire areas in all stories or which separates two (2) or more buildings to restrict the spread of fire; and which is supported on a foundation and extends continuously through all stories to and above the roof; except in buildings of fireproof construction. 
    Garage, private. An accessory building or an accessory portion of the principal building which is intended for and used for storing the private passenger vehicles and one commercial vehicle of not more than one and one-half (11/2) ton load capacity of a family or families resident upon the premises, and in which no business, service or industry connected directly or indirectly with the automotive vehicles is carried on, provided that not more than one-half (1/2) of the space may be rented for the private passenger vehicles of persons not resident on the premises, except that all the space in a garage of one- or two-car capacity may be so rented. 
    Garage, public. Any building within which automotive vehicles are painted, repaired, rebuilt, reconstructed or stored for compensation. 
    Garage, storage. A building used for housing only of motor vehicles pursuant to previous arrangements and not by transients; and where no equipment or parts are not rebuilt, serviced, repaired, hired or sold, except that fuel, grease or oil may be dispensed within the building to vehicles stored therein. 
    Grade. The mean curb level; or when the curb has not been established or all the walls of the building are more than fifteen (15) feet from street lot lines, the word "grade" means the mean elevation of the ground adjoining the building on all sides. 
    Habitable room. A room or enclosed floor space in a basement, first or upper story arranged for living, eating or sleeping purposes, not including bath or toilet rooms, laundries, pantries, foyers or communicating corridors or cellar recreation room, which is provided with approved means of light and ventilation. See also minimum habitable room height and minimum habitable room size. 
    Hallway, grade. Public hallway on the grade floor providing direct access to the streets or other open public space from the stairways and elevators. 
    Hallway, public. A public corridor or space separately enclosed or providing common access to all the exitways of a building in any story. 
    Hotel. A building containing not less than fourteen (14) lodging rooms, a general kitchen and dining room, a common entrance lobby, halls and stairway; and where lodging rooms do not have a doorway opening directly to the outdoors, except for emergencies; and where more than fifty (50) percent of the lodging rooms are for rent, with or without meals, to transient guests for a continuous period of less than thirty (30) days. 
    Interior lot line. Any lot line other than one adjoining a street or public space. 
    Lodging house. See rooming house. 
    Lot line. A property boundary line of any lot held in single or separate ownership, except that where any portion of the lot extends into the abutting street or alley, the lot line shall be deemed to be the street or alley right-of-way lines. 
    Minimum dwelling unit: 
(1)  In two-family dwelling buildings: A dwelling unit consisting of at least three (3) habitable rooms, one of which shall have a floor area of not less than one hundred sixty (160) square feet and one shall be a bedroom, plus a bathroom and two hundred (200) cubic feet of general storage space in closets, utility room, accessible attics, basement or garage. 
(2)  In multifamily dwelling buildings: A dwelling unit consisting of at least two (2) habitable rooms, one of which shall have a floor area of not less than one hundred sixty (160) square feet, or, if used for cooking, dining and living purposes, shall have a floor area of at least two hundred twenty (220) square feet; plus a bathroom and one hundred (100) cubic feet of general storage space within the dwelling unit. 
    Minimum habitable room height. A clear height from finished floor to finished ceilings of not less than seven and one-half (71/2) feet in the basement, of not less than eight (8) feet in the first story for at least seventy-five (75) percent of the floor area and of not less than seven and one-half (71/2) feet in the second and third stories. Rooms under sloping roofs shall have a minimum ceiling height of seven (7) feet six (6) inches for not less than fifty (50) percent of the floor area. No area having a ceiling height of less than five (5) feet shall be considered as a part of the required floor area. 
    Minimum habitable room size. A room with a minimum dimension of eight (8) feet and a minimum area of eighty (80) square feet between enclosing walls or partitions, exclusive of closet and storage space. 
    Motor vehicle repair shop. A building, structure, or enclosure in which the general business of repairing motor vehicles is conducted, including a public garage in which motor vehicles are repaired for profit. 
    Motor vehicle service station. Any building or portion thereof or premises used for dispensing or offering for sale at retail any automotive fuels or oils, and having pumps and storage tanks thereon; also where battery, tire and other similar services are rendered, but only if rendered wholly within lot lines. Automobile service stations do not include open sales lots as defined herein. When such dispensing, sale or offering for sale of any fuels or oils is incidental to the conduct of a public garage, the premises shall be classified as a public garage. 
    Noncombustible. Incombustible; a general relative term. 
    Noncombustible material. (Check Test). Any material which will neither ignite nor support combustion in air at a temperature of twelve hundred (1,200) degrees F., six hundred fifty (650) degrees C., during an exposure of five (5) minutes in a vented tube or a vented crucible furnace. 
    Occupancy load. The number of individuals normally occupying the building or part thereof, or for which the exit facilities have been designed. 
    Occupiable room. A room or enclosed space designed for human occupancy in which persons congregate for amusement, education or similar purposes, or in which persons are engaged at labor, and which is provided with exits, light and ventilation meeting the requirements of this code. 
    Party wall. A wall starting from the foundation and extending continuously through all stories to or above the roof which separates one building from another, and is in joint use by each building. 
    Penthouse. An enclosed structure above the roof of a building, other than a roof structure, extending not more than twelve (12) feet above the roof and occupying not more than thirty-three and one-third (33 1/3 ) percent of the roof area and not considered a story. See "roof structure." 
    Petroleum bulk storage. A building or structure for the storage of lubricating oils with a flash point of three hundred (300) degrees F. or higher and storage space for not more than one motor vehicle. 
    Place of assembly. A room or space with an occupancy load of seventy-five (75) or more for religious, recreational, educational, political, social or amusement purposes, or for the consumption of food or drink, including all connecting rooms and space with a common means of entrance and exit. 
    Place of outdoor assembly. All premises used or intended to be used for public gatherings when the structure or group of structures or part of structure in which persons assemble is open to the air on one or more sides for a horizontal distance equal to not less than thirty-three and one-third (33 1/3 ) percent of its perimeter and for a height of not less than eight (8) feet in each seating level or story. 
    Public corridor. An enclosed public passageway with access to and from individual apartments, offices or rooms leading to a public hallway or exitways. 
    Public space. A plot or area of land outside of a building dedicated or devoted to public use by legal mapping or any other lawful procedure. 
    Repair. The replacement of existing work with the same kind of materials for the purpose of its maintenance, but not including additional work that would affect safety, or affect required exit facilities, or a vital element of an elevator, plumbing, gas piping, wiring, ventilating or heating installations, or any work that would be in violation of a provision of this code or any other law governing building construction. 
    Roof covering. The covering applied to the roof for weather resistance, fire resistance or appearance. 
    Roof structure. A structure other than a penthouse above the roof of any part of a building enclosing a stairway, tank elevator machinery, ventilating apparatus or other service equipment, or such part of a shaft that extends above the roof. 
    Rooming house, boardinghouse or tourist home. A building or portion thereof containing lodging rooms which accommodate persons who are not members of the keeper's family, and where lodging rooms or meals, or both, are provided for compensation. 
    Standard fire test. The standard controlled furnace test formulated under the procedure of the American Standards Association and designated ASA Standard A-2.1 1956 and A-2.2 1960. 
    Story. That portion of a building included between the surface of any floor and the surface of the floor next above; or if there is no floor above, the space between the floor and the ceiling next above. A basement shall be counted as a story and a cellar shall not be counted as a story. 
    Street (avenue, place, lane, road, boulevard, terrace or parkway). A right-of-way of required width which affords a primary means of access to abutting property. 
    Street lot line. The lot line dividing a lot from a street or other public space. 
    Structure. Anything erected the use of which requires more or less permanent location on the ground, or attached to something having a permanent location on the ground. A sign or other advertising device, detached or projecting, shall be construed to be a separate structure. 
    Tourist home. See rooming house. 
    Use groups. The classification of a building or structure based on the purpose for which the building or structure is designed or used. 
    Writing. The term shall be construed to include handwriting, typewriting, printing, photo-offset or any other form of reproduction in legible symbols or characters. 
    Written notice. When required under the provisions of this code, written notice shall be considered to have been served, if delivered in person to the individual, person or parties intended, or if delivered at or sent by registered mail to the last business address known to the party giving the notice. 
    Yard. An open space on a lot which is unoccupied and unobstructed from its lowest level to the sky. A yard extends along a lot line and at right angles to such line to a depth or width specified in the yard regulations for zoning district in which such lot is located. 
    Zoning. The reservation of certain specified areas within a community or village for use of buildings and structures or land for specified purposes, with other limitations such as height, lot coverage and other stipulated requirements. 
(Ord. No. 59-13, Art. II, 2-22-65) 
Sec. 6-48. - Standards. 
    The standards, regulations and specifications contained in this code shall be deemed and considered as minimum standards for the construction of buildings for the protection of public health and safety. Any materials or methods of construction not specifically mentioned in this code which give the same protection to public health and safety from the standpoint of strength, fire protection and other factors relevant thereto may be used in substitution for the specific materials or methods prescribed in this code. 
(Ord. No. 59-13, Art. I,  1.02, 2-22-65) 
Sec. 6-49. - Discretionary powers. 
    Wherever in this code provision is made that work be done subject to the approval of the building inspector, or to his satisfaction, or in a manner prescribed by him, this shall be construed as authorizing the building inspector only to determine whether or not the work or materials involved comply with the provisions of this code; and no such provision shall be construed as giving the building inspector discretionary authority or power, or any power or authority other than is necessary to enforce the provisions of this code. 
(Ord. No. 59-13, Art. I,  1.03, 2-22-65) 
Sec. 6-50. - Compliance required. 
    It shall be unlawful to erect, construct, repair or alter, remove or demolish any building or structure in the village in violation of any of the provisions of this article, or without complying with the provisions of this article. It shall be unlawful to vary from the terms of any building permit, including the plans and specifications relative thereto, in connection with any such work; provided that a building permit may be amended upon proper application as provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 59-13, Art. I,  1.04, 2-22-65) 
Sec. 6-51. - Building inspector. 
(a)  There is hereby created the employed position of building inspector, who shall be an employee of the village. 
(b)  The village engineer shall also serve as building inspector. 
(c)  To be eligible for appointment, the building inspector shall be generally informed on the equality and strength of building materials, and prevailing methods of construction for safety, comfort and convenience. 
(d)  It shall be the duty of the building inspector to enforce all laws relating to the construction of and the alterations, repair, removal, and demolition of existing buildings and structures, and the installation of equipment and appurtenances thereto. 
(e)  The building inspector shall receive applications required by this code, issue permits and such notices or orders as may be necessary to enforce compliance with law. He shall keep careful and comprehensive records of applications, of permits issued, of inspections made, and of notices or orders issued. 
(f)  The building inspector, in the discharge of his duties, shall have authority to enter any buildings, structures or premises provided that such entry is constitutionally lawful. He may request and shall receive, so far as may be necessary, the assistance of the village engineer, the chief of police, the village attorney and other village officials in matters appropriate to their powers and functions. 
(g)  The compensation of the building inspector shall be fixed by ordinance. 
(h)  Plumbing inspector. A plumbing inspector shall serve as plumbing inspector whose duties shall include the examination of plans and specifications, inspection of plumbing, sewerage and drainage installations and enforcement of all provisions of this code affecting plumbing and drainage not otherwise required by law to be enforced by other officials shall be appointed. 
(i)  Electrical inspector. An electrical inspector shall serve as electrical inspector whose duties shall include the examination of plans and specifications of electric wiring and equipment, and enforcement of all provisions of this code effecting electrical work shall be appointed. 
(Ord. No. 59-13, Art. I,  1.05, 2-22-65; Ord. No. 360-71,  2, 10-11-71; Ord. No. 604-76,  2, 3-1-76; Ord. No. 1548-87,  3, 4-13-87; Ord. No. 2008-3425,  3, 12-15-08) 
Sec. 6-52. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2008-3425,  3, adopted December 15, 2008, repealed  6-52, which pertained to building committee and derived from Ord. No. 59-13, Art. I,  1.06, 2-22-65. 
Sec. 6-53. - Permits. 
(a)  No building or structure shall hereafter be built, enlarged, altered or moved, nor shall repair or maintenance work be done which in any way affects the structural, fire protection or protection of health qualities of a building or structure, nor shall any cesspool, cistern, septic tank or well for drinking water nor electrical work, nor signs, except as provided hereinafter, be installed, erected, altered or repaired without a permit from the building inspector. 
(b)  Application for permit shall be made in writing upon printed blanks or forms furnished by the building inspector for such purpose. The application shall be made by the owner or his duly appointed representative. It shall include a brief description of the proposed work, the use or uses to which the building or structure will be put, estimated cost of construction, and complete legal description of the property, and shall give such additional information as may be required by the building inspector for an intelligent understanding of the proposed work. 
(c)  The application shall be accompanied by two (2) copies of the plans and specifications clearly illustrating and specifying the work to be done. Both copies of the plans and specifications shall, if approved, and a permit issued for the work to be started, be signed or stamped by the building inspector. One signed or stamped copy of plans and specifications shall be kept on file in the office of the building inspector, and one signed or stamped copy shall be returned to the applicant and shall be kept at the place where the work is being done until its completion. (Additional copies of plans and specifications may be requested by the building inspector if such are required by other officials or agencies whose jurisdiction may be affected.) 
(d)  There shall be filed also a plot plan as part of the working drawings, drawn to scale, with all dimensions figured, showing accurately the size and location of all proposed new construction and the relation to other existing or proposed structures on the same lot and other structures on adjoining property within ten (10) feet of the property lines. This plan shall also show the proposed location of water supply and sewage disposal lines, wells and septic tank systems, if any, and lines or ditches for disposal of surface water. In the case of demolition, the plot diagram shall show such construction as is to be demolished and existing buildings and structures that are to remain. The plot plan will not be required for interior alterations, repairs or electrical work, nor for additions or other new construction which do not occupy ground area in addition to that occupied by the existing structure. 
(e)  No permit shall be issued unless the plans and specifications accompanying such permit are signed or stamped by a registered architect or engineer. Provided, however, the signature or stamp of a registered architect or engineer is not necessary on plans and specifications in the following instances, only: 
(1)  When a person, mechanic, or builder makes drawings or specifications for the erection, enlargement, or alteration of buildings or any parts thereof to be constructed by themselves or their own employees for their own use, when title to such property is held by the persons, mechanics, or builders for at least two (2) years, provided that the working drawings for such construction are signed by the authors thereof, with a true statement thereon of their relation to such construction and that the makers thereof are not architects; and 
(2)  The construction, remodeling, or repairing of a detached single-family residence on a single lot; except in cases or remodeling involving structural changes where the total cost exceeds ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00); and 
(3)  Interior alterations of existing buildings which do not involve structural changes. 
(f)  The building inspector shall refuse to approve an application or to issue a permit unless the plans and specifications and other data which accompany such application shall bear a certification by the registered architect or engineer or persons, mechanics or builders as aforesaid responsible for the preparation of the plans that the proposed work is in all respects in accordance with this code. 
(g)  Requirements: 
(1)  No permit shall be issued for the erection of any building or structure which is not completely in conformity with the provisions of the Roselle Zoning Ordinance and Subdivision Regulations now in effect or hereafter enacted. 
(2)  No permit shall be issued hereunder for any premises unless the sanitary sewer mains of the village shall have been extended to said premises or unless a temporary permit shall have been issued pursuant to authorization by the corporate authorities of the village for the installation on said premises of facilities other than modern plumbing facilities properly connected with one of the sanitary sewer systems of the village, and unless there shall have been installed or unless provision is made in the plans and specifications for the installation on said premises of facilities for the disposal of human waste and excreta and other similar sewage in accordance with the ordinances of the village. 
(3)  No building permit shall be issued hereunder for the erection of a building for residential purposes on any tract or parcel of real estate unless the condition or all of the conditions, as the case may be, mentioned or enumerated in one of the following subparagraphs, exist: 
a.  Water and sanitary sewer facilities, which are in good working order and available for the satisfactory servicing of said premises, shall have been extended to the property line of the premises. Also some street upon which said premises border shall have been satisfactorily improved with a paved roadway surface which extends in such condition from said premises to an Illinois state highway or to another street or streets extending in such condition to such a highway. Also adequate storm sewer facilities shall have been installed in the vicinity of said premises, to prevent the flooding of the premises by surface waters; 
b.  The building is to be constructed on a lot or parcel of real estate bordering upon a section of a street, over which travel extends for ingress and egress purposes between a residence already erected at the time of the enactment of this condition, and an existing improved public street or highway; or 
c.  Provision is made under contract entered into with the village by some person, persons, copartnership, trust or corporation, for the installation of water and sanitary sewer facilities, surface drainage facilities and street improvements, such as are provided for in subparagraph a. above, in the block upon which such lot or parcel of real estate is located, supported by a performance and indemnity bond or bonds in favor of the village and duly filed with the village in such amount or amounts and with such surety company or companies as may be approved by the corporate authorities; provided, however, that no occupancy permit shall be issued for any building for which a building permit shall have been issued pursuant to this sub-paragraph c. until all of the improvements provided for by the aforesaid contract shall have been fully satisfied and duly approved and accepted by the corporate authorities and each building permit issued pursuant to this subparagraph c. shall so recite. 
The building inspector shall determine whether or not the condition or conditions enumerated in one of the foregoing subparagraphs exist before any such building permit is issued on the strength of the existence of said condition or conditions; provided, however, that if the building inspector is in doubt as to the facts, or if notice in writing is filed by any interested person with the building inspector demanding that the relevant facts under this paragraph (3) be determined by the corporate authorities of the village or if said corporate authorities elect to take over the making of the determination of such facts as applied to any particular application, then the building inspector shall not act in the premises until said corporate authorities shall make finding of fact on the premises and shall be bound thereby in acting upon the application for a permit involved in connection therewith. 
d.  The senior building inspector or director of community development may issue a limited permit for the construction of a foundation, to be constructed between October 1st and December 1st, or at other times when approved by the senior building inspector or director of community development based on unique and urgent hardship, and containing such special conditions related to construction scheduling, building completion, barricading and removal of a foundation, as deemed appropriate by the senior building inspector or director of community development for the protection of the public health, safety and welfare only where: 
i.  The permittee has complied with all zoning, grading, foundation, floor and structural plan requirements of the code. Additional plans or specifications that may be necessary to evaluate the adequacy of a foundation plan may be required by the senior building inspector or director of community development for review and prior to approval. 
ii.  The permittee has paid all required fees, license costs, and posted any required bonds, insurance or security pertaining to the foundation; and 
iii.  The permittee has executed a waiver and indemnification agreement acknowledging that the permittee proceeds at his own risk and without assurance that a full building permit will issue, and waives any claims in law or equity against the village related to the foundation permit, and further agrees to indemnify and hold the village harmless from any and all damages, claims, actions, causes of action, and costs, including reasonable attorney's fees, that may result in consequence of the issuance of the foundation permit and further agrees to remove the foundation and properly regrade the site within thirty (30) days of receipt of written notice by the senior building inspector or director of community development that the foundation only permit has expired. 
(h)  Reserved. 
(i)  The building inspector shall examine all applications for permits within a reasonable time after filing. If he finds that the proposed work will be in compliance with all applicable laws, codes and ordinances, and that the proposed construction will be safe, he shall issue a permit within fifteen (15) days from receipt of the application. If for any reason an application cannot be approved, he shall notify the applicant in writing, stating the reasons for disapproval. 
(j)  The building inspector shall sign or cause to be signed all permits, certificates and notices required to be used by this code. 
(k)  Reserved. 
(l)  If after a building or other permit required by this article shall have been granted, the operations called for by such permit shall not be begun within six (6) months after the date thereof, such permit shall be void and no operations thereunder shall be begun or completed until an extended permit shall be taken out by the owner or his agent, and a fee of twenty-five (25) percent of the original cost of the permit shall be charged for such extended permit; provided, however, that in no case shall a permit or extended permit be issued for a fee of less than two dollars and fifty cents ($2.50). An extended permit shall be valid for six (6) months following the date of expiration of the original permit and must be applied for within ten (10) days after the expiration of the original permit. Two (2) extensions only shall be granted, and if work is not begun within eighteen (18) months after the date of issuance of the original permit, all rights under the permit shall thereupon terminate by limitation. Where, under authority of a permit, or extended permit, work has begun and has been abandoned for a continuous or cumulative period of twelve (12) months, all rights under such permits shall thereupon terminate by limitation. 
(m)  Additional condition precedent to issuance of building permit: Notwithstanding any provisions contained herein and the BOCA Building Code, in affect to the contrary, no permit required by the provisions of this chapter shall be issued to any individual, partnership, corporation, land trustee or other business activity, if the individual, partnership, corporation, is [land trustee or other business activity] financially indebted to the Village of Roselle. 
(Ord. No. 59-13, Art. I,  1.07, 2-22-65; Ord. No. 824-79,  2, 1-22-79; Ord. No. 1549-87,  5, 4-13-87; Ord. No. 1653-88,  1, 1-25-88; Ord. No. 2085-91,  1, 5-28-91; Ord. No. 2008-3425,  3, 12-15-08) 
Sec. 6-53.1. - Building contractors. 
(a)  Contractor's responsibility. It shall be unlawful to engage in the business of construction, demolition, rehabilitation, alteration or repair of buildings or other structures, sidewalk or street pavements, landscaping which makes changes to the topography of the property, or the installation of electrical, plumbing, heating, ventilating, air conditioning or other mechanical systems, or any such business, all hereinafter referred to as "contractor's work," in the Village of Roselle, as a general contractor, subcontractor or otherwise, without first registering with the village as a contractor as hereinafter provided. Any person or entity engaged in contractor's work shall be deemed a contractor for purposes of this section. Any contractor that controls or contracts two (2) or more other contractors shall be deemed a general contractor for the purposes of this section. Contractor's work shall include a homeowner or a building owner constructing a new primary structure on their property. 
(b)  Compliance with applicable ordinances. It shall be the duty of contractors to comply with all laws, ordinances and regulations relating to any contractors work performed in the village. 
(c)  Compliance by employees. Every contractor shall be responsible conform to the requirements of this section and all other village ordinances by its own employees and by every contractor working under its control. 
(d)  Contractor's registration. Before performing any work in the Village every contractor, except plumbers, shall be required to register with the Village of Roselle as a contractor. Annual registration fees for contractors shall be seventy five dollars ($75.00). Every contractor's registration shall remain in effect for one year from the date the fee is received. 
(e)  Contractor's surety bond. Every person and entity engaged in contractors work shall submit to the village clerk a surety bond to guaranty the contractor's compliance with the provisions of this building code and other applicable ordinances and regulations of the Village of Roselle, cosigned by a surety authorized by the Illinois Department of Insurance to sell and issue sureties in the State of Illinois, in the amounts as follows: general contractors, demolition contractors, and wreckers shall post with the village a twenty-five thousand dollar ($25,000) surety bond; and all other contractors shall post a ten thousand dollar ($10,000.00) surety bond; provided, however, that no such surety bond shall be required in the event said applicant has obtained a unified license and permit bond from DuPage County or Cook County, in accordance with the requirements of the Contractor Unified License and Permit Bond Act, and has filed a certified copy of said unified bond with the village clerk. 
(f)  Certificates of insurance. Every person and entity, except plumbers, engaged in contractors work shall submit to the village clerk a current certificate or certificates of insurance issued by a company having at least a "B+/VII" rating in "The Best Insurance Guide", evidencing the following coverage in not less than the following amounts: 
(1)  Commercial general liability insurance: One million dollars ($1,000,000.00) each occurrence covering liability arising from premises, operations, independent contractors, products completed operations, and personal injury. 
(2)  Workers' compensation insurance: In the amounts and coverage required by law. 
(3)  The insurance requirement of this section shall not be applicable to the plumbers who present a current State of Illinois plumbing contractor's license issued by the Illinois Department of Public Health pursuant to the Illinois Plumbing Licensing Law (PA 92-0338). 
(g)  Plumbing requirements. Every contractor performing plumbing work shall submit to the village clerk a copy of its State of Illinois Plumbing License showing an expiration date not earlier than the expiration date of the registration for which it is applying. Plumbers shall not be required to post a surety bond or certificate of insurance unless state statute is amended to permit the imposition of a surety bond and/or certificate of insurance. 
(h)  Electrical requirements. Every electrical contractor shall submit to the village clerk a copy of its electrical license certified from an established commission or a certifying municipality showing an expiration date not earlier than the expiration date of the registration for which it is applying. 
(i)  Roofing requirements. Every roofing contractor shall submit to the village clerk a certified copy of its State of Illinois roofing certificate showing an expiration date not earlier than the expiration date of the registration for which it is applying. 
(j)  Contractor's requirements for permit. Every person and entity engaged in contractors work shall be registered, bonded and insured in accordance with the requirements of this ordinance before a building permit is processed and approved. In the event that a building permit is issued in error or a contractor's registration is suspended, revoked, expires or he, she or it fails to maintain at least the minimum insurance requirements under this title, the building inspector may issue a stop work order and suspend a building permit until such time as there is compliance. 
(k)  Homeowner's license requirements. The provisions of this ordinance shall not require a homeowner to be registered as a contractor to, rehabilitate, alter or repair his/her own home, but any non-homeowner who assists the homeowner shall be so licensed. Any homeowner applying for new home construction permit shall be considered a contractor for purposes of this ordinance and conform to all its provisions. 
(l)  Registered contractor list. A file of all registered contractors listed alphabetically shall be maintained in the community development department and the village clerk's office. The list shall not constitute, nor be interpreted, as an endorsement, recommendation, guaranty, certification or warranty of any contractor by the village. It shall only be a record identifying those contractors registered with the village for purposes of the village enforcing the terms of this article. The list shall contain a disclaimer that it does not constitute any endorsement, recommendation, guaranty, certification or warranty of any contractor by the village. When permitted work is not completed within one year after issuance of a permit, and no extended permit has been granted, the permit shall expire. 
(Ord. No. 2006-3242,  1, 8-28-06; Ord. No. 2008-3425,  3, 12-15-08; Ord. No. 2015-3807,  1, 12-7-15) 
Sec. 6-54. - Certificates. 
(a)  No certificate of occupancy under the zoning ordinance shall be issued for the occupancy of any building constructed or altered after the enactment of this article, unless the building has been constructed or altered in compliance with the provisions of this code. Upon making final inspection of any construction work for which a permit is required, the building inspector may execute a document indicating that such final inspection has been made and that he has found no violation of the provisions of this article in connection therewith, but such document shall be in no way a certificate or statement that the work done has been properly done in compliance with the article and shall not be considered as an assurance that the work has been so properly done. 
(b)  No building subsequently erected or altered shall be occupied or used for any purpose excepting in compliance with the zoning ordinance. 
(c)  In addition to the certification as to compliance with the provisions of this code, the certificate of occupancy shall state the purposes and classification for which the building may be used in its several parts, and all special stipulations of the permit, if any. 
(d)  Upon request of the holder of a building permit, the building inspector may issue a temporary certificate of occupancy for part or parts of a building; provided that such a temporary occupancy or use would not jeopardize life or property. Such temporary certificates of occupancy shall not be issued to cover a period of more than six (6) months. 
(e)  A certificate of occupancy shall be issued within five (5) days after written application therefor, if the building at the time of such application shall be entitled thereto. 
(f)  No change of occupancy or use shall be made in a building hereafter erected or altered that is not consistent with the last issued certificate of occupancy for such building, unless a permit is secured. In case of an existing building, no change of occupancy that would bring it under some special provision of this Code shall be made, unless the building inspector finds, upon inspection, that such building conforms to the provisions of the Roselle Zoning Ordinance and other applicable laws and ordinances with respect to the proposed new occupancy and use, and issues a certificate of occupancy therefor. 
(g)  The use of a building or premises shall not be deemed to have changed because of a temporary vacancy or change of ownership or tenancy. This reestablishment in a building, after a change of occupancy has been made, of a prior use that would not have been permitted in a new building of the same type of construction is prohibited. 
(h)  Where no village water or sanitary sewer can be constructed to service a property, no cesspool, cistern, septic tank or well for drinking water nor any electrical work, except as otherwise provided hereinafter, for which a permit is required, shall be used in whole or in part until a certificate of compliance shall have been issued by the building inspector attesting that all work has been done in accordance with the provisions of this Code and the Roselle Zoning Ordinance and Subdivision Regulations and all other applicable laws and ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 59-13, Art. I,  1.08, 2-22-65; Ord. No. 2008-3425,  3, 12-15-08) 
Cross reference- Permits,  6-53; fees and deposits,  6-55. 
Sec. 6-54.1. - Certificate of re-occupancy vacant building. 
    Any building or structure previously granted an occupancy permit, which becomes unoccupied or vacant for a period of sixty (60) days, or more, shall require an inspection and re-occupancy permit prior to re-occupancy. Upon determining that a building or structure has been unoccupied or vacant for a period of sixty (60) days, or more, the building inspector shall post the building or structure as being subject to inspection and a re-occupancy permit and the building department may mail such notice to the last known owner. The notice may also be recorded with the recorder of deeds for the county in which the building or structure is located. The inspector based on the condition of the building or structure shall have the authority to deny a re-occupancy permit where any condition exists which renders the property uninhabitable or may order independent testing where it reasonably appears that such tests are appropriate. An example of independent testing, includes but is not limited to, testing for mold in a building which has been flooded during the vacancy. Prior to the issuance of a re-occupancy permit any and all fees incurred by the village for independent testing shall be reimbursed to the village regardless of the result of the independent test. Where an independent test is required the property owner shall hire at the owners own cost the testing person or company. Such person or company shall be in the business of providing such testing and subject to the reasonable approval of the village building department. The results of all independent testing shall be provided to the building department as a pre-condition of a re-occupancy permit. The building department shall use reasonable diligence in processing re-occupancy permit applications. 
(Ord. No. 2009-3460,  1A., 7-13-09)

Sec. 6-56. - Inspections. 
(a)  Required inspections as set forth in appendix A. 
(b)  The building inspector shall examine all buildings or structures for which application has been made for a permit to enlarge; remove or alter such building or structure to determine whether or not such permit may be granted. 
(c)  The building inspector shall inspect, or cause to be inspected, all installations of cesspools, cisterns, septic tanks, wells for drinking water and electrical work for which a permit has been issued, to determine whether or not such installations have been made in compliance with this code and other applicable codes or ordinances. If the installation is approved, a certificate of compliance shall be issued. This inspection shall be made at the time the installations are completed, but before backfilling or enclosing is done, so that all parts may be satisfactorily examined. 
(d)  The building inspector shall inspect all buildings or structures which are, from any cause whatsoever, in a dangerous condition to persons or property, and he shall notify the owner thereof of such conditions in writing. 
(Ord. No. 59-13, Art. I,  1.10, 2-22-65; Ord. No. 2008-3425,  3, 12-15-08) 
Sec. 6-57. - Unsafe buildings and structures. 
(a)  Any building or part thereof, or any structure of like nature (including the foundation to any such building) which is uncompleted or abandoned or which is in a condition dangerous or unsafe to the occupants, or those passing, or to any adjacent building, by reason that the same are uncompleted or abandoned or by reason of bad conditions of walls, overloaded floors, defective heating apparatus, vibrations from machinery, defective flues, confined or cramped stairways, insufficient exits, narrow or dark passageways, or which is unsafe or dangerous for the purpose for which it is used or intended to be used, or is in danger of being set on fire from any defect in its construction or is especially dangerous in case of fire by reason of its dilapidated condition or defective construction, or from other causes, or which may be prejudicial to the public health or the health of the inhabitants of the neighborhood, shall be deemed and is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. 
(b)  Whenever it shall come to the knowledge of the building inspector, fire chief, health officer, or when a complaint shall be made to them or any of them in writing by any two (2) reputable residents of the village, that any building walls or structure within the village is in dangerous condition as described in subsection (a), said building inspector, fire chief or health officer, as the case may be, shall forthwith report the same to the board of trustees. 
(c)  If after due investigation of such report, it shall appear to the board of trustees that such building, walls or structure is in such dangerous condition, notice thereof in writing shall be served upon the owner or owners of such real estate and, where applicable, upon his agent, lessee or occupant. Where, upon diligent search, the identity or whereabouts of the owner or owners of any such building shall not be ascertainable, notice mailed to the person or persons in whose name such real estate was last assessed shall constitute sufficient notice under this section. Said notice shall specify wherein such building is unsafe, defective or unlawful; and shall require such owner, agent, lessee or occupant to correct and make safe the same within fifteen (15) days or such further time as the circumstances may warrant. Upon failure so to do, the board shall order the building inspector to correct and make safe said building, wall or structure or to have the same demolished. 
(d)  Every building which shall appear to the building inspector, health officer or fire chief to be especially dangerous in case of fire, by reason of bad conditions of walls, overloaded floors, defective construction, decay or other causes, shall be held to be an unsafe building and the building inspector, fire chief or health officer as the case may be, in addition to proceeding as provided in subsection (c), shall also affix a notice of the dangerous character of the building in a conspicuous place on the exterior wall thereof. Any person removing, defacing or disturbing such notice so affixed shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to the penalties provided in section 6-477 of this code. 
(e)  The building inspector, health officer or fire chief may order that no person shall be permitted to enter, occupy or use a dangerous building or any portion thereof until the same shall have been made safe; and may post such order in a conspicuous place on the exterior wall of such building. No person shall enter, occupy or use, except for the purpose of repairing and making safe, any building or portion thereof after the posting of such notice until such building or portion thereof shall have been made safe. 
(f)  If the building or portion thereof found dangerous shall be devoted to any purpose requiring a license, the president may suspend the license pending the period of making repairs; and he may revoke the license in case of failure on the part of the owner or party having an interest in such unsafe building or portion thereof to make safe without delay and at their expense. 
(g)  It shall not be lawful to occupy for human habitation any building which is declared by the health officer to be unfit for such habitation by reason of defective sanitary conditions, until such conditions have been remedied and the premises approved by said health officer as fit for occupancy. 
(h)  In case the building inspector or health officer finds any building or part of a building in such condition as to endanger life, or liable to cause serious accident, and that such danger may be averted by the immediate application of precautionary measures, said officers, or either of them, shall have and exercise the power without the preliminary direction of the board of trustees, to take such precautionary measures as in his or their opinion may be necessary to render any building or part thereof safe; provided, however, the owner, lessee, occupant or agent of said building refuses or neglects to take such precautionary measures after being notified so to do by said officers or any of them. 
(i)  An itemized account of the expenses of tearing down and removing such structure or of putting the same into safe condition shall be kept by the building inspector, and shall be presented to the owner or owners of said structure, or his or their agents, or to such lessee or occupant, for payment. In case such owner, or owners, lessee or occupant, as the case may be, shall fail or refuse to pay the same, upon demand, then the same may be recovered from such owner or owners, lessee or occupant of such real estate and shall be a lien thereon. 
(Ord. No. 59-13, Art. I,  1.11, 2-22-65; Ord. No. 279-69,  1, 10-13-69) 
Sec. 6-57.1. - Demolition of buildings. 
(a)  No building or other structure shall be demolished, razed or wrecked unless a permit is first obtained therefor from the building inspector. All costs in connection therewith, including connections and disconnections to the combined water and sewer system of the village, shall be at the expense of the person owning the property. 
(b)  Application for a demolition permit as required in subsection (a) above shall be made to the building inspector and be accompanied by the following: 
(1)  A description of the proposed building or structure to be wrecked, its location, nature of construction, method and procedure of its proposed demolition, and reason therefor. 
(2)  A cash deposit in the sum of five hundred dollars ($500.00) to assure the filling in of any below-grade areas and completion of other measures deemed necessary to restore the premises to a safe condition following the completion of the proposed demolition. 
(3)  A bond with good and sufficient sureties, acceptable to the president and board of trustees, indemnifying, keeping and saving harmless the village against any loss, cost, damage, expense, judgment or liability of any kind whatsoever which the village may suffer, or which may accrue against, be charged to or be recovered from the village, or any of its officials, from or by reason or on account of accidents to persons or property during any such demolition, razing or wrecking operations, and from or by reason or on account of anything done under or by virtue of any permit granted for any such demolition, razing or wrecking operations. Such bond shall be in the penal sum of twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) for structures not exceeding three (3) stories in height, and forty thousand dollars ($40,000.00) for structures of four (4) or more stories. 
(4)  Releases from all utilities serving the premises stating that their respective services have been disconnected and terminated in a safe and approved manner. 
(5)  Such other information as may be required by the building inspector, such as a site plan. 
(c)  The building inspector shall issue such demolition permit when he finds that: 
(1)  A permit fee has been paid. 
(2)  That the application and the proposed operations fully comply with all provisions of this code, including the prior issuance of any other permits, such as street occupation permits. 
(d)  All demolition, razing and wrecking operations carried on under permit shall conform to the following requirements: 
(1)  The provisions of Chapter 48, sections 60 through 69, Illinois Revised Statutes, as amended, relating to the protection and safety of persons in and about construction and removal of buildings. 
(2)  All provisions of this code respecting safety procedures to be used in occupying streets and making excavations, including lighting, guard railing, temporary sidewalks and proper scaffolding, including the provisions of Article II of Chapter 18 of the Code of Ordinances of the Village covering excavations. Sewer services shall be terminated at the property line in a manner as prescribed by the building inspector. If, for any good reason it is determined by the building inspector that said sewer service be terminated at another location, this shall be left to his discretion. Water service lines shall be shut off at the corporation cock on the water main. In no case shall lead service lines be allowed to be reused. Any deviation with regard to where the service line shall be discontinued shall be the determination of the building inspector. 
(3)  Rubble causing dust so as to cause a nuisance shall be adequately sprinkled. 
(4)  Except as to buildings no more than two (2) stories in height and wholly of wood frame construction, no more than one story at a time shall be wrecked. No wall, chimney or other construction shall be allowed to fall in mass on an upper floor. Bulky material, such as beams and columns, shall be lowered and not allowed to fall. 
(5)  Chutes for the removal of materials and debris shall be provided in all parts of demolition operations that are more than twenty (20) feet above the point where the removal of material is effected. Such chutes shall be completely enclosed. They shall not extend in an unbroken line for more than twenty-five (25) feet, but shall be equipped at intervals of twenty-five (25) feet or less with substantial stops to prevent descending material from attaining dangerous speeds. The bottom of each chute shall be equipped with a gate, or stop, with suitable means for closing or regulating the flow of material. 
(6)  All pits, holes or other areas below street grade shall be filled and leveled. All debris shall be removed and the premises left in a safe condition. 
(e)  The foregoing provisions to the contrary notwithstanding, where a permit for new construction has been issued on the premises where such demolition, razing or wrecking is to occur, upon satisfactory arrangements being made with the building inspector, the requirements of subsections (b)(2) and (d)(6) shall not apply. 
(Ord. No. 581-75,  2, 11-3-75; Ord. No. 2008-3425,  3, 12-15-08) 
Sec. 6-57.2. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2008-3425,  3, adopted December 15, 2008, repealed  6-57.2, which pertained to right of entry and derived from Ord. No. 581-75,  2, 11-3-75. 
Sec. 6-58. - Validity. 
    If any section or part of section or paragraph of this code is declared invalid or unconstitutional, it shall not be held to invalidate or impair the validity, force or effect of any other section or sections or part of section or paragraph of this code. 
(Ord. No. 59-13, Art. I,  1.12, 2-22-65; Ord. No. 581-75,  2, 11-3-75) 
Sec. 6-59. - Special technical problems. 
    Upon receipt of an application for site plan approval, engineering approval or building permit, the village administrator or his/her designee, determine whether the design or magnitude of construction is beyond the technical expertise of the village staff. If any such application is deemed to require professional review, the appropriate material shall be submitted to a consultant for further examination and recommendation. 
    Technical studies may be required for any area of concern deemed necessary. For the purposes of this section, consultant reviews may include, but not be limited to, the following technical areas of concern: Building design, engineering design, traffic/transportation system design, sprinkler/fire protection system design, HVAC design, plumbing system design, electrical system design and landscape design. 
    If any consultant reviews shall be performed, the costs of such review shall be charged to the individual or firm requesting approval of said application. Such cost shall be in addition to those permit fees, application fees or other fees required by ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 59-13, Art. I,  1.13, 2-22-65; Ord. No. 581-75,  2, 11-3-75; Ord. No. 1520-87,  2, 1-12-87) 
Sec. 6-60. - Architectural design. 
(a)  Whereas, it is universally recognized that many neighborhoods in urban areas have deteriorated in the past by reason of poor planning and indiscriminate and unregulated building, and by the progressive erection of inferior and unsuitable buildings in such neighborhoods, and whereas such deterioration has been invariably accompanied by a drastic reduction in property values and by a deterioration in conditions of health, sanitation and safety in such neighborhoods, and for the purpose of preventing such deterioration and preserving unto the owners and residents of property within the Village of Roselle of the property values now existent and to secure the beneficial interest and purpose thereof, which are the preservation and improvement of the existing standards of public health, welfare, sanitation and safety within the Village of Roselle, the following provisions are enacted. 
(b)  All new buildings shall be of an architectural design suitable for a good suburban community. No permit shall be issued for any new building, or for an improvement to an existing building which is of such architectural design, that the same is manifestly inferior or so radically different as to impair marketability or property values of existing buildings in the same immediate vicinity. Freestanding buildings and buildings fronting on more than one street shall have the same material or architecturally harmonious materials used for all exterior walls. Buildings partially freestanding shall have the same material or architecturally harmonious materials used for exposed exterior walls and exposed portions of exterior walls. Single-family residences located adjacent to each other shall be varied in design and shape so as to avoid the appearance of being identical. These considerations shall apply to the R-1, R-2, R-2A and R-2B districts. 
(c)  The identical exterior elevation cannot be repeated oftener than every fifth building. This consideration shall apply in the R-1, R-2, R-2A and R-2B districts. 
(d)  To promote and protect property values, the use of metal siding from grade level to roof eaves shall be prohibited within the B-1, B-2, B-3, B-4, B-5, ORI and M zoning districts, unless each wall section shall have a both a minimum area of fifty (50) percent and a minimum height of fifty (50) percent from grade to eave, of masonry, wooden veneers, concrete panel or other aggregate material as may be deemed acceptable by the village engineer or building inspector. 
(e)  Within the B-1, B-2, B-3, B-4, B-5, ORI and M zoning districts, all wall sections shall be constructed of material decorative in appearance (face brick, sculptured block are permitted and concrete panel or other aggregate material as may be deemed acceptable by the zoning administrator). 
(f)  A variance may be granted to subsections (b) through (e) of this section 6-60 by the corporate authorities of the village to allow the use of different materials, and percentages of materials, than those required when the different materials are consistent with materials used in existing structures which will remain on a property and where such use of different materials is consistent with materials used in the neighborhood in other existing structures. When considering a request for a variance under this subsection the corporate authorities shall consider the existing character of the neighborhood and whether the neighborhood is undergoing redevelopment inconsistent with the requested variance. 
(Ord. No. 59-13, Art. III, 2-22-65; Ord. No. 1412-86, ㎣ 2, 3, 2-24-86; Ord. No. 1719-88,  1, 6-27-88; Ord. No. 2007-3283,  1, 2-26-07; Ord. No. 2008-3425,  3, 12-15-08) 
Sec. 6-61. - Classification of occupancy and types of construction. 
    For purposes of this code, all building and structures shall be classified in one of the classes of occupancy which are defined as follows: 
(1)  Assembly building: A building in which persons congregate for civic, political, educational, religious, social or recreational purposes; including among others, courthouses, schools, colleges, libraries, museums, exhibition rooms, dance halls, theaters, bathhouses, armories, recreation halls, stadiums, passenger stations, bowling alleys, skating rinks, gymnasiums, grandstands, motion picture theaters, auditoriums, taverns, restaurants. 
(2)  Institutional building: A building in which persons are harbored to receive medical, charitable or other care or treatment, or in which persons are held or detained by reasons of public or civic duty, or for correctional purposes; including among others, hospitals, asylums, sanitariums, fire houses, police stations, jails, penal institutions, orphanages, infirmaries, homes for the aged, reformatories, nurseries, houses of correction. 
(3)  One-family residence building: A building designed or used for not more than one family unit, which may provide additional sleeping accommodations for not more than five (5) lodgers or boarders. 
(4)  Two-family residence building: A building arranged for two (2) separate dwelling units each to accommodate one family unit and not more than two (2) lodgers or boarders. 
(5)  Multifamily residence building: A building designed or used for three (3) or more family units, or designed or used for sleeping accommodations, other than family units, for more than five (5) persons, including among others, apartment buildings, boardinghouses, clubs, convents, dormitories, fraternities, hotels, lodging houses, monasteries, rooming houses, tourist homes. 
(6)  Business building: A building, or part thereof, designed or used for the transaction of business or for the rendering of professional service or for other services that involve only such storage of stocks of goods, wares or merchandise as is necessary to the conduct of the business, including among others, office buildings, village halls, markets, stores, shops, laundries, laboratories, telephone exchange, radio stations, cleaning establishments, automobile sales and service stations. 
(7)  Industrial building: A building, or part thereof, used primarily for manufacturing, or in which five (5) or more persons are engaged in fabricating, assembling or processing of products or materials; including among others, assembly plants, bakeries, boiler works, breweries, canneries, ice plants, manufacturing plants, processing plants, pumping plants, shops for diesel locomotives, workshops. 
(8)  Storage building: A building, or part thereof, used primarily for the storage of goods, wares or merchandise, and in which less than five (5) persons are engaged in manufacturing of products or materials; including among others, cold storage buildings, freight depots, garages, hangars, livestock shelters, warehouses. 
(9)  Hazardous use building: A building in which the contents stored or handled are liable to burn rapidly, cause an explosion or emit poisonous fumes; or in which the process conducted or the contents, alone or in combination with other materials, are liable to cause dust, flammable vapors, explosive gases or poisonous fumes. 
    When a building is occupied by two (2) or more occupancies not included in one classification, the provisions of this chapter applying to each use shall apply to such parts of the building as come within that classification. 
    All buildings built under (1) through (9) shall be built of noncombustible materials. 
(Ord. No. 59-13, Art. III, 2-22-65) 
Sec. 6-62. - Occupancy permits. 
    No building or part thereof hereafter erected, or the structure of which shall hereafter be altered or repaired and for which [an] erection, alteration, or repair permit shall be required as provided in this article, shall be occupied in whole or in part for human habitation or use until issuance of a certificate of occupancy by the building inspector, certifying that said building construction, alteration, or repair has been substantially completed in accordance with the plans upon which the building permit required by this article issued and in accordance with the building code of the village. Within five (5) days from the date of application for any such certificate, a certificate of occupancy shall be issued or the building inspector shall state in writing his reasons for a denial. Substantial completion shall be understood to include all stoops to be installed, prime coats to be applied to all exterior surfaces, and rough grading completed. 
(Ord. No. 1965-90,  1, 6-11-90) 
Sec. 6-63. - Violations. 
    Any person who violates a provision(s) of chapter 6 "Buildings" shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day. Each day a violation exists shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2008-3425,  3, 12-15-08; Ord. No. 2016-3836,  2, 3-28-16) 
Secs. 6-64-6-71. - Reserved.

Sec. 6-72. - Adoption of plumbing code. 
    The Illinois Plumbing Code (77 Ill. Admin. Code, Part 890) promulgated by the Illinois Department of Public Health, and as may be amended from time to time, is hereby adopted as the Plumbing Code of the Village of Roselle as if fully set forth in this ordinance with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes prescribed in sections 6-72.1 and 6-73 of this division. 
(Ord. No. 2690-99, ㎣ 3, 4(a), 6-17-99; Ord. No. 2008-3425, ㎣ 4, 5, 12-15-08; Ord. No. 2016-3816,  1, 1-25-16) 
Sec. 6-72.1 - Required use of watersense products. 
    Pursuant to 17 Ill. Admin. Code 3730.307(c)(4) and subject to the Illinois Plumbing Code (77 Ill. Admin. Code 890) and the Lawn Irrigation Contractor and Lawn Sprinkler System Registration Code (77 Ill. Admin. Code 892), it is hereby ordained that when available, all new and replacement plumbing fixtures and irrigation controllers installed after the effective date of this ordinance shall bear the official WaterSense label designated by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency WaterSense Program. 
(Ord. No. 2016-3816,  2, 1-25-16)
