Sec. 6-74. - Plumbing enforcement. 
    All enforcement shall be in compliance with the State Plumbing Code or in this code except when preempted. 
(Ord. No. 2008-3425,  5(c), 12-15-08) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2008-3425,  5(c), adopted December 15, 2008, repealed the former  6-74, and enacted a new  6-74 as set out herein. The former  6-74 pertained to enforcement and derived from Ord. No. 59-13, Art. IV,  4.01, 2-22-65; Ord. No. 2690-99,  5, 6-17-99. 
Sec. 6-75. - Sewer permits. 
    No private sewer shall be connected with a public sewer in the village unless a permit therefor is first obtained. Applications for such permits shall conform to the general provisions relating to licenses and permits, and shall be referred to the building inspector. 
(Ord. No. 59-13, Art. IV,  4.02, 2-22-65; Ord. No. 2690-99,  5, 6-17-99) 
Sec. 6-76. - Testing. 
(a)  Notification; certificate of approval; defective work. The entire plumbing system, when roughed in, any building, shall be tested by the plumber in the presence of the building inspector and as directed by him, under a water pressure test. The water pressure test for plumbing shall be applied by closing the lower end of the vertical pipes and filling the pipes to the highest opening above the roof with water. Special provision shall be made to include all joints and connections to the finished line or face of floors or side wells, so that all vents or revents, including lead work, may be tested with the main stacks. All pipes shall remain uncovered in every part until they have successfully passed the test. All defective pipes or fittings shall be removed and all defective work shall be made good so as to conform to the provisions of this article. 
    In the case of extension or alteration of any existing plumbing system, the same, if new stacks are run, shall be tested when roughed in and when completed, as hereinbefore provided. In other alteration work, a peppermint test, and only this test, shall be applied by using five (5) fluid ounces of oil of peppermint. 
(b)  When the plumbing in any building is ready for inspection the plumber in charge of the work shall immediately notify the building inspector in writing of such fact at least twenty-four (24) hours in advance of inspection. 
(c)  If said plumbing is approved by the building inspector, he shall issue a certificate of satisfactory inspection, but no certificate shall be issued unless all plumbing construction, fixtures, apparatus or appliances are in strict conformity with the rules and regulations herein set forth. 
(d)  All fixtures, bowls, basins, tubs, pipes and other apparatus from or through which any sewerage is discharged into any sewer pipe in any street, alley or other public place in the village shall be subject to inspection by the building inspector, and if upon inspection it shall appear that any part thereof is defective or fails to conform to the requirements of this chapter or by reason of such failure is inefficient and tends to create a nuisance, the same shall be repaired or replaced as the nature of the case may require; and if upon ten (10) days' notice in writing to the occupant of the premises where located, given by the building inspector, such repairing and replacing shall not have been done, the owner and the occupant of such premises or either of them, shall pay a fine of five dollars ($5.00) for each day after the day fixed in such notice that such replacing shall not have been done. 
(Ord. No. 59-13, Art. IV,  4.03, 2-22-65; Ord. No. 2690-99,  5, 6-17-99) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1507-56,  3, adopted December 8, 1986, repealed former  6-75, remodeling work, in its entirety. Former  6-75 derived from Ord. No. 59-13, Art. IV,  4.04, adopted February 22, 1965. 
Sec. 6-77. - Penalty. 
    Whoever unlawfully shall disturb or injure any public pipe or manhole, or catchbasin, or other appurtenance connected with any public sewer, or shall violate any of the provisions of this division, when no other penalty is provided, shall be subject to a penalty of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense, and each day said offense is allowed to continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 59-13, Art. IV,  4.05, 2-22-65; Ord. No. 2690-99,  5, 6-17-99) 
Secs. 6-78-6-89. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1507-86,  3, adopted December 8, 1986, repealed ㎣ 6-77-6-89 in their entirety. The aforesaid sections were concerned with general requirements, and derived from Ord. No. 59-13, adopted February 22, 1965; Ord. No. 355, adopted July 26, 1971; Ord. No. 467-74, adopted January 14, 1974; and Ord. No. 673-77, adopted July 5, 1977. 
 Ord. No. 2690-99,  5, adopted June 17, 1999, renumbered sections preceding the reserved designation, changing said reserved section designations from ㎣ 6-77-6-89 to ㎣ 6-78-6-89. 
Sec. 6-90. - Sewers. 
(a)  Types of connection. All connections with any sewer in any street, alley or other public place in the village shall be made by means of a Y fitting, and in every case of proposed connection to be made notice shall be given to the building inspector of the time and place, when and where the work of such connection is to commence. Such notice shall be in writing and shall be given at least one day prior to the commencement of the work. Any person making or attempting to make any such connections without first obtaining the required permit, shall upon conviction be fined in the sum of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(b)  Restoring pavement. In each case of connection so made, the street disturbed thereby shall be restored to its original condition within forty-eight (48) hours from the time the work commenced. If for any the reason the street cannot be restored to its original condition within forty-eight (48) hours the person responsible for the work being done shall notify the village. 
(c)  Sewer pipe defined. "Sewer pipe" in this division shall mean any pipe to be used for the carrying off of sewerage, such as the waste water from any washbowl or basin or sink, or other waste, or the outflow from any closet and bathroom through soil pipe or other waste pipe of any kind. 
(d)  Pipes for connections. All connections shall be made with public sewer with vitrified tile pipe no less than six (6) inches in diameter, and such pipe shall be provided with seal joints meeting ASTM designation C425 Type I. Sewer within the building and to a point three (3) feet outside of building wall shall be not less than four (4) inch extra heavy cast-iron pipe. There shall be a suitable cleanout installed at the foot of each stack and one on the main sewer located within two (2) feet of front wall of the basement, and shall project to floor level. All sewers whether inside or outside of building to be left uncovered until inspection is made. Tile sewer may be used for private garages. 
(e)  Old and separate connections. The entire plumbing and drainage system of every building shall be entirely separate and independent from that of any other building, except where there are two (2) buildings on one lot, one in the rear of the other. Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the village engineer, to meet all requirements of this division. 
(f)  Vaults. No connection from any cesspool or privy vault shall be allowed to be made with any public or private sewer pipe. 
(g)  Prohibited use. No butcher's offal or garbage, dead animals or obstruction of any kind whatever, shall be passed through or deposited in any receiving basin or sewer in the village. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to a penalty of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. 
(h)  Stop water drains. Rain spouts or roof leaders shall not be connected to any sanitary sewer, trunk line or branch thereof. 
(i)  Hot water. No water of a higher temperature than one hundred twenty (120) degrees Fahrenheit shall be permitted to enter any house sewer direct. 
(j)  Penalty. Any person, firm or corporation violating or failing to comply with any of the provisions of this Code shall, where no other penalty is provided, be fined not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. 
(k)  Septic tank. Where septic tanks are installed they shall comply with county code. Person must notify the village before installing the system. A certificate of acceptance from the county is required before a permit will be issued. 
(l)  Hot water heater. To have a ten-year guarantee. 
(m)  Overhead sewers. All new buildings with basements, floors, rooms or habitable areas below ground level at the building site and served by the public or private sewer system, shall have overhead sewers, except with written permission of the village. When overhead sewers are required, a second sump pump is necessary to discharge the basement floor drains and laundry tray. This pump is connected to the sanitary sewer. 
(Ord. No. 59-13, Art. IV,  4.19, 2-22-65; Ord. No. 522-75,  2, 1-27-75; Ord. No. 1000-81,  1, 3-9-81) 
Sec. 6-91. - Water supply. 
(a)  Tapping of water main. Any water main located within village limits of Roselle shall be tapped by the village superintendent or in his presence. All taps to be one inch. One-inch water service to the meter shall be provided. 
(b)  Shutoff box. Shall be of type specified by village and have rod and spacer. 
(c)  Water service. Shall be one-inch (I.D.) Type K copper tubing only. Shall have one-inch gate valve as a shutoff, one valve each side of meter. The incoming waterline is to be extended minimum four (4) feet above the floor on an inside wall. It is to be fastened to the wall with copper pipe straps two (2) feet O.C. The meter in all cases is to be above any obstacle that may block its installation or repair. 
(d)  Water meter. Location of meter shall be determined by plumbing inspector and have a shutoff valve located on both sides of meter not more than one foot away from meter. 
(1)  A telephone jack, type R-J-11, or equivalent, shall be installed in all new construction requiring a water meter. 
(e)  Water pipes. Shall be of galvanized steel pipe or of copper tubing. 
(f)  Air chambers. Shall be installed on all water supply connections to plumbing fixtures and shall not be less than twelve (12) inches in length. 
(g)  Relief valves. Shall be installed on all hot water heaters and shall be of the temperature and pressure type. The relief valve shall be installed on hot water side and not more than six (6) inches from the heater. Shutoff valve shall be installed on cold water line and not more than six (6) inches from the heater. Shutoff valve shall be installed on cold water line. 
(h)  Submerged water supply. No plumbing fixture shall be installed unless water supply enters said fixture at least two (2) inches above any overflow connection. 
(i)  Wells. 
(1)  The type construction and location of wells shall be in accordance with the recommendations of the State of Illinois Department of Health. 
(2)  In all cases where wells are used as a source of water supply, the construction and location of the wells shall be approved by the building inspector and before any water is used from said wells, a sample of said water shall be submitted to the building inspector and said building inspector shall submit said sample to the State of Illinois Department of Health and shall not permit the use of said well for drinking purposes until the State of Illinois Department of Health has indicated its approval of said water as being fit for use, and an occupancy permit for any building which has for its water supply a well shall not be issued until approval of the water supply shall have been obtained. 
(Ord. No. 59-13, Art. IV,  4.20, 2-22-65; Ord. No. 445-73, ㎣ 2, 3, 8-27-73; Ord. No. 828-79,  2, 2-26-79; Ord. No. 2104-91,  1, 7-22-91) 
Sec. 6-92. - Water softeners. 
(a)  All persons engaged in the business of selling, servicing or installing water softeners shall obtain a permit from the village for such activity. The fee for such permit shall be ten dollars ($10.00) plus an additional five dollars ($5.00) should more than one inspection become necessary. 
    A surety bond in the amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) to insure faithful performance and compliance with the ordinances of the village shall be required at the time of issuance of such permit. 
(b)  The following regulations shall apply to all water softeners installed in the village: 
(1)  The waste line from any water softener shall not be connected directly to any sewer, soil, waste or vent line. 
(2)  All water softeners shall be installed with a trapped outlet with an open site connection from the softener. 
(3)  Every softener shall have a valved bypass on the water supply so that the failure of the water softener will not interfere with water service to the building. All work shall comply with the provisions of the National Electrical Code. 
(4)  All softeners shall be installed with unions or flare disconnect types of water connections to allow ease of disconnection of the softener and servicing equipment. 
(c)  Any person, firm or corporation who violates, disobeys, neglects or refuses to comply with the provisions of this ordinance shall upon conviction be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense. 
(Ord. No. 430-73, ㎣ 1-3, 5-14-73; Ord. No. 2008-3425,  5(d), 12-15-08) 
Editor's note- This section 6-92, included herein at the direction of the village, was derived from Ord. No. 430-73, adopted May 14, 1973. This ordinance was previously codified as Division 14 of Chapter 9 of the Code. 
Sec. 6-93. - Water recycling systems. 
(a)  Air conditioners. In all new construction and in all new remodeling, water cooled air conditioners shall be of the closed system type. 
(b)  Car washes. In all newly constructed and in all new remodeling, drive-through automobile laundry installations (i.e. car washes) shall be equipped with a water recycling system. 
(Ord. No. 1194-83,  1, 11-7-83) 
Sec. 6-94. - Sump pumps. 
(a)  No sump pumps shall be installed and connected so as to discharge stormwater runoff onto adjoining property, or upon any street or public way, nor shall any such sump pump be connected to a sanitary sewer. 
(1)  Single-family residential: Sump pump discharge shall be piped through the rear wall and directed toward the rear yard. Discharge other than the above must be reviewed and approved by the village engineer. Approvable concepts for review are: discharge to a detention/retention facility, connections to stormwater systems such as storm sewers or back of curb drains, ditch where no curbs or storm sewers exist. Proven alternatives will be considered by the village engineer upon request. Plan approval will be dependent upon floor elevation, surrounding grades, building location, proximity to stormwater facilities and their respective elevations. 
(2)  Multifamily, commercial, industrial: Sump pump discharge shall be properly connected to the storm sewer system, reviewed and approved by the village engineer. 
(b)  No sump pump discharge shall ever be connected to the sanitary sewer system. The fine for such is one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per offense per day. 
(Ord. No. 1418-86, ㎣ 2-4, 3-10-86) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1418-86 added  6-92, which the editor has redesignated  6-94 since the Code already contained ㎣ 6-92, 6-93. 
Secs. 6-95-6-101. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ELECTRICITY 

Sec. 6-102. - Adoption of electrical code. 
    That National Electric Code, 2008 edition, as amended, published by the National Fire Protection Association; is hereby adopted as the Electrical Code of the Village of Roselle as if fully set forth in this division with the additions, insertions, deletions, and changes prescribed in section 6-103 of this division. 
(Ord. No. 2690-99, ㎣ 6, 7(a), 6-17-99; Ord. No. 2008-3425, ㎣ 6, 7(a), 12-15-08) 
Sec. 6-103. - Additions, insertions and changes. 
    That the National Electric Code 2008 is hereby amended and revised as follows: 
1.  The following articles of said Code are hereby deleted in their entirety: 
a.  Article 320 - Armored Cable: Type AC 
b.  Article 328 - Medium Voltage Cable: Type MV 
c.  Article 330 - Metal-Clad Cable: Type MC 
d.  Article 334 - Nonmetallic-Sheathed Cable: Types NM, NMC, and NMS 
e.  Article 338 - Service Entrance Cable: Types SE and USE 
f.  Article 348 - Flexible Metal Conduit: Type FMC 
g.  Article 362 - Electrical Nonmetallic Tubing: Type ENT 
h.  Article 382 - Nonmetallic Extensions 
i.  Article 388 - Surface Nonmetallic Raceways 
j.  Article 394 - Concealed Knob-and-Tube Wiring 
k.  Article 398 - Open Wiring on Insulators 
l.  Article 604 - Manufactured Wiring Systems 
2.  Article 605-Office Furnishings: That Article 605 entitled "Office Furnishings (consisting of lighting accessories and wired partitions) including sub-Section 605-1 through 605-8 is hereby deleted in its entirety and replaced with a new 605-1, which shall be entitled "Office Furnishings" and shall read; "All office furnishings shall be hard wired and served by junction boxes. Junction boxes shall not be hidden or enclosed within partitions or other portions of the office furnishings, but shall remain open as to permit inspection. Three duplex receptacle per one person cubicle." 
(Ord. No. 2690-99, ㎣ 6, 7(b), 6-17-99; Ord. No. 2008-3425, ㎣ 6, 7(b), 12-15-08) 
Sec. 6-104. - Compliance. 
    It shall be unlawful to install any electrical wiring or equipment in the village except in compliance with the provisions of the code adopted in section 6-102, provided that the provisions of this code shall not be applicable to Illinois power supply companies or communication agencies in respect to the generation. Exceptions: The use of armored cable shall be limited to flexible connections of not to exceed three (3) feet. 
(Ord. No. 2233-92,  2, 8-24-92; Ord. No. 2008-3425,  7(c), 12-15-08) 
Editor's note- Sections 6-102 and 6-103 were originally derived from Ord. No. 59-13, sections 5.01 and 5.02, as amended by Ord. No. 463-74, adopted January 7, 1974. These sections were replaced with the provisions now set out as sections 6-102 and 6-103 pursuant to the directions of the village. 
Sec. 6-105. - Additional electrical requirements. 
(a)  All new electrical installation shall be piped in EMT or rigid conduit. 
(b)  All service entrances conductors shall be enclosed in rigid galvanized conduit or rigid aluminum conduit to the point of disconnect. 
(c)  Service for single-family dwellings up to one thousand five hundred (1,500) square feet shall have a minimum of one-hundred (100) ampere rating with a minimum thirty (30) circuit positions. Single-family dwellings between one thousand five hundred one (1,501) to three thousand four hundred ninety-nine (3,499) square feet shall have a minimum of 200 ampere rating with a minimum of forty circuit positions. Single-family dwellings of three thousand five hundred or over shall have a minimum of a 400 ampere rating with a minimum of eighty (80) circuit positions. 
(d)  Installation of 100 Amp shall consist of 3 - #3 THWN conductors in 11/4' rigid conduit. Installation of 200 Amp shall consist of 3 - #3/0 THWN conductors in 2' rigid conduit. Installation of 400 Amp shall consist of two 200 amp with a main breaker located outside in the meter socket. 
(e)  Rigid galvanized conduit shall be used in all concrete slabs and outside construction. 
(f)  All electrical installations shall be UL listed. 
(g)  All emergency lighting shall be equipped with one and one-half (11/2) hour battery backup - lights shall be all glass and metal construction and two-hour rated. Exist lights shall be metal case, plastic lens LED or equal. Examples of approved LED fixtures include Cooper SLX 70RWH and Astra lite, model #3200 with LED metal case, and plastic lens or equivalent. This requirement shall apply even if a generator is in place. 
(h)  All closets and storage areas over six (6) square feet shall be equipped with florescent or recessed can light fixtures. 
(i)  Grounding electrode conductors shall be bonded to the street side of the water meter with a bonding jumper across meter, unless otherwise approved by the electrical inspector. 
(j)  Renewable fuses are prohibited. 
(k)  All services shall be installed with a main breaker. Sequence switching is prohibited and all disconnects shall be within five (5) feet of a building entrance. 
(l)  It shall be unlawful for any person(s) to over fuse any conductor motor or apparatus in excess of the maximum permitted by the electrical code. 
(m)  All commercial and industrial work shall use minimum #12 current carrying conductors. 
(n)  No lighting or switching less than eight (8) feet above the floor shall exceed one hundred fifty (150) volts to ground. 
(o)  All garages shall have a minimum of two (2) GFI protected outlet receptacles; three (3) GFI protected outlet receptacles for three-car garages, on different walls and one (1) in ceiling for each garage door. 
(p)  All fire alarm cable run in free air shall be UL listed for free air runs and red in color. When conduit is used, fire alarm conduit shall be RED from manufacturer. 
(q)  Ceiling boxes located in bedrooms, family rooms, studies, or where a fan could be installed shall be UL listed fan boxes. 
(r)  All feeds run to roof top air conditioning or heating units shall run outside the unit and shall not run through it. 
(s)  When a three-quarter conduit enters a box, a deep 1900 box shall be used except where the conduit is used for phone or data. 
(t)  Extension boxes are prohibited. 
(u)  PVC conduit shall be allowed outside the building (four (4) walls) and below grade only. 
(v)  Dishwashers and disposals shall not be cord connected when permanently installed. 
(w)  All commercial or industrial electrical panels shall have bolt on breakers. 
(x)  A panel mounted surge protector shall be installed for all residential installations including service revisions. 
(y)  All panels shall have a main breaker. No sub panels are allowed. 
(z)  All panels shall have fifteen (15) percent spare space for future use. 
(aa)  All electrical work shall be done by a licensed electrician unless it is a homeowner working on his personally occupied dwelling unit. 
(bb)  Outdoor electrical outlets shall use approved outdoor covers that are sunlight resistant or metal. 
(cc)  All unused electric equipment such as conduit, wire voice, data cables, and fixtures must be removed. 
(Ord. No. 2690-99,  7, 6-17-99; Ord. No. 2008-3425,  7, 12-15-08) 
Secs. 6-106-6-113. - Reserved.

DIVISION 7. - FIRE LIMITS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Adoption of Basic Building Code,  6-26; fire limits established,  6-28. 

Sec. 6-256. - Boundaries. 
    All property within the village zoned for any use other than residential use is hereby declared to be and established as the fire limits of the village. 
(Ord. No. 59-13, Art. XVII,  17.01, 2-22-65) 
Sec. 6-257. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 6-257, which was originally derived from Ord. No. 59-13, Art. XVII,  17.02, has been deleted. Said section was superseded by Ord. No. 392-72, adopted 7-24-72 and Ord. No. 74-502, adopted 10-7-74. These ordinances appear in this chapter as Article II. 
Sec. 6-258. - Moving buildings. 
    It shall be unlawful to move into the fire limits any wooden building which could not be constructed in the fire limits within the fire limits within the provisions of this division; and it shall be unlawful to move any such wooden building from one location or lot in the first limits to another location or lot within the fire limits. 
(Ord. No. 59-13, Art. XVII,  17.03, 2-22-65) 
Sec. 6-259. - Damaged buildings. 
    It shall be unlawful to remodel or reconstruct any wooden building or structure, in the fire limits, which has been damaged or injured or become decayed to the extent of fifty (50) percent of its total value. In the case of any decay, damage or injury to any such building, where a permit to reconstruct is sought, the president shall appoint an impartial person who together with the building inspector and the owner of the damaged building shall act as a committee to determine the extent of the damage done. If this committee shall determine that the building is damaged to the extent of fifty (50) percent of its value no permit for reconstruction or' remodeling shall be issued. 
(Ord. No. 59-13, Art. XVII,  17.04, 2-22-65) 
Secs. 6-260-6-269. - Reserved.

DIVISION 9. - GRADING, SIDEWALKS AND DRIVEWAYS 

Sec. 6-297. - Grading. 
    Grading or drainage or both shall be performed so that water will drain away from the building on all sides and off the lot in a manner which will provide reasonable freedom from erosion and pocketed surface water. Construction such as walks, driveways and retaining walls shall be installed so that they will not interfere with drainage. 
    There shall be a permit required, issued by the Roselle Building Department, for any excavation or any change in grades, whether or not in connection with a proposed building or structure. There shall be submitted a drainage plan showing facilities for channeling and discharge of storm water, in such detail as may be required by the building official, a plan or description of any bracing, shoring, piling or other safety structures required. The building inspector shall examine applications for permits and shall submit safety and drainage plans to the village engineer for examination and approval within a reasonable time after filing. If, after examination, the village engineer finds no objections to the same and it appears that the proposed work will be in compliance with the laws and ordinances applicable thereto, and the proposed construction or work will be safe, he shall approve such application and issue a permit for the proposed work as soon as practicable. 
(Ord. No. 59-13, Art. XX,  20.01, 2-22-65; Ord. No. 252-69,  1, 2-24-69; Ord. No. 590-75,  2, 12-8-75) 
Sec. 6-298. - Sidewalks. 
    Public sidewalks shall be five (5) feet in width, set a minimum of six (6) inches above crown of road and one foot outside of lot line. All walks shall be five-inch concrete, six (6) bag mix, placed on a two-inch bed of crushed limestone or crushed gravel. All sidewalk crossing driveways shall be reinforced with six (6) by six (6) #6 wire mesh. Sidewalk that crosses utility trenches shall be reinforced with four (4) #4 ten-foot zero inch reinforcing bars, equally spaced and equally spanning the trench. 
(Ord. No. 59-13, Art. XX,  20.02, 2-22-65; Ord. No. 191-66,  1, 8-22-66; Ord. No. 238-68,  1, 7-22-68; Ord. No. 252-69,  1, 2-24-69; Ord. No. 509-74,  1, 11-18-74) 
Sec. 6-299. - Driveways and parking areas. 
    Driveways and parking areas shall be improved with a base and surfaced with a hard-surfaced, all weather, dustless material in accordance with the village standards and specifications. 
Editor's note- The above section reads as herein set out pursuant to the request of the village. Formerly, the section was derived from Ord. No. 59-13, section 20.03, as amended by Ord. No. 252-69, adopted February 24, 1969. 
Sec. 6-300. - Culverts. 
    A metal corrugated culvert to be installed before construction starts; size (minimum twelve-inch) to be specified by building inspector from watershed data supplied by village engineer. 
(Ord. No. 59-13, Art. XX,  20.04, 2-22-65; Ord. No. 252-69,  1, 2-24-69) 
Secs. 6-301-6-518. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 10. - FENCES[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 1416-86, adopted Mar. 3, 1986, repealed former Div. 32, ㎣ 6-519-6-531, derived from Ord. No. 595-76, ㎣ 1-12, 14, adopted Jan. 12, 1976, and added a new division, ㎣ 6-519-6-527. 

Sec. 6-519. - Title. 
    This division shall be known as, referred to and cited as the Fence Ordinance of the Village of Roselle, Illinois. 
(Ord. No. 1416-86,  1, 3-3-86) 
Sec. 6-520. - Purpose and intent. 
    The purpose of a fence is to provide privacy, security, boundary definition, aesthetic appearance, weather control (snow fencing), decoration and safety for the residents of the village and for the various land uses within the corporate limits of the village. The intent of the regulations is to provide a framework for the protection of public and private property through the regulation of the installation, construction and placement of fences on such property. 
(Ord. No. 1416-86,  1, 3-3-86) 
Sec. 6-521. - Rules and definitions. 
(a)  All provisions contained herein shall relate only to those areas within the applicant's property lines. 
(b)  The language set forth in the text of this article shall be interpreted in accordance with the following rules of construction: 
(1)  Words used in the present tense shall include the future and the past tenses, and words used in the future tense shall include the present. 
(2)  Words in the singular number include the plural number, and words in the plural number include the singular number. 
(3)  The phrase "used for" shall include the phrases "arranged for," "designed for," "intended for," "maintained for" and "occupied for." 
(4)  The word "shall" is mandatory. 
(5)  The word "may" is permissive. 
(6)  The words "yard" or "yards" when used in this division shall refer to those yard requirements and definitions as are set forth in the Roselle Zoning Ordinance, 1985, as amended [see appendix A]. 
(c)  The following words and terms, wherever they occur in this division, shall be interpreted as herein defined: 
(1)  Fence, structural. A structure which is a barrier and is used as a boundary or means of protection or confinement, which is made of manufactured material, such as but not limited to chainlink, wood or stone material. This definition shall not be construed to include dog runs. 
(2)  Fence, natural. A series or group of plantings which forms a barrier, is used as a boundary, or is used as a means of protection or confinement, which is made of natural growth such as shrubs, evergreens, hedges, etc., planted less than ten (10) feet apart and exceeding thirty (30) inches in height. 
(3)  Fence, decorational. That type of fence which is purely for decorational purposes only and is not intended in any way to be used as an enclosure, barrier, or means of protection or confinement. Such decorative fences shall be not more than forty-eight (48) inches in height and shall in no way interfere with vision. No permit shall be required for such fence. 
(4)  Fence, privacy. A structural fence which is designed to screen a patio, deck or swimming pool. 
(5)  Fence, split rail. An undressed fence rail split lengthwise from a wooden log and set at either end into an upright post. For the purposes of definition, a split rail fence shall be classified as a decorational fence. 
(6)  Yard, front. A yard extending along the full length of the front lot line between the side lot lines. On a corner lot, the front yard is also considered to extend along the corner side lot line from the front yard to the rear lot line. 
(7)  Yard, side. A yard extending along a side lot line from the front yard to the rear yard. 
a.  Yard, corner side (also side yard adjoining a street). A yard extending along the corner side lot line from the front yard to the rear lot line. 
b.  Yard, interior side. A yard extending along the interior side lot line from the front yard to the rear yard. 
(8)  Yard, rear. A yard extending along the full length of the rear lot line between the side lot lines. On a corner lot, the rear yard extends along the rear lot lines between the interior side lot line and the corner side yard. 
(9)  Dog run. Any fenced area intended to enclose a dog. 
(10)  Street. A public or private right-of-way which affords a primary means for vehicular access to abutting properties, whether designated as a street, avenue, highway, road, boulevard, lane, throughway, or however otherwise designated, but excepting driveways to buildings. 
(Ord. No. 1416-86,  1, 3-3-86) 
Sec. 6-522. - Permits, application, fee. 
(a)  Permit required to erect or alter fence. No fence shall be erected or altered until a permit has been secured from the village by the person desiring to erect or alter such fence. 
(b)  Application requirements. Plans drawn to scale, a plat of survey, and specifications showing work to be done and location of proposed fence on the owner's premises shall be submitted with each application for a building (fence) permit. 
(c)  Permit fee. The fee for permits issued for the erection or alteration of structural fences shall be twenty dollars ($20.00). 
(Ord. No. 1416-86,  1, 3-3-86) 
Sec. 6-523. - General provisions. 
(a)  No fence, structural or otherwise, shall be allowed on any part of a required front yard or side yard adjoining a street in any zoning district except as specifically stated elsewhere in this division. Fences shall be allowed in a side yard as long as they do not extend beyond the first floor living area, except when specifically permitted elsewhere in this division. For purposes of this division, a first floor living area shall not include a garage. A side yard fence may attach at a single point to a garage so long as the fence does not extend in front of the first floor living area. 
(b)  All structural fences shall provide a clear sight distance easement in accordance with the provisions of section 4.06 E. of the Roselle Zoning Ordinance [see appendix A]. 
(c)  Where there is a change in grade between adjoining lots, fences shall be measured from the height of the average grade measured within six (6) feet on either side of the line where the fence is to be erected. If the grade change is greater than one foot, a cross section of the property along the two (2) lots where the fence is to be erected shall be prepared, reviewed and approved as part of the permit application for the erection of a fence. 
(d)  Fences shall be designed and constructed to resist a horizontal wind pressure of not less than thirty-five (35) pounds per square foot in addition to all other forces to which they may be subjected. 
(e)  Fences must be erected so that the posts and all other supporting members face to the owner's side. The rough part of a fence shall face the owner's property. This restriction shall not apply in the case of a fence erected by a residential district property owner on the lot line abutting an agricultural, business, office-research or industrial district, nor in the case of a residential property abutting an alley separating a residential district from said districts. 
(f)  No fence, wall or shrubbery may be erected, constructed or maintained on any portion of a lot where the natural stormwater runoff would be impeded or where such fence would interfere with drainage of contiguous properties. 
(g)  Barbed wire shall only be allowed in conformance with the requirements of the Roselle Zoning Ordinance. 
(h)  The use of electrically charged fences is prohibited except in the agricultural district to enclose animal grazing areas. 
(i)  Spikes, sharply pointed pickets (of any material), broken glass, etc., shall not be used; and any fence construction which presents sharp, potentially hazardous surfaces is prohibited (including chainlink fences without top rails). 
(j)  No fence, structural or otherwise, shall be erected, planted or otherwise located within the right-of-way of any street within the village. 
(k)  Fire hydrants shall not be blocked by fence or bushes. 
(l)  Temporary fences, e.g., snow fences, construction site enclosures, safety fences pursuant to other ordinances, and the like, shall be deemed to be exempt from the provisions of this division. 
(m)  Maintenance of fences governed by the provisions of this division shall be the duty of the occupant and/or owner of the property upon which such fence is located. All fences erected shall be well maintained. Proper maintenance shall include but is not limited to painting, resetting of nails, trimming of natural fences, and repair of broken or weak boards, posts, torn chain link, etc. 
(n)  All permanent fences which are in existence at the time of passage of this division, but which do not conform to one or more applicable provisions of this division, shall be allowed to remain until such time as they are damaged or removed. If repaired or replaced, that portion or portions shall be made to comply with the requirements of this division. Natural fences shall be maintained and trimmed in such manner as to not become a nuisance, hazard or vision clearance obstruction. 
(Ord. No. 1416-86,  1, 3-3-86; Ord. No. 2134-91,  1, 11-25-91; Ord. No. 2001-2859,  1, 7-23-01) 
Sec. 6-524. - Fences in the residence and agricultural districts. 
(a)  Structural fences shall not exceed six (6) feet in height when located in a side or rear yard. When located in a front yard or corner side yard the following limitations shall apply: 
(1)  Shall not exceed three (3) feet in height. 
(2)  Shall be at least seventy (70) percent open. 
(3)  Shall not interfere with vision clearance on corner lots (see section 4.06(E) of the Roselle Zoning Ordinance) [appendix A]. 
(b)  Natural fences shall not be restricted as to height when located in a side or rear yard. When located in a front yard or corner side yard, the following limitations shall apply: 
(1)  On either side of a driveway or alley, natural fences shall not exceed forty-two (42) inches in height for a distance of ten (10) feet measured in any direction from the intersection of the driveway of alley lines with a public walk or established street pavement line where sidewalks do not exist. 
(2)  On corner lots, natural fences shall not exceed three (3) feet in height for a distance of twenty-five (25) feet in either direction as measured along the intersecting street right-of-way lines (see section 4.06(E) of the Roselle Zoning Ordinance), or from that intersecting point to the front building lines, whichever is shorter. 
(3)  No person shall maintain a hedge or shrub or tree on any portion of this property which interferes with clear view of traffic or pedestrians by drivers on streets or in driveways. 
(c)  Privacy fences to screen a deck or patio shall not exceed eight (8) feet. Such a fence shall be allowed without a permit if it meets both of the following conditions: 
(1)  It does not extend more than five (5) feet beyond the perimeter of the deck or patio. 
(2)  It is not located in a required yard. 
(d)  Recreational fences shall conform to the following requirements: 
(1)  Private residential swimming pools shall be completely enclosed by a structural fence in accordance with the provisions of section 6-562, "Fences" of the Roselle Building Code. 
(2)  Tennis courts may be totally enclosed with an open-type fence (at least eighty (80) percent open, e.g., chainlink or woven wire fence without slats) not to exceed ten (10) feet in height and located in conformance with the requirements for detached accessory buildings contained in the several zoning districts of the Roselle Zoning Ordinance. 
(3)  All other fence-type enclosures for recreational facilities shall be approved by the zoning board of appeals in accordance with the procedures established for variations in the Roselle Zoning Ordinance. 
(e)  Dog runs shall not be located in required front yards or corner side yards, nor within five (5) feet of a side lot line. A dog run shall be limited to not more than seven (7) feet in height. Dog runs shall not be classed as a fence for the other portions of this division, except that a fence permit is required. 
(Ord. No. 1416-86,  1, 3-3-86) 
Sec. 6-525. - Fences in the business, office-research, and industrial districts. 
(a)  Fences, structural or otherwise, shall not be located in a front yard or corner side yard. When located in a side or rear yard, a fence shall not exceed ten (10) feet in height. 
(b)  Fences abutting residential lots shall be set back from the lot line a sufficient distance to screen the fence from residential lots with natural plantings. 
(c)  All fences exceeding six (6) feet in height shall have regularly spaced apertures to provide adequate wind passage and aesthetic appearance. 
(Ord. No. 1416-86,  1, 3-3-86) 
Sec. 6-526. - Administration. 
    The zoning administrator, as established in the Roselle Zoning Ordinance [appendix A], shall be in charge of the administration and enforcement of this division. In furtherance thereof, the zoning administrator shall exercise supervision over all fences erected, altered, constructed or maintained, and to cause inspection by inspectors of all fences to be made. Whenever it shall appear to the inspector that any such fence or any part thereof has been erected in violation of this division or of any condition or has become unstable or insecure or is in such a condition as to be a menace to the safety or health of the public, he shall thereupon issue or cause to be issued a notice in writing to the owner of such fence, or to the person maintaining the same, or to the owner of the property upon which the fence is being placed, informing such person, firm or corporation of the violation of this division and the dangerous condition of such fence, and directing him to make such alterations or repairs thereto and to do such acts or things as are necessary or advisable to cause such fence to be brought into a safe, substantial and secure condition, and to make the same comply with the requirements of this division, within such reasonable time as may be stated in the notice. Any and all fences installed or maintained in violation of this division, or any of the clauses or provisions of the same, or in violation of any of the laws of the village or the state are declared to be public nuisance and subject to treatment and abatement as such. Any such fence so erected or maintained contrary to law shall be abated as common nuisance. 
    In addition to the declaration that a fence has become a nuisance under the provisions of this division, any person, firm or corporation who violates any provision of this division shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined in accordance with the general provision of this Code of Ordinances relating to fines for violations of the provisions herein. 
(Ord. No. 1416-86,  1, 3-3-86) 
Cross reference- General penalty,  1-8. 
Sec. 6-527. - Variation. 
(a)  The zoning board of appeals may, after a public hearing and a recommendation by the plan commission and with the limitation hereinafter set forth, vary the provisions of this division in cases in which there are, by reason of an exceptional situation topography, surroundings or condition of a specific piece of property, or by reason of exceptional narrowness or shallowness, difficulties or particular hardship in the way of carrying out the strict letter thereof, provided that such variation will not impair an adequate supply of light and air to adjacent property or endanger the public safety, or unreasonably diminish or impair established property values within the surrounding area, or in any other respect impair the public health, safety, comfort, morals or welfare of the inhabitants of the village. 
(b)  A written petition for a variation under this section shall be filed in the community development department upon such forms as may be prescribed by the zoning board of appeals and shall be accompanied by a filing fee in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00). The zoning administrator shall give written notice of the filing of such petition to the owners of all contiguous property and also to the owners of all properties across a street, alley, easement (public or private), of any type, immediately opposite the subject property. Such notice shall show the date of the public hearing, a description of the type of fence and the nature of the variation requested. The public hearing may not be held sooner than fifteen (15) days from the date of mailing or other delivery of the notice. 
(Ord. No. 1416-86,  1, 3-3-86) 
Secs. 6-528-6-540. - Reserved.

DIVISION 13. - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2110-91, 1, adopted Aug. 26, 1991, amended the Code by repealing Art. III, Div, 13, ㎣ 6-585-6-588, which pertained to antenna towers and derived from Ord. No. 431-73, ㎣ 1-3, adopted May 29, 1973. Said ordinance also renumbered Divs. 14-17 as Divs. 13-16. See the Code Comparative Table for a detailed analysis of inclusion. 

Sec. 6-610. - Property maintenance requirement. 
    The requirements of this division shall be applicable to the following zoning districts of the Village of Roselle: B-1, B-2, B-3, B-4, B-5, M, ORI, R-3, R-4. 
(Ord. No. 1585-87,  2, 7-13-87; Ord. No. 2002-90,  1, 10-8-90) 
Sec. 6-611. - Maintenance of public access areas. 
    All sidewalks, steps, driveways, parking spaces and similar paved areas for public use shall be kept in a proper state of repair and free of all hazardous conditions. All parking areas with four (4) or more spaces shall have the spaces clearly delineated with paint striping. Wheel stops must be in their proper place in good condition and permanently affixed. If any sidewalk, driveway, or parking area or any portion thereof by virtue of its state of repair shall constitute a danger to public health and safety, the sidewalk, driveway, or parking area or portion thereof shall be replaced by the owner. Steps shall comply with the requirements for exterior stairs. 
(Ord. No. 1585-87,  2, 7-13-87) 
Sec. 6-612. - Exterior landscaping. 
    All properties shall be free from litter, garbage, and other debris. All landscaping and plant materials shall be neatly trimmed and free from weeds. Appropriate care and maintenance of plant material shall be provided to keep such growth alive and in good condition; diseased or dead plant material shall be replaced. 
(Ord. No. 1585-87,  2, 7-13-87) 
Sec. 6-613. - Parking and loading areas. 
    All parking and loading areas, automobile services stations, drive-in food establishments, and any other establishment providing on-site parking or driveway areas shall be paved with bituminous, concrete, or equivalent surfacing and shall be free from potholes, dirt and other litter and kept in good repair. Safe traffic flow shall be ensured through the use of directional arrows and signage. When lighted for nighttime use, lights shall not be permitted to face directly upon dwellings nearby. 
(Ord. No. 1585-87,  2, 7-13-87) 
Sec. 6-614. - Exterior structure. 
(a)  General. The exterior of a structure shall be maintained in good repair, structurally sound and sanitary so as not to pose a threat to the health, safety or welfare of the occupants and so as to protect the occupants from the adverse effects of the environment. 
(b)  Street numbers. Each structure to which a street number has been assigned shall have the number so assigned displayed in a position easily observed and readable from the public right-of-way. 
(c)  Structural members. All supporting structural members of all structures shall be kept structurally sound, free of deterioration and maintained capable of safely bearing the dead and live loads imposed upon them. 
(d)  Exterior surfaces (foundations, walls and roof). Every foundation, exterior wall, roof, and all other exterior surfaces shall be maintained in a workmanlike state of maintenance and repair and shall be kept in such condition as to exclude rats. 
(e)  Foundation walls. All foundation walls shall be maintained so as to carry the safe design and operating dead and live loads and shall be maintained plumb and free from open cracks and breaks, so as not to be detrimental to public safety and welfare. 
(f)  Exterior walls. Every exterior wall shall be free of holes, breaks, loose or rotting boards or timbers, and any other conditions which might admit rain or dampness to the interior portions of the walls or to the occupied spaces of the building. All exterior surface materials, including wood, composition, or metal siding, shall be maintained weatherproof and shall be properly surface coated when required to prevent deterioration. 
(g)  Roofs and drainage. The roof shall be structurally sound, tight, and not have defects which might admit rain. Roof drainage shall be adequate to prevent rain water from causing dampness or deterioration in the walls or interior portion of the building. Roof water shall not be discharged in a manner that creates a nuisance to owners or occupants of adjacent premises, or that creates a public nuisance. 
(h)  Decorative features. All cornices, entablatures, belt courses, corbels, terra cotta trim, wall facings and similar decorative features shall be maintained in good repair with proper anchorage and in a safe condition. 
(i)  Signs, marquees, and awnings. All canopies, marquees, signs, metal awnings, stairways, fire escapes, standpipes, exhaust ducts and similar overhang extensions shall be maintained in good repair and be properly anchored so as to be kept in a safe and sound condition. They shall be protected from the elements and against decay and rust by the periodic application of a weathercoating material such as paint or other protective treatment. 
(j)  Chimneys and towers. All chimneys, cooling towers, smoke stacks, and similar appurtenances shall be maintained structurally safe, sound, and in good repair. All exposed surfaces of metal or wood shall be protected from the elements and against decay or rust by periodic application of weather-coating materials such as paint or similar surface treatment. 
(k)  Stairs and porches. Every stair, porch, fire escape, balcony, and all appurtenances attached thereto shall be so constructed as to be safe to use and capable of supporting the anticipated loads and shall be maintained in sound condition and good repair. Every stair, porch and fire escape shall be maintained free of hazardous conditions such as snow, ice, mud and other debris. 
    Every flight of stairs which is more than four (4) risers high shall have a handrail on at least one side of the stair, and every open portion of a stair, fire escape, porch, landing or balcony which is more than thirty (30) inches (762 mm) above the grade below shall have guardrails. Handrails shall be not less than thirty (30) inches (762 mm) nor more than thirty-four (34) inches (864 mm) high, measured vertically above the nosing of the treads. Guardrails shall be not less than thirty (30) inches (762 mm) high above the floor of the porch, landing or balcony. Every handrail and guardrail shall be firmly fastened and capable of bearing normally imposed loads and shall be maintained in good condition. 
(Ord. No. 1585-87,  2, 7-13-87) 
Sec. 6-615. - Refuse container screens. 
(a)  Locations. All refuse containers, trash dumpsters, and compactors shall be located in rear or interior side yards as defined by the Roselle Zoning Ordinance and in a manner so as not to interfere with egress and ingress to any structure or firefighting access to the structure. Locations shall be as far from residential property as practical. 
(b)  Screening. All refuse containers and trash dumpsters, not including compactors or dumpsters temporarily located on construction sites or for village clean up days, having a capacity of more than thirty-two (32) gallons shall be screened as follows: 
(1)  All such refuse containers and trash dumpsters, having a capacity of thirty-two (32) gallons or more shall be screened from the views of public streets and from any adjacent property. Screening shall be at least as high as the container or dumpster. 
(2)  Screening materials shall consist of opaque materials constructed of brick, wood, chainlink fence with slats, building wall, earth berm, or combination thereof. Newly constructed buildings shall have screening materials compatible with the building. Compatibility, strength, appearance, and design shall be appropriate to anticipated use conditions. 
(3)  All screening immediately surrounding the container an all four (4) sides shall be maintained so as to have a six-inch opening at the bottom of a minimum of fifty (50) percent of the screening perimeter to allow air and water circulation and no harborage of vermin. 
(4)  Any gates provided shall contain devices for keeping the gates closed. Gates shall not be locked, but shall be kept closed between pickups. 
(5)  All such refuse containers and trash dumpsters not screened as of the date of the passage of this section shall be brought into compliance with the terms of this section no later than December 15, 1990 in the B, M, ORI districts and no later than July 15, 1991 in R-3 and R-4 districts. Any refuse container or trash dumpster having screening as of the date of the passage of this section shall be brought into full compliance with this section at such time as the existing screening requires repair to the extent of fifty (50) percent of the value of the screening, or when a principle building located on the property where the screening is located is remodeled to the extent of fifty (50) percent of the value of the building. 
(c)  Maintenance. Owner or user of refuse containers, trash dumpsters, and compactors shall repair or replace refuse containers, trash dumpsters, compactors and any required screening as soon as practical after damage or extreme wear. 
(d)  Permits. A building permit shall be obtained from the village prior to the construction of refuse container screening. There shall be no fee for this permit. 
(1)  The chief building inspector of the village shall review and approve all applications for screening permits. Additional or alternative screening materials, dimensions, and locations may be approved by the chief building inspector if he determines that such additions or alternatives are necessary to satisfy the purpose and intent of this section and best serve the public health and safety. 
(Ord. No. 1585-87,  2, 7-13-87; Ord. No. 1718-88,  1, 6-27-88; Ord. No. 1973-90,  1, 7-9-90; Ord. No. 2002-90,  2, 10-8-90) 
Sec. 6-616. - Enforcement. 
    Violations of this division shall be abated within ten (10) days or as determined by the building official. In determining the schedule of compliance with this division, the building official shall consider unusual circumstances and hardships. 
(Ord. No. 1585-87,  2, 7-13-87) 
Secs. 6-617-6-620. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 14. - GENERAL PROVISIONS AND AUTHORIZATION[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1585-87,  1, adopted July 13, 1987, renumbered Div. 14, General Provisions and Authorization, as Div. 15. See also the editor's note at Div. 13. 

Sec. 6-621. - General. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with, or who resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this article, shall, upon conviction, be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense and may be committed to the county jail or to any place provided by ordinance for the incarceration of offenders until the fine, penalty and costs are fully paid. No imprisonment, however, shall exceed six (6) months for any one offense. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
    In the event any building or structure constructed, reconstructed, altered, repaired, converted or maintained, or any building, structure or land used is in violation of this article, the proper local authorities of the municipality, in addition to other remedies, may institute any appropriate action or proceeding (1) to prevent the unlawful construction, reconstruction, alteration, repair, conversion, maintenance or use, (2) to prevent the occupancy of the building, structure or land, (3) to prevent any illegal act, conduct, business, or use in or about the premises or (4) to restrain, correct or abate the violation. 
(Ord. No. 59-13, Art. XXXVII,  37.01, 2-22-65) 
Sec. 6-622. - Saving clause. 
    The various provisions of this article shall be considered separable, and the invalidity of any section or portion of a section of this article shall not affect the validity of any other provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. 59-13, Art. XXXVII,  37.02, 2-22-65) 
Sec. 6-623. - Present construction. 
    Construction work under any building permit lawfully issued prior to the time this article goes into effect may continue in accordance with the provisions of the ordinances in force at the time such permit was issued. 
(Ord. No. 59-13, Art. XXXVII,  37.03, 2-22-65) 
Sec. 6-624. - Repeal. 
    All ordinances and parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby repealed; provided that nothing in this article shall be construed as repealing any portion of the zoning ordinance of the village. 
(Ord. No. 59-13, Art. XXXVII,  37.04, 2-22-65) 
Sec. 6-625. - Additional remedies. 
    In addition to the remedies and enforcement authority set forth in this division, the community development director and building inspector, when they mutually concur, shall have all other remedies and enforcement authority provided by state statute except the initiation of chancery litigation or lien foreclosure litigation which shall be only undertaken with the express authority of the corporate authorities of the village. 
(Ord. No. 2008-3425,  11, 12-15-08) 
Secs. 6-626-6-630. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 15. - HEAT AND SMOKE DETECTION AND ALARM SYSTEMS[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note- Ord No. 1637-87,  1, adopted Dec. 14, 1987, purported to amend the Code by adding Div. 15, ㎣ 6-601-6-603. Inasmuch as there already exists in the Code a Div. 15, numbered ㎣ 6-621-6-624, the provisions of said Ord. No. 1637-87 have been numbered as Div. 16, ㎣ 6-631-6-633 by the editor. See also the editor's note at Div. 13. 

Sec. 6-631. - Installation and maintenance of heat and/or smoke detection systems. 
    All heat and smoke detection systems shall be installed and maintained in accordance with the current edition of the National Fire Protection Association Pamphlet No. 72A "Standards for the Installation, Maintenance and Use of Local Protective Signaling Systems for Watchmen, Fire Alarm and Supervisory Service," the current International Building Code 2006, the National Fire Protection Association 2006 Life Safety Code, and the 2006 Edition of the International Fire Code. 
(Ord. No. 1830-89,  1, 5-22-89; Ord. No. 2008-3425,  12, 12-15-08) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1830-89,   1 adopted May 22, 1989, repealed ㎣ 6-631 and 6-632 and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out in ㎣ 6-631 and 6-632. Former ㎣ 6-631 
and 6-632 pertained to interior fire alarm systems required and installation and maintenance of heat and/or smoke detection systems and derived from Ord. No. 1637-87,  1, adopted Dec. 14, 1987. 
Section 2 of said Ordinance No. 1830-89 provides that, "The fire alarm systems and fire extinguishing equipment recited in Section 1 of this ordinance shall be installed in all uses and structures constructed from and after the date of this ordinance and shall be installed and in place in all existing structures within one (1) year from the date of this ordinance." 
Sec. 6-632. - Fire detection, fire alarm, fire extinguishing equipment for restaurants. 
    In addition to the requirements which apply to restaurants in the National Fire Protection Association 2006 Edition of the Life Safety Code, 2006 Edition of the International Building Code, and the 2006 International Fire Code, all restaurants utilizing electrical, gas or other fuel cooking equipment, such as, but not limited to ovens, deep fryers, stoves, ranges, griddles and broilers, shall have: (1) an interior fire detection and alarm system shall be connected to the Roselle Fire Department communications center, and (2) automatic fire extinguishing equipment. These provisions shall not apply to restaurants using cooking equipment such as microwaves, hot dog rollers, pop corn machines, rotisseries, pizza ovens or similar equipment, which in the opinion of the fire inspector does not constitute a fire hazard, unless such equipment utilizes an open flame or hot grease for cooking. These provisions shall apply to carry-out restaurants and food dealers when food is prepared for consumption off-premises. 
(Ord. No. 1830-89,  1, 5-22-89; Ord. No. 2008-3425,  12, 12-15-08) 
Note- See editor's note at  6-631. 
Sec. 6-633. - Residential smoke detection systems. 
    In addition, the heat and smoke detection requirements of the National Fire Protection Association, 2006 Edition of the Life Safety Code, the following requirements shall supplement for residential dwellings: 
(1)  All residential dwelling units shall contain an approved smoke detector in all sleeping rooms, in hallways within twenty (20) feet of all sleeping rooms, on all floors, including any basement. For purposes of this requirement all sleeping rooms are rooms of seventy (70) or more square feet with a closet. 
(2)  Carbon monoxide detectors shall be installed and maintained within twenty (20) feet of all sleeping rooms. Combined smoke and CO detectors can be utilized to meet the above standards. 
(Ord. No. 1637,  1, 12-14-87; Ord. No. 2008-3425,  12, 12-15-08) 
Secs. 6-634-6-639. - Reserved.

ARTICLE IV. - EMERGENCY ENERGY PLANS[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2697-99,  2, adopted July 26, 1999, did not specifically amend the Code; hence inclusion herein as a new art. IV was at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 6-671. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, unless the context otherwise requires: 
    Control area means an electrical system bounded by interconnection (tie-line) metering and telemetry. It controls generation directly to maintain its interchange schedule with other control areas and contributes to frequency regulation of the interconnection. 
    Control area emergency means that control area is at risk of having to shed firm load, having taken or committed to take all feasible mitigating action short of shedding firm load and firm sales. 
    Controlled rotating interruptions of electrical service means the implementation of a plan to curtail electric service to firm load customers for a short period of time and rotating this curtailment of electric service through different areas within the electric utility's service territory in a situation where the demand has exceeded or is at significant risk of exceeding the supply of electricity available to the electric utility. The action of an electric utility to interrupt or curtail electric service to a customer participating in or taking service under an interruptible or curtailable rate is not included in this definition of a "controlled rotating interruption of electric service." 
    Emergency energy plan means the portions of the emergency load conservation procedures, which immediately precede and include the controlled rotating interruption of electrical service to firm load customers within the village. The emergency energy plan shall include the following steps: 
(1)  A request for emergency help from neighboring utilities; 
(2)  A declaration of a control area emergency; 
(3)  A public appeal for voluntary curtailment of electricity use; and, 
(4)  Implementation of the plan for controlled rotating interruptions of electrical service. 
    Emergency load conservation procedures means a planned course of action developed by an electric utility company to be implemented in emergency situations when the demand for electricity exceeds, or is at significant risk of exceeding, the supply of electricity available to the electric utility. 
    Electric utility company or electric utility means any person or entity engaged in the business of distributing, transmitting, or otherwise delivering electricity, regardless of its source, for use or consumption within the village (city). This term shall not include any person or entity that delivers electricity to fewer than fifty (50) customers within the village. 
(Ord. No. 2697-99,  2, 7-26-99) 
Sec. 6-672. - Submittal of emergency energy plan. 
(a)  Every electric utility company shall adopt an emergency energy plan no later than thirty (30) days after the effective date of this article, or within thirty (30) days after becoming an electric utility company, whichever is later. Every such electric utility company shall submit to the village administrator an emergency energy plan adopted by the company no later than thirty (30) days after the effective date of this chapter, or within twenty-four (24) hours of the time the plan is adopted, whichever is later. The electric utility company shall examine and update as needed its emergency energy plan at least annually. The electric utility company shall notify the foregoing public official(s) in writing of any material revisions to its plan and the rationale for said revisions within five (5) business days of the time said revisions are made. 
(b)  The emergency energy plan shall include, at a minimum, information detailing: 
(1)  Circumstances that would require the implementation of the emergency energy plan; 
(2)  Stages of the emergency energy plan; 
(3)  The approximate geographic limits of each outage area provided for in the emergency energy plan; 
(4)  The approximate number of customers within each outage area provided for in the emergency energy plan; 
(5)  The police facilities, fire stations, hospitals, nursing homes, schools, day care centers, senior citizen centers, community health centers, dialysis centers, community mental health centers, correctional facilities, stormwater and wastewater treatment or pumping facilities, and water-pumping stations that have been identified by the village (city) and persons on life-support systems that are known to the company, and that could be affected by controlled rotating interruptions of electric service under the emergency energy plan; and 
(6)  The anticipated sequence and duration of intentional interruptions of electric service to each outage area under the emergency energy plan. 
(Ord. No. 2697-99,  2, 7-26-99) 
Sec. 6-673. - Review of plan. 
(a)  Upon submittal of the emergency energy plan to the village, the village (city) shall review the emergency energy plan in order to determine if the emergency energy plan is complete and to assure appropriate coordination with public health and safety agencies. The village may reject the emergency energy plan if it does not contain all the information required under subsection 6-672(b), in which case the village shall notify the electric utility company in writing of said rejection and the reasons therefor. The electric utility company shall thereafter submit a complete emergency energy plan to the village no later than thirty (30) days after such notice is sent by the village. 
(b)  The Village and the electric utility shall work cooperatively to: 
(1)  Identify customers and facilities for which a controlled rotating interruption of electric service would require heightened response by village public health and safety agencies; 
(2)  Mitigate the potential impact of the plan on public health and safety; and 
(3)  Mitigate the potential impact of the plan on the duties of the village's public health and safety agencies. 
(Ord. No. 2697-99,  2, 7-26-99) 
Sec. 6-674. - Implementation of emergency energy plan. 
(a)  Whenever an electric utility company determines that it may be necessary to implement a controlled rotating interruption of electrical service due to the demand for electricity exceeding, or being at significant risk of exceeding, the supply of electricity available to the electric utility company, the electric utility company shall do the following: 
(1)  Take appropriate action in preparation for implementing a controlled rotating interruption of electric service and notify the appropriate electric utility company personnel; and 
(2)  Notify the chief of police, village administrator and village board that the electric utility company will be implementing its emergency energy plan. The notification shall be made pursuant to a notification procedure approved by the chief of police, village administrator and village board after consultation with the chief of police, village administrator and village board. The chief of police, village administrator and village board may waive the notice requirement to accommodate exigent circumstances. 
(b)  Subsequent to providing the notice as required above, an electric utility company shall reasonably and separately advise the designated village officials when it implements each of the steps of the emergency energy plan. Such steps shall include the following: 
(1)  A request for emergency help from neighboring utilities; 
(2)  A declaration of a control area emergency; 
(3)  A public appeal for voluntary curtailment of electricity use. 
(c)  The electric utility company shall give a separate notice to the chief of police, village administrator and village board, immediately upon the determination that there will a controlled rotating interruption of electric service pursuant to the emergency energy plan. The notification shall include the areas to be interrupted; the sequence and estimated duration of the service outage for each area; and the affected feeders and number of affected customers in each area. Whenever practical, the notification shall be made at least two (2) hours prior to the time of the outages, and in no case shall the notification be made less than thirty (30) minutes prior to the outages, if the company is aware that controlled rotating interruptions may be required. 
(d)  Notification required by this section shall be in addition to any notification requirements set forth in any applicable franchise agreement or franchise ordinance, or as may be required by applicable federal or state law or regulation. 
(Ord. No. 2697-99,  2, 7-26-99) 
Sec. 6-675. - Violations; enforcement. 
    Any electric utility company that knowingly violates this chapter or any rules promulgated thereunder shall be subject to a fine of not less than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) and not more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for each offense. Each day that a violation continues shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
    The Village may apply to any court of competent jurisdiction for an injunction or order to compel the other party to comply with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2697-99,  2, 7-26-99) 
Sec. 6-676. - Construction. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed to preclude or interfere with the implementation by an electric utility company of measures necessary to assure the provision of adequate, efficient, reliable and environmentally safe service, as required by the Illinois Public Utilities Act (220 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq.). Nothing set forth in this article shall be deemed to modify the terms of any existing franchise agreement or franchise ordinance otherwise applicable to any electric utility company, or to excuse any performance required by such agreement or ordinance, or to limit any authority that may be exercised pursuant to such agreement or ordinance, or to limit any remedy that may be available under such agreement or ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2697-99,  2, 7-26-99) 
Sec. 6-677. - Severability. 
    Should any section, paragraph, sentence, clause, phrase or word of this article be declared invalid or unconstitutional by a court or agency of competent jurisdiction, such invalidity or unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining words, phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs or sections of this article, since the same would have been enacted by the board of trustees without the incorporation in this article of any such invalid or unconstitutional word, phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. 
(Ord. No. 2697-99,  2, 7-26-99) 
Chapter 7 - FIRE PROTECTION AND PREVENTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2502-96, adopted Mar. 11, 1996, repealed former ch. 7, ㎣ 7-1-7-14, 7-22-7-24, 7-41-7-53, which pertained to similar subject matter. Section 1 of said ordinance added a new ch. 7 to read as herein set out. See the Code Comparative Table. 
Cross reference- Chief of the fires department,  2-162 et seq.; department of public safety,  2-291 et seq.; emergency services disaster agency,  2-316 et seq.; heat and smoke detection and alarm systems,  6-631 et seq.; fire extinguishers in service stations,  9-330; regulation of dry cleaners,  9-413 et seq.; licensing of foreign fire insurance companies,  9-441 et seq.; fireworks,  13-11; damage to property by means of fire or explosives, ㎣ 13-42(2), (3), 13-44(2), (3); burglar and fire alarms,  13-122 et seq.; burning on streets prohibited,  18-18. 

ARTICLE I. - GENERAL 

Sec. 7-1. - Department established. 
    There is hereby created and established a fire department for the Village of Roselle which shall be a department of the village consisting of a fire chief and such full time and part time employees, and independent contractors as may from time to time be necessary by the corporate authorities of the village. 
(Ord. No. 2502-96,  1, 3-11-96) 
Sec. 7-2. - Fire chief. 
    There is hereby created and established the position of Fire Chief of the Village of Roselle who shall be the full time administrative head of the fire department and shall be appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. The fire chief shall be selected based upon his training, experience, executive, administrative qualifications, and overall merit. The Roselle Fire Chief shall reside in the Village of Roselle within a time to be determined by the board of trustees but not to exceed two (2) years. The fire chief shall have control of the fire department and all fire apparatus belonging to the village and shall have the full authority to execute and administer any and all laws, ordinances, regulations, rules, and orders relating to fire prevention, fire fighting, and the fire department of the village. He shall be responsible for the training and discipline of employees of the department and for the organization of the department. He shall further keep all records of all fires and fire calls, investigate the causes of fires, be responsible for the compliance by all employees of the fire department with ordinances and rules established by the board of trustees. The fire chief shall be responsible for enforcement of all ordinances relating to fire prevention and shall have full authority to survey all premises and cause removal or abatement of all fire hazards. The fire chief shall prepare rules, regulations, and departmental orders for the fire department. The fire chief shall be responsible for preparing an annual budget for the fire department. 
(Ord. No. 2502-96,  1, 3-11-96) 
Sec. 7-3. - Disciplinary action. 
    The fire chief shall be responsible for maintaining discipline within the fire department and shall undertake any and all appropriate investigations and/or disciplinary measures in conformance with this chapter, lawfully promulgated rules, regulations, and department orders, and in conformance with the laws of the State of Illinois. 
(Ord. No. 2502-96,  1, 3-11-96) 
Sec. 7-4. - Officers of the department. 
    Officers of the department shall consist of those positions created from time to time as deemed necessary by the fire chief and approved by the board of trustees. All full time sworn officers' positions shall be filled in conformance with the laws of the State of Illinois by the Roselle Police and Fire Commission. 
(Ord. No. 2502-96,  1, 3-11-96) 
Sec. 7-5. - Command at fire. 
    In the case of fire, the fire chief and his assistants in order of rank shall take command of the fire department and direct the management thereof for the suppression of fire or any other fire protection and prevention activities as described in this chapter where it may be necessary for the protection of other property or to prevent the spread of a conflagration, the officer in command may cause buildings to be removed, torn down, or destroyed in that manner deemed necessary by the officer in command. 
(Ord. No. 2502-96,  1, 3-11-96) 
Sec. 7-6. - Duty to extinguish and prevent fires. 
    It shall be the function and duty of the fire department and its employees to extinguish accidental or destructive fires and to prevent the occurrence or spread of such fires. 
(Ord. No. 2502-96,  1, 3-11-96) 
Secs. 7-7-7-16. - Reserved.

Each day a violation exists shall be considered a separate offense.

(Ord. No. 2502-96,  1, 3-11-96; Ord. No. 2691-99,  2, 6-14-99; Ord. No. 2008-3425,  16(b), 12-15-08) 
ARTICLE III. - BUREAU OF FIRE PREVENTION 

Sec. 7-20. - Bureau established. 
    A bureau of fire prevention in the fire department of the Village of Roselle is hereby established which shall be operated under the direction and supervision of the chief of the fire department. The chief of the fire department and village administrator shall designate an individual as inspector of the bureau of fire prevention, who shall hold this office at the pleasure of the chief of the fire department. The chief of the fire department may also designate such number of assistant inspectors as shall from time to time be authorized by the president and board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 2502-96,  1, 3-11-96) 
Sec. 7-21. - Duties and powers generally. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the officers of the bureau of fire prevention to enforce all laws and ordinances of the state, county, and village, covering the following: 
(1)  The prevention of fires; 
(2)  The storage and use of explosives and flammables; 
(3)  The installation and maintenance of automatic and other fire alarm systems, and fire extinguishing equipment; 
(4)  The maintenance and regulation of fire escapes; 
(5)  The means and adequacy of exit in case of fire, from factories, schools, hotels, lodging houses, asylums, hospitals, churches, halls, theaters, amphitheaters, and all other places in which numbers of persons work, live, or congregate, from time to time, for any purpose; 
(6)  The investigation of the cause, origin, and circumstances of fires. 
(b)  They shall have such other powers and perform such other duties as are set forth in other sections of this article, and as may be conferred and imposed from time to time by law. The chief of the fire department may delegate any of his fire prevention powers or duties under this article to the chief inspector. 
(Ord. No. 2502-96,  1, 3-11-96) 
Sec. 7-22. - Recommendation of amendments; ordinances for safeguarding life and property against fire. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of the fire department to investigate and to recommend to the president and board of trustees such additional ordinances, or amendments to existing ordinances, as he may deem necessary for safeguarding life and property against fire. 
(Ord. No. 2502-96,  1, 3-11-96) 
Sec. 7-23. - Preparation of instructions and forms.
