    The chief of the fire department shall prepare instructions for the chief inspector and his assistants, and forms for their use in the reports required by this article. 
(Ord. No. 2502-96,  1, 3-11-96) 
ARTICLE IV. - FIRE SUPPRESSION AND CONTROL 

Sec. 7-24. - Yard systems. 
    All new and existing petroleum storage or sales facilities, lumber yards, amusement or exhibition parks, and educational or institutional complexes and similar occupancies and uses involving high fire or life hazards, and which are located more than one hundred fifty (150) feet from a public street or which require quantities of water beyond the capabilities of the public water distribution system shall be provided with properly placed fire hydrants. Such fire hydrants shall be capable of supplying fire flows as required by the fire prevention code official and shall be connected to a water system in accordance with accepted engineering practices. The fire prevention code official shall designate and approve the number and location of fire hydrants. The fire prevention code official may require the installation of sufficient fire hose and equipment housed in accordance with the approved rules when the hazard involved requires such measures. Private hydrants shall not be placed into or removed from service until approved by the fire prevention code official. 
(Ord. No. 2502-96,  1, 3-11-96) 
Sec. 7-25. - Maintenance and use of fire suppression equipment. 
    No person or entity shall obstruct, remove, tamper with, disturb, or use any fire hydrant, waterline, watermain, or water flowing into a fire hydrant or a waterline providing water to a fire hydrant installed, maintained, or owned by the village except by the express authority of the corporate authorities of the Village of Roselle or upon issuance of a permit for such use by the Village of Roselle. Whenever a fire hydrant, fire appliance, or waterline attached to a fire hydrant is removed, disturbed, or otherwise used as herein permitted, it shall be replaced or reinstalled or restored as soon as practicable. Defective or nonapproved fire appliances or equipment shall be replaced or repaired as directed by the fire chief or fire prevention code official. 
(Ord. No. 2502-96,  1, 3-11-96) 
Secs. 7-26-7-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - VIOLATIONS 

Sec. 7-36. - Interference with fire department operations. 
    It shall be unlawful to interfere with, attempt to interfere with, conspire to interfere with, obstruct, or restrict the mobility of, or block the path of travel of any fire department emergency vehicle in any way, or to interfere with, attempt to interfere, conspire to interfere with, obstruct or hamper any fire department operation. 
(Ord. No. 2502-96,  1, 3-11-96) 
Sec. 7-37. - Compliance with orders. 
    A person shall not fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order or direction of the department official or to interfere with the compliance attempts of another individual. 
(Ord. No. 2502-96,  1, 3-11-96) 
Sec. 7-38. - Vehicles crossing fire hose. 
    A vehicle shall not be driven or propelled over any unprotected fire hose of the fire department when laid down on any street, alley way, private drive or any other vehicular roadway without the consent of the department official in command of said operation. 
(Ord. No. 2502-96,  1, 3-11-96) 
Sec. 7-39. - Operation of vehicles on approach of authorized emergency vehicles. 
    Upon the approach of any authorized emergency vehicles (as defined under the laws of the State of Illinois), which is giving audible and visual signal, the operator of every other vehicle shall immediately drive the same to a position as near as possible and parallel to the right-hand edge or curb of the street or roadway, clear of any intersection, and shall stop and remain in such position until the authorized emergency vehicle or vehicles shall have passed, unless otherwise directed by the department official or a police officer. 
(Ord. No. 2502-96,  1, 3-11-96) 
Sec. 7-40. - Vehicles following fire apparatus. 
    It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicles, other than one on official business, to follow closer than three hundred (300) feet from any fire apparatus traveling in response to a fire alarm, or to drive any vehicle within the block or immediate area where fire apparatus has stopped in answer to a fire alarm. 
(Ord. No. 2502-96,  1, 3-11-96) 
Sec. 7-41. - Unlawful boarding or tampering with fire department emergency equipment. 
    A person shall not without proper authorization from the department official in charge of said fire department emergency equipment, cling to, attach him/her self to, climb upon or into, board or swing upon any fire department emergency vehicle, whether the same is in motion or at rest, or sound the siren, horn, bell, or other sound-producing device thereon, or to manipulate or tamper with, or attempt to manipulate or tamper with any levers, valves, switches, starting devices, brakes, pumps, or any equipment or protective clothing on, or a part of, any fire department emergency vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 2502-96,  1, 3-11-96) 
Sec. 7-42. - Damage, injury to fire department equipment, personnel. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to damage or deface, or attempt, or conspire to damage or deface any fire department emergency vehicle at any time, or to injure, or attempt to injure or conspire to injure fire department personnel while performing departmental duties. 
(Ord. No. 2502-96,  1, 3-11-96) 
Sec. 7-43. - Sale of defective fire extinguishers. 
    A person shall not sell, trade, loan or give away any form, type or kind of fire extinguisher which is not approved by the fire prevention code, or which is not in proper working order, or the contents of which do not meet the requirements of the fire prevention code. The requirements of this section shall not apply to the sale, trade or exchange of obsolete or damaged equipment for junk when said units are permanently disfigured or marked with a permanent sign identifying the unit as junk. 
(Ord. No. 2502-96,  1, 3-11-96) 
Sec. 7-44. - Street obstruction. 
    A person or persons shall not erect, construct, place, or maintain any bumps, fences, gates, chains, bars, pipes, wood or metal horses or any other type of obstruction in or on any street, within the boundaries of the municipality. The word street as used in this chapter, shall mean any roadway accessible to the public for vehicular traffic, including, but not limited to, private streets or access lanes, as well as all public streets and highways within the boundaries of the municipality. 
(Ord. No. 2502-96,  1, 3-11-96) 
ARTICLE VI. - CARBON MONOXIDE DETECTORS 

Sec. 7-45. - Carbon monoxide detectors required. 
    All new residential structures or existing residential structures being improved or rehabilitated so as to require a building permit which contain cooking stoves and/or fireplaces, shall be equipped with a minimum of one carbon monoxide detector installed within twenty (20) feet of each sleeping room. The carbon monoxide detector shall be in minimum compliance with Underwriters Laboratories' 2034 Standard. 
(Ord. No. 2001-2885,  1, 11-12-01) 
Sec. 7-46. - Audibility. 
    The sound of the carbon monoxide detectors shall be audible in all sleeping rooms protected by the device. 
(Ord. No. 2001-2885,  2, 11-12-01) 
Sec. 7-47. - Power supply. 
    The primary power source for the carbon monoxide detectors shall be the residential structures AC power source. All carbon monoxide detectors required by this article shall have a battery backup capable of functioning if primary power is interrupted. 
(Ord. No. 2001-2885,  3, 11-12-01) 
Sec. 7-49. - Occupancy permits. 
    No occupancy permit shall be granted for any new residential structure required to have a carbon monoxide detector under the terms of this article until inspectors of the Village of Roselle have determined that the residential property is in compliance with this article. Any existing residential structure required to have carbon monoxide detectors pursuant to section 7-45 of this article shall not receive final permit approval until carbon monoxide detectors are provided in conformance with the article. 
(Ord. No. 2001-2885,  4, 11-12-01) 
Sec. 7-50. - Maintenance. 
    All carbon monoxide detectors required by [this] article shall be maintained in proper working order and shall be replaced as required by the manufacturer's specifications. 
(Ord. No. 2001-2885,  5, 11-12-01) 
Secs. 7-51-7-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - FIRE PREVENTION BUREAU: INSPECTION AND TESTING FEES 

Sec. 7-60. - Fire prevention bureau fee schedule established. 
    Fees for inspections, reviews and tests performed by or through the fire prevention bureau shall be those set forth in appendix A, which is incorporated into this section as if fully set forth. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3512,  1, 4-26-10) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2010-3512,  1, adopted April 26, 2010, set out provisions intended for use as  7-50. Inasmuch as  7-50 currently exists in the Code, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as  7-60. Appendix A is available in the office of the village clerk. 
Sec. 7-61. - Payment required before issuance of occupancy permit. 
    No occupancy permit for any structure or building, or permit for any special event, requiring fire prevention bureau review, inspection, or testing, shall be issued until the same is approved by the fire prevention bureau, and only then upon full payment of the fees set forth in section 7-50 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3512,  1, 4-26-10) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2010,  1, adopted April 26, 2010, set out provisions intended for use as  7-51. For purposes of classification, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as  7-61. 
Chapter 8 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Animals and fowl, Ch. 4; property maintenance,  6-610 et seq.; food dealers,  9-137 et seq.; cleanliness of establishments selling tobacco,  9-342; regulation of barber and beauty shops,  9-392 et seq.; sanitation of dry cleaning establishments,  9-419; sanitation of pet shops,  9-464; sanitation of laundries,  9-473; sanitary facilities for trailer parks,  9-524; nuisances, Ch. 12; weeds generally,  21-19 et seq.; water and sewers, Ch. 22. 
State Law reference- General authority to provide for health, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  11-20-5. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-1. - Spitting. 
    It shall he unlawful to spit or expectorate on any public sidewalk or other public place, or on the floor or walls of any store, theater, hall, public vehicle or other place frequented by the public or to which the public is invited. 
(Code 1956,  608) 
Sec. 8-2. - Dense smoke. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to cause or permit the emission of dense smoke from any indoor or outdoor fire, chimney, engine, oil burner, or any other manner in the village so as to cause an annoyance, nuisance, discomfort or negative health effect to village residents. 
(b)  Smoke shall constitute an annoyance, nuisance, discomfort, or negative health effect under this section, when such smoke creates an annoyance, negative health to one or more village residents for more than five (5) minutes in any one hour whether such period of time is consecutive or not. 
(c)  It shall further be unlawful to burn in any outdoor or indoor fireplace anything other than natural gas, dry hardwood or softwood logs or branches, commercially manufactured artificial fire logs, or charcoal briquettes. This section shall not be interpreted to restrict or prohibit the use of fire starters, kindling or other lawful accelerant used to start a fire or the cooking of food. 
(d)  Upon investigation and determination that dense smoke is any annoyance, nuisance, or discomfort as defined in this section, the investigating village official may instruct that the fire be extinguished. Upon instruction from the investigating village official to extinguish the fire causing the nuisance, as described herein, the person so instructed shall extinguish the fire. Refusal to extinguish the fire upon such direction from the village official shall constitute a separate and distinct offense from a violation of subsection (a) or (d) of this section. 
(e)  Upon conviction for any violation of subsections (a) or (c) of this section by a court of competent jurisdiction, a person shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). Upon a conviction for a violation of subsection (d) of this section, by a court of competent jurisdiction, a person shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Code 1956,  609; Ord. No. 2001-2855,  1, 6-25-01) 
Sec. 8-3. - Stagnant water. 
    Any stagnant pool of water in the village is hereby declared to be a nuisance. It shall be unlawful for any persons to permit any such nuisance to remain or exist on any property under his or its control. 
(Code 1956,  597) 
Sec. 8-4. - Cemeteries, burials prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to establish a cemetery within the village limits. 
(Code 1956,  599) 
Sec. 8-5. - General requirements for premises. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to use for residential or business purposes in the village any structure erected, moved or maintained in violation of any ordinance of the village and it shall be unlawful to use for residential purposes any trailer, stationary railroad car or truck in the village. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to use for residential purposes any building or structure not adequately provided with water and sewage disposal facilities. And it shall be unlawful to conduct or operate any business or establishment to which the public is invited for the purpose of eating, entertainment, or recreation unless there are provided on the premises adequate separate toilet facilities for the use of male and female patrons. 
(Code 1956,  600) 
Sec. 8-6. - Heat in residences. 
    Premises used for residential purposes shall have heating equipment and appurtenances which are properly installed and maintained in safe and good working condition and which can be so operated so as to provide heat sufficient to maintain all habitable rooms and bathrooms at a temperature of not less than sixty-eight (68) degrees Fahrenheit (20 degrees Centigrade) at a distance of thirty-six (36) inches above floor level, unless the occupant of the premises shall choose otherwise. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner or person in charge of any premises so used, where there is a central heating plant controlled by the owner or such person in charge, to maintain and provide such heat at all times during the period between September fifteenth and June first of each year when needed. 
(Code 1956,  601; Ord. No. 1051-81,  1, 11-2-81) 
Sec. 8-7. - Common drinking utensils. 
    It shall be unlawful to maintain any common drinking cup, or cups, dipper or other similar utensil, for the use of more than one person in any public hall, theater, store or other public place frequented by the public. 
(Code 1956,  605) 
Secs. 8-8-8-16. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WASTE AND WASTE CONTAINERS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Disposal of waste in food establishments,  9-147, Item 12; rubbish resulting from outdoor advertising activities,  9-488; regulation and licensing of scavengers,  9-510; removal of garbage in trailer parks,  9-526; collection of recyclable materials placed for village collection program unlawful, exceptions,  13-47. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2010-3509,  1, adopted April 12, 2010, repealed the former Div. 1, ㎣ 8-17-8-28, and enacted a new Div. 1 as set out herein. The former Div. 1 pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table for full derivation. 

Sec. 8-17. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article II the following terms shall mean: 
    Acceptable waste : shall mean those things identified in appendix A. 
    Excluded waste : shall mean those things identified in appendix B. 
    Recyclables : shall mean those things identified in appendix C. 
    Yard waste : shall mean those things identified in appendix D. 
    Hazardous waste: shall mean those things identified by state and federal environmental laws as hazardous waste. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3509,  1, 4-12-10) 
Sec. 8-18. - Excluded waste deposit prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to cause or permit any excluded waste to be placed for pick-up by the village's waste contractor, except upon specific agreement between a customer and the village's waste contractor or other licensed waste handler. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3509,  1, 4-12-10) 
Sec. 8-19. - Hazardous waste. 
    It shall be unlawful to dispose of any hazardous waste within the village except in conformance with state and federal environmental laws. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3509,  1, 4-12-10) 
Sec. 8-20. - Refuse subject to blowing and run-off. 
    It shall be unlawful to cause or permit the accumulation of any waste, dust, ashes, recyclables, or yard waste, in such a manner that the same can be wind scattered or carried into the stormwater drainage system. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3509,  1, 4-12-10) 
Sec. 8-21. - Containers required. 
    Every owner or tenant of any property within the Village of Roselle that generates acceptable waste, recyclables, or yard waste shall secure and maintain in good order authorized containers for acceptable waste, recyclables, and yard waste, consistent with section 8-22 of this article II. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3509,  1, 4-12-10) 
Sec. 8-22. - Waste to be properly sealed in containers. 
    It shall be unlawful to place or deposit anywhere in the village any waste, recyclables, or yard waste, excluding yard waste bundles, except in fully closed-in waste containers as described in section 8-25 of this article II. Waste and recyclables shall not protrude from the container. Yard waste may only protrude from a yard waste container when the waste is firmly contained in the container so as not to be subject to becoming loose or scattered. Yard waste bundles shall not contain trees or parts thereof (except small branches bound in bundles not exceeding four (4) feet in length, containing branches less than two (2) inches in diameter, with a total bundle maximum of two (2) feet in diameter and a maximum weight of fifty (50) pounds). Food and vegetable garbage shall be tightly wrapped or enclosed prior to being deposited in a waste container to prevent the emission of odors. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3509,  1, 4-12-10) 
Sec. 8-23. - Composting. 
    Yard waste may be composted so long as it is stored in a neat and functioning compost pile. Compost piles shall be placed in rear yards, as defined by the Roselle Zoning Ordinance, and shall not be closer than seven and one-half (71/2) feet from any side lot line, nor closer than ten (10) feet from any rear lot line. In no case shall a composting pile be located in any drainage easement, drainageway, floodway, or floodplain. Composting piles shall be no more than five (5) feet in height, nor shall they exceed a maximum ground base of more than one hundred (100) square feet. All compost piles shall be constructed and maintained so as to function properly and without the emissions of odors. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3509,  1, 4-12-10) 
Sec. 8-24. - Waste prohibited in rights-of-way. 
    It shall be unlawful to deposit any waste or recyclable on any public alley or street of the village, except when acceptable waste, recyclables, or yard waste is collected and placed in the parkway behind the curb line, or where there is no curb no closer than two (2) feet from the edge of pavement, for pick up by the village's waste contractor or other licensed waste handler, in conformance with sections 8-20, 8-21, 8-25, and 8-27 of this article II. No acceptable waste container, recyclable container, or yard waste bundle authorized herein shall be deposited at any time on the paved portion of any street. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3509,  1, 4-12-10) 
Sec. 8-25. - Types of containers. 
    All containers for waste, recyclables, and yard waste shall be only those authorized and identified in appendix E to this article II. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3509,  1, 4-12-10) 
Sec. 8-26. - Combustible refuse. 
    It shall be unlawful to store, or permit to be stored, any combustible waste or recyclables in such a manner as to create a fire hazard. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3509,  1, 4-12-10) 
Sec. 8-27. - Schedule for placement of waste and recyclables. 
    All acceptable waste containers, recyclable containers, or yard waste bundles shall be placed for pick-up by the village's waste contractor, or other licensed waste handler, no earlier than 6:00 p.m. on the day before the scheduled pick-up day and shall be removed by midnight of the day in which the pick-up is made. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3509,  1, 4-12-10) 
Sec. 8-28. - Burning, burying garbage, and offensive accumulations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to burn or bury waste or recyclables in the village or to permit the same to accumulate in any manner so as to create a nuisance or attract flies, vermin, or other animals. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3509,  1, 4-12-10) 
Sec. 8-29. - Waste, recyclable and yard waste screening. 
    In all residential zoning districts, acceptable waste containers, recyclable containers, yard waste bundles, and excluded waste that is subject to a special agreement between the customer and the village's waste contractor for pick-up shall be kept, maintained, and located in the residential property's rear yard, the back portion of an interior side yard to the rear of the front elevation of the principal residence, or within the residence's garage, except when placed on the right-of-way for pick-up in conformance with sections 8-24 and 8-27 of this article II. Waste, recyclables, and yard waste, including yard waste in bundles, located in a side yard shall be enclosed by opaque fencing or opaque evergreen plant material of equal or greater height than that of the container or bundle, so as to be screened from viewing from the public street fronting the residential property. All fencing utilized for this purpose shall comply with section 6-524 of chapter 6 of the Code of Ordinances of the Village. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3509,  1, 4-12-10) 
APPENDIX A 
DEFINITIONS OF ACCEPTABLE WASTE 
    The following words and phrases shall have the meanings as specified herein: 
    Acceptable Waste: All kitchen wastes including but not limited to cans, bottles, household food, accumulation of animal food and vegetable matter attendant to the preparation, use, cooking, and serving of foods. General household trash and refuse, including but not limited to, ashes, empty cartons, crates, boxes, wrapping materials, newspapers and magazines, cloth materials, empty cans, discarded toys, discarded clothing, and similar materials. Bulk items including but not limited to furniture, appliances, and small quantities of building materials from "do it yourself" projects. Such "do it yourself" material includes only small items placed in suitable disposable containers, or in bundles not exceeding two (2) feet in diameter or four (4) feet in length. Carpeting may be disposed of in four-foot lengths, not exceeding two (2) feet in diameter. 
    Bulk Materials: Any items set forth as acceptable waste which are too large to fit into an approved refuse container and which exceed, in total, fifty (50) pounds in weight. Examples include sofas, large tables and chairs, dressers, televisions, bookcases, mattresses and box springs, other large household furniture, and large appliances which do not contain CFC or HCFC refrigerant gas, PCB containing capacitors, mercury switches, or other hazardous components. 
    Household Construction and Demolition Debris: Waste materials from "do-it-yourself" interior and exterior household construction, remodeling, and repair projects, including, but not limited to, drywall, plywood, paneling, lumber, and other building materials; cabinets; carpeting; disassembled household fixtures; and small amounts of sod, earth, clay, sand, concrete, rocks, and similar materials. 
    Household Waste: All organic household or kitchen wastes, such as rejected or unused food and food residues, paper used in wrapping food, household refuse, inorganic and incombustible household waste (i.e., cans, metalware, broken glass, crockery, stoneware, and similar waste resulting from the regular operation of the household) empty cartons and crates, discarded toys, discarded clothing and furniture, and similar materials. Household waste shall not include waste from any manufacturing process, construction materials, broken concrete, lumber, large rocks, and other similar materials. 
    Refuse: Household waste, household construction and demolition debris, white goods, and bulk materials. 
    White Goods: Any domestic and/or commercial large appliance that contains CFC or HCFC refrigerant gas, capacitors containing PCBs, mercury switches, or other hazardous components. Examples include, but are not limited to, refrigerators, freezers, air conditioners, ranges (both electric and gas) humidifiers, dehumidifiers, water heaters, furnaces, and other similar large appliances. 
APPENDIX B 
DEFINITIONS OF EXCLUDED WASTE 
    Excluded Waste: The hazardous materials, wastes or substances; toxic substances, wastes or pollutants; contaminants; pollutants; infectious wastes; medical wastes; or radioactive wastes, each as defined by applicable federal, state, or local laws or regulations. 
APPENDIX C 
DEFINITIONS OF RECYCLABLES 
    The following words and phrases shall have the meanings as specified herein: 
    Aluminum Formed Containers/Wrap: Aluminum cans, foil, trays, pie plates, and other similar formed containers. 
    Catalog: A book made from either glossy or non-glossy paper stock, which contains an itemized listing of names or articles arranged in orders or classified. 
    Chipboard (also referred to as paperboard): A thin, single layer of cardboard used in the packaging of consumer goods. Examples include cereal boxes, cracker boxes, clothing boxes, tissue boxes, and other similar products. 
    Corrugated Cardboard: A sturdy paperboard consisting of two paper grades, a wavy inner portion and a thick outside lining which is most commonly used for packaging. 
    High Density Polyethylene (HDPE) #2 Blow Molded Containers: Plastic milk and water jugs, laundry detergent, shampoo, personal care, and other similar blow molded containers used inside the home. 
    Juice Boxes: Aseptic cartons consisting of a high-grade paperboard coated with polyethylene plastic and aluminum foil, excluding milk cartons. 
    Junk Mail: Brochures, advertisements, flyers, post cards, greeting cards, window envelopes, file folders, mailing tubes and other similar correspondences. 
    LDPE (#4): Low-density polyethylene. 
    Magazines: Periodical publications made from either glossy or non-glossy paper stock. 
    Mixed Papers: Stationary, computer paper, notebook paper, typing paper, letterhead, index cards, computer cards, bond envelopes, post-it notes, and other similar paper products. 
    Other High Density Polyethylene (HDPE) #2 Containers: Margarine tubs, baby wipe containers, and other similar molded containers used inside the home. 
    Other Polyethylene Terephthalate (PET#1) Containers: Plastic plates, trays, cups, and other similar ejection molded containers used inside the home. 
    Polyethylene Terephthalate (PET #1) Blow Molded Containers: Soft drink, liquor, cooking oil, personal care, and other similar blow molded containers used inside the home. 
    Polypropylene (PP#5): Yogurt, cottage cheese and sour cream tubs, syrup bottles, etc. 
    Polyvinyl/Chloride (PVC #3): Health and beauty aid bottles. 
    Recyclables: (Also referred to as recyclable materials) Materials which have a useful second life in the economic cycle if they are successfully collected, separated, processed, and marketed for return to the economic mainstream. Recyclable materials shall include: 
COMMINGLED CONTAINERS: 
? Aluminum Cans, Trays & Foil 
? Steel Cans & Tins 
? Aseptic Packaging & Gable Top Containers (milk & juice cartons) 
? Glass Bottles and Jars - (clear, brown, green) 
? PET Soda, Water, & Flavored Beverage Bottles (#1 clear and green plastic resin) 
? HDPE Milk & Juice Jugs (#2 clear plastic resin) 
? HDPE Detergent & Fabric Softener Containers (#2 colored plastic resin) 
? PVC Narrow Neck Containers Only (#3 plastic resin), such as health & beauty aid products, household cleaners. 
? LDPE Grocery Containers (#4 plastic resin), such as margarine tubs, frozen dessert cups, six and twelve pack rings. 
? PP Grocery Containers (#5 plastic resin), such as yogurt cups, and narrow neck syrup and ketchup bottles. 
? #7 Plastic Resin Narrow Neck Containers Only. 
? Plastic Buckets, such as kitty litter containers (5 gallon size maximum) 
? No metal handles. 
PAPER FIBER: 
? Newspaper, including inserts (remove plastic sleeves) 
? Cardboard (no waxed cardboard) 
? Kraft (brown paper) Bags 
? Magazines, Catalogs and Telephone Books 
? Office, Computer, Notebook & Gift Wrap Paper (no metal clips, spirals, binders) 
? Chipboard (cereal, cake & food mix boxes, gift boxes, shoe boxes, etc.) 
? Carrier Stock (soda & beer can carrying cases) 
? Junk Mail & Envelopes (no plastic cards, stick on labels or unused stamps) 
? Paper Back Books (no hard cover books) 
    Wet Strength Carrier Stock: Paperboard containers with special coatings to prevent tearing of the packages or smearing of the ink from moisture when refrigerated or frozen; i.e. paper beverage carriers and frozen food packages. 
APPENDIX D 
DEFINITIONS OF YARD WASTE 
    The following words and phrases shall have the meanings as specified herein: 
    Chipping: The mechanical process of breaking up woody yard waste into smaller pieces to be used as a landscape mulch or a bulking agent. 
    Composting: The process by which aerobic micro organisms decompose organic matter into a humus-like product. 
    Hard Landscape Waste: Brown stemmed branches and shrub pruning with large stems or trunks not to exceed four (4) feet in length and fifty (50) pounds in weight and two (2) inches in diameter individually, excluding Christmas trees, with a total diameter of the bundle not to exceed two (2) feet. 
    Soft Landscape Waste: Grass and garden clippings, leaves, pruning of small diameter green stemmed shrubs, weeds, plant materials, etc. 
    Yard Waste: Hard landscape waste and soft landscape waste. 
APPENDIX E 
DEFINITIONS OF ACCEPTABLE CONTAINERS 
    The following words and phrases shall have the meanings as specified herein: 
    Curbside: A position immediately behind the curb and within the parkway used for the collection of Acceptable Waste, Yard Waste, and Recycling containers. 
    Waste Containers: Waste containers shall include: 
Waste Container: A plastic or galvanized metal can of a capacity not less than four (4) gallons and not to exceed thirty-four (34) gallons in size. No waste container shall exceed fifty (50) pounds in weight when filled. 
Waste Bag: A plastic bag of a capacity not to exceed thirty-three (33) gallons in size and fifty (50) pounds in weight when filled. 
Cart: A wheeled plastic container with a tight-fitting top, not to exceed ninety-six (96) gallons in size, requiring a semi-automated mechanism for collection. All carts must be approved by and/or supplied by the Contractor for an additional monthly collection charge, if not supplied as part of the base service. 
    Recycling Containers: Recycling containers shall include: 
Recyclables Container: A plastic or galvanized metal can of a capacity not less than four (4) gallons and not to exceed thirty-four (34) gallons in size. No can shall exceed fifty (50) pounds in weight when filled. 
Cart: A wheeled plastic container with a tight-fitting top, not to exceed ninety-six (96) gallons in size, requiring a semi-automated mechanism for collection. All carts must be approved by and/or supplied by the Contractor for an additional monthly collection charge, if not supplied as part of the base service. 
    Yard Waste Containers: Yard waste containers shall include: 
Waste Container: A plastic or galvanized metal can of a capacity not less than four (4) gallons and not to exceed thirty-four (34) gallons in size, properly labeled with the words "Yard Waste Only", stickers for this purpose are available from the Contractor at no cost to the resident. No yard waste container shall exceed fifty (50) pounds in weight when filled. 
Kraft Paper Bag: A special biodegradable paper bag, not to exceed thirty-three (33) gallons in size, which will shred and degrade quickly in the composting process. 
Cart: A wheeled plastic container with a tight-fitting top, not to exceed ninety-six (96) gallons in size, requiring a semi-automated lifting mechanism for collection. All carts must be approved by and/or supplied by the Contractor for an additional monthly collection charge. 
Bundle: Any material allowed under the definition of Hard Landscape Waste such as limbs, branches, or other loose items which do not exceed four (4) feet in length and fifty (50) pounds in weight. Each branch shall not exceed two (2) inches in diameter, with the total diameter of the bundle not to exceed two (2) feet. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3509,  1, 4-12-10) 
Secs. 8-30-8-35. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DUMPING[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Dumping on property of another,  12-14. 

Sec. 8-36. - Permit required. 
    No person shall dump or deposit anywhere within the village, except at such place as may be authorized by the chief building inspector by a written permit, any garbage, refuse, ashes, yardwaste miscellaneous waste, manure, or other substance that may contain disease germs, or be scattered by the wind, or decompose or become filthy, noxious or unhealthful. No permit is required for a yardwaste pile. Such dumping without a permit is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 255-69,  1, 3-24-69; Ord. No. 1972-90,  5, 6-25-90) 
Cross reference- Permits generally, Ch. 9. 
Sec. 8-37. - Permission of property owner required. 
    It shall be unlawful to dump or deposit any waste matter upon private property unless the written consent of the owner or his authorized agent shall first be obtained and filed with the building inspector. 
(Ord. No. 255-69,  1, 3-24-69) 
Sec. 8-38. - Procedure for permit application. 
    Whenever application shall have been made for a permit and the written consent of the owner of the property in question shall have been filed as herein required, the building inspector shall give notice to the board of trustees at its next regular public meeting that such application has been made. Such application shall then be held in abeyance until the next regular meeting of the board of trustees. In case no action thereon is taken by the board of trustees at said next regular meeting, the building inspector may issue such permit if the dumping privileges so requested will not constitute a nuisance and the applicant executes a statement that he will comply with the ordinances of this village and the rules and regulations of the building inspector pertaining to the dumping of the abovementioned substances. Such permit shall not authorize any person to dump any of the said substances on private property above the street grade. 
(Ord. No. 255-69,  1, 3-24-69) 
Sec. 8-39. - Acts prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and a nuisance for any person to obstruct or pollute any water course or source of water supply in this village. It shall also be unlawful and a nuisance for any person, in person or by his agent or employee, to cast, throw, sweep, sift or deposit in any manner in or upon any public way or other public place in this village or any streams, ponds, public water, drain, sewer or receiving basin within the jurisdiction of this village, any kind of dirt, rubbish, waste article, thing or substance whatsoever, whether liquid or solid. Nor shall any person cast, throw, sweep, sift or deposit any of the aforementioned items anywhere within the jurisdiction of this village in such manner that it may be carried or deposited, in whole or in part, by the action of the sun, wind, rain or snow, into any of the aforementioned places. 
(b)  Provided that this section shall not apply to the deposit of material under a permit authorized by any ordinance of this village; or to goods, wares or merchandise deposited upon any public way or other public place temporarily in the necessary course of trade and removal therefrom within a reasonable period after being so deposited. 
(Ord. No. 255-69,  2, 3-24-69) 
Sec. 8-40. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this division shall not be construed to apply to the use of fertilizer for agricultural or horticultural purposes, nor to the collection, removal, and disposal of garbage, refuse and ashes as provided in Division 1 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 255-69,  3, 3-24-69) 
Secs. 8-41-8-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MUNICIPAL WASTE DISPOSAL[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1697-88, adopted May 23, 1988, was nonamendatory of the Code; hence, inclusion of ㎣ 1.5, 2.1 and 2.2 of said ordinance as Art. III, ㎣ 8-61-8-63, was at the editor's discretion. 
Cross reference- Property maintenance,  6-610 et seq.; refuse enclosures,  6-615; waste and waste containers generally,  8-17 et seq.; dumping,  8-36 et seq.; junkyards prohibited,  9-273; storing and disposal of refuse by scavengers,  9-513. 

Sec. 8-61. - General findings. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of Section 3.2 of the Intergovernmental Cooperation Act, as amended, 1987 Illinois Revised Statutes, Chapter 127, Section 743.2 (the "Act"), it is in the best interests of the municipality to establish a municipal waste system within its corporate limits, to require that this municipal waste system shall be the exclusive method of collection, transportation, processing, transfer, storage and disposal of all (or a specified portion) of the municipal waste within all (or a specified part) of its corporate limits and to provide for the imposition of fees, charges and rates upon all (or a specified portion) of the users of the municipal waste system in order to satisfy the obligations of the municipality under its interim agreement and any other agreements and to ensure a constant flow of municipal waste to the municipal waste system notwithstanding the fact that competition may be displaced. 
(Ord. No. 1697-88,  1.5, 5-23-88) 
Sec. 8-62. - Establishment of municipal waste system. 
(a)  Definition of municipal waste system. The municipal waste system is hereby established to encompass the entire Village of Roselle, and shall include all waste, including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  All kitchen waste including cans, bottles, household food, accumulation of animal food and vegetable matter attendant on the preparation, use, cooking, and serving of foods; 
(2)  General household trash and refuse, including ashes, empty cartons, crates, boxes, wrapping materials, newspapers and magazines when securely and neatly bound in convenient size bundles, cloth materials, empty cans, discarded toys, discarded clothing and similar materials; 
(3)  Yard refuse materials, including grass, clippings, weeds, leaves in bags, Christmas trees, bushes, brush clippings and branch clippings when securely bound in bundles not exceeding four (4) feet in length; 
(4)  Folk items, including furniture, appliances, and small quantities of building materials from "do it yourself" projects. 
(b)  The municipal waste system shall not include the following: 
(1)  Hazardous or toxic waste; 
(2)  Trees or parts thereof except small branches bound in bundles not exceeding four (4) feet in length; 
(3)  Earth, sod, rocks, concrete, building materials and refuse from remodeling or construction generated by a building or other construction contractor, resulting from the performance of construction work done by such contractor within the village, with the exception of small quantities of materials from "do it yourself" projects. 
(Ord. No. 1697-88,  2.1, 5-23-88) 
Sec. 8-63. - System type/licensing or franchise system. 
(a)  No person shall engage in the enterprise of collecting, transporting, processing, storing or disposing of municipal waste (as defined and within the limits established in section 8-62) without first having secured a license or franchise for performing such enterprise from the municipality. 
(b)  Each licensee shall maintain its equipment used in licensed service in good repair and working order, shall perform its operations efficiently and faithfully, and shall punctually perform all obligations imposed on it pursuant to this article. 
(c)  Each licensee shall make and keep proper books and accounts (separate and apart from all other records and accounts of the licensee) in which complete entries shall be made of all transactions relating to licensed services, which books and accounts shall be available to inspection by the municipality. 
(d)  All licensees or franchisees shall meet any other standards and specifications, with respect to service, fees and collection thereof, and manner of performance, as may from time to time be required by agreement of the municipality and such licensee or franchisee. 
(e)  The municipality shall establish rates, fees, and charges and may revise the same from time to time as may be necessary to produce funds sufficient for all purposes provided in the interim agreement until all the municipality's obligations under the interim agreement have been discharged. The municipality shall provide for a collection mechanism of said rates, fees and charges and may from time to time revise the collection mechanism as may be necessary to provide for efficient collection. 
(Ord. No. 1697-88,  2.2, 5-23-88) 
Editor's note- The interim agreement referenced in  8-63(e) refers to the interim project use agreement dated May 2, 1988, with the solid waste agency of Northern Cook County pursuant to Ordinance No. 1680-88. 
Chapter 8.5 - HISTORICAL AREAS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; buildings, Ch. 6; parks and recreation, Ch. 14; planning and zoning generally, Ch. 15; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 18; trees, shrubs and weeds, Ch. 21; zoning, App. A; subdivision regulations, App. B. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8.5-1. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to: 
(1)  Safeguard the village's historic, cultural, architectural, and community heritage as embodied in its landmarks; 
(2)  Protect, enhance and perpetuate the distinctive visual characteristics of the Village of Roselle; 
(3)  Promote the educational, cultural, economic and general welfare of the Village of Roselle by providing for a mechanism whereby historic landmarks, including landmarks reflecting local and regional culture, which are located in the Village of Roselle, may be identified as historically significant, preserved in a suitable harmonious environment, and studied and enjoyed now and hereafter. 
(Ord. No. 888-79,  1, 10-8-79) 
Sec. 8.5-2. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Alteration. Any act which changes the exterior architectural appearance of a structure, or which changes the appearance of a site, which has been designated as a landmark pursuant to this chapter. 
    Board. The village board of the Village of Roselle, Illinois. 
    Certificate of appropriateness. A certificate from the board authorizing plans for the alteration of or construction on a site, or authorizing the alteration, removal or demolition of a structure, which has been designated as a landmark pursuant to this chapter. 
    Demolition. Any act which destroys in part or in whole a structure. 
    Exterior architectural appearance. Includes the architectural character, a general composition, and general arrangement of the exterior of a structure, including the kind and texture of the building material and the type and character of all windows, doors, exterior walls, roofing, light fixtures, signs, and appurtenant elements visible from a public street or thoroughfare or from nearby property or improvements thereon. 
    Landmark. Any site or structure which has special historical interest or which has special value as part of the heritage of the Village of Roselle, or the nation, state, or region, and which has been designated by the board as a landmark. 
    Structure. Any building, parking facility, fence, gate, wall, work of art, or other object constituting a physical improvement to real property, which has been designated by the board as a landmark, or which is a part of any such physical improvement designated by the board as a landmark. (This definition of the word "structure" is different from the definition of the word in the village's building code and intended for purposes of this chapter only.) 
(Ord. No. 888-79,  1, 10-8-79; Ord. No. 1580-87,  1, 6-22-87) 
ARTICLE II. - BOARD AND ADMINISTRATION 

Sec. 8.5-3. - Jurisdiction and power of the board. 
    The board, upon consultation with and recommendation of, the Roselle Historical Foundation, shall have the authority to: 
(1)  Designate sites and structures with the village as landmarks; 
(2)  Prescribe conditions for their alteration, demolition, and removal; 
(3)  Evaluate any application for zoning amendment, variation, or special use affecting any landmark, pursuant to the purpose of this chapter as stated in section 8.5-1. Such applications submitted to the zoning board of appeals shall be forwarded to the commission, which in its discretion may present evidence at the public hearing on the proposed zoning amendment, variation, or special use, either in support of or in opposition to, or it may recommend modifications thereof; 
(4)  Visually identify designated landmarks (i.e., plaques, markers, etc.). 
(Ord. No. 888-79,  1, 10-8-79; Ord. No. 1580-87,  1, 6-22-87) 
Sec. 8.5-4. - Principles for decision-making. 
    In making its decisions the board shall be guided by the following principles: 
(1)  To be reasonable in judgment so as not to cause undue hardship to any property owner; 
(2)  To be careful in judgment so that the cost of the compliance is not so great as to constitute a taking of private property without just compensation; 
(3)  To be consistent in judgement with the purpose of this chapter and with the comprehensive plan of the village. 
(Ord. No. 888-79,  1, 10-8-79; Ord. No. 1580-87,  1, 6-22-87) 
Sec. 8.5-5. - Landmark designation. 
(a)  Landmark designation criteria. Landmarks are herein characterized as sites or structures which are: 
(1)  Important to the development, heritage or culture of the village; 
(2)  Identified as the place of a significant historical event; 
(3)  Identified with a person or persons who significantly contributed to the development of the village or of the region; 
(4)  Possessed of distinguishing characteristics of an architectural style common in the village or general area; 
(5)  Possessed of elements of architectural design, details, materials or craftsmanship which have historical significance; 
(6)  An established visual feature of the village; 
(7)  Valuable for the study of a period, style, or method of construction; or 
(8)  Significant because of their unique utilitarian purpose. 
(b)  Application for landmark designation. 
(1)  Any person, group of persons or association may request a landmark designation for any site or structure within the corporate limits of the village which may have historic significance as set forth in the criteria section in section 8.5-5(a) in this chapter. The village clerk shall supply application forms upon request. Completed forms shall be returned to the village clerk who shall forward applications to the board. 
(2)  An application to designate property as a landmark shall contain the name and address of the owner of the property, the location of the property including the street address, the legal description of the property, a physical description of the property including its external dimensions and other relevant data, the reasons the property should be designated as a landmark according to the provisions of this chapter, and the name and address of the person applying for landmark designation. An application shall be signed by the applicant. 
(c)  Action on application for landmark designation. 
(1)  Within twenty (20) days after receipt of an application for landmark designation, the board shall notify in writing the owner of the property of the proposed designation. 
(2)  Upon receipt of the application, the board shall schedule a public hearing to consider the application, to be held within sixty (60) days. At least twenty (20) days prior to the hearing the board shall give written notice to the owner and to the applicant of said hearing. Such notification shall set forth the date, time and place of the hearing. 
(3)  The board shall arrange for public notice of the time, date and place of the public hearing by publication, at least once, not more than thirty (30) and not less than fifteen (15) days before the hearing, in a newspaper published in the village or in a newspaper with a general circulation in the village published in DuPage or Cook County. The notice shall contain a brief description of and the location of the property proposed for landmark designation. 
(4)  At such hearing the applicant and the owner may be present with agents, attorneys and experts of their choosing and they, and any interested citizen, may present their respective position in the matter. At such hearing the board shall hear testimony and argument and admit evidence relating to the designation of the property as a landmark of the village. The hearing may be continued on the direction of the board but shall be concluded within sixty (60) days after it is opened. 
(5)  Within forty-five (45) days after the close of the public hearing the board shall decide whether or not to designate the property being considered as a landmark of the village. The decision of the board shall be written and mailed to the property owner and to the applicant within ten (10) days after it is made. 
(d)  Voting on landmark designation. A decision to designate property as a landmark of the village shall be made by a majority of the members of the board. 
(e)  Appeal of designation decision. If the property owner or the applicant wishes to appeal the board's decision [to the board] he may do so. Such appeal shall be made by requesting in writing a review of the decision of the board [by the board]. Such request shall be made to the village clerk within fifteen (15) days after notification of the board's decision. Procedures before the board shall be as provided by village ordinance and by law. The board shall consider and vote on the appeal within sixty (60) days after it is received by the village clerk. Further appeal to the courts shall be as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 888-79,  1, 10-8-79; Ord. No. 1580-87,  1, 6-22-87) 
Sec. 8.5-6. - Discharge from landmark designation. 
(a)  Application for discharge from landmark designation. 
(1)  Any person, group of persons or association may request if the designation has been in effect for two (2) years, that the property be discharged from the status of a landmark. If such request is denied it may not be made again for a period of two (2) years from the date of denial. Application to discharge a site or structure from the status of a landmark shall be submitted to the village clerk, who shall forward applications to the board. 
(2)  An application to discharge property from possessing the status of a landmark of the village shall contain: The name and address of the applicant and the name and address of the owner of the site or structure, the name and address of the applicant's attorney, if any, the location of the site or structure including the street address and the legal description, a physical description of the site or structure indicating what it consists of in reasonable detail, the external dimensions and other relevant data, and the reasons why the site or structure should be discharged from the status of a landmark referring to the criteria set forth in section 8.5-5(a) of this chapter. An application shall be signed by the applicant. 
(b)  Action on application for discharge from landmark designation. 
(1)  Within ten (10) days after the receipt of such application, the board shall give written notice to the owner, present applicant and to the original applicant at the last known address of the original applicant according to the board's records, of a public hearing of the board to be held to consider the application. The public hearing shall be held within sixty (60) days after receipt of the application. The notice shall set forth the date, time and place of the hearing. 
(2)  The board shall arrange for public notice of the time, date and place of the public hearing by publication, at least once, not more than thirty (30) days and not less than fifteen (15) days before the hearing, in a newspaper published in the village or in a newspaper with a general circulation in the village published in DuPage or Cook County. The notice shall contain a brief description of the property sought to be discharged from the landmark status, and its location. 
(3)  At such hearing the owner and the applicant may be present with agents, attorneys and experts of their choosing and they and any interested citizen may present their position in the matter. At such hearing the board shall hear testimony and argument and admit evidence relating to the discharge of the property from landmark status. The hearing may be continued on the direction of the board, but shall be concluded within sixty (60) days after it is opened. 
(4)  Within forty-five (45) days after the close of the public hearing the board shall decide whether or not to discharge the property from landmark status. The decision shall be made in writing and mailed to the owner and to the applicant within ten (10) days after it is made. 
(c)  Voting on discharge from landmark status. A decision to discharge property from landmark status shall be made by a majority vote of the members of the board. 
(d)  Appeal of discharge decision. If the property owner, original landmark applicant or the present discharge applicant wishes to appeal the discharge decision of the board [to the board,] he may do so. Such appeal shall be made by requesting in writing a review of the decision of the board [by the board.] Such request shall be made to the village clerk by the owner or the original landmark applicant or present discharge applicant within fifteen (15) days after notification of the board's decision. Procedures before the board shall be as provided by village ordinances and by law. The board shall consider and vote on the appeal within sixty (60) days after it is received by the village clerk. Further appeals to the courts shall be as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 888-79,  1, 10-8-79; Ord. No. 1580-87,  1, 6-22-87) 
Sec. 8.5-7. - Certificate of appropriateness. 
(a)  When required. There shall be no construction, no demolition, no movement, no alteration visible from a public way or from nearby property, in respect to a landmark, without there having been issued a certificate of appropriateness by the commission relating to such construction, demolition, movement, or alteration. 
(b)  Application for certificate of appropriateness. 
(1)  An application for a certificate of appropriateness shall be filed with the village clerk who shall promptly submit it to the board. The village clerk shall have available and dispense upon request, forms for such an application to any owner or developer of a designated landmark. 
(2)  The application for a certificate of appropriateness shall contain the name and address of the applicant and of the owner of the landmark, if different from the applicant, the name and address of the applicant's attorney, if any, the name and address of the architect, if any, for the applicant, the street address of the property, the legal description of the site or parcel of property on which the structure is located, a detailed description of the site or structure, a complete description of the proposed construction, demolition, movement or alteration, and drawings or sketches that are available and helpful in showing what is proposed. The description of what is to be done must be such as to enable an unsophisticated layman to accurately determine what the final appearance and use will be. The application for a certificate of appropriateness shall be signed by the applicant. 
(3)  A copy of the application for a certificate of appropriateness shall be forwarded to the building inspector. No application for a building permit affecting the construction, alteration, demolition or movement of a landmark shall be approved by the building inspector unless a copy of the certificate of appropriateness has been issued for the same work. 
(c)  Processing of application for certificate of appropriateness. 
(1)  If the board receives an application for a certificate of appropriateness which, on its face shows that failure to promptly grant the certificate of appropriateness will cause a substantial and imminent threat to health, safety, life or property, then said chairman shall convene an emergency meeting of the board as soon as possible but within seven (7) days after such receipt by the chairman. The board shall inform the applicant of the date, time and place of the meeting. At such a meeting, the applicant and/or his representatives may present evidence, testimony, and argument in support of the contention that failure to issue the certificate of appropriateness will cause a substantial and imminent threat to health, safety, life or property. If the board, by a three-fourths (3/4) majority vote of the members present at such meeting, decides that failure to promptly grant a certificate of appropriateness will because a substantial and imminent threat to health, safety, life or property, the commission shall waive the normal review procedures prescribed in section 8.5-7(c)(2) through section 8.5-7(c)(8) of this chapter and will promptly issue the certificate of appropriateness. If the board decides that failure to promptly grant a certificate of appropriateness will not cause substantial or imminent threat to health, safety, life or property, the application for the certificate of appropriateness will be reviewed according to the procedures prescribed in section 8.5-7(c)(2) through section 8.5-7(c)(8) of this chapter. 
(2)  Upon receipt of an application for a certificate of appropriateness which does not show that failure to act promptly will cause an imminent and substantial threat to health, safety, life or property, the board shall schedule a public hearing to consider the application to be held within sixty (60) days after receipt of the application. Within ten (10) days after the receipt of the application, the board shall arrange for written notice to the applicant of the date, time and place of the hearing when the application will be considered. 
(3)  The board shall arrange for public notice of the time, date and place of the public hearing by publication, at least once, not more than thirty (30) days, nor less than fifteen (15) days, before the public hearing, in a newspaper with a general circulation in the village published in DuPage or Cook County. The notice shall contain a brief description of the property, its location, and the proposed construction, demolition, alteration or movement for which a certificate of appropriateness is sought. 
(4)  At the hearing, the applicant, his representative and any interested citizen may present their position in the matter. The board shall hear testimony and argument and admit evidence relating to the application for the certificate of appropriateness. The hearing may be continued upon direction of the board, but shall be concluded within sixty (60) days after it is opened. 
(5)  During the hearing on the application for the certificate of appropriateness the board members shall make known their objections, if any, to the applicant, regarding the application. Consideration may be given to minimizing or removing the adverse effect, if any, which the proposed alteration, construction, movement or demolition would have on the landmark. Consideration may be given to alternative means, if there are such, of accomplishing the purpose of the applicant. Consideration may be given to the use proposed by the applicant for the landmark. The application for the certificate of appropriateness may be amended by the applicant upon a majority of the board members present to do so. 
(6)  Within forty-five (45) days after the close of the hearing, the board shall either approve or disapprove the application. If by a majority vote of the members of the board, the application for certificate of appropriateness is approved, the board shall promptly issue the certificate under his or her signature. Within ten (10) days after the decision is made, copies of the certificate shall be forwarded to the owner, applicant and to the building inspector. 
(7)  If the application for the certificate of appropriateness is not approved by a majority vote of the members of the board, the board shall notify the applicant and the building inspector in writing of the disapproval, and of the reasons for the disapproval. 
(8)  The factors to be considered and the standards for issuance or denial of the certificate of appropriateness shall be those set forth in section 8.5-7(f) of this chapter. 
(d)  Criteria for issuance of certificates of appropriateness. 
(1)  If the board finds that the alteration, construction, movement or demolition proposed in the application for a certificate of appropriateness will not adversely affect any significant historical, architectural or aesthetic feature of the property and is consistent with the spirit and purpose of this chapter, the commission shall issue a certificate of appropriateness. 
(2)  In making a determination whether or not to issue a certificate of appropriateness, the board may consider among other things the following: 
a.  The effect upon all exterior architectural features including signs, fences, porches, outbuildings, landscaping, paving and other appurtenances; 
b.  The violation of the general design and arrangement; 
c.  The modification to texture, materials, patterns and colors; and 
d.  The change in height, shape, scale, and proportion. 
(3)  In making a determination whether or not to issue a certificate of appropriateness, the board shall be governed by the following standards: 
a.  Every reasonable effort should be made to provide a use for a building which will require minimum alteration to the building and its environment. 
b.  Rehabilitation work should not destroy the distinguishing quality or character of the property. The removal or alteration of any historical or architectural features should be held to the minimum. The proposed work should preserve, highlight or enhance the historic or architectural character of the building. 
c.  Deteriorated features should be repaired rather than replaced whenever possible. In the event that replacement is necessary, the new material should match the material being replaced in composition, design, texture, and other visual qualities. 
d.  Some changes to buildings and environments which have taken place in the course of time are evidence of the history of the building. These changes may have developed significance in their own right, and this significance should be recognized and respected. 
e.  All buildings should be recognized as products of their own time. Alterations to create an appearance inconsistent with the actual character of the building should be discouraged. 
f.  Whenever possible, additions or alterations to a building should be done in such a manner that if they were removed in the future, the essential form and integrity of the original would be unimpaired. 
g.  Contemporary design for additions to existing buildings should not be discouraged if such design is compatible with the size, scale, color, material and character of the building and its immediate environment. 
(e)  Procedures following denial of application for certificate of appropriateness. 
(1)  If after the public hearing, an application for a certificate of appropriateness is disapproved by the board, said application will be denied for a period of not more than nine (9) months. During this period, the board and the owner or applicant or their representative shall bargain in respect to the objections raised by the board to the action proposed in the application for the certificate of appropriateness. At least two (2) weeks prior to a meeting for such bargaining, the board shall give written notice to the applicant or his representatives. Such meetings must be scheduled at reasonable times and not more frequently than is necessary for reasonable consideration of the board's objections and fair exploration of alternatives. 
At such meetings there may be consultation with private civic groups, interested private citizens and public boards or agencies in an effort to find a means of preserving the landmark. Consideration may be given to alternative use or sale of property. Consideration may be given to anything that would tend to preserve the site or structure as a landmark. 
(2)  If after the period of denial no agreement has been reached between the board and the applicant and if the applicant has reasonably explored alternatives to the proposed activity in accordance with the aforementioned procedures, then the board shall issue the certificate of appropriateness in accordance with section 8.5-7(c)(6) of this chapter. 
(3)  In granting the certificate of appropriateness, the board may prescribe any conditions it deems necessary, consistent with the granting of the certificate of appropriateness. 
(f)  Appeal of decision. If the owner or applicant wishes to appeal the decision of the board [to the village board,] he may do so. Such appeal shall be made by requesting in writing a review of the board's decision [by the board]. Such request shall be made to the village clerk by the owner or applicant within fifteen (15) days after being notified of the board's decision. Procedures before the board shall be as provided by village ordinances and by law. The board shall consider and vote on the appeal within sixty (60) days after it is received by the village clerk. Further appeal to the courts shall be provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 888-79,  1, 10-8-79; Ord. No. 1580-87,  1, 6-22-87) 
Sec. 8.5-8. - Alternate landmark designation. 
(a)  The board may enter into an agreement with a property owner or other party in control of a parcel of property, whether the property is improved or unimproved, for the purpose of providing for the designation of such property as an official landmark in the Village of Roselle. 
(b)  Such agreement shall provide for the placing of a plaque upon such property in a manner acceptable to the board and such property owner or other party in control of such property. The nature of the plaque, the positioning of the plaque upon the property and the manner in which it is affixed to the property may be included in such agreement. 
(c)  Such agreement shall provide that the board or the property owner or other party in control of the property, with whom the agreement is made, may, at any time, upon two (2) weeks' notice to the other party, remove the plaque on such property, giving or not giving a reason therefor. If substantial demolition of a designated landmark property is anticipated, notice by the property owner or other party in control to the board for the removal of the plaque from such property shall be given at least thirty (30) days prior to such removal. In such case, notice shall include notification of the intention of such substantial demolition. Upon the removal of such plaque, such property shall no longer be an historical landmark in the Village of Roselle. In the event the owner or other party in control of the property at the time the agreement is made is not the same person or entity as the owner or other party in control of the property at the time such notice is sought to be given, such notice may be given by or given to, and such removal may be made by, the owner or the other party in control of the property, as the case may be, at the time such notice is sought to be given. 
(d)  Property designated as landmark property as of February 13, 1984, pursuant to section 8.5-5 of this Code may be discharged from landmark status in accordance with the following procedure. Written notice shall be given by the board to the owner or other party in control of such property within sixty (60) days after adoption of this section 8.5-8. Such notice shall briefly explain the far less restrictive and nonbinding nature of landmark designation under this section 8.5-8. Such notice shall advise the owner or other party in control that within sixty (60) days after the receipt of such notice the owner or other party in control may request in writing to the board that such property be discharged from landmark status under this section 8.5-8 and that upon receipt of such request by the board, such property shall be designated from landmark status. Such notice by the board shall also advise that such request by the owner or other party in control may include a request for landmark status under this section 8.5-8 and that if made such request will be granted. 
(Ord. No. 1220-84,  3, 2-13-84; Ord. No. 1580-87,  1, 6-22-87) 
Sec. 8.5-9. - Enforcement; penalties for violation. 
(a)  Every owner (whether the owner is an owner of record or a beneficial owner not of record) or developer of a landmark will be subject to the following penalties if he carries out, or concurs in the carrying out, or fails to object, in writing to the carrying out of the alteration, construction, movement or demolition of any landmark of which he is the owner or developer for which a certificate of appropriateness is required by this chapter, and for which a certificate of appropriateness has not been issued. Such owner or developer, upon conviction, shall be fined not less than twenty dollars ($20.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each violation and each offense. Every day an offense exists shall constitute a separate violation. 
(b)  In addition to the aforedescribed penalty, the village may bring an appropriate suit to enjoin any act undertaken by an owner or developer in violation of this chapter, and to require restoration of any landmark to its condition prior to such unauthorized act. 
(Ord. No. 888-79,  1, 10-8-79; Ord. No. 1220-84,  2, 2-13-84) 
Sec. 8.5-10. - Relationship to other ordinances. 
    Nothing herein is to be construed as relieving any landmark owner or developer from meeting the requirements of other ordinances of the village in respect to the construction, demolition, movement of buildings or other improvements, or in respect to the alteration of property and improvements thereon. If there is a conflict between the regulations of this chapter and the regulations of any other ordinance of the village, the more restrictive regulations shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 888-79,  1, 10-8-79; Ord. No. 1220-84,  2, 2-13-84) 
Chapter 9 - LICENSES, PERMITS AND BUSINESS REGULATIONS[1] 
Div. 6.5. Flea Markets, ㎣ 9-276-9-280 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Regulation of alcoholic beverage establishments, Ch. 3; dog licenses,  4-21 et seq.; bicycle licenses,  5-5 et seq.; dumping permits,  8-36; municipal waste collection licensing,  8-63; regulation of sound trucks,  11-13 et seq.; offensive businesses prohibited,  12-4; sign permits,  17-19; paving permits,  18-6 et seq.; excavation permits,  18-31 et seq.; driveway permits,  18-65 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 9-1. - Persons subject to license. 
    Whenever in this Code or by ordinance a license is required for the maintenance, operation or conduct of any business or establishment, or for doing business or engaging in any activity or occupation, any person shall be subject to the requirement if by himself or through an agent, employees or partner, he holds himself forth as being engaged in the business or occupation; or solicits patronage therefor, actively or passively; or performs or attempts to perform any part of such business or occupation in the village. 
(Code 1956,  177) 
Sec. 9-2. - Engaging in more than one line of business. 
    Every person engaged in any category of business or occupation specified in this chapter shall pay the highest fee for any such occupation or business in which so engaged, which shall entitle the licensee to engage in any other business or occupation licensed hereunder without procuring additional licenses as provided for herein, with the exception of an alcoholic liquor establishment, dealer in coin-operated devices, tobacco dealer, or automobile filling station for which a separate license must be procured as provided in this Code. 
Sec. 9-3. - Applications. 
    Unless otherwise provided, applications for all licenses and permits required by this Code or by ordinance shall be made in writing to the village clerk in the absence of provision to the contrary. Each application shall state the name of the applicant, the permit or license desired, the location to be used, if any, the time covered and the fee to be paid; and each application shall contain such additional information as may be needed for the proper guidance of the village officials in the issuing of the permit or license applied for. 
(Code 1956,  176) 
Sec. 9-4. - Forms. 
    Forms for all licenses and permits, and applications therefor, shall be prepared and kept on file by the village clerk. 
(Code 1956,  178) 
Sec. 9-5. - Signature. 
    Each license or permit issued shall bear the signature of the clerk in the absence of any provision to the contrary. 
(Code 1956,  179) 
Sec. 9-6. - Inspections. 
    Upon the receipt of an application for license or permit where the ordinances of the village necessitate an inspection or investigation before the issuance of such permit or license, the village collector shall refer such application to the proper officer for making such investigation within forty-eight (48) hours of the time of such receipt. The officer charged with the duty of making such investigation or inspection shall make a report thereon, favorable or otherwise, within ten (10) days after receiving the application or a copy thereof. The health officer shall make or cause to be made an investigation in regard to such licenses in connection with the care and handling of food and the prevention of nuisances and the spread of disease, for the protection of health; and the building inspector shall make or cause to be made any such inspections relative to the construction of buildings or other structures. All other investigations except where otherwise provided shall be made by the chief of police or some other officer designated by the president. 
(Code 1956,  180) 
Sec. 9-7. - Cooperation with inspecting officers. 
(a)  Whenever inspections of the premises used for or in connection with the operation of a licensed business or occupation are provided for or required by ordinance, or are reasonably necessary thereto to secure compliance with any ordinance provision or to detect violations thereof, it shall be the duty of the licensee, or the person in charge of the premises to be inspected, to admit thereto for the purpose of making the inspection any officer or employee of the village who is authorized or directed to make such inspection at any reasonable time that admission is requested. 
(b)  Whenever any analysis of any commodity or material is reasonably necessary to secure conformance with any ordinance provision or to detect violations thereof, it shall be the duty of the licensee of the village whose business is governed by the provision to give any authorized officer or employee of the village requesting the same sufficient samples of such material or commodity for such analysis upon request. 
(c)  In addition to any other penalty which may be provided, the president and board of trustees may revoke the license of any licensed proprietor of any licensed business in the village who refuscs to permit any such officer or employee who is authorized to make such inspection or take such sample to make the inspection, or take an adequate sample of the said commodity, or who interferes with such officer or employee while in the performance of his duty in making such inspection, provided that no license shall be revoked for such cause unless written demand is made upon the licensee or person in charge of the premises, in the name of the village, stating that such inspection or sample is desired at the time it is sought to make the inspection or to obtain the sample. 
(Code 1956,  188) 
Sec. 9-8. - Payment of fees; prorating deposit; penalty for late applications. 
(a)  In the absence of provision to the contrary all fees and charges for licenses or permits shall be paid in advance at the time application therefor is made to the village collector. When an applicant has not engaged in the business until after the expiration of part of the current license year the license fee shall be prorated by quarters and the fee paid for each quarter or fraction thereof during which the business has been or will be pursued. Except as otherwise provided all license fees shall become a part of the corporate fund. 
(b)  If an application and payment of the annual license fee for annual licenses is not received prior to the start of the license year, a late fee shall be charged for each month or portion thereof the applicant is late, as follows: 
Annual License Fee Late Fee Per Month $ 15.00 or less $ 2.50   15.01-$99.99   5.00  100.00 or more  10.00  
(c)  When an applicant does not engage in a licensed business until after the start of the license year, the applicant must submit an application and pay the annual license fee prior to engaging in such business. If the applicant does not, a late fee per subsection (b) above shall be charged for each month or portion thereof the applicant engages in such business without having obtained a license. 
(Code 1956,  181; Ord. No. 1228-84,  1, 3-26-84) 
Sec. 9-9. - When licenses expire; notice. 
(a)  All annual licenses shall terminate on the last day of the fiscal year of the village, where no provision to the contrary is made. 
(b)  The village collector shall mail to all annual licensees of the village a statement of the time of the expiration of the license held by the licensee, three (3) weeks prior to the date of such expiration.
