Provided, that a failure to send out such notice, or the failure of the licensee to receive it shall not excuse the licensee from a failure to secure a new license, or a renewal thereof, nor shall it be a defense in action for operation without a license. 
(Code 1956,  182) 
Sec. 9-10. - Noncomplying premises not to be licensed. 
    No license shall be issued for the conduct of any business and no permit shall be issued for any thing or act, if the premises and building to be used for the purpose do not fully comply with the requirements of the ordinances of the village. No such license or permit shall be issued for the conduct of any business or performance of any act which would involve a violation of the zoning ordinances of the village. 
(Code 1956,  183) 
Sec. 9-11. - Change of location. 
    The location of any licensed business or occupation, or of any permitted act, may be changed, provided ten (10) days notice thereof is given to the village collector, in the absence of any provision to the contrary, provided that the building, zoning and frontage consent requirements of the ordinances are complied with. 
(Code 1956,  184) 
Sec. 9-12. - Nuisance business. 
    No business, licensed or not, shall be so conducted or operated as to amount to a nuisance in fact. 
(Code 1966,  187) 
Cross reference- Nuisances generally, Ch. 12. 
Sec. 9-13. - Revocation. 
    Any license or permit for a limited time may be revoked by the president and board of trustees during the life of such license or permit for the violation by the licensee or permittee of any ordinance provisions relating to the license or permit, the subject of the license or permit or to the premises occupied. Such revocation may be in addition to any fine imposed. 
(Code 1956,  189) 
Sec. 9-14. - Posting. 
    It shall be the duty of any person conducting a licensed business in the village to keep his license posted in a prominent place on the premises used for such business at all times. 
(Code 1956,  190) 
Sec. 9-15. - Marking of vehicles. 
    Whenever the number of vehicles used is a basis of a license fee, the village collector shall furnish each licensee with a tag or a license sticker for each vehicle covered by the license, and such tag or sticker shall be posted in a conspicuous place on each such vehicle while it is in use. 
(Code 1956,  191) 
Sec. 9-16. - License fees. 
    It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate any of the businesses named in this section without having first obtained a license therefor or without paying the annual license fee provided herein. Applications for such licenses shall be made in compliance with the general provisions of this chapter pertaining to licenses. The annual fee for such licenses shall be as set out opposite the listed business or occupation.

ARTICLE II. - AMUSEMENTS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- General authority to license, tax, regulate amusements, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  11-42-5. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 9-27. - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this article, except as to licensing and fees, shall apply to all public shows, theatricals, circuses and other amusements in the village, whether specifically licensed in another division in this article or not. 
(Code 1956,  193) 
Sec. 9-28. - Miscellaneous amusement licenses, fees. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate any amusement which is open to the public and for admission which a fee is charged without having first secured a license therefor; provided that the provisions of this section shall not be held to apply to those amusements which are specifically licensed by any other ordinance of the village. 
(b)  Applications for such licenses shall be made to the collector and shall comply with the general provisions of the ordinances relating to such application. 
(c)  For licenses the fees for which are not otherwise provided, a fee of five dollars ($5.00) per day shall be paid. 
(Code 1956,  194) 
Sec. 9-29. - Waiver of amusement license fees. 
    Amusement license fees may be waived with the approval of the president and board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 257-69,  1, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 9-30. - Use of public places. 
    No license shall be granted for any carnival exhibition, show or other amusement to be given on any public street or sidewalk or in such a place that the only main accommodation for the public or the audience will be in a public place, except on order of the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1956,  195) 
Sec. 9-31. - Permit for coin-operated machines. 
    It shall be unlawful to offer or maintain for public use any coin-operated device, machine or mechanism to produce or reproduce music or such coin-operated machine operating for amusement purposes without having first obtained a permit therefor. The annual fee for such permits shall be as provided in section 9-16. 
(Code 1956,  196) 
Sec. 9-32. - Athletic exhibitions-License required. 
    It shall be unlawful to conduct, operate or exhibit any race between persons, animals or vehicles, or any baseball games, boxing or wrestling matches or any other athletic contest or exhibition for admission to which a fee is charged without having procured a license therefor. 
(Code 1956,  197) 
Sec. 9-33. - Same-Statement of gross receipts; payment of fee. 
    The proprietor of athletic exhibitions shall submit to the village clerk, a statement verified under oath, of the gross receipts of each such game, contest or race, within one week after such exhibition. At the same time the proprietor or person exhibiting or operating such exhibition shall pay to the clerk the fee prescribed by section 9-16. 
(Code 1956,  197) 
Sec. 9-34. - Same-Maintenance of order; checking on receipts. 
    Sufficient members of the police department shall be admitted free of charge to all athletic exhibitions for the purpose of preserving and maintaining order; and the clerk may post a person or any number of persons at the box office of each performance and may examine all the books pertaining to such performance showing or tending to show the gross receipts. 
(Code 1956,  197) 
Sec. 9-35. - Orderliness; crowding. 
(a)  Orderliness. The audience of any amusement, show or theatrical must be orderly and quiet at all times, and it shall be unlawful for any person attending such amusement, show or theatrical to create a disturbance in the audience. 
(b)  Crowding. It shall be unlawful to permit or gather such a crowd to witness any amusement show or theatrical as to create a dangerous condition because of fire and other risks. 
(Code 1956,  199) 
Sec. 9-36. - Inspections required. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police and fire marshal to see that every exhibition, amusement, show, theatrical or other public performance is inspected by a member of the police and of the fire departments, and to insure conformity with the provisions concerning such amusements. 
(Code 1956,  200) 
Sec. 9-37. - Indecent performances. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to present, exhibit, conduct or take part in any indecent show, theatrical, play, motion picture, exhibition or other form of amusement or show. 
(Code 1956,  201) 
Cross reference- Obscenity generally,  13-31. 
Sec. 9-38. - Smoking-Prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to smoke or carry a lighted cigar, cigarette or pipe on or beneath any stage or in a dressing room of any building used as an assembly hall with seating accommodations for more than one hundred (100) persons or in which theatricals, shows, amusements, lectures or other entertainments are offered, operated, presented or exhibited. 
(Code 1956,  202) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention generally,  7-22 et seq. 
Sec. 9-39. - Same-Signs required. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner of any amusement premises in which smoking is prohibited or of the occupant in charge, to provide and place printed signs on which the words "NO SMOKING" shall appear in letters at least four (4) inches high, in conspicuous places, at least two (2) such signs to be placed upon the stage or in the wings thereof and one in each dressing room. 
(Code 1956,  203) 
Sec. 9-40. - Exit lights required. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant in charge of any building or hall used as an assembly hall with accommodations for one hundred (100) persons or more, in which theatricals, shows, amusements, lectures and other entertainments are offered, operated or presented, to provide and place a sign on which the word "EXIT" shall appear in letters at least six (6) inches high, over every door or other opening from such hall to every means of egress therefrom; and a light shall be provided with a red globe and placed at or over such sign, which light shall be kept burning during the entire period that the hall is open to the public and until the audience has left the hall. 
(Code 1956,  204) 
Secs. 9-41-9-45. - Reserved.

Footnotes:

Sec. 9-46. - License required. 
    No person shall operate, maintain or conduct a billiard, pool, bagatelle or pigeon hole table open to the public without having first secured a license therefor as is herein provided. 
(Code 1956,  206) 
Sec. 9-47. - License applications. 
    All applications for licenses required by this division shall state thereon the intended location of the place of business and the number of tables to be used therein. 
(Code 1956,  206) 
Sec. 9-48. - License fee. 
    The annual fee for any license required by this division shall be as prescribed by section 9-16. 
(Code 1956,  207) 
Secs. 9-49-9-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - BOWLlNG ALLEYS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to license, tax, regulate bowling alleys, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  11-42-2. 

Sec. 9-56. - License required. 
    No person shall operate or maintain a bowling alley open to the public without having first obtained a license therefor. 
(Code 1956,  210) 
Sec. 9-57. - License application. 
    Applications for bowling alley licenses shall be made in writing to the village collector and shall state thereon the intended location of the place of business and the number of alleys to be used. 
(Code 1956,  210) 
Sec. 9-58. - License fee. 
    The annual fee for bowling alley licenses shall be as prescribed by section 9-16. 
(Code 1956,  211) 
Secs. 9-59-9-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CIRCUSES AND CARNIVALS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 1691-88, adopted April 25, 1988, repealed Div. 4, ㎣ 9-66-9-73, concerning similar subject matter, and added new provisions in lieu thereof to read as herein set out. Said former provisions were derived from Code 1956, ㎣ 213-219. 

Sec. 9-66. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate any carnival or circus, which is open to the public and for which an admittance fee is charged or for which a fee is charged for carnival rides or other carnival type amusements, without first having obtained a license approved by the village board. 
(Ord. No. 1691-88,  2, 4-25-88) 
Sec. 9-67. - Applications. 
    Applications for circus or carnival licenses shall be made to the village clerk on an application form specifying the following: 
(1)  The name and business address and telephone number of the person or company conducting the circus or carnival; 
(2)  The name, address, and telephone number of the person who will he responsible for the management and/or supervision of the circus or carnival or who shall act as the liaison between the village and the owners/operators of the circus or carnival; 
(3)  The name or names and telephone number or telephone numbers of the person or persons who will be responsible for organizing, soliciting, promoting, and managing the circus or carnival; 
(4)  The proposed date or dates and the proposed beginning and ending hours of the circus or carnival; 
(5)  The estimated number of food concessions, game booths, and amusement rides which will be present; 
(6)  The approximate dimensions of the area in which the circus or carnival shall be conducted; 
(7)  The purpose of the circus or carnival; 
(8)  Whether or not charity, gratuity, or offerings will be solicited or accepted; 
(9)  Whether or not sales of food or beverages will occur. 
(Ord. No. 1691-88,  3, 4-25-88) 
Sec. 9-68. - Police protection. 
    The licensee further agrees to provide police protection at its own expense. The licensee shall submit its proposal for police protection to the chief of police of the village who shall approve or disapprove the plan after his examination of all factors which he may deem pertinent including but not limited to: anticipated crowd size; the dimensions of the area in which the circus or carnival are being conducted; the types of activities available at the circus or carnival; and anticipated traffic conditions and parking availability. 
(Ord. No. 1691-88,  4, 4-25-88) 
Sec. 9-69. - Indemnification. 
    Licensees shall agree in writing to assume the defense of and indemnify and save the village, its elected officials, employees, and agents from any and all suits, actions, damages, or claims to which the village may be subjected of any kind whatsoever resulting from, caused by, arising out of, or as a consequence of the circus or carnival and the activities permitted in connection therewith. 
(Ord. No. 1691-88,  5, 4-25-88) 
Sec. 9-70. - Denial of license. 
    The village board may approve or disapprove in its sole discretion any application based upon its consideration of the following factors: the proposed hours of operation of the circus and/or carnival; the proposed location of the circus and/or carnival; the impact that the circus or carnival will have on vehicular and pedestrian traffic patterns; the applicant's proposed plan for police protection; the applicant's prior history; the proposed activities which will be available at the circus and/or carnival; the impact the circus and/or carnival will have on surrounding neighborhoods; whether the circus or carnival will conflict with other previously scheduled public or charitable events; and what arrangements the applicant has made for refuse collection and clean-up. 
(Ord. No. 1691-88,  6, 4-25-88) 
Sec. 9-71. - License fee. 
    The fee for circuses or carnivals shall be as described by section 9-16. 
(Ord. No. 1691-88,  7, 4-25-88) 
Sec. 9-72. - Refuse collection deposit. 
    The licensee shall deposit the sum of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) cash to insure refuse collection and clean-up. If refuse collection and clean-up is satisfactorily completed by the licensee, the deposit, or that portion thereof not used for refuse collection and clean-up, shall be refunded. 
(Ord. No. 1691-88,  8, 4-25-88) 
Secs. 9-73-9-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - MOTION PICTURES AND THEATRICALS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to license, tax, regulate shows, theatricals, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  11-42-5. 

Sec. 9-81. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful to give, present, or conduct any motion pictures or theatricals for admission to which a fee is charged, excepting performances given solely for the benefit of and under the supervision of a religious, educational or charitable organization, without having first secured a license therefor as is herein provided. 
(Code 1956,  221) 
Sec. 9-82. - License applications. 
    Applications for license required by this division shall be made in conformance with the general provisions relating to such applications, and shall state in addition to the other information required the place of the intended performance and the seating capacity thereof. 
(Code 1956,  222) 
Sec. 9-83. - License fee. 
(1)  Any person securing an annual license for motion pictures or theatricals, naming a specific place or building where the performances are to be presented, may present therein any number of performances, including theatrical, during the year for which the license was secured without having to pay an additional fee. 
(2)  The license fee shall be as prescribed by section 9-16. 
(Code 1956,  223) 
Sec. 9-84. - Performances in unlicensed premises. 
    For motion pictures or theatricals, which are to be presented in premises which are not covered by a license, the fee to be paid shall be as prescribed by section 9-16; provided that no such motion picture or theatrical shall be presented in or on any premises or building which does not fully comply with requirements of the ordinances for the construction and maintenance of buildings for this purpose. 
(Code 1956,  224) 
Sec. 9-85. - Prohibited pictures. 
    It shall be unlawful to permit any persons to offer or present any motion picture which has a tendency to cause a riot or public disturbance of the peace; or any immoral or indecent picture or performance. 
(Code 1956,  225) 
Cross reference- Obscenity generally,  13-31. 
Sec. 9-86. - Orderliness; crowding. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to permit any person, excepting ushers or other theater employees, to remain standing in a hall or room in which a motion picture is presented during the time of such performance. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to admit to any such hall more persons than can be accommodated by the seating arrangements of the premises. 
(Code 1956,  226) 
Sec. 9-87. - Scenery. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use any scenery in any theater other than nonflammable scenery or such as shall have been rendered nonflammable by the application of fire preventive coatings. 
(Code 1956,  227) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention generally,  7-22 et seq. 
Sec. 9-88. - Building requirements. 
    It shall be unlawful to present any public motion picture or theatrical in any building or structure which does not contain the number of exits required by the ordinances of the village or by statutes concerning buildings or places intended for such performances, or in premises in which the electric wiring does not fully comply with the ordinances. All places used for the exhibition of motion pictures or theatricals must be kept adequately ventilated during the performance for so long a time as the audience remains therein. 
(Code 1956,  228) 
Cross reference- Building requirements, generally, Ch. 6. 
Sec. 9-89. - Obstructing means of egress. 
    It shall be unlawful to obstruct or permit the obstruction of any aisles, corridors, or exits leading from any room or enclosure in which a motion picture performance or theatrical is being given or in which an audience for such a performance is seated. 
(Code 1956,  229) 
Secs. 9-90-9-95. - Reserved.

    No person shall operate or maintain a miniature golf course open to the public without having first obtained a license therefor. 
(Ord. No. 2063-91,  1, 3-16-91) 
Sec. 9-111. - License application.

(Ord. No. 2063-91,  1, 3-16-91) 
Sec. 9-112. - License fee.

(Ord. No. 2063-91,  1, 3-16-91)

DIVISION 8. - SKATING RINKS 

Sec. 9-120. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate or maintain a public skating rink in the village without first having obtained a license therefor as is herein provided. 
(Code 1956,  244) 
Sec. 9-121. - License application. 
    Applications for skating rink licenses shall be made in conformance with the provisions of this Code and the ordinances relating to licenses and shall specify the location of the proposed skating rink and the person or organization sponsoring the same. 
(Code 1956,  245) 
Sec. 9-122. - Character of licensee. 
    No skating rink license shall be issued to a person who is not of good moral character, nor to a corporation or organization which is not represented in the village by a person of good moral character. 
(Code 1956,  245) 
Sec. 9-123. - Investigation of applicant. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police to make or cause to be made an investigation into the character of each applicant for a license hereunder and report the results of such investigations to the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1956,  245) 
Sec. 9-124. - License fee. 
    The fees for skating rink licenses shall be as prescribed by section 9-16. 
(Code 1956,  246) 
Sec. 9-125. - Exits. 
    It shall be unlawful to conduct a public skating rink in any hall or building which is not equipped with sufficient and adequate exits; and no hall or building which is not provided with at least two (2) exits of four (4) feet or more in width shall be used for such purpose. 
(Code 1956,  247) 
Sec. 9-126. - Conduct. 
    It shall be unlawful to indulge in any improper conduct or to permit any improper conduct at any public skating rink, and it shall be unlawful to permit music at any public skating rink after the hour of 12:00 midnight. 
(Code 1956,  248) 
Secs. 9-127-9-136. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FOOD DEALERS[8] 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation generally, Ch. 8; sanitation of alcoholic beverage establishments,  3-17; regulation of ice dealers,  9-251 et seq.; conduct of patrons at drive-in restaurants,  13-20. 
State Law reference- Inspections authorized, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  11-20-3. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 9-137. - Definitions. 
    As used in this division: 
    Canteen truck vendor shall mean any person engaged in the retail delivery or sale or products of food and drink by a motorized vehicle used to reach the site(s) from which delivery or sale is authorized by section 9-151(e). 
    Caterer shall mean any person engaged in the preparation and/or serving of food at a location other than the principal place of business. 
    Employee shall mean any person who handles food or drink during preparation or serving, or who comes in contact with any eating or cooking utensils, or who is employed in a room in which food or drink is prepared or served. 
    Food store shall mean grocery store, butcher shop, delicatessen store, confectionery store, bakery store, butter and egg store, milk store, fruit and vegetable store, fish store, drugstore, ice cream store, or any combination of the foregoing, or any place where food or drink is prepared, handled, stored, offered for sale, or sold at wholesale or retail. 
    Itinerant restaurant shall mean one operating for a temporary period in connection with a fair, carnival, circus, public exhibition, or other similar gatherings. 
    Itinerant vendor shall mean any person engaged in the house to house delivery or sale of any products of food and drink. 
    Mobile vendor shall mean any person engaged in the delivery or sale of products of food and drink, but only at a designated or specific site owned or leased by the village. 
    Open-air market shall mean any establishment engaged only in the handling and storage of fruits and vegetables offered for sale, or sold at wholesale or retail, such establishment not being entirely enclosed. 
    Restaurant shall mean restaurant, coffee shop, cafeteria, short order cafe, luncheonette, tavern, sandwich stand, soda fountain, and all other eating and drinking establishments as well as kitchens or other places in which food or drink is prepared for sale elsewhere. 
    Utensils shall mean any kitchenware, tableware, glassware, cutlery, utensils, or containers, or other equipment with which food or drink comes in contact during storage, preparation or serving. 
(Ord. No. 58-30, Art. II,  1, 2-24-58; Ord. No. 1143-83,  2, 2-7-83; Ord. No. 2063-91,  2, 3-16-91; Ord. No. 2353-93,  2, 8-23-93) 
Sec. 9-138. - Compliance required. 
    From and after twelve (12) months of the date of its first inspection no existing restaurant or food store shall continue to operate within the village unless it conforms with the Grade A or Grade B requirements of this division, and no existing open-air market or itinerant vendor shall operate without conforming to the approved open-air market or itinerant vendor requirements of this division. No restaurant or food store shall open for business unless it conforms to the Grade A requirements of this division and no open-air market or itinerant vendor shall begin operating without conforming to the requirements of this division. 
    Itinerant restaurants must comply with the itinerant restaurant requirements of this division before they will be permitted to operate. 
(Ord. No. 58-30, Art. II,  8, 2-24-58) 
Sec. 9-139. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any food dealer to engage in or do business in the village without having first secured a license therefor. Applications for such licenses shall be made in compliance with the general provisions of this Code relating thereto, and shall state the kind of food intended to be sold or handled. The annual license fee for the food dealers shall be as prescribed by section 9-16. 
(Code 1956,  251) 
Sec. 9-140. - Permits required; posting. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a restaurant, itinerant restaurant, food store, open-air market, or to operate as an itinerant vendor of food in the village who does not possess an unrevoked permit from the health officer. Such permit shall be posted in a conspicuous place. Only persons who comply with the requirements of this division shall be entitled to receive and retain such a permit. 
(Ord. No. 58-30, Art. II,  2, 2-24-58) 
Sec. 9-141. - Suspension, revocation of permit. 
    A permit required by this division may be temporarily suspended by the health officer upon the violation by the holder of any of the terms of this division, or revoked after an opportunity for a hearing by the health officer upon serious or repeated violation. 
(Ord. No. 58-30, Art. II,  2, 2-24-58) 
Sec. 9-142. - Display of grade placard. 
    The health officer shall post in a conspicuous place in every restaurant and food store a decalcomania or placard stating the grade of the establishment. Relocating, removing, obliterating, or concealing in any way said decalcomania or placard, or causing or inducing its relocation, removal, obliteration or concealment shall be deemed a violation of this Code. The operator of any restaurant or food store shall notify the health officer within twenty-four (24) hours of any damage to or deterioration of the decalcomania or placard which seriously impairs its legibility. 
(Ord. No. 58-30, Art. II,  3, 2-24-58) 
Sec. 9-143. - Examination, condemnation of unwholesome adulterated food and drink. 
    Samples of food and drink and other substances may be taken and examined by the health officer as often as may be necessary for the detection of unwholesomeness or adulteration. The health officer may condemn and forbid the sale of, or cause to be removed or destroyed, any food or drink which is unwholesome or adulterated. 
(Ord. No. 58-30, Art. II,  4, 2-24-58) 
Sec. 9-144. - Inspections. 
    At least once every six (6) months, the health officer shall inspect every restaurant and food store located within the village. In case the health officer discovers the violation of any item of sanitation required for the grade then held, he shall make a second inspection after the lapse of such time as he deems necessary for the defect to be remedied, and the second inspection shall be used in determining compliance with the grade requirements of this article. Any violation of the same item of this article on such second inspection shall call for immediate degrading or suspension of the permit. 
(Ord. No. 58-30, Art. II,  5, 2-24-58) 
Sec. 9-145. - Inspection reports. 
    One copy of the inspection report shall be posted by the health officer upon an inside wall of the restaurant or food store and said inspection report shall not be defaced or removed by any person except the health officer. Another copy of the inspection report shall be filed with the records of the health department. 
(Ord. No. 58-30, Art. II,  5, 2-24-58) 
Sec. 9-146. - Cooperation with health officer. 
    The person operating the restaurant or food store shall upon request of the health officer permit access to all parts of the establishment and shall permit copying any or all records of food purchased. (Ord. No. 58-30, Art. II,  5, 2-24-58) 
Sec. 9-147. - Requirements for Grade A establishments. 
    All Grade A restaurants and food stores shall comply with all of the following items of sanitation: 
Item 1. Floors . The floors of all rooms in which food or drink is stored, prepared, or served, or in which utensils are washed, shall be of such construction as to be easily cleaned, shall be smooth, and shall be kept clean and in good repair. 
Item 2. Walls and ceilings . Walls and ceilings of all rooms shall be kept clean and in good repair. All walls and ceilings of rooms in which food or drink is stored or prepared shall be finished in light color. The walls of all rooms in which food or drink is prepared or utensils are washed shall have a smooth washable surface up to the level reached by splash or spray. 
Item 3. Doors and windows . When flies are prevalent, all openings into the outer air shall be effectively screened and doors shall be self-closing, unless other effective means are provided to prevent the entrance of flies. 
Item 4. Lighting . All rooms in which food or drink is stored or prepared or in which utensils are washed shall be well lighted. 
Item 5. Ventilation . All rooms in which food or drink is stored, prepared, or served, or in which utensils are washed, shall be well ventilated. 
Item 6. Toilet facilities . Every restaurant shall be provided with adequate and conveniently located toilet facilities for its employees conforming with the ordinances of the village. In restaurants hereafter constructed toilet rooms shall not open directly into any room in which food, drink, or utensils are handled or stored. The doors of all toilet rooms shall be self-closing. Toilet rooms shall be kept in a clean condition, in good repair, and well lighted and ventilated. Handwashing signs shall be posted in each toilet room used by employees. In case privies or earth closets are permitted and used, they shall be separate from the restaurant building, and shall be of a sanitary type constructed and operated in conformity with the standards of the state board of health. 
Item 7. Water supply . Running water under pressure shall be easily accessible to all rooms in which food is prepared or utensils are washed, and the water supply shall be adequate, and of a safe, sanitary quality. 
Item 8. Lavatory facilities . Adequate and convenient handwashing facilities shall be provided including hot and cold running water, soap, and approved sanitary towels. The use of a common towel is prohibited. No employee shall resume work after using the toilet room without first washing his hands. 
Item 9. Construction of utensils and equipment . All multi-use utensils and all show and display cases or windows, counters, shelves, tables, refrigerating equipment, sinks, and other equipment or utensils used in connection with the operation of a restaurant shall be so constructed as to be easily cleaned and shall be kept in good repair. Utensils containing or plated with cadmium or lead shall not be used; provided, that solder containing lead may be used for jointing. 
Item 10. Cleaning and bactericidal treatment of utensils and equipment . All equipment, including display cases or windows, counters, shelves, tables, refrigerators, stoves, hoods, and sinks, shall be kept clean and free from dust, dirt, insects, and other contaminating material. All cloths used by waiters, chefs, and other employees shall be clean. Single-service containers shall be used only once. All multi-use eating and drinking utensils shall be thoroughly cleaned and effectively subjected to an approved bactericidal process after each usage. All multi-use utensils used in the preparation or serving of food and drink shall be thoroughly cleaned and effectively subjected to an approved bactericidal process immediately following the day's operation. Drying cloths, if used, shall be clean and shall be used for no other purpose. 
No article, polish, or other substance containing any cyanide preparation or other poisonous material shall be used for the cleaning or polishing of utensils. 
Item 11. Storage and handling of utensils and equipment . After bactericidal treatment utensils shall be stored in a clean, dry place protected from flies, dust, and other contamination, and shall be handled in such a manner as to prevent contamination as far as practicable. Single-service utensils shall be purchased only in sanitary containers, shall be stored therein in a clean, dry place until used, and shall be handled in a sanitary manner. 
Item 12. Disposal of wastes . All wastes shall be properly disposed of, and all garbage and trash shall be kept in suitable receptacles, in such manner as not to become a nuisance. 
Item 13. Refrigeration . All readily perishable food or drink shall be kept at or below fifty (50) degrees Fahrenheit except when being prepared or served. Waste water from refrigeration equipment shall be properly disposed of. 
Item 14. Wholesomeness of food and drink . All food and drink shall be clean, wholesome, free from spoilage, and so prepared as to be safe for human consumption. All milk, fluid milk products, ice cream, and other frozen desserts served shall be from approved sources. Milk and fluid milk products shall be served in the individual original containers in which they were received from the distributor or from a bulk container equipped with an approved dispensing device; provided, that this requirement shall not apply to cream, which may be served from the original bottle or from a dispenser approved for such service. All oysters, clams, and mussels shall be from approved sources, and if shucked shall be kept until used in the containers in which they were placed at the shucking plant. 
Item 15. Storage, display, serving of food and drink . All food and drink shall be so stored, displayed, and served as to be protected from dust, flies, vermin, depredation and pollution by rodents, unnecessary handling, droplet infection, overhead leakage, and other contamination. No animals or fowl shall be kept or allowed in any room in which food or drink is prepared or stored. All means necessary for the elimination of flies, roaches, and rodents shall be used. 
Item 16. Cleanliness of employees . All employees shall wear clean outer garments and shall keep their hands clean at all times while engaged in handling food, drink, utensils, or equipment. Employees shall not expectorate or use tobacco in any form in a room in which food is prepared. 
Item 17. Miscellaneous . The premises of all restaurants shall be kept clean and free from litter or rubbish. None of the operations connected with a restaurant shall be conducted in any room used as living or sleeping quarters. Adequate lockers or dressing rooms shall be provided for employees' clothing and shall be kept clean. Soiled linens, coats, and aprons shall be kept in containers provided for this purpose. 
(Ord. No. 58-30, Art. II,  6, 2-24-58) 
Sec. 9-148. - Requirements for Grade B establishments. 
    Grade B restaurants and food stores are those which fail to comply with items 1, 2, 4, 5 or 17, but which conform with all other items of sanitation required for Grade A restaurants or food stores. 
(Ord. No. 58-30, Art. II,  6, 2-24-58) 
Sec. 9-149. - What constitutes Grade C establishments. 
    Grade C restaurants and food stores are those which fail to comply with either the Grade A or B requirements. 
(Ord. No. 58-30, Art. II,  6, 2-24-58) 
Sec. 9-150. - Itinerant restaurants. 
(a)  Itinerant restaurants shall be constructed and operated in an approved manner. The health officer shall approve an itinerant restaurant only if it complies with the following sanitation requirements: 
(1)  It shall be located in clean surroundings and kept in clean and sanitary condition. 
(2)  It shall be so constructed and arranged that food, drink, utensils, and equipment will not be unduly exposed to insects or to dust or other contamination. 
(3)  Only food and drink which is clean, wholesome and free from adulteration shall be sold or served. 
(4)  An adequate supply of water of safe, sanitary quality shall be easily available and used for drinking and for cleaning utensils and equipment. 
(5)  If multi-use utensils are used in the serving of food or drink, they shall be thoroughly washed with hot water and a satisfactory detergent and effectively subjected to an approved bactericidal process after each use and so handled and kept as to be protected from contamination. Adequate provisions shall be made for refrigeration of perishable food and drink. 
(6)  Ice used in or with food or drink shall be from a source approved by the health officer and so handled as to avoid contamination. 
(7)  Garbage and refuse shall be kept in tightly covered, watertight containers until removed and shall be disposed of in a place and manner approved by the health officer. 
(8)  Dishwater and other liquid wastes shall be disposed of so as not to create a nuisance. 
(9)  No person suffering from any disease transmissible by contact or through food or drink, or who is the carrier of the germs of such a disease shall be employed in any capacity. 
(10)  Adequate and satisfactory toilet and hand-washing facilities shall be readily accessible to employees. 
(11)  No person engaged in the handling or serving of food and drink shall return to his work, after using the toilet, without first thoroughly washing his hands. 
(b)  Upon failure of any person maintaining or oparating an itinerant restaurant, after warning, to comply with any of these requirements, it shall be the duty of the health officer summarily to forbid the further sale or serving of food or drink therein. Any person continuing to serve or sell food or drink in such a restaurant after being so forbidden, shall be subject to the penalties provided for violation of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 58-30, Art. II,  7, 2-24-58) 
Sec. 9-151. - Itinerant vendors, mobile vendors and canteen truck vendors. 
(a)  Itinerant vendors, mobile vendors and canteen truck vendors of food shall operate in an approved manner. The health officer shall approve an itinerant vendor, mobile vendor or a canteen truck vendor only if such a vendor complies with the following sanitation requirements: 
(1)  Vehicles used in the delivery of food and drink shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, and the vehicle shall be so constructed and arranged that food, drink, utensils, and equipment will not be exposed to insects, rodents, dust or other contamination. 
(2)  Only food and drink which is clean, wholesome, and free from adulteration shall be sold or delivered. 
(3)  Adequate provisions shall be made for refrigeration of perishable food and drink. 
(4)  No person suffering from any disease transmissible by contact or through food and drink or who is the carrier of the germs of such a disease shall be employed in any capacity. 
(b)  The health officer shall summarily forbid the further sale or delivery of food or drink by any vendor operating as an itinerant vendor, mobile vendor or a canteen truck vendor, after warning, to comply with any of these requirements. Any vendor continuing to sell or deliver food or drink after being so forbidden, shall be subject to the penalties provided for the violation of this Code. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any mobile vendor to operate on property owned or leased by the village without first obtaining a written lease or sublease from the village. 
(d)  A mobile vendor shall be construed to be a nonmoving vehicle as provided for in section 18-21 of Chapter 18 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(e)  A canteen truck vendor shall be licensed through the village to sell, dispense and distribute by moving vehicle on private property where prior permission has been granted by the property owner. Canteen trucks shall not deliver or sell food or drink within any public highway or right-of-way in the village. 
(Ord. No. 58-30, Art. II,  7, 2-24-58; Ord. No. 1143-83,  3, 2-7-83; Ord. No. 2353-93,  3, 8-23-93) 
Sec. 9-152. - Open-air markets. 
(a)  Open-air markets shall be operated in an approved manner. The health officer shall approve an open-air market only if it complies with the following sanitation requirements: 
(1)  It shall be located in an area that is clean, well drained, and the area shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(2)  All fruits and vegetables which are not encased in a skin, shell, or wrapper that is removed at or before consumption or which fruits and vegetables will not be washed or cooked before consumption must be protected from promiscuous handling by customers and from contamination by dust and flies. 
(3)  All equipment and utensils used in the storing, display, preparation and handling of fruits and vegetables must be kept clean. 
(4)  An adequate supply of water of safe, sanitary quality shall be readily available and used for drinking and for cleaning utensils and equipment. 
(5)  Such utensils and equipment shall be subjected to an approved bactericidal process. Garbage and refuse shall be kept in tightly covered watertight containers, until removed, and contents shall be disposed of in a place and manner approved by the health officer. 
(6)  No person suffering from any disease transmissible by contact or through food or drink, or who is the carrier of the germs of such a disease, shall be employed in any capacity. 
(7)  Adequate and satisfactory toilet and hand-washing facilities shall be readily accessible to employees. 
(8)  No person engaged in the handling of fruits and vegetables shall return to his work, after using the toilet, without first thoroughly washing his hands. 
(b)  Upon failure of any person maintaining or operating an open-air market, after warning, to comply with any of these requirements, it shall be the duty of the health officer summarily to forbid the sale of fruits and vegetables therein. Any person continuing to sell fruits or vegetables in such an open-air market after being so forbidden, shall be subject to the penalties provided for violation of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 58-30, Art. II,  7, 2-24-58) 
Sec. 9-153. - Regrading, reinstatement of permits. 
(a)  Any restaurant or food store, the grade of which has been lowered and all grade displays have been changed accordingly, or the permit of which has been suspended, or any itinerant restaurant, itinerant vendor, or open-air market, the permit of which has been suspended, may at any time make application for regrading or the reinstatement of the permit. 
(b)  Within one week after the receipt of a satisfactory application accompanied by a statement signed by the applicant to the effect the violated provision or provisions of this division have been conformed with, the health officer shall make a reinspection, and thereafter as many additional reinspections as he may deem necessary to assure himself that the applicant is again complying with the higher grade requirements, and in case the findings indicate compliance, shall award the higher grade or reinstate the permit. 
(Ord. No. 58-30, Art. II,  9, 2-24-58) 
Sec. 9-154. - Diseased employees prohibited. 
    No person who is affected with any disease in a communicable form or is a carrier of such disease shall work in any restaurant, itinerant restaurant, food store, open-air market, or work as an itinerant vendor, and none of the abovementioned establishments or businesses shall employ any such person or persons suspected of being affected with any disease. If the manager of an establishment suspects that any employee has contracted any disease in a communicable form or has become a carrier of such disease, he shall notify the health officer immedintely. A placard containing this section shall be posted in all toilet rooms. 
(Ord. No. 58-30, Art. II,  10, 2-24-58) 
Sec. 9-155. - Procedure when disease suspected. 
    When suspicion arises as to the possibility of transmission of infection from any employee of any restaurant, itinerant restaurant, food store, open-air market, or from any itinerant vendor, the health officer is authorized to require any or all of the following measures: 
(1)  The immediate exclusion of the employee. 
(2)  The immediate closing of the establishment of business concerned until no further danger of disease outbreak exists in the opinion of the health officer. 
(3)  Adequate medical examination of the employee and his associates, with such laboratory examinations as may be indicated. 
(Ord. No. 58-30, Art. II,  10, 2-24-58) 
Secs. 9-156-9-161. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FOOD DELIVERIES 

Sec. 9-162. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful to use or permit the use of any vehicle, including wagons, motor vehicles and vehicles propelled by human power, for the storage or carrying of any meat, poultry, fish, cheese, lard, vegetables, coffee, tea, extracts, bread or bakery products, or any other provisions intended for human consumption, including beverages and milk, in the village for the purpose of delivering any such foodstuffs to any place in the village for use and consumption or for resale in the village for such purposes, unless a license for each such vehicle so delivering is first secured and the provisions of this division complied with. 
(Code 1956,  261) 
Sec. 9-163. - License application; list of licensees. 
    Applications for food delivery licenses shall be made to the village collector, and shall recite the name and address of the owner of the vehicle, the name or names of the persons from whom such deliveries are made, and the nature of the goods carried. The collector shall issue such license, and shall give to the village president a list of all such licenses issued. 
(Code 1956,  262) 
Sec. 9-164. - License fee; duration. 
    The annual fee for food delivery vehicles shall be as prescribed by section 9-16 and licenses shall be issued for one year beginning on the first day of May of each year. Such fees shall be paid to the village collector who shall turn them over to the village treasurer. 
(Code 1956,  264; Ord. No. 56-1-A,  3, 4-23-56) 
Sec. 9-165. - Exemptions from fee. 
    No license fee shall be required for any vehicle that is used to deliver foodstuffs fiom any establishment which is licensed and inspected in the village; but all provisions of this division, other than that providing for the payment of a fee, shall be complied with in connection with such vehicles. 
(Code 1956,  263) 
Sec. 9-166. - Regulations. 
(a)  All food delivery vehicles shall be kept in a clean sanitary condition and shall be thoroughly cleaned each day they are so used. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to permit stale food, decaying matter, or any other waste material or product to accumulate in or on any such vehicle while it is so used. 
(c)  If unwrapped foodstuffs are transported in any such vehicle, such goods shall be carried in a portion or compartment of the vehicle which is screened and protected against dust and insects. 
(Code 1956,  265) 
Sec. 9-167. - Inspections. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police to make or cause to be made such inspections as may be necessary to insure compliance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1956,  266) 
Secs. 9-168-9-172. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - MILK AND MILK PRODUCTS 

Sec. 9-173. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and the enforcement of this division. 
    Adulterated . Any milk or milk product which contains any unwholesome substance, or which if defined in this division does not conform with its definition, or which carries a grade label unless such grade label has been awarded by the Illinois Department of Public Health and not revoked, shall be deemed adulterated and misbranded. 
    Milk and milk products shall mean and include milk, cream, sour cream, half and half, skimmed milk, defatted milk, fat-free milk, nonfat milk, flavored milk, flavored drink, reconstituted or recombined milk, reconstituted or recombined cream, buttermilk, cultured milk, cultured skimmed milk, vitamin fortified milk, vitamin fortified skimmed milk, homogenized milk, soft curd milk, goat milk, breed milk, and other products made by the addition of any substance to milk or any of these products and used for similar purposes. Milk and milk products shall be defined as in Chapter 561/2 Section 115, of the Illinois Revised Statutes. 
    Pasteurization and similar terms shall be defined as in Chapter 561/2 Section 115, of the Illinois Revised Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 58-30, Art. I,  1, 2-2458) 
Sec. 9-174. - Possession, sale of adulterated, misbranded milk or products. 
    No person shall, within the village or its police jurisdiction, sell, offer, or expose for sale, or have in possession with intent to sell, any milk or milk product which is adulterated or misbranded. It shall be unlawful for any person, elsewhere than in a private home, to have in possession any adulterated or misbranded milk product. 
(Ord. No. 58-30, Art. I,  2, 2-24-58) 
Sec. 9-175. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to bring into, send into or receive into the village for sale, or to sell, or offer for sale therein, or to have in storage where milk or milk products are sold or served, any milk or milk product, who does not possess a permit from the health officer and all other permits required by law. 
(Ord. No. 58-30, Art. I,  3, 2-24-58) 
Sec. 9-176. - Compliance prerequisite to permit. 
    Only a person who complies with the requirements of this division shall be entitled to receive and retain a permit required by this division. 
(Ord. No. 58-30, Art. I,  3, 2-24-58) 
Sec. 9-177. - Permit suspension, revocation. 
    A permit required by this article may be suspended by the health officer, or may be revoked after an opportunity for a hearing by the health officer, upon the violation by the holder of any of the terms of this division. 
(Ord. No. 58-30, Art. I,  3, 2-24-58) 
Sec. 9-178. - Milk products which may be sold. 
    No milk or milk products shall be sold to the final consumer or to hotels, hospitals, soda fountains, restaurants, grocery stores, milk depots, milk stations, or similar establishments except Grade A pasteurized milk and Grade A pasteurized milk products produced and processed in accordance with Illinois Revised Statutes, Chapter 561/2, Sections 170-220; provided, that when any pasteurized milk distributor's permit to use the Grade A label is suspended by the Illinois Department of Public Health, the health officer is authorized to permit the sale of ungraded pasteurized milk or ungraded pasteurized milk products during a temporary period not exceeding thirty (30) days, or in emergencies, such longer period as it may deem necessary. 
(Ord. No. 58-30, Art. I,  4, 2-24-58) 
Secs. 9-179-9-188. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[9] 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic generally, Ch. 10. 

DIVISION 1. - RESERVED 

Secs. 9-189-9-195. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TAXICABS 

Sec. 9-196. - License required. 
    No person shall conduct the business of hackman, cabman or of operating a public passenger vehicle for hire, other than a bus operating on a fixed route, without having first obtained a license therefor, as is herein provided; and every person conducting such business shall conform to the provisions herein contained. 
(Code 1956,  463) 
Sec. 9-197. - Application for license; fee. 
    Application for a license to conduct such business shall be made to the village clerk, and shall specify the number of vehicles owned and operated by the applicant. A fee as prescribed by section 9-16 shall accompany the application, and no license shall be issued without payment of this fee. 
(Code 1956,  464) 
Sec. 9-198. - Bond required. 
    No license required by this division shall be issued to any person unless the applicant has secured the bond provided by statute. 
(Code 1956,  466) 
Cross reference- Requirements for surety bonds,  1-13. 
Sec. 9-199. - Age of licensee. 
    No vehicle license required by this division shall be issued to any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years. 
(Code 1956,  467) 
Sec. 9-200. - Register required. 
    It shall be the duty of the village clerk to keep a register of the names of persons to whom licenses are granted, or transferred, the number of the license and the description of the vehicle or vehicles licensed. 
(Code 1956,  468) 
Sec. 9-201. - Inspection of vehicles. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police to test or cause to be tested, at such intervals as he deems necessary, all taxicabs licensed hereunder; and it shall be the duty of every owner, operator or person in control of such taxicab to permit such inspection at any reasonable time. 
(Code 1956,  470) 
Sec. 9-202. - License revocation, suspension. 
(a)  The village board may revoke any license issued hereunder for violation of or failure to comply with any of the provisions of this article or for a violation of any state or village traffic ordinance. In such an event the fee paid for the unexpired term of such license shall not be refunded. 
(b)  If any taxicab licensed hereunder shall become unsafe for the transportation of passengers or unsightly in appearance, the license for said taxicab may be suspended by the chief of police until the said vehicle is put in fit condition for public use. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the chief of police to inspect every vehicle licensed hereunder a sufficient number of times each year to insure compliance with the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1956,  471) 
Sec. 9-203. - Driver's picture required. 
    A picture of the driver of a taxicab shall be conspicuously displayed in the taxicab in view of passengers. 
Sec. 9-204. - Marking on vehicles. 
    Every vehicle licensed as aforesaid shall bear on the outside thereof, in a conspicuous place, the name of the owner thereof, in letters not less than two (2) inches high, which letters shall be of a color in contrast to the color of the vehicle, and shall be properly proportioned and legible. 
(Code 1956,  472) 
Sec. 9-205. - Fares. 
(a)  The prices or rates of fare to be asked or demanded by the operator or owner of any vehicle licensed hereunder shall not exceed the amount that is set by ordinance. 
(b)  The distance to which the above rates apply shall be determined by the nearest traveled route from the point where the passenger enters the vehicle to the point where the passenger shall alight therefrom. 
(c)  There shall be affixed on the inside of each vehicle in a conspicuous place and in such manner that the same may be easily read by any person riding in such vehicle, a card upon which shall be printed in plain, legible type, the rates of fare. 
(d)  Any passenger shall be allowed to have conveyed upon any of the vehicles aforesaid, without charge, his ordinary traveling baggage; provided that ordinary hand baggage shall not be construed to mean trunks or sample cases. 
(e)  Upon request of any passenger the driver of such vehicle shall give the person requesting the same a receipt for the amount of fare demanded and paid. 
(Code 1956,  473) 
Sec. 9-206. - Overcharging. 
    The owner, driver or operator of any vehicle licensed as aforesaid, who may have demanded and received any fare in excess of what is provided for by ordinance shall return the excess received, and in addition, be liable to prosecution for violation of this Code and may have his license revoked. 
(Code 1956,  474) 
Sec. 9-207. - Advance payment of fare. 
    Every owner, operator or driver of a vehicle licensed hereunder shall have the right to demand in advance his fare of the person or persons so employing him or entering his vehicle, and may refuse to convey any person who shall not comply with said command. 
(Code 1956,  475) 
Sec. 9-208. - Duty to carry passengers. 
    No owner, operator or driver of any vehicle licensed as aforesaid, shall refuse to convey in the village, any person without or with hand baggage as aforesaid, when applied to for that purpose; or having undertaken to convey such person, shall omit or neglect to do so; under penalty of ten dollars ($10.00) for each offense. 
(Code 1956,  476) 
Sec. 9-209. - Parking on streets. 
    No person in charge of any public taxi or vehicle carrying passengers for hire shall permit the same, except when receiving or discharging passengers or when instructed by their passengers to do so, to stand on any street, avenue or alley in the village for any period longer than five (5) minutes, except as otherwise provided by ordinance. 
(Code 1956,  477) 
Sec. 9-210. - Soliciting trade. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner, operator or driver of any vehicle, licensed hereunder, to solicit by word, gesture or otherwise, the patronage of any person at any railroad station, or upon any public street in the village, and it shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle aforesaid to stand or be upon the platform of any railway until the expiration of three (3) minutes after the departure of such train, except to assist persons who have indicated a desire to patronize the vehicle in his charge. Whoever shall be guilty of any of the offenses mentioned in this section shall be fined not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each offense. 
(Code 1956,  478) 
Secs. 9-211-9-220. - Reserved.

DIVISION 5. - ITINERANT MERCHANTS[13] 

Footnotes:

Sec. 9-261. - License required; definition. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to do business as an itinerant merchant without having first secured a license as is herein provided. For the purpose of this division any merchant engaging or intending to engage in business as a merchant in the village for a period of time not exceeding one hundred (100) days shall be considered as an itinerant merchant; provided that peddlers shall not be construed as itinerant merchants. 
(Code 1956,  368) 
Sec. 9-262. - License application.
