DIVISION 6.5. - FLEA MARKETS[15] 

Footnotes: 
--- (15) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 1690-88, adopted April 25, 1988, amended the Code by adding provisions designated as  9-276; for purposes of classification, at the editor's discretion, said provisions have been incorporated as Div. 6.5, ㎣ 9-276-9-278. 

Sec. 9-276. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this division, a "flea market" shall be defined as a sale in a filed location by one or more itinerant merchants offering for sale, trade or barter items of merchandise or services and operating under the auspices of a not-for-profit corporation. 
(Ord. No. 1690-88,  2, 4-25-88) 
Sec. 9-277. - Certain items prohibited. 
    Itinerant merchants participating in a licensed flea market shall be prohibited from selling the following items: food, alcohol, fireworks, prescription or nonprescription drugs or medications, weapons of any kind, ammunition, animals, or pornographic materials. 
(Ord. No. 1690-88,  9, 4-25-88) 
Sec. 9-278. - Permit requirements. 
(a)  No person, corporation or organization shall participate in, advertise for or in any way promote, organize, control, manage, solicit, participate in or induce participation in a flea market unless such person or corporation is a not-for-profit corporation or charitable institution which has first obtained a permit authorized by the village board. 
(b)  Only not-for-profit and charitable organizations shall be qualified to obtain a flea market permit. 
(c)  Flea markets shall be permitted in all zoning districts. 
(d)  An application for a flea market permit shall be made upon a form provided by the village clerk and shall contain all of the following information: 
(1)  The name and business address and telephone number of the not-for-profit corporation or charitable institution and the name, address, and telephone number of the person or persons from the not-for-profit corporation or charitable institution who will be responsible for the management and supervision of the flea market or who shall act as the liaison between the not-for-profit corporation or charitable institution and flea market manager; 
(2)  The name or names and telephone number or telephone numbers of the person or persons who will be responsible for organizing, soliciting, promoting, and managing the flea market; 
(3)  The proposed date or dates and the proposed beginning and ending hours of the flea market; 
(4)  The estimated number of itinerant merchants who will participate; 
(5)  A list of the names and addresses of those itinerant merchants known to the applicant at the time of the application; 
(6)  The approximate dimensions of the area in which the flea market shall be conducted; 
(7)  The purpose of the flea market; 
(8)  Whether or not charity, gratuity, or offerings will be solicited or accepted; 
(9)  Whether or not sales of food or beverages will occur. 
(e)  The application shall be filed not less than thirty (30) days prior to the scheduled date of the flea market. Failure to file on time shall constitute a denial of the permit. 
(f)  Applicants shall provide and remove such barriers and warning devices as are deemed necessary and acceptable to the chief of police. Applicants shall also provide for the collection and removal of all trash, garbage, and litter caused by or arising out of such flea market. 
(g)  Applicants shall agree in writing to assume the defense of and indemnify and save the village, its elected officials, employees, and agents, from any and all suits, actions, damages, or claims to which the village may be subjected of any kind or nature whatsoever resulting from, caused by, arising out of, or as a consequence of such flea market and the activities permitted in connection therewith. 
(h)  Prior to the issuance of a permit under this division, all applicable ordinances and laws shall be complied with and all permits and licenses shall be secured in connection with such flea market, or the proposed activities associated therewith including, but not limited to, charitable solicitations, collection or acceptance of gratuities, sale of food, beverages, or other merchandise. 
(i)  Any permit granted under this division may contain conditions reasonably calculated to reduce or minimize the dangers and hazards to vehicular or pedestrian traffic and the public health, safety, tranquility, morals or welfare, including, but not limited to, changes in time, duration, number of participants or noise levels. 
(j)  Any permit for a flea market may be revoked by the chief of police at any time for reason of emergency, disaster, calamity, disorder, riot, extreme traffic conditions, violation of this division or any permit conditions, or undue burden on public services, or when he determines that the health, safety, tranquility, morals or welfare of the public or the safety of any property requires such revocation. Notice of the revocation shall be deemed served upon the applicant when mailed to at least one person named on the permit or when one person named on the permit is notified orally in person or by telephone. Continued operation of a flea market after revocation of permit is unlawful. 
(k)  The licensee shall be responsible for refuse collection, removal, and clean-up. The licensee shall deposit the sum of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) cash to insure refuse collection and clean-up. If refuse collection and clean-up is satisfactorily completed by the licensee, the deposit, or that portion thereof not used for refuse collection and clean-up, shall be refunded. In the discretion of the village board, this fee may be waived. 
(l)  The fee for a flea market permit shall be as prescribed by section 9-16(41). (Ord. No. 1690-88, ㎣ 3-8, 10-15, 4-25-88) 
Secs. 9-279, 9-280. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - LUMBER AND WOOD DEALERS[16] 

Footnotes: 
--- (16) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to license, tax, regulate lumberyards, see Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  11-42-1. 

Sec. 9-281. - License required; definition; application. 
    No person shall establish, conduct or maintain a lumber yard in the village without having first obtained a license therefor as is required in this division. Any place used for the storage of lumber, wooden containers or wood in an amount exceeding five thousand (5,000) board feet shall be construed to be a lumber yard. Applications for such license shall be made to the village clerk in writing and shall state thereon the location and size of the lumber yard for which such license is intended. 
(Code 1956,  387) 
Sec. 9-282. - License fee. 
    The annual fee for a license for a lumber yard shall be as prescribed by section 9-16 and no license shall be issued without payment of this fee. 
(Code 1956,  388; Ord. No. 56-I-A,  9, 4-23-56) 
Sec. 9-283. - Prohibited in fire limits. 
    No lumber yard shall be established or licensed within the fire limits of the village, but this section shall not be construed to require the removal of any lumber yard which is already located and established therein. 
(Code 1956,  389) 
Cross reference- Fire limits established,  6-28. 
Sec. 9-284. - Fire apparatus. 
    It shall be the duty of every person owning or operating a lumber yard to have the same equipped with sufficient fire apparatus to handle any small fires which may start and to prevent their spreading. 
(Code 1956,  390) 
Cross reference- Fire protection and prevention generally, Ch. 7. 
Sec. 9-285. - Piling lumber. 
    It shall be unlawful to pile any lumber in a lumber yard in such a way that the lumber is hanging over, or in danger of falling onto, any adjoining property, street, alley or public way. 
(Code 1956,  391) 
Sec. 9-286. - Inspections. 
    It shall be the duty of the fire chief to inspect or cause to be inspected every lumber yard in the village to insure compliance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1956,  392) 
Secs. 9-287-9-293. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - PAWNBROKERS[17] 

Footnotes: 
--- (17) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to license, tax, regulate pawnbrokers, see Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  11-42-5. 

Sec. 9-294. - License required. 
    No person shall conduct or operate the business of pawnbroker without having first secured a license therefor as is herein provided or in violation of any of the provisions herein contained. 
(Code 1956,  405) 
Sec. 9-295. - License application; investigation. 
    Application for a pawnbroker's license shall be made to the clerk and shall state thereon the name of the applicant; the place of business; and the number of employees intended to be engaged. The chief of police or any other officer of the village designated by the board shall investigate each applicant for such license and shall report back to the board whether or not such applicant is a person who has been convicted of the offense of receiving stolen goods or of burglary or robbery. 
(Code 1956,  406) 
Sec. 9-296. - License fee. 
    The annual fee to be paid for a pawnbroker's license shall be as prescribed by section 9-16. 
(Code 1956,  407; Ord. No. 257-69,  1, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 9-297. - Records. 
    Every pawnbroker doing business in the village shall keep a record of every article pledged with him or sold to him, and this record shall be open to the inspection of any police officer at any time during the hours of business. 
(Code 1956,  408) 
Sec. 9-298. - Weapons. 
    No pawnbroker shall receive as a pledge or purchase any revolver, pistol, blackjack or sawed-off shotgun, and no pawnbroker shall display in his window or shop any such weapons for sale. 
(Code 1956,  409) 
Sec. 9-299. - Age of licensee; dealing with minors. 
    No pawnbroker's license shall be issued to any person who is not twenty-one (21) years of age or over; and no pawnbroker shall employ a person of less than twenty-one (21) years of age to assist him in his business. No pawnbroker shall have any business dealings as a pawnbroker with any person less than twenty-one (21) years of age, except with the written consent of the parent or guardian of the minor to each particular transaction. 
(Code 1956,  410) 
Sec. 9-300. - Report of lost, stolen items. 
    It shall be the duty of every pawnbroker to report to the police any article pledged with him, or which it is sought to be pledged with him, if he shall have reason to believe that the article was stolen or lost, and found by the person attempting to pledge it in the case of a lost article. 
(Code 1956,  411) 
Sec. 9-301. - Acting as secondhand dealer. 
    No pawnbroker shall conduct the business of a secondhand dealer without having obtained the license required for such dealer in addition to his pawnbioker's license. 
(Code 1956,  412) 
Secs. 9-302-9-309. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - SECONDHAND STORES[18] 

Footnotes: 
--- (18) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to license, tax, regulate secondhand dealers, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  11-42-3. 

Sec. 9-310. - License required; fee. 
    No person shall operate or conduct a secondhand store in the village without having first obtained a license therefor, or without complying with the provisions of this division. The annual license fee for a secondhand store shall be as prescribed by section 9-16, and no license shall be issued except on payment of this fee. 
(Code 1956,  434; Ord. No. 257-69,  1, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 9-311. - License applications; investigations; character of licensee. 
    Applications for licenses required by this division shall be made to the clerk in writing and shall state the location intended to be used. Upon receipt of any such application the clerk or any person authorized by the president and board of trustees to do so shall investigate the character of the applicant and shall report to the village board the result of such investigations. No license shall be issued to a person of bad character nor to any person who shall have been convicted of receiving stolen goods, burglary or robbery. 
(Code 1956,  435) 
Sec. 9-312. - Refunds. 
    Every person operating a secondhand store shall keep a record of all articles purchased, which records shall be, together with the articles themselves, open to inspection by any member of the police department at all reasonable hours. 
(Code 1956,  436) 
Sec. 9-313. - Pawnbroking. 
    No person operating a secondhand store shall do business as a pawnbroker without first securing a pawnbroker's license in addition to the secondhand dealer's license. 
(Code 1956,  437) 
Secs. 9-314-9-319. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 10. - SERVICE STATIONS[19] 

Footnotes: 
--- (19) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention generally,  7-22 et seq.; gas pumps on streets and sidewalks,  18-40. 

Sec. 9-320. - Defined. 
    A service station is any place of business where gasoline or any highly volatile fuels for motor vehicles or internal combustion engines are sold or offered for sale. 
(Code 1956,  440) 
Sec. 9-321. - License required; fee. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate a service station in the village without having first obtained a license therefor. The annual fee for such license shall be as prescribed in section 9-16. 
(b)  No such license shall be issued unless the location and equipment to be used fully comply with this Code and the ordinances of the village. 
(Code 1956,  439; Ord. No. 56-1-A,  11, 4-23-56) 
Sec. 9-322. - Compliance by nonhusiness stations. 
    Any person maintaining or operating any storage tank for gasoline for the use of automobiles of the owner, lessee, employees or agents of such person, shall comply with all of the provisions of this division other than the requirement for the payment of a fee. 
(Code 1956,  441) 
Sec. 9-323. - Sales other than into vehicles. 
    No motor fuels shall be dispensed at any service station except into the fuel tanks of motor vehicles, when such tanks are connected with the carburetion system of such vehicles, provided, however, that individual sales up to five (5) gallons may be made in metal receptacles when painted red and labeled in full conformity with Illinois law, such individual sales to be limited to five (5) gallons to any one person. 
(Code 1956,  442) 
State Law reference- Color, labeling of gasoline containers., Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 1271/2,  153 et seq. 
Sec. 9-324. - Storage to be underground; maximum. 
    Storage shall be underground in compliance with the fire prevention code. 
(Code 1956,  443) 
Sec. 9-325. - Building requirements. 
(a)  No basement or excavation shall be permitted under any service station building. 
(b)  The floor level shall be above grade so as to prevent flow of liquids or vapors into building. 
(c)  The floor shall be of concrete. 
(Code 1956,  451) 
Cross reference- Buildings generally, Ch. 6. 
Sec. 9-326. - Grease pits prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to construct, maintain or use a grease pit. 
Sec. 9-327. - Sewer connection to washing, greasing rooms. 
    If a sewer connection is made to a washing or greasing room an adequate grease trap shall be provided to intercept grease and oils. The trap shall be cleaned out at least every thirty (30) days. 
(Code 1956,  454) 
Cross reference- Sewers generally, Ch. 22. 
Sec. 9-328. - Self-service. 
    Self-service gasoline stations are permitted within the village limits of Roselle in accordance with the following: 
(1)  Except at service stations which hold current and valid self-service station permits issued pursuant to the "Rules and Regulations Relating to the Storage, Transportation, Sale, and Use of Gasoline and Volatile Oils" effective May 1, 1977, from the division of fire prevention of the State of Illinois, by the state fire marshal, no person other than an owner of a service station, or an employee of such owner, shall use or operate any motor fuel dispensing equipment at any service station. No owner of a service station shall permit any person to violate the provisions of this section. 
(2)  Definitions. As used in this section, the terms specified in this section have the meanings ascribed to them in this paragraph: 
(a)  Service station . Any place of business where Class I, II or III liquids are sold or offered for sale at retail, and dispensed into the fuel tanks of motor vehicles. 
(b)  Self-service station . That portion of property of a service station where flammable and combustible liquids used as motor fuels are stored and subsequently dispensed from fixed approved dispensing equipment into the fuel tanks of motor vehicles by persons other than the service station attendant. 
(c)  Approved self-service dispensing device . Any device for the dispensing of Class I, II, or III liquids into the fuel tanks of motor vehicles as approved by the state fire marshal pursuant to the "Rules and Regulations Relating to the Storage, Transportation, Sale, and Use of Gasoline and Volatile Oils" but shall not include dispensing devices which are coin or card operated. 
(d)  Owner . Any individual(s) or legal entity holding title, lease, license or any interest in a service station or self-service station. The legal name, residence, address, and county of any individuals who are owners shall be filed with the state fire marshal and the village clerk. 
(e)  Attendant . The owner or any person who is paid wages by an owner of a service station to dispense motor fuel at such service station. 
(3)  The following rules shall be adhered to at all self-service stations, and violation of any said rules shall constitute good and just cause for suspension or revocation of a self-service station permit by the state fire marshal: 
(a)  The installation or use of unattended self-service dispensing devices for motor fuel of any kind is hereby prohibited. 
(b)  No dwelling unit or sleeping facilities of any kind for the owner, attendant or any person shall be permitted at a self-service station. 
(c)  Dispensing of Class I, II or III liquids at locations not open to the public does not require an attendant or supervisor. Such locations may be used by commercial, industrial, governmental, or manufacturing establishments for fueling vehicles used in connection with their businesses. However, this shall not include private fraternal clubs or associations. 
(d)  Special dispensing devices for motor fuel are not to be installed or used without prior written approval of the state fire marshal. 
(e)  Approved self-service dispensing devices are permitted at service stations available and open to the public provided that all dispensing of Class I, II or III liquids by a person other than the service station attendant is under the supervision and control of a qualified attendant and the dispensing nozzle is a listed automatic closing type without a hold open latch, and must be approved by the state fire marshal. 
(f)  It shall be the responsibility of the attendant to: 
1.  Dispense Class I, II or III liquids into approved portable containers; 
2.  Control sources of ignition; and 
3.  Immediately handle accidental spills and fire extinguishers if needed. 
The attendant on duty shall be mentally and physically capable of performing the functions and assuming the responsibility prescribed in this section. 
(g)  One type ABC fire extinguisher with a capacity of ten (10) pounds shall be provided for each pump island containing four (4) or less dispensing pumps; on pump islands containing more than four (4) dispensing pumps, an additional extinguisher shall be provided for each four (4) additional dispensing pumps or fraction thereof. Such extinguishers shall be plainly marked, shall be protected from the weather, and shall be maintained in operable condition and available at all times when the self-service station is open to the public. Such extinguishers shall be located at points approved by the state fire marshal, away from the dispensing area but close enough to the dispensing area to be readily available. All employees of the self-service station shall be thoroughly instructed as to the locations and proper use of such extinguishers and shall, upon request, demonstrate their ability in such use to the approval of representatives of the state fire marshal. 
(h)  Signs giving instructions for the operation of gasoline dispensing equipment shall be conspicuously posted at each self-service station offering self-service. 
(i)  Signs bearing the following words shall be conspicuously posted on each gasoline pump island where self-service is offered: 
"WARNING:" 
1.  "STOP ENGINE" 
2.  "NO SMOKING" 
3.  "It is unlawful and dangerous for anyone other than the attendant to dispense gasoline into portable containers" 
4.  "It is unlawful and dangerous to dispense gasoline without an attendant on duty" 
(j)  The signs shall be made of all-weather rigid material and the wording, lettering, size, design, material, mounting and location of said sign shall be subject to the approval of the state fire marshal. 
(k)  All fuel dispensing units shall be mounted or protected against collision damage by suitable means in a manner approved by the state fire marshal. 
(l)  Every self-service station shall maintain a control station in a location approved by the state fire marshal, equipped in such manner that the flow of liquid fuel from any or all fuel dispensing units may be stopped from such control station; a master electric switch shall be maintained at such control station so that electric power and pump lighting to all pumps may be disconnected at one time, and said switch shall be plainly marked and easily accessible. The control station shall be located at ground level not more than one hundred (100) feet from the farthest pump. The control station shall be so located that the attendant of such control station shall have a clear and unobstructed view of all pumps. The attendant shall at all times be able to communicate with persons in the dispensing area. The state fire marshal may at his discretion require a communications system between the control station and each pump island. 
(m)  At all times when a self-service station is open for public use, not less than one attendant shall be on duty, and no motor fuel shall be dispensed at any time when such attendant is not at or near the control station or pump island. The attendant's primary duty shall be to supervise the dispensing of motor fuels, motor oils and services normally related to such dispensing. Such attendant shall refuse service to any person who is smoking or who appears for any reason to be unable to dispense fuel safely, and shall shut off the dispensing unit if a patron fails to follow instructions in compliance with the rules. All attendants and other employees of the service station shall be thoroughly instructed in the operation and use of the communication system, control station, the fire extinguishing equipment, the operation of the dispensing units, and safety regulations for the dispensing of motor fuels. 
(4)  It shall be a violation of this section for any self-service gasoline station to install or operate any self-service dispensing device unless said device is equipped with a holding circuit. 
(5)  It shall further be a violation of this section for any self-service gasoline station to install or operate any self-service dispensing device unless each nozzle on said device is equipped with a splash guard. 
(Ord. No. 762-78,  1, 6-12-78) 
Sec. 9-329. - Fire prevention precautions. 
(a)  The fuel tank of no motor vehicle shall be serviced until motor and ignition have been shut off. 
(b)  No smoking shall be permitted on premises at any time. 
(c)  No open lights or flames shall be permitted except within a stove in the station building. 
(d)  Premises must be kept clean and neat, free from rubbish and trash. 
(e)  Cleaning with gasoline, naptha or other highly flammable liquids of Classes I and II (as defined in the fire prevention code) shall not be permitted in or around a service station. 
(Code 1956,  456) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention generally,  7-22 et seq. 
Sec. 9-330. - Fire extinguishers. 
    Each service station shall be equipped with at least one chemical fire extinguisher suitable for oil or gasoline fires. 
(Code 1956,  457) 
Cross reference- Fire protection and prevention generally, Ch. 7. 
Sec. 9-331. - Plans required. 
    Drawings or blueprints made to scale shall be submitted in triplicate to the president and board of trustees and shall be approved by them before any new construction, addition or remodeling is undertaken. Drawings shall carry the name of the person proposing the installations, the location, and shall in addition show the following: 
(1)  The plot to be utilized and its immediate surroundings on all sides; all property lines to be designated and adjacent streets and highways to be named. 
(2)  The complete installation as proposed, including tanks and their capacity, pumps, buildings, drives and all equipment. 
(3)  Clearance from tanks to property lines. 
(4)  Type of construction of service station building or buildings, with a clear showing that there will be no basement, cellar or excavation under any portion. 
(5)  Location of basements, cellars, or pits of other buildings on property or on adjacent property, and location of tanks with reference thereto as is provided in this division. If a building has no basement, cellar, or pit, make note to that effect. 
(6)  Location of sewers, manholes, catch basins, cesspools, septic tanks, wells or cisterns (whether on the property or adjacent property or in adjoining streets, highways or alleys) and location of tanks with reference thereto. If there is no sewer, manhole, or catch basin in a street or alley, or no sewer, manhole, or cesspool, no septic tank, well or cistern on property, make notation to that effect in proper place. 
(7)  Location of vent pipe outlets and location of fill pipe. 
(8)  Ventilation of greasing pit if greasing pit is located within a building or enclosure. 
(9)  Drawing shall be accompanied by an application for approval made out in triplicate on blanks furnished by the village clerk. 
(Code 1956,  458) 
Sec. 9-332. - Unlawful advertising of gasoline prices; penalty. 
(a)  It shall be unlawfuI for any licensed gasoline station in the village to advertise by sign, banner or any other devise whatsoever, a price for gasoline different than the actual pump price of gasoline dispensed at said gasoline filling station. 
(b)  Any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this section shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each such offense, and upon conviction the license of such gasoline filling station shall be suspended for a period of not less than ten (10), nor more than thirty (30) days. 
(Ord. No. 547-75, ㎣ 1, 2, 4-14-75) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 547-75, ㎣ 1, 2, adopted April 14, 1975 did not expressly amend the Code, hence codification herein as  9-332 was at the discretion of the editor. 
DIVISION 10.5. - CAR WASHES 

Sec. 9-333. - Defined. 
    A car wash, vehicular laundry or vehicular detailing business is any place of business used for the cleaning or detailing of any type or size motor vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 2063-91,  3, 3-16-91) 
Sec. 9-334. - License required; fee. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate a car wash, vehicular laundry or vehicular detailing business in the village without first having obtained a license therefor. 
(b)  The annual fee for such license shall be as prescribed in section 9-16. 
(Ord. No. 2063-91,  3, 3-16-91) 
Secs. 9-335-9-339. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 11. - TOBACCO DEALERS 

Sec. 9-340. - License required; application; character of applicant. 
    No person shall engage in the sale at retail of cigarettes, cigars, or tobacco in any form, or maintain a vending device for the sale or distribution of the same without obtaining a license as is herein provided. Applications for such licenses shall be made in writing to the clerk, and he shall cause an investigation to be made of the character of the applicant. No such license shall be issued to any person who is not a person of good character. 
(Code 1956,  480; Ord. No. 56-1-A,  12, 4-23-56) 
Sec. 9-341. - License fee. 
    The annual fee for licenses required by this article shall be as prescribed by section 9-16. 
(Code 1956,  481) 
Sec. 9-342. - Cleanliness; inspections. 
    Premises and buildings used for the sale of cigarettes, cigars or tobacco in any form must be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. The chief of police and the health officer shall inspect such premises frequently enough to insure compliance with the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1956,  482) 
Sec. 9-343. - Distribution or possession by minors. 
(a)  Definitions. As used in this section, the term "tobacco" shall mean cigar, cigarette, smokeless tobacco, chewing tobacco, snuff, pipe tobacco, tobacco in any of its other forms, pipes, cigarettes papers, or rolling papers. 
(b)  Prohibitions. It shall be unlawful: 
(1)  Sale to minors. For any person, including a licensee, the licensee's employee or agent to sell, offer for sale, give away or deliver tobacco to any person under eighteen (18) years of age. 
(2)  Possession by minor. It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of eighteen (18) years to possess any tobacco; provided, however, that the possession of tobacco by a person under the age of eighteen (18) years under the direct supervision of the parent or guardian of such person in the privacy of the parent's or guardian's home shall not be prohibited. 
(3)  Misrepresentation of age. For any person under eighteen (18) years of age to purchase tobacco or to misrepresent their identity or age in any manner for the purpose of purchasing tobacco. 
(4)  Distribution public property. For any licensee, licensee's employee or agent, or any other person in the business of selling or otherwise distributing, promoting, or advertising tobacco, to distribute, give away, or deliver tobacco products free of charge to any person, regardless of age, on any right-of-way, park, playground, or other property owned by the village, or any school district, park district, or public library within the village. 
(c)  Signs. Every licensed premises or vending machine offering tobacco for sale or distribution shall post a prominently displayed and plainly visible sign stating: 
    "THE SALE OF TOBACCO TO PERSONS UNDER 18 YEARS OF AGE IS PROHIBITED BY ROSELLE VILLAGE ORDINANCE, CHAPTER 9, SECTION 9-343." 
(d)  Penalties. 
(1)  Any licensee, employee, agent or adult who violates any provision of this section shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for a first offense. Repeat violators shall be fined not less than one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(2)  Minors. Any person under the age of eighteen (18) years violating any provision of this section related to the possession of tobacco shall be fined not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. 
(3)  Settlement. Any person accused of a first violation of this section may settle the claim by delivering the violator's copy of the ticket and cash, a check, or a money order made payable to the village at 31 South Prospect Street, Roselle, Illinois, in the following amounts: 
a.  First violation of section 9-343(b)(1): fifty dollars ($50.00). 
b.  First violation of section 9-343(b)(2): twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
All subsequent offenses shall require a court appearance. 
(4)  Any fine not paid in conformance with subsection (d)(3) of this section, after being given written notice by the village, shall have ten (10) days to settle the ticket or shall appear in traffic court and be subject to fine as descrbed in subsection (d)(2). 
Any person charged simultaneously with more than one violation of this section shall appear in court on those charges, including first violations of subsection (b)(1) or (b)(2). 
(Code 1956,  483; Ord. No. 2001-2833,  1, 4-9-01) 
State Law reference- Sale of tobacco to minors, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 23,  2357. 
Sec. 9-344. - License revocations. 
    Any license issued under this article may be revoked for a violation of any provision of this division, or of any ordinance relating to cigarette, cigar or tobacco dealers or their licenses or premises used. 
(Code 1956,  484) 
Secs. 9-345-9-350. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PREMISES SOLICITATION[20] 
Footnotes: 
--- (20) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2002-2946, adopted Oct. 28, 2002, repealed the former Art. VI, ㎣ 9-351-9-391, and enacted a new Art. VI as set out herein. The former Art. VI pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1956,  756; Ord. No. 322-70;  2, adopted 11-2-70; Ord. No. 1044-81,  1, adopted 9-28-81; Ord. No. 2212-92,  1, adopted 7-13-92. 
Cross reference- Regulation of itinerant merchants,  9-261 et seq.; noisy hawking or peddling,  11-2(1). 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 9-351. - Purpose. 
(a)  It is the purpose of this article to protect the health and welfare of the citizens of the Village of Roselle, to ensure clear direction to the police department in the regulation of commercial and noncommercial solicitation; and to protect the First Amendment Rights of solicitors, canvassers and peddlers operating within the Village of Roselle. It is further declared to be the policy of the corporate authorities of the Village of Roselle, that the occupants of residences, commercial establishments, or industrial buildings ("premises") located within in the village, have the right to determine whether any solicitor, canvasser or peddler shall be invited to their respective premises, and those persons who violate the provisions of this article constitute a public and private nuisance, and a detriment to the health, safety and welfare of the residents of the Village of Roselle. 
b)  The operation of any solicitor, canvasser or peddler in conformance with the terms of this article shall not be interpreted to be an endorsement of any solicitor, canvasser or peddler by the Village of Roselle, its elected officials, or employees. 
(Ord. No. 2002-2946,  1, 10-28-02) 
Sec. 9-352. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this article, the following words as used herein shall be construed to have the following meaning: 
    Premises. A premise shall mean and include every separate unit occupied for any purpose by one or more persons contained within any type of building or structure. 
    Solicit/solicitation. Solicit/solicitation shall mean and include any one or more of the following activities: any attempt or activity in furtherance of selling, acquiring or otherwise obtaining orders or contracts for the purchase of goods, wares, merchandise, food products, or any other property of any kind, character or description, including but not limited to, real estate and personal property of any kind or type, or services of any kind, character, or description whatsoever, for any kind of consideration whatsoever; and any activity which is carried on for the benefit of any charitable or non-profit association, organization, corporation or project or which seeks the contributions of alms, food, clothing, money, subscriptions, property or donations with or without an exchange of consideration. 
(Ord. No. 2002-2946,  1, 10-28-02) 
Sec. 9-353. - Premises occupant notice prohibiting solicitation. 
(a)  Any citizen of the Village of Roselle desiring to prohibit solicitors, canvassers or peddlers from their premises shall: post a sign indicating that solicitors, canvassers or peddlers are prohibited from entering onto the premises; and attach the sign to the principal structure located on the premises near or at the main entrance to said structure; and the text of such sign shall be at least one-third inch in height and state "No Solicitors Invited". 
(b)  If the principal structure on any premises is divided into multiple premises or dwelling units, each occupant of a premise to avail themselves of this article may post a sign in conformance with the requirements of subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  Signs posted as provided herein shall constitute sufficient notice to any solicitor or canvasser that they are not permitted at or on the premises. 
(Ord. No. 2002-2946,  1, 10-28-02) 
Sec. 9-354. - Duty of solicitors. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every solicitor, canvasser or peddler going upon any property within in the Village of Roselle to examine the area near or on the main entrance to said building or structure to determine whether it is posted with a notice consistent with this article. If a sign is posted consistent with the terms of this article, the solicitors shall immediately and peacefully depart from the property. 
(b)  Not withstanding the prohibitions set forth in this article, any solicitor, canvasser or peddler who has gained entry to any premises within the village, whether invited or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises when requested to do so by any occupant thereof. Such requests shall be phrased so as to lead a reasonable person to understand that they are no longer welcome on the premises. If a solicitor, canvasser or peddler fails to comply with the requirements of this paragraph, said failure shall constitute a separate, distinct and additional act of uninvited solicitation as prohibited by this article. 
(Ord. No. 2002-2946,  1, 10-28-02) 
Sec. 9-355. - Uninvited solicitation prohibited. 
    It shall be a violation of this article for any solicitor, canvasser or peddler to go upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or, at or near any door or create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant in such premises for the purposes of securing an audience with the occupant thereof and engage in any solicitation as defined herein, in contravention or defiance of any notice exhibited at the premises in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2002-2946,  1, 10-28-02) 
Sec. 9-356. - Time limit on soliciting. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and constitute a trespass for any solicitor, canvasser or peddler to go upon any premises and ring any door bell at, upon or near any door of any premises located thereon, or rap or knock upon any door and create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant in such premises for the purposes of securing an audience with the occupant thereof and engage in solicitation as defined herein, prior to 9:00 a.m. or after 9:00 p.m. on any weekday, or prior to 10:00 a.m. or after 6:00 p.m. on any weekend day. 
b)  Each premises visited in violation of this section shall constitute a separate and distinct violation of this article and shall be punishable by separate fine. 
Sec. 9-357. - Solicitation on roadways. 
    Only persons soliciting or canvassing for any not-for-profit company or organization, any religious institution or any political candidate, political party or any individual making political statements may solicit on the public roadways within the Village of Roselle provided that; any person soliciting shall otherwise comply with the terms and conditions of this article, except that roadway soliciting or canvassing may commence one hour after dawn, and shall terminate one-half hour before sunset. Any person soliciting or canvassing shall further comply with all provisions of ILCS ch. 625,  5/11-1006; and no solicitation or canvassing shall occur on any public roadway that poses a hazard to public safety or impedes or disrupts the free flow of traffic. All other soliciting, canvassing or peddling on public roadways is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 2002-2946,  1, 10-28-02) 
Sec. 9-358. - Fraud. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, engaged in any soliciting as defined herein, to make a false or misleading statement which is material to the subject matter of the solicitation, canvassing or peddling. For purposes of this section, the terms false and misleading shall have the meanings described to them by a dictionary of common circulation. Each false or misleading statement shall constitute a separate and distinct violation of this provision and shall be punishable by a separate fine. 
(Ord. No. 2002-2946,  1, 10-28-02) 
Sec. 9-359. - Convicted felon. 
    Solicitation or canvassing by any person convicted of any felony under the laws of the United States or any state of the United States is hereby prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 2002-2946,  1, 10-28-02) 
Sec. 9-360. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any person found guilty of committing a violation of this article shall be subject to a fine of not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and each separate violation of this article shall be considered as a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2002-2946,  1, 10-28-02) 
Secs. 9-361-9-391. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - OTHER BUSINESSES 
DIVISION 1. - BARBER AND BEAUTY SHOPS[21] 

Footnotes: 
--- (21) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to license, tax, regulate barbers, barbershops, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch.  11-42-1. 

Sec. 9-392. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or operate a barbershop in the village without having first obtained a license therefor. For the purposes of this division a beauty shop or beauty salon shall be also defined as a barbershop. 
(Code 1956,  313) 
Sec. 9-393. - License application. 
    Application for barbershop licenses shall be made in writing to the clerk and shall state thereon the number of chairs to be used in the establishment. 
(Code 1956,  314) 
Sec. 9-394. - Fee. 
    The annual fee for such licenses shall be as prescribed by section 9-16. 
(Code 1956,  315; Ord. No. 56-1-A,  6, 4-23-56; Ord. No. 257-69,  1, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 9-395. - Sanitation. 
    Premises used for a barbershop shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, and it shall be unlawful to permit waste material of any kind to accumulate therein. It shall be unlawful to employ in such establishments any person afflicted with a venereal or contagious disease. 
(Code 1956,  316) 
Sec. 9-396. - Implements. 
    It shall be unlawful to use in any establishment used as a barbershop any implements or tools upon any person after the same have been used upon a person afflicted with any skin disease or any scalp disease without first sterilizing the implement or tool. It shall be unlawful to use any towel on any customer after the same has been used before without having such towel sterilized and cleaned prior to such second usage. 
(Code 1956,  317) 
Sec. 9-397. - Inspections. 
    It shall be the duty of the health officer or some other person designated by the president and board of trustees to inspect every establishment licensed under this division as often as necessary to insure compliance with this division and all other ordinances relative thereto. 
(Code 1956,  318) 
Secs. 9-398-9-402. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - COIN-OPERATED DEVICES AND COIN-OPERATED AMUSEMENTS 

Sec. 9-403. - Permit required for music, amusement machines; fee. 
    It shall be unlawful to offer or maintain for public use any coin-operated device, machine or mechanism to produce or reproduce music or such coin-operated machine operating for amusement purposes without having first obtained a permit therefor. The annual fee for such permits shall be as prescribed in section 9-16. 
(Ord. No. 90-62,  1, 3-26-62) 
Sec. 9-404. - Permit required for vending machines; fee. 
    It shall be unlawful to offer or maintain for public use any coin-operated device, machine or mechanism for vending purposes without having first obtained a permit therefor. The annual fee for such permits shall be as prescribed in section 9-16. 
(Ord. No. 90-62,  1, 3-26-62) 
Sec. 9-405. - Sanitation requirements for vending machines. 
    Permits shall be issued for coin-operated devices, machines or mechanisms for vending purposes only if such devices, machines or mechanisms and the owners thereof comply with the following sanitation requirements: 
(1)  Vehicles used in the delivery of food and drink shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and the vehicle shall be so constructed and arranged so that food, drink, utensils and equipment shall not be exposed to insects, dust or other contamination. Only food and drink which is clean, wholesome and free from adulteration shall be sold or delivered and the devices, machines and mechanisms shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition in order that the food and drink shall be clean, wholesome and free from adulteration. Adequate provisions shall be made for refrigeration of perishable food and drink. Utensils used in the delivery of food from vehicles to delivery point shall be constructed so as to protect that food from dust, insect or other contamination. 
(2)  No person suffering from any disease transmissible by contact or through food or drink or who is the carrier of the germs of such a disease shall be employed in any capacity. 
(Ord. No. 90-62,  2, 3-26-62) 
Sec. 9-406. - Noncomplying vending machines. 
    Upon failure of any person owning, maintaining or operating a device, machine or mechanism for vending purposes, after warning, to comply with any of these requirements, it shall be the duty of the health officer summarily to forbid the further sale or serving of food or drink therein. Any person continuing to serve or sell food or drink in such device, machine or mechanism after being so forbidden, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 90-62,  3, 3-26-62) 
Sec. 9-407. - Definitions. 
    Coin-operated amusement device . The term "coin-operated amusement device" as used herein means any amusement machine or device operated by means of the insertion of a coin, token, or similar object, for the purpose of amusement or skill and for the playing of which a fee is charged, which returns to the player thereof no money or property or right to receive money or property. The term does not include vending machines in which are not incorporated gaming or amusement features, nor does the term include any coin-operated mechanical musical devices. 
    Game room . "Game room," when used herein, shall mean any premises in which ten (10) or more coin-operated amusement devices are operated for commercial purposes. 
    Game room licensee . "Game room licensee," when used herein, shall mean any person, firm, corporation or association in immediate control of premises, including any owner or lessee thereof, within or upon which ten (10) or more coin-operated amusement devices are operated for commercial purposes. 
    Person . "Person," as used herein, shall include the following: Any person, firm or corporation or association which owns or leases any coin-operated amusement device; the person, firm, corporation or association in whose place of business any such device is placed for use by the public; and the person, firm, corporation or association having control over such device. 
    Proprietor . "Proprietor," is hereby defined to be any person, firm, corporation, partnership, association or club who, as the owner, lessee, or proprietor has under his or its control any establishment, place or premises in or at which such device is placed or kept for use or play, or on exhibition for the purpose of use or play. 
    Recreational/amusement facility . "Recreational/amusement facility," as used herein, shall include and be limited to bowling alleys, skating rinks, and indoor miniature golf facilities. 
    Restaurant . "Restaurant," as used herein, means any public place kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public as a place where meals are served, and where meals are actually and regularly served, without sleeping accommodations, such place being provided with adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining room equipment and capacity, a dining room or rooms seating a minimum of forty (40) persons, having employed therein a sufficient number and kind of employees to prepare, cook and serve suitable food for its guests. 
(Ord. No. 1035-81,  1, 8-24-81; Ord. No. 1074-82,  1, 4-12-82) 
Editor's note- Former ㎣ 9-407-9-412 pertained to coin-operated amusement devices as derived from Ord. No. 937-80,  1, adopted May 12, 1980. Such provisions were deleted and new material relative to similar subject matter was set forth in lieu thereof pursuant to Ord. No. 1035-81,  1, adopted Aug. 24, 1981. 
Sec. 9-408. - Permit required for coin-operated devices and number thereof. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall engage in the business of a proprietor of coin-operated amusement devices as the term is herein defined, and no person, firm or corporation shall locate, maintain or operate within the village any coin-operated amusement device for use by the public without first having obtained a license therefor, as herein provided. 
    In addition to the other requirements of this division, the number of such licenses to be issued to any such person, firm or corporation to engage in the business as such a proprietor shall not exceed the following: 
(1)  Businesses in operation in the village less than six (6) months shall be permitted zero (0) machines; 
(2)  Those in operation more than six (6) months and less than one year shall be permitted three (3) machines; 
(3)  Those in operation more than one (1) year shall be permitted up to the maximum of six (6) as provided elsewhere in this division; 
(4)  New businesses that have as their principal business the serving of food for consumption on the premises or those whose principal business is entertainment, including bowling alleys, may make application to the president for approval by the village board, for exceptions to the above requirements. 
(Ord. No. 1035-81,  1, 8-24-81; Ord. No. 1074-82,  1, 4-12-82; Ord. No. 1090-82,  1, 6-7-82) 
  Note- See the editor's note following  9-407. 
Sec. 9-409. - Application for licenses. 
    An application for a Class "A" license for licensing nine (9) or fewer coin-operated amusement devices shall be made to the village clerk. An application for a Class "B" game room license, for a variance to operate ten (10) or more coin-operated devices shall be made to the village president and filed with the village clerk with a nonrefundable application and investigation fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). In the event a Class "B" or a Class "C" license is issued, the application fee shall be applied to the licensee's first annual license fee. 
    Each application for a game room license shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and phone number of the applicant; 
(2)  Location of the place of business; 
(3)  Principal business engaged in by applicant; 
(4)  Statement of whether business will be conducted by a manager or agent, and the name, address and phone number of any such manager or agent; 
(5)  A diagram showing the number of coin-operated amusement devices to be located on the premises and the location of each device on the premises. A description of each device, including the serial number, shall be supplied within thirty (30) days after license is issued; 
(6)  The charge to be made to the player for operating each such device; 
(7)  If a corporation, set forth the following: 
(a)  Corporate name and address; 
(b)  Date and place of incorporation; 
(c)  Names and addresses of corporate officers and directors; 
(d)  Names and addresses of all persons or legal entities owning five (5) per cent or more of the corporation's stock; 
(8)  If a partnership, set forth the following: 
(a)  Date and place when the partnership was formed; 
(b)  The names of all general partners; 
(c)  If a limited partnership, the names of all limited partners owning five (5) per cent or more interest in the partnership; 
(9)  State whether any individual, partner, officer, or named shareholder has ever been convicted of any criminal offense in any state or federal court or has ever forfeited an appearance bond on a felony charge; if yes, state the offense; 
(10)  If the business on the subject premises will be conducted by a manager or agent, state whether the manager or agent has ever been convicted of any criminal offense in any state or federal court or has ever forfeited an appearance bond on a felony charge; if yes, state the offense. 
    If an approved application for a game room license is not put into use by the applicant within ninety (90) days of the date of approval by the village president, the license will not be considered valid for the operation of a game room. 
    Applications for license shall be made out in duplicate, one copy being referred to the chief of police and the other copy to be referred to the village administrator. The application shall be investigated by the chief of police and village administrator in accordance with the provisions of section 9-610 of this Code. The village president shall thereupon issue the license to the applicant. If it is determined that the applicant does not qualify for a license, the applicant shall have the right of appeal pursuant to section 9-611 of this Code. No license shall be issued hereunder if the applicant, or if a partnership or corporation, any officer, director, or shareholder owning five (5) percent or more of the shares of said corporation, or any member of the partnership, or any manager or agent in charge of the premises has been convicted of a felony or any crime involving dishonesty or false statement. 
(Ord. No. 1035-81,  1, 8-24-81; Ord. No. 1074-82,  1, 4-12-82) 
  Note- See the editor's note following  9-407. 
Sec. 9-410. - Classification of licenses; scope; fees. 
    Coin-operated amusement devices may be located, maintained or operated in or upon any single business establishment except, where the number is permitted in accordance with Class B described herein, so long as their operation is secondary or incidental to the main or principal occupation or business being conducted or to be conducted by the applicant in or upon said establishment. Every person operating one or more of such devices shall pay an annual license fee as follows: 
(1)  Class "A" license. A Class "A" license shall permit the operation of no more than nine (9) individual coin-operated amusement devices in a qualified establishment. The license fee for a Class "A" license shall be sixty-five dollars ($65.00) for each coin operated amusement device. 
(2)  Class "B" license. A Class "B" license shall permit the operation of a game room located in a recreational/amusement facility or restaurant, containing more than nine (9) coin-operated amusement devices. The license fee for a Class "B" license shall be sixty-five dollars ($65.00) for each of the first nine (9) devices and ninety dollars ($90.00) for each device over nine (9). In addition to the fee for each device, each Class "B" licensee shall pay the sum of five hundred fifty dollars ($550.00) per year. Such license fees shall be paid annually in advance, or may be paid in two (2) identical semi-annual installments equal to fifty-two and one-half (52.5) percent of the full annual fee. Licenses paid for in two (2) semi-annual installments shall expire on October 31 with respect to the first installment and may be reissued to expire April 30 upon payment of the second installment. 
(3)  For each coin-operated amusement device, the village clerk shall issue an individual license, which shall be affixed on the front or on a clearly exposed side of the device. Such license for each individual device may be transferred from one coin-operated amusement device to another similar device upon application to the village clerk; such application to include a description and serial number of the new coin-operated device. No fee shall be required for the transfer of a license hereunder. The village clerk may, in the alternative, issue a single license to each business authorized to operate coin-operated amusement devices for a given number of such devices. Such license shall be posted in a prominent place on the premises of the licensee and the number of coin-operated amusement devices on the premises shall not exceed the number listed on the license. 
    A license shall be purely a personal privilege, good for not to exceed one year from issuance unless sooner revoked as in this chapter provided, and shall not constitute property, nor shall it be subject to attachment, garnishment or execution, nor shall it be alienable or transferable, voluntarily or involuntarily, or subject to being encumbered or hypothecated. 
    The village president may revoke or suspend any license issued pursuant to the provisions of this division if he determines that the licensee has violated any of the provisions of Illinois law or of any valid ordinance or resolution enacted by the president or board of trustees or any applicable rule or regulations established by any governmental body having authority. However, no such license shall be so revoked or suspended except after a public hearing by the village president with a three-day written notice to the licensee affording the licensee an opportunity to appear and defend. The village president shall within five (5) days after such hearing, if he determines after such hearing that the license should be revoked or suspended, state the reason or reasons for such determination in a written order of revocation or suspension and shall serve a copy of such order within the five (5) days upon the licensee. 
(Ord. No. 1035-81,  1, 8-24-81; Ord. No. 1074-82,  1, 4-12-82; Ord. 1808-89,  1, 3-27-89; Ord. No. 1935-90,  1, 3-26-90; Ord. No. 2089-91,  1, 6-10-91; Ord. No. 2016-3819,  2, 1-25-16) 
  Note- See the editor's note following  9-407. 
Sec. 9-411. - Operation and conduct for a game room. 
    The licensing of ten (10) or more machines to be located, maintained or operated at one business establishment may be permitted by applying to the village president for a variance and fulfilling certain conditions established herein for a Class "B" or Class "C" game room license. 
    Class "B" license : 
(1)  There shall be no more than one Class "B" game room license in the aggregate outstanding at any one time. 
(2)  The operation of a Class "B" game room shall be an accessory commercial purpose to the principal occupation or business being conducted or to be conducted by the applicant upon the same premises which shall be a recreational/amusement facility as defined herein. 
(3)  All coin-operated amusement devices shall be operated in a separate room from the principal business activities which permits a full view of game room activities and provides a minimum of twenty (20) square feet per device and not more than ten (10) per cent of total gross floor area of the business establishment. 
(4)  The licensee of the game room shall provide a recreational activity that will not disturb the peace of persons otherwise properly within or without the licensed premises including, but not limited to, the employment of security personnel in controlling the game room facility. Such personnel shall not be less than eighteen (18) years old. 
(5)  The licensee of a game room shall prohibit alcoholic beverages in the game room and also post signs in and around the game room prohibiting alcoholic beverages. 
(6)  The game room shall be open and operated only during the hours that the primary business establishment shall be open to the public. 
(7)  All licensees or attendants hereunder shall have the affirmative duty to report to the police department any and all incidents of a "disturbance of the peace" as defined and regulated in this Code of Ordinances, and which take place within the licensed premises or outside the premises within one hundred (100) feet from the entrance, whether personally observed, or upon observation or notification. Failure to report to the police as herein provided shall be sufficient cause to revoke the license issued hereunder. 
    Class "C" license : 
(1)  There shall be no more than one Class "C" game room license in the aggregate outstanding at any one time. 
(2)  The operation of a Class "C" game room shall be an accessory commercial purpose to the principal occupation or business being conducted by the applicant upon the premises which shall be a restaurant, as defined herein. 
(3)  All coin-operated amusement devices shall be operated in a separate area from the restaurant activities which permits a full view of game room activities and provides a minimum of twenty (20) square feet per device. Seventy (70) percent of the total gross floor area of the restaurant shall be devoted to restaurant facilities, including but not limited to service area, food preparation areas, seating areas, and washrooms. Not more than thirty (30) per cent of the total floor area of the business establishment shall be devoted to coin-operated amusement devices. 
(4)  The total gross floor area ofa business granted a Class "C" license shall be not less than three thousand five hundred (3,500) square feet. 
(5)  The licensee of the game room shall provide a recreational activity that will not disturb the peace of persons otherwise properly within or without the licensed premises including, but not limited to, the employment of management personnel in controlling the game room facility. Such personnel shall not be less than eighteen (18) years old. 
(6)  The licensee of a Class "C" game room shall prohibit alcoholic beverages in the game room and also post signs in and around the game room prohibiting alcoholic beverages within the game room. 
(7)  The game room shall be open and operated only during the hours that the restaurant shall be open to the public and while food is being served or offered for service from substantially the full menu of the restaurant. Failure to offer or to provide from substantially the full menu shall be sufficient cause to revoke the license as issued hereunder. 
(8)  All licensees or attendants hereunder shall have the affirmative duty to report to the police department any and all incidents of a "disturbance of the peace" as defined and regulated in this Code of Ordinances, and which take place within the licensed premises or outside the premises within one hundred (100) feet from the entrance, whether personally observed or upon notification. Failure to report to the police as herein provided shall be sufficient cause to revoke the license as issued hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 1035-81,  1, 8-24-81; Ord. No. 1074-82,  1, 4-12-82; Ord. No. 2004-90, 1, 10-22-90) 
  Note- See the editor's note following  9-407. 
Sec. 9-412. - Violations; penalty. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person licensed to engage in the business of keeping or providing coin-operated amusement devices for commercial purposes within the village to fail to comply with the conditions and regulations set forth in this Division 2. 
    Any person violating or refusing to comply with any of the provisions of this Division 2 shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 1035-81,  1, 8-24-81; Ord. No. 1074-82,  1, 4-12-82) 
  Note- See the editor's note following  9-407. 
DIVISION 3. - DRY CLEANERS[22] 

Footnotes: 
--- (22) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention generally,  7-22 et seq. 

Sec. 9-413. - Definitions. 
    As used in this division: 
    Dry cleaning means the process of cleaning fabric by immersion and agitation, or by immersion only, in volatile solvents including, but not by way of limitation, solvents of petroleum distillate type, the coal tar distillate type and the chlorinated hydrocarbon type (and processes incidental thereto) including, but without limitation to, spotting, cleaning, wet cleaning, and finishing. 
    Dry cleaning establishment means any structure, store, building or other place where the service of dry cleaning, wet cleaning as a process incidental to dry cleaning, dyeing, spotting, and/or finishing any fabric is rendered for hire, or is sold, resold or offered for sale or resale. 
    Fabric means any article of wearing apparel, household furnishing, rugs, texiles, fur and leather. 
    Finishing means the process of pressing or reshaping any fabric, which is designed to restore as nearly as possible the shape, dimensions and contour of said fabric. 
    Spotting means the process designed to remove spots or stains which remain in a fabric after it has been subjected to the other processes of dry cleaning. 
(Code 1956,  326) 
Sec. 9-414. - License required. 
    No person shall conduct, operate or maintain any dry cleaning establishment in the village without first securing a license as is herein required. 
(Code 1956,  327) 
Sec. 9-415. - Application for license. 
    Applications for licenses required by this division shall be made in writing to the village clerk and shall be referred to the fire chief. 
(Code 1956,  327) 
Sec. 9-416. - Investigation of premises. 
    The fire chief shall investigate or cause to be investigated the premises intended to be used, and shall report the result of the investigation to the president and board of trustees of the village before the issuance of a license. 
(Code 1956,  327) 
Sec. 9-417. - Compliance with ordinances. 
    No license required by this division shall be issued to any person not complying with all the provisions of this division, with the provisions of the building code, the zoning ordinance, and all ordinances relating to flammable liquids. 
(Ord. 1956,  327) 
Sec. 9-418. - Fee. 
    The annual license fee for dry cleaners shall be as prescribed in section 9-16, and no license shall be issued without payment of this fee. 
(Code 1956,  328) 
Sec. 9-419. - Requirements for premises; sanitation. 
    No dry cleaning establishment shall be operated in a frame building. Such establishment shall be kept free from inflammable wastes so far as possible, and it shall be unlawful to maintain or permit a stove or open flame of any kind in the premises. Smoking in such premises is hereby prohibited, and appropriate signs to that effect shall be posted in conspicuous places in the establishment. The premises must be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and must be kept free from rats, mice and vermin. No person afflicted ath a contagious or venereal disease shall be employed in any dry cleaning establishment. 
Sec. 9-420. - Periodic inspections; report of violations. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police or other official designated by the president and board of trustees to inspect or cause to be inspected every establishment licensed under this division, at least once every six (6) months. Any violations, of this division or any other ordinance relating to dry cleaners, premises or flammable liquids, shall be reported to the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1956,  330) 
Sec. 9-421. - Inspection for fire hazards. 
    The chief of the fire department shall have the right to enter any building or premises situated in the village and occupied by any dry cleaning establishment, in order to examine the same and to determine whether or not said building and premises, or any material, chemical or compound kept therein, or used thereon, or any article or fabric dry cleaned, dyed, spotted or finished, as received, used, kept, maintained or stored on said premises or building conforms to the fire ordinances and regulations of the village or constitutes a fire hazard in the village. 
(Code 1956,  331) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention generally,  7-22 et seq. 
Secs. 9-422-9-429. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - ELECTRICAL CONTRACTORS[23] 

Footnotes: 
--- (23) --- 
State Law reference- Registration of electrical contractors, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  11-33-1. 

Sec. 9-430. - Defined. 
    The term "electrical contractor" as used in this division shall mean and he construed to include any person engaged in the business of installing or altering by contract, equipment and electrical appliances for the utilization of electricity supplied by light, heat or power not including radio apparatus or equipment for wireless reception of sounds and signals, and not including apparatus, conductors and other equipment installed for or by public utilities, including common carriers, which are under the jurisdiction of the Illinois Commerce Commission for use in their operation as public utilities; but the term "electrical contractor" does not include employees employed by such contractor to do or supervise such work. 
(Code 1956,  335) 
Sec. 9-431. - Registration required; application. 
    No person shall engage in the business of electrical contractor without having first secured a certificate of registration therefor as herein required. Applications for such certificates shall be made to the village clerk and a list of all contractors registered shall be given by the clerk to the building inspector. 
(Code 1956,  333) 
Sec. 9-432. - Registration fee; register year. 
    The annual fee for registering as an electrical contractor shall be as prescribed in section 9-16; provided that on application made after the expiration of the first six (6) months of the register year, a certificate shall be issued upon the payment of one-half (1/2) this fee. The register year shall correspond to the license year. 
(Code 1956,  334) 
Sec. 9-433. - Compliance with regulations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person registered under the provisions of this division to install any electrical appliances, wiring or fixtures without strict compliance with the ordinances relating to such fixtures, and it shall be unlawful for any such person to do any work without having obtained such permits as may be required. 
(Code 1956,  336) 
Secs. 9-435-9-440. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE COMPANIES[24] 

Footnotes: 
--- (24) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2499,  1, adopted Jan. 22, 1996, repealed former div. 5, ㎣ 9-441-9-444, which pertained to similar subject matter, and added a new div. 5, ㎣ 9-441-9-444 to read as herein set out. 
State Law reference- Foreign fire insurance companies, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  11-10-1 et seq. 

Sec. 9-441. - Tax imposed. 
    There is hereby imposed upon every corporation, company and association which is not incorporated under the laws of the state and which is engaged in effecting fire insurance in the village, a tax in the sum of two (2) percent of the gross receipts received from the fire insurance upon property situated within the village for the maintenance, use and benefit of the fire department. 
(Ord. No. 2499-96,  1, 1-22-96) 
Sec. 9-442. - Payment to treasurer. 
    Any such corporation, company or association shall pay to the village treasurer for the maintenance, use and benefit of the fire department a sum of money equal to two (2) percent of the gross receipts each year received for premiums by any and all agents of any such corporation, company or association or received as premiums in any way for fire insurance policies on any property in the city. Such payments shall be made for the year ending the first of July of each year. 
(Ord. No. 2499-96,  1, 1-22-96) 
Sec. 9-443. - Annual account of premiums. 
    Every person acting as representative of agent for or on behalf of any such corporation, company or association shall, on or before the fifteenth day of July of each year, render to the village clerk a full and true account, verified by his/her oath, of all premiums which have been received by him on behalf of the corporation, company or association during the year ending the preceding July 1 on fire insurance policies. The report shall specify the amounts received for fire insurance and payment of the amount due shall be made at the time of rendering the report. 
(Ord. No. 2499-96,  1, 1-22-96) 
Sec. 9-444. - Foreign fire insurance board. 
(a)  Established. There is hereby established a foreign fire insurance board. 
(b)  Definitions. For purposes of establishing a foreign fire insurance board, the following definitions shall apply: 
    Board means the Roselle Foreign Fire Insurance Board. 
    Department means the Roselle Fire Department. 
    Members of the department means all sworn full-time firefighters, full-time officers, including the fire chief. 
    Nomination and election committee means the Roselle Fire Department Election Committee. 
(c)  Election of members. 
(1)  The village foreign fire insurance board is hereby created to consist of four (4) members. Four (4) officers shall comprise the board and shall be elected from all members of the village fire department and shall have full voting privileges on any matter before such board: 
a.  President. 
b.  Vice president. 
c.  Fire insurance board treasurer. 
d.  Secretary. 
The offices of the board shall be filled by election by the members of the village fire department. In addition to the officers as provided above, the fire chief of the village fire department or his designee shall be an ex-officio member, unless otherwise elected to the board at an election held in accordance with the provisions of this division. As an ex-officio member, the fire chief shall not have any voting privileges, but shall have the right to participate in all open or closed session discussions regarding the management of the foreign fire insurance tax funds, preparation of annual budgets, or any other matter within the scope of the powers and duties of the board and notice of any regular or special meeting in the same manner given to any voting member. 
(2)  Elected members of the board shall serve two-year terms and until their successors are elected and installed. However, terms of the members of the first board elected shall consist of two (2) terms of one (1) year, and two (2) terms of two (2) years. The initial terms of office of the elected members of the board shall begin on January 1, 1996 and expire on December 31, 1996 and December 31, 1997. 
(3)  Vacancies shall be filled by election by the members of the department for the balance of the unexpired term, if more than three (3) months remain in the term. 
(4)  No probationary member of the fire department may hold an office during the period of probation. 
(d)  Election procedure. 
(1)  There is hereby established a Roselle Fire Department Nomination and Election Committee. The election committee shall consist of three (3) members of the department, the chief of the fire department and two (2) other members of the department. 
(2)  The nomination and election committee shall be responsible for organizing, conducting and supervising the initial election of department members to serve on the board. The election committee shall establish election procedures consistent with this section. Thereafter, the elected board shall establish its own election procedures consistent with this section. 
(3)  The nomination and election committee shall adopt a procedure for the nomination of members to serve on the board. The nominating procedure shall be established a minimum of sixty (60) days prior to the expiration of the board members' terms of office. 
(4)  The nomination and election committee shall adopt a procedure for the final election of department members on the board. The final election procedure shall be established a minimum of thirty (30) days prior to the expiration of the board members' terms of office. 
(5)  The nomination and election committee may adopt rules and regulations governing the election of officers of the board. All rules and regulations with respect to the election process shall be posted throughout the department not less than thirty (30) days prior to the election. 
(e)  Payment of funds received to department treasurer. 
(1)  A Village of Roselle Fire Department Foreign Fire Insurance Tax fund is hereby created and all revenue received by the village from foreign fire insurance tax shall be deposited into the fund and shall be held and expended according to the procedures of this division. 
(2)  The board treasurer shall provide to the village treasurer a quarterly accounting of receipts and expenditures from the fund. 
(3)  The board treasurer shall be responsible for payment the service charge levied by the Illinois Municipal League for the collection of the foreign fire insurance tax, provided such fee is chargeable by state law, and provided that the service charge has not already been retained by the Illinois Municipal League prior to the disbursement of the tax. 
(4)  The board shall have the power to approve the expenditures for the maintenance, use and benefit of the department. No expenditure shall be made for any purpose which is inconsistent with department operations, procedures, standards and policies. 
(5)  Treasurer of the board shall give a bond to the village to ensure faithful performance of which shall be subject to approval by the mayor and the board of trustees. Fees for set bond shall be paid from the funds collected from the foreign fire insurance tax. 
(6)  The board shall pay for the foreign fire insurance board portion of the village's annual audit. 
(f)  Officer; quorum; special meetings. 
(1)  The board shall, in accordance with the Open Meetings Act, establish a regular time and place for its meetings. The chairman shall preside at the meetings. The secretary shall keep a record of all resolutions, proceedings, minutes and actions of the board and these records shall be open to the public. 
(2)  Three (3) members of the board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of its business. The affirmative vote of three (3) members of the board shall constitute approval of business before it. 
(3)  Special meetings may be called by the chairman, or by no less than three (3) members of the board in the manner required by law. 
(g)  Powers and duties. 
(1)  The board shall have the power to approve the expenditure of monies from the fund for maintenance, use and benefit of the department. The board shall develop and maintain a list of those items that are valid expenses under the foreign fire insurance tax. 
(2)  The board may adopt rules and regulations for governing the board and the execution of the duties of the board, and provide for election of the board and management of the fund which are not inconsistent with the terms of this division. 
(3)  The board may amend or repeal rules and regulations adopted by it. 
(4)  The board shall, in accordance with budget and appropriations procedures, annually prepare a budget for the use of foreign fire insurance tax funds, which shall be considered by the village board, together with the fire department budget. However, expenditures shall be made solely from the receipts from the foreign fire insurance tax. 
(5)  Any expenditure made from the fund shall be made in accordance with village rules, regulations, practices and ordinances, as may be amended from time to time, which govern the procurement of goods and services. 
(Ord. No. 2499-96,  1, 1-22-96) 
Secs. 9-445-9-450. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - HOUSE MOVING, RAISING OR SHORING[25] 

Footnotes:
