Each day that a violation exists with respect to display and offer for sale of drug paraphernalia and each separate occurrence of sale of drug paraphernalia shall constitute separate offenses for each offense; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 2013-3698,  1, 9-23-13) 
Secs. 13-94-13-101. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - RECREATIONAL VEHICLES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 10 

Sec. 13-102. - "Camping and recreational vehicle" defined. 
    For the purpose of this article, a "camping and recreational vehicle" shall mean and include any boat, boat mounted on a trailer, any camp trailer, travel trailer, or other unit built or mounted on a vehicle or chassis, without permanent foundation, which may legally be driven or towed by a motor vehicle on a highway. 
(Ord. No. 1799-89,  1, 2-27-89) 
Sec. 13-103. - Definitions generally. 
(a)  Camper or travel trailer is a vehicle, portable in structure, built on a chassis, designed to be used as a temporary dwelling for travel, recreational and vacation uses, and which is drawn by a motor vehicle. 
(b)  Pick-up coach is a structure designed primarily to be mounted on a pick-up truck chassis and with sufficient equipment to render it suitable for use as a temporary dwelling for travel, recreational and vacation uses. 
(c)  Motorized home or camper is a portable dwelling designed as an integral part of a self-propelled vehicle. 
(d)  Trailer is a closed or open vehicle designed to be pulled or propelled by a truck or car to be used primarily for the hauling of materials, tents, boats or other similar uses, has no living quarters, and is licensed as a trailer. 
(e)  Boat trailer shall include every vehicle designed or utilized for the transportation of any boat having the gross weight of less than five thousand (5,000) pounds, without motive power, designed for being drawn by another vehicle. 
(f)  Boat means any device used or capable of being used for navigation on water. 
(g)  Trailer camp is a plot of ground where any house-car trailer, with or without wheels, used as living and sleeping quarters may be located, regardless of whether or not a charge is made for such accommodations. 
(h)  Building line means the front of a building structure. 
(i)  Driveway means an established and surfaced portion of the lot, the use of which is for the purpose of ingress and egress to a carport, garage, parking area or loading and unloading station for vehicles. 
(j)  Lot line means the property line bounding a lot. 
(k)  Side yard means a yard extending around the side lot line between the front and rear yards. 
(l)  Rear yard means an open space on the same lot with a building between the rear line of the building and the rear line of the lot, for the full width of the lot. 
(m)  Derelicts means any vehicular equipment no longer capable of the function intended. 
(n)  Owner means a person other than a lienholder having the ownership of property or title to recreational equipment as defined above. 
(Ord. No. 1799-89,  1, 2-27-89) 
Sec. 13-104. - Trailer camps prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to remove the wheels or other transportation device from any house-car trailer or travel trailer, or to otherwise fix the house-car or travel trailer, except for normal maintenance and seasonal storage, or to otherwise fix the house-car trailer or travel trailer, to the ground as to prevent ready removal of the trailer. 
(Ord. No. 1799-89,  1, 2-27-89) 
Sec. 13-105. - Habitation. 
    No camper or travel trailer, pick-up coach or motorized home or boat shall be used for living or sleeping or housekeeping therein with the limits of the Village of Roselle. 
(Ord. No. 1799-89,  1, 2-27-89) 
Sec. 13-106. - Parking and storage generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to keep, maintain or store any camping vehicle or house trailer on any real property within the Village of Roselle, except as hereinafter provided: 
(1)  If a camper or travel trailer, pick-up coach, motorized home, or other trailer, or boat shall not exceed the overall width of eight (8) feet and shall not exceed the overall length of twenty-nine (29) feet, including hitch, and shall not exceed an overall height of ten (10) feet, excluding mast, it may be parked or stored within the driveway section for a period not to exceed forty-eight (48) hours within one calendar week for the purpose of loading and unloading said vehicle. 
(2)  If a camper or travel trailer, pick-up coach, motorized home or other trailer or boat shall not exceed the overall width of eight (8) feet, shall not exceed overall length of twenty-nine (29) feet, including hitch, and shall not exceed an overall height of ten (10) feet, excluding mast, it may be parked or stored on single-family dwelling property to the rear of the building setback or inside a garage. 
(3)  At no time shall parked or stored vehicles be occupied or used for living, sleeping or housekeeping purposes. 
(4)  The owner of a camper or travel trailer, pick-up coach, motorized home or other trailer or boat shall not park or store such camper or travel trailer, pick-up coach, motorized home or other trailer or boat in such a manner as to create a dangerous or unsafe condition on the property where parked or stored. Parking or storage in such a fashion that the camper or travel trailer, pick-up coach, motorized home or other trailer or boat, whether loaded or not, may readily tip or roll or shall obstruct any exit-way from all structures by a minimum of three (3) feet, or a street or the free and easy access of any emergency, fire or police personnel to any portion of a residence shall be considered a dangerous and unsafe condition. 
(5)  A vehicle parked or stored on a licensed business premise for the purpose of repair, rental or sale shall not be considered in violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 1799-89,  1, 2-27-89) 
Sec. 13-107. - Service connections. 
    No camper or travel trailer, pick-up coach, motorized home or other trailer or boat shall have a connected gas, electric, water or sewer service, except for temporary hook-up for cleaning and maintenance. 
(Ord. No. 1799-89,  1, 2-27-89) 
Sec. 13-108. - Derelicts. 
    No vehicular equipment shall be stored out of doors on residential premises unless it is in condition for safe and effective performance of the function for which it is intended. 
(Ord. No. 1799-89,  1, 2-27-89) 
Sec. 13-109. - Parking permit. 
    An owner of a camper, travel trailer, pick-up coach, motorized home or other trailer or boat who does not reside within the Village of Roselle may obtain a permit to park said vehicle on a specified single-family dwelling premise, for a period of not to exceed thirty (30) days in any calendar year, by paying the sum of one dollar ($1.00) for such permit, to be obtained from the police department. Permits shall designate the owner's address, where the vehicle is to be stored, permanent occupant of said premises, dates on which the parking shall begin and end, and name and address of person obtaining the permit. 
(Ord. No. 1799-89,  1, 2-27-89) 
Sec. 13-110. - Registration. 
(a)  An owner of a camper, travel trailer, motorized home or other trailer who resides within the village and maintains, keeps or stores said vehicle in the village shall apply for and obtain from the village clerk, for an annual fee of three dollars ($3.00) for two-wheel vehicles and five dollars ($5.00) for three-wheel vehicles and up, a registration of said vehicle, with the exception of vehicle-stickered vehicles. 
(b)  The applicant for registration under the provisions of this article, upon payment of the fee, shall be given a plate or sticker which shall be affixed to the vehicle in a conspicuous location. 
(Ord. No. 1799-89,  1, 2-27-89) 
Sec. 13-111. - Penalties. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be subject to a fine of not less than ten dollars ($10.00), nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day a violation is permitted to exist shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 1799-89,  1, 2-27-89) 
Secs. 13-112-13-121. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - BURGLAR AND FIRE ALARMS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 2004-3133,  1, adopted November 8, 2004, repealed the former Art. VIII., ㎣ 13-122-13-138, and enacted a new Art. VIII as set out herein. The former Art. VIII pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 1799-89,  1, 2-27-89; Ord. No. 1911-90,  1, 2-12-90; Ord. No. 1951-90, ㎣ 1-3, 5-14-90; Ord. No 2002-2924,  1, 5-13-02. 
Cross reference- Fire protection and prevention, Ch. 7; police, Ch. 16. 

Sec. 13-122. - Definitions generally. 
(a)  Alarm equipment suppliers. Any person, firm, partnership, or corporation that sells, leases, or installs automatic protection devices or alarm systems that transmit alarms upon receipt of a stimulus from a detection apparatus. 
(b)  Automatic protection device. An electrically operated instrument, which automatically sends a voice alarm over regular public telephone lines upon detection of a fire, unauthorized intrusion or medical emergency. 
(c)  Alarm system. Any assembly of equipment, mechanical or electrical, arranged to signal the occurrence of any actual or attempted burglary, robbery, fire or medical alarm to which the police or fire departments are expected to respond. 
(d)  Signal line. A line not connected to any standard telephone equipment which leads into an indicator panel in the communications center of the police department or to such a panel in either a central station protective system or a modified central station and which is designed to transmit electrically an alarm signal readily identifiable as to the location or origin. 
(e)  Special trunkline. A telephone line leading into the communications center of the police department that is for the primary purpose of handling emergency messages which originate from automatic protection devices and are transmitted directly or through an intermediary. 
(f)  False alarms. A visual and/or audible signal transmitted by an automatic protection device or alarm system that indicates the existence of any emergency situation when in fact, no such emergency situation exists. 
(g)  Restricted numbers. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to install, maintain, or operate an automatic protection device except to such telephone numbers as designated by the permit issued under the provisions of this article. 
(h)  Annual permit. Each permit holder shall pay to the Village on or before July 1 of each year a fee in the amount of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) to reimburse the village for the cost of providing special telephone lines or other equipment to receive calls from automatic protection devices, maintenance of equipment, record keeping and other expenses of operations. Other governmental organizations and not-for-profit organizations shall not be required to pay this fee. 
(i)  Key (to a telephone line). To use a telephone line for transmitting a message, either by direct connection or by a mechanism not so connected that utilizes the microphone of a standard telephone to do so. 
(j)  Village. The Village of Roselle, Illinois. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3133,  1, 11-8-04) 
Sec. 13-123. - Automatic protection devices-Regulated. 
(a)  No automatic protection device that is installed after the effective date hereof by any person on premises of any kind in the village shall be keyed to a special trunkline. 
(b)  After the effective date hereof, any alarm equipment supplier who installs automatic protection devices in the village for the purpose of sending pre-recorded emergency messages directly to the police department shall first obtain necessary instructions, including a designated telephone number, from the chief of police with the type of messages, in order to key such devices to a special trunkline into the department. 
(c)  Within ninety (90) days after the effective date hereof, all automatic protection devices in the village that were keyed on that date to a special trunkline shall be disconnected there from. The owner or lessee of any such device shall be responsible for the disconnecting of it. 
(d)  An owner or lessee of an automatic protection device who has it disconnected as required by paragraph (c) of this section; may authorize an alarm equipment supplier to key the automatic protection device to a special trunkline into the police department, provided that the device meets operational requirements, as set forth in this article, and written approval has been obtained from the chief of police. 
(e)  After the effective date hereof, no one except an alarm equipment supplier who has received written approval from the chief of police as required by this article, shall install any automatic protection device in the village and/or key the same to a special trunkline. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3133,  1, 11-8-04) 
Sec. 13-124. - Current list of installations required. 
(a)  Within thirty (30) days after the effective date hereof, every alarm equipment supplier who has keyed any automatic protection devices in the village to a special trunkline shall furnish the chief of police with a current list of such installations, showing the following: 
(1)  Name, residence address and telephone number of owner or lessee; 
(2)  Address of place where device is installed and telephone number at that location; and 
(3)  Name and telephone number of any other person at a different location who is authorized to respond to an emergency and open the place where the device is installed. 
(b)  Within ten (10) days after the end of each calendar quarter, every alarm equipment supplier shall furnish the chief of police with a supplemental list of any such additional installations that he has keyed to a special trunkline, along with any corrections or deletions. 
(c)  The information required in paragraphs (a) and (b) above shall be restricted to use only by the chief of police and the departments concerned. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3133,  1, 11-8-04) 
Sec. 13-126. - Operational requirements. 
    Automatic protection devices installed on premises of any kind in the village that are keyed to a special trunkline shall meet minimum operational requirements, as determined by the chief of police, as follows: 
(1)  The content of the type of recorded message to be transmitted by such device must be intelligible and in a format approved by the chief of police as appropriate for the nature of the alarm. 
(2)  No recorded message shall be delivered to the police department more than three (3) times as the result of a single stimulus of the sensory mechanism. 
(3)  The length of time for transmitting the recorded message must not exceed fifteen (15) seconds. 
(4)  The time gap between delivery of each recorded message must be between ten (10) to twelve (12) seconds. 
(5)  Such device must be capable of transmitting an alarm message to two (2) or more recipients, so that upon installation, any message will be sent not only on a special trunkline, but also on the line of an authorized person having a key to the premises who is available to respond to an emergency. 
(6)  The sensory mechanism used in connection with such devices must be adjusted to suppress false indications of an emergency, so that the devices will not be actuated by including but not limited to impulses due to transient pressure changes in water pipes, short flashes of light, wind noises such as the rattling or vibrating of doors or windows, vehicular noise adjacent to the installation or other forces unrelated to an emergency. 
(7)  All components comprising such a device must be maintained by the owner or lessee in good repair to assure reliability of operation. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3133,  1, 11-8-04) 
Sec. 13-127. - Instructions on operation. 
(a)  Each alarm equipment supplier that sells or leases an automatic protection device which is installed on premises in the village after the effective date hereof, and which is keyed to a special trunkline, shall furnish owner or lessee instructions as to the way the device operates, along with a maintenance manual and a correct circuit diagram pertaining to such device. 
(b)  Each alarm equipment supplier, as referred to in paragraph (a) above, shall also furnish the chief of police with a copy of the instructions as to the way the device operates, along with a maintenance manual and a correct circuit diagram. If the chief of police finds such to be incomplete, unclear, or otherwise inadequate, he may require the alarm equipment supplier to have the same revised to meet the chief of police's approval and then promptly distributed to persons for whom installations of such devices have already been made as well as to persons for whom installations are henceforth made. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3133,  1, 11-8-04) 
Sec. 13-128. - Repair service for. 
(a)  Each alarm equipment supplier that sells or leases an automatic protection device which is installed on such person's premises in the village after the effective date hereof, and which is keyed to a special trunkline must offer service, directly or through an agent, on a twenty-four-hour basis, seven (7) days a week, to repair such device, so as to correct any malfunction of the same that may occur. 
(b)  At the time of installation, each alarm equipment supplier shall furnish to the owner or lessee written information as to how service can be obtained at any time, including the telephone number to call for service; and such person shall be responsible for having the device repaired as quickly as possible after he learns, either from his own sources or from notification by the chief of police or any member of the fire department or police department, that the device is not working properly. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3133,  1, 11-8-04) 
Sec. 13-129. - Operational defects to be remedied. 
    When messages evidencing failure to comply with the operational requirements set forth in section 13-128 are received by the police department, and the chief of police concluded that the automatic protection device sending such messages should be disconnected in order to relieve the police department of the burden of responding to false alarms, he is authorized to demand that the owner or lessee of such device, or his representative at the place where it is installed, disconnect such device until it is made to comply with said operations requirements. If disconnection of the defective automatic protection device is not accomplished promptly by such demand and the chief of police determines that the malfunctioning device is repeatedly sending false alarms in succession without an intermittent valid alarm, he may then take whatever steps are necessary to disconnect the defective automatic protection device. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3133,  1, 11-8-04) 
Sec. 13-130. - Authority to inspect installations designated. 
    For the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this article, the chief of the fire department and the chief of the police department shall each have the authority, at reasonable times and upon oral notice, to enter upon any premises within the Village to inspect the installation and operation of an automatic protection device or alarm system, the purpose of which is to report an emergency to the police department, either directly or through an intermediary. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3133,  1, 11-8-04) 
Sec. 13-131. - Testing of equipment. 
    No person shall conduct any test or demonstration of an automatic protection device or alarm system designed to make direct connection with headquarters of the police department, without first obtaining permission from the chief of police. Where the equipment to be tested or demonstrated is keyed to an intermediary, such permission is not required unless the alarm or signal is to be relayed to the police department. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3133,  1, 11-8-04) 
Sec. 13-132. - Alarm systems for protection of financial institutions. 
    Any financial institution that is required by regulations of federal supervisory agencies issued pursuant to the Bank Protection Act of 1968 to have an appropriate device for notifying the police department that a burglary or robbery has occurred or is in progress, may arrange to have the particular alarm system installed so as to operate pursuant to approval by the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3133,  1, 11-8-04) 
Sec. 13-133. - Alarm user permit; application; approval. 
(a)  Permit required. No person shall operate or maintain any automatic protection device or alarm system which transmits a signal, message, or warning to a village police department or fire department telephone line without first obtaining a permit as required by this article. 
(b)  Application for permit. 
(1)  Applications for permits to install, maintain, and operate an automatic protection device or alarm system shall be filed with the chief of police on forms supplied by the village with an application fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). Said application shall set forth the name, address, and telephone number of both the installer and the person or business on whose premises the system will be installed, emergency contact telephone numbers, as well as a description of the system and location where it is proposed to be installed. Governmental organizations and not-for-profit organizations shall not be required to pay this fee. 
(2)  The chief of police shall approve such application if he finds that: 
a.  The use of said automatic protection device or alarm system to transmit a signal, message or warning to a designated village police department telephone line will not interfere with the orderly conduct of municipal business; and 
b.  The alarm equipment supplier installing the system maintains a service organization capable of promptly and effectively repairing, maintaining, and otherwise servicing the automatic protection devices or alarm systems sold or leased by him. 
Notwithstanding the foregoing, the police chief may impose reasonable conditions on the issuance and exercise of said permit. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3133,  1, 11-8-04) 
Sec. 13-134. - Contract for alarm systems authorized; charges. 
(a)  Monitoring system. The village police department is authorized to contract for the installation of a uniform monitoring system to receive visual and/or audible signals over a signal line or other method of transmission or lines at a central location. This system shall have a capacity for nine hundred ninety-nine (999) terminals and shall be available to any subscriber who meets the requirements for a permit for connection. 
(b)  Subscription charges. Nothing herein shall preclude the alarm equipment supplier from charging a permit holder for all equipment at their location and connection fees to the monitoring system and maintenance charges necessitated by the installation, operation, and maintenance of the signaling device in the monitoring system. The company supplying and maintaining the monitoring system shall have the right to charge subscribers or their alarm equipment supplier a reasonable fee for connection to and maintenance of the system. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3133,  1, 11-8-04) 
Sec. 13-135. - Permit required for local audible alarms. 
    No local alarm which is audible beyond the premises being served shall be installed or maintained within the village without a permit. The chief of police or his authorized representative may issue a permit for such an alarm provided the intensity of sound does not exceed sixty-five (65) decibels at any location outside the premises being served. No such alarm may be installed or maintained unless controlled by an automatic timing device to silence the alarm after a period not to exceed fifteen (15) minutes. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3133,  1, 11-8-04) 
Sec. 13-136. - False alarms; records; charges. 
(a)  Commercial charges. A permit holder or alarm owner for a commercial location shall be charged an additional fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each false alarm in excess of three (3) false alarms but not more than six (6) false alarms in any calendar year transmitted by any automatic protection device or signaling device, to the police department; an additional fee to two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each false alarm in excess of six (6) false alarms but not more than ten (10) false alarms in any calendar year transmitted by any automatic protection device or signaling device, transmitted to the police department; an additional fee of three hundred dollars ($300.00) for each false alarm in excess of ten (10) false alarms any calendar year transmitted by any automatic protection device or signaling device, to the police department. Such charge shall be remitted to the village by such permit holder or alarm owner upon receipt of a statement of such charge. 
(b)  Residential charges. A permit holder or alarm owner for a residential location shall be charged an additional fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each false alarm in excess of three (3) false alarms but not more than six (6) false alarms in any calendar year transmitted by any automatic protection device or signaling device, to the police department; an additional fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each false alarm in excess of six (6) false alarms but not more than ten (10) false alarms in any calendar year transmitted by any automatic protection device or signaling device, transmitted to the police department; an additional fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for each false alarm in excess of ten (10) false alarms any calendar year transmitted by any automatic protection device or signaling device, to the police department. Such charge shall be remitted to the village by such permit holder or alarm owner upon receipt of a statement of such charge. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3133,  1, 11-8-04) 
Sec. 13-137. - Alarm user permit revocation; reactivation. 
(a)  Permit revocation. The chief of police may revoke or suspend any permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, after giving written notice to the permit holder; or order that an alarm signal be disregarded and the alarm system disconnected for the following reasons: 
(1)  The automatic protection device or alarm system under said permit has been installed, maintained, or operated in violation of the provisions of this chapter or of any term or condition of said permit; or 
(2)  There is a false statement of a material matter in the application for the permit; or 
(3)  The permit holder has failed to make timely payment of any charge, fee or fine required under this chapter; or 
(4)  There have been more than ten (10) false alarms transmitted to the police department within a calendar year. 
(b)  Reactivation. An alarm which has been ordered disregarded or disconnected by the chief of police, shall be reactivated after the alarm permit holder or alarm owner provides documentation of an inspection and repair/adjustment of the alarm system, completed by a licensed alarm company and payment of a three hundred dollar ($300.00) reactivation fee for a commercial alarm location and one hundred fifty dollar ($150.00) reactivation fee for a residential alarm location and any outstanding false alarm fees or permit fees as required by this article, to the village. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3133,  1, 11-8-04) 
Sec. 13-138. - Liability of village limited. 
    The village assumes no liability for any defects in operation of automatic protection devices and alarm systems for any failure or neglect to respond appropriately upon receipt of an alarm from such a source, nor for the failure or neglect of any person in connection with the installation and operation of equipment, the transmission of alarm signals, and pre-recorded alarm messages or the relaying of such signals and messages. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3133,  1, 11-8-04) 
Sec. 13-139. - Failure to pay application fee, permit fee or false alarm fee. 
    Any person, firm, partnership or corporation who fails to pay any application fee or permit fee after notice or false alarm fee as set forth in this section, shall be guilty of a violation of this article and subject to the penalties as set forth is section 13-140. For purposes of this article, notice shall be deemed complete upon in person notification, posting written notice at the location of the alarm system or by depositing a written notice in the United States Mail addressed to alarm system owner or user notifying the owner or alarm system user that any failure to pay an application fee, permit fee or false alarm fee constitutes a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3133,  1, 11-8-04) 
Sec. 13-140. - Penalties for violation of article. 
    Any person, firm, partnership or corporation violating section 13-139 of the provisions of this article shall be subject to a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day that such violation exists shall constitute as a separate and distinct offense. The penalties set fourth in this section are separate and distinct from fees provided in section 13-122(h), section 13-133(b), section 13-136 and section 13-137(b). 
(Ord. No. 2004-3133,  1, 11-8-04) 
Secs. 13-141-13-144. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - PROHIBITED POLITICAL ACTIVITIES/GIFT BAN[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2004-3113, ㎣ 1, 2, adopted December 23, 2004, repealed the former Art. IX., ㎣ 13-145-13-149, and enacted a new Art. IX as set out herein. The former Art. IX pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 2685-99,  1, 5-24-99. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 13-145. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Campaign for elective office mean any activity in furtherance of an effort to influence the selection, nomination, election or appointment of any individual to any federal, state or local public office or offices in a political organization, or the selection, nomination, or election of presidential or vice-presidential electros, but does not include activities (i) relating to the support or opposition of any executive, legislative, or administrative action, (ii) relating to collective bargaining, or (iii) that are otherwise in furtherance of the person's official duties. 
    Candidate means a person who has filed nominating papers or petitions for nomination or election to an elected office, or who has been appointed to fill a vacancy in nomination, and who remains eligible for placement on the ballot at a regular election, as defined in Section 1-3 of the Election Code (10 ILCS 5/1-3). 
    Collective bargaining has the same meaning as the term is defined in Section 3 of the Illinois Public Labor Relations Act (5 ILCS 315/3). 
    Compensated time means, with respect to an employee, any time worked by or credited to the employee that counts toward any minimum time requirement imposed as a condition of his or her employment, but for purposes of this article, does not include any designated holidays, vacations periods, personal time, compensatory time off or any period when the employee is on a leave of absence. With respect to officers or employees whose hours are not fixed, "compensation time" includes any period of time when the officer is on premises under the control of the employer and any other time when the officer or employee is executing his or her official duties, regardless of location. 
    Compensatory time off means authorized time off earned by or awarded to an employee to compensate in whole or in part for time worked in excess of the minimum work time required of that employee as a condition of his or her employment. 
    Contribution has the same meaning as the term is defined in Section 9-1.4 of the Election Code (10 ILCS 5/9-1.4). 
    Employee means a person employed by the Village of Roselle, whether on a full-time or part-time basis or pursuant to a contract, whose duties are subject to the direction and control of an employer with regard to the material details of how the work is to be performed, but does not include an independent contractor. 
    Employer means the Village of Roselle. 
    Gift means any gratuity, discount, entertainment, hospitality, loan, forbearance, or other tangible or intangible item having monetary value including, but not limited to, cash, food and drink, and honoraria for speaking engagements related to or attributable to government employment of the official position of an officer or employee. 
    Leave of absence means any period during which an employee does not receive (i) compensation for employment, (ii) service credit towards pension benefits, and (iii) health insurance benefits paid for by the employer. 
    Officer means a person who holds, by election or appointment, an office created by statute or ordinance, regardless of whether the office is compensated for service in his or her official capacity. 
    Political activity means any activity in support of or in connection with any campaign for elective office or any political organization, but does not include activities (i) relating to the support or opposition of any executive, legislative, or administrative action, (ii) relating to collective bargaining, or (iii) that are otherwise in furtherance of the person's official duties. 
    Political organization means a party, committee, association, fund or other organization (whether or not incorporated) that is required to file a statement of organization with the state board of elections or a county clerk under Section 9-3 of the Election Code (10 ILCS 5/9-3), but only with regard to those activities that require filing with the state board of elections of a county clerk. 
    Prohibited political activity means: 
(1)  Preparing for, organizing, or participating in any political meeting, political rally, political demonstration, or other political event. 
(2)  Soliciting contributions, including but not limited to the purchase of, selling, distributing, or receiving payment for tickets for any political fundraiser, political meeting, or other political event. 
(3)  Soliciting, planning the solicitation of, or preparing any document or report regarding anything of value intended as a campaign contribution. 
(4)  Planning, conducting, or participating in a public opinion poll in connection with a campaign for elective office or on behalf of a political organization for political purposes or for or against any referendum question. 
(5)  Surveying or gathering information from potential or actual voters in an election to determine probable vote outcome in connection with a campaign for elective office or on behalf of a political organization for political purposes or for or against any referendum question. 
(6)  Assisting at the polls on Election Day on behalf of any political organization or candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum question. 
(7)  Soliciting votes on behalf of a candidate for elective office or a political organization or for or against any referendum question or helping in an effort to get voters to the polls. 
(8)  Initiating for circulation, preparing, circulating, reviewing, or filing any petition on behalf of a candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum question. 
(9)  Making contributions on behalf of any candidate for elective office in that capacity or in connection with a campaign for elective office. 
(10)  Preparing or reviewing responses to candidate questionnaires. 
(11)  Distributing, preparing for distribution, or mailing campaign literature, campaign signs, or other campaign material on behalf of any candidates for elective office or for or against any referendum question. 
(12)  Campaigning for any elective office or for or against any referendum question. 
(13)  Managing or working on a campaign for elective office or for or against any referendum question. 
(14)  Serving as a delegate, alternate or proxy to a political party convention. 
(15)  Participating in any recount or challenge to the outcome of any election. 
    Prohibited source means any person or entity who: 
(1)  Is seeking official action (i) by an office or (ii) by an employee, or by the officer or another employee directing that employee; 
(2)  Does business or seeks to do business (i) with the officer or (ii) with an employee, or with the officer or another employee directing that employee; 
(3)  Conducts activities regulated (i) by the officer or (ii) by an employee, or by the officer or another employee directing that employee; or 
(4)  Has interest that may be substantially affected by the performance or non-performance of the official duties of the officer or employee. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3113,  1, 12-23-04) 
DIVISION 2. - PROHIBITED POLITICAL ACTIVITIES 

Sec. 13-146. - Prohibited political activities. 
(a)  No officer or employee shall intentionally perform any prohibited political activity during any compensated time, as defined herein. No officer or employee shall intentionally use any property or resources of the Village of Roselle in connection with any prohibited political activity. 
(b)  At no time shall any officer or employee intentionally require any other officer or employee to perform any prohibited political activity (i) as part of that officer or employee's duties, (ii) as a condition of employment, or (iii) during any compensated time off (such as holidays, vacation or personal time off). 
(c)  No officer or employee shall be required at any time to participate in any prohibited political activity in consideration for that officer or employee being awarded additional compensation or any benefit, whether in the form of a salary adjustment, bonus, compensatory time off, continued employment or otherwise, nor shall any officer or employee be awarded additional compensation or any benefit, whether in the form of a salary adjustment, bonus compensatory time off, continued employment or otherwise, nor shall any officer or employee be awarded additional compensation or any benefit in consideration for his or her participation in any prohibited political activity. 
(d)  Nothing in this section prohibits activities that are permissible for an officer or employee to engage in as part of his or her official duties, or activities that are undertaken by an officer or employee on a voluntary basis which are not prohibited by this article. 
(e)  No person either (i) in a position that is subject to recognized merit principles of public employment or (ii) in a position the salary for which is paid in whole or in part by federal funds and that is subject to the federal standards for a merit system or personnel administration applicable to grant-in-aid programs, shall be denied or deprived of employment or tenure solely because he or she is a member or an officer of a political committee, of a political party, or of a political organization or club. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3113,  1, 12-23-04) 
DIVISION 3. - GIFT BAN 

Sec. 13-147. - Gift ban. 
    Except as permitted by this article, no officer or employee, and no spouse of or immediate family member living with any officer or employee (collectively referred to herein as "receipts"), shall intentionally solicit or accept any gift from any prohibited source, as defined herein, or which is otherwise prohibited by law or ordinance. No prohibited source shall intentionally offer or make a gift that violates this section. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3113,  1, 12-23-04) 
Section 13-148. - Gift ban exceptions. 
    Exceptions. Section 13-147 is not applicable to the following: 
(1)  Opportunities, benefits, and services that are available on the same conditions as for the general public. 
(2)  Anything for which the officer or employee, or his or her spouse or immediate family member, pays the fair market value. 
(3)  Any (i) contribution that is lawfully made under the Election Code or (ii) activities associated with a fundraising event in support of a political organization or candidate. 
(4)  Educational materials and missions. 
(5)  Travel expenses for a meeting to discuss business. 
(6)  A gift from a relative, meaning those people related to the individual as father, mother, son, daughter, brother, sister, uncle, aunt, great aunt, great uncle, first cousin, nephew, niece, husband, wife, grandfather, grandmother, grandson, granddaughter, father-in-law, mother-in-law, son-in-law, daughter-in-law, brother-in-law, sister-in-law, stepfather, stepmother, stepson, stepdaughter, stepbrother, stepsister, half brother, half sister, and including the father, mother, grandfather, or grandmother of the individual's spouse and the individual's fiance or fiancee. 
(7)  Anything provided by an individual on the basis of a personal friendship unless the recipient has reason to believe that, under the circumstances, the gift was provided because of the official position or employment of the recipient or his or her spouse or immediate family member and not because of the personal friendship. In determining whether a gift is provided on the basis of personal friendship, the recipient shall consider the circumstances under which the gift was offered, such as: (i) the history of the relationship between the individual giving the gift and the recipient of the gift, including any previous exchange of gifts between those individuals; (ii) whether to the actual knowledge of the recipient the individual who gave the gift personally paid for the gift or sought a tax deduction or business reimbursement for the gift; and (iii) whether to the actual knowledge of the recipient the individual who gave the gift also at the same time gave the same or similar gift to other officers or employees, or their spouses or immediate family members. 
(8)  Food or refreshments not exceeding seventy-five dollars ($75.00) per person in value on a single calendar day; provided that the food or refreshments are (i) consumed on the premises from which they were purchased or prepared or (ii) catered. For the purposes of this section, "catered" means food or refreshments that are purchased ready to consume which are delivered by any means. 
(9)  Food, refreshments, lodging, transportation, and other benefits resulting from outside business or employment activities (or outside activities that are not connected to the official duties of an officer or employee), if the benefits have not been offered or enhanced because of the official position or employment of the officer or employee, and are customarily provided to others in similar circumstances. 
(10)  Intra-governmental and inter-governmental gifts. For the purposes of this Act, "intra-governmental gift" means any gift given to an officer or employee from another officer or employee, and "inter-governmental gift" means any gift given to an officer or employee by an officer or employee of another governmental entity. 
(11)  Bequests, inheritances, and other transfers at death. 
(12)  Any items or items from any one prohibited source during any calendar year having a cumulative total value of less than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
Each of the exceptions listed in this section is mutually exclusive and independent of every other. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3113,  1, 12-23-04) 
Sec. 13-149. - Disposition of gifts. 
    An officer or employee, his or her spouse or an immediate family member living with the officer or employee, does not violate this article if the recipient promptly takes a reasonable action to return a gift from prohibited source to its source or gives the gift or an amount equal to its value to an appropriate charity that is exempt from income taxation under Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as now or hereafter amended, renumbered or succeeded. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3113,  1, 12-23-04) 
DIVISION 4. - ETHICS ADVISOR 

Sec. 13-150. - Village attorney. 
    The village attorney shall act as the ethics advisor for the village. The duties of the ethics advisor may be delegated to another officer or employee of the Village of Roselle in circumstances in which the village attorney informs the mayor that the village attorney can serve as ethics advisor in an objective manner. If neither the village attorney or an officer or an employee of the Village of Roselle can act as an ethics advisor, the Mayor of the Village of Roselle, with the advice and consent of the corporate authorities of the Village of Roselle, may designate another as an ethics advisor. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3113,  1, 12-23-04) 
Sec. 13-151. - Duties. 
    The ethics advisor shall provide guidance to the officers and employees of the Village of Roselle concerning the interpretation of and compliance with the provisions of this article and state ethics laws. The ethics advisor shall perform such other duties as may be delegated by the corporate authorities of the Village of Roselle. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3113,  1, 12-23-04) 
DIVISION 5. - ETHICS COMMISSION 

Sec. 13-152. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a commission to be known as the ethics commission of the Village of Roselle. The commission shall be established by intergovernmental agreement between the Village of Roselle, the Village of Itasca, and the Village of Bloomingdale and shall be comprised of three members appointed by the mayor of each municipality with the advice and consent of their respective corporate authorities. No person shall be appointed as a member of the commission who is related, either by blood or by marriage up to the degree of first cousin, to any elected officer of the Village of Roselle. In absence of an intergovernmental agreement establishing the ethics commission of the Village of Roselle the mayor of the Village of Roselle, with the advise and consent of the corporate authorities of the village shall designate an attorney to investigate, and where there is probable cause, to prosecute violations of division 3 of this article in the Courts of the Eighteenth Judicial Circuit, DuPage County, Illinois or the Circuit Courts of Cook County, Cook County, Illinois as determined by proper venue. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3113,  1, 12-23-04) 
Sec. 13-153. - Terms; appointments. 
    At the first meeting of the commission, the initial appointees shall draw lots to determine their initial terms. Two (2) commissioners shall serve two-year terms, and the third commissioner shall serve a one-year term. Thereafter, all commissioners shall be appointed to two-year terms. Commissioners may be reappointed to serve subsequent terms. 
    At the first meeting of the commission, the commissioners shall choose a chairperson from their number. Meetings shall be held at the call of the chairperson or any two (2) commissioners. A quorum shall consist of two (2) commissioners, and official action by the commission shall require the affirmative vote of two (2) members. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3113,  1, 12-23-04) 
Sec. 13-154. - Removal of commissioner. 
    The (chief executive officer), with the advice and consent of the (corporate authorities), may remove a commissioner in case of incompetency, neglect of duty or malfeasance in office after service on the commissioner by certified mail, return receipt requested, of a copy of the written charges against the commissioners and after providing an opportunity to be heard in person or by counsel upon not less than ten (10) days notice. Vacancies shall be filled in the same manner as original appointments. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3113,  1, 12-23-04) 
Sec. 13-155. - Powers and duties. 
    The commission shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  To promulgate procedures and rules governing the performance of its duties and the exercise of its powers. 
(2)  Upon receipt of a signed, notarized, written complaint, to investigate, conduct hearings and deliberations, issue recommendations for disciplinary actions, impose fines in accordance with section 13-158(8) of this article and refer violations of division 2 or division 3 of this article to the appropriate attorney for prosecution. The commission shall, however, act only upon the receipt of a written complaint alleging a violation of this article and not upon its own prerogative. 
(3)  To receive information from the public pertaining to its investigations and to require additional information and documents from persons who may have violated the provisions of this article. 
(4)  To compel the attendance of witnesses and to compel the production of books and papers pertinent to an investigation. It is the obligation of all officers and employees of the Village of Roselle to cooperate with the commission during the course of its investigations. Failure or refusal to cooperate with requests by the commission shall constitute grounds for discipline or discharge. 
(5)  The powers and duties of the commission are limited to matters clearly within the purview of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3113,  1, 12-23-04) 
Sec. 13-156. - Appointed attorney's powers and duties. 
    Any attorney appointed to investigate and prosecute violations of division 2 or division 3 shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  Interview witnesses, perform all reasonable and necessary investigations, receive information from the public pertaining to the investigation, require the production of additional information and documents from persons who may have violated the provisions of this article, file complaints with the courts, negotiate settlement agreements, and prosecute complaints to verdict. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3113,  1, 12-23-04) 
Sec. 13-157. - Mayor conflict of interest. 
    Whenever the Mayor of the Village of Roselle is accused of the violation of division 2 or division 3 of this article the Board of Trustees of the Village of Roselle shall appoint a mayor pro-term who shall have all of the powers and duties set forth in this article for purposes of the allegations against the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3113,  1, 12-23-04) 
Sec. 13-158. - Complaints. 
(a)  Where an ethics commission exists pursuant to intergovernmental agreement under section 13-152 complaints alleging a violation of this article shall be filed with the ethics commission. 
(b)  Within three (3) business days after the receipt of a complaint, the commission shall send by certified mail, return receipt requested, a notice to the respondent that a complaint has been filed against him or her and a copy of the complaint. The commission shall send by certified mail, return receipt requested, a confirmation of the receipt of the complaint to the complainant within three (3) business days after receipt by the commission. The notices to the respondent and the complainant shall also advise them of the date, time and place of the meeting to determine the sufficiency of the complaint and to establish whether probable cause exists to proceed. 
(c)  Upon not less than forty-eight (48) hours' public notice, the commission shall meet to review the sufficient of the complaint and, if the complaint is deemed insufficient to allege a violation of this article, to determine whether there is probable cause, based on the evidence presented by the complainant, to proceed. The meeting may be closed to the public to the extent authorized by the Open Meetings Act. The commission shall issue notice of the complainant to the respondent of the commission's ruling on the sufficiency of the complaint and, if necessary, on probable cause to proceed within seven (7) business days after receiving the complaint. 
If the complaint is deemed sufficient to allege a violation of division 3 of this article and there is a determination of probable cause, then the commission's notice to the parties shall include a hearing date scheduled within four (4) weeks after the complaint's receipt. Alternatively, the commission may elect to notify in writing the attorney designated by the corporate authorities to prosecute such actions and request that the complaint be adjudicated judicially. If the complaint is deemed not sufficient to allege a violation or if there is no determination of probable cause, then the commission shall send by certified mail, return receipt requested, a notice to the parties of the decision to dismiss the complaint, and that notice shall be made public. 
If the complaint is deemed sufficient to allege a violation of division 2 of this article, then the commission shall notify in writing the attorney designed by the corporate authorities to prosecute such actions and shall transmit to the attorney the complaint and all additional documents in the custody of the commission concerning the alleged violation. 
(d)  On the scheduled date and upon at least forty-eight (48) hours' public notice of the meeting, the commission shall conduct a hearing on the complaint and shall allow both parties the opportunity to present testimony and evidence. The hearing may be closed to the public only if authorized by the Open Meetings Act. 
(e)  Within thirty (30) days after the date the hearing or any recessed hearing is concluded, the commission shall either (i) dismiss the complaint or (ii) issue a recommendation for discipline to the alleged violator and to the (chief executive officer or other officers having authority to discipline the officer of employee), or impose a fine upon the violator, or both. The particular findings in the case, any recommendation for discipline, and any fine imposed shall be a matter of public information. 
(f)  If the hearing was closed to the public, the respondent may file a written demand for a public hearing on the complaint within seven (7) business days after the issuance of the recommendation for discipline or imposition of a fine, or both. The filing of the demand shall stay the enforcement of the recommendation or fine. Within fourteen (14) days after receiving the demand, the commission shall conduct a public hearing on the complaint upon at least forty-eight (48) hours' public notice of the hearing and allow both parties the opportunity to present testimony and evidence. Within seven (7) days thereafter, the commission shall publicly issue a final recommendation to the alleged violator and to the (chief executive officer or other officer having authority to discipline the officer or employee) or impose a fine upon the violator, or both. 
(g)  If a complaint is filed during the sixty (60) days preceding the date of any election at which the respondent is a candidate, the commission shall render its decision as required under subsection (e) within seven (7) days after the complaint is filed, and during the seven (7) days preceding that election, the commission shall render such decision before the date of the election, if possible. 
(h)  The commission may fine any person who intentionally violates any provision of division 3 of this article in an amount of not less than one thousand one dollars ($1,001.00) and not more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). The commission may fine any person who knowingly files a frivolous complaint alleging a violation of this article in an amount of not less than one thousand one dollars ($1,001.00) and not more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). The commission may recommend any appropriate discipline up to and including the discharge. 
(i)  A violation of division 2 of this article shall be prosecuted as a criminal offense by an attorney for the Village of Roselle by filing in the circuit court information, or sworn complaint, charging such offense. The prosecution shall be under and conform to the rules of criminal procedure. Conviction shall require the establishment of the guilt of the defendant beyond a reasonable doubt. 
A violation of division 3 of this article may be prosecuted as a quasi-criminal offense by an attorney for the Village of Roselle, or, if an ethics commission has been created, by the commission through the designated administrative procedure. 
(j)  In addition to any other penalty that may be applicable, whether criminal or civil, an officer or employee who intentionally violates any provision of division 2 or division 3 of this article is subject to discipline or discharge. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3113,  1, 12-23-04) 
Secs. 13-159, 13-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6 - UNCONSTITUTIONALITY 

Sec. 13-161. - Unconstitutionality. 
    If the Illinois Supreme Court declares any part of Public 93-617 adopted by this article unconstitutional but upholds the constitutionality of other portions of the Act adopted by this article then the constitutional portion of this article shall remain in full force and effect and that part of the ordinance adopting the unconstitutional portions of Public Act 93-617 shall be deemed repealed without further action by the corporate authorities of the village. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3113,  2, 12-23-04) 
Secs. 13-162-13-165. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - RESERVED[7] 

Footnotes:

Secs. 13-166-13-175. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - BICYCLES[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2010-3535,  1, adopted September 27, 2010, set out provisions intended for use as ㎣ 13-165-13-169. Inasmuch as ㎣ 13-165-13-169 currently exists in the Code, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as ㎣ 13-176-13-180. 

Sec. 13-176. - Bicycles; riding on the sidewalks. 
    It shall be legal to operate bicycles on sidewalks and other public areas when the sidewalk or public area is not congested with pedestrian traffic. Bicycle riders shall exercise due care when riding in the area of pedestrians and, if a sidewalk or other public area is congested with pedestrian traffic, shall walk the bicycle. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3535,  1, 9-27-10) 
Sec. 13-177. - Bicycles, yielding the right-of-way on sidewalks. 
    A person operating a bicycle upon or along a sidewalk or other public area shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian and shall give an audible signal before overtaking or passing such pedestrian. The audible signal may be given by voice, bell or other warning device and at such distance and in such manner as to reasonably notify the person being overtaken and passed. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3535,  1, 9-27-10) 
Sec. 13-178. - Bicycles, emerging from an alley or driveway. 
    The operator of a bicycle emerging from an alley, driveway or building shall, upon approaching a sidewalk or a sidewalk area extending across an alley or driveway, yield the right-of-way to all pedestrians approaching on such sidewalk area and, upon entering the street, shall yield the right-of-way to all approaching vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3535,  1, 9-27-10) 
Sec. 13-179. - Bicycle, parking. 
    No person shall park a bicycle upon a sidewalk in a manner such as to unduly interfere with pedestrian traffic or vehicular traffic, or such manner as to interfere with building entrances. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3535,  1, 9-27-10) 
Sec. 13-180. - Vehicle Code. 
    The Illinois Vehicle Code, in accordance with its specific terms, is and shall remain applicable to the operation of bicycles within the village. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3535,  1, 9-27-10) 
Secs. 13-181-13-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - PARK DISTRICT ORDINANCES[9]

Sec. 13-191. - Adopted. 
    For purposes of the enforcement of Roselle Park District ordinances regulating the use of parks and property owned and controlled by the Village of Roselle Park District, the Village of Roselle hereby adopts by reference as if fully set forth herein an "Ordinance Regulating the Use of Parks and Property Owned or Controlled by the Village of Roselle Park District (Conduct Ordinance)", and any amendments adopted by the Village of Roselle Park District subsequent hereto, and an "Ordinance Regulating the Use of the Skate - Bike Park owned and operated by the Roselle Park District in Parkside Park", and any amendments adopted by the Village of Roselle Park District subsequent thereto, said ordinances being fully incorporated into this Chapter 13 as Appendix A. The ordinances adopted hereby shall be ordinances of the Village of Roselle and shall be fully enforceable by law enforcement authorities of the village. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3537,  1, 9-27-10) 
Appendix A is available in the office of the village clerk. 
Chapter 14 - PARKS AND RECREATION 

Sec. 14-1. - Playground and recreation board ordinance saved from repeal. 
    Nothing contained in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect Ordinance Number 239-68, enacted July 22, 1968, pertaining to the playground and recreation board, and said ordinance is continued in force and effect. 
Chapter 15 - PLANNING AND ZONING GENERALLY[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Emergency services disaster agency,  2-316 et seq.; buildings, Ch. 6; zoning, App. A; subdivision regulations, App. B. 

Sec. 15-1. - Planning and zoning commission-Established. 
    There is hereby established a planning and zoning commission for the village. 
(Code 1956,  68) 
Editor's note- The editors have amended sections 15-1, 15-3 and 15-5, by inserting "planning and zoning commission" in lieu of "plan commission" in light of the changes made in section 15-2 by Ord. No. 1575-87,  2, adopted June 22, 1987. 
State Law reference- Authority to have plan commission, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  11-12-4. 
Sec. 15-2. - Same-Membership. 
    The present village plan commission is hereby dissolved. A new village planning and zoning commission is hereby created; the planning and zoning commission shall consist of seven (7) members to serve, respectively, for the following terms: one for one year, one for two (2) years, one for three (3) years, one for four (4) years, one for five (5) years, one for six (6) years, and one for seven (7) years; and the successor to each member so appointed to serve for a term of five (5) years. 
(Ord. No. 1575-87,  2, 6-22-87) 
Sec. 15-3. - Same-Powers, duties. 
    The planning and zoning commission shall have the powers and perform the duties assigned to it by statute or ordinance. 
(Code 1956,  69) 
Note- See editor's note at  15-1. 
Sec. 15-4. - Reserved. 
Sec. 15-5. - Meeting fees. 
    The fee for the recording of minutes per petition of the zoning board of appeals and planning and zoning commission shall be fifteen dollars ($15.00) per hour. 
(Ord. No. 118-63-A, 11-13-64; Ord. No. 2166-92,  1, 4-27-92) 
Sec. 15-6. - Fees for annexations. 
    The fees for annexation petitions and annexations shall be as follows: 
(1)  The application fee for annexation petitions for single family residential lot where there is an existing home and no proposal to subdivide the lot shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) and five hundred dollars ($500.00) for all other annexation petitions. 
(2)  Upon annexation of any property for R-1 single family residence or R-2 single family residence, the annexation fee shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00) per lot. 
(3)  In the event any R-1 or R-2 lot is annexed and within twenty (20) years of annexation is subdivided, there shall be a charge of two hundred dollars ($200.00) per lot for each additional lot resulting from the subdivision. 
(4)  For any land which is annexed to the Village in conjunction with submission of a plat of subdivision for R-3 and R-4 general residence district, the charge for each lot annexed shall be four cents ($0.04) per square foot. 
(5)  For any land which annexed to the village as R-3 and R-4 residence district and within twenty years of said annexation is resubdivided within the R-3 or R-4 general residence district, there shall be a charge of four cents ($0.04) per square foot for each additional lot resulting from such subdivision. 
(6)  For any land annexed to the village under any classification other than those above described under subsections (1)-(5) of the section, there shall be a minimum annexation fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per lot. The village board may increase this fee should it determine that the impact of the use or proposed use of the annexed property has a greater effect on municipal services than that which is compensated by the minimum fee. Any increased fee for lots falling within this designation shall be a legislative determination based upon applicable legislative standards. Nothing in this section shall be interpreted to obligate the corporate authorities of the village to grant an annexation petition. 
(7)  For purposes of interpreting this section 15-6(2)-(6), the annexation fees shall be based upon the zoning or re-zoning of the property coincidental with the annexation and not the zoning of the property prior to annexation. 
(8)  No petition for annexation shall be submitted without full payment of all application fees required by village ordinance. 
(9)  No plat of annexation shall be signed and recorded without payment of all annexation fees required herein. Any applicant for annexation shall pay all annexation fees imposed by subsections (1)-(6) of this section within thirty (30) days of passage of the ordinance annexing property. Any failure to make said payment within thirty (30) days shall result in said annexation ordinance and any other ordinances or resolutions passed in conjunction therewith to become null, void and without effect. The thirty-day period maybe extended by the village board at its discretion upon written request submitted by the petitioner. 
(Ord. No. 230-68, ㎣ 1, 2, 4-22-68; Ord. No. 2080-91,  1, 4-22-91; Ord. No. 2003-3041,  1, 12-8-03) 
Sec. 15-7. - Hearing fees other than annexations. 
(a)  Rezoning fees. 
(1)  Rezoning fees for any petitions seeking rezoning to R-2 Single-Family Residence shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) per petition. 
(2)  Rezoning hearing fees for any petitions seeking rezoning to an R-3 or R-4 General Residence District shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00) per petition. 
(3)  Rezoning hearing fees for any petitions seeking rezoning to Business (B), Limited Industrial (M) or Office, Research and Light Industrial (ORI) shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00) per petition. 
(b)  Special use fees. 
(1)  Special use hearing fees for any parcels designated as R-1 or R-2 shall be three hundred dollars ($300.00) per petition. 
(2)  Special use hearing fees for any parcels designated as R-3, R-4, (B), (M) or (ORI) shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00) per petition. 
(c)  Variation fees. 
(1)  Variation hearing fees for any vacant land parcels designated as R-1 or R-2 shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) per petition. 
(2)  Variation hearing fees for any parcels by the owner of an existing single-family attached or detached residence in an R-1, R-2, R-2A, R-2B or R-3 residential zoning district shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) per petition. 
(3)  Variation hearing fees for any parcels designated as R-3, R-4, (B), (M) or (ORI) shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00) per petition. 
(d)  Appeal fees. 
(1)  Appeal fees shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per petition. 
(e)  Subdivision fees. 
(1)  The subdivision fee for any parcel designated as R-1 or R-2 shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) per lot. 
(2)  The subdivision fee for any parcel designated as R-3, R-4, (B), (M) or (ORI) shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00) per lot. 
(f)  Planned unit development fees. 
(1)  The hearing fee for any PUD designated as R-1 or R-2 shall be twenty dollars ($20.00) per acre. 
(2)  The hearing fee for any PUD designated as R-3, R-4, (B), (M) or (ORI) shall be forty dollars ($40.00) per acre. 
(g)  Site plan fees. The fee for site plans subject to the review and approval of the zoning administrator shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(h)  Right-of-way vacations: 
(1)  All petitions for vacation of rights-of-way shall be accompanied by a non-refundable application fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) 
(2)  The petitioner(s) shall pay all and other fees and costs related to the vacation prior to board of trustees approval of the vacation unless specifically waived by the board of trustees including but not limited to the following: property appraisal, vacation fee equal to appraised value, hearing notices, outside review fees and utility relocation. 
(3)  The petitioner(s) shall pay any and all recording fees charged by the county recorder of deeds. 
(i)  Payment. No plat, ordinance or other recorded document, shall be signed without payment of all fees to the village clerk unless and until the president and the board of trustees shall, by resolution, authorize such payments to be made at a later date. 
(Ord. No. 1525-87,  1, 2-2-87; Ord. No. 1796-89, ㎣ 1, 2, 2-13-89; Ord. No. 2080-91,  2, 4-22-91; Ord. No. 2120-91, ㎣ 1, 2, 9-9-91; Ord. No. 2166-92,  2, 4-27-92; Ord. No. 2316-93,  1, 4-19-93) 
Sec. 15-8. - Zoning-related deposits. 
    Any petition or application for annexation, zoning appeals, rezoning, special use permits, variations, subdivision improvements, or PUD agreements shall be accompanied by an escrow deposit which shall be applied towards the payment of legal fees, consulting fees, and fees for any services which pertain to annexations, rezoning, and special use permits and which are outside the scope of the village staff. The escrow deposit shall be made at the time of filing of a petition for annexation, rezoning petition, or special use permit petition. All legal fees, consulting fees, and other fees for any services which are outside the scope of the village staff shall be the responsibility of the petitioner and payment of the same may be a condition precedent to the issuance of building or occupancy permits. The schedule of deposit fees for all petitions shall be as follows: 
(1)  Deposits for annexation petitions. 
a.  For any land, containing an existing residence, which shall be annexed to the village coincident with the submission of a request for R-1 or R-2 Single-Family Residence Zoning, no deposit will be required. 
b.  For any vacant land which shall be annexed to the village coincident with the submission of a request for R-1 or R-2 Single-Family Residence Zoning, a deposit of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per petition will be required. 
c.  For any land which shall be annexed to the village coincident with the submission of request for R-3 or R-4 General Residence District Zoning, a deposit of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per petition will be required. 
d.  For parcels brought in on an acreage basis, not accompanied by a plat of subdivision, requested to be zoned as an R-1 or R-2 Single-Family District, a deposit of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per petition will be required. 
e.  For parcels brought in on an acreage basis, not accompanied by a plat of subdivision, requested to be zoned as an R-3 or R-4 General Residence District a deposit of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per petition will be required. 
f.  For any land annexed to the village under any zoning classification other than those herein above described in this section under paragraphs a., b., c., d., and e., a deposit of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per petition will be required. 
(2)  Deposits for rezoning petitions. 
a.  Deposits for any petitions seeking rezoning as an R-1 or R-2 Single-Family Residence District shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) per petition. 
b.  Deposits for any petition seeking rezoning as an R-3 or R-4 General Residence District shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00) per petition. 
c.  Deposits for any petitions seeking rezoning as Business (B), Limited Industrial (M), or Office, Research and Light Industrial (ORI) shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00) per petition. 
(3)  Deposits for special use petitions. 
a.  Deposits for special use petitions for parcels designated as R-1 or R-2 shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00) per petition. 
b.  Deposits for special use petitions for parcels designated as R-3, R-4, (B), (M) or (ORI) shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00) per petition. 
(4)  Deposits for variation petitions. 
a.  Deposits for variation petitions for any vacant land parcels designated as R-1 or R-2 shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) per petition. 
b.  Deposits for variation petitions for any parcels, containing an existing single-family attached or detached residence designated as R-1, R-2, R-2A, R-2B, or R-3 shall be waived. 
c.  Deposits for variation petitions for any parcels designated as R-3, R-4, (B), (M) or (ORI) shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00) per petition. 
(5)  Deposits for appeal petitions. 
a.  There shall be no deposit required for appeals. 
(6)  Deposits for subdivision petitions. 
a.  Deposits for subdivision petitions for any parcels designated as R-1 or R-2 shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) per lot for subdivisions containing three (3) lots or less and five hundred dollars ($500.00) for subdivisions containing four (4) or more lots. 
b.  Deposits for subdivision petitions for parcels designated as R-3, R-4, (B), (M) or (ORI) shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00) per petition. 
(7)  Deposits for Planned Unit Development petition. 
a.  Deposits for any PUD designated as R-1 or R-2 shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00) per petition. 
b.  Deposits for any PUD designated as R-3, R-4, (B), (M) or (ORI) shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00) per petition. 
(8)  Additional funds. Upon depletion of the petitioner's escrow deposit, the petitioner shall deposit such additional escrow amounts as are requested by the village board. Failure of the petitioner to post additional escrow deposits shall be cause to deny the applicant's petition or to withhold building and/or occupancy permits. 
(9)  Refunds. Upon request from a petitioner, any funds not used from petitioner's deposit shall be refunded thirty (30) days after final signing of ordinance, plats, or other recording documents, or thirty (30) days after final charge is assessed to the village, whichever date is later. 
(10)  Deposit for site plans. 
a.  Deposits for site plans petitions for any parcel as required elsewhere in this code shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) per petition. 
(Ord. No. 1525-87,  2, 2-2-87; Ord. No. 1686-88, ㎣ 1, 2, 4-25-88; Ord. No. 2080-91,  3, 4-22-91; Ord. No. 2316-93,  2, 4-19-93) 
Sec. 15-9. - Waiver zoning related deposits. 
    The fees required by section 15-6, annexation; section 15-7, hearing fees other than annexations; and/or section 15-8, zoning related deposits, may be waived or reduced where an applicant has obtained a positive majority vote of the president and board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 2049-91,  1, 2-11-91) 
Sec. 15-10. - Review fees. 
    The fee for professional study and/or report preparation by village staff shall be charged at a rate of thirty dollars ($30.00) per hour in excess of four (4) hours, and by village attorney or outside review service contracted by the village shall be charged at the actual cost of such service. 
(Ord. No. 2166-92,  3, 4-27-92) 
Chapter 16 - POLICE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Arrest authority of village officers generally,  2-60; chief of police,  2-169 et seq.; department of public safety,  2-291 et seq.; emergency services disaster agency,  2-316 et seq.; burglar and fire alarms  13-122 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Department created; composition. 
    There is hereby created a police department, an executive department of the village. The police department shall consist of the chief of police, and such other members as may be provided for from time to time by the president and board of trustees. The chief of police and other members of the police department need not be residents of the village either at the time of appointment or while serving as such chief of police or police officer. 
(Code 1956,  70; Ord. No. 524-75,  1, 1-27-75) 
Cross reference- Petty cash fund,  2-6. 
Sec. 16-2. - General duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the members of the police department to see to the enforcement of all ordinances of the village, and of all statutes effective in the village, and to preserve order and prevent infractions of the law and to arrest violators thereof. Every member of the police department is hereby declared to be a conservator of the peace. 
(Code 1956,  71) 
Sec. 16-3. - Administrative duties of chief. 
    The chief of police shall be keeper of the village jail, and shall have custody of all persons incarcerated therein and of all property pertaining thereto. He shall keep such records and make such reports concerning the activities of his department as may be required by statute or ordinance. The chief shall be responsible for the performance by the police department of all its functions, and all persons who are members of the department shall serve, subject to the orders of the chief of police. 
(Code 1956, ㎣ 73, 104) 
Sec. 16-4. - Custody of lost, abandoned, stolen property. 
    The chief of police shall be custodian of all lost, abandoned or stolen property in the village. 
(Code 1956,  74) 
Sec. 16-5. - Service of process. 
    The chief of police shall be authorized to serve writs, summonses, and other processes, but no patrolman shall serve any such summons or process except on the order of the chief of police or of the village president. 
(Code 1956,  75) 
Sec. 16-6. - Duty to appear as witnesses; fees. 
    Every member of the police department shall appear as a witness whenever that is necessary in a prosecution for a violation of a village ordinance or of a state or federal law. No such member shall receive any witness fee for such services in any action or suit to which the village is a party. All fees due for such services, shall if paid, be turned over to the village treasurer. 
(Code 1956,  76) 
Sec. 16-6.1. - Compensation for court time; rate. 
(a)  Police officers shall be entitled to be compensated for attendance in court on municipal business. 
(Ord. No. 359-71,  2, 9-27-71; Ord. No. 2013-3688,  2, 6-24-13) 
Sec. 16-7. - Regulations governing department. 
    The chief of police may make or prescribe such rules and regulations for the guidance of the members of the department as he shall see fit. Such rules, when approved by the president and board of trustees, shall be binding on all members. 
(Code 1956,  77) 
Sec. 16-8. - Part-time police officer. 
(a)  Employment. The Village of Roselle may employ part-time police officers from time to time as they deem necessary. 
(b)  Duties. A part-time police officer shall have all the responsibilities of a full-time police officer and such specific duties as delineated in the general orders of the Roselle Police Department but the number of hours a part-time officer may work within a calendar year is restricted. Part-time police officers shall not be assigned to supervise or direct fulltime police officers. Part-time police officers shall be trained in accordance with the Illinois Police Training Act (50 ILCS 705/1 et. seq.) and the rules and requirements of the Illinois State Police Training and Standards Board. 
(c)  Hiring standards. Any person employed as a part-time police officer must meet the following standards: 
(1)  Be of good moral character, of temperate habits, of sound health, and physically and mentally able to perform assigned duties. 
(2)  Be at least twenty-one (21) years of age. 
(3)  Possess a high school diploma or GED certificate.
