(4)  Possess a valid State of Illinois driver's license. 
(5)  Possess no prior felony convictions, or misdemeanor convictions of moral turpitude. 
(6)  Any individual who has served in the U.S. military must have been honorably discharged. 
(d)  Discipline. Part-time officers shall be under the disciplinary jurisdiction of the chief of police. Part-time police officers serve at the discretion of the village authorities, shall not have any property rights in said employment, and may be removed by the village authorities at any time. Part-time police officers shall comply with all applicable rules and general orders issued by the police department. 
(e)  Authority. Duly appointed Part-time police officers shall be considered to be an employee of the Village of Roselle and a conservator of the peace. 
(f)  Compensation. Part-time police officers shall be entitled to such compensation as determined by the mayor and board of trustees of the village. 
(Ord. No. 328-70, 12-7-70; Ord. No. 2013-3688,  1, 6-24-13) 
Sec. 16-9. - Chief of police authorized to establish and enforce temporary traffic and parking regulations. 
    The chief of police shall have the power to establish and enforce temporary traffic and parking regulations in circumstance of emergency, special conditions or events, or to test prospective rules and regulations under actual traffic conditions, for a period of no more than ninety (90) days. The police chief shall file a report describing any and all temporary traffic and parking regulations with the village clerk and village administrator within seventy-two (72) hours of the temporary regulation taking effect. The village administrator shall immediately publish such temporary traffic and parking regulations in a locally published newspaper. 
(Ord. No. 1891-89,  1, 11-13-89) 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 10. 
Sec. 16-10. - Police officer-Eligibility. 
(a)  Education requirement. The following shall be the minimum requirements established for original appointment as a full-time police officer with the police department: 
(1)  Associate's Degree in any field of study; or 
(2)  Successfully received credit for a minimum of 60 credit hours toward a bachelor's degree, in any field of study, from an accredited college or university. 
(Ord. No. 2018-3974, 7-9-18) 
Sec. 16-11. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IA. - POLICE PENSION FUND[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 320-70, ㎣ 1-6, being nonamendatory of this Code, has been included herein as Art. IA, ㎣ 16-12-16-17 at the discretion of the editors. 

Sec. 16-12. - Established. 
    There shall be a police pension fund established in the municipality, as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 320-70,  1, 11-2-70) 
Sec. 16-13. - Board of trustees; composition, appointment and election of members, term, meetings. 
    The board of trustees of the said fund shall consist of five (5) members, two (2) appointed by the village president, and two (2) elected by the members of the police department, and one elected by the beneficiaries of the pension fund. The elections shall be held on the third Monday in April, and the term of each member shall be two (2) years. The pension board shall meet at least quarterly as provided by law, and shall hold such additional meetings as may be called by the president of the pension board. 
(Ord. No. 320-70,  2, 11-2-70) 
Sec. 16-14. - Composition of fund. 
    The money in the police pension fund shill be held in a separate account by the municipal treasurer, as provided by statute. This fund shall consist of the deductions from the pay of policemen subject to the [Policemen's Pension Fund] Act, as provided by statute, and there shall be annually levied a tax sufficient to enable the police pension fund to meet all its obligations. 
(Ord. No. 320-70,  3, 11-2-70) 
Sec. 16-15. - Duty of board to invest, manage, control fund and pay beneficiaries. 
    It shall be the duty of the members of the police pension board to manage, invest, and control the police pension fund and all monies pertaining thereto in the manner provided by statute and to pay the beneficiaries as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 320-70,  4, 11-2-70) 
Sec. 16-16. - Reserve. 
    There shall be established and maintained a reserve in the police pension fund, as required by statute. This reserve shall be built up to an amount of at least ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for each policeman and each beneficiary entitled to the protection of the pension fund, and sufficient tax shall be levied for the benefit of the pension fund to build this reserve up to the required amount within the forty (40) years, as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 320-70,  5, 11-2-70) 
Sec. 16-17. - Effective date of salary deductions. 
    This fund shall be established and deductions from salary payments from the pay of policemen shall begin effective as of November 8, 1969, being the date of a census whereby it was determined that the Village of Roselle became subject to the Policemen's Pension Fund Act. 
(Ord. No. 320-70,  6, 11-2-70) 
ARTICLE II. - AUXILIARY POLICE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Auxiliary policemen, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24,  3-6-5. 

Sec. 16-18. - Appointment authorized; fingerprinting; termination. 
    The village president is hereby authorized to appoint twenty-four (24) auxiliary policemen as employees, subject to the advice and consent of the board of trustees. Prior to appointment, all proposed auxiliary policemen shall be fingerprinted and their fingerprints shall be checked with the Federal Bureau of Identification, Washington, D. C., for any possible criminal record. The appointment of any or all auxiliary policemen may be terminated by the village president subject to the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 256-69,  1, 3-24-69) 
Sec. 16-19. - Not to be regular policemen. 
    Auxiliary policemen shall not be members of the regular police department of the village or any other police department. 
(Ord. No. 256-69,  2, 3-24-69) 
Sec. 16-20. - Residence not required. 
    Auxiliary policemen need not be residents of the village. 
(Ord. No. 256-69,  2, 3-24-69) 
Sec. 16-21. - Identification symbols. 
    Identification symbols worn by auxiliary policemen shall be different and distinct from those used by the regular police department and shall be selected and chosen by the chief of police of the village. 
(Ord. No. 256-69,  2, 3-24-69) 
Sec. 16-22. - Control by police chief. 
    Auxiliary policemen shall at all times during the performance of their duties be subject to the direction and control of the chief of police of the village. 
(Ord. No. 256-69,  2, 3-24-69) 
Sec. 16-23. - Powers, duties. 
    Auxiliary policemen shall have the following powers and duties, when properly assigned and on duty: 
(1)  To aid or direct traffic in the municipality. 
(2)  To aid in control of natural or manmade disasters. 
(3)  To aid in case of civil disorder. 
(4)  To perform normal and regular police duties when assigned by the chief of police on occasions when it is impracticable for members of the regular police department to perform normal and regular police duties. 
(5)  To arrest or cause to be arrested, with or without process, all persons who break the peace, or are found violating any municipal ordinance or any criminal law of the state. 
(6)  To commit arrested persons for examination. 
(7)  If necessary, to detain arrested persons in custody overnight or Sunday in any safe place, or until they can be brought before the proper magistrate. 
(8)  To exercise all other powers as conservators of the peace that the corporate authorities may prescribe. 
(9)  To serve and execute all warrants for the violation of municipal ordinances, or the state criminal law, within the limits of the village, and for this purpose to have all the common law and statutory power of sheriffs. 
(Ord. No. 256-69,  3, 3-24-69) 
Sec. 16-24. - Carrying firearms. 
    Auxiliary policemen shall not carry firearms except with the permission of the chief of police of the village and then only when in uniform and in the performance of their duties. 
(Ord. No. 256-69,  4, 3-24-69) 
Sec. 16-25. - Training. 
    Auxiliary policemen shall receive a course of training in the use of weapons and other police procedures by the chief of police of the village. Such course of training shall be not less than forty (40) hours in duration. Upon completion of the course of training, the chief of police shall file a certificate attesting to the auxiliary policeman's completion of said course, with the village clerk. 
(Ord. No. 256-69,  5, 3-24-69) 
Sec. 16-26. - Compensation. 
    Auxiliary policemen shall be paid at the rate established from time to time by the salary ordinance of the village, provided such service is performed at the direction of the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 256-69,  6, 3-24-69) 
Secs. 16-27-16-36. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - JAIL AND PRISONERS 

Sec. 16-37. - Jail designated. 
    The place in the village heretofore established and used as the jail, or any other place which may be hereafter used for that purpose, is hereby declared to be the village jail. 
(Code 1956,  103) 
Sec. 16-38. - Use of jail. 
    The jail shall be used for the incarceration of all persons arrested for violating any laws of the State of Illinois, the United States, or for violating any village ordinance until such person shall be lawfully brought before a magistrate for a hearing or until such person shall be lawfully transferred to some other place of incarceration or otherwise lawfully released. 
(Code 1956,  105) 
Sec. 16-39. - Escape. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to escape or attempt to escape from jail. 
(Code 1956,  106) 
Cross reference- Rescuing or attempting to rescue prisoners,  13-5. 
State Law reference- Escape, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 38,  31-6 et seq. 
Sec. 16-40. - Communications with prisoners. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to communicate with any prisoner held in the jail without the permission of the chief of police or the police officer in charge. 
(Code 1956,  107) 
Secs. 16-41-16-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - INTERGOVERNMENTAL POLICE SERVICE ASSISTANCE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 964-80, ㎣ 1-8, adopted Sept. 8, 1980, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, inclusion herein as Art. IV, ㎣ 16-51-16-58, has been at the discretion of the editor. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stats. Ch. 24, 떰 1-4-6, 11-1-2.1. 

Sec. 16-51. - Purpose of agreement. 
    It is recognized that in certain situations the use of police personnel and equipment to perform police duties outside of the territorial limits of the municipality where such officers are legally employed, is desirable and necessary in order to preserve and protect the health, safety and welfare of the public. 
(Ord. No. 964-80,  1, 9-8-80) 
Sec. 16-52. - Power and authority. 
(a)  Each participating municipality does hereby authorize and direct its chief of police or his designee to render and request mutual police aid to and from other participating municipalities to the extent of available personnel and equipment not required for adequate protection of the municipality rendering aid. The judgment of the chief of police or his designee of each municipality rendering aid, as to the amount of personnel and equipment available, shall be final. 
(b)  A municipality requesting aid shall first seek such aid from the nearest member municipalities possessing the needed personnel and equipment. 
(c)  Personnel who shall be commanded by their superior authority to maintain the peace or perform police duties outside the territorial limits of the municipality which regularly employs such personnel shall be under the direction and authority of the chief of police or his designee of the member municipality requesting aid. Such personnel furnishing aid shall be under the direction and authority of officers of the local municipality in whose command they are placed and, if they are police officers in their own municipality, they shall have all of the powers of police officers of the requesting municipality. 
(d)  No municipality shall be liable to another municipality for a failure to render aid or the withdrawal of aid once furnished pursuant to this agreement. 
(Ord. No. 964-80,  2, 9-8-80) 
Sec. 16-53. - Compensation. 
(a)  Cooperative police service and assistance shall be rendered without charge to a participating municipality during the normal conduct of police business. 
(b)  Whenever a municipality anticipates unusual or burdensome costs in assisting another municipality under this agreement, it shall inform the municipality to receive assistance of those anticipated unusual and burdensome costs, so that an agreement for reimbursement can be reached. No assisting municipality shall be obligated hereunder to incur unusual and burdensome costs without agreement for reimbursement. 
(Ord. No. 964-80,  3, 9-8-80) 
Sec. 16-54. - Indemnification. 
    Each municipality requesting aid under this agreement does hereby agree to indemnify, defend and hold harmless any municipality, employee, or officer thereof, rendering aid for any liability, cost, expense, claim, demand, judgment or attorney's fees arising out of injury or damage caused by any employee or officer involved in rendering aid, including, but not limited to false arrest, detention or imprisonment, wrongful death, malicious prosecution, defamation, assault and battery, invasion of privacy, failure to protect, deprivation of civil rights, trespass or pain and suffering or damage to the property of any third party, except that there shall be no indemnification for any liability arising out of any willful misconduct of any employee. Provided, however, that the total extent of such indemnification including the costs of defense shall be limited to the greater of the following: 
(1)  The limits of liability in Chapter 24, Section 1-4-6 of the Illinois Revised Statutes. 
(2)  The limits of liability for such an occurrence established by a self-insurance pool of which the municipality liable is a member. 
(3)  The limits of liability of any insurance policy which provides coverage to the municipality liable for the claim. 
(Ord. No. 964-80,  4, 9-8-80) 
Sec. 16-55. - Liability. 
    All employee benefits, wage and disability payments, pension and workmen's compensation claims, damage to or destruction of equipment and clothing and medical expense of the municipality rendering aid shall be paid by the municipality regularly employing such person performing services pursuant to this agreement. 
(Ord. No. 964-80,  5, 9-8-80) 
Sec. 16-56. - Rules and regulations. 
    Each participating municipality may establish rules and regulations concerning the method, type and level of response to a request for aid. 
(Ord. No. 964-80,  6, 9-8-80) 
Sec. 16-57. - Effective date of agreement. 
(a)  This agreement shall be in full effect and legally binding at such time as an ordinance authorizing its execution has been passed and approved by at least fifteen (15) municipalities located in whole or in part within DuPage County, Illinois. This agreement may be executed in duplicate counterparts containing the authorized signatures of one or more municipalities. 
(b)  Copies of such an ordinance entering into this agreement shall be filed with the Executive Director of DuPage Mayors and Managers Conference within thirty (30) days of passage and approval. 
(Ord. No. 964-80,  7, 9-8-80) 
Sec. 16-58. - Termination of agreement. 
(a)  Any participating municipality may withdraw from this agreement at any time, at its option, by ordinance of its board or council. 
(b)  Copies of such an ordinance withdrawing from the agreement shall be filed with the Executive Director of DuPage Mayors and Managers Conference within thirty (30) days of passage and approval. 
(Ord. No. 964-80,  8, 9-8-80) 
Chapter 17 - SIGNS AND ADVERTISING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Use of loudspeakers for advertising,  11-2(c); use of sound trucks,  11-13 et seq.; nuisance advertising,  12-13; advertising fortunetelling prohibited,  13-103; advertising gambling places prohibited,  13-108. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2010-3538,  1, adopted September 27, 2010, repealed the former Art. I, ㎣ 17-1-17-5, and enacted a new Art. I as set out herein. The former Art. I pertained to distributing handbills, samples prohibited in public places; consent required to post bills, advertising; obscene, unlawful advertising; advertising unlawful businesses, articles; damaging advertising and derived from ㎣ 352, 400, 401, 750, 755 of the 1956 Code. 

Sec. 17-1. - Signs in public rights-of-way and on public property. 
    No sign shall be permitted in the public right of way or on public property except; 
(a)  Signs of a duly constituted governmental body, including traffic and regulatory signs or similar instructional signs related to directions, health, hazards, parking, swimming, or dumping; 
(b)  Flags and identification signs of duly constituted governmental bodies; 
(c)  Political campaign signs only where authorized by state statute; 
(d)  Decorations or temporary information signs promoting local festivals, community events or national holidays when approved by the corporate authorities of a duly constituted governmental body, but in such case such signs shall be displayed no more than thirty (30) days prior to the festival, community event or national holiday, nor more than seven (7) days after the local festival, community event or national holiday. These decorations and temporary informational signs shall comply with all other applicable ordinances of the village. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3538,  1, 9-27-10) 
Sec. 17-2. - Penalty. 
    In addition to the declaration that a sign violating this article constitutes a nuisance, penalties for violations of this article shall be those set forth in section 1-8, general penalty for violation of Code; continuing violations of the Code of Ordinances for the Village of Roselle, or section 1-8.1, alternative settlement/fines for certain violations/administrative adjudication, as the case may be. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3538,  1, 9-27-10) 
Secs. 17-3-17-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SIGNS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 827-79, ㎣ 1, 2, passed Feb. 26, 1979, repealed former Art. II, ㎣ 17-16-17-54, and added a new Art. II, ㎣ 17-16-17-23. Former Art. II was derived from Ord. No. 259-69, ㎣ 1-5, 7-9, adopted April 14, 1969. Subsequently  1 of Ord. No. 1415-86, adopted Mar. 3, 1986, added a new Art. II, ㎣ 17-16-17-26. 
Cross reference- Licensing and regulation of outdoor advertisers,  9-481 et seq. 

Sec. 17-16. - Title. 
    This article shall be known as, referred to and cited as the Sign Code of the Village of Roselle, Illinois. 
(Ord. No. 1415-86,  1, 3-3-86; Ord. No. 2481-95,  1, 9-25-95) 
Sec. 17-17. - Purpose and intent. 
    The purpose of the sign code is to provide reasonable regulations for the location, size, construction, alteration, use and maintenance of signs within the village for the mutual benefit of the residents of the village and of the various interests utilizing signs as a means of identification and/or advertising. The intent of the regulations is to provide a framework to promote the public health, safety, comfort, morals, convenience and general welfare by: 
(1)  Enhancing the physical appearance of the village; 
(2)  Promoting the safety of public travel on village streets; 
(3)  Protecting the public investment in streets and highways by reducing distractions that may increase traffic accidents; 
(4)  Assuring compatibility of signs with surrounding land uses; 
(5)  Enhancing the economy of the village by promoting the reasonable, orderly and effective display of signs and outdoor advertising; 
(6)  Allowing the full expression of commercial and noncommercial advertising and dissemination of information as provided by the protections accorded through the First Amendment to the United States Constitution. 
(Ord. No. 1415-86,  1, 3-3-86; Ord. No. 2481-95,  1, 9-25-95) 
Sec. 17-18. - Rules and definitions. 
(a)  Rules . The language set forth in the text of this article shall be interpreted in accordance with the following rules of construction: 
(1)  Words used in the present tense shall include the future and the past tenses, and words used in the future tense shall include the present tense. 
(2)  Words in the singular number include the plural number, and words in the plural number include the singular number. 
(3)  The word "shall" is mandatory. 
(4)  The word "may" is permissive. 
(5)  All measured distances or standards shall be to the nearest integer; if the fraction is one-half (1/2) or less, the integer next below shall be taken. 
(6)  Where the conditions imposed by any provision of this article upon the control of signs are either more restrictive or less restrictive than comparable provisions of this article or of any other law, ordinance, resolution, rule or regulation of any kind, the regulations which are more restrictive or which impose higher standards or requirements shall govern. 
(7)  This article is not intended to abrogate any easement, covenant or any other private agreement; provided that where the regulations of this article are more restrictive or impose higher standards or requirements than such easements, covenants or other private agreements, the requirements of this article shall govern. This provision does not waive the village's right to amend or waive any section or provision of the sign code. 
(8)  When a sign type is not specifically listed in the sections devoted to permitted signs, it shall be assumed that such signs are hereby expressly prohibited. If it is determined by the zoning administrator that such sign is similar to signs that are listed, such sign may be permitted provided that it complies with other applicable provisions of this article. 
(9)  The definition of "sign" shall not, however, be interpreted as prohibiting any structure, vehicle, device or any part thereof used for the purpose of disseminating political, economic, social or philosophical ideas entitled to constitutional protections as noncommercial speech. In any instance where this Code would purport to prohibit any such activity, the conditions of this Code shall be interpreted as permitting the utilization of a sign to express such noncommercial speech subject to such other limitations as are included in this code. 
(b)  Definitions . The following words and terms, wherever they appear in this article, shall be construed as herein defined: 
    Abandoned signs. Except as otherwise provided in this Code, any sign which is located on property which becomes vacant and unoccupied for a period of three (3) months or more or any sign which pertains to a time, event or purpose which no longer applies shall be deemed to have been abandoned. Permanent signs applicable to a business temporarily suspended because of a change of ownership or management of such business shall be deemed abandoned if the property remains vacant for a period of more than six (6) months. An abandoned sign is prohibited and shall be removed by the owner of the premises. 
    Address information signs. Address information shall be displayed in close proximity to the front and rear entry of the business. The area of an address identification information sign shall not be included in the total square foot area allowed for a building, plaza or shopping strip. When identifying a rear entry, the business name and address shall both be displayed. Signs pertaining to business hours, and "OPEN/CLOSED" signs, will be classified to include this type of sign. The area of address information signs shall not exceed four (4) square feet (and this area will not be included in the maximum allowable sign area). 
    Banner sign. Any sign printed or painted on cloth or canvas or other material used for attracting the attention of the public shall be considered temporary signs. 
    Billboard or advertising sign. Any sign which directs attention to a business, commodity, service or activity not conducted, sold or offered upon the premises where such sign is located. 
    Business sign. Any sign which directs attention to a business, commodity, service, activity, idea, slogan or entertainment conducted, sold, offered or available upon the premises where such sign is located or to which it is affixed. 
    Canopy or marquee sign . Any sign copy attached to or constructed in or on a canopy or marquee which is attached to a permanent building (see "wall sign"). 
    Caricature sign. Any two- or three-dimensional sign which is an exaggerated representation of the size of any human, animal or vegetable shape, including consumer items sold on the premises. 
    Changeable copy sign (manual). A sign on which copy is changed manually in the field, i.e., reader boards with changeable letters or changeable pictorial panels. 
    Directory sign. Any sign listing the names of multiple property owners or tenants. 
    Electronic message sign. A sign, such as an electronically or electrically controlled public service time, temperature and date sign, message center or reader board where different copy changes of a public service or commercial nature are shown on the same lamp bank. 
    Flag. A construction of fabric, plastic or paper depicting through symbols, characters, design or letters, a nation, political subdivision, institution or business when hung, without frame, from a staff or pole. National, state and other political subdivision flags shall not count towards the total allowable sign area. All other flags shall be considered freestanding signs. 
    Flashing sign. Any sign in which the illumination is not kept stationary or constant in intensity and color at all times, including the illusion of intermittent or flashing light by means of animation, internal illumination, or externally mounted intermittent light sources. Electronic message signs are not considered to be flashing signs. 
    Flush sign. Any sign mounted flat against a wall which does not extend further than twelve (12) inches from the wall. A pointed wall and/or a sign painted directly on a wall shall be considered a "flush sign." 
    Freestanding sign. Any sign supported by posts, poles, pylons, upright braces or other supports extending upward from the ground and not attached to any building. Free standing signs shall be located on the same lot or property which conducts the business activity advertised on the sign. 
    Ground sign. Any freestanding sign wherein the lowest level is not elevated more than six (6) inches above ground level. 
    Identification sign. Any sign which directs attention to a business, profession, commodity, service, or entertainment sold or offered upon the premises where such sign is located. 
    Illuminated moving sign. Any sign depicting illuminated information displayed in words, symbols, pictures, graphics and or numbers which moves or changes at intervals shorter than twenty-four (24) hours. 
    Illuminated moving sign message. Any combination of words, symbols, pictures, graphics and/or numbers displayed simultaneously on an illuminated moving sign. 
    Illuminated sign. Any sign which emanates light either by means of exposed tubing or lamps on the surface or by means of light transmitted through the sign face. 
    Illuminated sign, indirectly. Any sign which reflects light from a source intentionally directed upon it, for example, by means of floodlights, gooseneck reflectors, or externally mounted florescent light fixtures. 
    Interior sign. Any sign placed in the interior of a building which is normally visible through any and all windows and/or doors of the building involved. 
    Linear lighting. All types of illumination, static or flashing, internal or external, fully or partially outlining architectural features such as doors, windows, walls, wall edges or other structural/building elements and which may attract attention or be used as a means of identification or marketing, not including holiday decorations. All holiday decorations shall comply with the village adopted National Electric Code. Linear lighting shall not be used as security lighting or ingress/egress lighting. 
    Moving sign. Any sign that has any external or visible part or parts that move, rotate or spin. Moving signs shall include those which are powered by the wind or mechanically, as well as those signs which simulate movement through the reflective properties of light. 
    Off-premises sign (off-site sign). Any sign that advertises goods, products, services or facilities or directs persons to a location different from the location where the sign is installed. These signs are strictly prohibited (see "billboard"). 
    Office plaza. A commercial development of offices improved with one or more buildings sharing common parking areas and access drives. 
    On-premises sign. Any sign identifying or advertising a business, person, activity, goods, products or services located on the premises where the sign is installed and maintained (see "business sign"). 
    Owner. The person or entity who possesses title to the property. 
    Plaza sign. Any sign advertising the name of a shopping center or shopping plaza. Such sign shall not display any information other than the name of the center or plaza. An address identification number shall be on the plaza sign. 
    Political sign. Any sign advertising any person, group or issue to be voted upon by the public shall be considered a temporary sign. 
    Portable sign. Any sign that is not permanent affixed to a building, structure or the ground. 
    Projecting sign. Any sign, other than a canopy, which is attached directly to a building wall and which extends more than twelve (12) inches from the face of the wall. This type of sign is prohibited. 
    Public service/information sign. Any sign which provides general public service information, such as time, date, temperature, weather, directional information or commercial messages which are commonly used to augment business identification signs. 
    Residential development sign. Any permanent ground sign placed at the major entrances to and identifying a residential, multifamily development or planned unit development. 
    Real estate sign. Any temporary business sign placed upon a property advertising that particular property for sale, for rent or for lease. 
    Roof sign. Any sign erected upon, against or attached to a roof or building above the fascia, soffit or parapet line of a building. These signs are prohibited. 
    Shopping center. A commercial development with a structure of at least fifty thousand (50,000) square feet and containing five (5) or more distinct and separate retail businesses. 
    Shopping plaza. A commercial development with a structure containing three (3) or more distinct and separate retail businesses sharing common parking areas and access drives. 
    Sign. Any identification, description, illustration or device which is visible from any public place or is located on private property and exposed to the public and which directs attention to a product, service, place, activity, person, institution, business or solicitation, including any permanently installed or situated merchandise, any emblem, painting, banner, pennant, placard or temporary sign designed to advertise, identify or convey information with the exception of the national or state flags. Signs shall also include sign structures. 
a.  Area of sign. Except as otherwise provided herein, the total square footage will be the area of all sign faces. The area of the sign (shall be the area of the largest single face of the sign) within a perimeter which forms the outside shape, including any frame forming an integral part of the display, but excluding the necessary supports or uprights on which the sign may be placed. If the sign consists of more than one section, module or sign faces, all areas will be totalled. 
b.  Background area. Entire area of sign on which copy could be placed, as opposed to the copy area, when referred to in connection with fascia or wall signs. "Background area" is further defined as an area on the facade of a building, the boundaries of which shall form a square, a rectangular parallelogram, or other geometric shape which is free of windows, doors and all major architectural details. All signs in a shopping center or shopping plaza shall have common background color. 
c.  Copy area . The entire area within a single, continuous perimeter composed of squares or rectangles or other geometric shapes, which encloses the extreme limits of the advertising message, announcement, or decoration on a fascia or wall sign. 
d.  Height of sign . For freestanding signs, the vertical distance measured from the adjacent street grade or upper surface of the nearest street curb, other than an elevated roadway, to the highest point of such sign. 
    Suspended sign. Any sign that is attached to the under side of the soffit, fascia or other structure of a building. 
    Temporary sign. Any sign which is not intended to be located on the property permanently. All devices such as, but not limited to, banners, pennants, portable or trailer signs, searchlights, twirling or sandwich type signs, sidewalk or curb signs, balloons or other air and gas filled figures. 
    Temporary window or building sign. Any sign painted on the interior window of a building, and constructed of paper, cloth or other like material; or attached to the interior side of a window or displayed on the exterior of a building in order to direct attention of persons outside the building to a sale of merchandise or a change in the status of the business. 
    Trailer sign. Any portable sign attached to a trailer frame to allow towing and transport by a motor vehicle. These signs are prohibited. 
    Traffic regulatory sign. Any official governmental traffic device or sign, illuminated or nonilluminated, or any street sign in public right-of-way. 
    Vehicle sign. Any sign painted on or attached to any vehicle, which is parked for the purpose of displaying the same. All such signs shall be affixed to the vehicle and the vehicle must be in an operable condition. All applicable and current licenses must be displayed. 
    Village board. This term shall mean the president and board of trustees of the village. 
    Wall sign. A sign attached directly to a building wall or fixed canopy or marquee, which is parallel to the wall, canopy or marquee and does not extend more than twelve (12) inches from the face of the wall, canopy or marquee (See "flush signs"). Box signs with changeable panels shall be considered wall signs. 
    Zoning administrator. A person appointed by the village administrator under terms of the Roselle Zoning Ordinance of 1985, as amended, to administer, interpret, and enforce the provisions of the zoning ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 1415-86,  1, 3-3-86; Ord. No. 2481-95,  1, 9-25-95; Ord. No. 2547-96,  1, 10-28-96; Ord. No. 2004-3098,  1, 6-14-04); Ord. No. 2018-3957,  1, 2-26-18) 
Sec. 17-19. - Permits, application, fees. 
(a)  Permits required: 
(1)  No person shall erect, construct, enlarge, move or alter any sign within the village without first having obtained a permit as provided in this article, except for those signs exempted herein. Permits shall not be required for normal maintenance, cleaning, painting, repair and such, so long as the sign or sign structure is not modified in any way. 
(2)  A sign permit shall be issued for the erection, construction, enlargement, relocation or alteration of a sign upon proper application in compliance with the requirements set forth in this article and all other applicable ordinances of the village. 
(3)  Reserved. 
(4)  A sign permit shall become null and void if work has not commenced within one hundred eighty (180) days of its issuance. If work authorized by the permit has not been completed within one hundred eighty (180) days after the first date of commencement, the sign permit shall become null and void. If work authorized by the permit is suspended or abandoned for a period of one hundred eighty (180) days at a time after the work is commenced, the sign permit shall become null and void. In all such cases, a new permit application and payment of full permit fees shall be required. The zoning administrator may waive any of the provisions of this subsection when he determines that the delay has been due to unforseen circumstances outside the applicants control. 
(b)  Application. Application for sign permits shall be made upon forms available from the zoning administrator which shall contain or have attached thereto the following information: 
(1)  Name, address, phone number of the applicant, owner of the premises (person or entity) of the sign and person erecting the sign. 
(2)  A plat of survey or map drawn to scale showing the location of all buildings, structures, lot lines or other features relevant to the placement of signs on the property. In addition, an application for a flush, suspended or wall sign shall include a drawing of the facade upon which the sign will be mounted. An application for a freestanding sign shall indicate an accurate location on the ground, complete with distances from the front property line and the nearest side property line. All sign and facade drawings shall illustrate colors to be utilized. 
(3)  Blueprints or scale drawings of the sign showing the design of the sign, materials, dimensions, color, illumination, wind loads, electric, method of construction and means of attachment to the building or the ground. 
(4)  Illuminated signs shall include electrical drawings and blueprints, which conform to the electrical code. 
(5)  Such other information as may be required by the zoning administrator to show full compliance with this article and all other appropriate ordinances of the village. 
(6)  Certificate of compliance certifying all provisions of this article have been complied with. 
(7)  Temporary sign permit applications shall include site plan with dimensions of the temporary sign and its location on the property, and with a brief description of it's material types. Length of time (with a starting and ending date) shall also be included on the application. 
(c)  Fees. Prior to the issuance of a sign permit, a fee for each sign structure, except those specifically exempted by the article, shall be paid to the village as follows: 
(1)  Freestanding sign: Fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(2)  Temporary sign (less than thirty (30) days): Ten dollars ($10.00). 
(3)  Temporary residential marketing sign [as described in section 17-21(3)(f)(i-iii)]: Fifty dollars ($50.00) plus two dollars ($2.00) for every square foot of signage. 
(4)  All other signs requiring a permit: Thirty dollars ($30.00). 
(Ord. No. 1415-86,  1, 3-3-86; Ord. No. 1966-90,  1, 6-11-90; Ord. No. 2481-95,  1, 9-25-95; Ord. No. 2547-96,  2, 10-28-96; Ord. No. 2003-3019,  1, 9-22-03) 
Sec. 17-20. - General provisions. 
(a)  Placement of ground signs on a corner lot. On corner lots, a ground sign shall not exceed three (3) feet in height for a distance of twenty-five (25) feet in either direction as measured along the intersecting street right-of-way lines (see section 4.06E. of the Roselle Zoning Ordinance) [see appendix A]. The height of the sign within the sight triangle easement shall be measured from the crowns of the intersecting streets adjacent thereto. 
(b)  Placement of freestanding signs on a lot. No portion of a sign or sign structure shall be closer than five (5) feet to the front property line. Additional properties must have a side yard of fifty (50) feet between signs (if speed limit is under thirty-five (35) miles per hour). For speed limit areas of over thirty-five (35) miles per hour the separation shall be one hundred (100) feet. Additional setback shall be required if the sign exceeds ten (10) feet in height (see specific district regulation). Freestanding signs shall be allowed within the sight triangle easement described above provided that the bottom portion of any sign is at least ten (10) feet above grade and does not cause any sight obstruction of vehicular movement. 
(c)  Illumination of signs: 
(1)  Flashing signs, either exterior or interior, and normally visible through any window and or door of a building, are prohibited in all zoning districts. No rotating or revolving beams or beacons or other such devices shall be allowed which illuminates any signs, either on the exterior of a building or in the interior of a building and normally visible through any window and/or door of the building. 
(2)  All exterior and interior illuminated signs shall be wired in accordance with regulations as prescribed by the Roselle Village Electrical Code currently in force [see section 6-102]. Gooseneck reflectors and lights shall be permitted on freestanding signs and wall signs; however, any lights shall be installed in such manner that the direct rays of such lights shall be concentrated on the sign and shall be prevented from causing glare on, or striking the street or nearby property, or the reflector shall be provided with proper glass lenses concentrating the illumination on the area of the sign so as to prevent glare on the street or nearby property. The provisions of this paragraph shall apply to any light illuminating any sign, regardless of the location of the light itself. 
(3)  No exterior or interior illuminated sign shall be placed in such a manner as to interfere with any illuminated traffic signalized intersection. 
(4)  All signs shall satisfy the requirements of the National Electrical Code. 
(5)  Reserved. 
(d)  Letter size. Letter size for free-standing signs shall comply with the minimum letter height requirements appended hereto as if fully set forth as "Appendix A". No lettering shall be greater than one hundred fifty (150) percent of the allowable minimum letter height requirement. Minimum letter height requirements will not apply to lettering mandated by federal law. 
(e)  Sign color. There shall be contrast between information and background and all signs on a property shall have the same background color. 
(f)  Landscaping. Ground immediately surrounding freestanding signs shall be landscaped in an amount equivalent to a minimum of fifty (50) percent of one side of the sign. The maximum allowable size of any permitted sign may be increased by ten (10) percent of the original maximum size provided that landscaping equivalent to one hundred (100) percent of one side of the sign is provided. 
(g)  Construction, safety, maintenance and repair. 
(1)  No person shall erect any sign not complying with the provisions of this article or with any other applicable ordinances of the village. 
(2)  Every sign shall be maintained in a safe, presentable and good structural condition at all times including the replacement of defective parts, painting, cleaning and other acts required for the proper maintenance of the sign. Signs shall be constructed and maintained in compliance with the building, fire, electrical and all other codes of the village. 
(3)  All freestanding signs shall be constructed to withstand a minimum wind load of thirty (30) pounds per square foot of net exposed area. 
(4)  No person or entity shall maintain, or allow to be maintained on any property owned or controlled by him, any sign which is in a dangerous or defective condition. Any such sign shall be removed or repaired by the property owner. 
(5)  An abandoned sign is prohibited and shall be removed by the owner of the premises. 
(6)  The closest outside edge of a sign shall be at least ten (10) feet from any overhead wires. 
(7)  The zoning administrator shall cause to be removed any sign that endangers the public safety such as an abandoned, dangerous or materially, electrically or structurally defective sign or a sign for which no permit has been issued. The zoning administrator shall prepare a notice which shall state that if the sign is not removed or the violation is not corrected within thirty (30) days, the sign shall be removed in accordance with the provisions of this section. All notices shall be sent by certified mail-returned receipt requested. Any time period provided in this section shall be deemed to commence on the date of the receipt of the certified mail. 
For all other signs, notice shall be mailed to the owner of the property on which the sign is located as shown on the last equalized assessment roll. If known, or with reasonable care should be known, the notice should be mailed to or delivered to the owner of the sign and the occupant of the property. Any person having an interest in the sign or the property may appeal the determination of the notice ordering removal or compliance by filing a written notice of appeal to the village administrator within fifteen (15) days of the date of mailing the notice or fifteen (15) days of receipt if the notice was not mailed. The village administrator shall issue a written determination of the notice of appeal within ten (10) days of the date of mailing or ten (10) days after the receipt of the notice if the notice was not mailed. Any person having an interest in the sign or the property may appeal the determination of the village administrator by filing a written notice of appeal with the president and board of trustees. Such appeal must be filed within fifteen (15) days of the date of the determination. The president and board of trustees shall consider the appeal within thirty (30) days after the date of mailing or thirty (30) days after receipt of the notice if the notice was not mailed. The decision of the president and board of trustees shall be final. 
In cases of emergency, the zoning administrator may cause the immediate removal of a dangerous or defective sign without notice. 
Any sign removed by the village shall become the property of the village and may be disposed of in any manner deemed appropriate by the village. The cost of removal of the sign by the village shall be considered a debt owed to the village by the owner of the sign and the owner of the property and may be recovered in any appropriate court action by the village or by lien against the property. The cost of removal shall include any and all expenses, including reasonable attorney fees, incurred by the village in connection with the sign removal and enforcement of the lien. 
(Ord. No. 1415-86,  1, 3-3-86; Ord. No. 2481-95,  1, 9-25-95; Ord. No. 2547-96, ㎣ 3-7, 10-28-96) 
Sec. 17-21. - Sign regulations in the zoning districts. 
    The following regulations shall be observed in the respective zoning districts within the village. 
(1)  Prohibited signs, all zoning districts . The following signs are expressly prohibited: 
a.  Pennants, streamers, balloon, inflatable shapes and other temporary signs, except that these shall be allowed as temporary signs under the regulations of this chapter. 
b.  Billboards. 
c.  Illuminated signs in which the illumination is not steady and constant. 
d.  Roof signs. 
e.  Searchlights, other beams and/or any type of intense lighting. 
f.  Signs obstructing or interfering with traffic lanes or traffic-control signals or signs, traffic sight lines or signals at railroad grade crossings, and signs containing arrows and the word "stop" or "danger" or otherwise resembling or simulating official governmental traffic-control signs or signals. 
g.  Signs obstructing any window, door, fire escape, stairway or opening intended to provide light, air, ingress or egress for any building or structure. 
h.  Trailer-type signs. 
i.  Any sign not listed in this section as being a permitted temporary or permanent sign. 
j.  Linear lighting. 
(2)  Exempted signs, all zoning districts. Unless otherwise stated, signs listed in this section are permitted in all zoning districts and shall not be counted when calculating the number of signs or square footage on a premises. However, such signs shall conform with the general regulations (e.g., weight, area, setback, clearance, etc.) for signs enumerated in the remainder of this article: 
a.  The following signs shall be subject to the permit provisions as stated in this article; however, no permit fee shall be required: 
1.  Bulletin board signs for public, charitable or religious institutions, when the sign has an area of no more than thirty-two (32) square feet in a residential zoning district and no more than one hundred (100) square feet in a nonresidential zoning district. 
2.  Construction signs. One nonilluminated construction sign per construction project not exceeding thirty-two (32) square feet of sign area in residential districts or sixty-four (64) square feet in nonresidential districts. Prior to the issuance of a construction sign permit, applicant shall submit satisfactory evidence to the zoning administrator that building permits for the construction being advertised are being actively pursued. Construction signs shall be confined to the site of construction and shall be removed no later than ten (10) days following the issuance of a building's final occupancy permit or shall be removed within sixty (60) consecutive days of issuance if construction has not commenced, unless in the opinion of the zoning administrator, the building permit is being diligently pursued. 
3.  Home occupations. One nonilluminated sign, not to exceed one (1) square foot in area, identifying the name, address, home occupation, and/or professional services offered upon the premises. Such signs shall be a flush sign and mounted no higher than the bottom of the structure's eaves. 
4.  Nonilluminated signs which are permanently affixed to buildings or structures for the purpose of identifying the name of a building, date of erection or other historical information. Such signs shall not be more than four (4) square feet in area. 
5.  Name and address plates, not more than two (2) square feet in area, containing only the name and address of the occupant(s) of the building. 
6.  Signs regulating on-premise traffic and parking, when less than four (4) square feet in area and bearing no commercial advertising. 
7.  Signs identifying places of worship when located on the premises thereof. 
8.  Box panel inserts as long as they are in compliance with all other sections of this sign code. 
9.  Garage sale signs in residential areas not exceeding six (6) square feet. 
b.  The following signs shall not be subject to the permit or permit fee provisions of this article: 
1.  Flags, pennants, banners or insignia of any government or religious, charitable or fraternal organization. 
2.  Holiday decorations. Signs of a primarily decorative nature, customarily associated with any national or local event or religious holiday. 
3.  No-trespassing signs or other such signs regulating the use of property, not more than two (2) square feet in area in residential zones or six (6) square feet in all other zoning districts. 
4.  Political signs displayed in accordance with an official election or signs erected on behalf of candidates for public office provided that signs shall be placed so as not to interfere with motorists' line of sight. 
5.  Real estate signs in a residential district not exceeding six (6) square feet per sign face. 
6.  Signs erected by a governmental body, or under the direction of such a body, and bearing no commercial advertising, such as traffic signs, railroad crossing signs, safety signs, signs identifying schools and playgrounds, and public hearing notices. 
7.  Signs which identify restrooms, public telephones or provide instructions as provided by law or necessity, provided the sign does not exceed two (2) square feet in area. 
8.  Temporary signs not exceeding four (4) square feet in area pertaining to events of civic, philanthropic, educational or religious organizations, provided such signs are posted no more than seven (7) days before the start of the event and removed no more than two (2) days after the end of the event. 
9.  Signs advertising village sponsored community events. Such signs shall be subject to the approval of the village president and shall not be displayed for more than sixty (60) days prior to the start of any community event or more than fifteen (15) days after the end of the event. 
(3)  Permitted signs, residence and agricultural districts. The following signs shall be permitted subject to the regulations contained herein: 
a.  All signs listed in section 17-21(2) "exempted signs, all zoning districts," of this article. 
b.  Garage sale signs, not exceeding six (6) square feet in area, may be placed at the curb in residential areas, provided such signs are displayed no more than twice per year per dwelling unit for a cumulative total of six (6) days. 
c.  Identification signs for nonresidential uses, e.g., churches, cemeteries, golf courses, private nonprofit recreational areas, provided that such signs are limited to one (1) sign per building entrance, and provided that such sign is limited to thirty-two (32) square feet of total area, and eight (8) feet in height if a ground sign. 
d.  Identification signs for multifamily developments, provided that such signs are limited to one ground sign per building entrance, and provided that such sign be limited to thirty-two (32) square feet of total area and eight (8) feet in height. 
e.  Real estate signs, not exceeding six (6) square feet per side of sign area in the residential zone. Such real estate signs shall be removed within ten (10) days after the premises or lot advertised has been sold, rented or leased. Open house signs shall be permitted off-site during daylight hours. 
f.  Temporary residential marketing signs. 
1.  Temporary free standing signs to planned unit developments or residential subdivisions erected for marketing the development or subdivision and which shall not to exceed sixty-four (64) square feet per side or ten (10) feet in height and may contain the name of the development, sales information, and the names of the builders or units therein. The number and location of these signs shall be approved by the zoning administrator. In determining the number and location of such signs, the zoning administrator shall consider the five (5) factors listed in subsection 2. of this section. 
2.  Temporary wall signs erected for marketing located on buildings and within planned unit developments or residential subdivisions and which shall; have one (1) sign per wall, not to exceed ten (10) percent of the area of the building wall upon which the sign will be placed and not exceed ten (10) feet in height. The percentage allowed shall be considered separately for each wall and shall be non-cumulative. Temporary wall signs may contain the name of the development, sales information, and the names of the builders or units therein. No building shall display wall signs on more than two (2) sides of the building unless the building fronts on three (3) or more streets. The location of these signs shall be approved by the zoning administrator. In determining the location of such signs, the zoning administrator shall consider the following five (5) factors: 
i.  The location of the development. 
ii.  The size of the development. 
iii.  The visibility which the sign will achieve at particular entrances at which signage is sought. 
iv.  The proximity of the wall to existing residences not part of the planned unit development or residential subdivision it advertises. 
v.  Size of the proposed signage both with regard to individual signs and with total signage requested. 
3.  All temporary freestanding and wall signs shall be removed no later than one hundred eighty (180) days after the sign permit is issued for the planned unit development or residential subdivision. One (1) extension up to one hundred eighty (180) days may be granted by the village board for such signage. 
(4)  Permitted signs, business districts. The following signs shall be permitted subject to the regulations contained herein: 
a.  All signs listed in section 17-21(2) "exempted signs, all zoning districts," of this article. 
b.  Directional signs. Four (4) square feet per side and only containing information on ingress and egress and the name of the plaza or business. 
c.  Freestanding signs, as follows: 
1.  The maximum combination of all freestanding signs whether directory or nondirectory on any site shall not exceed two (2). 
2.  Directory signs. 
i.  One-half (1/2) square foot of sign area shall be allowed for each lineal foot of frontage of the property (both sides of a double-faced sign count toward the total sign area allowed). If property is less than fifty (50) feet wide, sign area will be one (1) square foot per lineal foot of frontage. 
ii.  Total sign area shall not exceed one hundred (100) square feet per sign face. 
iii.  For a shopping center, shopping plaza, multiple-use building, or single-use building, one freestanding directory sign shall be allowed for every two hundred (200) feet of frontage up to a maximum of two (2) signs; provided that the total sign area shall not exceed one-half (1/2) square foot for each one (1) foot of frontage of the property. When there are more than nine (9) businesses in the same center the same business(es) are not allowed to be listed on both signs, four (4) through eight (8) shall be listed on a second sign. Such signs will not exceed the additional limits in subsection 2., "directory signs." 
iv.  The height of any directory sign shall not exceed twenty-five (25) feet nor be more than five (5) feet over the existing building, whichever is less. 
v.  Any directory sign shall be setback one-half (1/2) foot for each one (1) foot of sign height, provided that the minimum setback shall be five (5) feet. 
vi.  A clearance of ten (10) feet from grade to the bottom of the sign shall be maintained in any location where the sign would interfere with pedestrian or vehicular traffic. 
vii.  Each freestanding directory sign shall include the street address of the business or shopping center. The design and size of such address display shall be three (3) inches or fifty (50) percent of average letter size, whichever is greater. Street address will not be included in calculating size of sign. 
viii.  No freestanding directory signs shall be placed directly adjacent to or immediately above or below any existing freestanding sign. There shall be a fifty-foot separation between freestanding signs if the speed limit is less than thirty-five (35) miles per hour and one hundred (100) feet separation if greater than thirty-five (35) miles per hour. 
ix.  Businesses at a location shall be identified in accordance with the following formula: 
2-4 businesses 100% of the businesses shall be listed 5-8 businesses 4-8 businesses shall be listed 9 and up 5-8 businesses shall be listed 2nd directory sign 4-8 businesses, same business not allowed on two (2) signs  
3.  Nondirectory, plaza, area signs or business freestanding signs as follows: 
i.  One-half (1/2) square foot of sign area shall be allowed for each lineal foot of frontage of the property (both sides of a double-faced sign count toward the total sign area allowed). If property is less than fifty (50) feet wide, sign area will be one square foot per lineal foot of frontage. 
ii.  Total sign area shall not exceed fifty (50) square feet per sign face. 
iii.  For a shopping center, shopping plaza, multiple-use building, or single-use building, one freestanding sign advertising a single business shall be allowed. After two hundred (200) feet of frontage, two (2) signs may be used, provided that the total sign area shall not exceed one-half (1/2) square foot for each one foot of frontage of property. Service stations shall be permitted a second sign for price listing of gas. 
iv.  The height of any nondirectory, plaza, area signs or business freestanding signs shall not exceed twenty-five (25) feet nor be more than five (5) feet above the existing building, whichever is less. 
v.  Any nondirectory, plaza, area signs, or business freestanding signs shall be setback one-half (1/2) foot for each one foot of sign height, provided that the minimum setback shall be five (5) feet. 
vi.  A clearance of ten (10) feet from grade to the bottom of the nondirectory sign shall be maintained in any location where the sign would interfere with pedestrian or vehicular traffic. 
vii.  The nondirectory sign copy of a plaza or area sign shall be limited to the name of the business or name of the shopping center, and applicable street address. 
viii.  Each freestanding nondirectory business sign shall include the street address of the business or shopping center. The design and size of such address display shall be three (3) inches or fifty (50) percent of average letter size, whichever is greater. Street addresses shall not be included in calculating size of the sign area. 
ix.  No freestanding non-directory sign shall be placed directly adjacent to, or immediately above or below any existing freestanding sign. There shall be a side yard separation of fifty (50) feet between all freestanding signs if the speed limit is less than thirty-five (35) miles per hour, and one hundred (100) feet separation if the speed limit is over thirty-five (35) miles per hour. 
d.  Wall signs, including directory wall signs, painted wall signs and help wanted signs as follows: 
1.  Where a building has a street setback of forty-nine (49) feet or less, measured from the front of the unit furthest from the street, one square foot of signage shall be allowed for each lineal foot upon which a sign will be placed. 
2.  Where a building has a street setback of fifty (50) feet to ninety-nine and nine tenths (99.9) feet, measured from the front of the unit furthest from the street, one and one quarter (11/4) square feet of signage shall be allowed for each lineal foot upon which a sign will be placed. 
3.  Where a building has a street setback of one hundred (100) feet or more, measured from the front of the unit furthest from the street, one and one-half (11/2) square feet of signage shall be allowed for each lineal foot upon which a sign will be placed. 
4.  Each side of the building shall be considered separately with the square footage allowance based only on the side of the building upon which the sign will be displayed (square footage is noncumulative from wall to wall). 
5.  No building shall display signs on more than two (2) sides of the building unless the building fronts three (3) or more streets. 
e.  Multi-tenant signage: 
1.  Prior to the issuance of a permit for a sign at a multi-tenant building the village zoning administrator shall determine if a master sign plan is on file. If a master sign plan is not on file with the village, the village zoning administrator shall follow section 17-21(d)(5)c. of this ordinance. 
2.  Master sign plan. A master sign plan is a plan submitted by a multi-tenant building owner which has been reviewed by the village zoning administrator and approved by the village board. The master sign plan shall depict the type, dimensions, shape, lettering size, and locations of signs located at or which will be located at a multi-tenant building. The master plan shall be developed so as to result in a uniformity of size, lettering style, and materials to be used at locations throughout the multi-tenant building. A master sign plan shall further contain a description of a reasonable time schedule for implementing the plan so that all other legal non-conforming signage located on or about the multi-tenant building shall be brought into conformance with the master sign plan. This period shall not exceed five (5) years. When a master sign plan is on file with the village, the village zoning administrator shall follow the standards contained in the master sign plan in determining whether or not to issue a permit for a proposed sign. 
3.  Predominant theme. In the absence of a filed master sign plan, the village zoning administrator shall evaluate the existing signage on a multi-tenant building to determine that building's predominant sign theme. In determining the predominant theme of existing multi-tenant building signage, the village zoning administrator shall review the shape, dimensions, lettering style, materials, and locations of existing signs in the multi-tenant building. The village zoning administrator will then identify the most common features of the existing signs to determine the predominant theme of the signage. In issuing a sign permit for a multi-tenant building without a master sign plan, the village zoning administrator shall require a proposed sign to conform to the predominant theme of the multi-tenant building. 
4.  Any petition for a variance from the standards set forth in this section shall be submitted for a variance hearing in conformance with the other provisions of this chapter. 
f.  Other signs as follows: 
1.  Real estate signs shall be allowed. The maximum area requirement shall be determined by the developed or undeveloped condition of the property listed as follows: 
i.  Real estate signs erected on undeveloped property shall not exceed ten (10) square feet of total sign area for each one acre of land area, up to a maximum of two hundred (200) square feet of total sign area and one hundred (100) square feet on any sign face of a sign. 
ii.  Real estate signs erected on developed property shall not exceed fifteen (15) square feet of area on any single face of a sign. 
iii.  Real estate signs erected on developed property may be erected upon an existing freestanding sign, or may be erected as a freestanding sign. Real estate signs shall not be located upon the wall of any existing structure. 
2.  Painted windows shall be allowed provided that: 
i.  The sign copy provides only business identification information. 
ii.  The painted area does not exceed fifty (50) percent of total window area. 
iii.  Total allowed sign area, including any painted area and wall signage, shall not exceed the area allowed for wall signs. 
3.  Canopy, awning or marquee signs may be used in place of wall signs, providing that such signs do not extend more than four (4) feet from the face of the building and not within the right-of-way. Service station signs illustrating the name and/or logo of the business shall be allowed more than eighteen (18) inches below the canopy and not less than seven (7) feet six (6) inches above grade provided that such signs are permanently affixed to the canopy or canopy supports and the maximum area shall not exceed the area specified for wall signs. 
The total area of a canopy sign shall not exceed twenty-five (25) percent of the total front wall space attributable to a business tenancy. Area of such signs shall be calculated by multiplying height times width as viewed from front elevation. Copy area only includes lettering unless canopy is lit; then entire canopy is included towards allowable sign area. 
4.  Window signs of paper or similar materials shall be allowed provided that such signs are to be used to notify the public of special sales or current prices, and further provided that such signs do not take up more than fifty (50) percent of the total window area. No sign permit or sign permit fee shall be required for such signs. 
5.  Reserved. 
6.  Temporary signs shall be allowed to advertise the opening of a business or shopping center, provided that such sign shall not exceed thirty-two (32) square feet on any single face of the sign; such sign may be displayed for a period exceeding thirty (30) days. 
A temporary sign may be erected within one year of the grand opening of a business or a change in ownership. Such temporary sign may be erected on a one-time only basis in conformance with the remaining requirements of this article. 
7.  Temporary signs may be erected for the Rose Parade, Taste of Roselle, Chamber of Commerce sidewalk sale and any two (2) events requested by a business (i.e., anniversary, special sales, etc.) during the calendar year provided that they comply with the remaining requirements of this subsection. 
Display of temporary signs during the Rose Parade and Taste of Roselle shall be limited to the seven-day period preceding and including the final day of such event. Display of temporary signs during any other special event shall be limited to the three-day period preceding and including the final day of each event. 
Violation of the display or permit provisions of this article may result in the suspension of all special event permit privileges. 
8.  Moving/rotating signs. A variation shall be required subject to other conditions of this article. 
g.  Illuminated moving signs as follows: 
1.  All illuminated moving signs shall conform to all of other requirements of this chapter not inconsistent with this subsection. 
2.  All illuminated moving signs shall comply with the applicable lighting standards set forth in section 4.18 of the Village of Roselle Zoning Code. 
3.  Illuminated moving signs may be on a plaza or directory sign and are included as part of the total calculated sign area. The total calculated sign area for an illuminated moving sign shall be determined based on the standards set forth in section 17-21(4). 
4.  All illuminated moving signs shall comply with all applicable electrical code regulations. 
5.  For purposes of public safety, all illuminated moving signs within two hundred seventy-five (275) feet of an intersection controlled by a stop and go light, as measured from the pole of the nearest stop and go light to the nearest edge of the illuminated moving sign, shall comply with the following regulations: 
i.  The message shall not change more frequently than once every five (5) seconds. 
ii.  The illumination of the message shall be constant and not variable. 
iii.  When the message changes, the prior illuminated message shall disappear simultaneously and the new message shall appear simultaneously. 
iv.  The color of the lights displaying the message shall not be any shade of red, yellow or green. 
v.  The illuminated moving sign shall maintain a minimum height clearance of ten (10) feet, as measured from the street grade of the adjacent right-of-way to the underside of the illuminated moving sign. 
(5)  Permitted signs, office research and light industrial and limited manufacturing districts. The following signs shall be permitted subject to the regulations contained herein: All signs listed in section 17-21(4), "permitted signs-business district," of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1415-86,  1, 3-3-86; Ord. No. 1584-87, ㎣ 1-6, 7-13-87; Ord. No. 1979-90,  2, 7-23-90; Ord. No. 2012-90,  2, 11-26-90; Ord. No. 2172-92,  1, 5-26-92; Ord. No. 2335-93,  1, 6-14-93; Ord. No. 2481-95,  1, 9-25-95; Ord. No. 2547-97, ㎣ 8-13, 10-28-96; Ord. No. 2003-3019,  2, 9-22-03; Ord. No. 2004-3098, ㎣ 2, 3, 6-14-04; Ord. No. 2011-3574,  1, 4-25-11; Ord. No. 2018-3957,  2, 2-26-18) 
Sec. 17-22. - Nonconforming signs. 
    All permanent signs which are in existence at the time of passage of this article [September 25, 1995], but which do not conform to one or more provisions of this Code, shall be deemed to be a legal nonconforming use and may be continued only as provided in this Code. 
(1)  Any conforming sign rendered nonconforming by this amendment or by any subsequent amendment to the sign code may be continued in use after the effective date of such amendment, provided there is no physical change other than necessary maintenance and repair and except as provided in section 17-22 herein. Therein shall be a bonus of twenty-five (25) percent of maximum size allowed if current nonconforming sign is replaced with sign that meets proposed code within two (2) years of the effective date of this article. 
Any owner of property containing a sign which was granted a variance under prior versions of the sign regulations of the village shall be allowed to display such signs in accordance with the terms of the variance granted. In the event the terms of the variance previously granted are not complied with, such signs shall become nonconforming and shall be discontinued immediately. 
(2)  Whenever a nonconforming sign has been discontinued for a period of six (6) consecutive months, or whenever there is evident a clear intent on the part of the owner to abandon a nonconforming sign, such sign shall not, after being discontinued or abandoned, be reestablished, and the sign hereafter shall be made to conform to all the requirements of this article as may be applicable to such sign. 
(3)  If a nonconforming sign is damaged or destroyed by any means to the extent of fifty (50) percent or more of its replacement value at that time, the sign can be rebuilt or used thereafter only in compliance with the provisions of the code. In the event the damage or destruction is less than fifty (50) percent of its replacement value, based upon prevailing costs, the sign may then be restored to its original condition and the use may be continued which existed at the time of such partial destruction until the nonconforming sign is otherwise abated by the provisions of this code. In either event, restoration or repair must be stated within a period of six (6) months from the date of damage or destruction, and diligently prosecuted to completion. 
(4)  A legal nonconforming sign shall become unlawful if: 
a.  The sign is altered in any way in structure except for changeable copy, normal maintenance, changing or replacing of box sign panel inserts in conformance with subsection 17-21(4)e. of this article. 
b.  The sign is relocated except that a legal nonconforming billboard sign may be relocated only where its relocation is on the same property and where such relocation is necessary to permit development of the property and where the owner of the property agrees not to extend the lease for the billboard sign beyond the expiration date of that lease in force on the date of March 3, 1986. Any relocated billboard sign must otherwise comply with all applicable ordinances of the village and neither the owner of the property upon which the billboard sign is located nor any business operating on that property shall advertise on the billboard sign. 
c.  The complete sign is replaced, or at least fifty (50) percent of an individual business tenancy within a multitenant building is remodeled except that any sign which has been temporarily removed as a result of the official actions of a governmental entity other than the village may be reconstructed provided that such reconstruction is at the same location that the sign previously existed and only where the owner of the property on which the sign is located agrees that the sign may not remain upon the property beyond its current lease term. Should any of the foregoing conditions not be satisfied, or upon the expiration of the current lease, then such billboard sign shall become nonconforming and shall be discontinued immediately. 
d.  Maintenance and repair. Nothing in this section shall relieve the owner or user of a legal nonconforming sign or owner of the property on which the legal nonconforming sign is located from the provisions of this code regarding safety, maintenance and repair of signs contained in this code; however, any repainting, cleaning and other normal maintenance or repair of the sign or sign structure shall not modify the sign structure or copy in any way which makes it more nonconforming or the sign may lose its legal nonconforming status. 
e.  The zoning administrator shall, as soon as practicable after the passage of this sign code, notify each owner of a nonconforming sign the manner in which such sign is not in compliance with this code. The zoning administrator shall further notify each owner of the nonconforming status and submit such notice to the appropriate county government for official recording. 
(Ord. No. 1415-86,  1, 3-3-86; Ord. No.1944-90, ㎣ 1, 2, 5-14-90; Ord. No. 1979-90,  1, 7-23-90; Ord. No. 2012-90,  1, 11-26-90; Ord. No. 2481-95,  1, 9-25-95) 
Sec. 17-23. - Administration. 
    The zoning administrator, as established in the Roselle Zoning Ordinance [see appendix A], shall be in charge of the administration and enforcement of this article. In furtherance thereof, the zoning administrator shall exercise supervision over all signs erected, altered, constructed or maintained, and to cause inspection of all signs to be made; whenever it shall appear that any sign or part thereof has been erected in violation of this article or of any other ordinance of the village or is in an unsafe condition or has become unstable or insecure or is in such a condition as to be a menace to the safety or health of the public, he shall thereupon issue or cause to be issued, a notice in writing to the owner of such sign, or to the person maintaining the same, or to the owner of the property upon which the sign is placed, informing such person, firm or corporation of the violation of this article and the dangerous condition of such sign, and directing him to make such alterations or repairs thereto and to do such acts or things as are necessary or advisable to cause such sign to be brought into a safe, substantial and secure condition and to make the same comply with the requirements of this article, within such reasonable time as may be stated in the notice. Any and all signs installed or maintained in violation of this article, or any of the clauses or provisions of the same, or in violation of any of the laws of the Village of Roselle, or the State of Illinois are declared to be public nuisance and subject to treatment and abatement as such. Any such sign so erected or maintained contrary to law shall be abated as a common nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 1415-86,  1, 3-3-86; Ord. No. 2481-95,  1, 9-25-95) 
Sec. 17-24. - Penalty. 
    In addition to the declaration that a sign has become a nuisance under the provisions of the article, any person, firm or corporation who violates any provision of this article shall, upon conviction thereon, be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not less than seventy-five dollars ($75.00) or more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. Each day the violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 1415-86,  1, 3-3-86; Ord. No. 2481-95,  1, 9-25-95) 
Sec. 17-25. - Variations.
