(1)  Submit a completed application form provided by the village no later than the April 30 following the preceding calendar year; and 
(2)  Provide written proof of age acceptable to the village; and 
(3)  Provide a current property tax bill or current lease corresponding to the address for which the utility bills were paid by the resident and for which reimbursement is sought; and 
(4)  Provide a completed United States income tax return, IRS Notice 703 or other proof of income acceptable to the village showing the applicant's total gross income for the year for which reimbursement is requested. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3132,  2, 10-25-04; Ord. No. 2008-3374,  2, 1-28-08) 
Sec. 20-72. - Applicants turning sixty-five during a year for which reimbursement is sought. 
    Residents who turn age sixty-five (65) during a year for which relief is sought shall be reimbursed starting with the month in which the applicant becomes age sixty-five (65) for those billing periods which start in the month the applicant becomes age sixty-five (65) provided that such person otherwise qualifies. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3132,  3, 10-25-04; Ord. No. 2008-3374,  3, 1-28-08) 
Sec. 20-73. - Reimbursement; when paid. 
    The village shall reimburse a qualified applicant within thirty (30) days following receipt of a completed application provided that all of the requirements of this division have been satisfied. 
(Ord. No. 2004-3132,  4, 10-25-04; Ord. No. 2008-3374,  4, 1-28-08) 
Secs. 20-74-20-79. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - AUTOMOBILE RENTING OCCUPATION TAX[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1058-82,  2, adopted Jan. 11, 1982, did not specify manner of codification and has, therefore, been included herein as Art. V, ㎣ 20-46-20-48, at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 20-80. - Imposed; administration. 
(a)  Imposed. A tax is hereby imposed, in conformances with 65 ILCS 5/8-11-7, upon all persons engaged in the business of renting automobiles in the village, at the rate of one (1) percent of the gross receipt from such business. 
(b)  Administration. In the administration of and in compliance with this section, every person engaged in such business in the village shall have the same rights, remedies, privileges, immunities, powers and duties and be subject to the same conditions, restrictions, limitations, penalties and definitions of terms and employ the same modes of procedure as are prescribed in ILCS ch. 120, ㎣ 1702 and 1703, except as otherwise provided within such acts. 
(Ord. No. 1058-82,  2, 1-11-82; Ord. No. 2429-94,  2, 10-24-94; Ord. No. 99-2726,  1, 10-25-99) 
Sec. 20-81. - Report required. 
    Every such person engaged in such business in the village shall file on or before the last day of each calendar month, the report to the State Department of Revenue required by Sections Two and Three of "An Act in Relation to a Tax upon Persons Engaged in the Business of Selling Tangible Personal Property to Purchasers for Use or Consumption" approved June 29, 1933, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 1058-82,  3, 1-11-82; Ord. No. 2429-94,  2, 10-24-94) 
Sec. 20-82. - Payment. 
    At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the State Department of Revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed on account of the renting of automobiles during the preceding month. 
(Ord. No. 1058-82,  4, 1-11-82; Ord. No. 2429-94,  2, 10-24-94) 
Secs. 20-83-20-87. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - AUTOMOBILE RENTING USE TAX[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1058-82, ㎣ 2-4, adopted Jan. 11, 1982, being nonamendatory of the Code, has been included herein as Art. VI, ㎣ 20-51-20-53 at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 20-88. - Imposed. 
    A tax is hereby imposed upon the privilege of using, in the village, an automobile that is rented from a renter outside of Illinois, and which is titled or registered with an agency of this state's government, in the village, at a rate of one (1) percent of the rental price of such automobile while this article is in effect in accordance with 65 ILCS 5/8-11-8. 
(Ord. No. 1059-82,  2, 1-11-82; Ord. No. 2429-94,  2, 10-24-94; Ord. No. 99-2725,  1, 10-25-99) 
Sec. 20-89. - Collected, from whom. 
    The tax provided for in this article shall be collected from the persons whose Illinois address for titling or registration purposes is given as being in this village. 
(Ord. No. 1059-82,  3, 1-11-82; Ord. No. 2429-94,  2, 10-24-94; Ord. No. 99-2725,  2, 10-25-99) 
Sec. 20-90. - Payment. 
    The tax imposed by this article shall be paid to the Illinois Department of Revenue. 
(Ord. No. 1059-82,  4, 1-11-82; Ord. No. 2429-94,  2, 10-24-94; Ord. No. 99-2725,  3, 10-25-99) 
Secs. 20-91-20-95. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - MUNICIPAL HOTEL TAX 

Sec. 20-96. - Imposed. 
(a)  A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the village in the business of renting, leasing or letting rooms in a hotel on the gross rental receipts from such renting, leasing or letting, excluding, however, from gross rental receipts, the proceeds of such renting, leasing or letting to permanent residents of that hotel. The tax shall be at the rate of five (5) percent of the gross rental receipts. 
(b)  Persons subject to the tax hereby imposed may reimburse themselves for their tax liability for such tax by separately stating such tax as an additional charge, which charge may be stated in combination, in a single amount, with the state tax imposed under "The Hotel Operators' Occupation Tax Act" as provided in Chapter 120, paragraph 481b.31 et seq. of the Illinois Revised Statutes. 
(c)  The tax herein levied and imposed shall be paid in addition to any and all other taxes and charges. It shall be the duty of the hotel operator to pay the amount of the tax to the Village of Roselle under procedures prescribed by the director of finance or as otherwise provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 1514-86,  1, 12-22-86; Ord. No. 2429-94,  2, 10-24-94) 
Sec. 20-97. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this tax, the following definitions shall apply: 
(1)  Hotel means any building or buildings in which the public may, for a consideration, obtain living quarters, sleeping or housekeeping accommodations. The term includes inns, motels, tourist homes or courts, lodging houses, rooming houses and apartment houses. 
(2)  Operator means any person operating a hotel. 
(3)  Room or rooms means any living quarters, sleeping or housekeeping accommodations. 
(4)  Permanent resident means any person who occupied or has the right to occupy any room or rooms in a hotel for at least thirty (30) consecutive days. 
(5)  Rent or rental means the consideration received for occupancy, valued in money, whether received in money or otherwise, including all receipts, cash credits and property or services of any kind or nature. 
(6)  Person means any natural individual, firm, partnership, association, joint stock company, joint adventure, public or private corporation, or a receiver, executor, trustee, guardian or other representative appointed by order of any court. 
(Ord. No. 1514-86,  1, 12-22-86; Ord. No. 2429-94,  2, 10-24-94) 
Sec. 20-98. - Records. 
    Every operator shall keep records of every occupancy and of all rent paid, charged or due thereon and of the tax payable thereon in such form as may be required by regulation prescribed by the director of finance or as otherwise provided in this article. Such records shall be available for inspection and examination for any proper purpose at any reasonable time upon demand by the director of finance or a duly authorized agent or employee of the village and shall be preserved for a period of three (3) years unless the director of finance shall prescribe a shorter period of time. 
(Ord. No. 1514-86,  1, 12-22-86; Ord. No. 2429-94,  2, 10-24-94) 
Sec. 20-99. - Tax return; payment of tax. 
(a)  Every operator shall file monthly with the director of finance a return of occupancy and of rents and of the taxes payable thereon on forms prescribed by the director of finance and consistent with returns required under "The Hotel Operators' Occupation Tax Act" found in Chapter 120, paragraph 481b.31 et seq. The return shall be due on or before the last day of each calendar month for the preceding calendar month. A separate return shall be filed for each place of business within the village regardless of ownership. Each return shall state: 
(1)  Name. 
(2)  Principal place of business. 
(3)  Gross receipts during the prior month upon the basis of which the tax is imposed. 
(4)  Amount of tax. 
(5)  Such other reasonable and related information as the director of finance may require. 
(b)  Each person making the return shall, at the time of making such return, pay to the village treasurer, the amount of tax herein imposed. 
(Ord. No. 1514-86,  1, 12-22-86; Ord. No. 2429-94,  2, 10-24-94) 
Sec. 20-100. - Use of tax proceeds. 
    The proceeds from the tax collected pursuant to this article shall be used solely to promote tourism and conventions in the village or otherwise to attract nonresident overnight visitors to the village, unless otherwise permitted by state law. No such funds shall be used to advertise for or otherwise promote new competition in the hotel business. 
(Ord. No. 1514-86,  1, 12-22-86; Ord. No. 2429-94,  2, 10-24-94) 
Sec. 20-101. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who shall be convicted of violating any provision of this article shall be fined in accordance with section 1-8 of this Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 1514-86,  1, 12-22-86; Ord. No. 2429-94,  2, 10-24-94) 
Secs. 20-102-20-107. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - AMUSEMENT TAX[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 2003-2969, ㎣ 1-6, adopted January 13, 2002, amended article VIII in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, article VIII, ㎣ 20-108-20-115 pertained to similar provisions and derived from Ord. No. 2002-2960, ㎣ 1-5, 12-9-02. 

Sec. 20-108. - Definitions. 
    [As used in this article, the following words or phrases shall mean:] 
    Amusement as used in this article shall mean any theatrical, dramatic or musical performance, circus, rodeo, animal act, athletic contest, sport or similar exhibition or activity in which an attendee participates, and includes, without being limited thereto, animal and flower shows, skating, dancing, swimming or other water activity, racing or riding on animals or vehicles or other devices or equipment, baseball, basketball, softball, football, tennis, golf, hockey, track and field games, bowling, billiard and pool games, motion picture film projection, the leasing or rental of video and audio recordings and game cartridges, and any other activity, exhibition, performance, participation and entertainment sold, leased, rented not herein named, shown, exhibited, staged or conducted, within the corporate limits of the village and for which an admission fee or other charge to the spectators or participants is made. 
    Game cartridge shall mean any device intended or designed to interface with and provide supplemental data, computational capability or the like to equipment intended for use as or designed for video and audio amusement. 
    Gross receipts shall mean the consideration received for which an admission fee, rental or leasing fee, or activity fee valued in money, whether received in money or otherwise, including cash, credits, services and property of every kind and nature, and shall be determined without any deductions. 
    Person shall mean any person, trustee, receiver, administrator, executor, conservator, assignee, trust in perpetuity, trust, estate, firm, copartnership, joint venture, club, company, business trust, domestic or foreign corporation, association, syndicate, society, or any group of individuals acting as a unit, whether mutual, cooperative, fraternal, nonprofit, or otherwise. Whenever the term "person" is used in any clause prescribing and imposing a penalty, the term as applied to associations shall mean the owners or part-owners thereof, and as applied to corporations, the officers thereof. 
    Taxpayer shall mean a person engaged in business within the corporate limits of the village. 
    Video and audio recordings shall mean a physical medium, whether in the form of magnetic tape, laser readable disk or other recording formats, on which video, audio or video and audio images or signals are captured, for the purpose of the regeneration of same by the person leasing or renting such medium. Included within this category by way of illustration and not limitation are what are commonly referred to as "videocassettes", "laserdisks", "CD's", "CD ROM", "DVD's" and "MP3's", capable of video and/or audio reproduction. 
(Ord. No. 2003-2969,  1, 1-13-03) 
Sec. 20-109. - Tax imposed. 
    There is hereby levied and imposed a tax upon an amusement shown, exhibited, staged, conducted, rented or leased within the corporate limits of the Village of Roselle, equal to three (3) percent of the fee or other consideration received for the amusement. The tax levied by this section shall be collected from the person paying such tax at the time such amusement fees are collected, said person hereinafter being referred to as the "consumer." 
    The ultimate incidence of and liability for payment of said tax shall be borne by the consumer who seeks participation, admission or use of any amusement. It shall be the duty of every person receiving any consideration or charge upon an amusement, for which a tax is levied under this section, to secure said tax from the consumer, to act as trustee for and on account of the village, and to pay over to the village treasurer said tax under procedures prescribed by the village treasurer or as otherwise provided in this section. The person paying the tax to the village treasurer shall be referred to in this article VIII as the "taxpayer." 
(Ord. No. 2003-2969,  2, 1-13-03; Ord. No. 2010-3525,  1, 6-28-10) 
Sec. 20-110. - Exemptions. 
    The tax described in section 20-109 above shall not be applicable to any amusement shown, exhibited or staged by: 
(1)  A not-for-profit organization which is exempt from taxation pursuant to Section 501 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended; 
(2)  Any school district; or, 
(3)  Any government entity defined as such by Illinois Statute. 
(Ord. No. 2003-2969,  3, 1-13-03) 
Sec. 20-111. - Administration and enforcement. 
(a)  The village treasurer is hereby designated as the administrative and enforcement officer of the tax hereby imposed on behalf of the village. It shall be the responsibility and duty of the treasurer to collect all amounts due the village from the taxpayer. A sworn monthly amusement tax return, on a calendar month basis, shall be filed by each taxpayer with the treasurer, on forms prescribed by him, showing all receipts from the preceding month. Said returns shall be filed within twenty (20) days after the end of the month covered by said return, with the tax herein imposed due and owing as of the twentieth (20th) day of the month following the month covered by said return. 
(b)  Each return shall be accompanied by payment to the village of all taxes due and owing for the month covered by the return. 
(c)  During the normal business hours of any such taxpayer, the treasurer or any person certified by him as his deputy or representative may enter the premises of the taxpayer, upon reasonable notice, for the purpose of inspecting and examining the taxpayer's books and records for the proper administration of this article, and for the enforcement of the collection of the tax hereby imposed. It is unlawful for any person to prevent, hinder or interfere with the treasurer or his duly authorized deputy or representative in the discharge of his duties hereunder. It shall be the duty of every taxpayer to keep accurate and complete books and records and to keep same at the taxpayer's principle place of business within the village, containing all information necessary for the collection of the tax hereby imposed, to which the treasurer or his duly authorized deputy or representative shall at all times have full access, which records shall include a daily sheet showing: 
(1)  All tickets, admissions, and records showing rental/leasing sold during the immediately preceding day and the then current day; and 
(2)  The receipts collected for the dates in question. In the event that the inspection and examination by the treasurer discloses a discrepancy in excess of five (5) percent from the information furnished by the taxpayer, the cost of said inspection and examination shall be borne by said taxpayer. 
(Ord. No. 2003-2969,  4, 1-13-03) 
Sec. 20-112. - Enforcement; suit for collection; revocation of license. 
    Whenever any taxpayer shall fail to pay any taxes herein provided, the village attorney shall, upon request of the village president or the village administrator, bring or cause to be brought an action to enforce the payment of said tax on behalf of the village in any court of competent jurisdiction. If the village president, after a hearing held by or for him, shall find that any taxpayer has willfully evaded his responsibility to pay the tax imposed by this article, he may suspend or revoke all village licenses, including but not limited to any liquor license issued under the Municipal Code, held by such person. Hearings to suspend or revoke a village license shall be held as provided in village ordinances creating and administering such licenses or as may be established by the corporate authorities from time to time. Any suspension or conviction resulting from such hearing shall not relieve or discharge any civil liability for non-payment of the tax due. 
(Ord. No. 2003-2969,  5, 1-13-03) 
Sec. 20-113. - Interest and penalties. 
(a)  In the event of a failure by any taxpayer to pay to the village treasurer the tax required hereunder within ten (10) days after the same shall be due, interest shall accumulate and be due upon said tax at the rate of one (1) percent per month commencing as of the first day of the month following the month for which the tax was to have been collected. In addition, a penalty of ten (10) percent of the tax and interest due shall be assessed and collected against any taxpayer who shall fail to pay the tax imposed by this section. 
(b)  In addition to the provision of this section, any taxpayer found guilty in a court of competent jurisdiction of violating, disobeying, omitting, neglecting or refusing to comply with or resisting or opposing the enforcement of any provision of this article, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for the first offense, and not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for the second and each subsequent offense. Each day any violation of any provision of this article shall continue to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2003-2969,  6, 1-13-03) 
Secs. 20-114-20-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - EATING ESTABLISHMENT TAX 

Sec. 20-121. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following words or phrases shall mean: 
    Gross receipts shall mean the consideration received, valued in money, whether received in money or otherwise, including cash, credits, property and services, at a retail business subject to this article. Gross receipts shall not include amounts paid for federal, state and local taxes, including the tax levied by this article, and shall not include amounts paid as gratuities for the employees of the place for eating. 
    Owner shall mean any person(s) or legal entity having an ownership interest in or conducting the operation of a place for eating. 
    Patron or patrons shall mean any natural individual, firm, partnership, association, joint stock company, joint venture, public or private corporation, limited liability company, club, fraternal organization or a receiver, executor, trustee, conservator, or other representative appointed by order of any court. 
    Places for eating or place for eating shall mean all premises located within the corporate limits of the Village of Roselle where prepared food is sold at retail for immediate consumption, with seating provided for that consumption, whether consumed on premises or not, and whether or not such places for eating use is conducted along with any other use(s) in a common premises or business establishment. Places for eating or place for eating shall include, but is not limited to, those establishments commonly known as restaurants, eating places, drive-in restaurants, buffets, bakeries, banquet facilities, cafeterias, cafs, lunch counters, fast food outlets, catering services, coffee shops, diners, sandwich shops, soda fountains, bars, cocktail lounges, soft drink parlors, ice cream parlors, tea rooms, delicatessens, hotels, motels, wine shops or clubs, or any other establishment which sells at retail prepared food for immediate consumption. Places for eating or place for eating shall not include Illinois Not for Profit Corporations or Religious Corporations in good standing with the Office of the Illinois Secretary of State. 
    Prepared food shall mean and include any solid, liquid (including both alcoholic and non-alcoholic liquid), powder or item used or intended to be used for human internal consumption, whether simple, compound, or mixed, cooked or raw, and which has been prepared for immediate consumption. 
    Sold at retail shall mean to sell for use or consumption in exchange for a consideration, whether in the form of money, credits, barter or any other value, and not for resale, with said transaction being subject to either the Illinois Retailers' Occupation Tax (35 ILCS 120/1 et. seq.) or the Illinois Service Occupation Tax (35 ILCS 115/1 et. seq.). 
    Tax shall mean the tax imposed by this article. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3528,  1, 8-9-10) 
Sec. 20-122. - Tax imposed. 
(a)  There is hereby levied and imposed upon owners of places for eating within the corporate limits of the Village of Roselle a tax at the rate of one and one quarter percent (1.25%) of gross receipts received for prepared food sold at retail by the owner on or after June 1, 2016. 
(b)  The owner of a place for eating may collect an amount from patrons who purchase prepared food at the place for eating which shall reimburse the owner for the tax imposed on the owner by this article. Failure of an owner to collect the tax from patrons purchasing prepared food at the place for eating shall not absolve the owner of the duty to pay the tax. 
(c)  The tax levied shall be paid in addition to any and all other taxes and charges. 
(d)  In the event the prepared food is sold at retail on credit, an owner shall not be liable for payment of the tax imposed on such a sale until payment is received. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3528,  1, 8-9-10; Ord. No. 2015-3815,  1, 12-14-15) 
Sec. 20-123. - Administration and enforcement. 
    The village treasurer is hereby designated as the administrative enforcement officer of the tax hereby imposed. The village treasurer may enter the premises of any place for eating for inspection, examination, copying, and auditing of books and records including, but not limited to, Illinois Retailers' Occupation Tax and Illinois Service Occupation Tax returns filed with the Illinois Department of Revenue, in order to effectuate the proper administration and assure collection of the tax. To the extent reasonably possible, entry shall be done in a manner that is least disruptive to the business of the place for eating. It shall be unlawful for anyone to prevent, hinder, or interfere with the village treasurer in the discharge of their duties in the performance of this article. It shall be the duty of every owner to keep accurate and complete books and records to which the village treasurer shall have full access to at all times and which records shall include a daily sheet showing the amount of gross receipts received during each business day. In the event that the inspection and examination by the village treasurer discloses a discrepancy in excess of five (5) percent from the information furnished by the owner and the tax paid, the cost of said inspection and examination shall be borne by the owner. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3528,  1, 8-9-10) 
Sec. 20-124. - Transmittal of tax revenue by owner; delinquency. 
(a)  The owner or owners of each place for eating shall file a sworn monthly tax return showing the gross receipts received during each calendar month upon forms prescribed by the village treasurer. Said return shall be filed within twenty (20) days after the end of the month covered by said return, with the tax imposed being due and owing as of the twentieth (20 th ) day of the month following the month covered by said return. Notwithstanding the foregoing, in the event that the owner of the place for eating is allowed to file Illinois Retailers' Occupation Tax and Illinois Service Occupation Tax returns with the Illinois Department of Revenue at intervals which are greater than monthly, said owner(s) shall be allowed to file tax returns with the village for the tax at those greater intervals. At the time of the filing of the tax returns, the owner shall pay to the village treasurer all taxes due for the period to which the tax return applies. 
(b)  If for any reason any tax due is not timely paid penalties and interest thereon shall be imposed in accordance with the provisions of section 20-129. 
(c)  Owner(s) filing tax returns pursuant to this section shall, at the time of filing such return, pay to the village the amount of the tax less a commission of one (1) percent of the amount of the tax, which is allowed to reimburse the owner for the expenses incurred in keeping records, billing, preparing and filing returns, remitting the tax, and supplying data to the village upon request. No commission may be claimed by an owner for taxes not timely remitted to the village. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3528,  1, 8-9-10) 
Sec. 20-125. - Transmittal of excess tax collections. 
    If any owner collects an amount upon a sale not subject to the tax imposed, but which amount is purported to be the collection of said tax, or if an owner collects an amount upon a sale greater than the amount of the tax imposed and does not for any reason return the same to the purchaser who paid the same before filing the return for the period in which such occurred, said owner shall account for and pay over those amounts to the village along with the tax properly collected. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3528,  1, 8-9-10) 
Sec. 20-126. - Registration. 
    Every owner maintaining a place for eating in the Village of Roselle shall register with the finance department on a date no later than September 1, 2010, or within five business days of the date of becoming such an owner where the person becomes an owner after the effective date of this article [August 9, 2010]. A delay in registration shall not absolve an owner of the obligations imposed by this article. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3528,  1, 8-9-10) 
Sec. 20-127. - Collection. 
    Whenever any owner fails to pay the tax, the village attorney shall, upon direction of the corporate authorities of the village, bring or cause to be brought an action to enforce the payment of said tax on behalf of the village in any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3528,  1, 8-9-10) 
Sec 20-128. - Suspension of licenses. 
    If the village president, after holding a hearing, finds that an owner has willfully failed to pay any tax imposed by this article, that person's village licenses, including, but not limited to, any liquor license issued under the Municipal Code, may be suspended or revoked. Hearings to suspend or revoke a village license shall be held after notice to the owner. The owner shall have the opportunity to present evidence in defense of the allegations. The only defenses to any allegation of a failure to pay a tax shall be that the tax was paid or, where there is an issue of willfulness, that the violation was not willful. The rules of evidence shall not apply in the hearing. Any suspension or revocation of any license(s) shall not absolve or discharge the owner from liability for the payment of the tax or from prosecution for such offense. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3528,  1, 8-9-10) 
Sec. 20-129. - Interest and penalties. 
(a)  In the event of a failure by any owner to pay the village treasurer the tax within ten (10) days after it is due, interest shall be imposed and due upon said tax at a rate of one (1) percent per month commencing as of the first day of the month following the month for which tax was to have been paid to the village. In addition, a penalty of ten (10) percent of the tax and interest due shall be assessed and collected against any owner who fails to pay the tax. 
(b)  Any owner found guilty of violating, disobeying, omitting, neglecting, or refusing to comply with or unlawfully resisting or opposing the enforcement of any of the provisions of this article, upon conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for the first offense, and not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for the second and each subsequent offense in any one-hundred-eighty-day period. Each day that any violation of this article exists, shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. Any owner subjected to the penalties provided for by this section 20-129 shall not be discharged or released from the payment of any tax due. These fines may be imposed in addition to the suspension or revocation of licenses as set forth in section 20-128. 
(Ord. No. 2010-3528,  1, 8-9-10) 
Chapter 21 - TREES, SHRUBS AND WEEDS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Village forester,  2-175 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 537-75,  1, adopted April 7, 1975, specifically amended the Code by repealing former ㎣ 21-1-21-8 which contained general provisions relative to trees, shrubs and weeds. Said sections had been derived from Code 1956, ㎣ 159-166. Sec. 2 of Ord. No. 537-75 adopted new ㎣ 21-1-21-7 as herein set out. In several of the new sections, the "Arboricultural Specifications and Standards of Practice" is referred to, although such specifications and standards were not set out in Ord. No. 537-75. It is presumed that copies of said publication are available for public inspection and on file in the office of the village clerk. 

Sec. 21-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words use in the present tense include the future, words in the plural include the singular and words in the singular number include the plural number. The word "shall" is mandatory and not merely directory. 
(1)  Village. The Village of Roselle, Illinois. 
(2)  Trustees. The President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Roselle, Illinois. 
(3)  Forester. The Village Forester of the Village of Roselle, Illinois. 
(4)  Person. Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
(5)  Trees and shrubs. All woody vegetation except where otherwise indicated. 
(6)  Street or highway. The entire width between property lines of every way or place of whatever nature with in the village when any part thereof is open to the use of the public, as a matter of right, for the purpose of vehicular traffic. 
(7)  Parking. That part of the street or avenue or highway in the village not covered by sidewalk and lying between the lot line and the curbline; or, on unpaved streets, that portion of the street, avenue or highway lying between the lot line and that portion of the street usually traveled by vehicular traffic. 
(8)  Property owner. A person owning private property in Roselle, Illinois. 
(9)  Public property. Any and all property located within the confines of the village and owned by the village or held in the name of the village by any of the departments, commissions or agencies within the village government. 
(Ord. No. 537-75,  2, 4-7-75) 
Sec. 21-2. - Authority and duties of village forester and superintendent of public works. 
(a)  Authority. The superintendent of public works shall have authority to regulate the planting, maintenance and removal of trees and shrubs on streets and other public property in order to insure public safety and preserve the symmetry of public places. He shall promote public information on tree planting, maintenance and removal. 
(b)  Permits. The superintendent of public works shall have authority to issue such permits as are required under this chapter and to affix reasonable conditions to the granting of a permit in accordance with the terms of this chapter. 
(c)  Supervision. The superintendent of public works shall have the authority and it shall be his duty to supervise or inspect all work done under a permit issued in accordance with the terms of this chapter. 
(d)  Master street tree plan. The forester shall have the authority and it shall be his duty to prepare a plan for the location, size and variety of trees and shrubs on streets and public property. Upon approval by the president and board of trustees, this shall be known as the master tree plan to be followed in future planting and removal of trees and shrubs on streets and public property. 
(Ord. No. 537-75,  2, 4-7-75) 
Cross reference- Superintendent of public works,  2-135 et seq. 
Sec. 21-3. - Disturbance of trees and shrubs on public property; permits required. 
(a)  Maintenance or removal. No person, except the village or a person hired by the village, shall treat, trim, remove or otherwise disturb any tree or shrub on any street or other public property without first filing an application and procuring a permit to do so from the superintendent of public works. 
(1)  Application data. The application required herein shall be signed by the abutting property owner or his authorized agent, except as set forth in subsection (e) of this section; shall be submitted to the superintendent of public works, and shall state the location, number, size and species of trees or shrubs to be treated, trimmed, removed or otherwise disturbed; the reason therefor; the methods to be used; and such other information as the superintendent of public works shall find reasonably necessary to fairly determine whether a permit should be issued. 
(2)  Standards of issuance. The superintendent of public works shall issue the permit provided for herein if the proposed work is desirable and is in keeping with the master tree plan and if the methods and workmanship proposed comply with the Arboricultural Specifications and Standards of Practice as set out in this Ordinance No. 537-75. [See editor's note at beginning of Article I.} The person receiving the permit and any tree surgeon, forester, arborist or workman performing thereunder shall strictly abide by said specifications and standards unless an exception or exceptions thereto are set forth in writing on the permit. Any permit granted shall contain a definite date of expiration and it may be declared terminated if its terms are violated. 
(b)  Planting. No person shall plant or set out any tree or shrub in any street or public place of the village without first filing an application and procuring a permit from the superintendent of public works. 
(1)  Application data. The application required herein shall be signed by the abutting property owner or his authorized agent; shall be submitted to the superintendent of public works, and shall state the number of trees or shrubs to be set out; the location, grade, size and species of each tree or shrub; the method of planting; and such other information as the superintendent of public works shall find reasonably necessary to fairly determine whether a permit should be issued. 
(2)  Standards of issuance. The superintendent of public works shall issue the permit provided for herein if the proposed planting is desirable; if it conforms with the master tree plan as to species, size and location; and if the planting complies with the Arboricultural Specifications and Standards of Practice set out in this Ordinance No. 537-75. The person receiving the permit and any tree surgeon, forester, arborist or workman performing thereunder shall strictly abide by said specifications and standards unless an exception or exceptions thereto are set forth in writing on the permit. Any permit granted shall contain a definite expiration date and it shall be declared void if its terms are violated. 
(3)  Improper planting. Whenever any tree shall be planted in conflict with the provisions of this subsection, it shall be lawful for the superintendent of public works to require its removal, or to remove it himself. 
(c)  Excavation and construction. No person other than the village or a person hired by the village shall excavate any ditches, tunnels or trenches, or lay any drive within a radius of ten (10) feet from any public tree or shrub without first obtaining a written permit from the superintendent of public works. Trees, shrubs or plants near any excavation or construction of any building or structure shall be adequately protected and all building material, dirt or other debris shall be kept at least three (3) feet from such trees, shrubs or plants. 
(d)  Storage. No person shall deposit, place, store or maintain upon any street or other public property any stone, brick, sand, concrete or other material which may impede the free passage of water, air and fertilizer to the roots of any trees or shrubs growing therein, except by written permit of the forester. 
(e)  Public utility installation. All permits issued for the installation of public utilities that affect public trees or shrubs shall be approved by the superintendent of public works. A public utility may be issued a permit to treat, trim or remove any tree or shrub on any street or other public place. Said work shall be limited to the actual necessities of the service of the company and such work shall be done in accordance with the Arboricultural Specifications and Standards of Practice as set out in this Ordinance No. 537-75. The superintendent of public works may, if necessary in his estimation, assign an inspector to supervise the provisions of the permit, and the cost of such service shall be charged to the public utility. 
(Ord. No. 537-75,  2, 4-7-75) 
Cross reference- Excavations generally,  18-31 et seq. 
Sec. 21-4. - Felling of trees on streets. 
    The superintendent of public works or his authorized agent shall be notified prior to the time that any tree or shrub is to be trimmed, if said tree or shrub or any portion thereof will fall on a street, sidewalk or alley. 
(1)  Public property. If said tree or shrub is located on public property, the required notification shall be given on the original application to trim or remove. 
(2)  Private property. If said tree or shrub is located on private property, the property owner or his authorized agent must apply for a special permit to trim or remove. The superintendent of public works shall issue said permit provided that the trimming or removing will be done according to the specifications and standards of this chapter, and the requirements of this section. 
(3)  Safety requirements. 
a.  The person to whom the permit is issued shall be responsible for placing such signs, flags, flares and barricades as are needed to warn persons of the danger of using the street, sidewalk or alley. 
b.  No tree shall be felled onto any street without having persons stationed in the streets to stop traffic from both directions at the time the tree is being dropped, unless the street has been duly barricaded in accordance with village laws. 
c.  Trees or branches which are felled or trimmed on public property must be removed immediately unless an extension of time is granted by the superintendent of public works in writing. 
(4)  Insurance. Before any tree or branch is felled onto public property, the applicant must deposit with the clerk a certificate of liability insurance in the amount of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) per person, one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) per accident for bodily injury liability and ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) per person, and twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) aggregate for property damage liability. 
(Ord. No. 537-75,  2, 4-7-75) 
Sec 21-5. - Abuse or mutilation of trees on public property. 
    No person shall wilfully damage, cut, carve, transplant or remove a tree or shrub on public property, attach any rope, wire, nails or other contrivance to any such tree; cause or permit any wire charged with electricity to come in contact with such tree or shrub unless protected by approved methods; attach any electrical insulation to any public tree or shrub; allow any gaseous, liquid or solid substance which is harmful to said trees or shrubs to come in contact with them; or set fire or permit any fire to burn when such fire or heat thereof will injure any portion of any public tree or shrub, without first obtaining a written permit to do so from the superintendent of public works. 
(Ord. No. 537-75,  2, 4-7-75) 
Sec 21-6. - Tree spurs or climbers. 
    No person shall use tree spurs or climbers on trees located on streets or public property except by specific written permission of the superintendent of public works. 
(Ord. No. 537-75,  2, 4-7-75) 
Sec. 21-7. - Obstruction; trees trimmed. 
    Trees or shrubs on public or private property bordering on any street shall be trimmed to sufficient height to allow free usage of pedestrians and vehicular travel, and so they will not obstruct or shade the street lights, the vision of traffic signs, or the view of any street intersection. The minimum clearance of any overhanging portions of such trees or shrubs shall be nine (9) feet over all sidewalks and thirteen (13) feet over all streets. 
(1)  Notice to trim. When the superintendent of public works shall find it necessary to order obstructing trees or shrubs on private or public property to be trimmed, he shall cause notice to be served on the persons responsible requiring such tree or shrubs to be trimmed to the minimum height set out above within thirty (30) days after the receipt of the said notice. The notice required herein shall be served by mailing a copy of said notice to the last known address of the property owner or person responsible by certified mail. If the superintendent of public works is unable to secure notice on the property owner, or the person responsible, said notice may be served on the occupant or person in charge of the property in the same manner, as set out herein. 
(2)  Failure to comply. When a person to whom such notice is directed shall fail to comply within the specified time, the superintendent of public works shall cause to be trimmed such trees or shrubs, and the exact cost of such work shall be certified by the village clerk to the county treasurer of DuPage County and of Cook County, to be collected with and in the same manner as general property taxes. 
(Ord. No. 537-75,  2, 4-7-75) 
Secs. 21-8-21-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WEEDS 

Sec. 21-19. - Nuisance declared. 
    Any such weeds as jimson, burdock, ragweed, thistle, cockleburr, or other weeds of a like kind, found growing in any lot or tract of land in the village are hereby declared to be a nuisance, and it shall be unlawful to permit any such weeds to grow or remain in any such place. 
(Code 1956,  648) 
Cross reference- Nuisances generally, Ch. 12. 
Sec. 21-20. - Height. 
    It shall be unlawful for anyone to permit weeds, grass, or plants, other than trees, bushes, vegetables, flowers or other ornamental plants to grow to a height exceeding eight (8) inches within one hundred (100) feet of any developed lot or tract of land anywhere in the village. Developed lot or tract shall mean any land with building, park or street. 
(Code 1956,  649; Ord. No. 1018-81,  1, 5-11-81) 
Sec. 21-21. - Barberry prohibited. 
    It shall be a nuisance and unlawful to plant or permit the growth of the bush of the species of tall, common or European barberry further known as Barberis vulgaris, or its horticultural varieties, within the village. 
(Code 1956,  650) 
Sec. 21-22. - Removal; notice. 
(a)  All lots or tracts of land in the village must be mowed or trimmed as necessary to prevent weeds, grass, and other plants from exceeding eight (8) inches in height in accordance with section 21-20 of this Code. Any lot or tract of land on which construction or development is taking place shall be maintained in such a condition that proper mowing or trimming may be done so as to maintain the property in accordance with the provision of this article. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the director of public works to serve or cause to be served a notice upon the owner of any such premises on which weeds, grass, or other plants are permitted to grow in violation of the provisions of this article and to demand the abatement of the nuisance within seven (7) days. If any such notice is served by mail, it shall be sent by registered mail with a return receipt requested. 
(Code 1956,  651; Ord. No. 231-68,  1, 5-6-68; Ord. No. 1018-81,  1, 5-11-81) 
Sec. 21-23. - Abatement by village. 
    If the person so served does not abate the nuisance within seven (7) days after such notice, the director of public works may proceed to abate such nuisance, keeping an account of the expense thereof, and such expense, including an administrative fee of ten (10) percent of the cost of abating the nuisance but not less than five dollars ($5.00), shall be charged to and paid by the owner. 
(Code 1956,  632; Ord. No. 231-68,  1, 5-6-68; Ord. No. 1018-81,  1, 5-11-81) 
Sec. 21-24. - Lien. 
    Charges for weed cutting or removal shall be a lien upon the premises as provided by statute. 
(Code 1956,  653; Ord. No. 231-68,  1, 5-6-68; Ord. No. 1018-81,  1, 5-11-81) 
Sec. 21-25. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall be fined in accordance with section 1-8 of this Code. Each day any violation of any provision of this article shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. Whenever a bill for such charges remains unpaid for sixty (60) days, the village clerk shall file a lien claim as provided by statute. 
(Ord. No. 1018-81,  2, 5-11-81) 
Secs. 21-26-21-34. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - INFECTED TREES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2011-3561,  1, adopted January 24, 2011, repealed the former Art. III, ㎣ 21-35-21-42, and enacted a new Art. III as set out herein. The former Art. III pertained to Dutch Elm Disease and derived from Ord. No. 60-59, ㎣ 1-8, 2-8-60. 
Cross reference- Nuisances generally, Ch. 12. 

Sec. 21-35. - Enforcement of article. 
    The village forester is charged with enforcement of this article and to that end may enter upon private property at all reasonable times for purposes of inspecting trees, and may remove specimens as are required for purposes of analysis to determine whether or not the same are infected. It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent the village forester or his representative from entering on private property for purposes of carrying out his duties hereunder, or to interfere with such village forester or his representative in the lawful performance of his duties under the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2011-3561,  1, 1-24-11) 
Sec. 21-36. - Infected trees declared nuisances. 
    Trees within the Village of Roselle of all species and varieties of: 
(a)  Elm (Ulmus) and Zelkova affected with the fungus Ceratostomella ulmi , are hereby declared to be public nuisances and shall be removed and properly disposed of within fourteen (14) days following notification of the discovery of such infection; and 
(b)  Ash ( Fraxinus ) affected with the insect Emerald Ash Borer ( Agrilus planipennis ) are hereby declared to be public nuisances and shall be removed and chipped, or chemically treated by a certified arborist within fourteen (14) days following notification of the discovery of such infestation; and 
(c)  Any tree affected by a disease, fungus or insect identified by the Illinois Department of Agriculture as constituting an epidemical threat to trees or a species of tree are hereby declared to be a public nuisance and shall be removed, chipped, treated, or otherwise properly disposed of as directed by the village forester, within fourteen (14) days following notification of the discovery of such infection or infestation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person being the owner of property upon which such tree is situated to possess or keep such a tree, or parts of such a tree, after the expiration of fourteen (14) days following the notification of the discovery of said infestation unless the village forester has approved treatment and proof of the treatment has been submitted to the village forester as he directs. 
(Ord. No. 2011-3561,  1, 1-24-11) 
Sec. 21-37. - Notice, abatement required. 
    The village forester or his representative shall give to the owner of the premises where any public nuisance described in this article is found, a written notice of existence of such nuisance, and requiring the removal, chipping or treatment as the case may be of same within fourteen (14) days following such notice, such removal and destruction to be done under the direction and supervision of the village forester or his representative. Treatment by a certified arborist shall be approved by the village forester and proof of the treatment shall be submitted to the village forester as he directs. The notice shall also notify the owner of said premises that unless such nuisance is removed, destroyed or treated in compliance with the terms of the notice within such fourteen-day period, the village will proceed with the removal and destruction of such nuisance, and assess the cost thereof against the said property owner. In the alternative the village in its sole discretion may treat the nuisance and assess the costs of treatment against the property owner 
(Ord. No. 2011-3561,  1, 1-24-11) 
Sec. 21-38. - Manner of giving notice. 
    Service of such notice shall be by personal service where the owner of said premises is a resident of the village. Where the owner is a nonresident of the village, said notice shall be sent by certified mail and regular mail, addressed to said owner at his last known address. 
(Ord. No. 2011-3561,  1, 1-24-11) 
Sec. 21-39. - Manner of abatement. 
    Upon the service of notice, by certified mail or regular mail, it shall become the duty of the owner of the premises to cause such tree or breeding place to be removed and destroyed or treated, under the direction and supervision of the village forester or his representative. In lieu thereof, the person charged with such removal and destruction may request that the same be done by the village forester or his representative. If the village removes and destroys any tree, all expenses incurred in connection therewith shall be assessed against the property owner. 
(Ord. No. 2011-3561,  1, 1-24-11) 
Sec. 21-40. - Removal of trees on village property. 
    Trees on village-owned property shall be removed at the expense of the village. 
(Ord. No. 2011-3561,  1, 1-24-11) 
Sec. 21-41. - Effect of penalty on recovery of costs. 
    Imposition of any penalty for a violation of this article shall not be construed as a waiver of the right of the village to collect the costs of removal of such nuisances in accordance with the provisions of this article where it is necessary for the village to remove such nuisances in accordance with provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2011-3561,  1, 1-24-11) 
Chapter 22 - WATER AND SEWERS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Board of local improvements,  2-5; superintendent of public works generally,  2-135 et seq.; supervision of sewers generally,  2-137; supervision of water system,  2-139; sewer connections to service station washing and greasing rooms,  9-327; water supply for trailer parks,  9-523; sewer connection for trailer parks,  9-525; offensive deposits in sewers,  12-6. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Systems combined. 
    The waterworks system of the village and the sanitary sewerage system shall be owned and operated by this village as a combined utility, known as the combined waterworks and sewerage system of the village. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  1, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-1.1. - Procedures for administration of sewer permit ordinance-Manual adopted. 
    That certain document, at least three (3) copies of which are and have been on file in the office of the village clerk of the Village of Roselle for a period of fifteen (15) days prior to the date of the adoption of this section, the said document being marked and designated as the Manual of Procedures for Administration of the Sewer Permit Ordinance (Revised May 27, 1970) and adopted by the trustees of the Metropolitan Sanitary District of Greater Chicago on September 3, 1970, be and the same is hereby adopted as an integral part of the procedures of administration of the Village of Roselle, Illinois, and each and all of the regulations, provisions, conditions and terms of the said Manual of Procedures for the Administration of the Sewer Permit Ordinance of the Metropolitan Sanitary District of Greater Chicago are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this section; provided, however, neither the provisions of this section nor the regulations, provisions, conditions and terms contained in said manual of procedures shall be applicable to any part of the village located or situated in DuPage County, Illinois. 
(Ord. No. 345-71,  1, 5-15,1) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 345-71 did not expressly amend this Code, hence inclusion of  1 as  22-1.1 was at the editor's discretion. "Section" has been inserted in lieu of "ordinance" to maintain format and  2, directory provision, has been omitted. 
Sec. 22-2. - General jurisdiction of department. 
    The waterworks and sewerage department under the direction of the president and board of trustees shall have jurisdiction over supervision, management and control of the maintenance, enlargement and operation of the waterworks and sewerage system subject to the control exercised by the president and board of trustees. All matters and things connected with the operation, maintenance, and extension of the combined waterworks and sewerage system and preserving the property belonging thereto shall be under the jurisdiction of the waterworks and sewerage department. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  2, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-3. - Position of superintendent created; appointment; general duties. 
    There shall be a superintendent of public works for the waterworks and sewerage department to be appointed by the president and board of trustees who shall have supervision over all buildings and equipment used and the furnishing of water and sewerage service in the village and shall see that the objects and purposes of the waterworks and sewerage department are carried out and that the waterworks and sewerage system is conducted on an economical businesslike basis, and for this purpose, it shall be the duty of the superintendent of public works and all of the officers, employees and servants of said department to enforce all of the provisions of this chapter and to observe and obey and carry out the orders and directions of the president and board of trustees. The superintendent of public works shall prepare and keep in his office a complete atlas of the waterworks and sewerage system together with all valves, hydrants, water service connections and other appurtenances distinctly recorded therein. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  3, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-4. - Compensation of personnel. 
    The superintendent of public works and other officers and employees of the waterworks and sewerage department shall receive as compensation for their services, amounts to be fixed by the president and board of trustees from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  4, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-5. - Reports required. 
    The village treasurer shall, not later than the second Monday of each and every month, or oftener if required, submit a report in writing to the president and board of trustees listing therein, but not limited thereto, the following data: 
(1)  Billing for services rendered. 
(2)  Collections. 
(3)  Applications for service approved and fees received. 
(4)  Expenditures and accounts charged. 
(5)  Cash balances at beginning and end of period. 
(6)  Volume of water purchased, billed and unaccounted for. 
(7)  Number of metered and unmetered customers connected to the system at the beginning and at the end of period. 
(8)  Details of any major repairs and extensions to mains or other facts pertinent to his duties in the conduct of his office. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  5, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-6. - Water-only accounts. 
    A customer may avoid the payment of sanitary sewer charges based on water used exclusively for landscape irrigation by underground irrigation system(s) or exclusively in an industrial process system where, in such industrial process application the water is consumed exclusively for evaporative cooling and vented to the atmosphere, only when such customer establishes a water service account separate from the domestic water/sewer service account serving the premises, including the installation of a separate and independent water meter to measure the water used by the underground irrigation system(s) and/or industrial process system. In both instances of landscape irrigation and industrial process systems no water shall be discharged into the village sanitary sewer system. In order to remain qualified water only accounts the irrigation or industrial process system(s) shall be subject to periodic and random inspection by the village. Other than a waiver of the sanitary sewer charges, all other ordinances, sections and subsections of chapter 22 shall be applicable to accounts established under this section. 
(Ord. No. 2009-3476,  1, 10-12-09) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2009-3476,  1, adopted October 12, 2009, repealed the  22-6, and enacted a new  22-6 as set out herein. The former  22-6 pertained to landscape irrigation meters and derived from Ord. No. 2314-93,  1, 4-12-93. 
Sec. 22-7. - Deposit of village funds. 
    The village clerk shall, no later than three (3) working days after receipt thereof, deposit into the properly authorized bank account of the village, all monies collected by him in behalf of the waterworks and sewerage system taking such bank deposit ticket or receipt, in duplicate, therefor, one of which receipts he shall file with the treasurer of the village. The village clerk is expressly prohibited from keeping the monies of the village in his hands or in the hands of any person or corporation to his use beyond the time which is hereby prescribed for the deposit of the same in the proper bank to the credit of the village. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  7, 4-14-69; Ord. No. 734-78,  1, 2-13-78; Ord. No. 844-79,  1, 4-23-79) 
Sec. 22-8. - Reading of meters, collection of bills, issuance of permits. 
    The superintendent of public works, or such officer or employees of the waterworks and sewerage department as he shall direct, shall read water meters, prepare and distribute bills, collect the water and sewer rates, issue water and sewer permits, and shall perform such other duties as now are or may hereafter be imposed upon him by law or the ordinances of the village. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  8, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-9. - Application for connection required; issuance. 
    Any person desiring to make any connection with the combined system or use water therefrom shall first make application to the village clerk upon a blank form or forms furnished by the department. Said application shall contain an agreement on the part of the applicant that all the rules, regulations, conditions and provisions of this Code or of any ordinance relating to the waterworks system or sewerage system will be complied with; that all water rates, sewer rates, assessments and rents, and all fines and penalties assessed, charged or imposed against said applicant upon the property described in said application will be paid. When the applicant hereunder has complied with all of the provisions of this Code and the ordinances of the village, a permit shall then be issued by the village clerk authorizing the connection to be made and specifying the size thereof. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  9-1, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-10. - One service serving multiple premises. 
    No service pipe shall be laid or used to supply water to two (2) or more distinct premises or buildings unless separate curb stops for each of the premises or buildings shall be placed outside of such premises in the parkway as hereinafter provided and a permit fee shall be obtained for each service. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  9-1, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-11. - Turning on water seals. 
(a)  No person not duly authorized shall turn on any service cock, or use water therefrom when so turned on. Any person violating this section shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense, and the person so using or wasting water in such unlawful manner shall be liable to pay therefor at the regular water rates. 
(b)  No seal placed by the department for the protection of any meter, valve, fitting, or other water connection shall be defaced or broken except by a duly authorized employee of the department. 
(c)  No person or persons, other than members of the water department of the village, shall use water from any fire hydrant connected with the village waterworks system, except for extinguishing fires or unless especially authorized in writing by the director of village services, and having said written authorization in hand when using such water. Violators shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense. 
(d)  Lawn care companies shall be allowed to draw water from the village water system from the hydrant at well No. 4 only for a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per truck per year, and must display on the front window of each truck the water usage permit. Violators shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  9-2, 4-14-69; Ord. No. 753-78,  1, 4-24-78) 
Sec. 22-12. - Meters, valves required. 
    All water consumers supplied by the village shall be supplied through meters only except that in cases where it is temporarily impractical to set a meter, the use and consumption of water shall be governed by other applicable provisions of this chapter; in addition thereto there shall be installed with each such meter a Mueller H-14255 meter angle valve, which shall have a flared fitting on the inlet side for copper pipe; the discharge opening is to be three-quarters (3/4) inch in size to fit a five-eighths-inch by three-quarters-inch water meter. 
(Ord. No. 390-72, 6-26-72) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 390-72 amended this Code by repealing ㎣ 22-12 and 22-13 and enacting new provisions pertaining to the same subject matter. Former ㎣ 22-12 and 22-13 were derived from Ord. No. 258-69,  9-3, adopted April 14, 1969. 
Sec. 22-13. - Furnishing, ownership of meters and valves. 
    All meters used in connection with the waterworks system and all meter angle valves used in connection with the waterworks system shall be furnished only by the village and shall be and remain for all time the property of the village. The cost of the meter and the meter angle valve shall be paid by the building owner. 
(Ord. No. 390-72, 6-26-72) 
Note- See editor's note to  22-12. 
Sec. 22-14. - Metering of new buildings. 
    All new buildings shall have installed a two (2) wire of "thermostat type" from the point of where water meter is to be located to the outside of building in close vicinity of the electric meter. Wire on outside of building shall be installed in conduit. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  9-3, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-15. - Tampering with meters; meter valves. 
    After the meter is placed, only officers or employees of the department shall be allowed to repair, remove or in any manner interfere with the same. A meter stop or valve shall be placed on each side of the meter. These valves to be gate valve type, or as specified by the superintendent of public works. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  9-3, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-16. - Liability for meter maintenance. 
    The ordinary cost of keeping each meter in repair shall be paid by the village. The person upon whose application any meter is installed or the then owner or occupant of the premises served shall be jointly and severally liable for any breakage or damage done to such meter, including damage by freezing, hot water or breakage and also for the theft thereof and the cost of making good such loss or damage shall be paid by the owner or the occupant of the premises in which such meter was installed as soon as the bill for same is presented and the amount therefore shall be a lien against the premises for which said meter was installed to the extent and with the same effect as water rates. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  9-3, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-17. - Damaging, defacing meters; notice of defective meters. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to injure, deface, mar, destroy or in any manner to interfere with any meter. It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant to promptly notify the department of defects in any meter or of its failure to properly register the quantity of water passing through the same. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  9-3, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-18. - Determination of type of meters. 
    The president and board of trustees shall in all cases determine the kind and pattern of water meters to be installed, and no other kind shall be installed at any time. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  9-3, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-19. - Meter location. 
    Water meters shall be located at such places and in such manner as the superintendent of public works shall direct, within the premises to be served, and all such installations shall be made in accordance with the specifications to be prescribed by the superintendent of public works and such meter locations must be so situated as to prevent freezing of water flowing through such meters. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  9-3, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-20. - Right of access of village personnel. 
    The superintendent of public works, and every person authorized by him, and all meter inspectors shall have ready access to the premises, place or buildings where such meters are located for the purpose of reading, examining, testing and requiring the same, and examining and testing the consumption, use and flow of water, and it shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with, prevent or obstruct the superintendent of public works or such other person or inspector in his work hereunder. Every consumer of water shall take the same upon the conditions prescribed in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  9-4, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-21. - Rates generally. 
    All consumers, users or properties in the Village of Roselle and outside the corporate limits shall pay such rates for the use and service of the waterworks and sewerage system in such manners and amounts as have heretofore been and may hereafter be prescribed by ordinance by the board of trustees from time to time, and this Code shall not be construed to repeal any such ordinance. For rates based upon metered water volume, use and service of the waterworks and sewage system is defined as the volume of water flowing through the water meter. Leakage, unintentional use, misuse or unauthorized use of water by or through the consumer's plumbing system is the responsibility of the consumer and is subject to use charges based upon metered water volume as prescribed by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  9-5, 4-14-69; Ord. No. 2516-96,  1, 5-28-96) 
Sec. 22-22. - Combined waterworks and sewerage system rates and charges. 
    Effective for bills issued on or after May 1, 2016, rates and charges for the use of and for the services supplied by the combined waterworks and sewerage system of the Village of Roselle, DuPage and Cook Counties, Illinois, based upon the amount of water consumed as shown by the water meter, shall be as follows: 
(1)  Within the corporate limits of the village: 
a.  Water rates for each residential, apartment, commercial, or industrial user of the combined system within the corporate limits shall be: seven dollars and forty-five cents ($7.45) per one thousand (1,000) gallons, per monthly billing period. The minimum monthly charge for water service only shall be seven dollars and forty-five cents ($7.45) per monthly billing period. Effective for bills issued on or after January 1, 2017, water rates for each residential, apartment, commercial, or industrial user of the combined system within the corporate limits shall be: seven dollars and eighty cents ($7.80) per one thousand (1,000) gallons, per monthly billing period. The minimum monthly charge for water service only shall be seven dollars and eighty cents ($7.80) per monthly billing period. Effective for bills issued on or after January 1, 2018, water rates for each residential, apartment, commercial, or industrial user of the combined system within the corporate limits shall be: eight dollars and five cents ($8.05) per one thousand (1,000) gallons, per monthly billing period. The minimum monthly charge for water service only shall be eight dollars and five cents ($8.05) per monthly billing period. Effective for bills issued on or after January 1, 2019, water rates for each residential, apartment, commercial, or industrial user of the combined system within the corporate limits shall be: eight dollars and twenty-five cents ($8.25) per one thousand (1,000) gallons, per monthly billing period. The minimum monthly charge for water service only shall be eight dollars and twenty-five cents ($8.25) per monthly billing period. Effective for bills issued on or after January 1, 2020, water rates for each residential, apartment, commercial, or industrial user of the combined system within the corporate limits shall be: eight dollars and forty five cents ($8.45) per thousand (1,000) gallons, per monthly billing period. The minimum monthly charge for water service only shall be eight dollars and forty five cents ($8.45) per monthly billing period. 
b.  The capital improvement surcharge for each residential, apartment, commercial, or industrial user of the combined system within the corporate limits, shall be two dollars and ninety-five cents ($2.95) per one thousand (1,000) gallons, per monthly billing period. The minimum monthly charge for the capital improvement surcharge shall be two dollars and ninety five cents ($2.95) per monthly billing period. Effective for bills issued on or after January 1, 2017 the capital improvement surcharge for each residential, apartment, commercial, or industrial user of the combined system within the corporate limits, shall be three dollars and eighty-five cents ($3.85) per one thousand (1,000) gallons, per monthly billing period. The minimum monthly charge for the capital improvement surcharge shall be three dollars and eighty-five cents ($3.85) per monthly billing period. Effective for bills issued on or after January 1, 2018 the capital improvement surcharge for each residential, apartment, commercial, or industrial user of the combined system within the corporate limits, shall be four dollars and eighty cents ($4.80) per one thousand (1,000) gallons, per monthly billing period. The minimum monthly charge for the capital improvement surcharge shall be four dollars and eighty cents ($4.80) per monthly billing period. Effective for bills issued on or after January 1, 2019 the capital improvement surcharge for each residential, apartment, commercial, or industrial user of the combined system within the corporate limits, shall be five dollars and seventy-five cents ($5.75) per one thousand (1,000) gallons, per monthly billing period. The minimum monthly charge for the capital improvement surcharge shall be five dollars and seventy-five cents ($5.75) per monthly billing period. Effective for bills issued on or after January 1, 2020 the capital improvement surcharge for each residential, apartment, commercial, or industrial user of the combined system within the corporate limits, shall be six dollars and sixty-five cents ($6.65) per one thousand (1,000) gallons, per monthly billing period. The minimum monthly charge for the capital improvement surcharge shall be six dollars and sixty-five cents ( $6.65) per monthly billing period. 
(2)  Outside the corporate limits of the Village; 
a.  Users connected to the Roselle Water System outside the corporate limits of the village shall pay water rates and capital improvement surcharges for such connection and service supplied in a sum equal to one and one-half (1 1/2) times the rates and capital improvement surcharges applicable within the corporate limits of the village. 
b.  Users of the system who have only a sewerage system connection shall pay the rate specified in section 22-143(2) and (3) of this article. 
(Ord. No. 99-62, ㎣ 1-3, 8-6-62; Ord. No. 265-69,  1, 8-4-69; Ord. No. 308-70,  1, 9-14-70; Ord. No. 315-70,  1, 10-12-70; Ord. No. 373-72,  1, 1-3-72; Ord. No. 448-73,  1, 9-24-73; Ord. No. 449-73,  1, 9-24-73; Ord. No. 450-73,  1, 9-24-73; Ord. No. 542-75,  1, 4-7-75; Ord. No. 626-76,  1, 7-12-76; Ord. No. 758-78,  1, 5-22-78; Ord. No. 844-79,  1, 4-23-79; Ord. No. 909-80,  1, 1-7-80; Ord. No. 963-80,  1, 9-22-80; Ord. No. 1029-81,  1, 7-27-81; Ord. No. 1095-82,  1, 6-14-82; Ord. No. 1172-83,  1, 6-27-83; Ord. No. 1246-84,  1, 5-7-84; Ord. No. 1280-84,  1, 10-1-84; Ord. No. 1330-85,  1, 5-28-85; Ord. No. 1438-86,  1, 5-12-86; Ord. No. 1554-87,  1, 4-27-87; Ord. No. 1706-88,  1, 6-13-88; Ord. No. 1792-89,  1, 2-13-89; Ord. No. 2387-94,  1, 4-28-94; Ord. No. 2470-95,  1, 6-19-95; Ord. No. 2515-96,  1, 5-13-96; Ord. No. 2568-97,  1, 3-31-97; Ord. No. 2598-97,  2, 9-22-97; Ord. No. 2604-97,  1, 10-13-97; Ord. No. 2010-3514,  1, 4-26-10; Ord. No. 2010-3560,  1, 12-13-10; Ord. No. 2011-3578,  1, 5-9-11; Ord. No. 2011-3608,  1, 12-12-11; Ord. No. 2012-3658,  1, 12-10-12; Ord. No. 2013-3712,  1, 12-9-13; Ord. Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 2013-3760 states until January 1, 2015 the rates for all sewer and water charges shall be those imposed by Ord. No. 2013-3712. 
Sec. 22-23. - Payment of charges; discount. 
(a)  Bills for water and/or sewer service shall be due and payable upon receipt. Failure to receive a bill shall not be grounds for non-payment. 
(b)  A bill not paid within twenty-one (21) days will be considered delinquent. A penalty of one and one-half (1.5) percent per month shall be applied to each bill that becomes delinquent. In addition, a five-dollar and no cents ($5.00) per month administrative fee shall also be applied to each bill that becomes delinquent. A delinquency notice shall be sent to the customer. The customer shall have ten (10) days after the delinquent notice to settle his account. 
(c)  If a delinquent notice is not paid within (10) days after said notice is sent, a shut-off notice shall be processed and sent. A fifteen dollar ($15.00) fee shall be imposed on each account for each shut off notice. If the delinquent bill is not paid within seven (7) days after the day the shut-off notices were sent, then the customer shall be granted such hearing or hearings as shall be required by law, if any, and water service will thereafter be shut-off immediately without further notice. 
(d)  Any water service shut off for nonpayment of a bill shall not be turned on until all outstanding amounts have been paid. The charge for turning on water service after such shut off shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(e)  A customer whose bill becomes delinquent may make arrangements with the finance officer to pay the bill over a period of time to avoid shut-off procedures. If payment in full is not made prior to the time of issuance of a customer's next regular bill, a penalty of one and one-half (1.5) percent per month shall be applied to the unpaid balance, except that if the finance officer determines that extenuating circumstances resulted in the customer being delinquent, the finance officer may wave the penalty. 
(Ord. No. 475-74,  1, 3-18-74; Ord. No. 1135-83,  1, 1-10-83; Ord. No. 1635-87,  1, 11-23-87; Ord. No. 2598-97,  3, 9-22-97; Ord. No. 2604-97,  2, 10-13-97; Ord. No. 2607-97,  2, 11-10-97; Ord. No. 2003-2972,  1, 1-27-03) 
Sec. 22-24. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2011-3579,  1, adopted May 9, 2011, repealed  22-24, which pertained to filling of swimming pools and decorative fountains and derived from Ord. No. 488-74,  1, 6-17-74; Ord. No. 2168-92,  1, 4-27-92. Section 2 of Ord. No. 2011-3608 states until January 7, 2012, the rates for all sewer and water charges shall be those imposed by Ord. No. 2011-3578. 
Sec. 22-25. - When monthly periods begin, end; billing. 
    The monthly periods need not be concurrent throughout the village, but shall begin and end for areas of the village as the board of trustees shall direct. Where both sewerage and water service are provided to a premises, a single monthly bill shall be rendered therefor, said bill showing the total amount due for said sewerage and water service. 
(Ord. No. 99-62,  4, 8-6-62; Ord. No. 844-79;  1, 4-23-79; Ord. No. 2598-97,  5, 9-22-97)
