Editor's note- Ord. No. 844-79,  1, adopted April 23, 1979, repealed  22-26, which pertained to a required deposit and its refund, and which was derived from Ord. No. 258-69,  9-5, passed April 14, 1969; and Ord. No. 475-74,  1, passed March 18, 1974. 
Sec. 22-27. - Estimating water use. 
    The water used for which rates and methods of measurement are not specifically provided by ordinance shall be estimated by the superintendent of public works or by such officer as may be designated by the president and board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  9-5, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-28. - Purchasing water from sources other than village. 
    No person having his residence or place of business within the territorial limits of the village shall be permitted to buy water from any other municipal corporation or other public utility for such residence or place of business located in the village whenever the waterworks system of the village is adjacent to its property. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  9-6, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-29. - Lien; collection remedies, deposit. 
(a)  The property owner of record shall ultimately be responsible for bills for water and/or sewer service supplied to the property. If a bill for such service becomes delinquent, such delinquency shall constitute a lien upon the real estate and the village clerk shall file a sworn statement showing such delinquency together with an appropriate amount for filing such lien with the recorder of deeds of DuPage and/or Cook County, in the manner provided by statute. The filing of a statement of delinquency shall be deeded notice and demand for payment of the delinquent amounts. 
(b)  In the alternative, the village may, in its discretion, file suit to collect such amounts as are delinquent and due against the property owner or the real estate in a civil action and shall collect as well all attorney fees incurred by the village in such suit, the same to be fixed by order of the court. 
(c)  If a village water and/or sewer customer becomes delinquent for charges more than once during a one-year period, or has his water shut off due to nonpayment of his bill, such customer shall deposit fifty dollars ($50.00) with the village to retain his water service. Said deposit, less any outstanding amounts due, shall be refunded when a customer cancels his service or will be refunded upon request provided the customer does not have a delinquent bill for a period of two (2) years. 
(d)  If a check for water and sewer bills is returned due to insufficient funds, a charge of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be added to the outstanding amount due. If a customer's check is returned more than once, then his bill shall have to be paid in cash, money order or certified check from a financial institution. 
(e)  When water is shut off temporarily at the request of any customer and the meter is not removed, the customer shall pay the regular minimum rate per billing period. 
(f)  No person owing water and/or sewer charges and moving to other premises, where there are water connections to the village water system or where connections shall afterwards be made, shall be supplied with water until such charges in arrears are paid in full. 
(g)  Any person or party who shall vacate any premises, or any person or party who shall enter upon and occupy any premises, shall immediately before vacating or occupying such premises, notify the director of public works and secure a reading of the meter. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  9-7, 4-14-69; Ord. No. 1135-83,  1, 1-10-83) 
Sec. 22-30. - Fees for connection permits. 
    The fees to be charged for a permit to tap or otherwise make a connection with any water or sewer main shall be determined in such manners and amounts as shall be prescribed by ordinance passed by the president and board of trustees from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  9-8, 4-14-69)

(a)  There shall be and there is hereby established rates and charges against new or additional users for connections to the combined waterworks and sewerage system of the Village of Roselle, DuPage and Cook Counties, Illinois, to be known as a connection charge, all pursuant to Division 150 of the Illinois Municipal Code. Such rates and charges shall be as follows:

(Ord. No. 290-70, ㎣ 1, 2, 5-4-70; Ord. No. 388-72, ㎣ 1, 2, 6-12-72; Ord. No. 73-455,  2, 11-5-73; Ord. No. 538-75, 4-7-75; Ord. No. 549-75,  1, 4-28-75; Ord. No. 641-76,  1, 12-6-76; Ord. No. 1338-85,  1, 6-3-85; Ord. No. 1848-89,  1, 7-10-89; Ord. No. 2058-91,  1, 3-11-91) 
Sec. 22-30.2. - Amount to be paid for connection to extensions and improvements of combined waterworks and sewerage system. 
(a)  The improvements to the combined waterworks and sewerage system of the Village of Roselle, hereinbefore described in the preambles [of Ordinance No. 374-72,] be and the same are hereby accepted as a part of the combined waterworks and sewerage system of this village. 
(b)  The actual cost of the improvements described in the preambles hereof, as determined and approved by the engineer for the village, was twenty-five thousand one hundred five dollars ($25,105.00) for the improvements made to the sanitary sewers and one hundred twelve thousand eight hundred fifty-two dollars and fifty cents ($112,852.50) for the improvements made to the water mains and the water system. 
(c)  The equitable proper share of the cost of such construction to be borne by the owner of any property hereafter seeking to connect to the improvements heretofore described, in addition to the other fees required by the ordinances of this village, is a sum to be computed by multiplying the number of feet of frontage of each lot connected by three dollars and sixty-five cents ($3.65) for each connection made to a water main and by multiplying the number of feet of frontage of each lot connected by three dollars and eighty-three cents ($3.83) for each connection made to the sanitary sewer. 
(d)  No owner or owners of real estate in the Village of Roselle, DuPage and Cook Counties, Illinois, nor their lessees, agents, servants, nor independent contractors hired by them, nor any persons claiming by, through or under them, shall make any physical connection to that portion of the village water main or sanitary sewer main hereinbefore described, [in the preamble of Ord. No. 374-72,] nor shall any permit be granted to tap said water mains or sewer mains to any such person until such owner or owners, or the applicant for such permit, shall pay to the village clerk of the village, in addition to any other fees required to be paid under the water and sewer or combined water and sewer ordinances, or other ordinances, of the village, a sum equal to three dollars and sixty-five cents ($3.65) for each connection made to a water main multiplied by the number of feet of frontage of each lot connected and a sum equal to three dollars and eighty-three cents ($3.83) for each connection made to the sanitary sewer multiplied by the number of feet of frontage of each lot connected, said sums being hereby fixed as a proportionate share of the cost of constructing and installing the said water and sewer mains and improvements hereinbefore described. 
(Ord. No. 374-72,  1-4, 1-3-72) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 374-72, did not expressly amend this Code, hence inclusion of ㎣ 1-4, herein as  22-30.2 was at the discretion of the editors. 
Sec. 22-30.3. - Connecting to extensions and improvements to the combined water and sewerage works. 
(a)  It is the policy of the village to provide waterworks and sewerage systems to residents of the village only. In the instance of residents of the village only, the services provided shall be the combined waterworks and sewage systems of the village and residents of the village shall not be able to select only water works or sewage works. In those cases where any owners of real estate, which is contiguous to the village limits, desire to make direct or indirect connections, they shall be required to make connections to the combined waterworks and sewage works of the village and as a condition of such connection shall first annex such real estate to the village in the manner required by law. If real estate is not contiguous to the village, the owners may petition the village to provide combined waterworks and sewage works, or waterworks, or sewer works only. In the instance of real estate that is not contiguous to the village the corporate authorities may reject such application or require that the owner enter into a pre-annexation agreement with the village as a pre-condition of the extension of waterworks and/or sewerage whereby such owners agree to annex any real estate to be served to the Village when such real estate becomes contiguous to the village. The terms of the pre-annexation agreements shall be within the absolute discretion of the corporate authorities of the village and may include all terms and conditions the corporate authorities deem appropriate. An owner of real estate that is not contiguous to the village who is unwilling to agree to the terms and conditions required by the village in a pre-annexation agreement shall not be entitled to the extension of waterworks and/or sewer works. 
(b)  Any owners of real estate requesting waterworks or sewer works shall pay as determined by the corporate authorities all or part of the costs of extending the water lines and/or the sewer lines from the existing location of such lines to and across the entire frontage of the real estate to be served; provided, however, the village may agree to pay a part of the costs of such installation by a recapture agreement containing such terms and provisions as may be approved by the corporate authorities. 
(c)  Any agreement providing for the payment to the village for the proportionate share of costs of the improvements, shall require adjoining property owners who ultimately benefit from the improvement to pay as required by ordinance a proportionate share of their costs thereof, either to the village or the person paying all or a part of the cost of installing the improvement. 
(d)  The property owners shall also be required to pay the then current tap-on fees and such additional costs or charges as are established by ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 592-75, ㎣ 1-6, 12-22-75; Ord. No. 2016-3873,  1, 12-12-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 592-75, ㎣ 1-6, adopted Dec. 22, 1975, did not expressly amend the Code. Codification herein as  22-30.3 was therefore, at the discretion of the editor. It is presumed that where the provision of this section may conflict with  22-30.2, this section would prevail. 
Sec. 22-31. - Who may tap mains. 
    Whenever any permit for a connection with the water mains of the village is issued hereunder, only the superintendent of public works or employee of the village, or an approved contractor of the village so designated for the work by the superintendent of public works, shall tap the main of said system where such connection is to be made and shall insert the corporation stop. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  9-9, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-32. - Minimum size of connection to main. 
    No connection with any water main of the village shall be less than one inch. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  9-9, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-33. - Purchase, approval of water equipment. 
    All corporation stops, goosenecks, curb stops and buffalo boxes installed in connection with the waterworks system of the village must be purchased through the village, or approved by the superintendent of public works. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  9-9, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-34. - Obstructing access to water facilities. 
    No person shall in any manner obstruct or cause to be obstructed the free access of any duly authorized officer or employee of the village to any curb stop, water meter, shut off box or connection with any water main by means of any coal, lumber, brick, building material or by any other means or device whatsoever or to use or to prevent free access thereto by such officer or employee. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  9-9, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-35. - Installation, type of service pipes. 
    The connection from the main to the curb stop shall be placed at least five (5) feet below the level of the ground and the service pipe shall be laid sufficiently waving so that it shall be at least one foot longer than if laid in a straight line and shall be placed in such manner as to prevent rupture or breakage from settling of the ground. All service pipes shall be of type K copper tubing and shall be of not less than one inch nominal diameter. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  9-10, 4-14-69) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 283-69,  1, was enacted as adding a "new last paragraph" to  9-10 of Ord. No. 258-69, codified as  22-35 to 22-40 herein, hence codification as  22-40.1 was at the discretion of the editors. 
Sec. 22-36. - Furnishing water to another. 
    No person, whether owner or occupant in possession or control of any building, structure or premises into which water is supplied through the village waterworks system shall be allowed, without written permission from the president and board of trustees, to supply other persons or families or to supply water from such building or premises to any other building, structure or premises. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  9-10, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-37. - Discontinuing service for violation of sections 22-35 or 22-36. 
    The supply of water to a building, structure or premises of any person who violates any of the provisions of sections 22-35 or 22-36 shall be shut off and stopped forthwith, and water shall not again be turned on to such building, structure or premises from which it was cut off until there shall have been paid to the village such sum of money as the president and board of trustees shall deem properly due the village. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  9-10, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-38. - Fraudulent representations; wasting water. 
    If after the water supply shall have been turned on to any building, structure or premises, it shall be found by any officer or employee of the village that fraudulent representations have been made by the applicant for such water supply or that water is being used in or upon such building, structure or premises for purposes not set forth in the application made for such water supply or that there is wilful and unreasonable use or waste of water, the superintendent of public works or such employee of the village as he shall designate shall have the authority and it shall be his duty to cut off and stop the supply of water to such building, structure or premises forthwith, and the water shall not be turned on to such building, structure or premises until the person or persons responsible for such fraudulent representation or for such use of water or wilful or unreasonable waste thereof, shall pay the village such additional sum of money for such water supply or on account of such unreasonable waste of water as the president and board of trustees shall find properly to be due the village. Every person supplied with water from the village waterworks system shall, at his or her own cost and expense, have installed and kept in repair all pipes leading from the curb stop to his or her building, structure or premises as are supplied with water through such service pipe. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  9-10, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-39. - Curb stop required. 
    Each water service pipe shall be connected with said water main and shall extend horizontally at right angles with said water main to a point seven (7) feet outside the property line, or an approved location by the superintendent of public works, and shall there be provided with a bronze curb stop to be one inch in diameter of the Mueller oriseal type only, to be installed in a Mueller type 95 E curb box with rod and ring guide. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  9-10, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-40. - Angle of tapping main; position of corporation stop. 
    The water main must be tapped at an angle of forty-five (45) degrees with the vertical, and the corporation stop must be turned so that the T handle will be on top. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  9-10, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-40.1. - Installation of tee and valve for three-inch or larger connection. 
    Whenever it is necessary to make a three-inch connection or larger to a water main it shall be mandatory that a tee and valve be installed at the point of connection, which tee and valve shall be installed in a precast valve vault at least forty-eight (48) inches in diameter. Drawings and specifications therefor shall be submitted to the superintendent of public works for his approval. 
(Ord. No. 283-69,  1, 11-24-69) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 283-69,  1, was enacted as adding a "new last paragraph" to  9-10 of Ord. No. 258-69, codified as ㎣ 22-35 and 22-40 herein, hence codification as  22-40.1 was at the discretion of the editors. 
Sec. 22-41. - Use of village water required. 
    In all cases where a standard water main is now installed or hereafter may be installed in any street, alley, public way or easement in the village, all water users located on any such street, alley, public way or easement, shall make or cause to be made connection to such standard water main and pay the tapping charges therefor within three (3) months after the installation of such standard water main, and all users shall discontinue, within the same period of time, any connection which they theretofore may have had with any other water line. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  9-11, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-42. - Cross-connections prohibited. 
    Wherever a system of water supply piping, either inside or outside of any building, receives its supply from any source other than the waterworks system of the village, such system shall be kept entirely separate from and no cross-connections or connections of any kind shall be made with any pipe or system of piping which receives its supply from the village waterworks system. Water which has once been used for any purpose whatsoever shall not be returned to the building's water supply system. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  9-12, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-43. - Inspection, approval of service pipe and connection. 
    All service pipes and connections shall be inspected and approved by the superintendent of public works or other persons under his direction, and no such service pipes shall be covered until they have been so inspected. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  9-13, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-44. - Use of unmetered water. 
    Before a permit for the use of water shall be issued where meters cannot be conveniently used, the person applying for the same shall deposit twenty dollars ($20.00) as a payment on account of water to be used by him. On or before thirty (30) days from the date of the permit, the person to whom such permit is issued shall file with the department a statement in writing, verified by his affidavit, showing fully the purpose for which the water was used by him for that time, and the amount and location of all work done by him during said time in connection with which any water was used, or required. The superintendent of public works shall ascertain from said statement and any other information, the amount due for water so used. If the amount so found to be due, with all other fees and costs chargeable against such person is less than the sum deposited, the surplus shall be paid back to the depositor. If the amount due for water so used is more than the sum deposited, then the excess shall be paid at once to the department by such person. If such person desires to continue to use the water after he shall have filed his statement, he shall again deposit twenty dollars ($20.00) with the superintendent of public works and shall continue to make deposits thereafter and in the same manner as is provided herein with respect to the first deposit, and the method of determining the amount of water used and the charge for the same shall be the same as the provisions respecting the first deposit as hereinbefore provided. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  9-14, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-45. - Misuse of plumber's name. 
    No plumber shall allow his name to be used by any other person or party directly or indirectly for the purpose of obtaining permits or doing any work under his license. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  9-15, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-46. - Private disposal prohibited if sewer available. 
    No person having his residence or place of business within the territorial limits of the village shall be permitted to dispose of sewage of such residence or place of business located in the village otherwise than through the sewer mains of the village whenever the sewer mains of the sewerage system of the village are adjacent to his property without the written permission of the president and board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  10, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-47. - Sewer connections required. 
    In all cases where a standard sewer main is now installed or hereafter may be installed in any street, alley, public way or easement in the village, all sewerage users located on any lot or parcel of real estate fronting or abutting on any such street, alley, public way or easement, shall make or cause to be made connection to such standard sewer main and pay the tapping charges therefor within three (3) months after the installation of such standard sewer main if the same be not now installed, and all users shall discontinue, within the same period of time, any connection which they theretofore may have had with any other sewer line. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  13-5, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-48. - Permit required for work affecting system. 
    No person shall install or repair any sanitary building sewer or water main without first obtaining a written permit for such work from the waterworks and sewerage department. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  11, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-49. - Defective sewers. 
    Whenever a sanitary building sewer or drain thereto is obstructed, or if found to be broken or defective so that sewage or drainage escapes into surrounding soil, or into adjacent premises, repair or replacement may be ordered by the waterworks and sewerage department. Such repairs shall be at the expense of the owner or person in control of such property. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  13-3, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-50. - Back siphonage protection required. 
    Water pressure ejectors or siphons or pumps of any nature shall not be installed for the discharging of any sewage or waste unless adequately protected against back siphonage without the written permission of the president and board of trustees, said permission to be revocable at will. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  13-4, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-51. - Liability for costs of sewer connections; connection permits required; permit, inspection fees. 
    Applicants for sewer connections or house connections shall pay all costs of labor and materials for installing the sewer connections, except in those instances where the sewer connection is installed by the village, and shall in all cases pay all costs of labor and materials for installing the house connection, and installation may be made only after issuance by the president and board of trustees of a permit authorizing the sewer connection and house connection and specifying the size, grade and materials thereof. The permit and inspection fees for such sewer connection or house connection shall be as provided by ordinance of the village. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  13-6, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-52. - Sewer main and lateral extensions and connections to extensions. 
    Owners of premises abutting on the sewer mains or laterals of the village shall make application and the sewer connections and house connections shall be installed as hereinbefore set forth. Applicants who are owners of premises not abutting on the sewer mains or laterals of the village who desire sewer service from the village shall install at their expense sewer main or lateral extensions so as to provide sewer facilities for their premises. 
(1)  No person, firm, association, corporation or partnership shall make any extension to a sanitary sewer main or lateral of the village except as provided in this section. 
(2)  All extensions to the sewer mains or laterals of the village shall be made only after written application filed with the president and board of trustees, approval as to size, grade and materials by the consulting engineers of the village, and issuance by the village of a permit authorizing the same to be constructed and attached to the existing sewer mains or laterals of the village and thereupon said extensions shall become part thereof. There shall be no permit fee for the construction of an extension to the village sewer main or laterals. 
(3)  After completion and acceptance of a sewer main or lateral extension, title to it shall be transferred and conveyed to the village by the owner (or owners) free and clear of any and all liens and encumbrances, without cost to the village, and thereafter the village shall assume all costs of operation and maintenance of such extension. 
(4)  Applicants making sewer connections and/or house connections to sewer mains or lateral extensions under the provisions of this section shall pay all costs of labor and materials for installing the same. 
(5)  The permit fee and inspection fee for any sewer connection or house connection to a sewer main or lateral extension constructed under the provisions of this section shall be such amount as is prescribed by ordinance by the board of trustees from time to time; provided, however, that there shall be no permit fee if the owner requesting a sewer connection and/or house connection is in the process of constructing ten (10) or more homes on the same main or lateral extension. 
(6)  Such application for a sewer connection or house connection originating from an extension shall impose liability for a periodic sewer charge to be initially billed the owner not later than ninety (90) days after service is available to the owner's premises whether or not said owner makes physical connection to said sanitary sewer system. 
(7)  It shall be unlawful to place any sewer connection or house connection in the same excavation with, or directly over, any drainpipe or sewer pipe. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  13-7, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-53. - Installation of backflow and back siphonage devices. 
    When necessary, in the judgment of the director of public works for the safety of the water system, it shall be required that the property owner install at the property owners sole cost, an approved backflow and back siphonage prevention device. An approved backflow and back siphonage prevention device is a reduced pressure zone backflow assembly, a double check valve, or a fixed proper air gap. Such devices shall be installed as follows: 
(1)  Service to all commercial buildings involved in manufacturing or processing, including carwashes, hospitals, schools, and washaterias. 
(2)  Service line two (2) inches or greater. 
(3)  Service to any building more than two (2) stories high. 
(4)  Service to lawn sprinkler systems. 
(5)  Any building equipped with a pump taking a direct suction from the water service main. 
(6)  Other service to buildings as deemed necessary by the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  13-8, 4-14-69; Ord. No. 2009-3431,  1, 1-5-09) 
Sec. 22-53.1. - Inspection of backflow and back siphonage devices. 
    Required backflow prevention devises shall be maintained in operable condition and inspected annually by a certified cross connection device inspector. An inspection report shall be provided to the water department annually. Failure to maintain or test the backflow prevention device or provide an inspection report shall be a violation of this ordinance and the property owner shall be subject to disconnection of the water service. 
(Ord. No. 2009-3431,  1, 1-5-09) 
Sec. 22-54. - Use of water during construction. 
    During the construction of any building and before any water is installed as is herein provided the contractor so constructing such building may be permitted to use the village water supply by making application therefor, and paying the flat fee prescribed by the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  13-9, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-55. - Disclaimer of village liability. 
    All connections and water applied for hereunder, and all the water used hereunder shall be upon the express condition that the village shall not be liable, nor shall any claim be made against it for damages or injury caused by reason of the breaking of any main, branches, service pipes, apparatus or appurtenances connected with said system or plant, or any part or portion of said plant, or for any interruption of the supply by reason of the breakage of machinery or by reason of stoppage, alterations, extensions or renewals. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  14, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-56. - Restricted outdoor water use.[2] 
    From May 15 through September 15 each year, the following restrictions and procedures shall apply: 
(a)  There shall be no watering of lawns, gardens or any outdoor landscaping between the hours of 11 a.m. and 5 p.m. 
(b)  Properties with even address numbers may only water lawns, gardens or any outdoor landscaping on even numbered dates of the month. Properties with odd address numbers may only water lawns, gardens or any outdoor landscaping on odd numbered dates of the month. 
(c)  The Village Clerk or designee is authorized to issue a thirty (30) day permit allowing daily watering of new lawns or new outdoor landscaping. "New lawns" or "new outdoor landscaping" shall mean seeded lawns, sod and landscape materials that are less than ninety (90) days old. The permit shall be limited to those areas of a property containing new lawn and landscape materials and not extend beyond those areas. 
(d)  Fines and penalties. Any person who violates any provision of this section shall be subject to the penalties provided in the general penalty provisions of the Roselle Village Code. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  15, 4-14-69; Ord. No. 674-77,  1, 7-15-77; Ord. No. 693-77,  1, 8-22-77; Ord. No. 743-78,  1, 3-27-78; Ord. No. 868-79,  1, 7-9-79; Ord. No. 876-79,  1, 8-6-79; Ord. No. 934-80,  1, 4-14-80; Ord. No. 1099-82,  1, 7-6-82; Ord. No. 1331-85,  1, 5-28-85; Ord. No. 1940-90,  1, 4-23-90; Ord. No. 2313-93,  1, 4-12-93; Ord. No. 2000-2765,  1, 4-24-00; Ord. No. 2016-3817,  1, 1-25-16) 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 2016-3817,  1, adopted January 25, 2016, renamed  22-56 and amended the Code; previous Code pertained to similar subject matter. 

Sec. 22-57. - Installation of wye in sewer main. 
    In the event there is no wye connection or sanitary sewer stub from the main sewer in the street, it shall be installed by the property owner and said property owner shall pay all expenses thereof. Where there is no wye connection in the main sewer this connection shall be made by an approved diamond tip sewer tapping machine. Under no circumstances shall any hole be made in the main sewer by any other means, such as by the use of any hammer or chisel or other hand tool. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  16, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-58. - Responsibilities of village, property owner for sewer mains, connections, service pipes. 
    All sewer mains and connections after the installation thereof shall be the property of the village and the village shall assume all costs of maintenance and repair thereof, except that all service pipes or laterals from the main to premises served shall be installed by, and at the cost of, the owner of the property to be served or the applicant for the service, and shall thereafter be repaired and maintained by said owner or applicant; provided, however, in the event of an emergency, the village may make such repairs and in such event the owner or applicant shall reimburse the village for the cost for such repair work. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  17, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-59. - Bond required for work on sewers. 
    No permit for a sewer connection or a house connection, or a sewer extension shall be issued by the president and board of trustees of the village unless the person applying therefor or the contractor shall have evidenced to the village clerk a business license issued by the village together with further evidence that such person or contractor has heretofore filed in the office of the village clerk a performance bond with corporate surety thereon in the amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00); and for a sewer extension a sum equal to one and one-half (11/2) times the estimated cost of the work to be done. Such performance bond shall be approved by the president and board of trustees of the village, conditioned upon the applicant indemnifying and saving harmless the village, DuPage and Cook Counties, Illinois, for any and all damage to underground utilities or to the water and sewer mains and laterals of the village and from any failure to restore any road, ditch, pavement or portion thereof damaged during the construction of the sewer connection, or the sewer extension to the condition at the commencement of construction. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  18, 4-14-69) 
Cross reference- Requirements for surety bonds,  1-13. 
Sec. 22-60. - Insurance required for work on sewers. 
    No permit for a sewer connection or a sewer extension shall be issued by the president and board of trustees of the village unless the person applying therefor or the contractor shall have first procured public liability insurance in an amount not less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for injuries, including accidental death, to any one person and subject to the same limit for each person in an amount not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) on account of one accident, and property damage insurance in an amount not less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00). The persons to be indemnified and saved harmless in said insurance policy shall be the village, DuPage and Cook Counties, Illinois, and the applicant for sewer connection or sewer extension. A certificate of said insurance shall be filed with the village clerk. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  19, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-61. - Inspection, approval of sewer pipes. 
    All sewer pipes and connections shall be inspected and approved by the superintendent of public works or other persons under his direction and no such sewer pipes shall be covered until they have been so inspected. 
(Ord. No. 258-69,  20, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-62. - Violations. 
(a)  Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with, or who resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this article, unless otherwise provided, shall upon conviction be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)  In the event any building or structure constructed, reconstructed, altered, repaired, converted or maintained, or any building, structure, or land used is in violation of this article, the proper local authorities of the municipality, in addition to other remedies, may institute any appropriate action or proceeding: 
(1)  To prevent the unlawful construction, reconstruction, alteration, repair, conversion, maintenance, or use; 
(2)  To prevent the occupancy of the building, structure, or land; 
(3)  To prevent any illegal act, conduct, business, or use in or about the premises; or 
(4)  To restrain, correct, or abate the violation. 
Ord. No. 258-69,  21, 4-14-69) 
Sec. 22-63. - Waters and sewers: Additional shut-off authority. 
    In addition to those other powers provided in the ordinance the director of public works or his designate, in his reasonable discretion, shall have the power to shut-off any water, sewer connection, or line as a result of malfunction, leak, damage or other operational problem which represents a hazard to the life, limb or property or which may significantly compromise the village's ability to efficiently provide water or sewer service until such time as necessary and adequate repairs have been completed. 
(Ord. No. 2604-97,  3, 10-13-97; Ord. No. 2607-97,  3, 11-10-97) 
Sec. 22-64. - Prevailing rate of wages on public works projects. 
(a)  To the extent and as required by "An Act regulating wages of laborers, mechanics and other workers employed in any public works by the state, county, city or any public body or any political subdivision or by anyone under contract for public works", approved June 26, 1941, as amended, the general prevailing rate of wages in this locality for laborers, mechanics and other workers engaged in construction of public works coming under the jurisdiction of the Village of Roselle is hereby ascertained to be the same as the prevailing rate of wages for construction work in the Cook and DuPage Counties area as determined by the Department of Labor of the State of Illinois as of June of the current year, a copy of that determination being attached hereto and incorporated herein by reference. As required by said Act, any and all revisions of the prevailing rate of wages by the Department of Labor of the State of Illinois shall supersede the Department's June determination and apply to any and all public works construction undertaken by the village. The definition of any terms appearing in this section which are also used in aforesaid Act shall be the same as in the Act. 
(b)  Nothing herein contained shall be construed to apply said general prevailing rate of wages as herein ascertained to any work or employment except public works construction of this village to the extent required by the aforesaid Act. 
(c)  The village clerk shall publicly post or keep available for inspection by any interested party in the main office of the village this determination or any revisions of such prevailing rate of wage. A copy of this determination or of the current revised determination of prevailing rate of wages then in effect shall be attached to all contract specifications. 
(d)  The Village Clerk of the Village of Roselle shall mail a copy of this determination to any employer, and to any association of employers and to any person or association of employees who have filed, or file their names and addresses, requesting copies of any determination stating the particular rates and the particular class of workers whose wages will be affected by such rates. 
(Ord. No. 2005-3202, ㎣ 1-4, 10-24-05; Ord. No. 2009-3458, ㎣ 1-4, 6-8-09) 
Secs. 22-65-22-74. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - USE OF SEWERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-75. - Definitions. 
    As used in this division: 
    Building drain shall mean a sanitary sewer extending from any building or structure to the public sewer or septic system, as the case may be. 
    Public sewer shall mean a sewer in which all owners of abutting properties within the village have equal rights and which is controlled by the village. 
    Sanitary sewer or sewer shall mean a pipe or conduit which carries sewage and to which storm, surface, and ground waters are not intentionally permitted. 
    Storm drain or storm sewer shall mean a conduit or sewer which carries storm and surface waters and drainage but excludes sewage and industrial wastes. 
    Superintendent shall mean the superintendent of the combined water and sewer system of the village as appointed by the president and board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 278-69, Art. I, ㎣ 1, 4-7, 10-13-69) 
Sec. 22-76. - Unpolluted water prohibited in storm sewers. 
    No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged into the sanitary sewer system any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff water, subsurface drainage, runoff water from ground or paved areas, cistern overflow or water from air conditioning systems or industrial cooling operations. 
(Ord. No. 278-69, Art. II,  1, 10-13-69) 
Sec. 22-76.1. - Discharge of waste water into sanitary sewers prohibited; penalty. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to discharge sanitary and industrial waste water into the storm sewers constructed as part of the intersection improvement at Irving Park Road and Lawrence Avenue; nor shall there be any discharge of waste water into any storm sewer in Roselle. 
(b)  Any person violating this section shall be fined not less than thirty-five dollars ($35.00) or more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed for each and every day during which a violation continues or exists. 
(Ord. No. 966-80, ㎣ 1, 2, 9-22-80) 
Editor's note- Section 22-76.1 of the Code has been derived, at the discretion of the editors, from nonamendatory Ord. No. 966-80,  1, adopted Sept. 22, 1980. 
Sec. 22-77. - Discharging swimming pools into sanitary sewers. 
    No swimming pools shall be discharged into the sanitary sewer system except under written agreement with the president and board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 278-69, Art. II,  2, 10-13-69) 
Sec. 22-78. - Connecting water or filth to sanitary sewer. 
    No person or persons shall connect to any sanitary sewer any private building cesspool, underground drain, privy, privy vault or any other channel conveying water or filth. 
(Ord. No. 278-69, Art. II,  3, 10-13-69) 
Sec. 22-79. - Disconnection required on notice. 
    Whenever the superintendent or a duly authorized officer of this village shall deem it advisable to require any owner of any property within the village to disconnect any cesspool, underground drain, privy, privy vault or any other channel conveying water or filth from a public sanitary sewer as hereinabove provided, a notice of such direction shall be mailed to the last known address of the owner, tenant or occupant of said property ordering such disconnection of such cesspool, underground drain, privy, privy vault or any other channel conveying water or filth from the public sanitary sewer of the village within ninety (90) days after date of such notice. 
(Ord. No. 278-69, Art. II,  4, 10-13-69) 
Sec. 22-80. - Failure to disconnect after notice. 
    The failure of any owner, tenant, occupant or builder to disconnect such cesspool, underground drain, privy, privy vault or any other channel conveying water or filth from the public sanitary sewer of the village within the specified period in said notice shall be deemed, held and construed to be in violation of this provision and punishable as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. No. 278-69, Art. II,  5, 10-13-69) 
Sec. 22-81. - Village may disconnect or plug violations. 
    The village shall have the right to plug or disconnect the sewer at any point in the building drain whenever any person shall be shown to be in violation of this division. 
(Ord. No. 278-69, Art. III,  1, 10-13-69) 
Sec. 22-82. - Violations; enforcement. 
    Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with, or who resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this division, shall upon conviction be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. The superintendent is hereby designated and authorized to enforce this division. 
(Ord. No. 278-69, Art. III,  2, 10-13-69) 
Sec. 22-83. - Notice, correction of violations. 
    Whenever and wherever within the village it is made to appear that any person is violating any of the provisions of this division, the superintendent may, but is not required as a condition precedent to prosecution for village, cause to be served personally or by mail upon the alleged offender a notice in writing stating the date and nature of the alleged offense and directing that the same cease and desist immediately upon service of the notice and that the act or omission causing such violation be corrected within thirty (30) days or within such reasonable time as the circumstances may require. 
(Ord. No. 278-69, Art. III,  3, 10-13-69) 
Sec. 22-84. - Action on failure to comply with notice. 
    The failure, neglect and refusal of the person alleged to be in such violation to cease and desist therefrom within the time stated in such notice shall be deemed a violation of the provisions of this division and, in addition to other remedies, the proper local authorities may institute any appropriate action or proceeding: 
(1)  To prevent the unlawful construction, reconstruction, alteration, repair, conversion, maintenance, or use; 
(2)  To prevent any illegal act; or 
(3)  To restrain, correct or abate the violation, including compelling any person to disconnect any illegal connection to the public sanitary sewer of the village. 
(Ord. No. 278-69, Art. III,  4, 10-13-69) 
Secs. 22-85-22-91. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - INDUSTRIAL AND HARMFUL WASTES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 830-79,  1, Arts. I-IV, enacted Feb. 26, 1979, has been codified herein as superseding Div. 2, ㎣ 22-92-22-110, pertaining to the same subjects. Former Div. 2 was derived from Ord. No. 56-A-7,  1, passed April 9, 1956; Ord. No. 145-64,  1, passed Sept. 14, 1964; and Ord. No. 246-68,  1 each of Arts. I-IV, and App. 1 "A," passed Oct. 14, 1968. Ord. No. 830-79 did not specifically amend this Code, hence Arts. I-IV and App. A have been codified as ㎣ 22-92-22-110 at the discretion of the editors. 

Sec. 22-92. - General purposes. 
    The general purpose of this division is to provide the village with control over the quantity and quality of industrial waste admitted to the sewage works, watercourses or natural outlets within the boundaries of the village. 
(Ord. No. 830-79, 2-26-79) 
Sec. 22-93. - Definitions. 
    Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of the terms used in this division shall be as follows: 
    BOD (denoting Biochemical Oxygen Demand) shall mean the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five (5) days at twenty (20) degrees Centigrade, expressed in milligrams per liter. 
    Combined sewer shall mean a sewer receiving both surface runoff and sewage. 
    Garbage shall mean solid wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage or sale of meat, fish, fowl, fruit, or vegetables and condemned food. 
    Ground or comminuted garbage shall mean wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of foods that have been comminuted to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely in suspension under conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch in any dimension. 
    Industrial wastes shall mean the solids, liquid or gaseous wastes resulting from any industrial, manufacturing, trade or business process or from the development, recovery or processing of natural resources. 
    Natural outlet shall mean any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake, or other body of surface water. 
    Person shall mean any individual, firm, company, municipality, association, society, corporation or group. 
    Pollution shall be as defined in Section 326 bb of Chapter 42 of Illinois Revised Statutes and shall mean the discharge or deposit in or upon such waters of sewage, industrial wastes, or other wastes containing soluble or insoluble solids of organic or inorganic nature which may deplete the dissolved oxygen content of such waters, contribute settleable solids that may form sludge deposits, contain oil, grease, or floating solids which may cause unsightly appearance on the surface of such waters, or contain soluble materials detrimental to aquatic life, all beyond the content of such like substances present in an equal volume of the effluent discharge from the sewage treatment works of the village into similar receiving waters. 
    President and board of trustees shall mean the body of elected trustees charged with the administration of the affairs of the village. 
    Sewage shall mean a combination of water-carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions, and industrial establishments, together with such ground, surface and storm waters as may be present. 
    Sewage treatment works shall mean the arrangement of devices and structures for treating sewage and industrial wastes. 
    Sewage works shall mean all facilities for collecting, pumping, treating and disposing of sewage and industrial wastes. 
    Sewer shall mean a pipe or conduit for carrying sewage or other waste liquids. 
    Sewerage system shall mean the network of sewers and appurtenances for collection, transportation, and pumping of sewage and industrial wastes. 
    Storm sewer shall mean a pipe or conduit which carries storm, surface water and drainage but excludes sewage and industrial wastes. It may, however, carry cooling waters and unpolluted waters. 
    Slug shall mean any discharge of water, sewage or industrial waste which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flows exceeds for any period of duration longer than fifteen (15) minutes more than five (5) times the average twenty-four-hour concentration of flows during normal operation. 
    Superintendent of public works shall mean the superintendent of public works of the village or his authorized agent or representative. 
    Toxic substances shall mean any substance whether gaseous, liquid or solid which when discharged to the sewer system in sufficient quantities will interfere with any sewage treatment process, or will constitute a hazard to human beings or animals, or will inhibit aquatic life or create a hazard to recreation in the receiving waters of the effluent from the sewage treatment works of the village. 
    Village of Roselle shall mean the municipal corporation organized and existing under the laws of the State of Illinois and shall hereafter be referred to as the village. 
    Watercourse shall mean any channel, natural or artificial, whether lined or unlined, for drainage of storm water, ground water or clean water. 
    Waters shall mean all waters of any river, stream, watercourse, pond, or lake wholly or partly within the territorial boundaries of the village. 
(Ord. No. 830-79,  1, Art. I, 2-26-79) 
Sec. 22-94. - Policies pertaining to pollutants. 
    It shall be the policy of the village that no sewerage system which is planned or designed to discharge into any of the aforesaid waters any industrial wastes or other wastes that will cause the pollution of such waters, may be installed unless a written permit for such sewerage system has been granted by the president and board of trustees, and no changes, additions or extensions to any existing sewerage system shall be made in the village until plans for such changes, additions or extensions shall have been submitted to and a written permit obtained from the president and board of trustees; it shall be the policy of the village to admit to its sewage works those types and quantities of industrial waste that are not harmful or damaging to the structures, processes or operation of the sewage works and are not specifically prohibited by this division; and it shall be the policy of the village to prohibit discharge of industrial wastes which will cause pollution directly into the waters, watercourses or natural outlets within the boundaries of the village. 
(Ord. No. 830-79,  1, Art. II, par. 2, 2-26-79) 
Sec. 22-95. - Preliminary treatment required. 
    Whenever necessary, in the opinion of the president and board of trustees, the owner, operator or tenant of any industrial plant or other establishment discharging or proposing to discharge industrial wastes into any waters, sewer, watercourse or natural outlet in the village, at such owner's, operator's, or tenant's expense, shall provide such preliminary treatment or handling facilities as may be necessary to: 
(1)  Reduce or modify the objectionable characteristics or constituents of such industrial wastes to meet the limits or conditions provided for in section 22-97 hereof, and to comply with the pollution restrictions as indicated in the above definition of pollution. 
(2)  Control the quantities and rates of discharge of such industrial wastes over a twenty-four-hour day and a seven-day week to prevent surge discharges which may place an unreasonable burden upon the sewage works of the village. 
(Ord. No. 830-79,  1, Art. II, par. 2, 2-26-79) 
Sec. 22-96. - Plans for preliminary treatment required; approval. 
    Before any permit for the construction of preliminary treatment or handling facilities will be issued, plans, specifications and other pertinent data or information relating to the proposed preliminary treatment or handling facilities shall be submitted by the industry for the approval of the president and board of trustees, and no permit shall be issued and no construction of such facilities shall be commenced without the prior written approval of the president and board of trustees. No substantial alteration or addition to or in the sewerage system or preliminary treatment or handling facilities shall be made without the prior written approval of the president and board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 830-79,  1, Art. II, par. 2, 2-26-79) 
Sec. 22-97. - Prohibited wastes. 
    Except as otherwise provided by the president and board of trustees pursuant to the provisions hereof, no person shall discharge or cause to be discharged the following described wastes or waters into any sewer, watercourse, natural outlet or waters within the village. 
(1)  Water or wastes containing more than one hundred (100) parts per million (eight hundred thirty-three (833) pounds per million gallons) of fats, oils or greases if such water or wastes are, in the opinion of the president and board of trustees, sufficient: 
(a)  To interfere with the biological processes of a sewage treatment plant; 
(b)  Interfere with proper operation of the sewage works; 
(c)  Cause obstruction to flow in sewers; 
(d)  Cause pollution as herein defined. 
(2)  Liquids, solids, or gases which by reason of their nature or quantity are sufficient to cause fire or explosion or be injurious in any other way to the sewage works structures or to the operation of the sewage works. 
(3)  Noxious or malodorous liquids, gases or substances which either singly or by interaction with other wastes are sufficient to create a public nuisance or hazard to life or are sufficient to prevent entry into the sewers for their maintenance and repair. 
(4)  Water or wastes having a pH lower than five and one-half (51/2) or having corrosive properties sufficient to cause damage or hazards to structures, equipment, or personnel of the sewage works or [capable] of interfering with the proper operation of the sewerage system or sewage treatment works. 
(5)  Water or wastes containing toxic substances in quantities which are sufficient to interfere with the biological processes of the sewage treatment works. 
(6)  Garbage that has not been ground or comminuted to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely in suspension under conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch in any dimension. 
(7)  Radioactive wastes unless they comply with the Atomic Energy Commission Act of 1954 (68 Stat. 919 as amended and Part 20, Sub-part D-Waste Disposal, Section 20.303, of the Regulations issued by the Atomic Energy Commission or amendments, thereto). 
(8)  Solid or viscous wastes which cause obstruction to the flow in sewers or other interference with the proper operation of the sewerage system or sewage treatment works, such as grease, uncomminuted garbage, animal guts or tissues, paunch manure, bone, hair, hides, fleshings, entrails, feathers, sand, cinders, ashes, spent lime, stone or marble dust, metal, glass, straw, shavings, grass clippings, rags, spent grain, wastepaper, wood, plastic, gas tar, asphalt residues, residues from refining or processing of fuel or lubricating oil, gasoline, naphtha, and similar substances. 
(9)  Liquids or vapors having a temperature higher than one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit at the point of entrance into a public sewer. 
(10)  Waste or chemicals having a concentration greater than that shown in section 22-110. This listing will be amended as required. 
(11)  Any mercury or any of its compounds in excess of 0.0005 mg/l as Hg at any time except as permitted by the superintendent of public works in compliance with applicable state and federal regulations. 
(12)  Any cyanide in excess of 0.025 mg/l at any time except as permitted by the superintendent of public works in compliance with applicable state and federal regulations. 
(13)  Materials which exert or cause unusual concentrations of inert suspended solids (such as, but not limited to, Fuller's earth, lime slurries, and lime residues) or of dissolved solids (such as, but not limited to, sodium chloride and sodium sulfate). 
(14)  Materials which exert or cause excessive discoloration (such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning solutions). 
(15)  Materials which exert or cause unusual BOD, chemical oxygen demand, or chlorine requirements in such quantities as to constitute a significant bond on the sewage treatment works. 
(16)  Materials which exert or cause unusual volume of flow or concentration of wastes constituting "slugs" as defined herein. 
(17)  Waters or wastes containing substances which are not amenable to treatment or reduction by the sewage treatment process employed, or are amenable to treatment only to such degree that the sewage treatment plant effluent cannot meet the requirements of agencies having jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters. 
(Ord. No. 830-79,  1, Art. II, par. 3, 2-26-79; Ord. No. 1000-81,  3, 3-9-81) 
Sec. 22-98. - Disposal of clean water generally. 
    Wherever possible clean waters from air conditioning, cooling or condensing systems or from swimming pools or clean waters resulting from pretreatment of industrial wastes shall be discharged to a storm sewer, combined sewer or natural outlet approved by the village. 
(Ord. No. 246-68,  1, Art. II, 10-14-68; Ord. No. 830-79,  1, Art. II, par. 4, 2-26-79) 
Sec. 22-99. - Control manhole required. 
(a)  Each new industry and, as required by the director of public works, each existing industry shall be required to install a control manhole for the purpose of observation, sampling, and measurement of wastes. When required by the director of public works, the owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install necessary meters and other appurtenances in the building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of the wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessibly and safely located, and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the director of public works. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at his expense, and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
(b)  All measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in the Village Code shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater," published by the American Public Health Association, and shall be determined at the control manhole provided, or upon suitable samples taken at said control manhole. Sampling shall be carried out by customarily accepted methods to reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewage works and to determine the existence of hazards to life, limb and property. The particular analyses involved will determine whether a twenty-four-hour composite of all outfalls of a premise is appropriate or whether a grab sample or samples should be taken. Normally, but not always, BOD and suspended solids analyses are obtained from twenty-four-hour composites of all outfalls, whereas pH's are determined from periodic grab samples. 
(Ord. No. 830-79,  1, Art. II, par. 5, 2-26-79; Ord. No. 1000-81,  4, 3-9-81) 
Sec. 22-100. - Village's right to conduct sampling operation. 
    The owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall provide laboratory measurements, tests, and analyses of waters and wastes to illustrate compliance with this division and any special conditions for discharge established by the village or regulatory agencies having jurisdiction over the discharge. 
    The number, type, and frequency of laboratory analyses to be performed by the owner shall be as stipulated by the director of public works of the village, but no less than once per year the industry must supply a complete analysis of the constituents of the waste water discharge to assure that compliance with the federal, state, and local standards are being met. The owner shall report the results of measurements and laboratory analyses to the director of public works of the village at such times and in such manner as prescribed by the director of public works of the village. The owner shall bear the expense of all measurements, analyses, and reporting required by the director of public works of the village. At such times as deemed necessary, the village reserves the right to take measurements and samples for analysis by an outside laboratory service. 
(Ord. No. 830-79,  1, Art. II, par. 6, 2-26-79; Ord. No. 1000-81,  5, 3-9-81) 
Sec. 22-101. - Standards for measurements, tests, analyses; sampling. 
    All measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in this division shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater," published by the American Public Health Association, and shall be determined at the control manhole provided, or upon suitable samples taken at said control manhole. In the event that no special manhole has been required, the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is connected. Sampling shall be carried out by customarily accepted methods to reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewage works and to determine the existence of hazards to life, limb, and property. (The particular analyses involved will determine whether a twenty-four-hour composite of all outfalls of a premise is appropriate or whether a grab sample or samples should be taken. Normally, but not always, BOD and suspended solids analyses are obtained from twenty-four-hour composites of all outfalls, whereas pH's are determined from periodic grab samples.) 
(Ord. No. 830-79,  1, Art. II, par. 7, 2-26-79) 
Sec. 22-102. - Maintenance of preliminary treatment or flow-equalizing facilities. 
    Where preliminary treatment or flow-equalizing facilities are provided, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner at his expense. 
(Ord. No. 830-79,  1, Art. II, par. 8, 2-26-79) 
Sec. 22-103. - Where application to use village sewer made. 
    Application for permission to connect an industrial waste sewer to any sewer in the village or to discharge to any waters, watercourse or channel within the village shall be made on the standard form obtainable from the superintendent of public works of the village, 31 South Prospect, Roselle, Illinois. 
(Ord. No. 830-79,  1, Art. II, par. 9, 2-26-79) 
Sec. 22-104. - Enforcement by director of public works. 
(a)  The president and board of trustees, pursuant to the aforesaid statute, designates and appoints the director of public works of the village or a designate of the director of public works to act as its representative in matters affecting this division. The director of public works shall be empowered to recommend to the president and board of trustees, standards from time to time, as the case may be, and to recommend what constitutes an improper discharge of industrial wastes or other wastes into the sewers, the channel system or the treatment plants of the village. 
(b)  The director of public works of the village and other duly authorized employees of the village, the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency, bearing proper credentials and identification, shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, and testing in accordance with the provisions of this division. The director of public works or his representative shall have no authority to inquire into any processes, including metallurgical, chemical, oil refining, ceramic, paper or other industries beyond that point having a direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the sewers or waterway or facilities for waste treatment. 
(c)  While performing the necessary work on private properties referred to in the above section, the director of public works of the village or duly authorized employees of the village, the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency, and the U.S. Environmental Agency shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises established by the company shall be held harmless for injury or death to the village's employees and the village shall indemnify the company against loss or damage to its property by the village's employees and against liability claims and demands for personal injury or property damage asserted against the company and growing out of the gauging and sampling operation, except as such may be caused by negligence or failure of the company to maintain safe conditions as required in Chapter 22 of the Village Code. 
(d)  The director of public works and other duly authorized employees of the village bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all private properties for the purposes of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement, and sampling. 
(Ord. No. 830-79,  1, Art. II, par. 10, 2-26-79; Ord. No. 1000-81,  6, 3-9-81) 
Sec. 22-105. - Industrial wastes includes other wastes. 
    Industrial wastes as used in the division shall mean both "industrial wastes" and "other wastes." The term "other wastes" is included in order to correspond with language of the statute. 
(Ord. No. 830-79,  1, Art. III, 2-26-79) 
Sec. 22-106. - Order to discontinue discharge; notice, hearing. 
    Whenever the president and board of trustees shall determine that sewage or industrial wastes or other wastes are being discharged into any of the said waters, watercourses or sewers of the village, and when, in the opinion of the president and board of trustees, such discharge pollutes the waters or watercourses or interferes with the operation of the sewerage system of the village, such president and board of trustees may order whosoever causes such discharge to show cause before such board why such discharge should not be discontinued. A notice shall be served on the offending party directing him or it to show cause before the president and board of trustees or before the superintendent of public works, acting for the president and board of trustees, why an order should not be made directing the discontinuance of such discharge. Said notice shall specify the time and place where a hearing will be held and notice of the hearing shall be served personally or by registered mail at least ten (10) days before said hearing. The president and board of trustees or the superintendent of public works, acting for the president and board of trustees, may take evidence with reference to said matter and the president and board of trustees, after reviewing such evidence may issue an order by the president and board of trustees or the superintendent of public works to the party responsible for such discharge, directing that within a specified period of time thereafter such discharge be discontinued unless adequate treatment works shall have been installed or existing adequate treatment works be properly operated or unless the sewers through which such discharge is made are connected to a system of intercepting sewers to sewage treatment works of the village as directed by the president and board of trustees. The foregoing procedure shall be applicable to the provisions of sections 22-95 and 22-97. 
(Ord. No. 830-79,  1, Art. IV, par. 1, 2-26-79) 
Sec. 22-107. - Revocation, modification of permit. 
    Any permit authorized and issued under the provisions of this article may, when necessary, in the opinion of the president and board of trustees or as recommended by its superintendent of public works to prevent pollution of waters, watercourses or to prevent interference with the operation of the sewerage system of the village, be revoked or modified by such president and board of trustees on recommendation of the superintendent of public works, after investigation, notice and hearing as provided in section 22-106. 
(Ord. No. 830-79,  1, Art. IV, par. 2, 2-26-79) 
Sec. 22-108. - Litigation authorized to stop discharge. 
    If any person, firm, association or corporation discharges sewage or industrial wastes or other wastes into the aforesaid waters, watercourses or sewage system contrary to the orders of the president and board of trustees, the president and board of trustees may commence action in the circuit court of the Eighteenth Judicial District, DuPage County, Illinois or any court having jurisdiction thereof, for the purpose of having such discharge stopped either by mandamus or injunction. 
(Ord. No. 830-79,  1, Art. IV, par. 3, 2-26-79) 
Sec. 22-109. - Penalty. 
    Whoever violates any provision of this division and fails to comply with an order of the president and board of trustees in accordance with the provisions of this division, shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). Each day's continuance of such violation and failure shall constitute a separate offense. The penalties provided in this section shall be recoverable by the president and board of trustees upon its suit, as debts are recoverable at law. 
(Ord. No. 830-79,  1, Art. IV, par. 4, 2-26-79) 
Sec. 22-110. - Partial list of harmful chemicals. 
    Below is a partial list of chemicals which will upset biological action at the sewage treatment plant and the maximum concentration acceptable for discharge into the sewer system. 
Waste or Chemical Concentration mg/l Boron .....   1.0 Chromium (Hexavalent) .....   5.0 Chromium (Trivalent) .....  10.0 Copper .....   3.0 Cyanide .....   1.0 Iron .....  15.0 Lead .....   0.1 Nickel .....   3.0 Oil and Grease, etc. ..... 100.0 Temperature Not Over 150 Degrees Fahrenheit Acid Iron Pickling Waste or Concentrated Plating Waste .....   0.0 Free Acids and Alkalis pH between 4.5 and 10.0 Zinc .....   2.0 Cadmium .....   2.0 Chlorine Demand .....  30.0 Phenols .....   0.5  
(Ord. No. 830-79, App. A, 2-26-79) 
Sec. 22-111. - Interceptors. 
    Grease, oil, and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the village engineer they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand, or other harmful ingredients; except that such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the village engineer, and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. 
(Ord. No. 1000-81,  7, 3-9-81) 
Sec. 22-112. - Special agreements. 
    No statement contained in this chapter, division or Code shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the village and any industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted by the village for treatment, subject to payment therefor. 
(Ord. No. 1000-81,  8, 3-9-81) 
Secs. 22-113-22-119. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - USER CHARGES FOR SEWERS AND WASTEWATER TREATMENT[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1971-90,  1, adopted June 25, 1990, as amended by Ord. No. 1980-90,  1, adopted July 23, 1990, added provisions designated as ㎣ 22-120-22-156 to read as herein set out. 

Sec. 22-120. - Definitions. 
    Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms used in this article shall be as follows: 
    Act means the Federal Water Pollution Control Act 33 U.S.G. 1251 et seq. as amended by the Federal Water Pollution Control Act of Amendments of 1972 (Public Law 92-500 and P.L. 93-243), and Municipal Wastewater Treatment Construction Grant Amendments of 1981 (P.L. 97-317). 
    Administrator means the administrator of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. 
    Approving authority shall mean the president and board of trustees of the Village of Roselle acting by and through their duly authorized agent or representative, the director of public works. 
    Average strength sewage shall mean sewage with characteristics not exceeding a five-day twenty (20) degrees centigrade biochemical oxygen demand of two hundred (200) mg/l; a suspended solids content of two hundred forty (240) mg/l and an ammonia nitrogen content of two hundred (200) mg/l based on one hundred (100) gpcpd. 
    BOD (denoting biochemical oxygen demand) shall mean the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five (5) days at twenty (20) degrees C, expressed in milligrams per liter. 
    Building inspector shall mean the chief building inspector of the Village of Roselle as designated by the village administrator or his authorized deputy, agent or representative. 
    Building drain shall mean that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer or other approved point of discharge, beginning five (5) feet (1.5 meters) outside the inner face of the building wall. 
    Building drainage sewer shall mean a sewer which carries storm drainage, surface water, foundation drainage, and roof drainage, but excludes sewage and industrial wastes from the building plumbing to a public storm sewer or natural outlet. 
    Building sewer shall mean the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal. 
    Combined sewer shall mean a sewer which is designed and intended to receive wastewater, storm, surface and groundwater drainage. 
    Commercial user shall include transit lodging, retail and wholesale establishments or places engaged in selling merchandise, or rendering services. 
    Compatible pollutant means biochemical oxygen demand, suspended solids, pH and fecal coliform bacteria, plus additional pollutants identified in the NPDES Permit. 
    Control manhole shall mean a structure located on a site from which industrial wastes are discharged. Where feasible, the manhole shall have an interior drop. The purpose of a control manhole is to provide access for a village representative to sample and/or measure discharges. 
    Customer shall mean any person, partnership, corporation, trust or other party which uses and/or receives service from the waterworks and/or sanitary sewerage system of the village. 
    Debt service charge shall be the amount to be paid each billing period for payment of interest, principal and coverage of revenue bonds outstanding. 
    Director shall mean the director of public works of the Village of Roselle or his authorized deputy, agent or representative. 
    Easement shall mean an acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others. 
    Effluent criteria are defined by any applicable NPDES permit. 
    Federal grant shall mean the U.S. Government participation in the financing of the construction of treatment works as provided for by Title II, Grants for Construction of Treatment Works, of the Act. 
    Floatable oil is oil, fat, or grease in a physical state such that it will separate by gravity from wastewater by treatment in an approved pretreatment facility. A wastewater shall be considered free of floatable fat if it is properly pretreated and the wastewater does not interfere with the collection system. 
    Garbage shall mean solid wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation, cooking, and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage, and sale of produce. 
    Incompatible pollutant means any pollutant which is not a compatible pollutant as defined. 
    Industrial user shall include establishments engaged in manufacturing activities involving the mechanical or chemical transformation of materials or substance into products. 
    Industrial waste shall mean any solid, liquid or gaseous substance discharged, permitted to flow or escaping from any industrial, manufacturing, commercial or business establishment or process or from the development, recovery or processing of any natural resource as distinct from sanitary sewage. 
    Infiltration shall mean the water entering a sewer system, including building drains and sewers, from the ground, through such means as, but not limited to, defective pipes, pipe joints, connections, or manhole walls. (Infiltration does not include, and is distinguished from, inflow). 
    Infiltration/inflow shall mean the total quantity of water from both infiltration and inflow without distinguishing the source. 
    Inflow shall mean the water discharge into a sewer system, including building drains and sewers, from such sources as, but not limited to, roof leaders; cellar, yard, and area drains; foundation drains; unpolluted cooling water discharges; drains from springs and swampy areas; manhole covers, cross connections from storm sewers, and combined sewers, catch basins, stormwaters, surface runoff, street wash waters or drainage. (Inflow does not include, and is distinguished from, infiltration.) 
    Institutional/governmental user shall include schools, churches, penal institutions, and users associated with federal, state, and local governments. 
    Lot shall mean any parcel of land as set forth in the zoning ordinance of the village. 
    Living unit shall mean a structure or part thereof for the occupancy of one family. 
    State director means the chief administrative officer of the State of Illinois Environmental Protection Agency. 
    Major contributing industry shall mean an industrial user of the publicly owned treatment works that: (a) has a flow of fifty thousand (50,000) gallons or more per average work day; (b) has a flow greater than five (5) percent of the flow carried by the municipal system receiving the waste; (c) has in its waste, a toxic pollutant in toxic amounts as defined in standards issued under Section 307 (a) of the Act; or (d) is found by the permit issuance authority, in connection with the issuance of an NPDES permit to the publicly owned treatment works receiving the waste, to have significant impact, either singly or in combination with other contributing industries, on that treatment works or upon the quality of effluent from that treatment works. 
    Milligrams per liter shall mean a unit of the concentration of water or wastewater constituent. It is 0.001 g of the constituent in one thousand (1,000) ml of water. It has replaced the unit formerly used commonly, parts per million, to which it is approximately equivalent, in reporting the results of water and wastewater analysis. 
    Natural outlet shall mean any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface or groundwater. 
    NPDES permit shall mean a permit issued under the National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System for discharge of wastewaters to the navigable water of the United States pursuant to Section 402 of PL 92-500.
