SECTION 4.00. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

4.01. - Interpretation. 
(A)  Minimum requirements. In their interpretation and application, the provisions of this ordinance shall be held to be the minimum requirements for the promotion of the public health, safety, morals, and welfare. 
(B)  Interpretation of uses listed in definitions. Nothing contained in section 3.02, definitions, shall be construed to be a listing of permitted or special uses; uses which are contained among the several definitions are not necessarily found within any of the particular sections devoted to permitted or special uses, and to the extent that such uses are defined but not found in any particular section devoted to permitted or special use, such defined use shall be expressly prohibited. 
(C)  Uses not specifically permitted in district. Except as hereinafter provided, when a use is not specifically listed in a particular section devoted to permitted or special uses, it shall be expressly prohibited. 
(D)  Interpretation of use lists. The zoning administrator may allow land uses (permitted or special) which, though not contained by name in a zoning district list of permitted or special uses, are deemed to be similar in nature and clearly compatible with the listed uses. However, such nonlisted uses shall not be approved by the zoning administrator until an application for such use has been reviewed by the plan commission and zoning board and approved by the village board of trustees. All uses which are not listed but which have been approved by the village board shall be added by ordinance to the appropriate use list at the time of periodic updating and revision of this ordinance. 
(E)  Special uses: 
(1)  To provide for the location of certain uses hereinafter specified which are deemed desirable for the public welfare within a given district or districts, but which might have an adverse effect upon nearby properties or upon the character and future development of the district in which they are located, a classification of special uses is hereby established. Procedures for special uses are set forth in section 13.11. 
(2)  Where a building, structure or use of land lawfully exists at a special use on the effective date of this ordinance, and is classified by this ordinance as a special use such use shall be considered a lawful special use. Any special use as above stated may be expanded to the limits of the special use ordinance as adopted. 
(3)  Where a building, structure or use of land lawfully exists as a permitted use on the effective date of this ordinance, and is classified by this ordinance as a special use, such use shall be considered a lawful special use. Any expansion or major alteration of such existing lawful special use shall require a new special use ordinance to be issued pursuant to section 13.11, special uses. 
(4)  Where a building, structure or use is not allowed as a special use or permitted use in the district in which it is zoned under this ordinance, and exists as a special use under the terms of the ordinance immediately prior to the date of the adoption of this ordinance, such building, structure or use shall be considered to be nonconforming and shall be subject to the provisions of section 5.00, nonconforming buildings, structures, and uses. 
(5)  If a special use ceases for a period of more than one year, the special use permit shall be void and the special use cannot again be started except in conformance with the provisions of section 13.11, special uses. 
(F)  Administrative relief. Although the requirements of this ordinance are written in very specific terms, reasonable flexibility is offered through such devices as amendments, appeals, variations, special uses, and special use-planned unit development. 
4.02. - Separability. 
    It is hereby declared to be the intention of the Village of Roselle that the several provisions of this ordinance are separable in accordance with the following: 
(A)  If any court of competent jurisdiction shall adjudge any provision of this ordinance to be invalid, such judgment shall not affect any other provision not specifically included in said judgment. 
(B)  If any court of competent jurisdiction shall adjudge invalid the application of any provision of this ordinance to a particular property, building or other structure, such judgment shall not affect the application of said provisions to any other property, building, or structure not specifically included in said judgment. 
4.03. - Other laws and agreements. 
(A)  Relationship with other laws. Where the conditions imposed by any provision herein upon the use of land or buildings or upon the bulk of buildings are either more restrictive or less restrictive than comparable conditions imposed by any other provision herein or any other law, ordinance, resolution, rule or regulation of any kind, the regulations which are more restrictive (or which impose higher standards or requirements) shall govern. 
(B)  Effect of existing agreements. This ordinance is not intended to abrogate any easement, covenant or any other private agreement. Where the regulations of this ordinance are more restrictive (or impose higher standards or requirements) than such easements, covenants, or other private agreements the requirements herein shall govern. 
4.04. - Scope of regulations. 
(A)  Change in buildings, structures or uses. Except as may otherwise be provided, all buildings erected hereafter, all uses of land or building established hereafter, all structural alterations or relocation of existing buildings occurring hereafter, and all enlargements of or additions to existing uses occurring hereafter shall be subject to all regulations herein which are applicable to the zoning district in which such buildings, structures, uses, or land shall be located. 
(B)  Nonconforming buildings, structures and uses. Any lawful building, structure or use existing at the time of the enactment of the zoning ordinance may be continued, even though such building, structure, or use does not conform to the provisions herein for the district in which it is located. Whenever a district shall be changed hereafter, any then existing lawful use may be continued, subject to the provisions in section 5.00. 
(C)  Unlawful building, structure or use. Any building, structure or use which was not lawfully existing at the time of the adoption of this ordinance shall become or be made lawful unless such building structure or use shall be allowable under the terms of this ordinance; and to the extent that in any manner that said unlawful building, structure, or use is in conflict with the requirements of this ordinance, said building, structure, or use remains unlawful hereunder. 
(D)  Building permits. Where a building permit for a building or structure has been issued in accordance with law prior to the effective date of this ordinance, and provided that construction is begun within ninety (90) days of such effective date and diligently prosecuted to completion, said building or structure may be completed in accordance with the approved plans on the basis of which the building permit was issued. Further it may, upon completion, be occupied under a certificate of occupancy by the use for which it was originally designated, subject thereafter to the provisions of section 5.00. 
(E)  Open uses. Where a lot is to be occupied for a permitted use without buildings or structures, the side yards and front yard required for such lot shall be provided and maintained unless otherwise stipulated in this ordinance. However, side yards shall not be required on lots used for garden purposes without buildings or structures. No side or front yards shall be required on lots used for public recreation areas without buildings or structures. 
(F)  Required permits and certificates. Nothing contained in the Village of Roselle Zoning Ordinance shall be deemed to be a consent, license or permit to use any property or to locate, construct, or maintain any building, structure or facility or to carry on any trade, industry, occupation, or activity without obtaining appropriate building permits, zoning lot certification, and occupancy permits. 
4.05. - Bulk regulations. 
(A)  Continued conformity with bulk regulations. All new buildings and structures shall conform to the bulk regulations established herein for the district in which each building or structure shall be located. However, parapet walls, steeples, flagpoles, chimneys, cooling towers, elevator bulkheads, fire towers, water towers, stacks, and necessary mechanical appurtenances shall be permitted to exceed the maximum height provisions when erected in accordance with all other ordinances of the Village of Roselle. 
(B)  Maintenance of yards, courts, and other open spaces. The maintenance of yards, courts, and other open spaces and minimum lot area legally required for a building shall be a continuing obligation of the owner of such building or of the property on which it is located as long as the building is in existence. Furthermore, no legally required yards, courts, or other open space or minimum lot area allocated to any building shall by virtue of change of ownership or for any other reason be used to satisfy yard, court, or other open space, or minimum lot area requirements for any other building. 
(C)  Location of required yards, courts,, and other open spaces. All yards, courts, and other open spaces allocated to a building, buildings, or dwelling group shall be located on the same zoning lot as such building, buildings, or dwelling group. 
4.06. - Lots. 
(A)  Number of buildings on a zoning lot: 
(1)  Except in the case of a planned unit development, not more than one principal detached residential building shall be located on a residential lot, nor shall a principal detached residential building be located on the same zoning lot with any other principal building. 
(2)  Where two (2) or more permitted or special uses, each requiring a minimum lot area, are provided in the same building or on the same lot, the required lot area shall be the sum of the areas required for each use individually. Where two (2) or more buildings are proposed to be on the same lot or parcel of land in any of the Business, Office Research or Industrial Districts, such proposal shall be submitted to the plan commission for site plan review and approval prior to the issuance of building permits. 
(B)  Division of zoning lots. No improved zoning lot shall hereafter be divided into two (2) or more zoning lots unless all improved zoning lots resulting from each such division shall conform with all the applicable bulk regulations of the zoning district in which the property is located. 
(C)  Lot area and dimension: 
(1)  Contiguous lots or parcels in single ownership. If two (2) or more contiguous lots or parcels in single ownership are nonconforming with respect to lot area and width for the use district in which they are located, they shall be used or sold only in accordance with the requirements of section 5.02(A) of this ordinance. 
(2)  Single lots or parcels of land. When any single lot is nonconforming with respect to lot area and width for the use district in which it is located, it shall be used only in accordance with the requirements of section 5.02(B) of this ordinance. 
(3)  Minimum lot size. Every building or structure hereafter erected on a lot or parcel of land created subsequent to the effective date of this ordinance shall provide a lot or parcel of land in accordance with the lot size requirements of the district within which it is located. 
(D)  Reserve lots. Reserve lots (flag lots), enabling access to interior areas of a parcel from a dedicated street only, may be permitted in accordance with the following: 
(1)  All lots shall be a minimum of one acre, exclusive of the portion of the lot used as the reserve strip; 
(2)  Each reserve strip providing access to a lot shall be not less than twenty (20) feet in width; 
(3)  Not more than three (3) lots consisting of two (2) reserve lots with reserve strips, each twenty (20) feet in width, and one key lot with a frontage of not less than one hundred twenty-five (125) feet wide along the dedicated street shall be permitted; 
(4)  All reserve lots shall be subdivided in accordance with the subdivision regulations; and 
(5)  Where more than one reserve lot is created, the two (2) reserve strips, i.e., forty-foot access to interior lots, shall be marked as a private easement of access to interior lots, with only one permitted entrance to the dedicated street. 
(E)  Clear sight distance easement-Corner lots. All corner lots shall provide a clear sight distance easement. This easement shall begin no higher than three (3) feet above the centerline grade of the intersecting roadways and shall extend upward unoccupied and unobstructed from that point to the sky. The easement shall be located within the sight triangle (see definitions, section 3.02) and shall be measured along the intersecting right-of-way lines in accordance with the following specifications: 
(1)  All Residence Districts: Not less than twenty-five (25) feet. 
(2)  All Business, Office Research, or Industrial Districts: Not less than twenty (20) feet. 
(F)  Access to public streets. Except as otherwise provided for herein, every building shall be constructed or erected upon a lot or parcel of land which abuts upon a public street, unless a permanent easement of access to a public street was recorded prior to the adoption of the ordinance. 
(G)  Access across residential lot. No lot or parcel of land which is located in a Residence District shall be used for driveway, walkway, or access purposes to any land which is located in a Business, Office Research, or Industrial District or used for any purpose not permitted in a Residence District except in the case of planned unit developments. 
4.07. - Yard requirements. 
(A)  Yards, general: 
(1)  The minimum yard space required for one building or structure shall not again be considered as yard space for another adjoining building or structure. 
(2)  No lot shall be reduced in area so that the yards or other open spaces become less than required by this ordinance. 
(3)  Where fifty (50) percent or more of the frontage of a block has been developed with existing buildings, there shall be maintained a front yard setback for new construction of not less than the average existing setback or fifty (50) feet, whichever is smaller. 
(4)  On a vacant through or corner lot, either of the lot lines abutting a street right-of-way line may be established as its front lot line. However, where two (2) or more through lots are contiguous and a front lot line has been duly established, the same street lot line shall thereafter be deemed to be the front lot line of all such contiguous lots. On a through lot a front yard shall be provided along any lot line abutting a street. 
(5)  For the purpose of establishing permitted obstruction and setback lines, any yard which adjoins a street shall be considered a front yard except where otherwise provided. 
(B)  Permitted obstructions in required yards. The following accessory buildings, structures, and uses are permitted and may be obstructions in required yards as follows: 
Note:  F-Denotes permitted obstruction in front yards and side yards adjoining streets. 
S-Denotes permitted obstruction in interior side yards. 
R-Denotes permitted obstruction in rear yards. 
(1) Awnings or canopies for residential buildings which may project not more than three (3) feet. FSR (2) Arbors or trellises, freestanding. Where trellises are attached to the principal building, they may also project into a required yard. FSR (3) Air conditioning equipment: window units may project not more than two (2) feet: central air conditioning units may project by not more than six (6) feet, provided the unit is adequately screened. SR (4) Architectural entrance structures on a lot not less than one acre in area or at entrance roadways into subdivisions or planned unit developments containing twenty-five (25) or more lots. Such entrance structure may project to within five (5) feet of the lot line except on corner lots as provided in section 4.06(D). FSR (5) Balconies, projecting not more than four (4) feet. FR (6) Bay windows, projecting not more than three (3) feet. FR (7) Chimneys, attached, projecting not more than twenty-four (24) inches. FSR (8) Eaves and gutters on principal buildings or attached accessory buildings, projecting not more than eighteen (18) inches. FSR (9) Flagpoles. FSR (10) Garages or carports, detached (see zoning districts for limitations). SR (11) Lawn and garden equipment storage building. R (12) Open entrances, stoops, porches, terraces, when not covered, may project not more than ten (10) feet. FR (13) Open off-street loading spaces accessory to nonresidential uses, and open off-street parking spaces (see section 11.00, off-street parking and loading). (14) Ornamental light standards. FSR (15) Playground and laundry-drying equipment. R (16) Signs and name plates, see Article II, Chapter 17, entitled "Signs," of the Code of Ordinances of the Village of Roselle. (17) Sills, belt courses, cornices, and ornamental features of the principal buildings, projecting not more than eighteen (18) inches. FSR (18) Steps, four (4) feet or less above grade, which are necessary for access to a permitted building or for access to a zoning lot from a street or alley. FSR (19) Swimming pools, personal, when conforming also with other codes or ordinances of the village. R (20) Tennis courts, personal. R (21) Terraces, patios, decks, and outdoor fireplaces. R (22) Trees, shrubs and other plants (see section 4.06(D)). FSR  
4.08. - Accessory buildings, structures and uses. 
(A)  Time of construction. No accessory building, structure, or use shall be constructed or established prior to the time of construction or establishment of the principal building, structure, or use to which it is accessory. 
(B)  Yard requirements. Unless otherwise determined in specific zoning districts, accessory buildings, structures, and uses shall comply with the following yard requirements: 
(1)  Accessory buildings, structures, or uses may be attached to, established within, or detached from the principal building, structure, or use of land. 
(2)  All accessory buildings, structures, or uses shall comply with the front and corner side yard requirement of the zoning district in which located. 
(3)  Accessory buildings, structures, or uses attached to or established within the principal building or structure shall comply with the rear yard and interior side yard requirements of the zoning district in which located. 
(4)  Detached accessory buildings, structures, or uses may be located in the required rear yard or interior side yard of any zoning district. (See individual zoning districts for specific setback requirements.) Detached accessory buildings, structures or uses shall not be located within a corner side yard. 
(5)  [ Reserved. ] 
(6)  Accessory buildings, structures, or uses shall not be located on or within any utility or drainage easement created by a duly recorded document. 
(C)  Height limitations. All accessory buildings, structures, or uses shall comply with the height limitations of the zoning district in which located. However, in all Residence Districts the height of an accessory building, structure, or use shall not exceed fifteen (15) feet. 
(D)  Bulk regulations. All accessory buildings or structures shall comply with the bulk regulations of the zoning district in which they are located. The area of any and all the accessory building or structures shall be added to the area of any primary structure in the computation of the floor area ratio and comprehensive lot coverage. The combination of the area shall not exceed the bulk regulations of this ordinance unless a variance is granted in conformance with the other provisions of this code. In addition, accessory structures in residential zoning districts shall be subject to the following requirements: 
(1)  Garages. All garages shall be limited to one per zoning lot for zoning lots that are less than one (1) acre (forty-three thousand five hundred sixty (43,560) square feet) in area. Zoning lots that are at least one (1) acre in area or greater may be permitted a second garage as a special use subject to the special use provisions of section 13.11 this appendix. 
a.  Attached garages. The maximum area shall not exceed the total gross floor area of the residence. 
b.  Detached garages. The maximum area shall not exceed seven hundred sixty-eight (768) square feet. 
c.  Garage bonus. The first two hundred (200) square feet of all garages shall be excluded from comprehensive lot coverage and floor area ratio calculations as defined herein. 
(2)  The maximum size of a shed shall be one hundred twenty (120) square feet, and sheds shall be limited to one per zoning lot. 
(E)  [ Reserved. ] 
(F)  Barbed wire. 
(1)  Barbed wire shall be permitted as an accessory use to the utility and public service uses otherwise allowed in each zoning district provided. 
(2)  Where allowed, the barbed wire shall be placed at least six (6) feet above grade. It shall not be placed over a property line. 
(Ord. No. 2110-91,  3, 8-26-91; Ord. No. 2125-91,  2, 10-14-91; Ord. No. 2135-91,  1, 11-25-91; Ord. No. 2003-2988,  2, 4-14-03; Ord. No. 2005-3149,  1, 1-24-05; Ord. No. 2009-3445,  3, 4-13-09) 
4.09. - Floodplain regulations.[2] 
    This section of the Roselle Zoning Ordinance is designed to balance future development with physical environmental conditions by controlling the use of all floodplains and/or wetland areas in the Village of Roselle. 
(A)  Methodology of floodplain delineation. The floodplain shall be the high-water elevation and limits of the base flood as established by the most recent and best available data. Thedata to be used are listed below in descending order of accuracy, completeness, and currentness. When data of higher order become available, data of lower order will not be used. 
(1)  Federal Emergency Management Administration (FEMA)- Flood Insurance Studies (FIS) as certified by Illinois Department of Transportation, Division of Water Resources (IDOT-DWR). 
(2)  IDOT-DWR Regulatory Flood Plain Maps and Profiles. 
(3)  Soil Conservation Service-Metropolitan Sanitary District of Greater Chicago (SCS-MSDGC) Flood-Water Management Plans, using the "without project." 
(4)  Other detailed one hundred-year flood studies, if certified by IDOT-DWR. 
(5)  FEMA Flood Hazard Boundary Maps (FHBM) and approximate FIS data. 
(6)  USGS maps of flood-prone areas. 
(7)  USGS-NIPC Hydrologic Investigation Atlases (Floods of Records). 
When using maps under items (5) and (6) above, the regulatory high-water elevation shall be those of the flood of record. 
(B)  Purpose. The following criteria and purposes are established for the utilization and control of such floodplains and/or wetland areas: 
(1)  To consider flooding and drainage problems as space allocation or land use problems and to the degree practicable allocate the natural storage space, floodplains and wetlands, for this purpose. 
(2)  To use floodplains and wetlands for land use purposes which are compatible with their physical conditions, thereby preventing the creation of any new flood and drainage problems. 
(3)  To avoid the increase of upstream and downstream flood risks by preventing increased runoff and a redistribution of flood waters. 
(4)  To preserve and possibly enhance the quality of ground and surface water resources by helping to control excess infiltration into sanitary sewer systems and by prohibiting the location of septic systems and mixed fills in unfavorable physical environment. 
(5)  To preserve and possibly enhance the quality of groundwater supplies by maintaining open and undisturbed prime natural groundwater recharge areas. 
(6)  To preserve distinctive floodplain and wetland flora and fauna. 
(7)  To consider floodplain and wetland areas in density consideration in zoning and subdivision determinations. 
(8)  To lessen or avoid the hazards to persons and damage to property resulting from the accumulation or runoff of storm or flood waters, as essential for the health, safety and general welfare of the people of the Village of Roselle. 
(C)  Definitions. For the purpose of this ordinance, the definitions included in section 3.02, definitions, under "floodwater (stormwater) management regulations" shall apply. 
(D)  General provisions for floodplain. Mobile homes are not permitted in the special flood hazard area (SFHA). No development shall take place in channel areas (floodway) required to carry normal flow. Floodplain and/or wetland area(s) within the Village of Roselle shall not be disturbed, reshaped or otherwise affected by channel relocation, channel deepening, filling or grading of any type, or the erection of any structure (including but not limited to buildings, culverts, docks, dams or bulkheads), or the storage of any materials or equipment, except by special use permit. A special use permit will be required for normal maintenance of waterways, provided such maintenance is limited to the removal of accumulated debris and the control of vegetation which has the potential to interfere with flows in the waterways. 
(E)  Permitted uses in the floodplain. When permitted by the underlying base zoning district and upon issuance of a special use permit, the following uses shall be permitted within the floodplain and/or wetland area to the extent that they are not prohibited by any law or other provision of this ordinance: Agricultural uses without permanent buildings, such as, but not limited to, general farming, pasture, grazing, outdoor plant nurseries, floriculture, apiculture, horticulture, viticulture, truck farming, forestry, sod farming and wild crop harvesting; private or public recreational uses such as golf courses, tennis courts, golf driving ranges, hunting and fishing areas, hiking, horseback riding and bicycle riding areas; and portions of industrial, commercial, institutional, and residential uses such as natural areas, lawns, and unpaved play areas. 
(F)  Special uses in the floodplain. Special use permits shall be issued only after review and recommendation by the plan commission, public hearing and recommendation by the zoning board of appeals, and adoption of a special use ordinance by the president and board of trustees. All development in the floodplain area(s) granted a special use permit shall comply with the following provisions: 
(1)  No person, firm, or corporation shall commence any construction, substantial improvement, subdivision of land, placement of mobile homes or other development in the areas located in an "A Zone" without first obtaining a permit from the village engineer. The village engineer shall not issue such permit for construction substantial improvement, or other development that does not comply with the provisions of this ordinance or that has been denied a permit required by the federal or state law including Section 404, of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, 1972, 33 U.S.C. 1334. 
(2)  Within areas designated as "A Zones," each application for development shall be accompanied by elevations, in relation to mean sea level, of the lowest floor, including basement, and in the case of floodproof structures, the elevations to which it will be floodproofed. 
(3)  The village engineer shall require certification from a registered professional engineer or architect that floodproofing methods are adequate to withstand the flood depths, pressures, velocities, impact and uplift forces, and other factors associated with the base flood. 
(4)  The application shall also contain information on certification as reasonably may be required by the village engineer in order to determine eligibility for permits or to enforce the terms of this ordinance. 
(5)  The village engineer shall review applications for permit and determine before issuing a permit that the development activity would be reasonably safe from flood damage. 
(6)  All required federal and state permits shall be obtained. 
(G)  Prevention of increased damages: 
(1)  No development in the special flood hazard area shall create a damaging or potentially damaging increase in flood heights or velocity. 
For development proposals located in an identified floodway or within a riverine special flood hazard area where the floodway has not yet been identified, the following rule shall apply: The village engineer shall review the development plans to discern if: 
a.  A new obstruction to flood flows would be created; 
b.  The project will involve a channel crossing such as a bridge or pipeline; or 
c.  The project will modify the shape of the channel. 
If any of these three (3) situations will result from the project, the applicant shall be required to obtain a permit from the Illinois Department of Transportation, Division of Water Resources, issued pursuant to Illinois Revised Statutes Chapter 19, Section 70. The village engineer shall not approve issuance of a building permit unless the applicant has obtained either a Section 70 permit or a "waiver of permit required" from the Division of Water Resources. 
For development proposals located in a flood fringe, "AO Zone" or "AH Zone," identified as such on a special flood hazard area map or in a lakefront floodplain, ponding area, area of sheet flow, or other special flood hazard areas not subject to overbank flooding from an identified channel, the requirements of this subsection 4.09(G)(1) shall not apply. 
(2)  No development in the special flood hazard area shall include locating or storing chemicals, explosives, buoyant materials, flammable liquids, pollutants, or other hazardous or toxic materials below the floodplain elevation unless such materials are stored in a storage tank or floodproofed building constructed according to the requirements of section 4.09(H), protection of buildings, of this ordinance. 
(3)  Utilities standards shall be in conformance with section 4.09(K), utility standards, of this ordinance. 
(H)  Protection of buildings. In addition to the damage prevention requirements of section 4.09(G), prevention of increased damages, all buildings to be located in the special flood hazard area shall be protected from flood damage below floodplain elevation. This building protection requirement applies to the following situations: 
(1)  Construction or placement of a new building valued at more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00); 
(2)  Improvements made to an existing building that increase the first floor area by more than twenty (20) percent; 
(3)  Reconstruction or repairs made to a damaged building that are valued at or more than fifty (50) percent of the value of the building before the damaged occurred. This building protection requirement may be met by any one of the following methods: 
(1)  A building may be constructed on permanent land fill in accordance with the following: 
a.  The area to be filled shall be cleared of all standing trees, brush, down timber, trash, or other growth or objects unsuitable for use as foundation materials; 
b.  The fill shall be placed in layers no greater than one foot deep before compaction; 
c.  The surface of the fill shall be at or above the floodplain elevation. The fill shall extend at least ten (10) feet beyond the foundation of the building before sloping below the floodplain elevation. The lowest floor including basement, shall be at or above the floodplain elevation; 
d.  The fill shall be protected against erosion and scour during vegetative cover, rip rap, or bulkheading. If vegetation cover is used the slopes shall be no steeper than three (3) horizontal to one vertical; 
e.  The fill shall not adversely affect the flow of surface drainage from or onto neighboring properties; and 
f.  The village engineer shall maintain a record of the "as built" elevation of the lowest floor of the building. 
(2)  A building may be elevated in accordance with the following: 
a.  The building or improvement shall be elevated on stilts, piles, walls, crawl space, or other foundation that is permanently open to floodwaters and not subject to change by hydrostatic pressures; 
b.  The foundation and supporting members shall be anchored, shaped and aligned so as to minimize exposure to known hydrodynamic forces such as current, waves, and floating debris; 
c.  All areas below the floodplain elevations shall be constructed of materials resistant to flood damage. The bottom of the joists of the lowest floor and all utility meters shall be located above or at the floodplain elevation; 
d.  The village engineer shall maintain a record of the "as built" elevation of the lowest floor; 
e.  No area below the floodplain elevation shall be used for storage of items or materials subject to flood damage unless such items or materials are declared subject to flood damage unless such items or materials are declared "property and covered" by a standard flood insurance policy of the National Flood Insurance Program; and 
f.  Any future alteration of the area below the floodplain elevation that violates the requirements of this section shall be deemed a violation of this ordinance. The village engineer shall inform the applicant that any such alteration is considered a willful act to increase flood damages and therefore will cause coverage by a standard flood insurance policy to be suspended. 
(3)  A nonresidential building may be floodproofed in accordance with the following: 
a.  A registered professional engineer shall certify that the building has been designed so that below the floodplain elevation, the structure and attendant utility facilities are watertight and capable of resisting the effects of the base flood. The building design shall take into account flood velocities, duration, rate of rise, hydrostatic and hydrodynamic forces, the effects of buoyance, the impacts from debris or ice; 
b.  Floodproofing measures shall be operable without human intervention and without an outside source of electricity; and 
c.  The village engineer shall maintain the engineer's certificate and record of the "as built" elevation to which the building was floodproofed. 
(I)  New construction in the floodplain. All new construction and substantial improvements to structures located in an "A Zone" shall conform to the following: 
(1)  Residential structures. The lowest floor and opening including door sill, window sill, top of foundation, and any other openings in the outer wall, including basement, shall be elevated to one foot above the base flood elevation; 
(2)  Nonresidential structures shall have the lowest floor and opening including door sill, window sill, top of foundation and any other openings in the outer wall, including basement, elevated or floodproofed to one foot above the base flood elevation; 
(3)  Be designed or modified and adequately anchored to prevent flotation, collapse, or lateral movement of the structure; 
(4)  Be constructed with materials and utility equipment resistant to flood damage; 
(5)  Be constructed by methods and practices that minimize flood damage to other properties; 
(6)  Have all structural components below the base flood elevation designed to be watertight with walls substantially impermeable to the passage of water, and such structural components shall be designed to resist hydrostatic and hydrodynamic loads and the effects of buoyancy; and 
(7)  For any proposed development, the village board shall take into account flood hazards to the extent that they are known, in all official actions related to land management, use and development. 
a.  The village board shall not approve any annexation agreement or plat of subdivision located outside the corporate limits unless such agreement or plat is in accordance with the provisions of the zoning ordinance and Roselle Code. The village engineer shall obtain and maintain the best available special flood hazard area maps and data for areas being annexed to the village. 
b.  New subdivisions and planned unit developments (PUDs) shall meet the requirements of all sections of this ordinance. Plats or plans for new subdivisions, and PUDs shall include a signed statement by a registered professional engineer that the plat or plans account for changes in drainage of surface waters in accordance with Plat Act Illinois Revised Statutes 1979, Chapter 109, paragraph 2. 
c.  Plats or plans for new subdivisions, and PUDs shall display the following flood data: 
1.  The boundary of the special flood hazard area; 
2.  The boundary of the floodway, if shown on available special flood hazard area maps; 
3.  Easements of lands dedicated to the Village of Roselle for channel maintenance purposes; and 
4.  The floodplain elevation for each building site. Where the base flood elevation is not available from an existing study filed with the Illinois State Water Survey, the applicant shall be responsible for calculating the floodplain elevation and submitting it to the state water survey for review and approval at least available elevation data. 
d.  Plans for the development activities to be undertaken by the Village of Roselle in the special flood hazard area shall be reviewed by the village engineer to ensure that they comply with this ordinance. Except as exempted by law, no other local government shall commence any development activity in the special flood hazard area without first obtaining a development permit from the village engineer. 
e.  The village board shall take the following into consideration with preparing or revising the comprehensive plan, community development program, housing assistance plan, and other land use or development programs: 
1.  Preserving special flood hazard area land for open space uses such as farming or recreation; 
2.  Acquiring and removing frequently flooded buildings; 
3.  Prohibiting hospitals, water treatment plants, gas storage and other critical or specially hazardous facilities from locating in the special flood hazard area; 
4.  Identifying the elevations of the base flood and past floods, at entrances to public buildings on street signs, or other prominent locations; and 
5.  Other flood hazard mitigation or floodplain management activities that could help accomplish the purposes of this ordinance. 
(J)  Base flood elevation. The president and board of trustees shall obtain, review, and reasonably utilize the base flood elevation data available from federal, state or other sources as described in section 4.09(A). 
(K)  Utility standards. All new construction and substantial improvements to utilities located in an "A Zone" shall provide that: 
(1)  All new and replacement water supply systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of flood waters into the systems; 
(2)  All new and replacement sanitary sewage systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of flood waters into the systems and discharges from the systems into the floodwaters; 
(3)  All new and replacement on-site waste disposal systems shall be located to avoid impairment to them or contamination from them during flooding; and 
(4)  All sanitary sewer manholes constructed in the floodplain must be provided with watertight lock-type covers or the rims must be raised to an elevation not lower than twelve (12) inches above high water elevation. 
(L)  Watercourse standards. The village engineer shall notify adjacent communities and the Illinois Department of Transportation, Division of Water Resources, and the Federal Insurance Administration prior to any alteration or relocation of a watercourse. The flood carrying capacity within the altered or relocated portion of any watercourse shall be maintained. 
(M)  Reports and records: 
(1)  The village engineer shall provide the president and board of trustees, the Illinois Department of Transportation, Division of Water Resources, and the Federal Insurance Administration with an annual report on forms as provided the village by the Federal Insurance Administration. 
(2)  The village engineer shall maintain the records of lowest floor elevations, floodproofing, certifications, all variance documents required by Section 1910.6(a)(5) and (6) of the Rules and Regulations of the National Flood Insurance Program, permit applications, and all other records required by the Federal Insurance Administration. 
(N)  Variances. Upon application and after fifteen (15) days' notice of a public hearing, the president and board of trustees may grant a variance of this ordinance subject to compliance with the provisions of Section 1910.6(a) of the Rules and Regulations of the National Flood Insurance Program and such other conditions as the village president and board of trustees deem necessary to comply with the intent of this ordinance. The following guidelines shall be used for variances. 
(1)  The applicant must demonstrate that: 
a.  The development activity cannot be located outside the special flood hazard area; 
b.  A substantial economic hardship would result if a variance were not granted; 
c.  The relief requested is the minimum necessary; 
d.  There will be no additional threat to public health or safety or creation of a nuisance; 
e.  There will be no additional public expense for flood protection, rescue or relief operations, policing, or repairs to roads, utilities, or other public facilities; and 
f.  That all other provisions of this ordinance can still be met. 
(2)  The village engineer shall notify an applicant in writing that a variance from the requirements of section 4.09(H) of this ordinance, protection of buildings, that would lessen the degree of protection to a building will: 
a.  Result in increased premium rates for flood insurance up to amounts as high as twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for one hundred dollars ($100.00) of insurance coverage; 
b.  Increase the risks to life and property; and 
c.  That he will acknowledge in writing that he assumes the risk and liability. 
(3)  A variance from the requirements of section 4.09(H) of this ordinance, protection of buildings, may be granted to permit a "wet floodproofed," nonresidential building, that is a building to be intentionally flooded during a flood provided: 
a.  No part of such a building below the flood plain elevation may be subject to flood damage. 
b.  The variance shall be conditioned on the contents being: 
1.  Of materials resistant to flood damage; or 
2.  Items declared "property not covered" by a standard flood insurance policy of the National Flood Insurance Program; or 
3.  Readily moveable to a place of protection during a flood provided there will be personnel available and adequate warning. 
c.  Any future alteration of the area below the flood plain elevation that violates the conditions of the variance shall be deemed a violation of this ordinance. The village engineer shall inform the applicant that any such alteration is considered a willful act to increase flood damages and therefore will cause coverage by a standard flood insurance policy to be suspended. 
(4)  Variances requested in connection with restoration of a site or building documented as worthy of preservation by the Illinois Department of Conservation may be granted using criteria more permissive than the requirements of section 4.09(N)(1), of this ordinance. 
(5)  In granting a variance, the village board may require such variance be entered as a restriction on the deed for the property for which the variance is granted. 
(O)  Disclaimer of liability. The degree of flood protection required by this ordinance is considered reasonable for regulatory purposes and is based on available information derived from engineering and scientific methods of study. Larger floods may occur and flood heights may be increased by manmade or natural causes. This ordinance does not imply that development either inside or outside of the special flood hazard area will be free from flooding or damage. This ordinance does not create liability on the part of the Village of Roselle or any officer or employee thereof, for any flood damage that results from reliance on this ordinance or any administrative decision made lawfully thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 1405-86,  1, 1-29-86)

4.10. - Stormwater detention.[3] 
(A)  A combination of storage and controlled release of stormwater runoff shall be required for all commercial-industrial developments, for all multiple-family residential developments, for all single-family developments and single-family residences. 
(B)  The release rate of stormwater from all developments requiring detention shall not exceed the stormwater runoff rate from the area in its natural undeveloped state. A release rate of not greater than that calculated from a storm of three (3) years frequency with a runoff coefficient of zero point fifteen (0.15) will be acceptable unless the applicant can show by detailed calculations which are acceptable to the village engineer that the discharge rate of the natural outlet channel serving the area is greater. 
(C)  Storm sewer systems shall have adequate capacity to bypass the flow, through the development, from all upstream areas for a storm of design frequency assuming that the land is in a fully developed state under present zoning or any proposed zoning under the comprehensive plan, adopted April 9, 1979. The bypass flow rate shall be computed utilizing a runoff coefficient of not less than zero point three five (0.35). An allowance, equivalent to the reduction in flow rate provided, will be made for upstream detention when such upstream detention and release rate has previously been approved by the village and has been constructed. 
(D)  The live detention storage to be provided shall be calculated on the basis of one hundred-year frequency rainfall, as published by the U.S. Weather Bureau for this area. The detention volume required shall be that necessary to temporarily store the runoff of a one hundred-year rainfall, for any and all durations, from the fully developed drainage area tributary to the reservoir, less that volume discharged during the same duration at the approved release rate. 
(E)  Where any portion of the proposed development is a floodplain as defined in section 4.09, the volume shall be added to the volume of storage computed in accordance with paragraph (D) above. 
(F)  All detention facilities located on private property shall be privately maintained by the property owner. 
(G)  Where it is not practical for the property owner to construct a retention facility on his own property he may combine his requirements with those of another property owner to construct a joint facility or he may contract with the Village of Roselle to furnish the necessary storage. The cost of the storage would be eight thousand dollars ($8,000.00) per acre foot or the actual cost of the storage facility. 
(H)  The stormwater may be stored in a pond or in a basement or other underground storage area. Roofs may not be used for storage. Preliminary stormwater storage plans, including the concept and site plan details, shall be approved by the plan [planning and zoning] commission. 
(I)  In the event the downstream sewers are inadequate to receive the release rate hereinabove provided, then the allowable release rate shall be reduced to that rate permitted by the receiving downstream sewers and additional detention as determined by the village engineer shall be required to store that portion of the runoff exceeding the capacity of the receiving sewers. 
(J)  Plans, specifications and calculations for stormwater detention facilities in compliance with the plans approved by the plan commission as required herein, shall be submitted to the village engineer for approval prior to the issuance of a building permit. 
(K)  Stormwater management facilities: 
(1)  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to provide uniform standards by which stormwater detention/retention facilities should be designed and constructed in a manner which is functional and aesthetically pleasing. It is the goal of the Village of Roselle to combine stormwater detention/retention ponds where practical in one large facility in lieu of numerous scattered locations. 
(2)  Detention ponds shall be designed to serve a secondary purpose for recreation, open space or other types of uses that will not be adversely affected by occasional or intermittent flooding. The facility must be designed so that it is maintainable. An approved method of carrying the low flow through these areas shall be provided to a positive gravity outlet. 
(3)  The combination of storage water from the one hundred-year storm and the design release rate shall not result in a storage duration in excess of seventy-two (72) hours. Maximum depth of planned stormwater storage facilities shall not exceed four (4) feet unless the existing natural ground contours and other conditions lend to greater storage depth, which shall be approved by the village. Parking lots may not be used for storage if the maximum depth is greater then six (6) inches. Minimum grades for turf areas shall be one and one-half (11/2) percent and maximum slopes shall be six (6) to one (six (6) units horizontally to one unit vertically). Storage area side slopes shall be kept as close to natural land contours as practical and a six (6) to one side slope or less shall be used where possible. If slopes greater than six (6) to one are necessary to meet storage requirements or area restrictions, approvals shall be obtained from the village engineer and suitable erosion control provided in addition to the protection required to insure public health, safety and welfare. Pit type detention ponds with vertical side slopes are strictly prohibited. 
(4)  Outlet control structures shall be designed as simply as possible and shall require little or no attention for proper operation. If periodic maintenance of the proposed outlet control structure will be necessary adequate service drives must be provided at an elevation above the design high water level. Ingress/egress easements must be provided for any service drive. Each stormwater storage area shall be provided witha method of emergency overflow in the event that a storm in excess of the one hundred-year frequency storm occurs or the outlet structure fails. This emergency overflow facility shall be designed to function without attention. Any overflows from the emergency overflow must be directed to a natural surface channel through a drainage easement. No obstructive structures may be constructed within the overflow drainageway. Hydraulic calculations shall be submitted to substantiate all design features of the outlet control structure and emergency overflow facility. 
(5)  Both the outlet control structure and emergency overflow facilities shall be designed and constructed to fully protect public health, safety and welfare. Stormwater velocities shall be kept to a minimum and turbulent conditions at an outlet structure will not be permitted without complete protection for public safety. When excessive velocities greater than the maximum permissible velocity or the nonerodible velocity will occur, an approved maintainable method to stabilize the channel must be submitted to the village engineer for approval. 
(6)  A maintenance plan for each detention pond must be submitted for approval. The plan must indicate areas which require continual maintenance on a regular basis and unusual items which occur on an infrequent basis. The plan must provide for periodic inspection of all facilities on a regular basis of not less than annually or after all major storm events. The maintenance plan must be submitted along with the construction plans for the detention pond. 
(7)  Retention ponds shall be designed with all of the items required for a detention pond except that a low flow conduit and a system of drains with a positive outlet shall be eliminated. The following additional conditions shall be complied with: 
a.  Water surface shall not exceed one-tenth ( 1/10 ) of the tributary drainage area. 
b.  Shoreline protection shall be provided to prevent erosion from wave action. This protection must be provided from a minimum of one foot above the design highwater level to one foot below the design normal water level. The method of shoreline protection must be approved by the village. The maintenance plan must address the frequency for repairing the shoreline protection system. The shoreline protection system must be inspected not less than annually. 
c.  Minimum normal water depth shall be four (4) feet. If fish life is desirable, a minimum of one-third ( 1/3 ) of the pond area shall be a minimum of twelve (12) feet deep. 
d.  Facilities shall be available, if possible, to allow the pond level to be lowered by gravity flow for cleaning purposes and shoreline maintenance. 
e.  Control structures for stormwater release shall be designed to operate at full capacity with only a minor increase in the water surface level. Hydraulic calculations shall be submitted to substantiate all design features. 
f.  Aeration facilities to prevent pond stagnation shall be provided. Design calculation to substantiate the effectiveness of these aeration facilities shall be submitted with final engineering plans. Agreements for the perpetual operation and maintenance of aeration facilities shall be prepared and approved by the village engineer. 
g.  In the event that the water surface of the pond is to be raised for purposes of storing water for irrigation or in anticipation of the evapotranspiration demands of dry weather, the volume remaining for storage of excess stormwater runoff shall still be sufficient to contain the one hundred-year storm runoff. 
h.  The design of retention ponds shall consider the inflow of sediment from upstream areas. A method for capturing sediment in a method and location which is maintainable shall be considered during design. The need and frequency for removing sediment shall be addressed in the maintenance plan. 
(8)  Plans, specifications and all calculations for stormwater runoff control as required hereunder shall be submitted to the village engineer for review and approval prior to the approval of a final plat, in the case of subdivisions and planned unit developments, or issuance of a building permit, in the case of commercial or industrial construction. 
(9)  Where development of a property presents the threat of flooding or damage by flash runoff to downstream residents, the facilities for stormwater runoff control shall be constructed prior to any earthmoving or drainage construction on the project site. 
(10)  The construction of the stormwater control system shall be accomplished as part of the cost of land development. If the amount of storage capacity can be increased to provide benefit to the village negotiations for public participation in the cost of development may be feasible. 
(11)  The ability to retain and maximize the ground water recharge capacity of the area being developed is encouraged. Design of the stormwater runoff control system shall give consideration to providing groundwater recharge to compensate for the reduction in percolation that occurs when the ground surface is paved and roofed over. Specific design calculations and details shall be provided with the final plans and specifications presented for village review. The use of natural gravel deposits for the lower portions of storm runoff storage areas, the flattening of drainage slopes and the retention of existing topography are examples of possible recharge methods. 
(12)  During the construction phases of land development, facilities shall be provided to prevent the erosion and washing away of the earth. Silting of downstream areas can be prevented through the strategic use of stilling basins, sodding of runoff channels, and by limiting the period of time during which the earth is stripped of vegetation. 
(13)  Final engineering plans prepared by a registered professional engineer shall show complete details for all of the items covered in this section and shall be submitted for review and approved prior to the start of construction. 
(14)  It shall be unlawful for the owner of any property which has been improved, graded or developed in accordance with final engineering plans approved pursuant to this section or upon which a control structure has been installed or a by-pass channel or stormwater storage area has been constructed in accordance with such engineering plans, to alter or change any structure, grade, contour line, by-pass channel or stormwater storage area in contravention of such approved engineering plans; to alter or remove any control structure required by such approved engineering plans; to not perform the maintenance items in accordance with the approved maintenance plan; or to allow the property to remain in a condition which does not conform to such approved engineering plans in any respect. 
(15)  Enforcement. The village engineer is hereby authorized and directed to enforce all of the provisions of this chapter [appendix]. Upon presentation of proper credentials, the village engineer and his duly authorized representatives may enter at reasonable times upon any property within the village to investigate or ascertain the condition of the subject property in regard to any aspect regulated by this section. 
(16)  Duty of property owner. It shall be the duty of the owner of any property required to be improved or developed in conformance with final engineering plans approved pursuant to this section to bring such property into compliance with said engineering plans within thirty (30) days of receipt of notice from the village engineer that a determination has been made that the said property does not conform to final engineering plans under which said property was improved or developed. 
(17)  Variations. Because of the unique characteristics and existing intense development of a property, it is recognized that strict compliance with the stormwater detention regulations may create a particular hardship on the property owner. The owner of property may petition the village board for a variation from the stormwater detention regulations. No variation shall be granted except after a public hearing before the village board. 
(Ord. No. 1604-87, ㎣ 1, 2, 8-24-87; Ord. No. 2513-96,  1, 5-13-96)
