(b)  Light pole height limits. Poles supporting lights shall be no taller than twenty-three (23) feet in a residential zoning district; twenty-five (25) feet in a commercial district, a commercial portion of a residential planned unit development, or in office/business park districts, and thirty-two (32) feet in any industrial district. 
(4)  Glare. 
(a)  No land use or other activity in the village shall be conducted so that direct and indirect illumination from a point source of light causes illumination in excess of 0.2 foot-candles, as measured horizontally at the lot line at a height of three and one-half (31/2) feet above ground, at lot lines abutting residential districts, or 0.5 foot-candles at any lot line abutting a nonresidential district. 
(b)  For areas where a nonresidential district abuts another nonresidential district, no land use or other activity in the Village shall be conducted so that direct and indirect illumination from a point source of light shall cause illumination in excess of 2.0 foot-candles, as measured horizontally at the lot line at a height of three and one-half (31/2) feet above ground, at the lot line between said districts. 
(c)  In no event shall light fall upon a right of way in excess of one-half (1/2) foot candles. 
(5)  Lighting plan. 
(a)  A lighting plan shall be submitted to the village any time exterior lighting is proposed or modified that is associated with a residential use of greater density than a one-or two-family dwelling, or with any commercial, office, industrial or other use. The lighting plan shall be submitted with site plan information or independently if a site plan is not required. 
(b)  The lighting plan shall include a plan indicating the location of all light fixtures and the intensity of foot-candles at various points on the site, catalog cuts of the proposed fixtures, and a summary table containing average foot-candles, minimum foot-candles, maximum foot-candles, uniformity ratio (average/minimum), foot-candles at the property line, pole height, and light loss factor (LLF). The plan shall be sufficient to determine whether the proposed plan of lighting complies with this section. The plan shall also contain a certification by the property owner or agent and the preparer of the plan that the exterior lighting depicted on the plan complies with the requirements of this chapter. Once the lighting plan is approved, the exterior lighting of the property shall conform to and be maintained in conformance with the plan. If the exterior lighting as installed does not comply with this section, the owner shall make those revisions necessary to bring the lighting plan into conformance with this section. 
(6)  Exceptions and variances. 
(a)  Because of their unique requirement for nighttime visibility and their limited hours of operation, ball diamonds, playing fields, tennis courts, and other outdoor recreational facilities shall be exempted from the general standards of this section. Lighting for outdoor recreational facilities shall be shielded to minimize light and glare from spilling onto adjacent residential properties. The maximum permitted illumination at adjoining residential property lines shall be one foot candle. The maximum permitted illumination at adjoining nonresidential property lines shall be two (2) foot-candles. 
(b)  Luminaries used for public roadway illumination by a public transportation agency shall be exempt from the requirements of this section. 
(c)  Temporary emergency lighting used by police, firefighters, and other emergency services, as well as all vehicular luminaries, shall be exempt from the requirements of this section. 
(d)  Hazard warning lights that are required by local or federal regulatory agencies shall be exempt from the requirements of this section. 
(e)  Transportation facilities shall be exempt from the requirements of this section. 
(f)  Public walkways shall be exempt from the requirements of this section. 
(g)  When site characteristics are unique and the requirements of this section cannot be met, the Zoning Board of Appeals in the Village of Roselle may, at its discretion, approve nonconforming lighting designs if the illumination levels and/or uniformity ratios are not greater than twenty (20) percent of the values set forth in this section. All other nonconforming designs shall be subject to the approval of the village board of trustees through either annexation or development agreement. 
(7)  Nonconforming luminaries. Exterior lighting luminaries in existence on the effective date of this section shall be exempt from the standards of this section and shall be considered legally nonconforming. Such fixtures may be repaired and maintained. However, if any legal nonconforming luminaire is moved or damaged by any means to an extent that its total replacement is necessary, the luminaire, or replacement, shall comply with this section. For development activity involving an improved property, luminaires shall be required to comply with this section when the floor area of any building or structure, or parking areas, or any combination thereof, is increased by ten (10) percent or greater. 
(Ord. No. 2002-2923, ㎣ 1-7, 5-13-02) 
SECTION 5.00. - NONCONFORMING BUILDINGS, STRUCTURES AND USES 

5.01. - Statement of purpose. 
    The purpose of this section is to provide for the regulation of nonconforming buildings, structures, lots, and uses thereof, and to specify those circumstances and conditions under which those nonconforming lots shall be used and those nonconforming buildings, structures, and uses shall be gradually eliminated upon reaching the end of their respective normal useful life, in accordance with the authority granted by Illinois Revised Statutes, as amended, Chapter 24, Section 11-13. 
5.02. - Nonconforming lots of record. 
(A)  Contiguous lots in single ownership. When two (2) or more contiguous lots, or a combination of contiguous lots and portions of lots, in single ownership are of record at the time of passage or amendment of this ordinance, and if all or part of the lots do not meet the requirements for lot width and area for the use district in which they are located, the land involved shall be considered to be an undivided parcel for the purpose of this ordinance. No portion of said undivided parcel shall be used or sold which does not meet lot width and area requirements established by this ordinance, nor shall any division of the parcel be made which leaves remaining any lot width or area below the requirements stated in this ordinance. 
(B)  Single lots or parcels of land. When any single lot or parcel of land is of record at the time of passage or amendment of this ordinance and if said lot or parcel does not meet the requirements for lot width and area for the use district in which it is located, it shall be used only in accordance with the following requirements. 
(1)  In any district in which single-family, two-family or three-family dwellings are permitted, said buildings or structures and customary accessory buildings may be erected on a nonconforming lot. However, lot area, widths, and yard requirements shall be not less than eighty (80) percent of the minimum required dimensions. Variances greater than twenty (20) percent shall be obtained only through action by the zoning board of appeals (see section 13.09). 
(2)  In any district in which multiple-family dwellings or nonresidential buildings or structures are permitted, said buildings or structures and customary accessory buildings may be erected on a nonconforming lot. However, lot area, width, and yard requirements shall be not less than ninety (90) percent of the minimum required dimensions. Variances greater than ten (10) percent shall be obtained only through action by the zoning board of appeals (see section 13.09). 
(C)  Use district changes. Whenever the boundaries of a use district shall be changed so as to transfer an area from one use district to another, the foregoing provisions shall also apply to any lots made nonconforming by such change in use district. 
5.03. - Continuance of nonconforming buildings, structures and uses. 
    Any nonconforming building, structure, or use which existed lawfully at the time of the adoption of this ordinance and which remains nonconforming and any building, structure, or use which shall become nonconforming upon the adoption of this ordinance or of any subsequent amendment thereto, may be continued, some indefinitely, others for specified and respective periods of time, subject to the regulations which follow. 
5.04. - Exempted buildings, structures and uses. 
(A)  No building, structure, or use lawfully established on the effective date of this ordinance shall be subject to the amortization provisions of this section solely by reason of being nonconforming with respect to the bulk and other standards prescribed in this ordinance for any of the following: 
(1)  Floor area ratio; 
(2)  Yards, front, side, rear, or transitional; 
(3)  Lot area per dwelling unit; 
(4)  Lot width; 
(5)  Ground floor area per dwelling; 
(6)  Gross floor area; 
(7)  Building height; 
(8)  Off-street parking or off-street loading spaces; or 
(9)  Performance standards. 
(B)  No dwelling lawfully existing on the effective date of this ordinance shall be subject to the amortization provisions of this section. 
(C)  No building, structure or use located in a Business District shall be subject to the amortization provisions of this ordinance if it is a permitted building, structure or use in any Business District, except as provided for elsewhere in this ordinance. 
(D)  No building, structure or use lawfully established on the effective date of this ordinance and located in any Industrial District shall be subject to the amortization provisions of this section. 
(E)  For the purposes of this section a building or structure lawfully constructed or established on the effective date of this ordinance shall be deemed to include any building or structure for which a building permit has been lawfully issued, and on which construction is begun within the required period of time allowed by the unexpired building permit then in effect. 
5.05. - Restrictions on nonconforming buildings and structures, and on uses thereof. 
    Any lawfully existing building or structure which does not conform with the regulations of the district in which it is located shall be subject to the provisions of this subsection. 
(A)  Repairs and alterations. 
(1)  Ordinary repairs and alterations may be made to a nonconforming building or structure. However, no structural alterations except those required by law shall be made in or to such building or structure, all or substantially all of which is designed or intended for a use not permitted in the district in which it is located. Structural alterations may be made in order to make the building or structure and use thereof conform to the regulations of the district in which it is located. For the purpose of this section, ordinary repairs shall include the replacement of storage tanks where the safety of operation of the installation requires such replacement. 
(2)  A nonconforming building in a Residence District which contains residential uses may be altered in any way to improve livability provided no structural alterations shall be made which would increase the number of dwelling units or the bulk of the building. 
(B)  Additions and enlargements. A building or structure which is nonconforming as to bulk, or all or substantially all of which is designed or intended for a use not permitted in the district in which it is located, shall not be added to or enlarged in any manner unless such nonconforming building or structure and use thereof, including all additions and enlargements thereto, are made to conform to all the regulations of the district in which it is located. 
(C)  Moving of nonconforming building or structure. No building or structure which does not conform to all of the regulations of the district in which it is located shall be moved in whole or in part to any other location unless every portion of such building or structure is moved. The elevation of the ground at the original site shall be restored to the natural grade of the lot. The use of the building or structure at the new site shall be made to conform to all regulations of the district into which it is moved. 
(D)  Restoration of damaged nonconforming building or structure. A nonconforming building or structure which is destroyed or damaged by fire or other casualty or act of God to the extent that the cost of restoration to the condition in which it was before the occurrence will exceed fifty (50) percent of the cost of restoration of the entire building or structure new shall not be restored unless said building or structure and use thereof shall conform to all regulations of the district in which it is located. In the event that such damage or destruction is less than fifty (50) percent of the cost of restoration of the entire building or structure new, no repairs or reconstruction shall be made unless such restoration is started within one year from the date of the partial destruction and is diligently prosecuted to completion. 
(E)  Discontinuance of use of nonconforming building or structure. A nonconforming building, structure, or portion thereof, which is vacant on the effective date of this ordinance or thereafter becomes vacant and remains unoccupied, and is not used for a continuous period of six (6) months, shall not thereafter be occupied or used except by a use which conforms to the use regulations of the district in which it is located. 
(F)  Expansion of use in nonconforming building or structure. The use of a part of a nonconforming building or structure, may be expanded within the building or structure in which said use is presently located. However, no changes or structural alterations shall be made unless such changes or structural alterations and the use thereof conform to all the regulations of the district in which the building or structure is located. 
(G)  Change of use in nonconforming building or structure. The use of a nonconforming building or structure may be changed to another use permitted in the district in which the building or structure is located. However, no change shall extend or otherwise modify any provision made in this ordinance for elimination of such nonconforming building or structure and the use thereof. 
(H)  Termination of nonconforming buildings and structures. 
(1)  In Residence Districts any principal building or structure, all or substantially all of which is designed or intended for a use permitted only in a Business, Office Research, or Industrial District, shall be removed, or it shall be altered, remodeled or converted to a building or structure designed for a use permitted in the district in which it is located, within six (6) months after the termination of the respective periods of time set forth hereafter which are fixed as the normal useful life of said buildings and structures. 
(2)  In B-1 and B-2 Districts any principal building or structure, all or substantially all of which is designed or intended for a use permitted only in a B-3, B-4, B-5, ORI, or M Districts, shall be removed, or it shall be altered, remodeled, or converted to a building or structure designed for a use permitted in the district in which it is located, within six (6) months after the determination of the respective periods of time set forth hereafter which are fixed as the normal useful life of said buildings and structures. 
(3)  Amortization periods shall be based on the following schedule: 
a.  Assessed valuation more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) on the effective date of this ordinance. In accordance with the types of construction classifications set forth in the Building Code of the Village of Roselle. 
1.  Fireproof construction and noncombustible construction. Forty (40) years from date of building permit or twenty-five (25) years from effective date of this ordinance, whichever last occurs. 
2.  Exterior masonry wall construction. Thirty (30) years from date of building permit or twenty (20) years from effective date of this ordinance, whichever last occurs. 
3.  Frame construction. Twenty (20) years from date of building permit or ten (10) years from effective date of this ordinance, whichever last occurs. 
b.  Assessed valuation at least two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) but not more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) on the effective date of this ordinance. Eight (8) years from date of building permit or four (4) years from effective date of this ordinance, whichever last occurs. 
c.  Assessed valuation under two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) on the effective date of this ordinance. Four (4) years from date of building permit or two (2) years from effective date of this ordinance, whichever last occurs. 
(4)  The nonconforming use of a building or structure shall be terminated at the end of the amortization period for said building or structure, as set forth in this paragraph (H), and shall not thereafter be operated on the premises. 
5.06. - Condemnation of nonconforming buildings and structures. 
(A)  The Village of Roselle, at any time and from time to time, by ordinance duly enacted and in accordance with the authority vested in it by the Illinois Revised Statutes, as amended, Chapter 24, Section 11-12, may: 
(1)  Acquire by purchase, condemnation or otherwise any buildings or structures which do not conform to the standards fixed by the corporate authorities of the Village of Roselle pursuant to the Illinois Revised Statutes, as amended, Chapter 24, Section 11-12, and all land which is necessary or appropriate for the rehabilitation or redevelopment of any area blighted by substandard buildings or structures; 
(2)  Remove or demolish all such substandard buildings and structures so acquired; 
(3)  Hold and use any remaining property for public purposes; and 
(4)  Sell, lease, or exchange such property as is not required for public purposes, subject to the provisions of this ordinance or any amendment thereto. 
(B)  No such acquisition by condemnation shall be made until such time as the plan commission, at the request of the president and the board of trustees, or upon its own initiative, shall have made a study of the area within which such nonconforming building or structure is located and shall have filed a written report on such study with the president and the board of trustee. 
5.07. - Nonconforming use of buildings or structures. 
(A)  Expansion of nonconforming use. The nonconforming use of a part of a conforming building or structure, shall not be expanded or extended into any other portion of such building or structure. 
(B)  Discontinuance of a nonconforming use. If a nonconforming use of a conforming building or structure, is discontinued for a period of ninety (90) days, it shall not be renewed. Any subsequent use of the building or structure shall conform to the use regulations of the district in which the premises are located. 
(C)  Change of a nonconforming use. The nonconforming use of a part of a conforming building or structure shall not be changed to any other nonconforming use. 
(D)  Elimination of a nonconforming use. In all Residence Districts any use which lawfully exists on the effective date of this ordinance, but is permitted only in a Business Office Research, or Industrial District and which is located in a building, all or substantially all of which is designed or intended for a residential purpose, shall be entirely discontinued, and shall thereafter cease operation within five (5) years from the date of adoption of this ordinance. 
5.08. - Nonconforming use of land. 
    The nonconforming use of land not involving a building or structure, or in connection with which any building or structure thereon is incidental or accessory to the principal use of the land, may be continued subject to the following provisions: 
(A)  Expansion. A nonconforming use of land shall not be expanded or extended beyond the area it occupies. 
(B)  Discontinuance. If a nonconforming use of land is discontinued for a period of six (6) consecutive months, it shall not thereafter be renewed. Any subsequent use of the land shall conform to the regulations of the district in which the land is located. 
(C)  Change of use. A nonconforming use of land shall not be changed to any other use except to a use permitted in the district in which the land is located. 
(D)  Elimination of nonconforming use of land. The nonconforming use of land shall be discontinued and cease in accordance with the following, except that in R-1, R-2, R-2A, and R-2B Districts the allowable term shall be reduced by fifty (50) percent. 
(1)  Where no buildings or structures are employed in connection with such use, discontinued within one year. 
(2)  Where the only buildings or structures or other physical improvements employed are accessory or incidental to such use and have an assessed valuation of not more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) on the effective date of this ordinance, discontinued within two (2) years. 
(3)  Where the improvements, underground or substantially at ground level, which comprise all or substantially all of the improvements employed in a nonconforming use of land, and which have an assessed valuation of more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) on the effective date of this ordinance, discontinued within five (5) years. 
(4)  Where a nonconforming use of land is accessory to the nonconforming use of a building or structure, discontinued on the same date on which the nonconforming use of the building or structure is discontinued. 
5.09. - Amortization of pre-existing adult regulated uses. 
    Any nonconforming building[,] structure, lot or regulated use existing lawfully at the time of adoption of these amendments pertaining to adult regulated uses which shall be nonconforming upon adoption of these amendments to the zoning ordinance, or which shall become nonconforming upon annexation to the village, may continue as hereinafter provided. 
(A)  Upon written notice from the community development department to the owners or interests therein that any building[,] structure, lot or regulated use is a nonconforming adult use under the zoning ordinance as amended, the owners or interests therein shall within three (3) months from the date of such notice apply to the community development department for a certificate of nonconformance and amortization schedule. 
(B)  Failure to apply for a certificate of nonconformance and amortization schedule within three (3) months of the notice provided for in section 5.09(A) shall require the amortization of a nonconformance within six (6) months of the issuance of the notice provided for in section 5.09(A). 
(C)  Nonconformances that have obtained a certificate of nonconformance and amortization schedule from the department of building and zoning shall be discontinued within one (1) year of the issuance of the notice provided for by section 5.09(A). 
(D)  If the applicant seeks an amortization period longer than allowed by sections 5.09(B), (C), the application for the certificate of nonconformance and amortization schedule shall also include a statement in writing by the applicant or his designated representative as to the nature of the nonconformance and the reasons that the applicant seeks an amortization period longer than allowed by sections 5.09(B), (C). 
(E)  Any applicant seeking an amortization period longer than allowed by sections 5.09(B), (C), shall file an application for a special use permit in accordance with section 13.11 of the zoning ordinance. In addition to the requirements of section 13.11, the application for a special use permit will specify the additional period of time that the applicant is seeking to amortize as well as the reasons that the applicant is unable to amortize within the maximum of one (1) year and three (3) months permitted by this ordinance. In no event shall any amortization period including those extended by special use permit exceed a period of twenty-four (24) months from the date that the notice is provided in accordance with section 5.09(A). 
(Ord. No. 2276-93,  4, 1-11-93) 
SECTION 6.00. - ZONING DISTRICTS 

6.01. - Districts. 
    For the purposes and provisions of this ordinance, the Village of Roselle is hereby divided into the following districts: 
  Residence Districts 
R-1. Single-Family Residence District (16,000 square feet, 100-foot width) 
R-2. Single-Family Residence District (12,000 square feet, 80-foot width) 
 R-2 Development Area "A" (9,000 square feet, 65-foot width) 
 R-2 Development Area "B" (6,000 square feet, 50-foot width) 
R-3. General Residence District 
R-4. Multiple-Family Residence District 
Agricultural District 
AG. Agricultural District 
Business Districts 
B-1. Office-Transition District 
B-2. Neighborhood Shopping Center District 
B-3. Town Center Business District 
B-4. Service Business District 
B-5. Arterial Business District 
Office Research District 
ORI. Office, Research and Light Industrial District 
Industrial District 
M. Limited Industrial District 
6.02. - Map. 
    The location and boundaries of the districts established by this ordinance are set forth on the "Official Zoning District Map of the Village of Roselle, Illinois" which is incorporated herein and hereby made a part of this ordinance. The said map, together with everything shown thereon and all amendments thereto, shall be as much a part of this ordinance as through fully set forth and described herein. The said map shall be filed with the office of the village clerk and certified copies thereof in the office of the community development department and shall be open to public reference at all times during which those offices are open. 
6.03. - District boundaries. 
    When uncertainty exists with respect to the boundaries of the various districts, as shown on the Roselle Zoning District Map, the following rules shall apply: 
(A)  District boundary lines are either the centerlines of railroads, highways, streets, alleys, easements or tract or lot lines, or such lines extended unless otherwise indicated. 
(B)  In areas not subdivided into lots and blocks, wherever a district is indicated as a strip adjacent to and paralleling a street, highway or railroad, the depth of such strips shall be in accordance with dimensions shown on the maps measured at right angles from the centerline of a street, highway or railroad. The length of frontage shall be in accordance with dimensions shown on the map from centerlines of streets, highways or railroad rights-of-way unless otherwise indicated. 
(C)  Where a lot which is held in one ownership and is of record on the effective date of the ordinance is divided by a district boundary line, the entire lot shall be construed to be within the less restricted district. However, this construction shall not apply if it increases the less restricted frontage of the lot by more than twenty-five (25) feet. 
6.04. - Zoning of annexed land. 
    Whenever any parcel of land is hereafter annexed to the Village of Roselle, such territory upon annexation shall be classified or zoned as described below unless said parcel of land has been otherwise zoned after a preannexation zoning hearing in accordance with the provisions of sections 12.00 and/or 13.00 and 13.13 of this ordinance. 
(A)  Annexation of fully developed land. Single-family detached residential properties annexed to the village and which, on the date of such annexation, are fully developed and have insufficient area for the creation of a developable zoning lot shall, upon such annexation, be automatically classified into the residential zoning district that is, in the opinion of the board of trustees, most compatible with the development existing on and around such land. 
(B)  Annexation of undeveloped or partially developed land. All undeveloped or partially developed land annexed to the village which has sufficient area for the creation of a developable zoning lot, shall be automatically classified in the R-1 single-family residence district unless an application for alternative zoning is granted. 
(C)  Application for different classification. When any land is classified pursuant to this section, it shall remain so classified unless a rezoning application is filed and granted pursuant to sections 12.00 and/or 13.00 and 13.13 of this ordinance. Said application may be filed prior to or contemporaneously with the annexation. 
(Ord. No. 2324-93,  1, 5-10-93) 
6.05. - Zoning of public ways. 
    All streets, alleys, public ways, waterways and railroads rights-of-way, if not otherwise specifically designated, shall be deemed to be in the same zone as the property immediately abutting on such streets, alleys, public ways and railroad right-of-way or waterways. Where the centerline of a street, alley, public way, waterway or railroad right-of-way serves a district boundary, the zoning of such areas, unless otherwise specifically designated, shall be deemed to be the same as that of the abutting property up to such centerline. 
6.06. - Exemptions. 
    The following public utility uses are permitted in any district: Poles, wires, cables, conduits, vaults, laterals, pipes, mains, valves or any other similar distributing equipment, provided that installation and location shall conform with rules and regulations of the applicable administrative authorities and applicable ordinances and rules and regulations of this ordinance and other authorities having jurisdiction. 
SECTION 7.00. - RESIDENCE DISTRICTS 

7.01. - Purpose and intent. 
(A)  The Residence Districts implement the policies and intent of the Roselle Village Board as expressed in the official comprehensive plan adopted August 22, 2016, or any amendments thereto. 
(B)  The residence districts provide for the development of various types of dwelling units within a framework of standards designed to: 
(1)  Preserve and further promote low-density neighborhoods with single-family detached dwellings consistent with the predominant character of the village; 
(2)  Encourage the development of medium density single-family detached dwelling neighborhoods where it is possible to employ modern, efficient land planning techniques; 
(3)  Accommodate, within the R-2 Single-Family Residence District, two (2) development areas which have been identified for the purpose of providing appropriate lot area and lot width requirements to which existing platted lots at the time of adoption of this ordinance in the Village of Roselle can conform, taking into account previously subdivided and/or annexed properties having certain lot size characteristics. These areas have been designated as Development Area "A" and Development Area "B" on the zoning district map, with appropriate development regulations specified herein; 
(4)  Provide for the economically sound and aesthetically pleasing use of areas characterized by their proximity to heavy traffic, business, and office areas; and 
(5)  Encourage modern trends in residential planning such as the planned unit development concept. 
(C)  To encourage the conservation of energy in conformance with national concern, it will be necessary to provide for the maximum effective use of passive solar energy through proper orientation of residential buildings. 
    Solar orienting of residential buildings may require the granting of variations of the bulk requirements to provide for the proper orientation of the buildings and the development of solar skyspace easements to preserve solar access. 
    In considering solar orientation of buildings the following shall be considered: 
(1)  The configuration or orientation of the property; 
(2)  The nature of surrounding developments; 
(3)  The circulation patterns; 
(4)  The improved designs; 
(5)  The existing physical features of the site such as topography or vegetation; and 
(6)  The potential for providing solar skyspace easements. 
(Ord. No. 2016-3858,  1, 8-22-16) 
7.02. - General Requirements 
(A)  Signs shall be permitted in all Residence Districts in accordance with Chapter 17, Article II, signs, of the Code of Ordinances of the Village of Roselle. 
(B)  Home occupations in Residence Districts shall be allowed only upon the granting of the special use permits by the village board of trustees in accordance with section 13.11 of this ordinance. 
(C)  The performance standards specified in section 10.02 of this ordinance shall apply, where appropriate, to residential and nonresidential uses in all Residence Districts. 
(D)  Floodplain regulations and storm water detention shall apply to all development in the Residence Districts in accordance with sections 4.00 and 4.10 of this ordinance. 
(E)  Barbed wire shall be prohibited except as permitted in section 4.08(F). 
(F)  All outer edges of driveways shall have a minimum two-foot setback from adjacent property lines in all residential districts. 
(Ord. No. 2135-91,  2, 11-25-91; Ord. No. 2009-3445,  5, 4-13-09) 
7.03. - R-1 Single-Family Residence District. 
(A)  Permitted uses. The following uses are permitted: 
(1)  Single-family detached dwellings. 
(2)  Parks, forest preserves, and playgrounds, publicly owned and operated. 
(3)  Temporary buildings and uses in accordance with the provisions of section 4.12(B). 
(4)  Accessory uses including no more than one "stored vehicle" to the above permitted uses in accordance with the provisions of section 4.08. 
(B)  Special uses. The following uses may be allowed by special use permit in accordance with the provisions of section 13.11: 
(1)  Adult day care center. 
(2)  Child day care center. 
(3)  Churches, chapels, temples and synagogues, rectories, seminaries, convents, monasteries, and similar religious institutions, along with customary accessory uses required for operation. 
(4)  Cemeteries. 
(5)  Golf courses, but not including commercially operated driving ranges or miniature golf courses. 
(6)  Growing of crops in the open, including also truck gardens and tree nurseries, provided that no livestock, poultry or pigeons are kept, and that no offensive odors or dusts are created and further, that no retail sales are conducted from a stand, table or store erected or maintained on the premises. 
(7)  Home occupations (see section 4.11). 
(8)  Parks and playgrounds, privately owned and operated but not for profit. 
(9)  Planned unit developments (see section 12.00). 
(10)  Schools meeting State of Illinois educational criteria, public, private, or parochial-elementary, middle, junior high, or senior high (non-boarding). The minimum lot size shall be five (5) acres. 
(11)  Stables, private, provided they are accessory to a principal use which is located on a lot of not less than three (3) acres in area. 
(12)  Swimming pools, private. 
(13)  Swimming pools, public. 
(14)  Utility and public service uses including: 
a.  Electric substations and electric distribution centers; 
b.  Fire stations; 
c.  Police stations; 
d.  Railroad rights-of-way; 
e.  Railroad passenger stations; 
f.  Telephone exchanges and telephone transmission equipment buildings as may be required by public utilities; 
g.  Water filtration and sewage treatment plants, pumping stations, and reservoirs municipally owned and operated; and 
h.  Municipal facilities; 
i.  Other public utility service uses; and 
j.  Private utilities such as cable television, head end station, but not private water supply facilities. 
(15)  Public parking when it is an accessory use to an approved special use. 
(16)  Second garage, as defined in section 4.08 (D)(1) Garages. 
(C)  Minimum lot size. 
(1)  Lot area. Not less than sixteen thousand (16,000) square feet. 
(2)  Lot width. Not less than one hundred (100) feet at the building line. 
(3)  Floor area ratio. 
a.  Nonresidential permitted and special uses. The floor area ratio shall not exceed 0.6. 
(D)  Minimum yards. 
(1)  Front yard. Not less than thirty-five (35) feet. 
(2)  Side yards. 
a.  On an interior lot, two (2) interior side yards, each of which shall be not less than ten (10) feet. 
b.  On a corner lot, an interior side yard not less than ten (10) feet, and a corner side yard not less than thirty (30). 
c.  If a corner lot, subdivided and duly recorded on the effective date of this ordinance has insufficient width to provide a corner side yard of thirty (30) feet and maintain a buildable width of twenty-seven (27) feet a variation may be granted according to section 5.02(B). 
(3)  Rear yard. Not less than forty (40) feet. 
(4)  Yards: Nonresidential permitted uses and special uses. There shall be provided front, side, and rear yards as required above for buildings less than twenty-five (25) feet in height. For buildings twenty-five (25) to thirty (30) feet in height, each yard-front, side, and rear-shall be increased in width or depth by two (2) feet for each additional one foot of building height over twenty-five (25) feet. 
(E)  Off-street parking and loading. In accordance with provisions set forth in section 11.00 of this ordinance. 
(F)  Ground floor area per dwelling. In accordance with applicable regulations set forth in Chapter 6, Buildings, section 6-147 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(G)  Maximum building height. Not more than thirty (30) feet. 
(H)  Detached accessory buildings. A minimum of five (5) feet from the side lot line and three (3) feet from the rear lot line; these distances shall be increased to the dimension given on any easements which may be located in side and/or rear yards contained on duly recorded documents. 
(I)  [ Reserved. ] 
(Ord. No. 2125-91,  2, 10-14-91; Ord. No. 2525-94, ㎣ 1, 2, 10-10-94; Ord. No. 2426-94, ㎣ 1, 2, 10-10-94; Ord. No. 2569-97, ㎣ 3, 4, 3-31-97; Ord. No. 2005-3149,  2, 1-24-05; Ord. No. 2009-3445,  2, 4-13-09; Ord. No. 2010-3517,  1, 5-24-10; Ord. No. 2017-3894, ㎣ 2, 3, 3-13-17) 
7.04. - R-2 Single-Family Residence District. 
(A)  Permitted uses. The following uses are permitted: 
(1)  Uses permitted in the R-1 Single-Family Residence District. 
(B)  Special uses. The following uses may be allowed by special use permit in accordance with the provisions of section 13.11: 
(1)  The special uses allowed in the R-1 Single-Family Residence District. 
(2)  Colleges and universities and uses accessory and incidental thereto, but not colleges or trade schools operated for profit. 
(3)  Home for the aged and nursing homes, as defined in section 3.02, health care facilities. 
(4)  Municipal, park district and not-for-profit owned recreational buildings and community centers. 
(5)  Undertaking establishments and funeral parlors, but only along principal arterial streets. The minimum lot size shall be one acre. 
(6)  Training/therapeutic facilities, as defined in section 3.02, health care facilities. 
(C)  Minimum lot size. 
(1)  Lot area. Not less than twelve thousand (12,000) square feet. 
(2)  Lot width. Not less than eighty (80) feet at the building line. 
(3)  Floor area ratio. 
a.  Nonresidential permitted and special uses. The floor area ratio shall not exceed 0.6. 
(D)  Minimum yards. 
(1)  Front yard. Not less than thirty (30) feet. 
(2)  Side yards. 
a.  On an interior lot, two (2) interior side yards having a combined width of not less than twenty (20) feet. Neither interior side yard shall be less than eight (8) feet. On existing interior lots under eighty (80) feet in width, there shall be one side yard of ten (10) percent of the width of the lot, the other side yard shall be a minimum width of nine (9) feet. 
b.  On a corner lot, an interior side yard not less than eight (8) feet, and a corner side yard not less than thirty (30) feet. 
c.  If a corner lot, subdivided and duly recorded on the effective date of this ordinance has an insufficient width to provide a corner side yard of thirty (30) feet and maintain a buildable width of twenty-seven (27) feet, variation may be granted according to section 5.02(B). 
(3)  Rear yard. Not less than forty (40) feet. 
(4)  Yards: Nonresidential permitted uses and special uses. There shall be provided front, side, and rear yards as required above for buildings less than twenty-five (25) feet in height. For buildings twenty-five (25) to thirty (30) feet in height, each yard-front, side, and rear, shall be increased in width or depth by two (2) feet for each additional one foot of building height over twenty-five (25) feet. 
(E)  Off-street parking and loading. In accordance with provisions set forth in section 11.00 of this ordinance. 
(F)  Ground floor area per dwelling. In accordance with regulations set forth in Chapter 6, Buildings, section 6-147 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(G)  Maximum building height. Not more than thirty (30) feet. 
(H)  Detached accessory buildings. A minimum side yard of five (5) feet and a minimum rear yard of three (3) feet on eighty (80) foot lots. On existing lots, under eighty (80) feet in width, as of the date of this ordinance the side yard shall be a minimum of three (3) feet and the rear yard shall be a minimum of three (3) feet. 
(I)  [ Reserved. ] 
(Ord. No. 2125-91,  2, 10-14-91; Ord. No. 2003-3039,  2, 12-8-03; Ord. No. 2007-3315,  1, 7-23-07; Ord. No. 2009-3445,  2, 4-13-09) 
7.05. - R-2 Single-Family Residence District-Development Area "A." 
    Intent. The R-2 Development Area "A" has been developed for the sole purpose of providing appropriate lot area and lot width requirements to which existing platted lots at the time of adoption of this ordinance in the Village of Roselle can conform. The dimensions of these existing lots require lot areas of nine thousand (9,000) square feet and lot widths at the building line of sixty-five (65) feet. The areas in which these existing lots are located are as follows: 
(1)  Blocks in Cook County bounded by Washington Street and Roselle Road from Devon Avenue to Albion Street; 
(2)  Lots on the south side of Devon Avenue from Williams Street to Lincoln Street; 
(3)  Lots on both sides of Claria Drive, west of Roselle Road including Roselle Nursery Estates, etc.; 
(4)  Blocks bounded by Prospect Avenue and Rush Street from Walnut Street to Ardmore Place including Hillcrest Units No. 1, 2, and 3, Henry Siem's Farm Assessment Plat No. 3, etc.; 
(5)  Blocks bounded by Rush Street and White Oak Drive from Brookwood Terrace to Bryn Mawr Avenue including Hillcrest Unit No. 1, Hillcrest Woods, Hillcrest Woods Units No. 2 and 3, etc.; and 
(6)  Lots on both sides of Pinecroft Drive and Ash Street including portions of Springhill and Pinecroft Subdivisions; 
(7)  Block bounded by Roselle Road, Maple Avenue, 4th Avenue and Pine Avenue. 
(A)  Permitted uses: The following uses are permitted: 
(1)  Uses permitted in the R-1 Single-Family Residence District. 
(B)  Special uses: The following uses may be allowed by special use permit in accordance with the provisions of section 13.11: 
(1)  The special uses allowed in the R-1 and R-2 Single-Family Residence Districts, except that undertaking establishments and funeral parlors shall not be allowed. 
(C)  Minimum lot size:

(2)  Lot width. Not less than sixty-five (65) feet at the building line. 
(3)  Floor area ratio. 
a.  Nonresidential permitted and special uses. The floor area ratio shall not exceed 0.6. 
(D)  Minimum yards. 
(1)  Front yard. Not less than twenty-five (25) feet. 
(2)  Side yards. 
a.  On an interior lot, two (2) interior side yards having a combined width of not less than fifteen (15) feet. Neither interior side yard shall be less than six (6) feet. On existing interior lots under sixty-five (65) feet in width, there shall be one side yard of ten (10) percent of the width of the lot; the other side yard shall be a minimum width of five (5) feet. 
b.  On a corner lot, an interior side yard not less than six (6) feet, and a corner side yard not less than twenty-five (25) feet. 
c.  If a corner lot, subdivided and duly recorded on the effective date of this ordinance has insufficient width to provide a corner side yard of twenty-five (25) in width and still maintain a buildable width of twenty-seven (27) feet, variation may be granted according to section 5.02(B). 
(3)  Rear yards. Not less than forty (40) feet. 
(4)  Yards: Nonresidential permitted uses and special uses. There shall be provided front, side, and rear yards as required above for buildings less than twenty-five (25) feet in height. For buildings twenty-five (25) feet to thirty (30) feet in height, each yard-front, side, and rear shall be increased in width or depth by two (2) feet for each additional one foot of building height over twenty-five (25) feet. 
(E)  Off-street parking and loading. In accordance with provisions set forth in section 11.00 of this ordinance. 
(F)  Ground floor area per dwelling. In accordance with regulations set forth in Chapter 6, Buildings, section 6-147 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(G)  Maximum building height. Not more than thirty (30) feet. 
(H)  Detached accessory building. A minimum side yard of five (5) feet and a minimum rear yard of three (3) feet on sixty-five (65) foot lots. On existing lots, under sixty-five (65) feet in width, as of the date of this Ordinance the side yard shall be a minimum of three (3) feet and the rear yard shall be a minimum of three (3) feet.

These distances shall be increased to the dimension given on any easements which may be located in side and/or rear yards contained on duly recorded documents.

SECTION 7.50. - AGRICULTURAL DISTRICT 

7.51. - Purpose and intent. 
    The AG Agricultural District is intended to provide an environment suitable for and limited to those uses, activities, buildings and structures related to productivity for agricultural purposes until such time as the natural growth and development of municipalities precludes preservation thereof. 
    Agriculture includes all the processes of planting, growing, harvesting of crops and the raising and feeding of livestock and poultry; including farming, farm buildings, and farm dwellings, truck gardens, flower gardens, apiaries, aviaries, mushroom growing, nurseries, orchards, forestry, dairies, greenhouses, and commercial vegetables. 
    Agriculture shall not include the commercial feeding of garbage or offal to swine or other animals, the commercial feeding of animals on open lots where no feed is raised on the premises, or the commercial feeding of fur bearing animals, poultry broilers, or laboratory animals such as mice, rabbits, rats, etc., or the commercial slaughter of any animals. 
7.52. - General requirements. 
(A)  Signs shall be permitted in all Agricultural Districts in accordance with Chapter 17, Article II, signs, of the Code of Ordinances. 
(B)  Home occupations in Agricultural Districts shall be allowed only upon the granting of special use permits by the village board of trustees in accordance with section 13.11 of this ordinance. 
(C)  The performance standards specified in section 10.02 of this ordinance shall apply, where appropriate, to residential and nonresidential uses in all Agricultural Districts. 
(D)  Floodplain regulations and stormwater detention shall apply to all development in the Agricultural District in accordance with sections 4.09 and 4.10 of this ordinance. 
(E)  Barbed wire shall be prohibited except as permitted in section 4.08(F). 
(Ord. No. 2135-91,  3, 11-25-91) 
7.53. - AG Agricultural District. 
(A)  Permitted uses. The following uses are permitted: 
(1)  Agricultural use including the current employment of land and buildings supporting accepted farming practice for the purpose of raising, harvesting, and selling crops or by the feeding, breeding, management and sale of, or the produce of, livestock, poultry, or for dairying and the sale of dairy products or any other agricultural or horticultural use or animal husbandry or any combination thereof. Farm use shall include the preparation and storage of the products raised on such land for human use and animal use and proper disposal thereof in wholesale or retail quantities. 
(2)  Parks, forest preserves, and playgrounds-publicly owned and operated. 
(3)  Single-family detached dwellings. 
(4)  Temporary buildings and uses in accordance with the provisions of section 4.12(B). 
(5)  Accessory single-family farm tenant dwellings on unsubdivided farm land subject to the same intensity of use requirements (lot area and width) for this district. 
(6)  Accessory uses to the above permitted uses. 
(B)  Special uses. The following uses may be allowed by special use permit in accordance with the provisions of section 13.11. 
(1)  Churches, chapels, temples and synagogues, rectories, seminaries, convents, monasteries, and similar religious institutions along with customary accessory uses required for operation. 
(2)  Cemeteries. 
(3)  Golf courses, but not including commercially operated driving ranges or miniature golf courses. 
(4)  Home occupations (see section 4.11). 
(5)  Roadside stands in connection with an agricultural use, providing not more than one such stand shall be permitted, products for sale shall be produced on the premises and further provided no such stand shall exceed five hundred (500) square feet in floor area nor be erected within twenty-five (25) feet of any property line. 
(6)  Utility and public service uses including: 
a.  Electric substations and electric distribution centers; 
b.  Fire stations; 
c.  Police stations; 
d.  Railroad rights-of-way; 
e.  Railroad passenger stations; 
f.  Telephone exchanges, microwave relay towers, and telephone transmission equipment building as may be required by public utilities; 
g.  Water filtration and sewage treatment plants, pumping stations, and reservoirs municipally-owned and operated; 
h.  Municipal facility; 
i.  Other public utility service uses; 
j.  Private utilities such as cable television, head end station, but not private water supply facilities. 
(C)  Minimum lot size. 
(1)  Lot area. 
a.  For permitted uses, not less than twenty-five (25) acres under single ownership and/or control. 
b.  For special uses, lot area shall be provided as recommended by the zoning board of appeals and approved by the village board of trustees. 
(2)  Lot width. Not less than two hundred (200) feet at the building line. 
(3)  Floor area ratio. The floor area ratio shall not exceed 0.08. 
(D)  Minimum yards. 
(1)  Front yard. Not less than thirty-five (35) feet. 
(2)  Side yards. 
a.  On an interior lot, two (2) interior side yards, each of which shall be not less than ten (10) feet. 
b.  On a corner lot, an interior side yard not less than ten (10) feet, and a corner side yard not less than thirty (30) feet. 
(3)  Rear yard. Not less than forty (40) feet. 
(4)  Yards: Nonresidential permitted uses and special uses. There shall be provided front, side, and rear yards as required above for buildings less than twenty-five (25) feet in height. For buildings twenty-five (25) to forty-five (45) feet in height, each yard-fence, side, and rear shall be increased in width or depth by two (2) feet for each additional one foot of building height over twenty-five (25) feet. 
(E)  Off-street parking and loading. In accordance with provisions set forth in section 11.00 of this ordinance. 
(F)  Ground floor area per dwelling. In accordance with applicable regulations set forth in Chapter 6, buildings, Section 6-147 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(G)  Maximum building height. Not more than forty-five (45) feet except for barns and silos which have a maximum height of fifty (50) feet. 
(H)  Detached accessory buildings. Yards shall be the same as specified in section 7.53(D) above. 
(I)  Maximum lot coverage. Maximum lot coverage for permitted and/or special uses shall not exceed four (4) percent of the lot area. 
SECTION 8.00. - BUSINESS DISTRICTS 

8.01. - General requirements-All business districts. 
(A)  All business, service, storage, merchandise, display, and, where permitted, repair and processing shall be conducted wholly within enclosed buildings, except for off-street automobile parking, off-street loading, and open sales and rental lots in districts where they are permitted. 
(B)  Goods sold shall consist primarily of new merchandise. Any goods produced on the premises shall be sold at retail on the premises unless otherwise permitted herein for specified uses. 
(C)  Processes and equipment employed, and goods processed or sold, shall be limited to those which are not objectionable by reason of odor, dust, smoke, cinders, gas, noise, vibration, refuse matter, or water-carried waste. The performance standards specified in section 10.02 shall apply where appropriate to permitted uses in the Business Districts. 
(D)  All outside storage areas of goods, materials, products, or trash containers shall be enclosed with fences or landscaping of at least seventy-five (75) percent opacity. Lighting of the facility shall be directed away from surrounding properties. 
(E)  Site plan approval. All applications for building permits in the Business Districts shall be accompanied by a landscape plan prepared by a landscape architect, shall be approved by the plan commission in accordance with the site plan review process specified in section 13.12 of this ordinance and shall comply with the requirements contained herein. These provisions, however, do not apply to minor interior modifications, such as tenant spaces in shopping centers, which do not affect the intensity of use, type of use, or exterior features of the site. 
(1)  Site plan requirements. The site plan shall include the following information: 
a.  Names and addresses of owner, applicant, planner, architect, engineer, landscape architect, as appropriate. 
b.  Scale, north arrow, date. 
c.  Title of the project or property. 
d.  Location and dimensions of existing and proposed buildings and structures, including adjacent lot lines and significant features and buildings on adjoining properties. 
e.  Ground elevations, existing and proposed. 
f.  Location of floodplains, existing vegetation, fences, walls, etc. 
g.  Vehicular, service and pedestrian access, including driveways, sidewalks, curbs, streets, traffic signals and on-site parking and circulation signage. 
h.  Off-street parking and loading areas, including number of spaces and dimensions. 
i.  Lighting standards, including location, size, height, illumination and intensity. 
j.  Outdoor storage areas, if any. 
k.  Waste disposal areas, including type of containers, bins, dumpsters, etc., and enclosure methods. 
l.  Engineering, drainage, grading, floodplain, and on-site stormwater detention areas. 
m.  Landscaping plan. 
(2)  Landscape plan details. All areas of the site which are not paved shall be landscaped with trees, shrubs, flowers, ground cover and/or grass to retard water runoff, restrict blowing trash and litter, and deter improper or unsafe site access and use by the public. The landscape plan shall include the following information: 
a.  Species, size and location of plant material. 
b.  Quantity of each type of plant material. 
c.  Landscaping treatment such as berming, contouring, shaping, ornamental lighting, paving materials, nonplant elements, fences, planters, etc. 
d.  Screening of waste disposal areas (trash enclosures). 
e.  Transitional yard screening and perimeter area screening. 
f.  Screening where a Business District abuts a Residence District may be accomplished with the use of berms, plant material, fences, or a combination of these methods; placement of screening shall not impair the safety of pedestrians or vehicular traffic. 
g.  Screening where a Business District is directly across a public street from a Residence District may be required in the form of berms, trees, shrubs, or a combination of these methods; placement of screening shall not impair the safety of pedestrians or vehicular traffic. 
(3)  Specifications. Landscape materials shall be selected and sited to produce a hardy and drought-resistant landscape area. Selection shall include: consideration of soil type and depth; spacing for opacity; exposure to sun, wind, and water; slope and contours of the site; building walls, overhangs, and compatibility with existing native vegetation preserved on the site. 
a.  Deciduous trees shall have a minimum caliper of three (3) inches when measured eighteen (18) inches from grade at time of planting. 
b.  Evergreen trees shall be a minimum of five (5) feet in height from grade at time of planting. 
c.  Trash enclosures shall provide at least seventy-five (75) percent opacity. 
d.  Appropriate care and maintenance of plant material shall be provided to keep such growth alive and in good condition; diseased or dead plant material shall be replaced. 
e.  An irrevocable letter of credit in an amount equal to one hundred ten (110) percent of the uncompleted work as certified by the contractor in a form satisfactory to the village attorney shall be supplied prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy if landscaping and other external improvements are not completed at the time of final inspection. 
(4)  Procedure. The zoning administrator shall transmit copies of the site plan to the plan commission with a request for a report of its findings and recommendations thereto; to the village staff for review and comment; and to the village board for review and comment. The plan commission shall review the site plan submission at a regularly scheduled monthly meeting within forty-five (45) days after transmittal of said site plan by the zoning administrator. The decision of the plan commission shall be binding upon the applicant, except that appeals of said decisions may be taken to the village board of trustees. A written report of the plan commission review shall accompany such appeals. 
(F)  Overhead loading doors. Location to be determined by plan commission. 
(G)  Barbed wire shall be permitted provided the board of trustees finds the property to have an extraordinarily high risk of theft or vandalism and the barbed wire is designed to minimize personal injury. 
(H)  Drive-through facilities. 
(1)  Special use: "Drive through facilities" shall be special uses in the B-1, B-2, B-3, B-4, and B-5 business zoning districts and shall be subject to the requirements of section 13.11 special uses of the Roselle Zoning Ordinance. 
(2)  Setbacks: All drive-through facilities adjoining residential property shall locate drive-through lanes (including the required by-pass lane and the required stacking space requirements) not less than forty (40) feet from the closest residential property, measured as the distance between the residential property line and the nearest component of the drive-through facility, including but not limited to the drive-through lane(s), the stacking spaces, or the by-pass lane. 
(3)  By-pass: A minimum of a ten-foot by-pass lane shall be provided adjacent to the drive-through lane(s) in order for vehicles to by-pass the drive-through lane(s); a variance to this requirement may be granted by the Corporate Authorities of the Village of Roselle. 
(4)  Drive-through lane and stacking space requirements: 
a.  All drive-through lanes and stacking spaces shall be no less than nine (9) feet wide by eighteen (18) feet long. 
b.  Drive-through lanes and stacking spaces shall be designed to avoid crossing or conflicting with parking areas or pedestrian walkways or, where not practical, to minimize the impacts of the lanes and stacking spaces on parking spaces and pedestrian walkways. For safety and traffic circulation, design features shall be graphically submitted and approved as a condition of granting special uses for drive through facilities. This graphic shall depict cross pedestrian walkways, drive aisles or parking areas, including but not limited to: painted crosswalks, brick-pavers and/or signage to distinguish pedestrian walks from vehicular drives aisles, drive-through lanes, or parking areas; safety mirrors at corners; safety rails; and colored and tactile-domed sidewalk ramps to signal the transition from sidewalks to drive-aisles, parking areas, or thrive-through lanes. 
c.  All drive-through lanes and stacking spaces shall be distinct from the site access (public street, neighboring lots, etc.) and parking. 
(5)  Minimum standards for stacking: There shall be provided for each building, structure and use hereafter erected, structurally altered or enlarged with a drive-through lane, the minimum number of stacking spaces as set forth in section 11.05 of the Roselle Zoning Ordinance. 
(I)  Overnight parking. Unless otherwise permitted herein for specified uses, long-term overnight parking is prohibited in all Business Districts but short-term overnight parking is allowed in all Business Districts. 
(Ord. No. 1468-86,  2, 7-28-86; Ord. No. 2135-91,  4, 11-25-91; Ord. No. 2006-3255,  3, 10-23-06; Ord. No. 2012-3628,  5, 5-14-12) 
8.02. - B-1 Office Transitional District. 
    Intent. It is the intent of this district to provide for the development of offices and businesses which are compatible with or can be located adjacent to residential areas. Buildings in this district are generally low one- or two-story structures and can accommodate most professional office functions with less than twenty-five (25) percent of the lot covered by structures. The district is often near major traffic ways and serves as a buffer between vehicle traffic on arterial streets and adjacent residential neighborhoods. Site and building designs may require protective measures to make the buildings and uses compatible with adjacent residential uses. 
(A)  General conditions. 
(1)  Nonresidential and residential uses shall not be on the same floor of the same building. 
(2)  Nonresidential uses shall not be above the first floor in buildings containing dwelling units. 
(3)  Reserved. 
(4)  Each nonresidential establishment within a building shall be restricted to a maximum gross floor area of one thousand (1,000) square feet. 
(5)  Businesses conducting real estate closing activities are not permitted, unless approved as a special use permit. 
(B)  Permitted uses. The following uses are permitted: 
(1)  Banks, financial institutions, and investment companies excluding businesses conducting real estate closing activities. 
(2)  Barber shops and beauty shops. 
(3)  Consulting services (professional, skilled, and artistic). 
(4)  Dwelling units: 
a.  Existing dwelling units on lots, with a minimum width of fifty (50) feet and a minimum area of seven thousand (7,000) square feet. 
b.  Mixed uses: Dwelling units above first floor offices and permitted uses. 
(5)  Government, civic, and cultural services (excluding garages or outside storage). 
(6)  Offices: Business, financial, legal, medical, professional, service, etc. excluding businesses conducting real estate closing activities. 
(7)  Orthopedic/medical appliance sales. 
(7.1)  Parking, long-term overnight; when accessory to the following use: 
a.  Public and private utility facilities. 
(8)  Sales facilities within an office building, but limited to not more than twenty-five (25) percent of the gross ground floor area of the building. 
(8.1)  Small cell antenna in public right-of-way. 
(9)  Studios: Artist, dancers, musicians, photographers, etc. 
(10)  Temporary buildings and uses during construction and initial occupancy. 
(11)  Travel bureaus and transportation ticket offices. 
(12)  Typewriters, computers, printers, etc. sales/service. 
(13)  Accessory uses to the above permitted uses following the provisions of section 4.08. 
(C)  Special uses. The following uses may be allowed by special use permit following the provisions of section 13.11: 
(1)  Adult day care centers. 
(2)  Churches, convents, monasteries, theological schools, rectories, and parish houses. 
(3)  Day care centers, provided at least seventy-five (75) square feet of outdoor play area are provided for each child using the area at any one time (see Ord. No. 894B-79) [section 9-539 et seq. of this Code]. 
(4)  Drug stores within office building, but limited to not more than twenty-five (25) percent of the gross ground floor area of the building. 
(5)  Dry cleaning and laundry-receiving establishments, provided processing shall be done elsewhere. 
(6)  Businesses conducting real estate closing activities. 
(7)  Multiple-family dwelling units, on lots with a minimum width of seventy-five (75) feet, and an area of ten thousand five hundred (10,500) square feet. The minimum lot area per dwelling unit shall be three thousand five hundred (3,500) square feet. 
(8)  Fire stations. 
(9)  Funeral homes and parlors. 
(10)  Laboratories: Medical, dental, optical. 
(11)  Parking lots: First Division Motor Vehicles and Second Division Motor Vehicles under one point five (1.5) tons capacity. 
(12)  Parks and playgrounds. 
(13)  Philanthropic and charitable institutions. 
(14)  Planned unit developments. 
(15)  Public and private utility facilities. 
a.  Electric substations and electric distribution center; 
b.  Telephone exchanges and telephone transmission equipment buildings as may be required by public utilities; 
c.  Water filtration plants, pumping stations, reservoirs, and storage tanks municipally owned and operated; 
d.  Other public utility service uses; 
e.  Private utilities such as cable television (but not a head end station) or private water supply facilities. 
(16)  Schools: Business, dance, martial arts, music, etc. 
(16.1)  Small cell antenna on private property. 
(17)  Drive-through facilities. 
(18)  Municipal, park district and not-for-profit owned recreational buildings and community centers. 
(D)  Minimum lot size. 
(1)  Lot area. Not less than ten thousand five hundred (10,500) square feet for all nonresidential uses. 
(2)  Lot width. Not less than seventy-five (75) feet at the building line for all nonresidential uses. 
(3)  Floor area ratio. The floor area ratio shall not exceed 0.6. 
(E)  Minimum yards. 
(1)  Front yard. Not less than thirty (30) feet. 
(2)  Side yards. 
a.  At least one interior side yard shall be provided on each interior lot. The minimum interior side yard shall be ten (10) feet. 
b.  If a second interior side yard is provided on an interior lot, such yard shall be not less than five (5) feet. A residential lot shall require a second interior side yard which shall be not less than ten (10) feet. 
c.  On a corner lot, a side yard adjoining a street shall be not less than twenty-five (25) feet. If an interior side yard is provided on a corner lot, such yard shall be not less than five (5) feet. A residential lot shall require an interior side yard which shall be not less than ten (10) feet. 
(3)  Rear yard. Not less than thirty (30) feet. 
(4)  Transitional yards. When a side or rear lot line in a B-1 District coincides with a side or rear lot line in an adjacent Residence District, a yard shall be provided along such side or rear lot line equal in dimension to the side or rear yard required under this ordinance for the applicable Residence District; such yards shall be landscaped in accordance with the provisions of section 8.01(E) of this ordinance. 
(F)  Off-street parking and loading. In accordance with the provisions set forth in section 11.00 of this ordinance. 
(G)  Maximum building height. Not more than thirty (30) feet, except when adjacent to multiple-family or business districts may be thirty-five (35) feet in height. 
(H)  Maximum building height. Not more than thirty (30) feet. 
(I)  Trucks. The parking of trucks as an accessory use, when used in the conduct of a permitted business listed in the B-1 District, shall be limited to vehicles of not over one and one-half tons capacity when located within one hundred fifty (150) feet of a Residence District boundary line. 
(J)  Signs. See Chapter 17, Article II, signs, of the Code of Ordinances. 
(K)  Screening. See section 8.01(E) of this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2425-95, ㎣ 3, 4, 10-10-94; Ord. No. 2605-97, ㎣ 1-5, 10-27-97; Ord. No. 2001-2866, ㎣ 1-4, 8-27-01; Ord. No. 2006-3255, ㎣ 4, 5, 10-23-06; Ord. No. 2012-3628,  6, 5-14-12; Ord. No. 2016-3847,  1, 6-13-16; Ord. No. 2017-3894, ㎣ 4-6, 3-13-17) 
8.03. - B-2 Convenience Shopping Center District. 
    Intent. The Convenience Shopping Center District is intended to provide primarily retail convenience shopping for persons living in adjacent residential areas. Permitted uses shall be those which are necessary to satisfy basic shopping needs which occur daily or frequently and so require facilities in relative proximity to places of residence. These facilities will normally be in the form of a shopping center and will be located along arterial or major collector streets. Adequate buffering shall be provided between this District and adjacent Residence Districts. 
(A)  General conditions. 
(1)  Each B-2 District shall be developed as a shopping center containing more than one business establishment. 
(2)  Eating and drinking establishments shall not include entertainment and dancing. 
(3)  Each store in the shopping center shall be restricted to a maximum gross floor area of thirty thousand (30,000) square feet, exclusive of any floor area devoted to off-street parking or loading facilities. 
(B)  Permitted uses. The following uses are permitted: 
(1)  Uses permitted in a B-1 District, except for the following: 
a.  Existing dwelling units, single-family; 
b.  Dwelling units in combination with office and other permitted uses. 
(1.1)  Alterations/seamstress/tailor. 
(2)  Antique shops. 
(3)  Art and school supply stores. 
(4)  Automobile accessory stores. 
(5)  Bakeries where not more than fifty (50) percent of the floor area is devoted to processing, and not more than five (5) persons are employed. 
(6)  Reserved. 
(7)  Bicycle stores-sales, rental, and repair. 
(8)  Book and stationery stores. 
(9)  Camera and photographic supply stores. 
(10)  Candy and ice cream stores. 
(11)  Catering services, provided that they are accessory to the principal use, either a food store or a restaurant. 
(12)  Ceramics stores. 
(13)  China and glassware stores. 
(14)  Clothing stores. 
(15)  Currency exchanges. 
(16)  Drug stores, pharmacies. 
(17)  Electronic equipment, electrical and household appliance stores, including home computer, radio and television sales. 
(17.1)  Fitness establishments; containing 5,000 square feet or less of gross floor area. 
(18)  Furniture stores, including upholstery when conducted as part of the retail operation and secondary to the principal use. 
(19)  Furrier shops, including the incidental storage and conditioning of furs. 
(20)  Dry-cleaning and laundry-receiving establishments with processing done elsewhere; also dry-cleaning establishments, where not more than two thousand five hundred (2,500) square feet of floor area is devoted to processing, exclusive of offices and storage space, and provided said establishments are and can be operated in such manner as to comply with the applicable performance standards set forth in sections 10.01(A) and 10.02 of this ordinance. 
(21)  Florist shops. 
(22)  Food stores, grocery stores, meat markets, and delicatessens. 
(23)  Garden supply stores, no outside storage. 
(24)  Gift shops. 
(25)  Hardware stores. 
(26)  Hobby shops. 
(27)  Interior decorating shops, including upholstery and making of draperies, slip covers and other similar articles when conducted as part of the retail operations and secondary to the principal use. 
(28)  Jewelry stores, including watch repair. 
(29)  Laundries, automatic self-service type or hand, provided that laundry machines shall not exceed ten-pounds capacity each, and not more than two (2) persons are employed in addition to one owner or manager. 
(30)  Leather goods and luggage stores. 
(31)  Libraries, public branch. 
(32)  Liquor stores. 
(33)  Loan offices. 
(34)  Locksmith shops. 
(35)  Mail order service stores. 
(35.1)  Massage; when no more than one massage therapist practices massage on the premises at a time and when accessory to the following uses: 
a.  Barber shops and beauty shops. 
b.  Drug stores, pharmacies. 
c.  Fitness establishments containing 5,000 square feet or less of gross floor area. 
d.  Medical, dental or optical clinics. 
(36)  Medical, dental or optical clinics, including accessory laboratories. 
(37)  Motor vehicle parts store, not including installation. 
(38)  Musical instrument sales and repair. 
(39)  Numismatic and philatelic stores. 
(40)  Office supply store. 
(41)  Paint and wallpaper stores. 
(41.1)  Parking, long-term overnight; when accessory to the following uses: 
a.  Health care facilities. 
b.  Police stations. 
c.  Post offices. 
(41.2)  Pet shops, excluding the retail sale of dogs, cats, and large exotic birds. 
(42)  Photocopy establishments, including fast-copy print shops. 
(43)  Photography studios, including developing and printing of photographs. 
(44)  Picture framing, when conducted on the premises as an accessory use only. 
(45)  Repair shops, such as shoes, household appliances, radio and television sets, and similar items. 
(46)  Restaurants, when dancing or entertainment, other than music, is not provided. 
(47)  Schools: Business, dance, martial arts, music. 
(48)  Sewing machine sales and service. 
(49)  Shoe stores. 
(50)  Sporting good stores. 
(51)  Tobacco shops. 
(52)  Toy stores. 
(53)  Video equipment and accessories: Sales, service, rental. 
(54)  Accessory uses to the above permitted uses in accordance with the provisions of section 4.08. 
(C)  Special uses. The following uses may be allowed by special use permit in accordance with the provisions of section 13.11: 
(1)  Special uses allowed in a B-1 District, except for the following: 
a.  Dwelling units, multiple-family; 
b.  Such uses as are permitted uses in a B-2 District. 
(2)  Art galleries, but not including auction rooms. 
(3)  Automobile service stations. 
(3.1)  Automotive service station with a car wash as an accessory use. 
(4)  Banquet halls. 
(4.1)  Bowling alleys. 
(4.2)  Brewery with tap room. 
(5)  Carpet and rug stores. 
(5.1)  Distillery with tasting room. 
(6)  Health care facilities, ambulatory surgical treatment centers in accordance with the following requirements: 
a.  Each ambulatory surgical treatment center shall be restricted to a freestanding building, which building shall exclude all retail uses, but shall permit medical offices and a pharmacy as permissible accessory uses. 
b.  Each ambulatory surgical treatment center shall provide, as part of the building, a loading facility for the use of ambulances, which facility shall not be used for other vehicles. 
c.  Each ambulatory surgical treatment center shall provide an approved plan for vehicular ingress and egress. Approval shall take the form of a certificate signed by the chiefs of police and fire departments and the village engineer, certifying that the plan for ingress and egress proposed by the user will not interfere with either highway or abutting users' traffic, or increase the risk to persons or property. 
d.  Each ambulatory surgical treatment center shall meet the requirements of sections 4.05 and 4.06 for all zoning districts, as they apply to the B-2 Community Business District. 
(6.1)  Fitness establishments; containing 5,001 square feet or more of gross floor area. 
(6.2)  Kennels, excluding the outdoor boarding of dogs and excluding the breeding or retail sale of dogs. 
(7)  Museums or art galleries, public. 
(8)  Physical, cultural, and health services, such as but not limited to gymnasiums, reducing salons, massage therapist, health clubs, public baths, and handball clubs and buildings. 
(9)  Police stations. 
(10)  Post offices. 
(11)  Reserved. 
(12)  Restaurants, including live entertainment, but not including dancing. 
(13)  Taverns or cocktail lounges, where dancing or entertainment other than music, is not provided. 
(13.1)  Tobacco lounge, when in compliance with the Smoke Free Illinois Act as may be amended. 
(14)  Those permitted uses in the ORI, Office, Research, and Light Industrial District, excluding the following: (a) Contractors and construction offices and yards; (b) Motor vehicle sales; (c) Warehouse and storage facilities, except for those having no more than ninety (90) percent of floor area reserved for warehouse or storage use and the remaining floor area for office and/or showroom use. 
Such uses shall not include any outside overnight storage of semitrailer trucks designated as greater than Class "F" (as defined in the 1985 Illinois Revised Statutes) or sixteen thousand (16,000) pounds, or continuous idling of truck engines, between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. 
(D)  Minimum lot size. 
(1)  Lot area. Not less than twenty thousand (20,000) square feet. 
(2)  Lot width. Not less than one hundred (100) feet at the building line. 
(3)  Floor area ratio. The floor area ratio shall not exceed 1.0. 
(E)  Minimum yards. 
(1)  Front yard. Not less than twenty (20) feet, except that parking for motor vehicles may be located up to five (5) feet away from the front lot line. 
(2)  Side yards. 
a.  None required, unless abutting a Residence District (see (E)(4), transitional yards, below). If an interior side yard is provided, not less than five (5) feet. 
b.  On a corner lot, a side yard adjoining a street shall be not less than twenty-five (25) feet. 
(3)  Rear yard. Not less than twenty (20) feet. 
(4)  Transitional yards. When a side or rear lot line in a B-2 District coincides with a side or rear lot line in an adjacent Residence District, a yard shall be provided along such side or rear lot line equal in dimension to the side or rear yard required under this ordinance for the applicable Residence District; such yards shall be landscaped in accordance with the provisions of section 8.01(E) of this ordinance. 
(F)  Off-street parking and loading. In accordance with the provisions set forth in section 11.00 of this ordinance. 
(G)  Maximum building height. Not more than thirty (30) feet. 
(H)  Signs. See Chapter 17, Article II, signs, of the Code of Ordinances. 
(I)  Screening. See section 8.01(E) of this ordinance.
