8.04. - B-3 Town Center District. 
    Intent. The Town Center District is intended to accommodate the intense retail, service, and office uses which are characteristic of the major central business area of the village. This central core area is also intended to contain the primary governmental, civic, and cultural institutions of the village. 
(A)  General conditions. 
(1)  Dwelling units shall not be permitted below the second floor of any mixed-use building or structure. Dwelling units and business uses may be permitted on the same floor, above the ground floor, of mixed-use buildings or structures, provided that the public access to the business uses is separated from the entrance to the residential uses. 
(2)  The village board may waive the provisions of section 8.01(A) by designating certain days on which business establishments may conduct their businesses outside the building or structure. The provisions of section 8.01(A) shall not apply to the normal services and sales offered at automotive service stations. 
(3)  To carry out the intent of the town center plan as approved by the village board, lot area and width requirements shall be those of the individual existing platted lots at the time of adoption of this ordinance, or as may be hereafter modified by the village board in furtherance of said town center plan. 
(B)  Permitted uses. The following uses are permitted: 
(1)  Uses permitted in a B-2 District. 
(2)  Antique shops. 
(3)  Art galleries. 
(4)  Auction rooms. 
(5)  Automobile accessory stores. 
(6)  Banquet halls. 
(7)  Camera and photographic supply stores. 
(8)  Catering establishments, including food preparation for sale, retail and wholesale. 
(9)  Carpet and rug stores. 
(10)  China and glassware stores. 
(11)  Clothing and costume rental shops. 
(12)  Clothing stores. 
(13)  Department stores. 
(14)  Electronic equipment, electrical and household appliance stores, including home computer, radio, and television sales. 
(15)  Funeral homes. 
(16)  Furniture stores, including upholstery when conducted as part of the retail operation and secondary to the principal use. 
(17)  Furrier shops, including the incidental storage and conditioning of furs. 
(18)  Garden supply stores, outside storage permitted. 
(19)  Hotels. 
(20)  Jewelry stores, including watch repair. 
(21)  Leather goods and luggage stores. 
(22)  Libraries, public. 
(23)  Medical, dental or optical clinics. 
(24)  Musical instrument sales and repair. 
(25)  Newspaper offices, but not including printing. 
(26)  Numismatic and philatelic stores. 
(27)  Office supply stores. 
(27.1)  Parking, long-term overnight; when accessory to the following uses: 
a.  Hotels. 
b.  Motor vehicle and equipment sales. 
c.  Village hall. 
(27.2)  Parking, long-term overnight; when accessory to automotive repair garages and when a valid parking enforcement agreement applies to the location. 
(28)  Pet grooming. 
(29)  Pet shops. 
(30)  Picture framing, when conducted on the premises as an accessory use. 
(31)  Plumbing showrooms and shops, retail, fixtures only. 
(32)  Police stations. 
(33)  Post offices. 
(34)  Radio and television broadcasting studios. 
(35)  Recreation buildings, community centers, and meeting halls, public. 
(36)  Recording studios. 
(37)  Resale shops. 
(38)  Restaurants, including live entertainment, but not including dancing. 
(39)  Taverns or cocktail lounges, including live entertainment and dancing. 
(40)  Taxidermists. 
(41)  Telegraph offices. 
(42)  Toy stores. 
(43)  Typewriter, business machine, and adding machine sales and service establishments. 
(44)  Village hall. 
(45)  Accessory uses to the above permitted uses in accordance with the provisions of section 4.08. 
(C)  Special uses. The following uses may be allowed by special use permit in accordance with the provisions of section 13.11: 
(1)  Special uses allowed in a B-2 district, except for the following: 
a.  Such uses as are permitted uses in the B-3 town center district. 
b.  Kennels. 
(2)  Bowling alleys, pool halls, gymnasiums, swimming pools, and skating rinks, miniature golf, and game rooms. 
(3)  Automobile laundries. 
(4)  Automobile service stations. 
(5)  Blueprinting establishments. 
(6)  Buildings exceeding forty-five (45) feet in height. 
(7)  Clubs and lodges-private, fraternal, and religious-but not including teen dance centers, teen centers, dance halls, or dance clubs. 
(8)  Dwelling units, in combination with permitted uses, subject to the conditions of section 8.04(A)(1). 
(9)  Dwelling units, senior citizen housing complex. 
(9.1)  Dwelling units, town center. 
(10)  Garages, automotive repair, where body repair and painting are incidental accessory uses, but not including automobile wrecking yards. 
(11)  Garages, storage. 
(12)  Job printing shops, using presses having beds of not more than fourteen (14) inches by twenty (20) inches. 
(13)  Laundries, retail-where not more than two thousand five hundred (2,500) square feet of floor space is devoted to processing, exclusive of office and storage space. 
(14)  Meat processing, including the sale of meat and meat products to restaurants, hotels, clubs, or other similar establishments when conducted as part of the retail business on the premises. 
(15)  Motor vehicle and equipment sales. 
(16)  Reserved. 
(17)  Schools, commercial or trade, provided that operations do not involve danger of fire or explosion, nor objectionable standards of noise, vibration, smoke, dust, odor, glare, heat, or other nuisances. 
(18)  Telephone exchanges. 
(19)  Theatre. 
(20)  Veterinary clinics. 
(21)  Winery. 
(22)  Rowhouse dwellings. 
(D)  Minimum lot size. 
(1)  Lot area. That area contained on existing platted lots at the time of adoption of this ordinance, or as may be hereafter modified by the village board, consistent with the town center plan. 
(2)  Lot width. That width contained on existing platted lots at the time of adoption of this ordinance, or as may be hereafter modified by the village board, consistent with the town center plan. 
(3)  Floor area ratio. The floor area ratio shall not exceed 2.5. 
(E)  Minimum yards. 
(1)  Front yard. Not less than five (5) feet. 
(2)  Side yards. 
a.  None required, unless abutting a Residence District (see (E)(4), transitional yards, below). If an interior side yard is provided, not less than five (5) feet. 
b.  On a corner lot a side yard adjoining a street shall be not less than five (5) feet. 
(3)  Rear yard. Not less than twenty (20) feet. 
(4)  Transitional yards. When a side or rear lot line in the B-3 District coincides with a side or rear lot line in an adjacent Residence District, a yard shall be provided along each side or rear lot line equal in dimension to the side or rear yard required under this ordinance for the applicable Residence District; such yards shall be landscaped in accordance with the provisions of section 8.01(E) of this ordinance. 
(F)  Off-street parking and loading. In accordance with the provisions set forth in section 11.00 of this ordinance. 
(G)  Maximum building height. Not more than forty-five (45) feet, except as may be granted by special use permit. 
(H)  Signs. See Chapter 17, Article II, signs, of the Code of Ordinances. 
(I)  Screening. See section 8.01(E) of this ordinance. 
(J)  Articulated building elevations. As a condition of approval for special uses, the building elevations of residential structures and mixed-use structures shall have articulated wall recesses and projections so as to create an articulation of the building wall. In addition to the wall recesses, the building elevation shall contain articulation of the facade elements, including but not limited to bay windows, porches, turrets and balconies.

8.05. - B4 General Business District. 
    Intent. It is the intent of this district to provide for those retail and wholesale commercial activities which are considered roadside commercial uses and which may be incompatible with the predominantly retail uses permitted in other Business Districts. The service areas of these uses are not confined to any one neighborhood or even to the village as a whole. The district is located along principal arterial streets in areas that have been previously subdivided and may back up to rail facilities which provide additional transportation access for more intense commercial uses. 
(A)  General conditions. 
(1)  Residential uses, except for those uses existing on the effective date of this ordinance, shall require a special use permit, and shall be owner or proprietor occupied. Watchmen's dwellings shall be permitted only as accessory uses on the premises where employed. 
(2)  The provisions of section 8.01(A) shall not apply to the normal services and sales offered at automotive service station. 
(B)  Permitted uses. The following uses are permitted: 
(1)  Uses permitted in a B-3 District, except hotels, public recreation buildings, community centers, and meeting halls. 
(2)  Bowling alleys, pool halls, swimming pools, and skating rinks, miniature golf, and game rooms. 
(3)  Animal hospitals. 
(4)  Blueprinting establishments. 
(5)  Cartage and express facilities, providing storage of goods, motor trucks, or other equipment is in an enclosed structure. 
(6)  Contractors and construction offices. 
(7)  Discount department stores. 
(8)  Exterminators. 
(9)  Frozen food lockers. 
(10)  Reserved. 
(11)  Garages, storage. 
(12)  Greenhouses and conservatories. 
(13)  Home improvement center, no outside storage. 
(14)  Job printing shops, using presses having beds of not more than fourteen (14) inches by twenty (20) inches. 
(15)  Laboratories, medical, dental or optical. 
(16)  Laundries, retail, where not more than two thousand five hundred (2,500) square feet of floor space is devoted to processing, exclusive of office and storage space. 
(17)  Machinery sales. 
(18)  Monument sales. 
(19)  Motor vehicle and equipment sales. 
(20)  Pet grooming establishments. 
(21)  Rental service stores. 
(22)  Reserved. 
(23)  Schools, commercial or trade, provided that operations do not involve danger of fire or explosion, no objectionable standards of noise, vibration, smoke, dust, odor, glare, heat, or other nuisances. 
(24)  Wholesale establishments with storage of merchandise limited to samples only. 
(25)  Accessory uses to the above permitted uses in accordance with the provisions of section 4.08. 
(C)  Special uses. The following uses may be allowed by special use permit in accordance with the provisions of section 13.11:

c.  Adequate provision for parking and loading shall be made. 
d.  The entire operation, including storage of materials, shall be conducted within an enclosed building.

(7)  Mobile home sales or rental (no occupancy on-site).

(8.1)  Outdoor miniature golf. 
(9)  Trailer sales or rental. 
(10)  Warehouses, mini (located on rear half of lot). 
(11)  Wholesale establishments, with storage of merchandise not limited to samples only. 
(D)  Minimum lot size. 
(1)  Lot area. Not less than twenty thousand (20,000) square feet. 
(2)  Lot width. Not less than one hundred (100) feet at the right-of-way line. 
(3)  Floor area ratio. The floor area ratio shall not exceed 1.0. 
(E)  Minimum yards.

Where a front yard is across an existing or proposed right-of-way from a Residence District, the front yard shall be not less than forty (40) feet and shall be landscaped as recommended by the plan commission. 
(2)  Side yards. 
a.  None required, unless abutting a Residence District (see (E)(4), transitional yards, below). If an interior side yard is provided, it shall be not less than ten (10) feet. 
b.  On a corner lot a side yard adjoining a street shall be not less than twenty-five (25) feet. 
(3)  Rear yard. Not less than twenty (20) feet.

When a side or rear lot line in a B-4 District coincides with a side or rear lot line in an adjacent Residence District, a yard shall be provided along such side or rear lot line equal in dimension to the side or rear yard required under this ordinance for the applicable Residence District; such yard shall be landscaped in accordance with the provisions of section 8.01(E) of this ordinance. 
(F)  Off-street parking and loading. In accordance with the provisions set forth in section 11.00 of this ordinance.

8.06. - B-5 Arterial Business District. 
    Intent. It is the intent of this district to provide for the orderly development or redevelopment of business uses along certain arterial streets utilizing specialized planning techniques and controls. These include but are not limited to control of vehicular access and circulation, development of integral units, planned unit developments, common open space, interior landscaping, required yard landscaping and transitional yard buffering to provide screening protection to abutting residential areas within Roselle and the unincorporated areas. 
    These controls are necessary to assure the compatibility of development with nearby uses, prevent any adverse effect upon the natural environment, provide an appropriate level of vehicular circulation, and thus, promote the public health, safety, and general welfare of the community. 
(A)  General conditions. 
(1)  Residential uses, except for those uses existing on the effective date of this ordinance, shall not be allowed. Watchmen's dwellings shall be permitted only as accessory uses on the premises where employed. 
(2)  In no case shall an Arterial Business District be established which contains less than three (3) acres of land area. 
(3)  The land area requirement for individual site development shall be not less than three (3) acres, except where lots of record on the effective date of this ordinance contain less area than this requirement and additional land cannot reasonably be required. 
(4)  The planning, subdividing, development and use of each parcel of land shall be treated as an integral unit, and shall provide for retail and service business establishments, offices, off-street parking and loading, vehicular access and circulation, pedestrian circulation, common open areas, and landscape buffering. 
(5)  All storage shall be within completely enclosed buildings or effectively screened by a solid wall or fence (including solid entrance and exit gates) not less than six (6) feet nor more than eight (8) feet in height. 
(6)  Any exterior sign displayed shall permit only to a use conducted within the building and be of the same motif used in the Arterial Business District, and shall also conform to Chapter 17, Article II, signs, of the Code of Ordinances. 
(7)  Building permits will not be issued until the full review process of the preliminary and final plans or plats has taken place by the village; driveway permits issued by the Illinois Department of Transportation (IDOT), and any other appropriate highway authority must also be included. Location of curb cuts shall be determined by application of the guidelines contained in the Lake Street corridor study. 
(8)  Not less than ten (10) percent of the entire lot area (development site) shall be devoted to landscaping which shall be maintained as permanent open space. 
(B)  Permitted uses. The following uses are permitted. 
(1)  Uses permitted in a B-2 District. 
(2)  Reserved. 
(3)  Banquet halls. 
(4)  Camera and photographic supply stores. 
(5)  Carpet and rug stores. 
(6)  Clothing stores. 
(7)  Discount department stores. 
(8)  Electronic equipment, electrical and household appliance stores, including home computer, radio, and television sales. 
(9)  Funeral homes. 
(10)  Furniture stores, including upholstery when conducted as part of the retail operation and secondary to the principal use. 
(11)  Garden supply stores, outside storage for sale permitted. 
(12)  Medical, dental, or optical clinics. 
(13)  Musical instrument sales and repair. 
(14)  Office supply stores. 
(14.1)  Parking, long-term overnight; when accessory to the following uses: 
a.  Hotels. 
b.  Motels. 
c.  Motor vehicle and equipment sales. 
(14.2)  Parking, long-term overnight; when accessory to automotive repair garages and when a valid parking enforcement agreement applies to the location. 
(15)  Pet grooming establishments. 
(16)  Pet shops. 
(17)  Picture framing, when conducted on the premises for retail sale. 
(18)  Plumbing showrooms and shops, retail, fixtures only. 
(19)  Rental service stores. 
(20)  Restaurants, including live entertainment, but not including dancing. 
(21)  Taverns or cocktail lounges, including live entertainment and dancing. 
(22)  Toy stores. 
(23)  Typewriter, business machines, and adding machine sales and service establishments. 
(24)  Accessory uses to the above permitted uses in accordance with the provisions of section 4.08. 
(C)  Special uses. The following uses may be allowed by special use permit in accordance with the provisions of section 13.11. 
(1)  Special uses allowed in a B-3 District, except for the following: 
a.  Such uses as are permitted uses in a B-5 District; 
b.  Buildings exceeding forty-five (45) feet in height; 
c.  Dwelling units, in combination with permitted uses; 
d.  Dwelling units, senior citizen housing complex; 
e.  Dwelling units, town center; 
f.  Rowhouse dwellings. 
(1.1)  Automobile accessory stores, including parts replacement (mufflers, shock absorbers, tires, etc.). 
(2)  Hotels. 
(3)  Motels. 
(D)  Maximum lot size. 
(1)  Lot area. Each site to be developed shall contain a minimum of three (3) acres. (See exception in section 8.06(A)(3)). Each lot in a development site shall contain an area of not less than one acre. 
(2)  Lot width. Not less than one hundred fifty (150) feet at the right-of-way line. 
(3)  Floor area ratio. The floor area ratio shall not exceed 0.35. When a planned unit development concept is used, the floor area ratio shall not exceed 0.5. 
(E)  Minimum yards. The required yards in the Arterial Business District shall be used only for landscaping-planting strips to provide a buffer between this district and other abutting zoned districts. 
(1)  Front yard. Not less than twenty (20) feet for the purpose of developing a landscape buffer. If a fire lane is required, such land width shall be in addition to the required front yard. 
(2)  Side yards. 
a.  Not less than fifteen (15) feet unless abutting a Residence District (see [subsection] (E)(4) transitional yards below). No parking shall be allowed within the first five (5) feet of the required interior side yard. 
b.  On a corner lot, a side yard adjoining a street shall be not less than twenty (20) feet for the purpose of developing a landscape buffer. If a fire lane is required, such lane width shall be in addition to the required corner side yard. 
(3)  Rear yard. None required, unless abutting a Residence District (see (E)(4), transitional yards, below). If a rear yard is provided, it shall be not less than fifteen (15) feet. 
(4)  Transitional yards. When a side or rear lot line in a B-5 District coincides with a side or rear lot line in an adjacent Residence District within the incorporated area or another adjacent jurisdiction, a yard shall be provided along such side or rear lot line not less than twenty-five (25) feet in depth. The required transitional yard shall contain landscaping and planting suitable to provide at least seventy-five (75) percent opacity along such Residence District. See also section 8.01(E) of this ordinance. 
(F)  Off-street parking and loading. In accordance with provisions set forth in section 11.00 of this ordinance. 
(G)  Minimum building height. Not more than forty-five (45) feet. 
(H)  Signs. See Chapter 17, Article II, signs, of the Code of Ordinances. 
(I)  Screening. See section 8.01(E) of this ordinance. 
(J)  Landscaping. Additional interior site landscaping shall be required as recommended and approved by the plan commission. There shall be no parking or loading permitted in the required yards.

SECTION 9.00. - OFFICE RESEARCH DISTRICT 

9.01. - ORI Office, Research, and Light Industrial District. 
    Intent. The ORI Office, Research, and Light Industrial District is designed to provide an environment suitable for certain office, research, and light industrial activities that do not create appreciable nuisances or hazards, or for such activities that require a pleasant, hazard-and-nuisance-free environment. This district will often be found adjacent to Residence Districts. Thus it will require special yard setbacks and screening requirements in order to protect the adjacent residential uses. 
(A)  General conditions. 
(1)  Residential units, except for those uses existing on the effective date of this ordinance, shall not be allowed Watchmen's dwellings shall be permitted only as accessory uses on the premises where employed. 
(2)  All business, servicing or processing, except for off-street parking and off-street loading, shall be conducted within completely enclosed buildings, unless otherwise indicated hereinafter. 
(3)  Processes and equipment employed, and goods processed or sold, shall be limited to those which are not objectionable by reason of odor, dust, smoke, cinders, gas, noise, vibration, refuse matter, or water-carried waste. The performance standards specified in section 10.02, shall apply where appropriate to all uses in the Office, Research, and Light Industrial District. 
(4)  All outside storage areas of goods, materials, products, or trash containers shall either be enclosed with solid fences or walls (including solid entrance and exit gates) not less than six (6) feet nor more than eight (8) feet in height, or screened with natural landscaping which shall provide a minimum of one hundred (100) percent opacity when adjacent to a residence district, or seventy-five (75) percent opacity when adjacent to any other district. Such opacity calculation shall be on a full year basis. Lighting of the facility shall be directed away from surrounding properties. 
(5)  The retail uses in the ORI District shall be located within a building or structure containing a permitted use and shall not contain advertising visible from the outside of the building or structure. Such business uses shall be primarily for the service and convenience of the tenants and employees of the ORI District in which they are located. 
(6)  Site plan approval. All applications for building permits in the Office Research District shall require site plan approval which complies with the provisions of section 8.01(E). 
(7)  Overhead loading doors. Location to be determined by plan commission. 
(8)  Barbed wire shall be permitted provided the board of trustees finds the property to have an extraordinarily high risk of theft or vandalism and the barbed wire is designed to minimize personal injury. 
(B)  Permitted uses. The following uses are permitted. 
(1)  Banks and financial institutions. 
(2)  Business service and personal service uses shall be permitted only as accessory uses, to consist of not more than thirty (30) percent of the building use. 
a.  Automobile rental agencies. 
b.  Barber shops. 
c.  Beauty shops. 
d.  Blueprinting, photostating, and lithographing establishments. 
e.  Dry cleaning establishments. 
f.  Laundries. 
g.  Shoe repair shops. 
h.  Travel bureaus and transportation ticket service. 
(3)  Charitable and civic organizations. 
(4)  Clinics (medical, dental or optical). 
(5)  Contractors and construction offices and yards. 
(6)  Governmental buildings. 
(7)  Laboratories, offices and other facilities for engineering, testing, research, and development, including basic applied, development, and technical services. 
(8)  Low-nuisance industrial activities including, but not limited to, electronic and scientific precision instruments manufacture, cloth products manufacture, light machinery production and assembly, custom woodworking shop, and printing and publishing. 
(8.1)  Motor vehicle sales, only when all inventory and sales are conducted and stored indoors, but excluding any adjunct automotive repair and/or any adjunct sales of motor vehicle equipment or parts. 
(9)  Offices-Business, service, and professional. 
(10)  Offices-Medical, dental, optical, chiropractic, etc. 
(11)  Offices sales, including incidental distribution and servicing of products. 
(12)  Recreational facilities, including indoor skating rinks, swim clubs and swimming pools, tennis/racquetball/handball clubs, courts, and buildings containing such facilities, physical, cultural and health services, gymnasiums, reducing salons, and public baths, but not including teen dance centers, teen centers, dance halls, or dance clubs. 
(13)  Retail uses shall be permitted only as accessory uses, to consist of not more than thirty (30) percent of the building use. 
a.  Drug stores/pharmacies. 
b.  Gift shops. 
c.  Office supply stores. 
d.  Restaurants, including the sale of alcoholic beverages but not including drive-in or drive-through establishments. 
e.  Stationery stores. 
(13.1)  Small cell antenna in public right-of-way. 
(14)  Warehouses and storage facilities, but excluding motor freight terminals. 
(15)  Accessory uses to the above permitted uses. 
(C)  Special uses. The following uses may be allowed by special use permit in accordance with the provisions of section 13.00 of this ordinance: 
(1)  Home improvement center, including outside storage. 
(2)  Heliports, helistops, commercial and private, provided they conform with applicable federal, state, and other local government regulations. 
(2.1)  Monopole. 
(3)  Planned unit developments. 
(4)  Public and private utility facilities. 
(5)  Small cell antenna on private property. 
(D)  Minimum lot size. 
(1)  Lot area. Not less than twenty thousand (20,000) square feet. 
(2)  Lot width. Not less than one hundred (100) feet at the building line. 
(3)  Floor area ratio. The floor area ratio shall not exceed 0.8. 
(E)  Minimum yards. 
(1)  Front yard. Not less than twenty-five (25) feet. Where a front yard is across an existing or proposed right-of-way from a Residence District, the front yard shall be not less than forty (40) feet and shall be landscaped as recommended by the plan commission. 
(2)  Side yards. 
a.  On an interior lot, two (2) interior side yards, each of which shall be not less than fifteen (15) feet. 
b.  On a corner lot, one interior side yard which shall be not less than fifteen (15) feet in depth and one corner side yard which shall be not less than twenty-five (25) feet in depth. 
(3)  Rear yard. Not less than twenty-five (25) feet. 
(4)  Transitional yards. Where a side or rear lot line in an ORI District coincides with a side or rear lot line in an adjacent Residence District, a yard shall be provided along such side or rear lot line not less than twenty-five (25) feet in depth. The required transitional yard shall contain landscaping and planting suitable to provide at least seventy-five (75) percent opacity along such Residence District boundary line. See also section 8.01(E) of this ordinance. 
(F)  Offstreet parking and loading. In accordance with the provisions set forth in section 11.00 of this ordinance. 
(G)  Building height. Building height shall not exceed thirty (30) feet. 
(H)  Signs. See Chapter 17, Article II, signs, of the Code of Ordinances. 
(I)  Screening. See section 8.01(E) of this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2135-91,  5, 11-25-91; Ord. No. 2001-2867,  1, 8-27-01; Ord. No. 2002-2955,  7, 12-9-02; Ord. No. 2011-3597,  2, 10-10-11; Ord. No. 2017-3894, ㎣ 8-10, 3-13-17) 
9.02. - ORI-BP Business Park Subdistrict. 
    The ORI Business Park Subdistrict is intended to provide for a unified development of mixed office research and light industrial uses, in a campus-like setting, which will promote and maintain desirable economic activities. Such activities shall not create appreciable nuisances or hazards but shall provide a pleasant, hazard-and-nuisance-free environment. The campus-like setting adds many unique concepts to the Office Research District. The purpose of the district is to allow for large scale development for structures which (1) are adequately served by public improvements, (2) have access to arterial streets and (3) will be separated from surrounding uses by substantial landscape buffering. As a result, the landscaping treatment required herein deviates from the standards of landscaping set forth in section 4.14 of this ordinance to provide landscaping for a large tract of property rather than smaller, scattered sites. 
(A)  General conditions. 
(1)  The minimum net development area to be located in this district shall be twenty (20) acres. 
(2)  Residential units shall not be allowed. Watchmen's dwellings shall be permitted only as accessory uses on the premises where employed. 
(3)  All business, servicing or processing, except for off-street loading, shall be conducted within completely enclosed buildings, unless otherwise indicated hereinafter. 
(4)  Processes and equipment employed, and goods processed or sold, shall be limited to those which are not objectionable by reason of odor, dust, smoke, cinders, gas, noise, vibrations, refuse matter, or water-carried waste. 
(5)  The permitted accessory retail uses in the ORI-BP District shall be located within a building or structure containing a permitted use. 
(6)  No lot, parcel, or tract of land shall be used, and no building or structure shall be erected, altered or remodeled for any of the following uses: abattoirs; acid manufacture; arsenals; crematories; creosote treatment or manufacture; fat rendering; fertilizer manufacture; fireworks or explosive manufacture or storage; dumping or reduction of garbage, dead animals, offal or refuse; ore reduction; petroleum processing or refining; pyroxylin manufacture; synthetic polymers manufacturing; gutta percha manufacture or treatment; salt works; sauerkraut manufacture; soap manufacture; smelters; stock yards/or slaughter of animals or fowls; tallow, grease or lard manufacture or treatment; tanning, curing or storage of rawhides or skins; tar distillation or manufacture; or cement concrete or asphaltic concrete batch mixing plants. 
(7)  No activities involving the storage, utilization or manufacture of materials or products which decompose by detonation shall be permitted, except such as are specifically licensed by the Village of Roselle. Such materials shall include, but shall not be confined to: all primary explosives such as lead azide, lead styphnate, fulminates, and tetrocene; all high explosives such as TNT, RDX, HMX, PETN and picric acid; propellants and components thereof such as nitro-cellulose, black powder, boron dydrides, hydrazine, and its derivatives; pyrotechnics and fireworks such as magnesium powder, potassium chlorate and potassium nitrate; blasting explosives such as dynamite and nitroglycerine; unstable organic compounds such as acetylides, tetrazoles, perchloric acid, parchlorates, chlorates, hydrogen peroxide in concentrations greater than thirty-five (35) percent; and nuclear fuels, fissionable materials, and products and reactor elements such as Uranium 235 and Plutonium 239. 
(8)  Any use established in the ORI-BP District hereafter shall be operated in such a manner as to comply with applicable performance standards as hereinafter set forth governing noise, smoke, particulate matter, toxic or noxious matter, odors, fire and explosive hazards, or vibration, glare or heat. No use already established on the effective date of this ordinance shall be so altered or modified as to conflict with such applicable performance standards. Recognized testing may be required by the zoning administrator. 
(9)  Site plan approval. All applications for building permits in the ORI-BP District shall require site plan approval which complies with the provision of section 8.01(E) and section 9.01(H) of this ordinance. 
(B)  Permitted uses. The following uses are permitted: 
(1)  Manufacturing, fabricating, storing, cleaning, assembling, repairing or servicing establishments. 
(2)  Warehouses and storage facilities, but excluding motor freight terminals. 
(3)  Wholesale establishments. 
(4)  Buildings used exclusively for offices. 
(4.1)  Motor vehicle sales, only when all inventory and sales are conducted and stored indoors, but excluding any adjunct automotive repair and/or any adjunct sales of motor vehicle equipment or parts. 
(5)  Recreational facilities, including indoor skating rinks, swim clubs and swimming pools, tennis/racquetball/handball clubs, courts, and buildings containing such facilities, physical, cultural and health services, gymnasiums, reducing salons and public baths, but not including teen dance centers, teen centers, dance halls, or dance clubs. 
(5.1)  Shooting gallery and range, indoor, subject to the performance standards specified in section 10.02, as well as all other applicable environmental standards pertaining to shooting ranges including those standards required or recommended by various federal agencies, except that all noise generated within the interior of such establishments shall be wholly contained within the exterior walls of the building enclosing the establishment. Any shooting gallery or range, indoor, within five hundred (500) feet of the property line of a dwelling unit shall not operate between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 08:00 a.m., except as otherwise may be approved by the mayor and board of trustees. 
(6)  Showroom and sales area as accessory uses to principal uses. 
(6.1)  Small cell antenna in public right-of-way. 
(7)  Retail business services and personal services uses shall be permitted only as accessory uses, to consist of not more than fifteen (15) percent of the building use. The retail business and personal service uses shall be ones that primarily service the occupancy of the use permitted. 
(8)  Accessory uses to the above permitted uses. 
(9)  By permit, temporary storage in interior side yard and rear yards (not adjoining a street or residence district) for a period not to exceed ninety (90) days, provided it is solidly screened to a height of eight (8) feet and no storage shall be permitted over said solid eight-foot screen. Said temporary storage to be approved by the zoning administrator. 
(C)  Special uses. The following uses may be allowed by special use permit: 
(1)  Day care facilities. 
(2)  Hotels. 
(2.1)  Monopole. 
(3)  Restaurants. 
(4)  Public and private utility, and public service uses including all municipal facilities. 
(5)  Small cell antenna on private property. 
(D)  Minimum lot size. 
(1)  Lot area. Not less than two (2) acres except twenty-five (25) percent of total area of the district may be 1.75 acres in size. 
(2)  Lot width. Not less than one hundred fifty (150) feet at the building line. 
(3)  Floor area ratio. The floor area ratio shall not exceed 0.5. 
(E)  Minimum yards. 
(1)  Front yard. Not less than fifty (50) feet. Except front yards adjoining arterial streets shall not be less than seventy-five (75) feet. 
(2)  Side yards. 
a.  On a corner lot, an interior side yard of not less than fifteen (15) feet and a corner side yard of not less than fifty (50) feet. Corner side yards fronting on arterial streets shall not be less than seventy-five (75) feet. 
b.  On an interior lot two (2) interior side yards each of which shall not be less than fifteen (15) feet and a combined width of both yards of not less than thirty-five (35) feet. 
(3)  Rear yard. Not less than fifty (50) feet. Where a rear yard adjoins an arterial street, it shall be not less than seventy-five (75) feet. 
(4)  Transitional yard. A transitional yard shall be established: 
a.  Around the entire perimeter property lines of the Business Park Subdistrict in accordance with the following standards: 
Transition Yards Required Depth 
(in feet) Adjacent residential use/district 100 Adjacent nonresidential 25  
b.  Where Business Park Subdistrict property lines are adjacent to or across a public right-of-way from a residential use or district, the minimum yard setbacks shall be in addition to the 100-foot transitional yard. 
(F)  Building height. Building height shall not exceed thirty-five (35) feet. For buildings greater than twenty-five (25) feet in height, the minimum required yards shall be increased by one foot for each one foot in building height over twenty-five (25) feet. 
(G)  Maximum lot coverage. The maximum coverage of any lot within this district (for permitted uses listed in section 9.02(B) above) by buildings, parking, roads, or any other impervious surface shall not exceed seventy-five (75) percent. 
(H)  Landscaping requirements. In accordance with the provisions set forth in section 4.14 of this ordinance except as amended by the following provisions which are unique to this section: 
(1)  Transitional yard. Transitional yard landscaping and screening shall be provided in the transitional yard. 
a.  Such screening shall be a minimum of five (5) feet in height. When adjacent to residential lots, the height of such screen shall be increased so as to be measured from the average elevation of the adjoining residential property line. 
b.  When adjacent to a residence district, the use of a three-foot to five-foot berm shall be required. 
c.  When adjacent to a residence district, at a minimum, trees shall be planted within the transition yard and shall include: 
1.  Deciduous: Three (3) per one hundred (100) lineal feet. 
2.  Evergreen: Five (5) per one hundred (100) lineal feet. 
3.  Flowering: Five (5) per one hundred (100) lineal feet. 
d.  When adjacent to a nonresidential district other than M or ORI District, the use of a two-foot to four-foot earthen berm shall be required. At a minimum, trees shall be planted within the transition yard and shall include: 
1.  Deciduous: Three (3) per two hundred (200) lineal feet. 
2.  Evergreen: Five (5) per two hundred (200) lineal feet. 
3.  Flowering: Five (5) per two hundred (200) lineal feet. 
e.  When adjacent to another M or ORI [District] no plant material is required beyond the building lot or parking lot landscaping and screening standards. 
(2)  Streets and rights-of-way. To create "entranceways" into the development, landscaping, signage and other forms of monumenting shall be provided at major street intersections. These "entranceways" shall be accented with denser more mature plantings than required by other sections and shall include the installation of evergreen and other flowering shrubs. 
(3)  Lot landscaping. 
a.  Foundation. A minimum ten-foot strip in the front of the structure and a five-foot strip of landscaping along the rear and side lines of the structure. On a corner lot there shall be two (2) front faces of the structure (along the front and corner side yards). These areas shall contain a maximum of fifty (50) percent of ground cover (i.e. sod and/or herbaceous), unless shown to be functionally impractical due to building/structural appurtenances as determined by the zoning administrator. 
b.  Interior parking lots. For parking lots over six (6) spaces in size, landscaping islands will be required at both ends of every row of parking spaces and a mid-row landscape island must be provided for each twenty (20) parking spaces or five (5) percent of the parking area must be landscaped, whichever requires the greater amount. Three (3) feet of landscaping around the perimeter of the parking area may be applied to the five (5) percent landscape requirement provided that it is not part of a required setback. The minimum size of a planting area is one hundred eighty (180) square feet with a minimum width dimension of ten (10) feet. One shade tree must be provided for each one hundred eighty (180) square feet of landscaped area. 
c.  Parking lot screening. Unless sufficiently screened by transition yard landscaping and screening, all yards and off-street parking areas must be screened as required by section 4.14. 
d.  Interior side yards. As a minimum, one shade tree for each eighty (80) feet on center (as measured per lineal foot along the side lot line), and alternately spaced with the existing or proposed trees within an interior side yard or rear yard of an adjoining parcel. 
e.  Rear yard landscaping. As a minimum, one shade tree for each eighty (80) feet on center (as measured per lineal foot along the side lot line) and alternately spaced with the existing or proposed trees if within an interior side yard or rear yard of an adjoining parcel. 
(4)  General conditions on landscaping. 
a.  Berming. Mounding shall generally vary in height, width and length, to create a free-form, naturalistic effect. 
b.  [ Sideslope. ] The sideslope of berms shall not exceed 3:1 ratio, and a 6:1 ratio is desired. 
(5)  Landscape plan approval. The requirements of section 4.14 of this ordinance shall apply, except where in conflict with these requirements. 
(I)  Establishing a business park district. 
(1)  Application. 
(a)  Application for a ORI-BP District may be made by the owner or contract purchaser by filing an application for a zoning amendment with the zoning administrator, in accordance with requirements of section 13 of this ordinance; 
(b)  At the time the application is filed, the developer shall also submit plans, data, and other information as required by this ordinance in (I)(2), concept plan; submittals, below; 
(c)  Copies of the application and submittals shall be forwarded to the planning and zoning commission with the request to hold a public hearing; and 
(d)  The applicant shall give notice of the public hearing in accordance with procedures outlined in section 13 of this ordinance. 
(2)  Concept plan; submittals. At the time of the application, the developer shall submit fifteen (15) copies folded to an eight and one-half-inch by fourteen-inch size with the title block clearly displayed and one copy eleven (11) inches by fourteen (14) inches in size of the following materials: 
(a)  A location map, which illustrates the relationship of the property to the surrounding land uses; 
(b)  A plat of survey prepared by a registered surveyor, including a legal description of the subject property to be included in the district and locating lot lines and all existing structures; 
(c)  Architectural drawings and sketches illustrating the design and character of proposed structures; 
(d)  Concept landscape plan for the district, prepared by a landscape architect and showing proposed treatment of major entryways, rights-of-way, and perimeter buffers; 
(e)  A preliminary engineering study, including the following: 
1.  A general description of and location map showing location and size of existing sanitary sewers, storm sewers, water service facilities, streets and right-of-way widths within and adjacent two hundred (200) feet of the proposed district. 
2.  A study of existing site conditions including soils, wetlands, floodplain, stormwater runoff and any other significant natural features. 
3.  Proposed improvements necessary to properly handle the traffic, potable water, sanitary sewer, stormwater drainage and other service needs, upon development of the district; 
4.  Designation of proposed street system. 
(f)  A description of the modifications, exceptions and variations from this ordinance, if any, or the village's subdivision control ordinance, if any, which are being requested as part of the application for the establishment of the district; 
(g)  A development plan showing proposed phasing of the project and estimated time of completion for each phase; 
(h)  A traffic impact analysis prepared by a traffic engineer; 
(i)  Any other pertinent information as deemed necessary by the zoning administrator and/or planning and zoning commission. 
(3)  Concept plan approval. 
(a)  After the required submittals have been presented and reviewed during the public hearing, the planning and zoning commission shall submit its recommendation with respect to the application to the village board of trustees. The commission may recommend: 
1.  Approval of the application; 
2.  Approval of the application, with conditions; or 
3.  Disapproval of the application. 
(b)  The commission may recommend, or the village board may require, changes or revisions to the plans as are deemed necessary in the interest and needs of the community, provided they are in keeping with the intent of this ordinance. 
(c)  The commission shall set forth the reasons for its recommendation in a statement of findings of fact and recommendations, which shall be forwarded to the village board within thirty (30) days after the close of the hearing: 
1.  Any requested exceptions, modifications, or variations from this ordinance or the village's subdivision control ordinance, should be clearly documented in the statement of findings of fact and recommendations; 
2.  In the event of a favorable recommendation, the commission shall specify particular conditions which should be incorporated into an approval of the application, which may or may not include requested exceptions, modifications, or variations from this ordinance. 
(d)  Within forty-five (45) days after receipt of the commission's recommendation, the board of trustees shall either approve, approve with conditions, disapprove or send the application back to the developer and the planning and zoning commission for modification and review: 
1.  A conditional approval shall state what additions or deletions from the application as submitted shall be made in the application as approved; and 
2.  Any exceptions, modifications or variations from this ordinance that are granted by the board of trustees must be clearly stated and identified as part of the approval. 
(4)  Preparation of a development ordinance. 
(a)  Upon review and approval of the concept plans by the village board, the village attorney shall prepare an ordinance governing development of the property. This ordinance shall contain: 
1.  A list of exhibits which document the approved development plan; 
2.  A list of restrictions and conditions assuring the village that the development will be carried out in full compliance with the final plan and within the time schedule of construction submitted with the final plan; 
3.  Any modifications to development standards arising from unique conditions. 
(5)  Final plat of subdivision. Based upon the approved plan, the developer shall submit a final plat of subdivision in accordance with the process described in the village's subdivision regulations. 
(6)  Final plan approval for individual lots. 
(a)  All lots within the district shall be developed according to the approved concept plans, development ordinance, and all regulations and restrictions contained in the business park ordinance; provided however, upon approval of the final plat of subdivision of any portion of the development, the developer shall be able to build on part of a lot or on one lot and part of another lot without subdividing or resubdividing same; provided the combined lot or the remaining portion when combined with its adjoining lots meets the minimum lot size and setback requirements of the ordinance. 
(b)  Prior to the issuance of a building permit, the owner of a particular lot or tract within the district shall submit six (6) copies of final plan, at a scale not less than one inch equals fifty (50) feet, to village staff for review and approval. Except for provisions of this section, which may conflict, all requirements under section 4.13, site plan requirements and section 4.14, landscaping, shall be met. 
(J)  Off-street parking and loading. In accordance with the provisions set forth in section 11.00 of this ordinance. Except, however, off-street loading berths shall be enclosed on any side adjoining a residential district. 
(K)  Signage. Signage shall be provided by a master plan inclusive of standards for all sign types as recommended by the planning and zoning commission and approved by the village board of trustees.

9.03. - ORI-HC High Cube Subdistrict. 
    Intent. The ORI-HC High Cube Subdistrict is intended to provide for a unified development of mixed office, research and light or medium industrial uses, in a campus-like setting, which will promote and maintain desirable economic activities. Such activities shall not create appreciable nuisances or hazards but shall provide a pleasant, hazard-and-nuisance-free environment. The campus-like setting adds many unique concepts to the Office Research District. The purpose is to allow for large scale development for structures which (1) are adequately served by public improvements, (2) have access to arterial streets, and (3) will be separated from surrounding areas by substantial landscape buffering. The distinguishing feature of the High Cube Subdistrict is that structures provide for high bulk, open, free span structures typically associated with storage, warehousing and distribution facilities. As a result, the landscaping treatment required herein, at times, deviates from the standards of landscaping set forth in section 4.14 of this ordinance to provide landscaping for a large tract of property rather than smaller, scattered sites. 
(A)  General conditions. 
(1)  The minimum net development area to be located in this district shall be twenty (20) acres. 
(2)  Residential units shall not be allowed. Watchmen's dwellings shall be permitted only as accessory uses on the premises where employed. 
(3)  All business, servicing or processing, except for off-street parking and off-street loading, shall be conducted within completely enclosed buildings, unless otherwise indicated hereinafter. 
(4)  Processes and equipment employed, and goods processed or sold, shall be limited to those which are not objectionable by reason of odor, dust, smoke, cinders, gas, noise, vibrations, refuse matter, or water-carried waste. The performance standards specified in section 10.01 shall apply where appropriate to all uses in the ORI-HC District. 
(5)  All outside storage areas of goods, materials, or products shall be screened with a solid eight-foot fence (no chain link) and storage material not to exceed fence height. Maximum storage area may not exceed twenty (20) percent of proposed building footprint area. Storage shall be permitted in the rear of structures only. 
(6)  The permitted retail uses in the ORI-HC District shall be located within a building or structure containing a permitted use. 
(7)  No lot, parcel, or tract of land shall be used, and no building or structure shall be erected, altered or remodeled for any of the following uses: abattoirs; acid manufacture; arsenals; crematories; creosote treatment or manufacture; fat rendering; fertilizer manufacture; fireworks or explosive manufacture or storage; dumping or reduction of garbage, dead animals, offal or refuse; ore reduction; petroleum processing or refining; pyroxylin manufacture; synthetic polymers manufacturing; gutta percha manufacture or treatment; salt works; sauerkraut manufacture; soap manufacture; smelters; stock yards or slaughter of animals or fowl; tallow, grease or lard manufacture or treatment; tanning, curing or storage of rawhides or skins; tar distillation or manufacture; or cement concrete of asphaltic concrete batch mixing plants. 
(8)  No activities involving the storage, utilization or manufacture of materials or products which decompose by detonation shall be permitted, except such as are specifically licensed by the Village of Roselle. Such materials shall include, but shall not be confined to: all primary explosives such as lead azide, lead styphnate, fulminates, and tetrocene; all high explosives such as TNT, RDX, HMX, PETN and picric acid; propellants and components thereof such as nitro-cellulose, black powder, boron dydrides, hydrazine, and its derivatives; pyrotechnics and fireworks such as magnesium powder, potassium chlorate and potassium nitrate; blasting explosives such as dynamite and nitroglycerine; unstable organic compounds such as acetylides, tetrazoles, perchloric acid, perchlorates, chlorates, hydrogen peroxide in concentrations greater than thirty-five (35) percent; and nuclear fuels, fissionable materials, and products and reactor elements such as Uranium 235 and Plutonium 239. 
(9)  Any use established in the ORI-HC District hereafter shall be operated in such a manner as to comply with applicable performance standards as hereinafter set forth governing noise, smoke, particulate matter, toxic or noxious matter, odors, fire and explosive hazards, or vibration, glare or heat. No use already established on the effective date of this ordinance shall be so altered or modified as to conflict with such applicable performance standards. Recognized testing may be required by the zoning administrator. 
(10)  Site plan approval. All applications for building permits in the ORI-HC District shall require site plan approval which complies with the provisions of sections 8.01(E) and 9.01(H). 
(B)  Permitted uses. The following uses are permitted: 
(1)  Manufacturing, fabricating, storing, cleaning, assembling, repairing or servicing establishments. 
(2)  Public and private utility, and public service uses including all municipal facilities. 
(3)  Warehouses and storage facilities, but excluding motor freight terminals. 
(4)  Wholesale establishments. 
(4.1)  Motor vehicle sales, only when all inventory and sales are conducted and stored indoors, but excluding any adjunct automotive repair and/or any adjunct sales of motor vehicle equipment or parts. 
(5)  Recreational facilities, including but not limited to, tennis courts, golf courses, jogging, walking and biking trails and paths, but not including teen dance centers, teen centers, dance halls, or dance clubs. 
(6)  Showrooms and sales area as accessory to principal uses. 
(6.1)  Small cell antenna in public right-of-way. 
(7)  Retail business services and personal services uses shall be permitted only as accessory uses, to consist of not more than fifteen (15) percent of the building use. The retail business and personal service uses shall be ones that primarily service the occupancy of the use permitted. 
(8)  Accessory uses to the above permitted uses. 
(C)  Special uses. The following uses may be allowed by special use permit: 
(1)  Day care facilities. 
(1.1)  Monopole. 
(2)  Retail use. 
(3)  Outside, open storage. 
(4)  Buildings used exclusively for offices. 
(5)  Public and private utility, and public uses including all municipal facilities. 
(6)  Small cell antenna on private property. 
(D)  Minimum lot size. 
(1)  Lot area. Not less than three (3) acres. 
(2)  Lot width. Not less than two hundred (200) feet at the building line. 
(3)  Floor area ratio. The floor area ratio shall not exceed .625. 
(E)  Minimum yards. 
(1)  Front yard. Not less than fifty (50) feet. Except that front yards adjoining arterial streets shall not be less than seventy-five (75) feet. 
(2)  Side yards. 
(a)  On a corner, an interior side yard of not less than fifteen (15) feet and a corner side yard of not less than fifty (50) feet. Corner side yard fronting on arterial street shall not be less than seventy-five (75) feet. 
(b)  On an interior lot two (2) interior side yards each of which shall be not less than fifteen (15) feet and a combined width of both yards of not less than thirty-five (35) feet. 
(3)  Rear yard. Not less than fifty (50) feet. Where a rear yard adjoins an arterial street, it shall not be less than seventy-five (75) feet. 
(4)  Transition yard. A transition yard shall be established around the entire perimeter of the zoning district in accordance with the following standards: 
Transition Yard Required Depth 
(feet) Adjacent residential 100 Adjacent nonresidential 25  
(F)  Building height. Building height shall not exceed thirty-five (35) feet. For buildings greater than twenty-five (25) feet in height, the minimum yards shall be increased by one foot for each one foot in building height over twenty-five (25) feet. 
(G)  Maximum lot coverage. The maximum coverage of any lot within this district (for permitted uses listed in section 9.03(B) above) by buildings, parking, roads, or any impervious surface shall not exceed eighty (80) percent. 
(H)  Landscape requirements. In accordance with the provisions set forth in section 4.14 of this ordinance except as amended by the following provisions which are unique to this section: 
(1)  Transition yard. Transition yard landscaping and screening shall be provided in the transition yard. 
(a)  Such screening shall be a minimum of five (5) feet in height. When adjacent to residential lots, the height of such screen shall be increased so as to be measured from the average elevation of the adjoining residential property line. 
(b)  When adjacent to a residence district, the use of a three-foot to five-foot earthen berm shall be required. 
(c)  When adjacent to a residence district, at a minimum, trees shall be planted within the transition yard and shall include: 
(1)  Deciduous: Three (3) per one hundred (100) lineal feet. 
(2)  Evergreen: Five (5) per one hundred (100) lineal feet. 
(3)  Flowering: Five (5) per one hundred (100) lineal feet. 
(d)  When adjacent to a nonresidential district other than an M or ORI, the use of a two-foot to four-foot earthen berm shall be required. At a minimum, trees shall be planted within the transition yard and shall include: 
(1)  Deciduous: Three (3) per two hundred (200) lineal feet. 
(2)  Evergreen: Five (5) per two hundred (200) lineal feet. 
(3)  Flowering: Five (5) per two hundred (200) lineal feet. 
(e)  When adjacent to another M or ORI, no plant material is required beyond the building lot or parking lot landscaping and screening standards. 
(2)  Streets and rights-of-way. To create "entranceways" into the development, landscaping, signage and other forms of monumenting shall be provided at major street intersections. These "entranceways" shall be accented with denser more mature plantings than required by other sections and shall include the installation of evergreen and other flowering shrubs. 
(3)  Lot landscaping. 
(a)  Foundation. A minimum ten-foot strip in the front of the structure and a five-foot strip of landscaping along the rear and side lines of the structure. On a corner lot there shall be two (2) front faces of the structure (along the front and corner side yards). These areas shall contain a maximum of fifty (50) percent of ground cover (i.e. sod and/or herbaceous), unless shown to be functionally impractical to building/structural appurtenances as determined by the zoning administrator. 
(b)  Interior parking lots. For parking lots over six (6) spaces in size, landscape islands will be required at both ends of every row of parking spaces and a mid-row landscape island must be provided for each twenty (20) parking spaces or five (5) percent of the parking area must be landscaped, whichever requires the greater amount. Three (3) feet of landscaping around the perimeter of the parking area may be applied to the five (5) percent landscape requirement, provided that it is not part of a required setback. The minimum size of a planting area is one hundred eighty (180) square feet area with a minimum width dimension of ten (10) feet. One shade tree must be provided for each one hundred eighty (180) square feet of landscape area. 
(c)  Parking lot screening. Unless sufficiently screened by transitional yard landscaping and screening, all yards and off-street parking areas must be screened as required by section 4.14. 
(d)  Interior side yards. As a minimum, one shade tree for each eighty (80) feet on center (as measured per lineal foot along the side lot line), and alternately spaced with the existing or proposed trees within an interior side yard or rear yard of an adjoining parcel. 
(e)  Rear yard landscaping. As a minimum, one shade tree for each eighty (80) feet on center (as measured per lineal foot along the side lot line) and alternately spaced with the existing or proposed trees if within an interior side yard or rear yard of an adjoining parcel. 
(4)  General conditions on landscaping. 
(a)  Berming. Mounding shall generally vary in height, width and length, to create a free-form, naturalistic effect. 
(b)  [ Sideslopes. ]The sideslopes of berms shall not exceed 3:1 ratio, and 6:1 ratio is desired. 
(5)  Landscape plan approval. The requirements of section 4.14 of this ordinance shall apply, except where in conflict with these requirements and except that the Village of Roselle Community Development Director shall have review and approval authority in all such plans. 
(I)  Establishing a High Cube District. 
(1)  Application. 
(a)  Application for an ORI-HC District may be made by the owner or contract purchaser by filing an application for a zoning amendment with the zoning administrator, in accordance with the requirements of section 13 of this ordinance. 
(b)  At the time the application is filed, the developer shall also submit plans, data, and other information as required by this ordinance in (I)(2), concept plan; submittals, below; 
(c)  Copies of the application and submittals shall be forwarded to the planning and zoning commission with the request to hold a public hearing; and 
(d)  The applicant shall give notice of the public hearing in accordance with procedures outlined in section 13 of this ordinance. 
(2)  Concept plan; submittals. At the time of the application, the developer shall submit fifteen (15) copies folded to an eight and one-half-inch by fourteen-inch size with the title block clearly displayed and one copy eleven (11) inches by fourteen (14) inches in size of the following materials: 
(a)  A location map, which illustrates the relationship of the property to surrounding land uses. 
(b)  A plat of survey prepared by a registered surveyor, including a legal description of the subject property to be included in the district and locating lot lines and all existing structures. 
(c)  Architectural drawings and sketches illustrating the design and character of proposed structures. 
(d)  Concept landscape plan for the district, prepared by a landscape architect and showing proposed treatment of major entryways, rights-of-way, and perimeter buffers. 
(e)  A preliminary engineering study, including the following: 
1.  A general description of and location map showing location and size of existing sanitary sewers, storm sewers, water service facilities, streets and right-of-way widths within and adjacent two hundred (200) feet of the proposed district. 
2.  A study of existing site conditions including soils, wetlands, floodplain, stormwater runoff and any other significant natural features. 
3.  Proposed improvements necessary to properly handle the traffic, potable water, sanitary sewer, stormwater drainage and other service needs, upon development of the district. 
4.  Designation of proposed street system. 
(f)  A description of the modifications, exceptions, and variations from this ordinance, if any, or the village's subdivision control ordinance, if any, which are being requested as part of the application for the establishment of the district; 
(g)  A development plan, showing proposed phasing of the project and estimated time of completion for each phase. 
(h)  A traffic impact analysis prepared by a traffic engineer. 
(i)  Any other pertinent information as deemed necessary by the zoning administrator and/or planning and zoning commission. 
(3)  Concept plan approval. 
(a)  After the required submittals have been presented and reviewed during the public hearing, the planning and zoning commission shall submit its recommendation with respect to the application to the village board of trustees. The commission may recommend: 
1.  Approval of the application; 
2.  Approval of the application, with conditions; or 
3.  Disapproval of the application. 
(b)  The commission may recommend, or the village board may require, changes or revisions to the plans as are deemed necessary in the interest and needs of the community, provided they are in keeping with the intent of this section. 
(c)  The commission shall set forth the reasons for its recommendation in a statement of findings of fact and recommendations, which shall be forwarded to the village board within thirty (30) days after the close of the hearing: 
1.  Any requested exceptions, modifications, or variations from this ordinance or the village's subdivision control ordinance, should be clearly documented in the statement of findings of fact and recommendations. 
2.  In the event of a favorable recommendation, the commission shall specify particular conditions which should be incorporated into an approval of the application, which may or may not include requested exceptions, modifications, or variations from this section. 
(d)  Within forty-five (45) days after receipt of the commission's recommendation, the board of trustees shall either approve, approve with conditions, disapprove or send the application back to the developer and the planning and zoning commission for modification and review: 
1.  A conditional approval shall state what additions or deletions from the application as submitted shall be made in the application as approved; and 
2.  Any exceptions, modifications or variations from this section that are granted by the board of trustees must be clearly stated and identified as part of the approval. 
(4)  Preparation of a development ordinance. 
(a)  Upon review and approval of the concept plans by the village board, the village attorney shall prepare an ordinance governing development of the property. This ordinance shall contain: 
1.  A list of exhibits which document the approved development plan. 
2.  A list of restrictions and conditions assuring the village that the development will be carried out in full compliance with the final plan and within the time schedules of construction submitted with the final plan. 
3.  Any modifications to development standards arising from unique conditions. 
(5)  Final plat of subdivision. Based upon the approved plan, the developer shall submit a final plat of subdivision in accordance with the process described in the village's subdivision regulations. 
(6)  Final plan approval for individual lots. 
(a)  All lots within the district shall be developed according to the approved concept plans, development ordinance, and all regulations and restrictions contained in the High Cube Ordinance, provided however, upon approval of the final plat of subdivision of any portion of the development, developer shall be able to build on part of a lot or on one lot and part of another lot without subdividing or resubdividing same; provided the combined lot or the remaining portion when combined with its adjoining lots meets the minimum lot size and setback requirements of this section. 
(b)  Prior to the issuance of a building permit, the owner of a particular lot or tract within the district shall submit six (6) copies of final plan, at a scale not less than one inch equals fifty (50) feet, to village staff for review and approval. Except for provisions of this section, which may conflict, all requirements under section 4.13, site plan requirements and section 4.14, landscaping shall be met. 
(J)  Off-street parking and loading. In accordance with the provisions set forth in section 11.00, except, however, off-street loading berths shall be enclosed on any side adjoining a residential district. 
(K)  Signage. Signage shall be as provided by a master plan inclusive of standards for all sign types as recommended by the planning and zoning commission and approved by the board of trustees.
