(B)  Jurisdiction and authority. The zoning board of appeals is hereby vested with the following jurisdiction and authority: 
(1)  To hear and decide appeals from any order, requirement, decision, or determination to be made by the zoning administrator under this ordinance; 
(2)  To hear and decide variations from the terms provided in this ordinance in the manner and subject to the standards set forth in this section; and 
(3)  To hear and decide all matters referred to it or upon which it is required to pass under this ordinance, such as appeals from any decision or directive of the planning and zoning commission. 
(Ord. No. 1576-87,  1, 6-22-87; Ord. No. 1720-88,  3, 7-11-88; Ord. No. 2094-91,  10, 6-24-91) 
13.07. - Planning and zoning commission. 
(A)  Creation. The planning and zoning commission of the Village of Roselle, as heretofore created and established under the provision of Chapter 24, paragraph 11-12-4, Illinois State Statutes, as amended, is hereby designated as the planning and zoning commission referred to in this ordinance. 
(B)  Jurisdiction. The planning and zoning commission shall have the following duties under this ordinance: 
(1)  [ Reserved. ] 
(2)  To receive from the zoning administrator copies of all applications for amendments or special uses which have been introduced into the village board and submit reports to the zoning board of appeals setting forth its findings and recommendations in the manner prescribed in the section for amendments and special uses; 
(3)  To receive from the zoning administrator copies of all applications for special use-planned unit development (preliminary development plans) and submit reports and recommendations to the village board setting forth its findings and recommendations in the manner prescribed in section 12.00; 
(4)  To receive from the zoning administrator copies of all applications for special use-planned unit development (final development plans) and process them in the manner prescribed in section 12.00; 
(5)  To review the provisions of this ordinance and to make reports of its recommendations to the village board not less frequently than once each year; 
(6)  To provide a forum for developers to receive information and advice regarding general concepts and proposals for development of land within Roselle and its planning area without the need for fees or formal application; and 
(7)  To hear and decide all matters upon which it is required to pass under this ordinance, and to recommend repeal of amendments or special uses where no development has taken place within the specified time. 
(Ord. No. 1576-87,  1, 6-22-87; Ord. No. 1720-88,  3, 7-11-88; Ord. No. 2094-91,  10, 6-24-91) 
13.08. - Appeals. 
(A)  Authority. The zoning board of appeals shall hear and decide appeals from an administrative order, requirement, decision or determination made by the zoning administrator, relating to regulations of this ordinance. 
(B)  Initiation. An appeal may be taken to the zoning board of appeals by any person, firm or corporation or by any office, department, board or commission aggrieved by an administrative order, requirement, decision or determination under this ordinance by the zoning administrator. 
(C)  Processing. An appeal in triplicate shall be filed with the village clerk with the required fee. The village clerk shall forward such appeal to the zoning board of appeals for processing in accordance with the Illinois Revised Statutes as amended, forward one copy to the zoning administrator, and retain one copy for the village clerk's files. 
(D)  Decisions. All decisions, after hearing of the zoning board of appeals on appeals from an administrative order, requirement, or decision, or determination of the zoning administrator, or other authorized official of the Village of Roselle, shall, in all instances, be final administrative determinations and shall be subject to judicial review only in accordance with the Illinois Revised Statutes as amended. 
(Ord. No. 1576-87,  1, 6-22-87; Ord. No. 1720-88,  3, 7-11-88) 
13.09. - Variations. 
(A)  Authority. The zoning board of appeals shall grant or deny variations of the provisions of this ordinance in harmony with its general purpose and intent except the planning and zoning commission shall recommend and the board of trustees shall approve variations that are part of special uses. 
(B)  Initiation. An application for a variation may be made by any person, firm, or corporation or by any office, department, board or commission requesting or intending to request application for a zoning certificate. 
(C)  Application and processing. An application for a variation shall be filed with the zoning administrator with the required fee. The zoning administrator shall forward such application to the zoning board of appeals for processing in accordance with the Illinois Revised Statutes, as amended; to the village staff for review and comment; and to the village clerk for filing. The application shall contain such information as the zoning board of appeals may, by rule, require and shall include, at a minimum: 
(1)  Legal description and common address of subject property; 
(2)  Current plat of survey locating lot lines and all existing structures; 
(3)  Proof of ownership or disclosure of beneficial trust; 
(4)  Existing zoning of property; and 
(5)  Proposed variation. 
(D)  Hearing. No variation shall be granted by the zoning board of appeals except after a public hearing before the zoning board of appeals. For public hearing requirements, see section 13.13. 
(E)  Findings of fact. Within sixty (60) days of the public hearing, the zoning board of appeals shall grant or deny any petition for variation. Every variation which is granted by the zoning board of appeals shall be accompanied by findings of fact and shall refer to any exhibits containing plans and specifications for the proposed variation which shall remain a part of the permanent records of the zoning board of appeals. The findings of fact shall specify the reason, or reasons, for granting or denying the variation. 
(1)  Standards for variations. 
a.  The zoning board of appeals shall not vary the provisions of this ordinance as authorized in this section, unless it shall have made findings of fact based upon the evidence presented to it in the following specific cases: 
1.  That the property in question cannot yield a reasonable return if permitted to be used only under the conditions allowed by the regulations governing the district in which it is located; 
2.  That the plight of the owner is due to unique circumstances; or 
3.  That the variation, if granted, will not alter the essential character of the locality. 
b.  For the purpose of supplementing the above standards, the zoning board of appeals shall also take into consideration the extent to which the following facts, favorable to the applicant, have been established by the evidence: 
1.  That the particular physical surroundings, shape or topographical conditions of the specific property involved would bring a particular hardship upon the owner as distinguished from a mere inconvenience if the strict letter of the regulation were to be carried out; 
2.  That the conditions upon which the petition for variation are based would not be applicable generally to other property within the same zoning classification; 
3.  That the purpose of the variation is not based exclusively upon a desire to make more money out of the property; 
4.  That the alleged difficulty or hardship has not been created by any person presently having an interest in the property; 
5.  That the granting of the variation will not be detrimental to the public welfare or injurious to other property or improvements in the neighborhood in which the property is located; and 
6.  That the proposed variation will not impair an adequate supply of light and air to adjacent property, or substantially increase the danger of fire, or otherwise endanger the public safety, or substantially diminish or impair property values within the neighborhood. 
c.  The zoning board of appeals may require such conditions and restrictions upon the premises benefited by a variation as may be necessary to comply with the standards set forth in this section to reduce or minimize the injurious effect of such variation upon other property in the neighborhood and to implement the general purpose and intent of this ordinance. 
(2)  Guidelines for variations. Variations from the regulations of this ordinance may be decided by the zoning board of appeals in accordance with the standards set forth in this section: 
a.  To permit up to a twenty (20) percent reduction in the front, side or rear yard required by this ordinance; 
b.  To permit the use of a lot or lots for a use otherwise prohibited solely because of insufficient area or width of the lot or lots but in no event shall the respective area and width of the lot be less than eighty (80) percent of the required area and width; 
c.  To permit the same off-street parking spaces to qualify as required spaces for two (2) or more uses, provided that the maximum use of such facility by each user does not take place during the same hours of the day or on the same days of the week; 
d.  To reduce the applicable off-street parking or loading facilities required by not more than one parking space or loading space, or twenty (20) percent of the applicable regulations, whichever number is greater; 
e.  To increase by not more than twenty-five (25) percent the maximum distance that required parking spaces are permitted to be located from the use served; 
f.  To allow any use to exceed by no more than twenty (20) percent of the floor area ratio, ground floor area and lot coverage imposed by the applicable regulations; 
g.  To allow any use to exceed the building height imposed by the applicable regulations by no more than twenty (20) percent but in no case shall the building height exceed five (5) stories; 
h.  To reduce the applicable landscape requirements by not more than twenty-five (25) percent of any quantitative requirement; 
i.  To extend the period of time a nonconforming use may continue or remain; 
j.  To exceed any of the authorized variations allowed under this section, when a lot of record or a zoning lot, vacant or legally used on the effective date of this ordinance, is, by reason of the exercise of the right of eminent domain by any authorized governmental body or by reason of a conveyance under threat of an eminent domain proceeding, reduced in size so that the remainder of said lots does not conform with one or more of the regulations of the district in which said lot of record or zoning lot or structure is located; or 
k.  To exceed any of the authorized variations allowed under this section, and only where the board of zoning appeals makes specific factual findings of exceptional site, circumstances or conditions such variations shall require a favorable vote of two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of the members of the zoning board of appeals then holding office. 
(F)  Variation: Terms of relief. The terms of relief granted shall be specifically set forth in a conclusion or statement separate from the findings of fact. 
(G)  Zoning board of appeals action. The zoning board of appeals may approve variations from the regulations of this ordinance, in accordance with the provisions of sections 13.09(F)(1) and 13.09(F)(2). 
(H)  Status of variation granted. Every variation granted hereunder shall not be personal to the applicant therefore but shall be transferable and shall run with the land. No variation granted by the zoning board of appeals shall be valid for a period of time longer than six (6) months from the date of such variation unless the building permit is obtained within such period and the erection or alteration of the building is started or the use is commenced within such period. 
(I)  Decisions. All administrative decisions and findings of the zoning board of appeals on variations arrived at after the hearing shall be final, subject to judicial review only in accordance with the Illinois Revised Statutes as amended. 
(Ord. No. 1576-87,  1, 6-22-87; Ord. No. 1720-88,  3, 7-11-88; Ord. No. 1744-88,  2, 8-22-88; Ord. No. 1986-90,  1, 9-10-90; Ord. No. 2094-91,  11, 6-24-91; Ord. No. 2003-3018,  1, 9-22-03) 
13.10. - Amendments. 
(A)  Authority. For the purpose of promoting the public health, safety, and general welfare, conserving the value of property throughout the community, and lessening or avoiding congestion in the public streets and highways, the village board of trustees may, from time-to-time, in the manner hereinafter set forth, amend the regulations imposed in the districts created by this ordinance or amend district boundary lines on the zoning district map. However, in all amendatory ordinances adopted under the authority of this section, due allowance shall be made for existing conditions, the conservation of property values, the official comprehensive plan, adopted on August 22, 2016 as amended, the direction of building development to the best advantage of the entire community, and the uses to which property is devoted at the same time of the adoption of such amendatory ordinance. 
    No application for an amendment shall be acted upon by the village board of trustees until after hearing by the planning and zoning commission and written reports of the findings of fact and recommendations have been submitted to the village board of trustees. 
(B)  Initiation of amendment. Amendments (text and map) may be proposed by the village board of trustees, the planning and zoning commission, or the zoning board of appeals. Text amendments may also be proposed by any resident or owner of property in the Village of Roselle. Amendments to the zoning map may also be proposed by any person with a proprietary interest in the property affected by the proposed map amendment. 
(C)  Application for processing. An application for an amendment (text or map) shall be filed with the zoning administrator with the required fee. The zoning administrator shall forward such application to the planning and zoning commission with a request to hold a public hearing; to the village staff for review and comment; and to the village clerk for filing. The application shall contain such information as the planning and zoning commission may by rule require and shall include, at a minimum: 
(1)  Legal description and common address of subject property; 
(2)  Current plat of survey locating lot lines and all existing structures; 
(3)  Proof of ownership or disclosure of beneficial trust; 
(4)  Existing zoning on subject property and within one hundred (100) feet; 
(5)  Proposed zoning and land use; and 
(6)  Preliminary site plan or concept plan. 
(D)  Planning and zoning commission review. The planning and zoning commission shall review an application for an amendment at its next regularly scheduled monthly meeting or within forty-five (45) days after transmittal of said application by the zoning administrator. 
(E)  [Hearing.] No amendment shall be granted by the village board of trustees except after a public hearing before the planning and zoning commission. For public hearing requirements, see section 13.13. 
(F)  Findings of fact and recommendation. The planning and zoning commission shall make written findings of fact and shall submit same together with its specific recommendation to the village board within sixty (60) days following the close of the public hearing on each application, unless said application is withdrawn or tabled. 
    Where the purpose and effect of the proposed amendment is to change the zoning classification of a particular property, the planning and zoning commission shall make findings based upon the evidence presented to it in each specific case with respect to the following: 
(1)  Compatibility with surrounding land uses and the general area; 
(2)  The zoning classification of property within the vicinity of the property in question; 
(3)  The suitability of the subject property to the uses permitted under the existing zoning classification; 
(4)  The trend of development, if any, in the general area of the subject property including recent changes, if any, which have taken place in its zoning classification; and 
(5)  The relationship of the proposed zoning classification to the official comprehensive plan of Roselle, adopted on August 22, 2016. 
The planning and zoning commission shall not recommend the adoption of a proposed amendment unless it finds that the adoption of such amendment is in the public interest and not solely for the interest of the applicant, and that either the proposed amendment will correct an existing error or that changing conditions make the proposed amendment necessary. 
(G)  Site plan review by the planning and zoning commission. See section 13.12. 
(H)  Action by the village board. 
(1)  The village board shall not act upon a proposed amendment to this ordinance until it shall have received written reports and recommendations from the planning and zoning commission on the proposed amendment. 
(2)  The village board may grant or deny any application for an amendment. In case a written protest against any proposed amendment of the regulations or districts is signed and acknowledged by: 
a.  The owners of twenty (20) percent of the frontage proposed to be altered, or 
b.  The owners of twenty (20) percent of the frontage immediately adjoining or across an alley therefrom, or 
c.  The owners of twenty (20) percent of the frontage directly opposite the frontage proposed to be altered, 
and is filed with the village clerk, the amendment shall not be passed except by a favorable vote of two-thirds of the trustees then holding office. In such cases, a copy of the written protest shall be served by the protestor or protestors on the applicant for the proposed amendment and a copy upon the applicant's attorney, if any, by certified mail at the address of such applicant and attorney as shown in the application for the proposed amendment. 
(3)  If an application for a proposed amendment is not acted upon finally by the village board within ninety (90) days of the action by the planning and zoning commission, and such time is not extended by mutual consent of the village board and petitioner, it shall be deemed to have been denied. 
(I)  Effect of denial of amendment. No application for a map amendment which has been denied by the village board shall be resubmitted for a period of one year from the date of the order of denial, except on the grounds of new evidence or proof of change of condition found to be valid by the planning and zoning commission and the village board. 
(J)  Repeal of amendment. In any case where a change of boundary lines of the zoning district has been granted, and where no development has taken place within two (2) years, the planning and zoning commission may recommend to the village board that such zoning be affirmed or repealed and rezoned to its most appropriate district classification in accordance with the procedure under this ordinance for amendments. 
(Ord. No. 1576-87,  1, 6-22-87; Ord. No. 1720-88,  3, 7-11-88; Ord. No. 2094-91,  12, 6-24-91; Ord. No. 2016-3858,  1, 8-22-16) 
13.11. - Special uses. 
(A)  Purpose. The development and execution of the zoning ordinance is based upon the division of the village into districts, within any one of which the use of land and buildings and structures, as related to the land, are essentially uniform. It is recognized, however, that there are special uses which, because of their unique character, cannot be properly classified in any particular district or districts without consideration, in each case, of the impact of those uses upon neighboring lands and upon the public need for the particular use at the particular location. Such special uses fall into two (2) categories: 
(1)  Uses operated by a public agency or publicly regulated utilities or uses traditionally affected with a public interest, or 
(2)  Uses entirely private in character, but of such a nature that the operation may give rise to unique problems with respect of their impact upon neighboring property or public facilities. 
(B)  Authority. Special uses shall be authorized or denied by the president and board of trustees in accordance with the Illinois Revised Statutes as amended, and the regulations and conditions set forth in this ordinance for special uses. 
    No application for special use shall be acted upon by the village board of trustees until after review and public hearing before the planning and zoning commission and written reports of the findings of facts and recommendations of both boards have been submitted to the village board of trustees. 
(C)  Initiation of special use. Special uses may be proposed by any person, firm, or corporation with a proprietary interest in the subject property requesting, or intending to request, a zoning certificate. 
(D)  Application and processing. For the procedures pertaining to special use-planned unit developments see section 12.00. For all other special use applications, this section shall apply. 
    An application for a special use shall be filed with the zoning administrator with the required fee. The zoning administrator shall forward such application to the planning and zoning commission; to the village staff for review and comment; and to the village clerk for filing. 
    The applications shall contain such information as the planning and zoning commission may, by rule, require and shall include, at a minimum: 
(1)  Legal description and common address of subject property; 
(2)  Current plat of survey locating lot lines and all existing structures; 
(3)  Proof of ownership or disclosure of beneficial trust; 
(4)  Existing zoning on subject property and within one hundred (100) feet; 
(5)  Proposed zoning and land use; and 
(6)  Preliminary site plan or concept plan. 
(E)  Planning and zoning commission [review] . The planning and zoning commission shall review an application for a special use. After review of the application for special use, the planning and zoning commission shall prepare a report of its findings and recommendations and shall submit said report to the village board of trustees. 
(F)  Hearing. No special use shall be granted by the village board of trustees except after a public hearing before the planning and zoning commission. For public hearing requirements, see section 13.13. 
(G)  Findings of fact and recommendation. The planning and zoning commission shall make written findings of fact and shall submit same together with its specific recommendation to the village board within sixty (60) days following the close of the public hearing on each application, unless said application is withdrawn or tabled. 
(1)  The planning and zoning commission shall make findings based upon the evidence presented to it in each specific case with respect to the following: 
a.  Compatibility with surrounding land uses and the general area; 
b.  The zoning classification of property within the vicinity of the property in question; 
c.  The suitability of the subject property to the uses permitted under the existing zoning classification; 
d.  The trend of development, if any, in the general area of the subject property, including recent changes, if any, which have taken place in its zoning classification; and 
e.  The relationship of the proposed zoning classification to the official comprehensive plan of Roselle, adopted on August 22, 2016. 
(2)  The planning and zoning commission shall not recommend the approval of a proposed special use unless it finds that: 
a.  The approval of such special use is in the public interest and not solely for the interest of the applicant; 
b.  That the proposed use at that particular location requested is necessary or desirable to provide a service or a facility which is in the interest of public convenience and will contribute to the general welfare of the neighborhood or community; 
c.  That such use will not under the circumstances of the particular case be detrimental to the health, safety, morals or general welfare of persons residing or working in the vicinity or injurious to property values or improvements in the vicinity; and 
d.  That the proposed use will comply with the regulations and conditions specified in this ordinance for such use, and with the stipulations and conditions made a part of the authorization granted by the village board of trustees. 
(H)  Site plan review by the planning and zoning commission. See section 13.12. 
(I)  Conditions may be placed on a special use approval by the village that may limit construction, scheduling, location, operation and variations to minimum standards of this code as may be deemed necessary, and that protect and promote the special use criteria in section (G) above. 
(J)  Action by the village board. 
(1)  The village board shall not act upon a proposed special use until it shall have received written reports and recommendations from the planning and zoning commission on the proposed special use. 
(2)  The village board may grant, deny, or grant with modifications the proposed special use. 
(3)  If an application for a proposed special use is not acted upon finally by the village board within ninety (90) days of the date of action by the planning and zoning commission and such time is not extended by mutual consent of the village board and petitioner, it shall be deemed to have been denied. 
(K)  Effect of denial of special use. After a public hearing no application for special use which has been denied by the village board shall be resubmitted for a period of one year from the date of the order of denial, except on the grounds of new evidence or proof of change of condition found to be valid by the planning and zoning commission and the village board. 
(L)  Repeal of special use. In any case where a special use has been granted, and where no development has taken place within two (2) years, the planning and zoning commission may recommend to the village board that such zoning be affirmed or repealed, and changed to its most appropriate zoned district classification in accordance with the procedures under this ordinance. 
(M)  Minor changes to an approved special use may be approved according to the procedures in section 13.12. 
(Ord. No. 1576-87,  1, 6-22-87; Ord. No. 1720-88,  3, 7-11-88; Ord. No. 2094-91, ㎣ 13, 14, 6-24-91; Ord. No. 2016-3858,  1, 8-22-16) 
13.12. - Site plan review procedures. 
(A)  Intent. In order to ensure that proposed development complies with all the provisions of this code, all required site plans must be reviewed and approved by the village according to the following procedures. 
(B)  Procedures. 
(1)  Permitted use. The zoning administrator may approve or deny site plans for all uses permitted in each zoning district. 
(2)  Special use. The planning and zoning commission may recommend and the board of trustees may approve site plans for all special uses in each zoning district based on findings of fact made at public hearing. 
(3)  Changes. The zoning administrator may decide whether a plan change is minor or major. The zoning administrator may approve or deny minor changes to approved site plans and major changes to approved site plans for permitted uses. The planning and zoning commission may recommend and the board of trustees may approve major changes to approved site plans for all special uses based on findings of fact made at public hearing. 
(4)  Appeals. The applicant may appeal the ruling of the zoning administrator regarding a site plan to the planning and zoning commission who, at a public hearing, shall approve or deny a site plan. The applicant may appeal the ruling of the planning and zoning commission to the board of trustees who, at a public hearing, shall approve or deny a site plan. 
(Ord. No. 1576-87,  1, 6-22-87; Ord. No. 1720-88,  3, 7-11-88; Ord. No. 1826-89, ㎣ 1, 2, 5-22-89; Ord. No. 2094-91,  15, 6-24-91) 
13.13. - Public hearing procedures. 
(A)  Purpose. The village shall provide and protect due process rights for people affected by zoning changes. These public hearing procedures shall apply to all zoning procedures requiring public hearings, except annexation procedures shall be governed by state law and other village ordinances. If state law is more stringent with respect to any public hearings required under this ordinance, there shall be compliance with state law as well as this ordinance. 
(B)  Scheduling. Upon receipt of a completed application which is in compliance with state law and village ordinance, the zoning administrator shall schedule a prompt hearing taking into consideration: due dates for applications and existing agendas. Special meetings may be scheduled to conduct hearings if so approved by the hearing board. 
(C)  Publication. Any notice required by this ordinance shall be published in at least one local newspaper having general circulation in Roselle as follows: 
(1)  The notice shall appear in the newspaper(s) no less than fifteen (15) and no more than thirty (30) days prior to the hearing date. 
(2)  A certificate of publication issued by the newspaper or copy of the actual as shall be filed with the village zoning administrator prior to the hearing date. 
(3)  All notices shall contain the following information: Village name, case name and number, petitioner's name, location and/or address of site, size of site, current zoning and land use, proposed zoning and land use, hearing body, the place and time of the hearing, a telephone number where interested parties may obtain information regarding the petition, and a legal description of the site. The wording of any notice shall be submitted to and approved by the village zoning administrator prior to publication. 
(4)  All required newspaper notices shall be published and paid for by the petitioner, except for petitions filed by the owner of one existing single-family attached or detached structure in the R-1, R-2, R-2A, R-2B, or R-3 residential zoning districts. In the later case, the newspaper publication cost is included in the sixty dollar ($60.00) public hearing notice fee payable upon submission of the application in accordance with section 13.13(D)(1). 
(D)  Mail notification. Written notice shall be mailed to all owners of property within two hundred fifty (250) feet of the petition site, provided the number of feet occupied by all public roads, streets, alleys and other public ways shall be excluded in computing the two hundred fifty (250) feet, as follows: 
(1)  Single-family residential property. 
The village shall undertake public notification for petitions filed by the owner of an existing single-family attached or detached structure in the R-1, R-2, R-2A, R-2B, or R-3 residential zoning district including: the posting of a public hearing sign; publishing a public hearing notice in a newspaper of general circulation in Roselle; and mailing, by regular mail, written notice to all owners of property which are within two hundred fifty (250) feet of the petition site. Upon submission of the application, petitioner shall pay a sixty dollar ($60.00) public hearing notice fee to the village to cover all out-of-pocket expenses arising from said notification. 
(2)  All other property. 
(a)  Each letter shall be mailed certified mail, return receipt requested, not less than fifteen (15) days and not more than thirty (30) days before the hearing date. 
(b)  The contents of the letter shall be the same as the newspaper notice and shall be approved by the zoning administrator. 
(c)  An exemplar copy of the letter, all post office certifications, and a map or list of addresses where the letters are sent shall be filed with the zoning administrator prior to the hearing date. 
(3)  Homeowner's association notification. 
(a)  Any homeowner's group or resident who has filed a written request to receive notices for any public hearing with the zoning administrator may receive such notices as a courtesy of the village. 
(E)  Signs. Signs shall be posted providing notice of hearing as follows: 
(1)  Signs shall have minimum dimensions of two (2) feet by three (3) feet with white background and black letters at least two (2) inches high. All lettering shall be weather resistant, legibly painted or applied, and contain the following language: 
PUBLIC HEARING FOR A ZONING CHANGE ON THIS SITE, (DATE), (TIME), ROSELLE FIRE STATION, 100 EAST MAPLE AVENUE (OR OTHER HEARING LOCATION), (PHONE NUMBER). 
Any additional wording contained on the sign must be approved by the zoning administrator prior to posting. 
(2)  The sign shall be posted in a front yard in clear view of the public way at least three (3) feet above ground level. 
(3)  No sign giving notice of a public hearing shall be posted in the public right-of-way. 
(4)  Two (2) signs shall be posted where a site is larger than twenty (20) acres or has more than three (3) frontages. 
(5)  Sign posting locations shall be approved by the zoning administrator prior to posting. 
(6)  All signs shall be posted no less than fifteen (15) and no more than thirty (30) days prior to the hearing date and shall remain in place until the hearing is concluded. 
(7)  Upon completion of the hearing, signs shall be removed as soon as practical. 
(8)  The village shall post signs pertaining to zoning hearings on existing single-family residences. The petitioner shall post all other signs. 
(F)  Continued hearings. No new publication, mailing or sign posting shall be required where a public hearing is not concluded at the first scheduled meeting and is continued at the same meeting to another date provided that the continuation of the hearing is held within seventy (70) days of the original hearing date. 
(G)  Failure to notify. At the beginning of each public hearing, the hearing body must determine if all the notification requirements have been met. If they find that insufficient notice has been given, the hearing shall be concluded. 
(Ord. No. 1578-87, ㎣ 1, 2, 1-12-87; Ord. No. 1720-88,  3, 7-11-88; Ord. No. 2010-90,  1, 11-26-90; Ord. No. 2236-92, ㎣ 1-3, 9-14-92; Ord. No. 2325-93, ㎣ 1, 2, 5-10-93) 
13.14. - Fees. 
    The village board shall establish a schedule of fees, charges and expenses for zoning certification, occupancy certificates, appeals, application for amendments or special use, and other matters pertaining to this ordinance. This schedule of fees shall be posted in the office of the village clerk and may be altered or amended by the village board. 
    Until all applicable fees, charges, and expenses have been paid in full, no action shall be taken on any application or appeal. 
(Ord. No. 1720-88,  3, 7-11-88) 
13.15. - Violation, penalty, enforcement. 
    Any person, firm or corporation, who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with, or who resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this ordinance shall upon conviction be fined not less than thirty-five dollars ($35.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. The zoning administrator is hereby designated and authorized to enforce this ordinance. 
    In the event any building or structure is constructed, reconstructed, altered, repaired, converted or maintained, or any building, structure or land is used in violation of this ordinance, the proper local authorities of the municipality, or any owner or tenant of real property in the same contiguous zoning district as the building or structure in question, in addition to other remedies, may institute any appropriate action or proceeding: 
(1)  To prevent the unlawful construction, reconstruction, alteration, repair, conversion, maintenance, or use; 
(2)  To prevent the occupancy of the building, structure, or land; 
(3)  To prevent any illegal act, conduct business, or use in or about the premises; or 
(4)  To restrain, correct, or abate the violation. 
    When any such action is instituted by an owner or tenant, notice of such action shall be served upon the Village of Roselle at the time suit is begun by serving a copy of the complaint on the president of the village board. No such action may be maintained until such notice has been given. 
(Ord. No. 1720-88,  3, 7-11-88) 
13.16. - Adoption clause. 
    This ordinance was passed and approved on August 5, 1985, by Ordinance No. 85-1345. 
(Ord. No. 1720-88,  3, 7-11-88) 
APPENDIX B - SUBDIVISION REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1914-90,  2, adopted Feb. 26, 1990, enacted new subdivision regulations which are included herein as App. B. Section 1 of said ordinance repealed former subdivision regulations which were contained in Ch. 19. The user's attention is directed to the editor's note at Ch. 19 and the Code Comparative Table for a detailed analysis of inclusion of Ord. No. 1914-90. 

SECTION 1.00. - TITLE 
    This ordinance shall be known as the subdivision regulations of the Village of Roselle, Illinois. 
SECTION 2.00. - PURPOSE, JURISDICTION AND INTERPRETATION 

Sec. 2.01. - Purpose. 
    These regulations are adopted for the following purposes: 
(A)  To protect and provide for the public health, safety, and general welfare of the Village of Roselle. 
(B)  To guide the future growth and development of the village, in accordance with the comprehensive plan. 
(C)  To provide for adequate light, air, and privacy, to secure safety from fire, flood, and other danger, and to prevent overcrowding of the land and undue congestion of population. 
(D)  To protect the character and the social and economic stability of all parts of the village and to encourage the orderly and beneficial development of all parts of the village. 
(E)  To protect and conserve the value of land throughout the village and the value of buildings and improvements upon the land, and to minimize the conflicts among the uses of land and buildings. 
(F)  To guide public and private policy and action in order to provide adequate and efficient transportation, water, sewage, schools, parks, playgrounds, recreation, and other public requirements and facilities. 
(G)  To provide the most beneficial relationship between the uses of land and buildings and the circulation of traffic throughout the village, having particular regard to the avoidance of congestion in the streets and highways, and the pedestrian traffic movements appropriate to the various uses of land and buildings, and to provide for the proper location and width of streets and building lines. 
(H)  To establish reasonable standards of design and procedures for subdivision and resubdivisions, in the orderly layout and use of land, and to ensure proper legal descriptions and monumenting of subdivided land. 
(I)  To ensure that public facilities are available and will have a sufficient capacity to serve the proposed subdivision. 
(J)  To prevent the pollution of air, streams, and ponds; to assure the adequacy of drainage facilities; to safeguard the water table; and to encourage the wise use and management of natural resources throughout the village in order to preserve the integrity, stability, and beauty of the community and the value of land. 
(K)  To preserve the natural beauty and topography of the village and to ensure appropriate development with regard to these natural features. 
(L)  To provide for open spaces through the most efficient design and layout of the land, including the use of average density in providing for minimum width and area of lots, while preserving the density of land as established in the zoning ordinance of the village. 
Sec. 2.02. - Jurisdiction. 
    The subdivision ordinance of the Village of Roselle, Illinois shall apply to all subdivisions of land, as defined herein, located within the Village of Roselle or in part within the unincorporated area within one and one-half (11/2) miles of the corporate limits of the village in accordance with Chapter 24, of the Illinois Revised Statutes. The subdivision plans and plats, including planned unit developments, and proposed improvements to be installed, and all procedures relating thereto, shall in all respects be in full compliance with the regulations herein. 
    The planning and zoning commission of the Village of Roselle shall review divisions of land that are not defined herein as subdivisions according to the Plats Act to assure conformance with the area and bulk requirements of the zoning districts contained within the Roselle Zoning Ordinance. 
Sec. 2.03. - Interpretation. 
(A)  Minimum standards established. In their interpretation and application, the provisions of this ordinance shall be held to be the minimum requirements for the promotion of the public health, safety, and general welfare. 
(B)  Higher standards govern. Where the conditions imposed by any provisions of this ordinance upon the subdivision of land are either more restrictive or less restrictive than comparable conditions imposed by any other provisions of this ordinance or any other applicable law, ordinance, resolution, rule or regulation of any kind, the regulations which are more restrictive and impose higher standards or requirements shall govern. Under certain circumstances variations from standards and requirements contained in this ordinance may be granted by the board of trustees. 
(C)  Easement or covenants not abrogated. This ordinance is not intended to abrogate any easement, covenant, or any other private agreement (provided that such private agreements do not conflict with federal law), provided that where the regulations of this ordinance are more restrictive or impose higher standards or regulations that such easement, covenant, or other private agreement, the requirement of this ordinance shall govern. 
(D)  Existing subdivisions. No subdivision of land, which was not lawfully existing at the time of the adoption of this ordinance and, to the extent that said subdivision of land is in conflict in any manner with the requirements of this ordinance, remains unlawful hereunder. 
SECTION 3.00. - RULES AND DEFINITIONS 

Sec. 3.01. - Rules. 
    The language set forth in the text of this ordinance shall be interpreted in accordance with the following rules of construction: 
(A)  The singular number includes the plural and the plural the singular; 
(B)  The present tense includes the past and the future tenses, and the future the present; 
(C)  The word "shall" is mandatory, while the word "may" is permissive; 
(D)  The masculine gender includes the feminine and neuter; 
(E)  Whenever a word or term defined hereinafter appears in the text of this ordinance, its meaning shall be construed as set forth in the definition thereof, and any word appearing in parentheses directly after a word herein defined shall be construed in the same sense as that word; and 
(F)  All measured distance expressed in feet shall be to the nearest integral foot; if a fraction is one-half (1/2) foot or more, the integral foot next above shall be taken. 
Sec. 3.02. - Definitions. 
    The following words and terms, whenever they occur in this ordinance, shall be construed as here defined. 
    Accessory use. An accessory building, structure, or use, is one which: 
(A)  Is subordinate to and serves principal use; and 
(B)  Is subordinate in intensity of use, or purpose to the principal use served; and 
(C)  Contributes to the comfort, convenience, or necessity of occupants of the principal use served. 
    Alley. A right-of-way which affords only a secondary means of public access to abutting property along a side or rear property line. 
    Applicant. The owner or contract purchaser of land proposed to be subdivided or his legal representative. 
    Apron. An extension of a driveway lying between the public sidewalk (or the right-of-way line if there is no sidewalk), edge of pavement, curb and gutters of a street. The maintenance responsibility of this facility is with the owner of the driveway so extended. 
    As built plans. Plans showing the location and dimensions of actual civil engineering improvements as required by approved plans. 
    Block. A tract of land bounded by street rights-of-way, or by a combination of street rights-of-way, and public parks, cemeteries, railroad and utility rights-of-way, bulkhead lines or shorelines or waterway, or corporate limits lines. 
    Board of trustees. The Board of Trustees of the Village of Roselle, Illinois. 
    Bond. Any form of security approved as to form by the village attorney including a cash deposit, letter of credit, or instrument of credit in an amount and form accepted by the board of trustees. 
    Building. A structure, with permanent roof, separated on all sides from adjacent open space by exterior or party walls, built for the support, shelter, or enclosure of persons, animals, chattel, or movable property of any kind, and which is permanently affixed to the ground. 
    Building permit. Written permission issued by the Village of Roselle, for the construction, erection, repair, or alteration of a building or structure including, but not limited to, a fence, patio, terrace, swimming pool or sign. 
    Building setback line. A line within a lot marking the minimum horizontal distance between the front line of the building or structure and the front lot line. 
    Community development department. The Community Development Department of the Village of Roselle, Illinois. 
    Comprehensive plan. A plan for the Village of Roselle, Illinois including graphic and written material indicating the general locations recommended for the streets, parks, schools, public building and all physical developments of the village. Also, any plan and parts thereof adopted by the board of trustees. 
    Crosswalk. That portion of a street right-of-way and/or easement, paved or otherwise surfaced, intended for pedestrian and non-motorized cycle use. A crosswalk aligns perpendicular to and interconnects with sidewalks within a block. 
    Design manual. The most recent addition of the "Design Manual" published by the Illinois Department of Transportation as amended from time to time. 
    Development. Any manmade change to improved or unimproved real property, including, but not limited to, buildings or other structures, mining, dredging, filling, grading, paving, storage of materials, excavation or drilling operations located within the area of special flood hazard or elsewhere within the Village of Roselle or its area of planning jurisdiction. 
    Drainageway. Any natural or artificial water course, trench, ditch, swale, or similar depression into which surface water flows. 
    Easement. A grant by a property owner for the use by another, of any designated part of his property. 
    Engineer. A licensed registered professional engineer in the State of Illinois. 
    Excavation. Any act of changing the grade or subgrade of a tract of land by cutting, scraping, grading, trenching, digging, filling in, or otherwise reshaping the natural contour of the ground. 
    The following shall not be construed as excavating/filling: 
(A)  Any cutting, grading, trenching, digging, or backfilling of any foundation of a building approved for construction or reconstruction. 
(B)  Any cutting, grading, trenching, digging, or backfilling of any septic tank site, including septic field, which has been approved for construction or reconstruction. 
(C)  Top dressing in an area of existing homes provided the top dressing does not change the drainage patterns. 
    Fill. Any act by which earth, sand, gravel, rock, or any other material is deposited, placed, replaced, pushed, dumped, pulled, transported or moved to a new location and shall include the conditions resulting therefrom. 
    Floodplain. As defined in Ordinance 81-1019 adopted May 21, 1981 and as amended. 
    Information pertaining to the floodplain, including maps and profiles, is based on the studies and reports prepared by FEMA, identified as Flood Insurance Study, Village of Roselle, Illinois, dated November 19, 1980 and the Flood Insurance Rate Map (FIRM) Community Panel Nos. 170216-002B and 170216-0004B, effective May 19, 1981, and those maps for unincorporated portions of Cook and DuPage Counties within one and one half (11/2) miles of the corporate limits. 
    Grade. The degree of rise or descent of a sloping surface (land, road, street, sewer, or other public way) expressed in percent. 
    Grading. Excavation or fill or any combination thereof and shall include the conditions resulting from any excavation or fill. 
    Highway standards. The most recent edition of "Highway Standards" published by the Illinois Department of Transportation. 
    Improvements. Grading, street surfacing, curbs, gutters, sidewalks, water mains, fire hydrants, sanitary sewers, storm sewers, culverts, trees, bushes, landscaping and other additions to the natural state of land which increase its value, utility, or habitability in accordance with the provisions of this ordinance. 
(A)  Private improvement. Any installed or constructed facility for which the responsibility of maintenance and ownership will be retained by the private owner. 
(B)  Private common improvement. Any installed or constructed facility for which the responsibility of maintenance and ownership will be retained by the home owner or condominium association. This includes amenities such as, swimming pools, tennis courts, parks, etc. 
(C)  Public improvement. Any facility for which the Village of Roselle or other municipal body may ultimately assume the responsibility for maintenance and operation or which is constructed for general public use or benefit. 
    Lot. Parcel of land which is either a LOT OF RECORD or a ZONING LOT, intended as a unit for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of transfer of ownership or for building development. 
(A)  Lot, butt. A lot at the end of the block located between two (2) corner lots. 
(B)  Lot, corner. A lot or parcel of land abutting upon two (2) or more streets at their intersection, or upon two (2) parts of the same street forming an interior angle of less than one hundred thirty-five (135) degrees. 
(C)  Lot, interior. Any lot other than a corner lot. 
(D)  Lot of record. A lot which is part of a subdivision the plat of which has been recorded in the office of the Recorder of Deeds of DuPage or Cook Counties; or a parcel of land, the deed to which was recorded in the office of said recorder of deeds pursuant to Chapter 109 (Plats Act), paragraph 1(b). 
(E)  Lot, reserve (flag lot). A lot for which the access thereto is provided by a reserve strip of not less than twenty (20) feet in width. Reserve strips shall be no longer than three hundred (300) feet or twice the lot width, whichever is more restrictive. 
(F)  Lot, through. Any lot which fronts upon two (2) parallel streets, or which fronts upon two (2) streets which do not intersect at the boundaries of the lot. On a through lot, both street lines shall be designated front lot lines, and front yards shall be provided on both street frontages as required. 
(G)  Lot, zoning. A single tract of land, which (at the time of filing for a building permit) is designated by its owner or developer as a tract to be used, developed, or built upon as a unit, under single ownership or control. Zoning lot lines shall not cross zoning district boundary lines unless otherwise permitted in this ordinance. Therefore, a zoning lot or lots may or may not coincide with a lot of record. 
    Major change. A revision to an approved plat or an approved statement of agreement and conditions that is not a minor change. 
    Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices. The most recent edition of the "Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices" published by the Illinois Department of Transportation. 
    Minor change. A revision to an approved plat or an approved statement of agreement and conditions that meets the following criteria: 
a.  Conforms to the concept, purpose, and intent of the approved plat and any applicable development agreement. 
b.  Conforms to the concept, purpose, and intent of the Comprehensive Plan of the Village of Roselle. 
c.  Conforms to the concept, purpose, and intent of the subdivision code. 
d.  Conforms to the standards in the subdivision code. 
e.  Does not increase the number of lots by more than ten (10) percent. 
    Owner. Any individual, firm, association, partnership, corporation, trust, or any other legal entity having sufficient proprietary interest in the land sought to be subdivided to commence and maintain proceedings to subdivide the same under this ordinance. 
    Pavement width. Measurement of pavement width from back-of-curb to back-of-curb. 
    Paving improvements. Road excavation, aprons, base course, binder course, surface course, curb and gutter, sidewalk(s), street lights and related appurtenances excluding those in parking lots, as required in this ordinance. 
    Pedestrian way. A right-of-way across a block, or providing access within a block, to be used primarily by pedestrians. 
    Person. Any individual, firm or corporation, public or private, the State of Illinois and its agencies or political subdivisions, and the United States of America, its agencies and instrumentalities, and any agent, servant, offices, or employee of any of the foregoing. 
    Planning and zoning commission. The planning and zoning commission of the Village of Roselle. 
    Planned unit development. A parcel of land or contiguous parcels of land of a size sufficient to create its own character, controlled by a single landowner or by a group of landowners in common agreement as to control, to be developed as a single entity; the character of which is compatible with adjacent parcels and the intent of the zoning district or districts in which it is located. The developer or developers may be granted relief from specific land use regulations and design standards and may be awarded certain premiums in return for assurances of an overall quality of development, including any specific features which will be of exceptional benefit to the village as a whole and which would not otherwise be required by the zoning ordinance. 
    The area of a planned unit development shall remain under one ownership or unified control unless safeguards are provided that, in the opinion of the planning and zoning commission, will provide for the continuation of the original planned unit development concept and as modified from time to time by the planning and zoning commission and approved by the board of trustees. 
    Plan, sketch. A general map or drawing on which the subdivider's design for the subdivision of land is presented for discussion purposes prior to the preparation of the preliminary plat. 
    Plat. A map or drawing representing a tract of land, showing the boundaries and location of individual properties and streets. 
(A)  Plat, final. A map or plan of subdivision and any accompanying material as described in section 7.00 and subsection 6.03. 
(B)  Plat, preliminary. A tentative map or plan of a proposed subdivision as described in subsection 6.02 and section 7.00. 
    Plats Act. Chapter 109 of the Illinois Revised Statutes, as amended. 
    Principal use. The main or intended use of each lot or parcel in a subdivision or planned unit development. 
    Protective covenants. A contract entered into between private parties which constitute a restriction on the use of all private property within a subdivision for the benefit of property owners; and which also provide mutual protection against any undesirable aspect of development which would tend to impair stability of property values. 
    Procedures and Standards of Urban Soil Erosion and Sedimentation Control in Illinois. The most recent edition of "Procedures and Standards for Urban Soil Erosion and Sedimentation Control in Illinois" published by the Northeastern Illinois Soil Erosion and Sedimentation Control Steering Committee. 
    Recorder. Recorder means the Recorder of Deeds of Cook or DuPage County or the Registrar of Titles of Cook County, Illinois whichever is applicable. 
    Resubdivision. The relocation of property boundaries, or the reallocation of property in a plat of record. The dissolution of property lines not accompanied by the relocation of new property lines shall not constitute resubdivision. 
    Right-of-way. A general term denoting that portion of land dedicated, or acquired for, or used as a roadway or pedestrian way or other public use. 
    Road or roadway. Whenever the words "road" or "roadway" are used in this ordinance, it shall be deemed the paved area existing on the street right-of-way and not the street right-of-way width and shall include all curb and gutter facilities. 
    Sidewalk. That portion of the street right-of-way, paved or otherwise surfaced, intended for pedestrian use only, or, in nonbusiness areas, for non-motorized cycles and pedestrian use. A sidewalk typically runs parallel along and between a street and a front lot line. 
    Sight triangle. A triangular shaped portion of land established at street intersections in which nothing shall be erected, placed, planted, or allowed to grow in such a manner as to limit or obstruct the sight distance of a motorist entering or leaving the intersection. 
    Solar access. A property owner's right to have sunlight shine on his land. 
    Solar energy system. A complete design or assembly consisting of an active solar energy collector, an energy storage facility (where used), and components for the distribution of transformed energy. 
    Solar skyspace. The space between solar energy collector and the sun which must be free of obstructions that shade the collector to an extent which precludes its cost-effective operation. 
    Solar skyspace easement. A right, expressed as an easement, covenant, condition or other property interest in any deed or other instrument executed by or on behalf of any landowner, which protects the solar skyspace of an actual, proposed, or designated solar energy collector at a described location by forbidding or limiting activities or land uses that interfere with access to solar energy. 
    Street. A public or private right-of-way which affords a primary means of vehicular access to abutting properties, whether designated as a street, avenue, highway, road, boulevard, lane, throughway, or however otherwise designated, but excepting driveways or access drives to buildings and parking lots. 
(A)  Arterial street. A major or minor street of substantial length which is intended to serve as a large volume trafficway for both the immediate village area and region beyond. It may be designated on the DuPage County Year 2005 Street and Highway Plan or by the Cook County Highway Department as a principal or minor arterial, parkway, tollway, freeway, expressway, or equivalent term to identify those streets comprising the basic structure of the street plan. 
(B)  Collector street. A secondary street used primarily to carry traffic from minor streets to arterials. 
(C)  Marginal access street (frontage road). A minor street paralleling, adjacent to, and often within the right-of-way of an arterial which provides access to local street systems and protection from through traffic on the arterial. 
(D)  Minor street. A street of limited continuity used primarily for access to abutting residential properties. 
(E)  Other streets. 
(1)  Business service street. A minor street or collector street which serves business land uses and due to the type and volume of vehicular traffic, the street requires greater width and structural strength through residential streets of similar class. 
(2)  Industrial service street. A minor street or collector street which serves primarily industrial or manufacturing land uses and due to the type and volume of vehicular traffic, the street requires greater width and structural strength than residential streets of a similar class. 
(3)  Cul-de-sac street. A minor street of short length, having one end open to traffic and being permanently terminated at the other end by a vehicular turnaround. Such street shall be less than five hundred (500) lineal feet in length measured from the adjoining street centerline to the end of the street right-of-way. 
(4)  Half street. A street bordering one or more property lines of a tract of land in which the developer has allocated out part of the ultimate right-of-way width in accordance with the requirements as set forth in section 9.01. 
(5)  Loop street. A minor street of short length with openings to traffic beginning from the same street, and projecting parallel to each other and connecting at their termination by a loop. 
(6)  Private street. An undedicated street which is privately owned and maintained by, or an easement of access benefitting, a dominant tenant. 
(7)  Stub street. A minor street which terminates abruptly without the provision for vehicular turnaround. Such a street usually terminates at the boundary of a subdivision and is expected to continue through adjacent property in subsequent future development. 
    Subdivider. Any person commencing proceedings under this ordinance for himself or for another. 
    Subdivision. The division of land into two (2) or more lots or parcels, any of which is less than five (5) acres, for the purpose whether immediate or future, of transfer of ownership or building development, including all public streets, ways for public service facilities, parks, playgrounds, school grounds or other public grounds, and all the tracts, parcels, lots or blocks, and numbering of all such lots, blocks or parcels by progressive numbers, giving their precise dimensions. A planned unit development is, for the purpose of this ordinance, a subdivision whether or not it is divided into two (2) or more parts. The term subdivision includes resubdivision and, where it is appropriate to the context, relates to the process of subdividing or to the land subdivided, provided however, that the following shall not be considered a subdivision and shall be exempt from the requirements of this ordinance except as stated in section 5.00. 
(A)  The division or subdivision of land into parcels or tracts of five (5) acres or more in size which does not involve any new streets or easements of access; 
(B)  The division of lots or blocks of less than one acre in any recorded subdivision which does not involve any new street or easement of access; 
(C)  The sale or exchange of parcels of land between owners of adjoining and contiguous land; 
(D)  The conveyance of parcels of land or interest therein for use as a right-of-way for railroads or other public utility facilities and other pipe lines which does not involve any new streets or easements of access; 
(E)  The conveyance of land owned by a railroad or other public utility which does not involve any new streets or easements of access; 
(F)  The conveyance of land for highway or other public purposes or grants or conveyances relating to the dedication of land for public use or instruments relating to the vacation of land impressed with the public use; 
(G)  Conveyances made to correct descriptions in prior conveyances; 
(H)  The sale or exchange of parcels or tracts of land following the division into no more than two (2) parts of a particular parcel or tract of land existing on July 17, 1959, and not involving any new streets or easements of access; and 
(I)  The sale of a single lot of less than five (5) acres from a larger tract when a survey is made by a registered surveyor; provided, that this exemption shall not apply to the sale of any subsequent lots from the same larger tract of land, as determined by the dimensions and configuration of the larger tract on October 1, 1973, and provided also that this exemption does not invalidate any local requirements applicable to the subdivision of land. 
    Subdivision design standards. The guides, principles, and specifications for the preparation of subdivision plats indicating, among other things, the minimum and maximum dimensions of the various elements set forth in the plat. 
    Tee turn around. Means a temporary improvement to a stub street where an improved pad is provided perpendicular to the street improvement to permit vehicles street turning space (See Exhibit I). 
    Village. The Village of Roselle. 
    Village clerk. The Village Clerk of the Village of Roselle. 
    Village engineer. The Village Engineer of the Village of Roselle, or duly appointed representative of the village. 
    Village president (mayor). The Village President of the Village of Roselle. 
    Zoning administrator. The Zoning Administrator of the Village of Roselle. 
    Zoning board of appeals. Means the Village of Roselle Zoning Board of Appeals as created under the 1985 Roselle Zoning Ordinance, as amended. 
    Zoning ordinance. The zoning ordinance of the Village of Roselle, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 2106-91,  1, 8-12-91) 
SECTION 4.00 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 4.01. - General subdivision requirements. 
(A)  Wherever any subdivision of land shall hereafter be laid out within the incorporated limits of the Village of Roselle, or within contiguous territory not more than one and one half (11/2) miles beyond the incorporated boundaries of the Village of Roselle, the subdivider thereof or his agent, shall submit both a preliminary plat and final subdivision plat to the Village of Roselle for its approval. The subdivision plats and all procedures relating thereto shall in all respects be in full compliance with these regulations. 
(B)  Until final plat for the subdivision is approved: 
(1)  No land shall be subdivided, nor any street laid out, nor any improvements made. 
(2)  No lot, tract, or parcel of land within any subdivision shall be sold. 
(3)  No improvements, such as, sidewalks, water supply, stormwater drainage, sanitary sewage facilities, gas service, electric service, lighting, grading, paving, or surfacing of streets shall hereafter be made by any owner or owners or his or their agent. 
(C)  All offerings or dedications of land to the village or other governmental jurisdictions for use as streets, highways, alleys, schools, parks, playgrounds, or other public uses shall be referred to the planning and zoning commission and any other affected public agency other than the village for review and recommendation before being accepted by the board of trustees. 
(D)  The village engineering standards and specifications shall be the basis for all engineering determinations to be made pursuant to the provisions of these regulations. 
(E)  All sections of the Roselle Zoning Ordinance which regulate planned unit developments, excluding those sections which pertain solely to zoning regulations, are hereby incorporated into the Roselle Subdivision Ordinance by this section and are of full force and effect as though set out fully herein. 
(F)  The controlled release and storage of excess stormwater runoff shall be required in combination of all residential and nonresidential development in accordance with the Village of Roselle Zoning Ordinance, General Provisions. 
Sec. 4.02. - Vacation of a plat or subdivision. 
(A)  Any plat or any part of a plat may be requested for vacation by the owner of the premises, at any time before the sale of any lot therein, by a written instrument, to which a copy of such plat shall be attached declaring the same to be vacated. 
(B)  The procedure applicable to vacation of a plat of subdivision, or any portion thereof, shall be the same as set forth in these regulations for the subdivision of land. 
Sec. 4.03. - Dedication of park lands and school sites or for payments in lieu of dedication. 
    As a condition of approval of a final plat of subdivision, a final plat of a planned unit development, or upon issuance of building permit(s) proposing any type of residential use, each subdivider or developer will be required to dedicate land for park and recreational purposes and land for school sites, to serve the immediate and future needs of the residents or the development, or cash contribution in lieu of actual land dedication, or a combination of both, at the option of the corporate authorities of the village in accordance with the following criteria and formula. 
(A)  Criteria for requiring park and recreation land dedication. 
1.  Requirements and population ratio: The final estimated population of a proposed development shall bear directly upon the amount of land required for dedication. The total requirement shall be five and five-tenths (5.5) acres of land per one thousand (1,000) of final estimated population. The required five and five tenths (5.5) acres may be allocated by the board of trustees in its discretion, based upon the following criteria: 
2.  Location. The Roselle Comprehensive Plan shall be used as a guideline in locating sites. A central location which will serve equally the entire development is most desirable. In large developments, these sites can be located throughout the development according to established standards for park area distances. 
Types of Recreation Area Size Range Minimum Acres per 1,000 Population a) Playlot Minimum of 8,000 square feet Not applicable b) School Park 
(Neighborhood Playground) Minimum park of 8 acres 1.25 c) Neighborhood Park Minimum of 5 acres 1.00 d) District Wide Park Minimum of 10 acres 1.25 e) Community Park Minimum of 15 acres 2.00 _____Total 5.5 acres of land per 1,000 persons  
3.  Required improvements. Each park site shall be located to front on an improved street. At least ten (10) percent of the perimeter of the site shall have lineal contiguity to a public street. At least two (2) means of access shall be provided to a park site. One shall be by means of a public street. Any pedestrian access route shall be at least thirty (30) feet wide. Such pedestrian access may be screened and/or landscaped as required by the board of trustees. 
4.  Topographical considerations. Each park site shall have sufficient level grade, uninterrupted by streams and drainage ditches, as much as possible to permit development for play fields. 
a.  Slope: 
i.  Should not vary greatly in appearance from existing and adjacent slopes. 
ii.  Optimum slopes range from two (2) percent minimum to five (5) percent maximum. No less than two (2) percent slope is acceptable under any circumstances. 
iii.  That on-site drainage patterns be designed and constructed to: 
A.  Insure flow toward swales. 
B.  Insure drainage away from active recreation areas. 
b.  Grading: 
i.  Rough grading shall be completed at time of rough grading of adjacent contiguous areas. 
ii.  All grading shall comply with village subdivision regulations and approved plans. 
iii.  Finished grades should be uniform in slope between points for which elevations have been established. 
c.  Soils: 
i.  Soils shall not differ from those found occurring naturally. 
ii.  Soils shall not offer any restriction to proposed recreation and leisure utilization. 
iii.  Topsoil will be good, friable soil with good tillage, and shall be without any admixture of subsoil, gravel, stones, refuse, and or other subsurface elements. 
iv.  Topsoil shall not be placed in a muddy or frozen condition. 
v.  Topsoil shall contain no toxic substances which may be harmful to plant growth or human health. 
vi.  Topsoil shall be spread no later than the placement of topsoil on the first lot adjacent to the park site. 
vii.  A portion of each park site shall have soil to permit the construction of tennis courts, park buildings, or playgrounds, unless otherwise agreed. Such sites shall have a uniform soil bearing capacity of at least three thousand (3,000) psi based on soil boring data provided by the developer. 
d.  Shape: 
i.  Park sites shall be rectangular or nearly rectangular in shape. 
ii.  Non-usable areas and dead spaces shall be minimized. 
e.  Seeding: Fine grading and seeding shall be completed so that an acceptable stand of grass can be maintained prior to conveyance. 
5.  Special requirements for park sites which include storm water detention or retention areas. 
a.  Adequate overflow channels or structures shall be provided meeting all the requirements of the various agencies having jurisdiction over such water improvements. 
b.  At least sixty (60) feet of space shall be provided between static water lines of ponds and the back or side lots of the adjacent subdivision. 
c.  There shall be at least a twenty-foot suitable roadway access around the impoundment at high water level, wide enough for maintenance and emergency equipment. 
d.  On all park sites which include storm water detention areas, the following regulations will apply: 
i.  Minimum bottom surface area two hundred seventy-five (275) feet square or with one side curved (ball diamond) or a rectangle two hundred (200) feet wide by three hundred seventy-five (375) feet long (football/soccer field) with design of the entire area to be aesthetically pleasing and approved by the appropriate park district and the village. 
ii.  No more than fifty (50) percent of such park site shall hold water during a "100 year rainfall". 
iii.  At least fifty (50) percent of the available high ground within such park site shall be of sufficient size and quality to provide adequate recreational facilities, playgrounds, picnic areas, etc, unless otherwise agreed. 
iv.  Detention areas shall be so under-drained that there will be no surface water standing on such areas within twenty-four (24) hours after a "100-year rainfall". 
v.  Detention areas within parks shall be graded and seeded and an acceptable stand of maintainable grass established prior to dedication of the area to the appropriate park district. 
vi.  A "low-flow" drainage system will be incorporated into the design of the system so that the detention facility holds water only for those rainfalls in excess of a "10-year" storm. 
vii.  Detention areas nay not exceed a maximum difference of elevation of four (4.0) feet between the lowest inlet elevation and the designated overflow point. 
e.  On all park sites which include water retention, the following regulations will apply: 
i.  No more than fifty (50) percent of such park site shall hold water during a "100-year rainfall". 
ii.  At least fifty (50) percent of the site must be high ground of sufficient size and quality to provide adequate recreational facilities. 
iii.  The lake contours must be designed for aesthetic quality and recreational function (i.e. ice skating, fishing, etc.) as well as for hydraulic quality. 
iv.  Rip rap shall be provided above and below the static water level to protect the banks, and sodded above that point to the high water level (to be determined for each condition). 
v.  Each improvement shall be tapered and terraced for safety. A central trench of a twelve-foot depth shall be provided covering an area of twenty-five (25) percent of the lake in order to sustain fish life. 
vi.  Retention areas may not exceed a maximum of four (4.0) feet difference of elevation between normal pool elevation and the designated overflow point. 
vi.  The developer shall provide necessary engineering calculations indicating that satisfactory aerobic conditions will be maintained. If aerobic conditions are unacceptable it shall be the responsibility of the developer to install electrical aerobic devices. 
6.  Credit for private open spaces and recreation areas. When subdividers provide their own open space for recreation areas and facilities, it has the effect of reducing the demand for local public recreational services. Depending on the size of the subdivision or apartment development, a portion of the park and recreational area in subdivisions may, at the option of the board of trustees, be provided in the form of "private" open space in lieu of dedicated "public" open space. The extent of same shall be determined by the board of trustees based upon the needs of the projected residents and in conformance to the total park and recreation land for the general area. In general, a substitution of private open space for dedicated parks will imply a substantially higher degree of improvement and the installation of recreational facilities, including equipment by the subdivider as part of his obligation. Detailed plans of such areas, including specifications of facilities to be installed, must be approved by the village, and before any credit is given for private recreation areas, the subdivider must guarantee that these private recreation areas will be permanently maintained for such use by the execution of the appropriate legal documents. When an adjustment for private recreation areas is warranted, it will be necessary to compute the total park land dedication that would have been required from the subdivision and then subtract the credit to be given. 
(B)  Criteria for requiring school site dedication. 
1.  Requirements and population ratio. The ultimate number of students to be generated by a subdivision shall bear directly upon the amount of land required to be dedicated for school sites or the amount of money to be donated in lieu thereof. The land dedication requirement shall be determined by obtaining the ratio of: (1) estimated children to be served in each such school classification over the (2) maximum recommended number of students to be served in each such school classification as stated herein, and then applying such ratio to the (3) said minimum recommended number of acres for a school site of each such school classification as stated herein. The product thereof shall be the acres of land deemed needed to have sufficient land for school sites to serve the estimated increased children in each such school classification. 
2.  School classification and size of school site: Classifications and size of school sites within the village shall be determined in accordance with the following criteria: 
School Classification Grades Maximum Number of Students for Each Such School Minimum Number of Acres of Land for Each School Site for Such Classifications Elementary Schools, Grades Kindergarten through 5th (K-5) 600 Students 11 acres Junior High Schools, Grades 6th through 8th (6-8) 900 Students 19 acres High Schools, Grades 9th through 12th (9-12) 2300 Students 60 acres  
3.  Location: The comprehensive school plan and/or the standards adopted by the affected school district shall be used as a guideline in locating sites. 
4.  Condition of site and required improvements: Each proposed school site shall be located to front on one or more public streets. At least ten (10) percent of the perimeter of the site shall have lineal contiguity to a public street. However, in no event shall such required access onto a public street be less than five hundred (500) feet in length. The requirements of section 4.03(A)4., above, regarding site topography and soil shall apply as conditions to the dedication of school sites.
