1.  Reservation of additional land: Where the comprehensive plan of the Village calls for a larger amount of park and recreational land or school sites in a particular proposed subdivision or planned unit development than the developer is required to dedicate, the land needed beyond the subdivided contribution shall, if so determined by the board of trustees, be reserved for subsequent purchase by the village or other public body designated by the village provided that such acquisition is made within one year from the date of approval of the final plat. 
2.  Combining with adjoining developments: Where the subdivision is less than forty (40) acres, public open space or a school site which is to be dedicated should, where possible, be combined with dedications from adjoining developments in order to produce usable recreation areas or school sites without hardship on a particular subdivider. 
3.  Improved sites: All sites shall be dedicated in a condition ready for full service of electrical, water, sewer and streets (including enclosed drainage and curb and gutter) as applicable to the location of the site, or acceptable provision made therefore. The sidewalks and trees normally included within the definition of improved sites may be deleted due to the delay time between dedication of any such school sites and construction of school facilities thereon. 
4.  Title to sites: All sites shall be conveyed to the village or other public bodies as designated either by warranty or trustee's deed. The subdivider shall be responsible for conveying good, merchantable title to such sites, and shall be responsible for payment of all real estate taxes to the date of conveyance, including any agricultural roll back taxes which might be extended or levied against such sites, for any tax years or periods prior to the time of conveyance. Sites shall be conveyed when building permits are issued for twenty-five (25) percent of the number of numerically approved or anticipated principal uses for the entire subdivision. Conveyance shall be subject to condition of title and site being acceptable to village or other public body. 
5.  Title insurance, survey, assessment plats: Each deed or other instrument conveying land to the village, school district or park district shall be accompanied by (1) a written commitment issued by a title insurer licensed to do business in Illinois to insure the grantee's title to such real estate in an amount equal to its value computed pursuant to section 4.03(C)1., subject only to then current general real estate taxes, covenants, conditions and restrictions which do not prohibit the use of the subject real estate for school or park use, utility easements located within twenty (20) feet of the boundary lines of the subject real estate, and drainage ditches, feeders, laterals, and underground pipe or other conduit, and acts done or suffered by or judgment against grantee; (2) a current boundary line survey, certified to the grantee by a licensed Illinois Land Surveyor to be in compliance with the Illinois Land Survey Standards; and (3) except in instances where the real estate is to be conveyed is a lot in a recorded subdivision, an assessment plat and tax division petition in form acceptable to the appropriate county authorities so that the land to be conveyed can be assigned its own permanent index number for exemption purposes. 
(E)  Hold harmless: Any school district or park district seeking dedications of land or money in lieu of land dedications under this ordinance shall enter into an intergovernmental agreement with the village which requires the school district or park district to defend, hold harmless and indemnify the Village against any and all demands, claims, actions, or causes of action brought against the village challenging any aspect of the requirements of section 4.03 et seq. of the Roselle Subdivision Ordinance as it pertains to dedication of land or money in lieu of dedications specifically for the benefited school district or park district. 
(F)  TIF district dedications or donations: The amount of land dedication or money in lieu of land dedication required by this ordinance shall not be applicable to residential developments in a tax increment financing district except to the extent that they are negotiated by the corporate authorities of the village in a tax increment financing agreement. 
(Ord. No. 2003-2997,  1, 5-12-03; Ord. No. 2005-3177, ㎣ 1-3, 5-23-05) 
Sec. 4.04. - Adoption by reference. 
    The following standards, publications and specifications are hereby adopted by reference to the extent that they have not been modified and are not in conflict with other village codes and ordinances: 
(A)  "American National Standard Practice for Roadway Lighting," published by the Illuminating Engineering Society, latest edition. 
(B)  "American Standard for Nursery Stock," published by the American Association of Nurserymen, latest edition. 
(C)  "Annual Book of ASTM Standards," published by the American Society for Testing and Materials, latest edition. 
(D)  "Design Manual," published by the Illinois Department of Transportation, latest edition. 
(E)  "Flood Insurance Study," published by the Federal Emergency Management Administration-Federal Insurance Division latest edition. 
(F)  "Guide for Determination of Required Fire Flow," published by the Insurance Services Office, latest edition. 
(G)  "Manual for Structure Design of Portland Cement Concrete Pavement," published by the Illinois Department of Transportation, latest edition. 
(H)  "Manual of Instructions for the Structural Design of Flexible Pavements on Projects Involving MET, FAS and FAUS Funds," published by the Illinois Department of Transportation, latest edition. 
(I)  "Manual of Procedures for the Administration of Sewer Permit Ordinances," published by the Metropolitan Sanitary District of Greater Chicago, latest edition. 
(J)  "Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways," published by the Illinois Department of Transportation, latest edition. 
(K)  "National Electric Code," published by the National Fire Protection Association, latest edition. 
(L)  "Neenah Construction Castings," published by the Neenah Foundry Company, Eighth Edition, Copyright 1979. 
(M)  "Recommended Practice for Cold Weather Concreting," published by the American Concrete Institute, latest edition. 
(N)  "Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction," (abbreviated as SSR & BC), published by the Illinois Department of Transportation, latest edition. 
(O)  "Standard Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois," published by the Illinois Society of Professional Engineers, latest edition. 
SECTION 5.00. - LAND DIVISION OTHER THAN SUBDIVISIONS 

Sec. 5.01. - General provisions. 
(A)  Interpretation and scope. Any division of a lot, parcel, or tract of land into two (2) or more parcels or building sites, each parcel of which is less than five (5) acres in size, and not requiring the development and/or installation of any new street or easement of access, shall be subject to all the provisions of this ordinance (except plat requirements). 
(B)  Preliminary consultation required. Prior to the submission of the certified plat of survey required herein, the owner or subdivider is encouraged to meet with the planning and zoning commission for the purpose of minimizing the risk of objection to, or rejection of, the prepared plat of survey, and for the purpose of ascertaining the problems and requirements affecting the property. 
(C)  Procedure for approval. The owner or subdivider shall file with the zoning administrator, the original and five (5) contact prints and one reduced print (eleven (11) inches by seventeen (17) inches) of a certified plat of survey showing the proposed division of such lots, blocks, parcels, or tracts of land. Copies of the reduced print of the plat of survey shall be forwarded to the planning and zoning commission in accordance with the submittal deadlines established by the community development department. Not more than fifteen (15) days after the meeting at which the plat of survey is referred to the planning and zoning commission, the chairman of the planning and zoning commission shall notify the owner or subdivider whether a new street or easement of access is required. In the event that a new street or easement of access is required, the notice shall stipulate that an application for final plat approval containing such maps, certifications and supporting documents as required by the planning and zoning commission shall be filed with the zoning administrator for processing as herein set forth in this ordinance. 
    The planning and zoning commission shall, within forty (40) days, approve, approve conditionally, or reject the proposal. The board of trustees shall be notified in writing of any conditions of approval or the reasons of rejection. If not acted upon within forty (40) days, the proposal shall go to the board of trustees for consideration and final resolution. 
(D)  Requirements for approval. 
(1)  Compliance with this ordinance. To the extent reasonably practical, the division of land shall comply with the provision of this ordinance governing general requirements, design standards, and required improvements. 
(2)  Survey. The survey shall be performed and the map prepared by a Registered Illinois Land Surveyor. 
(3)  Monuments. All corners shall be monumented as follows: All lot corners shall be monumented in the field by iron pipes at least twenty-four (24) inches long and one inch in diameter, or by round or square iron bars at least twenty-four (24) inches long. 
(4)  The lines of lots that extend to rivers or streams shall be monumented in the field by iron pipes at least thirty (30) inches long and one inch in diameter or by round or square iron bars at least thirty (30) inches long. These monuments shall be placed at the point of intersection of the river or stream lot line with a meander line established not less than twenty (20) feet back from the bank off the river or stream. 
(E)  Certificates and affidavits. 
(1)  Affidavits required. The survey map shall include the affidavit of the surveyor who surveyed and mapped the parcels, typed, lettered, or reproduced legibly with "non-fading" black ink, giving a clear and concise description of the land surveyed by bearings and distances, commencing with some corner marked and established in the U.S. Public Land Survey. Such affidavit shall include the statement of the surveyor to the effect that he has fully complied with the requirement of this section. 
(2)  Certificates required. The certificate of approval of the planning and zoning commission shall be made as provided in Exhibit K-3 of this ordinance. 
(3)  Floodplain certification. The subdivider shall provide a written certification from a registered land surveyor stating that property to be subdivided is not in a floodplain. If a portion of the property is in a floodplain, the subdivider must provide a written certification from a registered land surveyor indicating the location and limits of the floodplain. 
(F)  Filing of the survey map. The village clerk shall retain a copy of the approved survey map and any supporting documents as required by the planning and zoning commission for the village records. The village clerk shall have recorded the original of the approved survey map with the Recorder of Deeds of DuPage or Cook Counties. 
Sec. 5.02. - Planning and zoning commission guidelines. 
(A)  Requirements of the community. The planning and zoning commission, in the examination of subdivision plans or plats for approval, and in the application of this ordinance, shall take into consideration the requirements of the community. Particular attention shall be given to width and location of streets, lot sizes and arrangements, as well as, but not limited to local requirements such as parks and playgrounds, schools and recreation sites, and other public uses. 
(B)  Conformity with comprehensive plan. The planning and zoning commission should especially require that all divisions conform to the provisions and conditions of the official comprehensive plan. (Ordinance No. 2016-3858, adopted August 22, 2016, and as amended from time to time.) Plat approval may be withheld if a subdivision does not conform to the provisions of the comprehensive plan. 
(C)  Area plan required. Where a tract of land proposed for a division is part of a larger, logical subdivision unit in relation to the village as a whole, the planning and zoning commission may, before granting approval, request that the subdivider, if he owns such tract, submit a plan for the entire area or neighborhood to be used by the planning and zoning commission as an aid in judging the proposed plan. The village engineer will make available, to the subdivider, any village information that is available concerning the area for which the plan is to be developed. 
(D)  Preservation of natural features. In all divisions, due regard shall be given to the preservation of natural features such as large trees, water courses, wetlands, wildlife habitats, historical sites or structures and similar features. 
(Ord. No. 2016-3858,  1, 8-22-16) 
SECTION 6.00. - SUBDIVISION PROCEDURES 
    The preparation of a subdivision for platting may be preceded by an initial investigation and shall go through three (3) phases: pre-application, preliminary plat, and final plat, all in accordance with the procedure as follows: 

Sec. 6.01. - Pre-application. 
(A)  Initial investigation. Prior to the preparation of a sketch plan and preliminary plat, it is suggested that the subdivider meet informally with village personnel to investigate the procedure and standards of the village with reference to this subdivision regulation ordinance and with the proposals of the comprehensive plan as they affect the area in which the proposed subdivision is located. At the subdivider's request, the zoning administrator shall organize and schedule a preapplication conference with appropriate village staff. The subdivider is encouraged to meet with the planning and zoning commission to discuss his ideas informally prior to the sketch plan phase. 
(B)  Sketch plan. 
(1)  Applicability. Any parcel of land larger than four (4) acres in area may be required to receive sketch plan approval prior to the submission of a preliminary plat of subdivision. 
(2)  Action by the subdivider. The subdivider shall submit to the zoning administrator five (5) copies of the sketch plan and all accompanying documentation in accordance with the submittal deadlines established by the community development department. The documentation shall include: 
a.  Written notification. Written notification in the form of a letter of intent from the subdivider to the planning and zoning commission establishing the subdividers intent to develop the land. 
b.  General subdivision information. General subdivision information that shall describe or outline the existing conditions of this site and the proposed development. This information shall include data on existing covenants, land characteristics, and available community facilities and utilities. Information describing the subdivision proposal shall include the number of residential lots and units broken down by type, square footage of buildings, and bedroom count; typical lot width and depth; business areas; school, playground and park areas; other public areas; street improvements; and soil boring test results. 
c.  Sketch plan. A plan prepared on reproducible medium that shall show in simple sketch form the proposed layout of streets, lots and other features in relation to existing conditions. The sketch plan may be a free hand sketch made directly on a print of the topographic survey. The sketch shall include all property owned or controlled by the applicant and those properties adjacent to or considered to be contiguous to the proposed subdivision. The sketch plan shall include the existing topographic data and contours of not more than two (2) foot intervals. Such topographic data for all or part of the plan may be provided at one foot intervals when determined necessary by the village engineer. This shall be attached to U.S.G.S. topographic data. The sketch plan should show: 
1.  Proposed name of subdivision, date and north point; 
2.  Location by township, range, section and parcel number; 
3.  Names and addresses of the subdivider and owner; 
4.  Names and addresses of the site planner, designer, engineer or surveyor who prepared the subdivision layout; 
5.  Adjacent property or property across an adjacent street, along with structures, roadways or significant features; 
6.  The location of any floodplain and wetland. 
d.  Tentative engineering proposals. Tentative engineering proposals regarding water supply, sewage disposal, stormwater drainage, and street improvements. 
(C)  Action by the planning and zoning commission. Upon written report by the zoning administrator and village engineer, the planning and zoning commission shall review the general subdivision information and specifically consider the following: 
(1)  Zoning verification. Check the existing zoning of the tract and advise the subdivider if a zoning change is necessary or desirable. 
(2)  Public facility impact. Determine the adequacy of existing or proposed schools, parks, and other public spaces in the vicinity of the proposed subdivision with the authorized public bodies involved. 
(3)  Site inspection. Inspect the site or otherwise determine its relationship to major streets, utility systems, and adjacent land uses, and determine any unusual problems with regard to topography, utilities, flooding, etc. 
(4)  School and park sites. Advise the developer of the potential acreage allotment, or funds in lieu thereof, to be donated and utilized for public school and park sites. 
(5)  Comprehensive plan conformity. Advise the developer of the comprehensive plan which delineates the land use areas. 
(6)  Location of floodplains and wetlands. Advise the developer of the need for a special use hearing if the proposed subdivision is located on a floodplain or wetland area as identified in the Village of Roselle Zoning Ordinance and any U.S. or state official regulatory maps. 
(7)  Subdivider advised. The planning and zoning commission, after checking the proposed sketch plan, shall advise the subdivider at that time or no later than the next regularly scheduled meeting following the presentation of the sketch plan as to the apparent adequacy of the proposed plan and shall apprise the subdivider of any requirements the village might have that should be incorporated into the design of the subdivision. At this stage, the subdivider should expect that the planning and zoning commission may require major alterations to be made in the plan if it is found necessary. 
Sec. 6.02. - Preliminary plat. 
(A)  Action by the subdivider. The subdivider shall cause to be prepared a preliminary plat. Said plat shall include all of the property owned or controlled by the applicant and those properties adjacent to or considered to be contiguous to the proposed subdivision together with improvements, plans, and other supplementary material as specified shall be submitted to the zoning administrator, with written application for approval. Accompanying this preliminary plat and an application for approval shall be five (5) copies of the preliminary plat, a reduced eleven-inch by seventeen-inch print of the plat and all accompanying documentation. The required filing fee shall accompany the application. These documents are due in accordance with the submittal deadlines established by the community development department. 
(B)  Action by the zoning administrator. The zoning administrator shall cause copies of the preliminary plat to be distributed to the appropriate village departments. The preliminary plat and any comments shall be received by the Village of Roselle Planning and Zoning Commission not less than five (5) days prior to a regular meeting of the planning and zoning commission. 
(C)  Action by the planning and zoning commission. The planning and zoning commission, zoning administrator and the village engineer shall review the preliminary plat for compliance with these regulations and other ordinances of the Village of Roselle. 
(1)  Planning and zoning commission recommendation. Within ninety (90) days of the date of application for subdivision, the planning and zoning commission shall make a recommendation of approval or disapproval of the plat. The planning and zoning commission will forward its recommendation to the board of trustees including any conditions of approval, the reasons for disapproval and the roll call vote. If such plat is disapproved, the zoning administrator shall notify the subdivider in writing within ten (10) days of the date of disapproval specifying with particularity the aspects which fail to conform to village ordinances, including the official map. A recommendation of the planning and zoning commission to disapprove a preliminary plat shall not prohibit the subdivider from seeking the board of trustees approval of the proposed plat. If portions of the preliminary plat submittal are revised as a result of planning and zoning commission deliberations, copies of the revised documents shall be required for submittal to the board of trustees. Any revised drawings must be submitted to the zoning administrator no later than seven (7) days before the meeting of the board of trustees at which the petitioner requests action on his plat. 
(2)  Statement of agreement and conditions (underlying subdivision agreement). A statement of agreement and conditions summarizing approval given by the village, conditions placed upon the subdivider, commitments made by the subdivider and any other agreement or variance which is part of the applicant's preliminary plat approval shall be prepared in a form that can be executed by the village and the applicant. 
(D)  Action by the board of trustees. 
(1)  The planning and zoning commission shall forward all recommendations regarding preliminary plats to the board of trustees which may accept, modify or reject the recommendations. The board of trustees may impose such special conditions and approval of a preliminary plat as it deems necessary to insure conformity with the comprehensive plan or the requirements of village ordinances. If the board of trustees rejects a recommendation to approve or disapprove a preliminary plat or substantially modifies a preliminary plat, it shall cause a written report to be submitted to the planning and zoning commission at its next available meeting describing the rejection or substantial modification. Substantial modifications shall be those satisfying the criteria of a "major change" as defined in this ordinance. Within thirty (30) days thereafter the planning and zoning commission shall submit its comments regarding the board of trustees' report to the board of trustees who, thereafter, within thirty (30) days of its next regularly scheduled board meeting shall accept, modify or reject the preliminary plat, unless such date is mutually extended as agreed by the subdivider and board of trustees. Upon final rejection of a preliminary plat, the board of trustees shall cause a written statement setting forth the reasons for the disapproval to be submitted to the subdivider. An approved preliminary plat is tentative and only involves the general acceptability of the layout as submitted. 
(2)  Approval of the preliminary plat shall be effective for a maximum period of one year, unless, upon application of the developer, the board of trustees grants an extension. The application for said extension must be received prior to expiration and shall not require an additional filing fee or the submittal of additional copies of the preliminary plat. 
(E)  Changes. Changes to an approved preliminary plat may be approved according to the procedures in section 6.05. 
(Ord. No. 2106-91,  2, 8-12-91; Ord. No. 2457-95,  1, 3-13-95) 
Sec. 6.03. - Final plat. 
(A)  Action by the applicant. The applicant shall prepare the original drawing, one transparency print, five (5) copies, and one reduced eleven-inch by seventeen-inch copy of the final plat which shall also contain all required signed certification and agreements, other than the signed certifications of approval by the planning and zoning commission and the board of trustees, and application for development approval plus all supporting information in accordance with these regulations. Final plat documents shall be submitted to the zoning administrator in accordance with the submittal deadlines established by the community development department. 
(B)  Final plat application deadline. Application for approval of a final plat shall be made not later than one year after approval has been granted for the preliminary plat. If, after one year from preliminary plat approval, no submission of a final plat in conformance with the procedures contained herein has occurred, the preliminary plat is declared void by the board of trustees. 
(C)  Approval in phases. If desired by the subdivider, the final plat may be submitted in stages. A staged final plat may constitute only the portion of the approved preliminary plat which the subdivider proposes to record and develop at that time. If the development is in stages, all staged final development plats shall conform substantially to the preliminary plat as approved and to all requirements of these regulations. If, after one year from the approval of the most recent staged final plat, the subdivider has failed to submit an additional staged final plat, the preliminary plat, as it applies to the unsubdivided area, shall be declared void by the board of trustees. In that case, the subdivider shall be required to return to the preliminary plat phase of the subdivision process before submitting any further staged final plats. 
(D)  Action by the zoning administrator. If any final plat is substantially similar to an approved preliminary plat, the zoning administrator shall refer one copy of the final engineering plans and specifications prepared in accordance with this ordinance to the village engineer in sufficient time to complete review prior to the board of trustees' consideration. Final plats will not be presented to the board of trustees until the final engineering plats and specifications have been reviewed and approved by the village engineer. After final engineering has been approved by the village engineer, the zoning administrator shall refer the final plat, together with any other complete documents required by this ordinance, to the board of trustees not less than fourteen (14) days prior to a regular meeting of the board of trustees. At that meeting, the board of trustees shall vote to approve or reject the final plat of subdivision, unless such date is mutually extended as agreed by the subdivider and board of trustees. Any final plat which is a substantial modification from an approved preliminary plat shall be referred by the zoning administrator to the planning and zoning commission for hearings in conformance with paragraph 6.02(D)(1) of this ordinance. Final plats of subdivision for a planned unit development shall be submitted to the planning and zoning commission for its review and recommendations as provided in the zoning ordinance. 
(E)  Statement of agreement and conditions (underlying subdivision agreement). The village staff will review and recommend on all supporting documents, engineering and financial surety. A statement of agreement and conditions shall be completed which summarizes and includes all agreements between the subdivider and the board of trustees. 
(F)  Action by the board of trustees. If, and when, the board of trustees is satisfied with the final plat and the subdivision improvement agreement, along with all improvements, conditions, documents and financial surety hereinafter noted, pertaining to said subdivision, the trustees shall by motion, approve said plat and subdivision improvement agreement and authorize and direct the president and village clerk to sign the plat for, and in the name of the village; and the clerk shall attach thereto the corporate seal. Such approval or denial shall be made within thirty (30) days of its next regularly scheduled board meeting following receipt of final plat by the zoning administrator, unless such date is mutually extended as agreed by the subdivider and board of trustees. 
(G)  Recording of final plat. At the expense of the subdivider, the village clerk shall cause the final plat and statement of agreement and conditions to be recorded in the office of the Recorder of Deeds DuPage or Cook County, Illinois. Said final plat after recording shall be returned to the office of the village clerk and a copy thereof shall be maintained on file and a copy shall be sent to the subdivider. 
(H)  Changes. Changes to an approved preliminary plat may be approved according to the procedures in section 6.05. 
(Ord. No. 2106-91,  3, 8-12-91; Ord. No. 2457-95, ㎣ 2-4, 3-13-95) 
Sec. 6.04. - Combined preliminary final plat approval. 
(A)  In order to qualify for combined preliminary final plat approval, the parcel proposed for subdivision must be less than three (3) acres in size and proposed for not more than five (5) lots not involving any new streets. 
(B)  The preliminary and final plat may be filed and approved simultaneously if all requirements for each independent review are met. The simultaneous submission does not abrogate the village's preparation of plans in their final form and is done at the subdividers expense. 
Sec. 6.05. - Changes. 
(A)  The village president may decide whether a change is major or minor. 
(B)  Major changes to preliminary and final plats and statement of agreement and conditions may be approved according to same procedures for new plats in sections 6.01-6.04. 
(C)  Minor changes to preliminary and final plats and statement of agreement and conditions may be approved or denied by the village president. 
(D)  The applicant may appeal the ruling of the village president regarding a plat to the board of trustees who, at a public hearing, may approve or deny the change. 
(Ord. No. 2106-91,  4, 8-12-91) 
SECTION 7.00. - PRELIMINARY AND FINAL PLAT REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 7.01. - Preliminary plat. 
    The following graphic and descriptive items are required to be shown on the preliminary plat, any accompanying maps and/or supporting documents accompanying application for approval. The lack of information under any item specified herein, or improper information supplied by the applicant, shall be a cause for disapproval of a preliminary plat: 
(A)  Application for approval. Written application by the owner, or his agent, for approval, on appropriate forms contained in the exhibits of this ordinance, shall accompany each preliminary plat. 
(B)  Drawings and data required. The preliminary plat and supplemental maps shall be drawn on a stable, translucent, reproducible medium in a manner that is clear so that legible contact prints can be made therefrom. They shall show the following information: 
(1)  Subdivision name. 
a.  Name of proposed subdivision if property is not within an existing subdivision. 
b.  Proposed name if not within a previously platted subdivision. The proposed name shall not duplicate the name of any plat previously recorded in Cook or DuPage Counties. 
c.  Name of property if no subdivision name has been chosen. (This is commonly the name by which the property is locally known.) 
(2)  Existing conditions map. 
a.  Proposed name of subdivision. 
b.  Boundary line of proposed subdivision clearly indicated. 
c.  Graphic (engineering) scale not smaller than one inch to one hundred (100) feet. 
d.  Total approximate acreage therein. 
e.  Existing zoning districts within the tract and to a distance of one hundred fifty (150) feet beyond the tract. 
f.  Location, widths, and names of all existing or previously platted streets or other rights-of-way showing type of improvement, if any, railroad and utility rights-of-way, parks and other public open spaces, permanent buildings and structures, easements, and section and corporate lines within the tract and to a distance of one hundred fifty (150) feet beyond the tract. 
g.  Location and size of existing sewers, water mains, culverts or other underground facilities within the tract and to a distance of one hundred fifty (150) feet beyond the tract also indicating such data as grades, invert elevations, and location of catch basins, manholes, and fire hydrants. 
h.  Location map, drawn at a scale of not less than one inch equals one thousand (1,000) feet, showing boundary lines of adjoining unsubdivided or subdivided land within an area bounded by nearest primary streets or other natural boundaries identifying type of use and ownership of surrounding land, and showing alignments of existing streets. 
i.  Topographic data including existing and proposed contours at vertical intervals of not more than two (2) feet within the tract and to a distance of one hundred fifty (150) feet beyond the tract or one-foot intervals deemed necessary due to unusual site considerations. In extreme topographical conditions as determined by the village engineer, such vertical intervals may be not more than five (5) feet. Topographic data shall refer to the U.S.G.S. data. 
j.  Locations of, or reference to, locations of existing monuments or survey markers used in the preparation of survey and grade elevation of each monument and marker. 
k.  Water courses, marshes, rock outcrops, wood areas, isolated, preservable trees six (6) inches or more in caliper at one foot above ground level, houses, barns, and other significant features. 
l.  Where stormwater drainage tile exists, their size and location shall be indicated on the topographical map heretofore mentioned. 
m.  For adjacent land, approximate direction and gradient of ground slope, including any embankments or retaining walls; character and location of buildings, railroads, power lines, towers, and other nearby nonresidential land uses or adverse influences and owner of adjacent unplatted land (for adjacent platted land refer to subdivision plat by name, recording date, and number and show approximate percent build up, typical lot size and dwelling type.) 
n.  A written certification from a registered land surveyor shall be provided when the proposed subdivision includes floodplain. 
(3)  Boundary survey map. 
a.  Boundary line survey on an accompanying map which is prepared and certified by a registered land surveyor in the State of Illinois. The subdivider shall set U.S.G.S. monument(s) on the site at the location designated by the village engineer. 
(4)  Preliminary plat. The preliminary plat shall be in substantial accord with the Roselle Comprehensive Plan adopted April 9, 1979, as amended. 
a.  Identification and description. 
1.  Proposed subdivision name. 
2.  Legal description. 
3.  Graphic (engineering) scale not smaller than one inch to one hundred (100) feet. 
4.  North point (designated as true north). 
5.  Drawing number and date of preparation. 
b.  The Village of Roselle zoning districts proposed for the subdivision shall be shown. 
c.  Required public improvements. The subdivider of any proposed subdivision within the corporate limits of the Village of Roselle and within one and one-half (11/2) miles of the corporate limits of the Village of Roselle shall provide, at the subdivider's expense, in accordance with the Engineering Standards and Specifications, the following public improvements within the boundaries of the subdivision: water mains, fire hydrants, streets, curbs and gutters, street name signs, traffic-control signs and indicators, stormwater sewers, sidewalks, street lighting, sanitary sewers, bikeways, and other improvements as may be determined by the planning and zoning commission. 
d.  Subdivision design features. 
1.  Layout of streets showing right-of-way widths and street names. The subdivider shall not duplicate any name of any street heretofore used in the village or its environs, unless the street is an extension of or in line with an already named street in which event that name shall be extended to the boundaries of the subdivision. The street numbering system as adopted by the village shall be used. 
The subdivider, at his own expense, shall improve all existing and proposed streets with roadway surfacing of such materials, width and thickness, and in conformity with such design and specifications as shall be required by the section 9.01. 
2.  Location and widths of pedestrian ways and utility easements. 
3.  Existing streets and proposed profile(s) of each street. 
4.  Typical cross section of streets together with an indication of the proposed stormwater runoff. 
5.  Layout, numbers, and typical dimensions of lots to the nearest foot, and proposed land use for each lot, parcel or tract. 
6.  Minimum front and side street building setback lines indicating dimensions. 
7.  Areas (other than those listed in d.1. above) intended to be dedicated or reserved for public use, indicating in each, the approximate area in acres. 
8.  Proposed location of sewer and water lines and stormwater drains and proposed methods of sewage and waste disposal including sufficient information to show the intent of surface drainage and detention and/or retention facilities conforming to standards of section 9.09 of this code and the Roselle Zoning Ordinance. 
9.  The subdivider of any proposed subdivision which is located within the corporate limits of a sanitary district or within a DuPage or Cook County Wastewater Facility Planning Area shall submit a letter from such sanitary district or wastewater facility planning area lead agency certifying that: 
Wastewater treatment plant capacity and/or sanitary sewers are available for said proposed subdivision, and the specifications and requirements of said agency for the construction of sanitary sewers within said proposed subdivision have been adequately met. 
10.  Bikeways shall be provided as shown in the Roselle Comprehensive Plan. 
11.  Sites, if any, intended for multifamily dwellings, shopping centers, churches, industry, or other nonpublic uses exclusive of single-family dwellings, shall be shown. 
12.  Signature blocks for the planning and zoning commission and board of trustees as contained in the exhibits. 
(5)  Accompanying documentation required. When deemed necessary, the preliminary plat of subdivision shall be accompanied by the following when required by the village engineer or zoning administrator: 
a.  Annexation statement. A statement that the proposed subdivision (where contiguous) is or will be annexed to the village. 
(6)  Preliminary plan for sewer and water. A preliminary engineering plan for sewer, water and storm sewers setting forth general plans for such improvements and indicating the method to be employed to overcome particular problems that may be encountered with the development of the proposed subdivision. 
(7)  Engineer's certification. An engineer's certification shall be secured of the ability of any tract or portion thereof to support a sewer or water facility, after any topographical changes, including filling, regrading, or soil removal have been made to the tract in question. 
(8)  Soils analysis. A soils analysis for each proposed subdivision shall be completed by an engineer registered in the State of Illinois and shall be of sufficient scope to point out potential ground absorption, runoff, flooding deficiencies, the presence of unstable soils or of soils of such low bearing capacity as to constitute problems for conventional construction, of the presence of subsurface rock that would affect the installation of underground improvements, or the provision of aboveground improvements. If the subdivision contains questionable soils, and in the opinion of the village engineer, additional soil investigations, boring, or other soil tests are necessary to determine the nature and extent of such questionable material, the owner or developer shall retain or cause to be retained the services of a competent testing laboratory to perform the needed investigations. 
a.  Copies of the completed reports prepared by the testing laboratory shall be filed with the village engineer. 
b.  Neither the village engineer nor the village shall have any liability for costs connected with the tests, boring, or interpretation of the results of such work. 
(9)  Protective covenants. Draft of protective covenants, whereby the subdivider proposes to regulate land use in the subdivision and otherwise protect the proposed development. 
(10)  Perpetual maintenance of common property. The perpetual maintenance of any common areas shall be provided for by a declarant entity. Prior to preliminary plat approval by the board of trustees, the developer/subdivider shall present the proposed method of providing perpetual maintenance. 
(11)  Soil conservation report. A report completed by the Kane-DuPage Soil and Water Conservation District shall be submitted with the application. 
Sec. 7.02. - Qualifications covering approval of preliminary plat. 
(A)  The planning and zoning commission may recommend or the board of trustees may require such changes or revisions as are deemed necessary in the interest and need of the village. 
(B)  The approval of a preliminary plat by the planning and zoning commission and the board of trustees is tentative only, involving merely the general acceptability of the layout as submitted. 
(C)  Subsequent to approval of the general acceptability of the layout and prior to filing a final plat, the planning and zoning commission shall review proposed plans and specifications pertaining to water supply and water distribution system; stormwater drainage system, sanitary sewage system; including mains and sewage disposal or treatment facilities; gas, telephone, and electric service, street lighting, street signs, fire hydrants, grading, gradients, widths of roadways and sidewalks, and the surfacing of streets and sidewalks. Also proposed detailed grading plans of blocks and lots as deemed necessary by the planning and zoning commission. Prior to review by the board of trustees, the village engineer and other public officials having jurisdiction shall approve or make recommendations for revision in the proposed plans and specifications, and they shall certify approval of final plans and specifications prior to approval of the final plat by the board of trustees. 
(D)  Subdivision of unsuitable land. No land shall be subdivided for any use which is determined by the planning and zoning commission after investigation by the village engineer, to be unsuitable for such a use by reason of the presence of poor soils, floodplain, poor drainage or wetland areas, adverse earth and rock formation of topography, or any other features likely to be harmful to the health, safety or welfare of the future residents in the proposed subdivision or of the community, except under the following conditions: 
(1)  Unsuitable land located within areas of special flood hazard may be subdivided only if the subdivider has complied with the Roselle Zoning Ordinance. 
(2)  Variances for land within areas of special flood hazard shall be subject to the provisions of the Roselle Zoning Ordinance. 
(3)  Unsuitable land located outside areas of special flood hazard may be subdivided only if the subdivider agrees to make improvements which will, in accordance with the village engineering standards and specifications, make the area safe for occupancy and provide adequate lot and street drainage and stormwater detention facilities. 
(4)  Where the developer or subdivider of unsuitable land outside areas of special flood hazard can show in writing and with appropriate documentation that the strict adherence to the design standards set forth causes an unnecessary hardship, the board of trustees may approve a variance. Such variance may be granted after recommendation by the planning and zoning commission and where topography and conditions peculiar to the site or surrounding area substantiates a variance without undermining the intent of the provisions of this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2457-95,  5, 3-13-95) 
Sec. 7.03. - Final plat. 
(A)  General. All information is to be shown accurately and drawn with waterproof India ink on mylar film, or equal, in such manner that clear and legible contact prints or photostatic copies can be made. 
(B)  The final plat shall show: 
(1)  Accurate angular and lineal dimensions for all lines, angles, and curvatures, with functions used to describe all boundaries including perimeter survey of tract, streets, alleys, easements, areas to be reserved for public use, and other important features. Error of closure of boundary line surveys shall not exceed one in ten thousand (one foot for each ten thousand (10,000) feet of perimeter survey). Lot lines shall show dimensions in feet and hundredths. When an angle occurs in any lot line between lot corners, the measurement of the angle shall be shown in degrees, minutes, and seconds. 
(2)  An identification system for all lots and blocks using consecutive numbers for lots within a block, and, where applicable, a street address number in accord with current village policies. 
(3)  True angles and distances to the nearest established street lines and official monuments (not less than three (3)), which shall be accurately described in the plat by location, size, and elevation, to which all dimensions, angles, bearing, and similar date on the plat shall be referred. 
(4)  Municipal, township, county or section lines, accurately tied to the lines of the subdivision by distances and angles. 
(5)  Accurate location of all monuments which shall be Portland cement concrete, four (4) inches by six (6) inches by twenty-four (24) inches, or approved equal, with iron pipe cast in center. Permanent stone or concrete monuments shall be set at each corner or angle on the outside boundary. Pipes three-quarter (3/4) inch diameter or steel rods one-half (1/2) inch in diameter by eighteen (18) inch length placed at the corners of each lot and block, at each intersection of street centerlines, at angle points, at the ends, and at suitable intervals along curves. All U.S. state, county, village or other official bench marks, monuments or triangulation stations in or adjacent to the property shall be preserved in precise position. 
(6)  Accurate outlines and legal descriptions of any areas to be dedicated or reserved for public use, or for the exclusive use of property owners within the subdivision, with the purpose indicated thereon. 
(7)  Protective covenants shall be lettered on the final plat or appropriately referenced with the purposes indicated thereon. 
(8)  Any access or cross-access easements. 
(9)  The delineation of any floodplain. 
(10)  A clear sight distance easement as required under section 4.06 (E) of the Roselle Zoning Ordinance, as amended. 
(11)  The delineation of any unsuitable land for development or construction and clearly marked as such. 
(C)  Certification required. The application for approval of the final plat shall not be deemed complete until applicable certificates, as contained in Exhibits K 1-K 14 and the required easement provisions have been duly executed (In preparing certifications for final plat approval, include applicable county name only.) 
(D)  Agreements. The final plat shall be accompanied by a statement signed by the owner or subdivider setting forth the following: 
(1)  Plans and specifications are completed for the required improvements clearly describing the same as approved by the village engineer. 
(2)  Agreement is executed by the owner and/or the subdivider wherein they agree to make and install the improvements in accordance with the plans and specifications accompanying the final plat. 
(E)  Supporting documents. The following supporting documents and data shall be submitted with said final plat. 
(1)  Any special studies or additional items required by the planning and zoning commission. 
(2)  Cost estimates of all public improvements and financing surety as required herein. 
(3)  All covenants such as perpetual maintenance of common property, homeowners association covenants and agreements which are to be applied to the property. 
(4)  A calculation of population equivalents for residential development. 
(5)  Evidence that the subdivider and appropriate governmental jurisdictions have determined an appropriate cash in lieu of land amount, as necessary. 
(6)  Statement of agreement and conditions underlying subdivision agreement. (See model subdivision agreement attached as Exhibit K. Such agreement may be amended and modified as necessary as determined by the board of trustees.) 
(7)  A description and justification for any variation from the preliminary plat and a description of any external factors which have changed since preliminary plat approval and which affect the layout of the final plat. 
(8)  Approval by the village engineer of names for the proposed streets and of the proposed systems of addresses along such streets. 
(9)  A land surveyor's calculation sheet that includes the square footage of each lot. If possible, the square footage of each lot shall be indicated on the plan. 
(10)  Landscaping and tree planting plan for parkways and public areas or other areas as required by the village tree plan or by PUD ordinance. 
(11)  All plans and supporting documents shall be dated and folded to fit in a folder eight and one-half (81/2) inches by eleven (11) inches. Unfolded plans will be returned to the petitioner. 
(12)  A subsidiary drainage plat in accordance with 765 ILCS 205, Plats Act. Said plat shall show typical drainage details and the manner run off will be handled between lots. 
(13)  Any special requirements for stormwater detention/retention facilities or contributions in lieu thereof. 
(14)  Submission of a soil erosion and sedimentation control plan as may be required under Chapter 6.5 of the Village of Roselle Code of Ordinances. 
(15)  Prior to the village president and village clerk executing the plat approval by signature, the subdivider must pay the engineering fees owed to the village in accord with the Roselle Code. 
(Ord. No. 2457-95, ㎣ 6, 7, 3-13-95) 
Sec. 7.04. - Construction bonds and maintenance bonds. 
(A)  Construction bonds. 
(1)  Board of trustee's approval required. Either in conjunction with the approval of a final plat of subdivision or as a contingency of signature of the final plat by the village president and village clerk, a construction bond is to be posted by the subdivider with the village clerk in the amount of one hundred ten (110) percent of the cost for the completion of the installation of all public improvements to be installed by the subdivider as estimated by the village engineer and as required by these regulations. Such bond shall be approved by the board of trustees, and conditioned upon the installation of required improvements, within two (2) years of the approval of the final plat. Construction bonds, submitted on approved village bond forms for required improvements, shall be secured to the village by one of the following methods in a form satisfactory to the board of trustees: 
a.  Cash; 
b.  Certificates of deposit made payable to the Village of Roselle; 
c.  Irrevocable letter of credit in a form approved by the village attorney. 
(2)  Security release. The board of trustees shall release construction bonds and any surety thereon with interest, if any, upon satisfaction of all the following: 
a.  The subdivider's engineer shall furnish two (2) complete sets of "as built" plans with each set clearly marked "as built" showing all changes which were necessitated due to field conditions and were approved by the village engineer. The cover sheet of "as builts" shall be signed by the village engineer. 
b.  Certification by the developer's engineer and by the village engineer that the improvements have been constructed in substantial compliance with the plans and specifications. 
c.  Satisfaction of the conditions of the bond itself. 
d.  Receipt of a maintenance bond in accordance with subsection 7.04(B). 
(3)  Partial security release. In the event the required improvements are constructed in part, upon recommendation of the village engineer, the board of trustees may partially release a bond posted under this section; however, the security shall not be reduced to less than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) or ten (10) percent of the original bond amount, whichever is greater. 
(B)  Maintenance bonds. 
(1)  Board of trustees approval required. Upon acceptance of all required improvements in accordance with section 9.11 and prior to the release of any construction bond, a maintenance bond shall be filed with the village clerk in the amount of fifteen (15) percent of the estimated cost of construction, and approved in the same manner as construction bonds guaranteeing repair of defects appearing in the workmanship and materials of said improvements for a period of two (2) years. 
(2)  Village engineer's inspection. Prior to the expiration date of the maintenance bond, but not sooner than eighteen (18) months following acceptance of the bond by the board of trustees, the village engineer shall conduct a final inspection of the improvements. The village engineer shall notify the developer's engineer in advance of the date, time and place of the final inspections. 
If such improvements are free of defects, the village engineer shall certify in writing that all improvements are free of defects in construction and shall give said certification to the developer, and the village clerk. In the event there are defects in the construction as determined by the village engineer, the village engineer shall give to the developer written notification of those defects and repairs to be made. 
(3)  Developer response deadline. The developer shall within sixty (60) days after receiving written notification from the village engineer cause to be repaired any defects in the construction of the improvements. 
(4)  Performance failure. Failure of the developer to complete the repairs within the sixty (60) days of the written notification by the village engineer shall authorize the village to complete the repairs. All costs of such repairs shall be paid for by the proceeds of the bond. Any unused balance shall be refunded to the depositor. 
(5)  Bond release. Upon written request by the developer, upon certification from the village engineer that all improvements are free of defects in construction, and upon satisfaction of the conditions of the bond, the board of trustees shall release maintenance bonds and the surety thereon. 
SECTION 8.00. - ENGINEERING PLANS AND IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 8.01. - Engineering plans and specifications. 
(A)  Engineering plans. The subdivider shall cause engineering plans and specifications to be prepared for all improvements required or regulated by this ordinance. Said improvements shall be designed to conform at least to the minimum standards set forth in this ordinance and shall also conform to the minimum standards and requirements of other local, state, and federal authorities which have jurisdiction over the development. Engineering plans and specifications shall be prepared under the supervision of a registered engineer pursuant to the laws of the State of Illinois and shall bear the engineer's seal and signature. 
(B)  Plan sheet dimensions. Plan sheet dimensions shall be twenty-four (24) inches by thirty-six (36) inches. Variations in dimensions may be approved by the village engineer, if such variations are requested prior to submission of plans. 
(C)  Village engineer review and approval. The subdivider shall submit engineering plans and specifications to the village engineer for review and written approval, prior to the commencement of construction of any improvements required or regulated by these regulations. The subdivider shall submit with the engineering plans and specifications an "application for approval of engineering plans and specifications." Said application shall include, but not be limited to: 
(1)  Written requests for waiver of minimum materials and construction standards, describing the degree of deviation, the necessity or advantage of it, and the alternate plan in a form provided as Exhibit D. 
(2)  A signed statement of the subdivider that he has authorized his engineer to provide complete inspection and observation during actual construction to enable the engineer to certify that the improvements required and/or regulated by these regulations were constructed in substantial accordance with these regulations and other applicable ordinances of the village. The subdivider must also submit a letter of intent from the developer's engineer that said engineer shall provide such complete inspection service during actual construction of the public improvements. 
(D)  Floodplains. When a development or part thereof is located in a flood prone area as designated by the Federal Emergency Management Administration, the developer shall provide at his expense such hydrolic, hydrologic design data calculations and utility and drainage plans as may be required by the village engineer to assure that the development is consistent with the need to minimize or eliminate flood damage. 
(E)  Village engineer review deadline. The village engineer shall, in writing, notify the subdivider of approval, conditional approval or disapproval of the engineering plans and specifications and the subsidiary drainage plat and studies. Such notification, specifying reasons for disapproval, conditional approval, shall be made within fifteen (15) days of the date of submission of all plans, specifications, and plats required by this section. Construction of improvements required or regulated by these regulations shall not commence until the village engineer has approved in writing engineering plans and specifications for said improvements, hydrologic design data as may be required by subsection (D) of this section, and the subsidiary drainage flat and studies. 
Sec. 8.02. - Construction of required improvements. 
(A)  Construction in accordance with approved plans. Improvements required and/or regulated by this ordinance shall be constructed in substantial accordance with approved engineering plans and specifications, the standards, requirements and regulations set forth in this ordinance, and other applicable ordinances of the village. 
(B)  Improvement modifications. If, in the course of construction, the developer desires to modify the size, type, quantity and/or location of any or all of the improvements required or regulated by these regulations, the subdivider's engineer shall submit a written, professionally sealed change request to the village engineer for review and obtain written approval prior to proceeding with installation of the modified improvement. 
(C)  Village engineer notification. The subdivider shall meet with the village engineer for a pre-construction meeting at least one week in advance of the commencement of construction. Subsequently, the subdivider or subdivider's engineer shall notify the village engineer of the commencement, suspension, or resumption of work at least one day prior to the commencement, suspension, or resumption of such work. This requirement shall not apply to work suspended due to adverse weather conditions. In the event that the subdivider or subdivider's engineer fails to comply with these requirements, the village engineer is hereby authorized to take whatever steps may be necessary to ensure that work performed complies with approved engineering plans and specifications, the standards set forth in these regulations, and other applicable ordinances of the village. 
Sec. 8.03. - Inspection of improvements. 
(A)  [ Generally. ] Actual construction of all required improvements and improvements regulated by this ordinance shall be inspected by competent and qualified personnel employed by and under the direction of the subdivider's engineer. Said inspection shall be adequate to assure that all work complies with the approved engineering plans and specifications and these regulations. 
(B)  Engineering tests. Required tests of this ordinance shall be performed solely by independent testing laboratories, selected by the village, and shall be performed at the subdivider's expense. The subdivider shall direct the testing agent that the results of required tests be mailed or delivered to the village engineer immediately on completion of the test and that no test results be withheld from the village engineer. 
Sec. 8.04. - Approval of improvements. 
(A)  Required documents. Upon completion of construction of required improvements or improvements regulated by this ordinance, the developer's engineer shall deliver to the village engineer: 
(1)  All required test data not previously forwarded to the village as may be required by the village engineer. 
(2)  A signed and sealed "engineer's certificate" in accordance with Exhibit J 5. 
    With approval of the village engineer, said certificate may certify to the completion of a portion of the improvements with specifically stated exceptions for which a bond shall be filed or retained in accordance with Section 7.04. 
(B)  Field inspection. Within two (2) weeks, weather permitting, of receipt of all documentation required in subsection 8.03, the developer's engineer shall conduct a final inspection of the required improvements regulated by this ordinance and shall approve and certify in writing all improvements which conform to the approved engineering plans and specifications and this ordinance. The developer's engineer shall give written notification of said approval to the subdivider and the village clerk. In the event that a construction bond was filed in accordance with section 7.04, the village engineer shall notify the village clerk of the percent of improvements approved and/or the amount of the bond which may be released upon approval by the board of trustees in accordance with section 7.04 or the amount of the maintenance bond which should be filed in accordance with section 7.04. 
(C)  Village engineer rejection. The village engineer is authorized to reject any construction which fails to conform to the approved plans and specifications of this ordinance. 
(D)  Improvement defects. In the event that there are defects in the construction of the improvements as determined from the final inspection by the village engineer, the village engineer shall give written notification to the subdivider of those defects and repairs to be made. If there is a disagreement about the defects, then a third engineer agreeable to the subdivider and the village engineer shall be selected. The third engineer shall inspect the improvements and prepare a report outlining the defects, if any, their probable cause, and the proposed method of repair. The reported findings of the third engineer shall be binding to the subdivider and the village. Payment to the third engineer for their services shall be paid one-half (1/2) by the developer and one-half (1/2) by the village. Upon completion of the repairs, the construction bond shall be released or reduced in accord with section 7.04 of this ordinance. 
(E)  Submission of "as built" plans. Following final inspection by the village engineer, a complete set of reproducible "as built" plans, each sheet of which is clearly marked "as built", shall be submitted to the village engineer. The reproducible medium shall be dimensionally stable and shall be of a mylar material. "As built" plans shall depict actual construction completed on the date of submittal of said plans and each sheet shall be so dated. 
SECTION 9.00. - SUBDIVISION DESIGN AND LAND IMPROVEMENT STANDARDS 
    The design and improvement requirements set forth under this section are to be considered as the minimum acceptable standards. Where standards are not specifically set forth, improvements shall comply with standards established by the "Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction" or "Standard Specification for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois". No final plat shall be approved by the planning and zoning commission without receiving a statement signed by the village engineer certifying that the improvements described in the subdivider's plans and specifications, together with agreements, meet the minimum requirements of the village, county, state and other authorities having jurisdiction and the improvements comply with the requirements of this section. 

Sec. 9.01. - Streets. 
(A)  Street plan. The subdivision of land, including the arrangement, character, extent, width, grade and location of all streets, crosswalks, easements, sites for parks, playgrounds, and schools or other land to be dedicated for public use, shall conform to the Comprehensive Plan and Official Map of the Village of Roselle. Approval of design standards shall be considered on the basis of their relation to existing and platted streets, reasonable circulation of traffic within the subdivision and adjacent land, topographic conditions, runoff of stormwater, public convenience and safety, and appropriately relate to the proposed uses of the area to be served. 
(B)  Design of streets. 
[(1)  Reserved.] 
(2)  Design and arrangement. 
a.  Where street arrangement is not shown on the comprehensive plan, and/or official map, the arrangement of streets within a subdivision shall either: 
1.  Continuity. Provide for the continuation or projection of existing principal streets in adjacent areas; or 
2.  Conformity with plan. Conform to the plan for the area or neighborhood approved or adopted by the planning and zoning commission to meet a particular situation where topographical or other conditions make continuance or conformance to existing streets impracticable; or 
3.  Minor streets. Provide alignments so that their use by through traffic will be discouraged. 
b.  Provision shall be made for serving lots for residential use abutting arterial streets and highways by either the use of (a) marginal access streets, or (b) backing lots to the primary street with a screen planting contained in an on-access reservation along the rear property line. These methods are recommended for the purpose of providing adequate protection of residential properties and to afford separation of through and local traffic. 
c.  Cul-de-sac streets shall be not more than five hundred (500) feet in length, measured along their center lines from streets of origin to the ends of their rights-of-way. Each cul-de-sac right-of-way shall have a terminus of nearly circular shape. Single-family areas shall have a minimum diameter of one hundred (100) feet, multiple-family and industrial areas shall have a minimum diameter of one hundred twenty (12) feet. Each cul-de-sac terminus shall be improved with a circular paving improvement a minimum diameter of eighty-six (86) feet in single-family, areas ninety-one (91) feet in multifamily areas, and one hundred (100) feet in industrial areas. The minimum paving width around the terminus shall be twenty-seven (27) feet back of curb to back of curb. The number of lots fronting on any cul-de-sac street or cul-de-sac street terminus shall be as recommended by the planning and zoning commission, and approved by the board of trustees in consideration of the intensity and type of land uses to front on such streets. 
d.  Proposed streets shall be extended and stubbed to the boundary of the tract to be subdivided, unless prevented by topography or other physical conditions, or unless in the opinion of the planning and zoning commission, such extension is not necessary or desirable for the coordination of the street system of the development. Such temporary stub streets in excess of two hundred fifty (250) feet shall be provided by a temporary tee (T) turn around. The type of construction shall be determined by the village engineer. 
e.  Half streets shall be prohibited. 
f.  Where a subdivision borders on or contains a railroad or major street, the planning and zoning commission may require a street approximately parallel to and on each side of such railroad or major street, at a distance suitable for the appropriate use of the intervening land, as for park purposes in residential districts, or for commercial or industrial purposes in appropriate districts. Such distances shall also be determined with due regard for the requirements of approach grades and future grade separations. 
g.  To assure positive drainage from residential buildings to the street, the top of foundation of homes shall be at least six (6) inches above the level of the curb. Driveway gradients shall be no less than one-half (1/2) percent and no greater than eight (8) percent. In cases of practical hardship, the village engineer may vary from these standards. 
(3)  Horizontal street deflection. (See Exhibit J). Where there is a deflection in horizontal centerlines within a given block at any given point in excess of ten (10) degrees, a curve measured along the centerline of the street shall be inserted with a radius of not less than: 
a.  Arterial streets-One thousand (1,000) feet. 
b.  Collector streets-Three hundred (300) feet. 
c.  Other streets-One hundred fifty (150) feet. 
(4)  Street gradients. (See Exhibit J). Gradients of streets shall be at least one-half (1/2) percent and shall not exceed on: 
a.  Arterial and collector streets-Five (5) percent. 
b.  Other streets-Seven (7) percent. 
(5)  Tangents. (See Exhibit J). Between reverse curves the minimum tangent distance shall be as follows: 
a.  Arterial streets-Three hundred (300) feet. 
b.  Collector streets-One hundred (100) feet. 
c.  Other streets-Fifty (50) feet. 
(6)  Street gradient connections. Different connecting street gradients shall be connected with vertical parabolic curves. Minimum length in feet of those curves shall provide a stopping sight distance of not less than three hundred (300) feet. 
(7)  Intersections. 
a.  All street intersections at arterial streets shall have a minimum curb return radius of forty (40) feet. All other curb intersections shall have a radius of not less than twenty-five (25) feet. 
b.  At all street intersections, line of sight easements shall be established within the triangular arc formed at the intersection of any street right-of-way lines by a straight line drawn between said right-of-way lines at a distance along each line of twenty-five (25) feet from their point of intersection. (See Illustration, Exhibit F.) 
c.  At all street intersections with arterial or collector streets, a maximum grade of three (3) percent shall be established at the intersecting right-of-way lines for a distance of not less than one hundred (100) feet. 
d.  All streets intersecting an arterial or collector street shall do so at right angles or as nearly as is possible. Intersecting angles of less than eighty (80) degrees shall not be permitted. 
e.  Curved streets intersecting with arterials and collector streets shall do so with a tangent section of centerline fifty (50) feet in length measured from the right-of-way line of the arterial or collector street. 
f.  An intersection of more than two (2) streets shall be avoided unless specific conditions of design indicate otherwise. 
(8)  Street jogs. Street jogs between arterial and collector streets with centerline offsets of less than two hundred twenty-five (225) feet are prohibited. Street jogs between minor streets with centerline offsets of less than one hundred twenty-five (125) feet are prohibited. 
(9)  Acceleration, deceleration, passing and turning lanes. Arterials or collector streets may be provided with paved acceleration and deceleration lanes, and passing or turning lanes. 
(10)  Driveways. All intersecting driveways shall comply with the requirements of the appropriate highway authority and the zoning ordinance. 
(C)  Minimum improvement standards and specifications for streets. 
(1)  All streets shall be designed and improved in accordance with Table A, Pavement Design and Right-of-Way Width Standards, the requirements of this section, the Roselle Official Comprehensive Plan, as amended, and "Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction." 
(2)  Street grading. Preparation of street subgrades shall be completed in accordance with "Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction" and shall be subject to inspection and testing as required by the village engineer. 
(3)  Street pavement. All streets shall be constructed with a minimum one inch bituminous concrete surface course with a one and one-half (11/2) inch bituminous concrete binder course constructed on a flexible base course and a stable well-drained subgrade. 
The minimum thickness of the base course shall be determined in accordance with the material used and the required structural number. In lieu of the materials stated above, a pavement design that results in the required structural strength will be permitted if approved by the village engineer. 
(4)  Portland cement concrete curb and gutter are required for all subdivision streets. Curbs shall be mountable (M3.18) type on residential streets and barrier type (B6.18) on all other streets. A minimum of eighteen (18) inches gutter flange is required. Existing roads may be repaired and/or replaced in kind. The curb at all driveway and sidewalk intersections shall be depressed. 
(5)  Street lighting. Street lighting is required in all subdivisions. Light standards shall be reinforced, prestressed concrete octagonal in cross section with a wiring hand hole. Luminaries shall be mounted at a minimum height of twenty-five (25) feet on a minimum six-foot mast arm. Mast arms at intersections shall be set diagonally into the intersection. Luminaries shall be l00 W high pressure sodium unless otherwise required or approved by the village engineer. The electrical installations shall conform to the most recent edition of the National Electric Code adopted by the village. Street lights shall be located so as to illuminate all street intersections and all curves in street alignment. Any direct burial cable used for street lighting shall be copper. Aluminum cable is specifically prohibited. 
(6)  Street signs. Street signs shall be provided at each intersection in accordance with village standards. Traffic-control signs and devices shall be provided as required by the village engineer. 
(7)  Street names. See section 7.01(B)(4)d.l. of this ordinance 
(8)  Parkways. All parkways shall be planted in an appropriate grass variety and trees shall be planted along all streets where trees do not exist. Tree spacing and location shall be determined by the village forester in accordance with the master tree planting plan except that trees shall normally be spaced at a distance of forty (40) feet on center. A permit for tree planting shall be required. Trees listed as prohibited species or forms shall not be planted. Adjacent to street intersections, trees shall not be planted within twenty-five (25) feet of projected lot lines to provide adequate vision of cross traffic. Trees shall not be planted where they will ultimately interfere with the functions of street lights, transmission lines, fire hydrants, traffic-control devices and other above ground facilities. 
a.  Prohibited plant species: 
Botanic Name Common Name Acer negundo Box Elder A. saccharinum Silver Maple or Soft Maple Ailanthus Altissima Tree of heaven Betula spp. Birch Catalpa speciosa Catalpa Elaeagnus spp. Russian Olive Ginkgo biloba (female) Female Ginko Maclura pomifera Osage Orange Malus pumila Apple Moris spp. Mulberry Populus spp. Cottonwood, Poplar, Aspen Prunus spp. Cherry, Plum Salix spp. Willow Ulmus spp. Elm  
b.  Prohibited plant forms: 
1.  Multiple stem forms. Those forms containing more than one stem. 
2.  Espaliers or topiary. Forms achieved through trimming or pruning which are distorted or contrary to the natural shape of the species. 
3.  Flowering shrubs. Those shrubs which typically grow taller than three (3) feet, yet not tall enough to be undertrimmed to a height of six (6) feet. 
4.  Topped or dehorned trees. Trees with most or all of the crown removed. 
c.  Parkway trees shall be baIled or burlapped and shall have a minimum trunk diameter of two (2) inches (measured at six (6) inches above ground level). They shall be northern grown in a nursery and shall be reasonably straight and free from disease and insect problems. All trees shall be tagged and identified as to species (botanic and common name), size and place of origin. Such tags shall not be removed by the developer prior to inspection by the village forester. 
d.  All trees (original or replacement) determined by the public works department not to be in vigorous growing condition after one growing season shall be replaced during the next succeeding planting season, at no cost to the Village of Roselle. 
e.  The planting of parkway trees as required by this ordinance shall be completed within one year of the issuance of a certificate of occupancy. 
f.  Planting of grass on vacant lots.
